We are safe. Evacuated last night. With my daughters. And our dog.  And just  two photos- a portrait of my daughters and a photo taken by my uncle Jim Alexander. 
My home is gone. 
I‚Äôll never stop praying for the safety and strength of my neighbors and all first responders. I do not know what will come next after this unimaginable loss but I am sure of just one thing: that the God of Love and Compassion is with me and has shown up in the form of loving people. My next door neighbors who watered the roof of my home. Friend who delivered groceries to me. Others delivered clothes for us. My cousin Alyson on the east coast, texted early this morning to check in. My siblings have checked in. Friends have offered my family place to stay. My family has been added to the prayer list at All Saints Church.  Strangers have walked my dog and wiped my tears. I Was so relieved to hear from a cousin who lives nearby that she is safe and with her daughter. My prayer is that everyone will receive all the love and care they so desperately need in this moment. As soon as I am able, I pray that I can be  part of the healing and rebuilding that is ahead for our community. 
I am in shock, heartbroken AND eternally grateful.  Stay safe, take care of yourselves and each other. xxK #altadenastrong #eatonfire
Fire trucks and bulldozers are here. The air is good for now. We are cleaning up debris and feel good about probably not evacuating (but we‚Äôll see.) #eatonfire

I started what I call ‚ÄúThe Porch Project‚Äù when we bought our home in November of 2020 when we were pregnant with Oliver. It was meant to document the kiddos through high school. Sadly this project was cut short today in 2025 when we lost our home in the Eaton Fire. We are devastated by this loss but grateful for the beautiful memories we‚Äôve made with so many friends, our family and sweet pups. We are grateful for your support and we truly love you all. Altadena is the most special home to so many of us. We üíó our community and all of you so much. #eatonfire

Spirit of Fire üî• we honor your power to eliminate all we have created. Albeit carefully, sometimes carelessly and definitely at times unconsciously. We have plagued these lands with our excess and greed. Taken, more than we have given. Passed down for others to clean later, as we cannot seem to be bothered. 

We humans have not learned our lesson. 

So you call in the Spirit of Wind üå¨Ô∏è 
to magnify your message to us. 

You bring us devastating loss, terror and fear. You remind us how small and un mighty we truly are, when we try to walk alone as just one. 

But what if this was instead our last lesson, the one in which we all finally chose to awaken. We realize it‚Äôs not our material gains and adornments. Our flash and our privilege. 

But rather our humbled humility, when realized we are stronger together, than in competition apart. That home is carried inside us, no matter where we ever, are. 

What if we bowed in devotion and really vowed to change? 

My heart is with friends, loved ones and those I call family who‚Äôve just lost everything.

And many more prayers for the days + long nights that are still upon us ‚Ä¶

#palisadesfire üôèüèºüí¶ü©µ‚ú® #eatonfire #losangeles

Eaton Fire burns Wednesday January 8th 2025 

Hundreds of homes burned to the ground.
Over 100k people told to evacuate.
Los Angeles cut their fire services budget last year by 17.6 million dollars. 
Insurance companies in California have stopped writing new fire insurance policies and cancled 72,000 policies last year.

For the heroic EMT and firefighters. I love you so much. Fearless men and women, some coming from Arizona and others coming from Oregon to help local fire teams here in California. Warms the heart knowing they're fighting, even as I type this up. It's traumatizing being out there. Believe what you see.

üíîPraying for the families that lost their homes and all the families that have been affected by these fires and all the businesses that have been affected by the fires in LA County. These Santa Ana winds the past few days have been ‚Äúhellacious!‚Äù 

It‚Äôs been a time of waiting and waiting for these winds to die down and feverishly checking on family and friends in the areas and checking on your friend‚Äôs family and friends.  Everyone has said they know of someone that has lost their home, I mean everyone.  Our counties are intertwined with one another with either growing up in LA County / Orange County or vice versa, We are SoCal! My own city has been affected numerous times with fires erupting out of control due to the high Santa Ana winds with devasting losses.  I know firsthand how the displacement is affecting these families and those precious children and pets. 

The year ahead will be filled with mourning and healing all at the same time and just grateful to have one another when the sun rises and the sun sets with each new day.

Our hearts go out to everyone impacted by the devastating wildfires in Los Angeles. As evacuations continue and many face the unimaginable loss of their homes, we must unite as a caring community and support each other in this trying time.

In this spirit, we are sharing important resources for free items and shelters for both people and animals. No one should ever feel alone or forgotten during such difficult timesüíõ

Please remember to check in with yourself and your loved ones; it‚Äôs okay to reach out for help. 

üíå We encourage you to share this post to help those in need find the support and resources available or visit the link in our bio for the full list.

Stay safe and look out for one another. Sending you mucho amor, 
Claudia & Nalani

In response to the devastating wild fires raging across Los Angeles, The Wild Orchid Foundation is directly assisting families who lost their homes and livelihood in the California wild fires, specifically the Eaton fires that have plagued the Altadena neighborhood. Presently we are offering emergency relief aid to a growing roster of families with children and we want to administer sustenance to every family presented to us. We therefore invite you to partake in this mission and make an immediate difference for these families. All donations make a direct impact to help families during this crisis. Your gift is tax exempt and deductible to the extent of the law. We will keep you updated on your direct influence and support to families in distress and their recovery. Thank you and God bless.

Donations accepted on the website as well as through PayPal: wildorchidfoundation

I was up all night last night, reliving every single step on my daily walks through our neighborhood. The rising sun cascading onto the mountains. The sounds of the parrots waking up for their day. The cool, damp ground and smell of flowers opening up. I laid in bed and tried to remember every house I would pass by, the way they cut their hedges. Every houses different mailbox. Im not a routine person, but around our neighborhood we were creatures of habit. ‚Ä®‚Ä®We would ride our dirtbikes on the same paths through Altadena, we called it ‚Äúthe track.‚Äù As we fired up the bikes and slid on our helmets, @mtstockwell and I would look at each other, ask ‚Äúthe track?‚Äù And that meant blasting past the golf course, way over the speed limit. Cruising through their parking lot beside the house with the wildflower garden I always slowed down to admire. ‚Ä®Rip up towards Millard or Rubio, pitstop at @sidepie. ‚Ä®‚Ä®We wouldn‚Äôt head up Lake, we would weave our way through side streets. ‚ÄúShould we head up to the big green house on Altadena Dr? Or should we go up past the school? Make a left at that weird street that Y‚Äôs off for no reason. Let‚Äôs hit the speedbumps where that house has that big wooden deck overlooks the entire valley. You think we can see the ocean from that house  on Rubio that has the golden retriever? The one that hates you?‚Äù ‚Äî- see more in comments ‚Äî-

It‚Äôs really hard to put into words how I‚Äôm feeling about what happened this past week in the city I‚Äôve lived in for almost 18 years now. Despite me not losing any property, the collective grief and sadness is quite palpable for me as I write this. I‚Äôm not exactly sure why I stayed in town, or why I went the other way when people were evacuating, but I felt compelled to document what was happening around me. 

None of these photos were edited or touched up, just raw 35mm as I experienced it. 

My heart goes out to all of my friends and colleagues who lost their homes and to all of the firefighters and first responders who have been on the front lines battling this historic fire. #eatonfire #lafires

I just wanted you all to know how much your support and donations mean to us (and maybe a some cathartic grieving for me). Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart. The outpouring of support is overwhelming and something we never expected. 

And a huge thank you to my sister @leahlag and her family for dropping everything and opening your home to all 6 of us. We feel so incredibly lucky and loved.

#Eatonfire 01-10-25, 1500 Hours. I was able to go to our HQ and set up a new CP and work with the Team to get some normalcy back. Lots of clean up and reorganizing after the HQ was hastily evacuated. There were a few downed trees to buck up. Still no power. Our emergency generator is BO ü•¥. Lots of learning moments!  The Team had units out assisting with the next planning fazes. Two units were doing animal rescues!

So many people are stepping up to help in anyway they can.
#palisadesfire #eatonfire #gratitude-first responders (photo by Karen Rigberg@bigrigmama)

Many of you know already that we lost our home in the Eaton Fire, along with so so many neighbors and friends. The impact is devastating and will take a long time to process and work out. But now fires are still burning and lives, homes, livelihoods still in danger. Be safe. Leave early if notified. Leaving history, hard heart work, heirlooms behind hurts so so so badly but ultimately your family, friends and health are what matters and will carry you through. Get out early and spare yourselves horror. Then, do not carry this alone. This tragedy has brought out the most beautiful incredible kindness throughout local communities but also the world. Please reach out to us if you need assistance and resources , connection and community. We are continuing to gather resources as we learn of them through our friends and neighbors. You are not alone. #altadena #eatonfire #denastrong

Hi friends,

I wanted to share an update and let you know that we are back home and safe in Pasadena. On Tuesday night, we evacuated soon after we learned about the Eaton Fire, which was uncomfortably close to our home. These past few days have felt like a month‚Äî a mix of sadness, fear and uncertainty that are hard to describe.

We‚Äôre incredibly grateful that our house is okay and that the evacuation warning for our area was lifted yesterday. However, our hearts are heavy for LA and for everyone directly impacted by this horrific fire. We‚Äôre especially devastated for our neighbors, friends and colleagues in Altadena, a community so close to us in every way. Altadena has been such a beautiful and special place, home to many of our favorite cafes, restaurants, and shops‚Äîso many of which are now gone.

Every day, we‚Äôre hearing more stories of people we know, and people they know, who have lost everything. The level of destruction is truly unimaginable, and yet it‚Äôs just blocks away. Our hearts go out to everyone who has been affected, and we‚Äôre keeping them in our prayers as they begin the difficult journey of healing and recovery.

We‚Äôre still uncertain about what‚Äôs next and are just trying to take things one moment at a time. The strength and generosity of our city, and the Pasadena and Altadena communities, are bringing us hope. Although we just moved here 5 years ago, we love LA so much and feel so grateful to call it home.

Thank you for your love, support, and for checking in on us‚Äîit means more than we can say. üôèüèºüíîüôèüèΩüíî

With Gratitude, Rebecca & Deepu 
#pasadena #altadena #eatonfire

Stormie needs our help to help her two-legged parents. Stormie is a well-behaved rottweiller who I take care of when my friends, her owners, go on vacation. They are all safe, but their home is one of the thousands that were lost in the Eaton Canyon Fire.

https://gofund.me/411f4005

Two years ago, when I was taking care of Stormie, there was a wildfire in the San Gabriel  Mountains near Azusa and it made me think about what I needed to save, if there was ever a wildfire in the hills above Altadena. I didn‚Äôt give it a lot of thought though because I thought the fire would have to go through so many houses just to get there, surely it couldn‚Äôt possibly happen. We were over 10 blocks away from the mountains. Surely it would be stopped before then. 

Well‚Ä¶last week, the impossible happened as the Eaton Canyon fire ravaged through Altadena and torched a community. Similar to the Pacific Palisades Fire, entire blocks were burned to the ground. 

This also happened to be my temporary home before I moved to Las Vegas. After I sold my house, I lived with Ron and Cyndy until I moved to LV. That room on fire behind the tree - that was my room! The garage, kitchen and living room were to the left. You can now see the back yard from the front yard. 

It‚Äôs hard to believe what I see and I can‚Äôt even imagine what my friends are going through. All their keepsakes and memories‚Ä¶GONE! The garden, fruit trees and koi pond‚Ä¶GONE! 

So I started a Go Fund Me campaign to help them with incidentals. All those little things you need just to get by add up. And when you‚Äôre stressed about big things, you don‚Äôt want to have to stress over little things, which are still important, like toys for Stormie. She loves playing tug-of-war, and let me tell you, she is strong! üí™ 

https://gofund.me/411f4005

So if you can help Stormie help her two-legged parents out, thank you. üôè I know there are many requests out there now, so I understand if you can not. Please feel free to share this with anyone in your network. 

Stormie says woof woof üê∂ thank you.

#Eatonfire 01/11/25, We were requested to check a couple radio repeaters on the Lowe Rd. Unfortunately Inspiration Points main structure was lost. The Western picnic spot looks fine. It looks fairly straight forward to rebuild. The concrete / steel supports are still intact!ü§ûüèº

Five Points to Idlehour is a moonscape!ü•∫

Today we were at the @ladreamcenter (LA Dream Center) in Echo Park from 12-4 PM, though these four hours felt like an 8hr shift. Needless to say today's volunteering was crazier than yesterday's. When we got there at noon, most volunteers were on the clothing section separating and organizing endless piles of clothes.

All of us were out in the sun throughout the shift, but the organizers at the Dream Center partnered up with local vendors and @iheartradio to provide food and drinks for everyone involved. I was also stationed in traffic control, and I cannot begin to express how amazing it was to meet so many people eager to volunteer.

This donation center was drive-thru style, so families would take their cars through the facility and volunteers would load up the vehicle with food, water and outfit bags. The goal was for each outfit bag to contain, well, prepared outfits by gender and size. Today's energy at the Dream Center was absolutely insane. Cars were wrapped around the block on both sides of the facility.

I will remain active on my stories with resources and volunteering sites throughout LA county now that I'm back in San Diego.

NO SITE IS ACCEPTING CLOTHING AT THE MOMENT!!! Most shelters and donation centers are extremely overwhelmed with donations. Please be mindful and check-in with the site organizers to find out what they need.

What they will need this week is consistent manpower and volunteers!! Get in contact with those communities that need it most. There are some heavy hitters here, places we‚Äôve loved so much and enjoyed while they were open. Let‚Äôs give the trails some time to heal before heading out there. Feeling blessed we‚Äôve had the opportunity to explore these places before the fires. Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll find in this post:

Palisades Fire Hike Closures
Eaton Fire Hike Closures
Sunset Fire Trail Closures
Hurst Fire Trail Closures
Kenneth Fire Trail Closures

We can expect trails that are part of these hikes are closed until further notice. We haven‚Äôt got the official word from the Forest Service regarding the closures of these trails in the Angeles Forest yet, but since the Angeles Forest is temporarily closed forest-wide until Jan 15th, we can expect we will get our answer soon.

This is not the final verdict of closed trails, we have to wait from the individual state, federal and city agencies for them to give the announcements before we can confirm these closures. Closures are not permanent (most of the time), give time to nature and people to heal from this. If anyone is encouraging you to hike right now, gracefully decline, until all fires are completely contained for a few days. 

ATTN: We have reached the limits of volunteers, if you decide to email now. You will be put on a reserve list. Thank you for your vested interest.

Additionally, Griffith Park is closed until further notice by the state. And a lot of @mrcaparks hikes are closed. Again, this is temporary further notice.

I‚Äôll be bringing you all an update on the stories of areas that have reopened. Please visit the last slide if you can interested in volunteering.

The correct email is lahikesofficial@gmail.com, hope to see you in the inbox!

INFORMATION SESSIONS RECORDED FOR REPLAY - SEE MY LINKTREE - today & tomorrow with public adjusters who have experience representing wild fire claims. Sessions are via zoom and of value to those of us who have lost our homes or businesses or who have lost use of our standing structures due to smoke or fire damage. 

The sessions are for general information but we have gathered a list of questions that should help us gain a better understanding of the claims process, how to both prepare and avoid potential pitfalls falls. 

Both companies have been kind enough to join us at no fee. Both advise that there is not a rush to make decisions and that certainly not everyone needs to hire a public adjuster. 
The sessions are informational only. 

My best to you all today. We are flung far and wide, scrambling for housing and a breath of fresh air. I look so forward to seeing your faces on zoom. 

Love to you and to our Altadena home. 
love+ grit

Teresa Fuller
DRE 01315387
Compass

Can‚Äôt find the words to express how devasting and heartbreaking this past week has been. From losing the trails that have brought me (and so many others) so much strength to watching 1000s of homes engulfed in flames. Entire neighborhoods gone, wildlife and pets lost, and just so much gone from my beautiful California, from Los Angeles. 

‚Ä¶ but in the midst of it all California and its people have shown up to care for one another; and so have our neighbors including Mexico, Canada and 9 US States. A big shout-out to all the firefighters literally fighting this fire around the clock since Tuesday last week and into this coming week, a huge thank you to the law enforcement keeping whats left safe from looters; and the 1000s of volunteers who have shown-up to the various centers to help in any way they can. This is what community looks like, this is what California looks like. 

And Thank You @pasadenajobcenter for opening your doors to those in need and volunteers alike. 
Solo el Pueblo, Salva al Pueblo. 

If you‚Äôre looking to make an impact and volunteer to help those affected by the LA Fires check out these places I‚Äôve found (follow their social media for updates and make sure they are accepting donations and/or volunteers):

If you‚Äôre looking to make monetary donations, any of the above organizations would be happy to take your donations of any dollar amount. You can also consider directly donating to GoFundMe created to help @phitcat of @213hikers (link in bio) who has lost his house in the Eaton Fire; and @miabohemia whose parents also lost their home in the Palisades Fire. 

Once it‚Äôs safe to rebuild and restore the following are asking for future volunteers (please follow their social media for updates and how to join):

PLEASE DONATE TO PASADENA HUMANE TO CARE FOR ANIMAL VICTIMS OF THE EATON FIRE üêæ‚ù§Ô∏èüêæ

Pasadena Humane has taken in over 400 animals from the Eaton Fire Emergency. They are desperately in need of monetary donations to help purchase medical supplies and other resources as they start to see a significant increase in the number of burned and injured animals coming to the shelter.

These animals are suffering from smoke inhalation, singed paws, burns, dehydration, and more. They have been treating each animal based on their needs, providing fluids, oxygen, pain medications and wound care as quickly as they can.

The best way to help the animals and families who are in need is to donate. This will give them the flexibility to cover critical expenses like medical care, facility maintenance, and support for lifesaving programs that ensure every animal has the best chance at a positive outcome! 

This is a human and animal tragedy on an unimaginable scale and they are only beginning to learn of the full impact.

As the Eaton Fire emergency continues, they anticipate taking in many more animals who are in need of emergency medical care. @pasadenahumane #pasadenahumane #animalrescue #help #eatonfire #animals

Dear Los Angeles, we‚Äôre thinking of you. We compiled a list of a few resources and hope this helps get you through these difficult days. Please follow guidance from local authorities and stay safe.

#LAfires #LAStrong #palisadesfire #EatonFire

I went dark last week. I had no words to string together to make sense of everything that has happened. My brain shut off as it took in hearing tragedy after tragedy. So many of our clients have had their homes and schools taken from them. Some have no city at all to return to, it‚Äôs beyond heartbreaking. 

I‚Äôve been trying to comprehend the severity of the situation. It‚Äôs unfathomable. LA is my home, I was born and raised here. I‚Äôve grown up going to these places that are no longer standing. I‚Äôve spent the last 8+ years working in the Palisades with a countless amount of families. My heartaches for each and everyone who has been affected by the fires. I will do my best to bring you some sort of comfort. 

I was able to safely see a few kids for classes last week and it was such a magical break from all the sadness. We were able to give parents a moment to breathe and the kids a moment to come together with their friends. I love my community so much, words cannot express my gratitude towards them. 

We will be announcing our action steps on how we will be helping our community in the next day or two. I do know that I will be opening up my home and my private studio to hold art classes for those who have been affected, hoping this will give parents a small break and kids an outlet to express themselves. Our schedule will be coming out this week ‚ù§Ô∏è 

A BIG shout out to the firefighters from all over who have come to help our city. Thank you to all the first responders who have helped keep us safe. 

Stay tuned for more to come, we are here for you my sweet and wonderful Angelenos. We will come together and try to help heal from this unimaginable pain. 

#LAstrong #losangelescommunity #palisadesfire #eatonfire #thankyoufirstresponders #thankyoufirefighters #cometogether #kidsartclasses #losangeleskids #lakids

The Palisades and Eaton Fires continue to burn in Los Angeles, and now another major wind storm is coming through. I am safe out in Ventura County, but am constantly checking @watchdutyapp for updates. My family and friends are in the thick of it and it‚Äôs scary to think they could lose everything at any moment. Keeping my fingers crossed they‚Äôll be the lucky ones ü§û 

News coverage makes it easy to think that the only people losing their homes are ultra-rich celebrities and industry tycoons with waterfront properties. They have the means to rebuild easily so, who cares right? (No, they‚Äôve experienced immense loss as well)

But the reality is far from that. The Palisades is a luxury zip code, but the communities of Altadena and Pasadena are full of working class and underprivileged families who have pinched, saved and toiled for decades to afford a home (not an easy feat in CA). They had hoped to leave that home to the next generation so their children and children‚Äôs children would be spared some of the hardships they‚Äôve endured. But all of that burned up in a flash last week. The evidence of their hard work lay ruined in smoldering ashes. The impact this will have on generations to come‚Ä¶ incalculable. (Don‚Äôt even get me started on the inevitable land grab by private equity firms eager to profit off tragedy üòë)

If you are looking to help, I encourage you to seek out organizations serving the Altadena and Pasadena communities, or donate to the @gofundme of those directly impacted by the Eaton Fire. Type in Altadena/Pasadena/Eaton Fire in the GoFundMe search bar and countless funds will pop up. I‚Äôll also post the GoFundMe links for the families/friends of friends that have been affected (saved as a Highlight). Every little bit, even $5 here and there, would mean so much to those who‚Äôve lost everything. If you can‚Äôt donate, please keep sharing these stories so they‚Äôre not forgotten.

Stay safe out there, friends ‚ù§Ô∏è Pray for the people of LA üôè

‚Ä¶

You may remember the Eagle Rock Music Studio, which was open from 2007 until its closing during COVID. Maybe you took lessons there. Maybe you sent your kid there. The owner, Sue Bray, was my guitar teacher for a while. 

Sue and her husband Pat (also a talented musician), had a lovely home on Altadena Dr. where they lived with with their 3 dogs, 2 cats, 2 turtles, and lifetime‚Äôs  collection of instruments. After the closing of the studio in Eagle Rock, Sue taught music lessons out of this home, which I would drive to once a week in the evening. 

I always loved the drive, and my time with her. Sue is one of the coolest people I‚Äôve met. She‚Äôs very chill, very even and has a generally really positive vibe. I always enjoyed seeing her beyond just improving at guitar. She‚Äôs also a bodybuilder. üí™üèº She‚Äôs 67.

Sue & Pat‚Äôs home burned to the ground, along with so many others in the Eaton Fire. With only 30 min to evacuate they sadly lost 1 cat, 2 turtles and most of their instruments. 

Two days after the fire, they dusted themselves off and played a gig Friday night. How is that for the power of music and healing? These people are incredible. I share this because I don‚Äôt know how much their GoFundMe will spread, with them being in their 60s and not on social media much. 

I know we‚Äôve all tapped deeply into our resources already, but if you can spare a few, I‚Äôd love to help out Sue and Pat. Will link the GoFundMe in my bio and stories. 

Thanks. ü§òüèº

#eatonfire #musicianshelpingmusicians #altadena #fire #helpothers #eaglerock

**RTE // FUNDRAISER BELOW**

We long for scenes like this one. We so miss the buzz of energy on Washington Boulevard that we‚Äôve all grown so accustomed to.

We are grieving deeply for our neighbors & friends that have lost their homes and businesses. And it is not lost on us how lucky we are that we will one day be able re-open this little corner shop. The Pasadena and Altadena communities welcomed us into our first home over 10 years ago, and they‚Äôve supported us through those early days and through the COVID pandemic and every day between and since then. Without them, we wouldn‚Äôt have been able to do what we have done, growing our community across the city and into the South Bay.

For now, are waiting for PWP to confirm that our water is safe to use and drink. The full extent of the Eaton Fire‚Äôs impacts on the water supply cannot be assessed until personnel can access necessary areas and make assessments.

We know it will take years for areas around the shop to heal and rebuild, but we are using our current resources to host a fundraiser this week at our Redondo Beach location. Redondo Beach and the South Bay have shown us a warmth reminiscent of those earliest days on Washington Blvd.; and now we ask that our extended community help us to help those who made all of this possible from the start.

WAYS TO DONATE IN LAVENDER & HONEY‚ÄôS FUNDRAISER benefitting Eaton Fire Relief efforts:

(1) Donate any $ amount at our Redondo register. Simply tell our cashier at check-out & this will be added to your ticket.

(2) 50% of all sales proceeds this week through 1/17 will be donated to @wckitchen and @gofundme‚Äôs Wildfire Relief Fund.

locationName: Westside Los Angeles Ronald McDonald House
caption:
Pt.1 - What‚Äôs going on has been nothing short of devastating.. Seeing so many people lose everything they have, along with the first responders spending tireless hours working day & night doing everything they can for us, I felt helpless just sitting back & I couldn‚Äôt just do nothing. 
I‚Äôve been Blessed & Grateful that this whole team was able to come together this weekend & make meals for our first responders. Everyone has been doing their part one way or another & for that we were able to make everything happen so efficiently. 

Saturday we had prepped/packaged 400+ meals, + 200PB sandwiches to be delivered on Sunday. (Along with the 200 fresh pizzas on Sunday that were made by @lapizzeriaco)(I will be getting to that in my next post!)
HUGEEE Thank you to our team @celestedurve, @u_getz, @akmirch & @chefcrystalblanchette for all coming together & being able to coordinate and pull this off!! And a huge thank you to all the volunteers that have come out to help!!
For everyone that has donated $$$, food, supplies, your time, thank you soo much!! 

The work & efforts aren‚Äôt stopping at the weekend, we will be looking to continue to raise more $$$, receive any donations of any kind(food, supplies, water, etc) as we will be continuing to make drop off‚Äôs to these locations that we have been serving. (& I will be making another post to go into more detail so everyone can understand who we‚Äôve met with & served.. W/O them all the work out there would not happen or be utter chaos)

I want to add how incredibly grateful the men & women on duty have been for us serving them, & I‚Äôm not talking just a quick ‚ÄúThank You,‚Äù I mean they were in utter disbelief and soo gracious for us showing up w/ everything we had, when we are the ones that truly owe it to them & should be doing anything we can for these brave men & women. 
So let‚Äôs continue to come together, chip in what‚Äôs possible, & continue giving back for all their tireless efforts! 
SENDING YOU LOVE, LIGHT, & BLESSINGS‚Ä¶ ALWAYSüôè‚ù§Ô∏è
-M.S. 
.

Thank you to everyone who has reached out to our family.  Like you, we are stunned and gutted by the destruction of our community.  Our hearts hurt for our friends and neighbors who have lost everything. We are so grateful to be safe. Holden and I left home last week due to smoke and falling ash. Rob stayed to watch the house and volunteer. We have the most lovely humans in our neighborhood and everyone is looking out for each other.
*
So much loss around every bend. Holden's amazing school - her safe place - is now gone (video above). But we are already talking about how to help rebuild.
*
I want to thank all the first responders and firefighters. Your fearlessness and dedication is awe-inspiring. I pray for you deeply and constantly. To my colleagues reporting on the fires - you are doing incredible work providing our community with vital information. There are countless volunteers who are doing everything they can to comfort others during this crisis. I see you and I can't wait to join you. 
*
I want to share a small symbol of hope. Years ago, one of the remarkable teachers at Holden's school placed a statue of St. Francis of Assisi outside the second grade classroom. He spoke to the statue and told him that ‚Äòthere are children who call this land home who need you.‚Äô The statue (second pic) is one of the only things standing after flames engulfed the campus. Saint Francis is the patron saint of all living things who chose to live a life of poverty and served those in need. Part of the Peace Prayer of Saint Francis says, "O divine Master, grant that I may not so much seek to be consoled, as to console, to be understood as to understand, to be loved as to love." 
‚ú®‚ù§Ô∏è‚ú®
*
LA is hurting. I am praying for the safety and restoration of a community I love. There is so much healing to do, but we will begin again. #Californiafires #Eatonfire #LosAngeles #Love #Hope

I have been at a loss for words watching the fires across Los Angeles this past week. ‚Å†In this time of uncertainty, it has been inspiring to watch communities across Southern California rise up in support of our neighbors affected by these unprecedented fires. ‚Å†
‚Å†
As of today, over 12,000 structures have been lost, and it has been heartbreaking to see some of our favorite and most important architectural landmarks among those buildings. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Among the losses is the 1887 Andrew McNally House in Altadena, who was a publisher and co-founder of Rand McNally. His grandson, architect Wallace Neff, would later help define the ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äù style of architecture we still celebrate to this day. ‚Å†

Due to looters and burglaries, the National Guard has set up checkpoints with Altadena, blocking access to large areas. The only people allowed through are emergency personnel, utility workers, and the press. Unfortunately, if you need to leave to get resources, you might not be allowed back in. This has been an issue for elderly residents, who with all of the confusion going on, are staying put. FEMA has been going in, which hopefully has been helpful. The National Guard I spoke with was friendly, having to deal with several concerned residents. LAPD on hand also had lots of helpful information and directions to receive resources. 
#altadena #eatonfire #losangeles #nationalguard

It‚Äôs hard to believe that just one week ago, I was in Malibu, and now the West LA area has been facing devastation from the Palisades fire. Looking back at these photos, it‚Äôs difficult to fully grasp the severity of the destruction these fires have caused, knowing I was in Malibu (devastated area) just 2 days before the Palisades fire started. My heart is with everyone in Los Angeles affected by the tragedies all the horrific wildfires have brought about. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

I've been crying a lot this week. We are OK, but Altadena is gone. 

Everyone I knew here has lost all they had I still can't wrap my head around it.

I was always here, either driving along Altadena Drive or visiting friends. My kids went to Woodbury Preschool Village (which has been spared) 

Whole lives full of memories, the beautiful surroundings, century old trees and incredible unreplicable architecture. Everything gone within hours.

Gregory Ain designed these 28 "Park Planned Homes" in 1948. Homes incorporating the collective spirit, good design that was supposed to be within reach for all. They are no longer...

Photos (first one) by Pam Remal and Dana Hursey

I'm worried about all the longtime residents who will not have the strength to rebuild and all the speculation that will follow and not include the original spirit of the neighborhood. But in the short term I am here, available to help in any way I can. 

If you or someone you know needs to talk, cry, find as new place. Please know I am available. I want the politicizing and "divide and conquer" politics of this country to stop here.
.
.
.
.
.
#highviewhomes #gregoryain #altadena #architecture #losangelesarchitecture #architecture #losangeleshistory #eatonfire

Navigating insurance and re-building is one of many issues on people‚Äôs plates right now. Tons of misinformation being thrown around. 

Please check and re-check your sources. Also be careful during this time when scam artist become active.

Since my children were little they‚Äôve gone to Camp Summerkids. Summerkids is a camp in Altadena set in a gorgeous area at the southern edge of the Angeles National Forest. It‚Äôs hard to overstate how beautiful it is. Generations of kids in Altadena, Pasadena, Glendale, and elsewhere consider @campsummerkids part of their childhood. The camp was scorched in the fire. All the buildings are gone. The future is unknown. But right now the camp is focused on supporting Jose, the camp‚Äôs caretaker. Jose has been living on site at the camp and lovingly kept it beautiful for the past decade. His home is gone. A GoFundMe was started for Jose, and you can donate here: https://www.gofundme.com/f/rebuild-our-caretaker-joses-life-after-fire-disaster Thank you so much. #altadena #eatonfire #eatoncanyonfire #fire #summerkidscamp #summerkids #pasadena #losangelesstrong

AMRT would like to recognize all those who continue to work in the fire zone. In addition to the various fire fighting agencies from around the country that have responded to the Eaton Fire, there are so many more who never receive the recognition they deserve in these situations. 

After the fires are extinguished, the recovery work begins. 

Downed power lines need to be checked, de-energized and removed if causing obstructions. Power needs to be restored in areas that survived the fires to prepare for residents to return. 

Fallen trees need to be cleared to open up roads and access routes for search teams, as well as allowing clear safe routes for residents upon return. 

Natural gas lines need to be inspected to ensure there are no leaks or fires and addressed accordingly. 

Water service needs to be inspected to ensure those who can return will have access.

Animals and pets need to be recovered and cared for. 

Phone and internet service restoration will allow residents to return and maintain communication. 

These are just some of the agencies/organizations we have seen in the area working around the clock.

Update on the California Fires:

üí® Santa Ana winds are (still!) set to cause critical fire conditions over the next 3Ô∏è‚É£ days, as we continue to battle historic and deadly blazes. 

So we are NOT out of woods yet, pun intended.

The wind-fed wildfires have:

ü•∫Killed at least 24 people (as of now)
ü•∫Rendered another 16 missing (as of now)
ü•∫Burned 40,000 acres in the Greater LA area 
ü•∫Destroyed 12,300 structures and entire communities

Evacuation orders for the largest blaze, the Palisades Fire have expanded. 

üî• It is 14% contained and threatens Brentwood, Encino and Westwood.

Evacuation orders are currently in effect for 92,000 L.A. residents, and 89,000 are in evacuation warning zones, which means they may need to leave at a moment‚Äôs notice. At its height, 180,000 people were evacuated.

This is a BIG freakin‚Äô deal.

What‚Äôs positive? 

Well, there are so many people out there offering to help: 

üêé People with massive horse trailers who can transport up to 20 horses are offering to help. 

üê∂ Animal shelters everywhere are offering pet housing.

ü•ò Tons of evacuation centers and donation centers are everywhere in LA County. It isn‚Äôt hard to find a place to donate supplies, food, clothes, or money.

Quick online searches immediately turn up all of these resources. 

I‚Äôve made a commitment to contribute to everyone I know who sends me a GoFundMe page for a friend or family member to rebuild a home, and have done that several times. That feels good, so keep ‚Äòem coming.

Thank you to people like @cmart1010 @cruzbomb and @loaracadavona (who I know from high school, run club, and a community board) who have shared these fundraisers for their extremely close friends and siblings. 

If you‚Äôre wanting a place to donate, these are three great options and I can forward those pages to you. 

We must STAY STRONG, Los Angeles.
.
.
.
.
.

Friends, Family & Community,
‚Ä®On Wednesday morning after we evacuated, our neighbor informed us that our (Max, Jasmine & Tim) home, as well as the entire neighborhood had been completely destroyed by the #EatonFire that started Tuesday night on 1/7‚Ä®‚Ä®On Thurs (1/9), our family was able to locate a back route to our home to see the devastations on our own. The worst was confirmed, everything is gone. ‚Ä®‚Ä®We are now thankful that we took the opportunity to do this, because the next day, National Guard arrived in Altadena blocking any route to our town. 

We feel strongly that we want to be in the #Altadena area for the time ahead so that we can access resources and be part of the community that we love. 

It is still so early in the process and we don‚Äôt know the ins and outs of the rebuilding process, so I will just express our desires. We want to rebuild on our home land. That dream is still intact. 

With the rebuild process we want to work with honest, hardworking people who will be fair and not look to price gouge us or our beloved community. 

Thank you to everyone who has already donated to our gofundme page. The support we have received since the fires broke out is incredibly humbling and overwhelming. One of our favorite movies is It‚Äôs a Wonderful Life, and we feel the love and generosity of our community just like George Bailey did at the end of the film. ‚Ä®‚Ä®We‚Äôve gotten so many messages, texts and calls, asking how they can help. Because we‚Äôre living out of our suitcases right now, we are living on only necessities, which have been covered. ‚Ä®‚Ä®Whatever you can give to our fund is extremely helpful and appreciated for unknown future expenses that won‚Äôt be covered by insurance or disaster relief (FEMA). Even if you can‚Äôt give, we‚Äôd appreciate all the eyes we can receive. ‚Ä®‚Ä®We love you all, and we feel that same love back at us!‚Ä®‚Ä®-Max, Jasmine, Tim and Charlie 

Link to gofundme is in our bio

If you are tempted to post political slant about the California fires, please think about it before you do. I have seen so many posts in the last few days attacking Los Angeles, saying folks ‚Äúdon‚Äôt care if celebrities lose their homes,‚Äù things about North Carolina being more of a tragedy, etc.

Posts like this are really hurtful when we have thousands of very real people out here losing their homes. People just like you.

My sister works at a school and 52 of her students have lost their homes. I personally know at least a dozen who have lost everything and so many more who have been evacuated due to smoke and air quality.

The devastation of what we are dealing with here does not make North Carolina any less of a tragedy. Both can be suffering and both can need assistance. Asheville is still in shambles and we will be the same for months and years to come.

Please don‚Äôt let the media convince you that anyone‚Äôs suffering isn‚Äôt important. There has been devastation here, there, and everywhere that deserves our kindness and compassion. We are all human beings surviving on the same planet. Please treat each other as such.

Tragedy is not a competition.
.
.

If you or someone you know experienced home loss or property damage from the recent LA wildfires, swipe for what to do next:

‚úÖ Ensure Safety: Once it‚Äôs safe to return, focus on preventing further damage.

‚úÖ Contact Insurance: Don‚Äôt delay filing your claim. File your claim ASAP.

‚úÖ Understand Coverage: A public adjuster can help maximize your claim if you‚Äôre unsure how to navigate the process.

‚úÖ Apply for Aid: Check @fema and local relief programs for temporary housing and essentials.

‚úÖ Start Rebuilding: Reach out to a housing expert (Like us!) to help with permits, structural assessments, and fire-safe design. @cacontractorsboard

Monday slides from the Angel City 

#LaFires #Eatonfire #palisadesfire #politics #news #losangeles 

Last slide music from Amy Holland ‚ÄúShooting for the moon‚Äù (1986)

As elementary school teachers by trade, our hearts will always be with schools, educators, and the sweet students and families that make the school a community. 

Today as we mark one week and counting since the Palisades, Eaton, and countless other LA-based fires began ravaging our city, our hearts are especially with the thousands of educators headed back to their classrooms today to greet their students once again. 

The devastation of dozens of schools across LA being damaged or completely lost to the fires is of course heartbreaking. How those communities will rebuild, how long it will take, and what they will do in the meantime only covers the logistical questions. Schools are a safe haven for our children, a place of learning, growth, creativity, and fun - and to not have access to the school you called home because of a destructive disaster like this is just beyond words. 

But today, we are especially thinking of those schools who escaped the obvious char of the building, escaped the power lines toppling down, escaped water damage, and the buildings are still standing as they always have been. Today we're thinking of all of the other schools who look the same from the outside, yet the people on the inside are forever changed.  As so many of our Angelenos return to school and "business as usual", you know that it must be incredibly hard for everyone. 

Harder for parents to let go of morning hugs with their child. 
Harder for kids to skip and laugh as they cross the threshold. 
And so difficult for educators to unplug from their own worries, fears, thoughts, desire to watch the news 24/7, and be fully available to hold space for their entire school community. 

Educators are heroes, they are the link from home to school that bridge students' two worlds, give them love and enough reassurance to inspire them to thrive, and provide consistency and stability for children when the outside world seems like its crumbling. 

Thank you educators for all that you do for each and every one of us, each and every day.  You are such an important piece in all of our recovery and we are so thankful for your patience and love during these challenging times. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π
Last night. The moon coming up over the mountain. Less smoke. The feeling of pending doom is lessening. #EatonFire God Bless all of those on the frontlines containing these fires.

Thank you to everyone who has reached out in one way or another.  We  are safe for now & grateful that there aren‚Äôt any fires in our proximity. We are in the Critical Fire Risk zone with a Red Flag Warning. 

Unfortunately, the Santa Ana Winds have started again until Wednesday, with gusts of up to 70 mph. This means we could have a second wave of fires, and with these winds, it is almost impossible to control them. 

My heart is heavy and broken for everyone affected by this ongoing tragedy, especially for our friends and colleagues who have lost everything or are close to those fires. When we received the evacuation warning at our office, we were able to successfully save all its contents for Dr. Marashi. He was one of the people who lost everything in the Pacific Palisades fire on Tuesday night. My heart breaks for the loss of Dr. Aubert‚Äôs home in Altadena during the Eaton fire. 

Diego has been working tirelessly at the command post, managing the logistics of the hospital and satellite cancer clinics to ensure patient safety, treatment, and the well-being of the staff. Over 30 of them have not only lost everything in their homes but also one lost her spouse, and a nurse actually coded. He has been up at 2am working every day since the fires started last Tuesday. 

Please keep LA in your prayers and send good thoughts to all of the people who have been displaced, lost loved ones, pets, and the wildlife who have also lost their habitats. May the 2nd wave we are preparing for be a mere drill and may we all remain strong and resilient and safe. 

#lafires #palisadesfire #eatonfire #hurstfire #prayforla #loveangeles #pleasehelp #lastrong  #firstreapondersareheros #santanawinds

U.S. Air Force Airmen assigned to the 153rd Airlift Wing tow a C-130H Hercules aircraft out of a hangar in Cheyenne, Wyoming, Jan. 10, 2025, in preparation to support firefighting efforts in the Los Angeles area. U.S. Northern Command activated three Wyoming Air National Guard C-130s equipped with Modular Airborne Fire Fighting Systems (MAFFS) and associated personnel to assist firefighting efforts in California. MAFFS, developed by the U.S. Forest Service, are portable fire-retardant delivery systems that convert C-130s into airtankers, capable of releasing up to 3,000 gallons of retardant in under five seconds. Since the fires broke out in LA, we've had a lot of questions from our community, namely 1) How can we help? and 2) Where can we send clothing/shoes/item donations?

The quickest and easiest way to help? Make a donation - a financial donation goes farther, faster and can directly help those in need, both now and in the days and weeks to come. You can also help by signing up to volunteer and donating blood or platelets. Winter weather and disasters impact blood drives nationwide, but patients still need blood every day. You can learn more by visiting the Red Cross website at redcross.org.

Want to donate items like clothing? Great! Call 2-1-1 to connect with organizations that specialize in this work. The Red Cross is unable accept these items but other partners can. Our focus is keeping evacuees sheltered, fed and safe, but other partner agencies are focused on collecting, sorting and distributing much-needed items like clothing, shoes and other essentials.

#eatonfire #palisadesfire #wildfires

California has always dealt with Santa Ana winds, wildfires, and droughts‚Äîthese aren‚Äôt new challenges. If this post offends you, YOU ARE THE DUMMY in your family. For the smart people, rely on websites that end in .gov; only consult a reputable organization for assistance, always contact any insurance company yourself, and KNOW your deductible before you advance large sums of cash. Also, understand how deductibles work. 

There are idiots out her claiming that insurance will reimburse for housing, cleaning fees, etc. But that may be contingent on paying your deductible first. Total loss deductibles are in the thousands of dollars. In context, if you spend $10k and your deductible is $30k, there is no reimbursement. If anyone tells you that you can get reimbursed for spending money, TELL THEM TO FRONT THE MONEY for you, and you'll pay them if you receive that amount in hand.

Fire in the Sky! üî•

I haven‚Äôt had the words or energy to share my grief. Despite living in Washington for the past five years, John and I still consider Los Angeles home. We were there last week. We drove through what felt like the end times to get to Palm Desert. All I can do is text all of my friends all day and night to make sure they are ok. Of course, no one is ok. Not one person is ok. Most of them have been evacuated. Some multiple times from multiple locations across the city. Some friends have lost everything. 

They are all traumatized. And the worst may still be to come. 

So many people in this country love to hate on Los Angeles and California as a whole. The shadenfreude is revolting, but real. I beg of you. Remember these are human beings who need love, compassion, and yes, money and support. Most people who live in L.A. are NOT rich. The entertainment industry that many enjoy, but also love to vilify, is made up of people who are just trying to pay their bills and take care of their families. And this industry was decimated long before the fires. Many of my friends have been without work for two years! Two of my friends from the industry were being evicted from their painfully expensive small apartments because there has been no work. 

And now this. Please be kind and show only compassion. Please don‚Äôt get caught up in a tragedy that is already being politicized‚Äîwhere people‚Äôs suffering is being ridiculed by the cruel human who was unimaginably elected into office. This is all insult to injury. I beg of you not to get on that bandwagon. It only shows weak character. 

I ask that you don‚Äôt fall prey to cruelty. And, whatever you do, don‚Äôt ever tell me that you hate my home because I could never do that to you. 

My heart is broken. üíî

#palisadesfire #ilovela #eatonfire

üö® Know the difference: An Evacuation WARNING means it's time to get ready and prepare to leave. If you have animals, children, or need additional time to evacuate, leave now. An Evacuation ORDER means you need to leave immediately. Don‚Äôt wait until it‚Äôs too late‚Äîif you feel unsafe, evacuate! 

If you're unsure whether your location is under an evacuation order or warning, you can check the Watch Duty app. Download the app at watchduty.org or view it in your browser at app.watchduty.org. 

You can also find out what zone you're in by referencing the Genasys Project at protect.genasys.com. 

Stay informed and stay safe during the #LAWildfires. üî•

I HEART Inc is currently raising money for L.A.
Wildfire Relief (donate link + contact in bio). 100% of your tax-deductible donation will go to those in need of immediate assistance. Los Angeles is our hometown and we‚Äôre heartbroken over the devastation but inspired to see our community coming together to help one another navigate this tragedy.

There are so many incredible organizations doing great work but so many of them are overwhelmed and struggling to deliver donations in a timely fashion to all of those in need.
And so we‚Äôre hoping to do our part by delivering relief in the form of grants ($250-$1000) to those who need immediate assistance and have been unable to get it.

We‚Äôre a small operation but we know we can take on some of the overflow. Any donations we are unable to distribute ourselves will be donated to highly rated non-profits that are working tirelessly for our community like American Red Cross, Direct Relief, 211LA, and Pasadena Humane.

‚ÄúDo what you can with where you are and what you‚Äôve got...‚Äù I HEART Inc is a 501(c) (3) non-profit organization, EIN 26-0652743. All contributions are tax deductible.

Our hearts are heavy for our Los Angeles community as we navigate the ongoing devastation of the recent fires. We know these fires have caused unimaginable loss‚Äînot only to homes and businesses but also to the memories, milestones, and dreams that make life so special.

Inspired by the incredible efforts of the Southern California wedding community and the amazing collaboration within groups like @plannerpower_ and @curatecalifornia_ , we‚Äôre following the lead of fellow planners like @aliciaandcoevents and @hllovely to step up and support couples affected by the recent fires.

How we‚Äôre offering support:

>> Venue Scouting | If your venue is no longer available, we‚Äôll help you find a new space that fits your vision and keeps your wedding dreams alive.
>> Budget Adjustments | We‚Äôll work with you to adjust your plans, re-prioritize, and ensure everything stays on track.

We know the weight of uncertainty is overwhelming, but you‚Äôre not alone. While weddings are only a small part of what many are facing, we‚Äôre committed to helping couples find joy and hope in the midst of loss. 

If you or someone you know needs this kind of support, please reach out via DM or email us at info@champagnedreams.co. To help us assist you more efficiently, please include ‚ÄòFire Relief Support‚Äô in the subject line of your email. This will ensure we can prioritize your message and provide assistance as quickly as possible.

To everyone who has been impacted‚Äîyou are in our hearts. To those donating, volunteering, or helping rebuild‚Äîyou are the soul of this community. Together, we can overcome this.

With hope,

Champagne Dreams + Co.

But this community‚Äîthe Palisades kids, the parents, the neighbors who always looked out for each other‚Äîwas never just about the places. It‚Äôs about the people. And together, we‚Äôll mourn, and then, hand in hand, rebuild. 

Let this be a reminder everyone: hold tight to the small things. They‚Äôre never small‚Äîthey‚Äôre what truly matter.

üåü Property Tax Relief for Disaster-Affected Property Owners üåü

The Los Angeles County Assessor‚Äôs Office is helping property owners recover after disasters like earthquakes, landslides, or fires. If your property has been damaged or its market value has dropped due to such events, you may qualify for property tax relief through one of these programs:

üîπ Decline-in-Value Review (Form RP-87)
If your property‚Äôs current market value is less than its assessed value as of January 1, you may apply for a Decline-in-Value Review.
üìÖ Filing Period: July 2 ‚Äì November 30 each year.
Note: If the final filing date falls on a weekend or holiday, applications postmarked on the next business day will still be accepted.

üîπ Application for Reassessment: Property Damaged or Destroyed by Misfortune or Calamity (Form ADS-820)
If your property suffers damage exceeding $10,000 in market value, you may qualify for reassessment.
üìå Eligibility Requirements:

Damage must be due to a calamity (e.g., earthquake, landslide, fire).
File Form ADS-820 within 12 months of the damage or destruction date.
üí° Key Details of the Misfortune & Calamity Program:

Assessed value reduction is effective from the date the damage occurred and remains in place until the property is repaired, rebuilt, or sold.
If the damage and restoration occur within the same tax year, you‚Äôll receive a refund for the damage period and a supplemental tax bill for the restoration period.
üí¨ How to Apply
1Ô∏è‚É£ Download forms and instructions at assessor.lacounty.gov/disaster.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Need help? Visit your local district or regional office for in-person assistance. View all locations at assessor.lacounty.gov/contact/officelocations.

Contact us at info@nicolailawfirm.com.

This has been a very heavy week. To this day, the Palisades fire is less than 15% contained and closely behind, the Eaton fire is at 27%, with a an overall death toll climbing to 24, and has swept through 40,000 acres. And Santa Ana winds are set to cause more critical fire conditions in the next few days.

I am grateful to be safe about 20 miles south of the Palisades fire, but the same can't be said for over 92,000 evacuated Los Angeles residents. People think of L.A. and for some reason they think everyone is wealthy or a celebrity. This couldn't be further from the truth. Families of ALL economic backgrounds have lost everything.

As I said before, I will be donating 100% of my profits to @coreresponse, who is actively responding to this disaster by focusing on short and long term recovery, especially for underserved communities.

Please support by buying these designs (more items have been added) if you have the means, and if not, please share and spread the word. Link in bio or comment with HELP and I'll send you the direct link (if you have a private profile I may not be able to DM you).

At DeMera DeMera Cameron, LLP, we stand with those affected by the ongoing wildfires in Los Angeles County. During these challenging times, it‚Äôs essential to prioritize safety and know that resources are available to help.

üí° Tax Tip for Wildfire Victims:
The IRS has extended the tax filing and payment deadlines for individuals and businesses in Los Angeles County and other FEMA-designated areas. Affected taxpayers now have until October 15, 2025, to file federal returns and make payments for deadlines originally falling between January 7 and October 15, 2025.

üëâ Uninsured or unreimbursed disaster-related losses can also be claimed on your 2024 or 2025 tax return. Don‚Äôt forget to write the FEMA declaration number 4856-DR on your return if claiming a loss.

For details on tax relief, visit the IRS‚Äôs Disaster Assistance page or contact our team for guidance.

üíõ Stay safe, Los Angeles. We‚Äôre here to help.

Please help! the Wetlands and Wildlife Care Center in Huntington Beach, CA are doing extra heavy lifting right now-they are receiving injured wildlife specifically from Pasadena & Altadena‚Äôs Eaton Fire driven to their emergency care center coming from Pasadena Humane Society to the Orange County Wetland and Wildlife Care Center on Pacific Coast Hwy.
With the Los Angeles fires damaging land and homes, wildlife is in need of assistance. Many of them can‚Äôt escape the fire on their own and are dependent on us to save their lives.
WE‚ÄôRE IN DIRE NEED OF AN OXYGEN CONCENTRATOR AND FUNDS TO BUY NECESSARY MEDICAL SUPPLIES FOR BURN VICTIMS AND HUSBANDRY FOR EXOTIC ANIMALS WE DON‚ÄôT TYPICALLY SEE .

TO DONATE

https://www.wwccoc.org/donate.html

They are a 501(c) since 1997
for rehab and release of orphaned native wildlife.
WWCC is capable of rehabilitating many many animals at a time. The facility is equipped with animal washing stations, a hospital, indoor and outdoor caging, areas to prepare food and a facilities container. The treatment and rehabilitation areas are closed to the general public.
The center has evolved over the years into a sophisticated network of rehabilitation professionals and volunteers, unique to the southland in accessibility, expertise and results.
We are proud of the dedicated veterinarians, trained wildlife technicians and certified volunteers who make our success possible.

When I arrived in the parking lot of the Griffith Observatory on the night of January 7th, my goal was to document the Palisades Fire that had been burning all day. When I got out of the car, I noticed a faint glow in the San Gabriel Foothills to the northeast. This was concerning because it was nowhere near the fire raging at the coast. The glow began to expand and I set up my tripod in the strong wind to try to capture what was happening. Many of the long exposures are blurry because of the conditions, but I have a number of frames that are sharp. I captured the very beginning of Eaton Fire which would go on to destroy nearly all of Altadena. The second photo was taken roughly 15 minutes after the first, so you can see how quickly the fire took off. 

I apologize for the recent number of fire pictures, but it is LA history now. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll be sharing more joyful content again soon.

CPI Can Help During Wildfires

We are thinking of everyone affected by the fires and send love and appreciation to each and every one of you.

Sadly, our beloved city, where many of us were born and raised, has faced wildfires before. We remember the Woolsey Fire in Malibu (2018) and the Getty Fire in Brentwood (2019). While the current fires are more severe, the heartbreak of losing a home remains the same.

We were there for people previously affected, and we are here for you now. 

If you decide to move forward with rebuilding, here are the essential steps to take:
- Start the Process Early: Begin as soon as possible to avoid delays.
- Gather Property Records: Locate existing plans of the damaged property or contact LADBS to obtain official records.
- Create a Loss Inventory: Make a detailed list of belongings lost in the fire.
- Collect Pre-Fire Photos: Gather any photos of the property‚Äôs exterior and interior taken before the fire for insurance purposes.
- Stay Informed:  Keep up with local and state regulations regarding insurance claims, debris removal, and rebuilding requirements.

We can assist you with any of these steps and provide guidance specific to your situation.

Please give us a FREE call at 323-938-1960, email shannon@citizenproperties.com or visit our website if you need support and have any questions about:

 - Insurance
 - Owner‚Äôs Rep
 - Debris Removal
 - Permitting and City records
 - Design/Build

We are here for you!

Love and blessings,
Team CPI

We are in Los Angeles, we are part of it, it is our home. This last week so many in our community, people we work with, friends and neighbors have lost everything. We have tried to help where ever we could, but we wanted see what else we could do, could we extend our reach. After all our jobs as designers is creative problem solving. We have stuff. Some of it is pretty cool. We have a very tiny , but hopefully mighty(?) Etsy shop. We set it upnot long ago as an outlet for some of the sometimes fun, sometimes beautiful, but always interesting things we find along the way and in the foreseeable future, sustainably focused items from our studio. For at least the balance of this month January it will a different focus. We have gathered items with a deep and direct connection to Los Angeles. These the Featured Items on the top of our Etsy shop page. All the profits from these items will go to support the victims of the Palisades and Eaton Fires. We are only allowed to feature four items at a time, but as they hopefully sell, we will add new items. In addition, if LA stuff is not your thing, we are also including 20% of all sales in January. Pictured are the first four items. Link to our Etsy shop is in our bio. Please share! Thank you!
#palisadesfire #eatonfire #lastrong #losangeles @asustainablekitchen

First of all, I hope you are currently safe and out of fire danger. 

I wrote this brief list of tips and recommendations for framing disaster mental health responses for my fellow clinicians and providers out there. 

You are a great resource for our Angelenos as we continue in this response phase. Be kind to yourself right now. Burnout is high already in our field, and then gets majorly amplified during times of natural and man-made disasters. Keep putting your oxygen mask on first. Then check in with your loved ones, family members, friends, and CLIENTs. Focus on immediate basic needs.

Active grief and all its forms is a normal reaction to the current situation. People‚Äôs lives and communities have forever been changed. And this is raw, visceral, and often unverbalized. Comfort one another. Check in on each other. Thank each other for help. LA will process these collective and individual losses more deeply as we shift from one disaster and emotional phase to another. When the shock wears off...therapists, counselors, social workers, doctors, nurses, vetmed/animal med staff, medical professionals, teachers, and coaches will be ready to provide more support.

This is a starting point for additional mental health and psychosocial services supported during a disaster.

Be kind and keep hope. 

Zack 
@zackreedfier.lpcc

#palisadesfire #eatonfire #hurstfire #disasterrelief #disasterresponse #disastermentalhealth #lastrong #crisismentalhealth

We stand with all the homeowners who lost their homes in the tragic Southern California wildfires. 

If you‚Äôre struggling with canceled policies or skyrocketing premiums, you‚Äôre not alone. 

Here are some tips to deal with insurance companies:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Know Your Rights: In California, insurers must give you 45 days‚Äô notice before canceling your policy.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Act Fast: Contact your insurance company immediately to explore your options and address the situation.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Work with an Expert: Consider working with an experienced insurance agent who knows the market and can advocate for you.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Check Admitted Insurers: Look for policies from admitted insurance companies that comply with state regulations.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Avoid Being Underinsured: Review your policy to ensure your coverage reflects your property‚Äôs actual value and replacement cost.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Compare Coverage Options: Take the time to evaluate different types of coverage and policy limits to ensure you‚Äôre getting the best fit.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Explore Surplus Lines: If traditional insurers won‚Äôt cover you, surplus lines insurance may offer another solution.

8Ô∏è‚É£ Use the FAIR Plan as a Last Resort: This state-backed plan is available when no other options remain, but only covers certain losses by fire and smoke. You can contact them at 800-339-4099

Please share these tips with anyone who could benefit from this crucial information üôè

Wildfires and natural disasters can have a lasting impact on our lives ‚Äì physically, emotionally, and
mentally. Whether you‚Äôve lived through one or witnessed the aftermath, it‚Äôs normal to feel a range of emotions, including grief.
 
Talking about grief can be tough, but it‚Äôs crucial to support your loved ones by creating a safe, open space for them to share their feelings. Sometimes, just listening can make a world of difference.
 
If you or someone you know is struggling with the mental health effects of a disaster, our expert team of psychiatrists, therapists, and mental health professionals is here for you. You don‚Äôt have to go through it alone.
 
Click the link in our bio to learn more about how we can support you through this journey.

Wildfires and natural disasters don‚Äôt just impact your safety, they affect your mental health too. Whether you‚Äôre directly affected or witnessing from afar, the emotional toll is real. Anxiety, stress, and uncertainty can take over, but prioritizing your mental health is just as important as protecting your physical well-being.

Grounding techniques can help calm your mind and bring you back to the present moment. But remember, it‚Äôs okay to seek professional support when the weight feels too much to bear.

At Clear Behavioral Health, we‚Äôre here to help our community navigate the emotional aftermath of disasters like wildfires. Our compassionate team provides crisis support and mental health services to those in need.

Click the link in our bio to learn how we can support you.

Today was helping out at the Santa Anita Racetrack with little sis and giving back some of what has been taken away.  Blown away by the generosity of so many dropping off everything from water, socks, diapers, and food; it was so heart warming.  Yet, so heart wrenching to see that many people in need where it filled the parking lot.  Blessed by the Chaplain and the smiles of so many, truly grateful to be surrounded by an amazing community.  I think what I will remember from these fires is how greatly I must love my friends‚Äî because I feel everything, from being evacuated out, sharing photos of how close the fire is getting, making sure they are okay, to just needing them to call or message to stop worrying.  To my firefighting family and the one working with FEMA, all the love in the world.  Happy and healthy.  Wishing and praying for everyone‚Äôs safety.  To @meemawshometownkitchen blessings my friend and thanks for the hug‚Ä¶ love my Oregon fam.

LA has always been a city of hope.  Whether it being the first people to settle this land, or the people who built this into a city, to the industries that have worked here, or the countless people who have moved here for the opportunity to make it big, this city has been one built on HOPE. 

As our city burns to the ground, and so many are losing so much, it‚Äôs easy to feel hopeless. We say: look around you.  Look to the helpers.  Look to the doers and the givers.  Find hope in their actions.  Tap into the very spirit this city was founded on: HOPE. 

We may be in some darkness now, but there‚Äôs light ahead.  We will be stronger for this struggle.  We will be stronger, together. 

Don‚Äôt let the fires burn your hope.

Today we went to the checkpoint near our home to deliver supplies to our neighbor who has stayed in his home since the fire.  Despite the news and city officials saying otherwise, the national guard and CHP officers REFUSED TO ALLOW US TO PASS OFF SUPPLIES TO OUR NEIGHBORS.  They stood between us and said that no one above the evacuation line was allowed to receive aid from anyone outside of the evacuation line.  I was delivering cat food for my stray cats, water, and phone charging banks.  The officer looked at my neighbor and said ‚Äúhe has enough.‚Äù WHO IS IN CHARGE OF THIS DISASTER!?!?!? Communication is non existent.  Messaging changes every minute.  And they are now trying to STARVE OUT HUMANS who have nowhere to go and who risked their lives to defend their property while the city was helpless.  I AM OUTRAGED.  #eatonfire #altadena @mayorofla @gavinnewsom

Nearly 20 years ago I started an archaeological project on Mount Lowe Resort and Railway in the San Gabriels. Sadly, the Eaton fire has burnt down much of the volunteer built infrastructure associated with the site, including a shelter and signage. The fire has also claimed friends' homes in the community below the mountains. I am so thankful for the kindness of folks in Altadena and Pasadena - my dissertation wouldn't have happened without their help and support. It is an absolute tragedy.

With everything moving so fast this week, we‚Äôve had little time to pause or chat. We‚Äôve worked alongside so many like-minded individuals, so fast, in fact, that we may never see each other again. We might not even remember each other‚Äôs names or faces, but we‚Äôll definitely remember everything we accomplished during this second week of 2025. With fewer riders on the streets and uncertainty in the air, our daily earnings have dropped significantly, making it harder to keep the shop running. We‚Äôve started a GoFundMe to help cover rent, staff wages, and operational costs during this tough time.

With gratitude and determination,
The Esquina Team

Diablo Supports Firefighters üöí‚ù§Ô∏è

In 2020 we saw the most devastating fires in California‚Äôs history and we rallied as a community by visiting base camps and writing notes of gratitude to the men and women protecting us.  Now in 2025, we are called to do so again.  However, finding effective ways to support and show appreciation for our firefighters and their families can be hard.  So Diablo is supporting with donations to smaller, direct-impact, vetted and First Responder recommended charities.

All proceeds will be given in the name of our community and divided among several including - the Gary Sinise Foundation‚Äôs disaster relief emergency fund for LA, The Overwatch Collective: a Bay Area foundation providing resources for ongoing mental health and awareness, First Responder Therapy Dogs: a locally based therapy dog foundation on-site in LA, a smaller Northern California Firefighter organization bringing aid to them on the front lines and support for their families at home. 

Donate through the link in our BIO.

Our first day of donations and essentials pick-up was incredibly successful, thanks to your generous support! Our hearts are filled to see the community stop by to get what they need. While we were at maximum capacity earlier today, we received an influx of families stopping by toward the end of the day, and we are no longer at capacity. The Drive continues to welcome anyone affected by the wildfires in our region. Join us daily until January 17th, from 12 PM to 4 PM in the Dining Hall. Please enter the Lower Parking Lot through the gates off Michillinda Ave.

Hot meals are available every day from 12 PM to 4 PM in the Dining Hall. A big thank you to @wckitchen for providing their food truck, @smpizzaco, @elportal, @hummuslabs, @nothingbundtcakes, and our dedicated volunteers for their support. School counselors are also available for student support, alongside art and prayer stations for those seeking solace.

Need a little uplift? Therapy puppies will be on campus in the Atrium from 12 PM to 3 PM on Thursday, January 16, ready to offer comfort and joy.

Lastly, if you are able, we invite you to give to the Lancer Support Fund which will provide support to current La Salle students and families directly impacted by the fires. Please visit lasallehs.org/lancersupportfund or click the link in our bio. Donations to the Lancer Support Fund are tax deductible as a 501(c)3 charitable organization gift to La Salle.

Thank you for your continued support of La Salle and one another. We will get through this together as a community.

There‚Äôs a new race against time caused by the wind and burn scars in the Palisades and Eaton fires: Removing the debris.

Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday issued an executive order to fast-track the debris removal from the scarred areas. The two fires have consumed nearly 40,000 acres and destroyed or damaged 12,000 structures.

Once bustling streets have been reduced to piles of blackened debris for blocks, prompting concern  about hazardous materials and other debris from the burned properties, and the impact if winter storms bring rainfall to the areas.

‚ÄúRemoving the debris generated by these devastating fires, with thousands of destroyed or damaged structures located in disparate parts of Los Angeles County, presents a monumental challenge,‚Äù Newsom‚Äôs executive order said.

If not dealt with quickly, according to the governor, it could result in damaging debris flows, mudslides and flash floods that could harm surrounding communities.

Read more at the link in our bio.

‚ÄúSelf Reflection‚Äù

Eaton Fire - January 2025
Altadena, CA

Half of my life was growing up in this town.  I attended kindergarten, elementary, middle school, junior high and high school in Altadena.  As a kid, I rode my bike everywhere with friends and we found every shortcut, vacant lot and spot to jump our bikes. From Eaton Canyon to Oak Grove, to the eateries of Washington Blvd and scenic views of Echo Mountain.  There wasn‚Äôt a place we didn‚Äôt explore.  Over the years, my friends would get married in the various churches around town and host receptions in the backyards of family.  Later buying homes and starting families of their own.  Many remained local, continuing the Dena legacy, while others moved on.  I, for one, followed my career down south but remain somewhat attached to the city.  My parents still reside and were recently evacuated, their house still remains (at last check), but we grieve for those who‚Äôve lost everything.  The photos I‚Äôve shared over the past week were not to chase likes or followers, but simply to share the current landscape with those both familiar and unfamiliar - guess it‚Äôs also my coping mechanism, my outlet.  I plan to return again soon, with camera, to document the rebuilding of this unique town and the resilience of its people.  For those who‚Äôve made it this far, thanks for listening. ‚úåÔ∏è
