L.A. restaurants are stepping up to offer free meals to fire evacuees and the brave first responders working tirelessly to protect our communities.

Firefighters are in the critical stage of their week-long battle against deadly wildfires across Los Angeles. While crews are making progress, officials warn the fire threat will remain very high with dangerous winds expected to return. Tragically, at least 24 lives have been lost, and dozens more are still missing. The true extent of the devastation is yet to be seen.

With the Eaton and Palisades Fires among California‚Äôs most destructive in history, it‚Äôs a reminder of the growing impact of climate change on our state. We can‚Äôt fight the flames, but we can come together to support those who are suffering and the heroes on the front lines.

Here‚Äôs a list of L.A. restaurants offering free meals‚Äîbecause even a small act of kindness can bring comfort during this difficult time.

Know other establishments offering help? Drop it in the comments to spread the word! üëáüèª

Stay safe, and keep each other close.

I‚Äôve been shooting the wildfires in Los Angeles for 20+ years but nothing could have prepared for the destruction I witnessed this last week. I am at a loss for words. What I can say is that Angelenos rise up in times of crisis and show how strong this city truly is. Thank you to our first responders on the front lines who risked their lives and fought tireless against all odds to keep the fires at bay- including all of the outside agencies who sent fire support from different cities, counties, states, and countries. Thank you to all of the volunteers and donors who‚Äôve put their lives on hold to help aid our friends in need during their darkest hour. You are all true heroes and the city will be forever grateful for your efforts. 

As the world changes, the threat of fast spreading fires becomes greater and we need to ensure our firefighters have the equipment they need to protect us. Wildfires are not our only concern. Fires in urban developments are inevitable and we‚Äôve all just witnessed the destruction they can cause. Please donate anything you can to help support the LAFD. They need our help so they can protect us when we need their help. If you are in a position to give more, please also consider making a donation to the California Fire Foundation. 

Lastly, if anyone still has animals left behind please dm me and I will do everything in my power to try get your babies to safety ü§ç 

@losangelesfiredepartment @calfire #losangeles #palisadesfire #eatonfire #lafd #calfire #wildfire

I know that we will rebuild. I know that the forest will regrow. I know that after the fire, a balance of flora and fauna will be restored. I know that once the smoke settles, wildlife vitality will improve because plants once overshadowed by looming trees will have a chance to thrive.  Regeneration will come after the grief. But for now, I am still grieving. First and foremost, my heart is with those who have lost family members in these fires. I am heartbroken for the countless people who have lost their homes in this disaster. So many people lost everything they own and their lives will never be the same. My heart also breaks for those whose home is the Angeles National Forest. I know many of us find our peace and our solice in these canyons and on these peaks. Surviving in Los Angeles requires a particular level of strength and practicing a certain level of self-care. I know that for many of us, a drive up the 2 or an escape to a waterfall is what we use to ground us and to grow us. I'm probably not the only one who feels more at home in these mountains than they do in their own apartment. At this time, I also think about the animals that live here who have done nothing to contribute to climate change but continue to be endangered and displaced. I know that we will regrow & rebuild, but I also know that things will never be or look the same. Pulling out 20 great memories from the vault, pictures taken on land that has already burned in the #palisadesfire and the #eatonfire, the 1st and 2nd most destructive fires in California State history. We are currently on Day 6 of these fires and neither fire is even 50% contained. We have to do better. I know we will rebuild. But I also hope that we will take on an increased responsibility in land management. üíîüíöüíô

The day the Eaton Fire ignited we had woken up to our thick wooden gate having been torn from its hinges by the wind. Debris was every where and it had pulled fruit trees from the ground. 

At 4pm we lost power and around 6pm we decided to head to dinner at Pie n Burger. The winds pushed our car as we drove and rattled the windows of the restaurant once we got there. It continued to blow and with enough force to rip the door open. 

At the end of our meal my grandma called us to say that Eaton Canyon was on fire and in the same time it took to google it it came up on the news in the diner. We were 4 miles away from home and our dog Fernando and 2 cats Beans and Paloma were inside. 

We raced back up the hill straight into the fire. Cars were streaming back down the hill and at one point I thought they might not let us through to save them. 

We could see the fire right over the tree line the bright orange drawing towards us with every minute. We grabbed the animals and packed the cars as fast as possible. I drove alone in the darkness with fire at my back, two screaming cats, and hurricane force winds pushing my small car and sending branches flying.

We evacuated to my grandpas house in el serno and watched all night long as our neighborhood burned. At 6am a neighbor called and asked for our help we were ‚Äútwo blocks from annihilation‚Äù so my dad and I decided to go back to defend the house. 

When we got to the house we could see the flames coming from the front yard. We immediately go to work clearing the brush, pulling explosive materials away from the house, and wetting it down. I cut down anything that might be touching the house. We worked hard to prep the yard if the worst case scenario was to unfold. 

At 2pm we were finally able to walk up and see the actual damage the fires had caused to our neighborhood. Our house and our block survived because a small group of neighbors stayed behind to defend our houses. They used buckets of water and small fire extinguishers to keep the fire back.

The last side is where one neighbor alone fought a fire that had engulfed the gate and bushes of a house one block up. He saved Pasadena. #altadena #lafires #eatonfire

There are just not words for tragedy unfolding in Los Angeles.  Tonight I want to highlight Altadena, a city that is very much in my heart.  Before moving out of LA 2 years ago we called the Pasadena area home. Back in 2018, we came very close to moving to Altadena.  We were drawn to the stunning historic homes, the diverse community, the bohemian vibe, and the wonderful neighborhoods. Last night my husband and I were looking at the area of devastation and we realized that every one of the homes we looked at were gone.  Including the one in this photo that we came closest to making an offer on and think about often.  It was built in 1915. 

I can‚Äôt begin to express the sorrow for the families affected by this fire.  Most homeowners in Altadena include young families that have invested everything they have, elderly families who raised their children in their homes where they have lived for 50+ years, and a thriving black community that has been there for generations and truly made Altadena what it is today. 

In this post, I‚Äôve highlighted some of these families that have lost everything. They are all families that I know personally, or are friends of friends.  There are so many people who have been impacted by this tragedy, but tonight I wanted to share some personal connections. 

Go to the link in my profile to give to the @gofundme pages of not only the families highlighted here, but also some I know that were impacted by the Palisades fire. 

Thank you to @keelerliz @mary_terterov @eonvaulter @lilliankang1 @iamgiselelima @itisnttoolate @octaviaklein_ for helping me to highlight these wonderful families.

I thought I'd write a piece about Mastering Calm in the Midst of Chaos. ( Linkindeets). After all, we've been struggling nonstop for a week with the #Palisadesfire & #eatonfire. This hellstorm has taken us all to a place of fear for our displaced brothers and sisters, fear for our own safety & and an over all fear consciousness across our beloved city of angels. It's a simple article, bkuz we need simple right now. Go easy on yourselves. This is a lot...We're grieving as a city, so give yourself little gifts of reprieve and replenishment. The smallest moments can sustain you and help you handle this disaster in an elevated way. You can do it. Take a nice deep breath. You're going to be okay. There ya go....xoxoLori

Altadena, CA - Eaton Fire

Day 1 of 3

It‚Äôs been 6 days since the #eatonfire has erupted. Since lives have completely changed. You never think something like this will happen to a community you love. A community where your sister and her family lives. A community where I started a family of four. A community you spend almost everyday in.

These next 3 series of posts is my letter. A form of expression through art. Through storytelling. To my old neighbors. My friends. To those who lost their homes. To the ones still in tact with battle scares. To the businesses I love and lost. To the ones I love still standing. To Harriet St. Janes Village. To Altadena from east to west. It‚Äôs all beautiful in its own way.

This post is a timeline. Pretty much in chronological order from my experience. It starts out with the conversation I had with my sister when I found out there was a fire in Altadena shortly after 6pm.

The perfect storm was brewing and nobody knew to the extent of what was about to unfold.

I love my city. Quick trip home to check in on my grandmother, Sadie. Thank you to so many of you who have inquired and extended concern regarding her safety. She‚Äôs fine. Sitting on her porch. Even Still, I could see the smoke from the Eaton (Altadena) fire as we were descending into LAX. What isn‚Äôt being discussed amongst the hideous things being thrown around in our political sphere is that many African-American families in Altadena are losing the opportunity to pass down generational wealth in the loss of these homes. My own grandparents chose between Altadena and Watts in the purchase of their first and only home together in 1950. They chose Watts. But the whom they would have chosen, right off Fair Oaks, would likely not be standing today. Please pray and assist where you can. #EatonFire #LAFires

My latest episode is about how the Los Angeles Fires have affected important literary sites. (The link is in my profile.)

Luckily, @nasajpl is safe, thanks to the heroic efforts of firefighters as well as some natural advantages of the site in the Arroyo Seco. But as you can see in the map image here, the Eaton Fire crept right up to JPL's doors. The boundary is represented by the red dotted line.

The space program, and especially JPL, has had a massive influence on storytellers. Science fiction would not be what it is without this facility, and as a kid I always was thrilled by any opportunity to visit. (They do very cool events for kids and schools.) Getting to party with literal rocket scientists who knew how to build space robots is exactly as amazing as you think.

The most recent work of fiction to hit it big which features JPL was The Martian by Andy Weir. This book was completely accurate in its description of the creativity, dedication, and hard work that JPLers put into everything they do. And while their lab is safe, unfortunately more than 150 of them have lost their homes and quite a lot more have been evacuated with no idea of when they'll be able to go home or what will remain there. There's a fundraiser for them, so if you are a fan of the many, many stories inspired by JPL, please consider donating.

The devastation in my hometown is Biblical. We have been housing families that lost everything in the Eaton Fire. So many of my projects were destroyed and burned down in the #PalisadesFire and #EatonFire.  So much energy spent paying attention to architectural details and Tracking purchases now gone. 
The real lesson this disaster has taught me is that stuff is temporary that we only rent  while here on Earth. 
A very wise man said to me when I was going through a difficult time and felt overwhelmed trying to solve my problem. He said ‚ÄòNothing is a true problem if it can be solved with money‚ÄùI have taken this philosophy to heart and put it to use daily. 
We wil rebuild ,estimated cost of half a trillion dollars, and money can solve this. What was also destroyed was the entire lifestyle of my fellow Angelenos.  they won‚Äôt be able to wave hello to their neighbors of 40+ years as they pull out of their driveway. They won‚Äôt be able to meet friends at their ‚Äòplace‚Äô because it burned to the ground. No chance to visit their Alma Mater or say goodbye to the dry cleaning lady. These are problems that can‚Äôt be solved with money. These relationships , 
which are the heart blood of daily life, will take years to rebuild and with an entirely new cast of characters. 

The pulse of the city died and that is difficult to restart or count in numbers instead It is counted in years lived not dollars spent. 
This has reminded me to treasure all of the people around me and be thankful no more lives were lost.  I‚Äôm so grateful to be safe in my  home with my Family around me 
But our lifestyle will change forever.

Link is in bio üôè ‚ÄúSadly, my sister and brother-in-law, Aimee and Damon Stout, lost their home in Altadena, California to the Eaton Canyon fires. Their home was a total loss. Damon is self-employed and lost his entire studio with over 30 years of equipment and past work. They have a long road ahead of them navigating insurance, hopefully being able to rebuild their home, and getting back to some normalcy after losing so much. Our hearts go out to everyone affected by the wildfires devastating Los Angeles. üôèüèª Thousands of homes, businesses, and beloved parks have been destroyed, displacing countless families and leaving communities in need of urgent support.

The American Red Cross is on the ground, providing shelter to wildfire victims and their domestic pets, along with food, water, health services, and emotional support. With clients, team members, and loved ones in the area, we are committed to amplifying these efforts to help those impacted.

Please consider donating to the @americanredcross to support these vital relief efforts. Together, we can help rebuild lives and bring comfort to those in need. ‚ù§Ô∏è Tap the link in our bio or check our stories to donate‚Äîevery contribution makes a difference!

If you poke around the motorcycling corner of the Internet, you're undoubtedly familiar with one of our friendly competitors, Motorcycle.com. While you're on the site, I'm sure you see the name Troy Siahaan.

We are sad to relay that Troy and his beautiful family lost their Altadena home in the Eaton Fire--total loss. While you are likely a fan of Troy's work, he is also truly one of the nicest, friendliest guys that you will ever want to meet.

There's a GFM effort to help The Siahaan Family out, if you're so inclined. We know Troy will undoubted appreciate any help he can get. Losing your house is just awful.

Let‚Äôs have big feelings + help our anxiety. 

Let‚Äôs let both things be true at the same time.

1. My heart is broken from the fires
+
2. I am not physically impacted by the fires at all.

What do we do?

Don‚Äôt feel guilty for being human and having empathy.

Take aligned action that feels doable for you and is the right fit. 

There is no one right way to help. It can feel overwhelming seeing big donations online or people taking huge action and make you feel paralyzed. 

Something I do anytime I hear of something that breaks my heart, an acquaintance having a tragedy or a natural disaster happening, I give a little money to something that I feel aligned with. Even if it is just $10 to someone I don‚Äôt know it helps my heart feel a little less helpless and a little less broken. 

Feel your feels. üíõ

Love to LA + the greater area.

While I am currently in Hamburg visiting family, my home in Altadena, CA burned to the ground, along with everything I owned. The entire block has been wiped out, and most of Altadena has suffered immense damage.
Although I had insurance, the road to recovery is long, and there are immediate expenses I need help with. My car, which was parked in the garage, is also a total loss.
I find it very difficult to ask strangers for help. Nevertheless, you support would be most welcome in this situation for me and others with whom I will share possible donations. 
Thank you for your kindness, this means the world right now. 
Anna & Fritzi

Acting Fire Capt. Ryan Grothe at McClellan-Palomar Airport has spent his career responding to emergencies, but his recent journey to document the Palisades Fire in Los Angeles left him awestruck by the sheer scale of destruction.

Grothe, a part-time freelance photographer, traveled north before sunrise on Jan. 9, navigating roadblocks and treacherous conditions to capture the wreckage from wildfires still rampaging across Los Angeles County.

"It looked like a bomb went off," Grothe said. "Power lines snapped in half, street lights knocked over, burned out cars ‚Äî (the fire) destroyed everything in its path in Pacific Palisades."

Story link in bio. Photos by Ryan Grothe (@palomar_airportfire_photo)

Fire House 36: This was the first station to respond to the Eaton Fire. They fought the blaze for the first 48 hours straight without sleeping before finally getting relieved Thursday when reinforcements arrived.

Here‚Äôs what I learned after visiting a couple of fire stations in Pasadena yesterday: They don‚Äôt actually need anything. At this point, they‚Äôre fully supplied. Unless you want to do what we did and bring them a couple dozen donuts as a ‚Äòthank you‚Äô, or some cases of Waterloo sparkling water, which they told us they refer to as ‚ÄúStation Beer‚Äù. (Awesome)

A few minutes after we arrived they got called back out, not to the Eaton Fire, but to an unrelated emergency. ( It‚Äôs well to remember that those are also still happening in the midst of all this.) Just as we were about to drive away, they walked out and said the call was canceled, and asked if we‚Äôd like a tour of the station. We went back inside and I snapped a few photos as we talked with them and they showed us around.

These are some of the nicest, bravest, most humble men you could ever meet. Holloway there, in the 4th photo, has been at this station for 45 years and has some crazy stories.

More on Station 36 soon. I jokingly asked if they had a suit tiny enough to fit me so that I could tag along, and they actually invited me to ride along with them this weekend and bring my camera. So, obviously, I‚Äôm doing that. 

Til then, there‚Äôs a new evacuation relief center that just opened at 930 Mateo St downtown. If you‚Äôre in DTLA and looking for a way to help, they need volunteers. I plan to be there throughout the week.

Having now seen the enormity of the Santa Anita Racetrack operation last night, I suggest dropping any large donations off there. 

Stay tuned. I‚Äôll do my best to share updates and advice on these operations and what they need as I find them. Helps everyone wrap their head around how best to help and where to go. 

#losangeles #eatonfire #pasadena #altadena #la #firefighters #firstresponders

Starting at 4 a.m. Tuesday and lasting until noon Wednesday, residents are urged to prepare for extreme fire conditions due to wind gusts reaching up to 70 mph and dangerously dry air.

- **Eaton Fire:** 33% contained, having burned 14,117 acres and damaged around 7,000 structures.
- **Palisades Fire:** 17% contained, with 23,713 acres scorched and significant damage to homes and businesses.

üè† **Evacuations in Effect:** Many neighborhoods including Malibu, Altadena, and Pasadena are under evacuation orders. Over 12,000 structures remain at risk, with more than 5,300 already impacted.

Firstly want to say I am safe. My family is safe. My sister and her family, my Mom and Dad, all safe. 

The outpouring of support and affirmation from friends distant and near - even here on IG! - has been felt and has been so dear. Voices from the past that I have not heard from in years. Voices of those I had no idea had an Altadena connection and yet, like me, have experienced this calamity in a personal way. 

Thank you. From my heart, thank you üôèüèº

There is much to tell and I find I can say next to nothing. Yesterday was the first day in over three weeks I had to myself and I'd set aside time to journal about the calamity that has befallen Altadena - the place of my rearing and my parents' place of residence for nearly forty years up until last Wed. I managed exactly two sentences. I sat in my own quiet home, weeping, before putting on my big boy pants (and lots of PPE) to get outside and clear the debris from last week. Highland Park is under a blanket of leaves and bracken, dust and toxic ash from days worth of smoke blowing straight off the mountain and into our face. 

This is a photo I didn't think much of when I took it two years ago. In an instant it is imbued with meaning and aching longing for all that's been lost.

It's a bridge in Eaton Canyon I've crossed over dozens of times in my life. We used to ride our bikes to this spot from my parents' house. Someone posted a video of it, and the railing is completely burned away to say nothing of the vegetation.

No amount of philosophizing or sermonizing can make this alright or diminish the aching in my heart or that of my fellow Angelenos in this time. I just want to say - take the pic. Don't just drive past that spot again. Pull over. Fix your lens on your house, your kids, your mom. Give them a hug and a kiss after you click.

Pt. 2 - After we got all the 400 meals + 200 PB Sandwiches prepped & packaged on Saturday, We went to make several deliveries on Sunday. And THANK YOU to everyone that volunteered their time to come help pack, & also assist with the deliveries!!‚ù§Ô∏èüôå

The first set for lunch on Sunday, Thankfully through @u_getz contact, was taken to the Fire Dept Headquarters for all the different departments that were located in there, for everyone that‚Äôs behind the scenes along with front liners that go in and out. They are working LONG hours and are often forgotten, so for us to deliver them their meals, meant the WORLD to them.
The constant Gratitude they had, the continuous thanks they kept giving us.. Us?! No, WE should be thanking YOU. 
(We were all so excited and grateful ourselves I forgot to ask for a picture with those beautiful faces for the memories)

Then from there, and thankfully through my friend who is a Sergeant with the Sheriffs Dept, we were able to deliver to the Emergency Operations Bureau to his old partner who is now the lead Sergeant of the whole Department, where the heads of every single Department / Agency you could think of that‚Äôs involved were working out of.. They delegate absolutely EVERYTHING for anything that is needed, any time, any place, whatever it may be, from A-Z. Without them, the brain, either none of this would happen/be possible, or it would all be utter chaos. Often forgotten, but also doing the absolute most and working through exhaustion, full days even up to 24 Hrs. 
The lead Sergeant brought us in the command room, to deliver the meals where they all were, & he took a moment to stop everyone in the middle of their work, to let everyone know that we were delivering food for them..
They too, were Grateful beyond words.. Constant thanks and smiles, and stunned faces.. But in reality, who are We..? YOU guys are the ones doing all this incredible work, We thank Each & Every One of You. 

As they had sensitive information up on the screens, I got to have a few of these amazing people come in the other room to snap a photo (with the Lead Sgt behind the camera taking the pic)

Stay tuned‚Ä¶another post ‚ÄòPt.3‚Äô for the 2nd part of our day..

I‚Äôm still at a loss for words. While my heart absolutely breaks for all the people who have lost everything, it breaks even more for all the animals displaced, abandoned, and with nowhere to go. Many evacuation orders happened during the day while people were at work and their pets were left behind as they weren‚Äôt allowed back into their neighborhoods. Wildlife narrowly escaped the forests that became engulfed in flames. Large animals like the horses pictured above had few options for transport to safety. The one silver lining is all of the organizations and people that have banded together to save as many animals as possible. It‚Äôs amazing how tragedy can bring people together despite everything.

HATS + TOTE BAGS 4 ALTADENA FIRE AID, 100% OF PROFITS DONATED!!!

All profit from the sales of these hats and totes will be going directly to help people from Altadena recover and rebuild from the fire. We‚Äôve been focusing our efforts on hand delivering supplies directly to our displaced neighbours, taking on community requests, and supporting people financially. 

Full transparency we are getting these hats and totes printed to order in the USA! Since we have been displaced we do not have a permanent space which we can ship larger things from so we are getting them printed to order and shipped to you.

Here is the pricing breakdown per hat and tote to show cost and how much will be donated:

HATS: Item cost $14.59 + shipping $4.39 = $18.98 cost to produce. $30 - $18.98 = $11.02 profit to be donated

TOTE BAGS: Item cost $14.15 + shipping $4.39 = $18.54 cost to produce. $25 - $18.54 = $6.46 profit to be donated

Any shares and reposts to help get the word out are always very appreciated ‚ù§Ô∏è

An Altadena History Thread by historian, archivist, and erudite @cilangee. She is a 3rd generation Altadena native who‚Äôs family has been impacted by the #eatonfire swipe to the end to support ‚ù§Ô∏è

The Atladena community was one of the last predominantly Black neighborhoods in Los Angeles County where many Black Americans retreated during the Great Migration. This small town has been fighting off erasure and gentrification, hence why it‚Äôs important we help them REBUILD. 

This is Black American history we are responsible for preserving and protecting by any means.

üî• PLEASE SHARE TO HELP OUR EFFORTS IN LA üî•

Tune into our live sale today, Tuesday 1/14 and Friday 1/17 here on Instagram at 3PM PST where we will be sharing new pieces and some restocks y‚Äôall have been begging us to make! 

We know people want to help those who have lost so much already here in LA. We want to be transparent with our efforts and where we are donating and causes we are actively supporting. There have been massive amounts of clothing being donated to various sites across LA. Many have stopped taking clothing or have very specific items they are looking for as it‚Äôs become overwhelming sorting what is good vs. people‚Äôs trash. We‚Äôve been in communication with several underwear brands who are excited to participate in our ‚ÄúPanty Party‚Äù where we will distribute underwear and bras to various sites across LA for this impacted by these fires in an array of sizes. We are also hoping to purchase at least 10 industrial grade rolling z-racks this week (the goal is ALL 30) to provide to @shopquirkla to aid with their free store providing clothing and necessities! 

When their infrastructure is more in place with z-racks, hangers and displays; we will rally our community to let them know exactly what is needed to serve our city with specific donations.

We know people want to help by donating their used clothing but, what is needed most at many of these sites is INFRASTRUCTURE to sort and display. On Sunday, multiple garment racks broke under the weight of the clothing! IT‚ÄôS SO DEFEATING trying to do this work and help others when the racks snap and have to be trashed! 

If you have any of the infrastructure items needed or want to purchase them, we‚Äôve included the wishlist for @shopquirkla and are happy to run things over to them if it is easier to bring to byVINNIK! They are doing the GOOD WORK and we are so happy we can all help our friends, family, neighbors and strangers who are part of the vibrant LA community üî•

Friends, family, everyone. Thank you for stopping to read this. As some may know, my 21st birthday is nearing. I wanted to go back to my hometown and celebrate the city that I feel so much love and connection to for my birthday. It‚Äôs devisating to know that I will be visiting during a time of such tragedy and heartbreak due to the fires that have broken out in the cities neighboring the town where I spent some of the best years of my life. 

For my birthday, I beg of you to not send me any presents. The greatest gift you all could give me would be to donate to the California Fire Foundation to help support the brave men and women risking their lives on the front lines, and for the recovery for the thousands of victims that have lost their homes and their families to these horrific fires. 

To all my friends in the city of angels, it was named that for a reason. The strength of that city will not let you down. I send my heart, blessings, and as much donation as I can to the victims of these fires. Thank you all ‚ù§Ô∏è

Altadena is a special place, -- which provided plenty of opportunities for meaningful connection and collaboration -- it also always gave us opportunities to be in reverence and enjoy a sense of peace. Some of my favorite moments for small joys and peace were taking in our 'Altadena' sunsets each night - the photo below is from my backyard which captures the first sunset of 2025 -- my house, like many of yours is gone.
I also loved walking around Altadena to enjoy the beauty of my neighbors' homes and landscaping - the photo below captures a buddha I discovered bathed in sunlight on Sunny Oaks Circle. I don't know if the buddha on sunny oaks circle is still there but I will think about and cherish all the memories of our homes, -- with their unique and splendid personalities.¬†
Please share the community memories you have of Altadena -- places, moments, and people that have brought you peace, joy, and connection.
‚Äî-- 1st image - First Sunset of 2025
‚Äî-- 2nd image - Buddha statue on Sunny Oaks Circle taken 1/1/25

Not only does @brent_rademaker put a lot of love into his music and the records he releases, but he is also putting a lot of love into the Los Angeles community right now to help deal with the impact these horrible fires have had on so many.

@curation_records is doing a 100% match on all purchases and donating the money to charities to help people in this heartbreaking and stressful time.

So there is no better time to throw some money their way. Picking up some great tunes and helping some people out at the same time sounds like a win-win to me.

If you are looking for recommendations, I highly recommend GospelBeach‚Äôs ‚ÄúWiggle Your Fingers‚Äù, The Beachwood Sparks ‚ÄúAcross The River of Stars‚Äù ,‚Äù Stewart Forgey‚Äôs ‚ÄúNature of the Universe‚Äú, The Evening Sons ‚ÄúTracks,or Luther Russell‚Äôs new record ‚ÄúHappiness For Beginners,‚Äú but honestly you could close your eyes and point and land on a killer record from this label.

I just picked up @silver.synthetic new Album, CD, and t-shirt bundle. The first single, ‚ÄúYr Gonna Be Happy,‚Äù sounds like a more jangly, cosmic power pop version of Loaded era Velvet Underground and 80‚Äôs Dead! I‚Äôm all in!

We all know that the powers that be don‚Äôt care all that much about us, so in the end, all we have in times like these is each other, so if you can help in some way, do it. Even doing a little can turn into a big thing and make a difference.

Spread the word, spread the money and spread the love.

THANK YOU to everyone who has stepped up during this crisis. Los Angeles has faced incredible challenges, and the outpouring of support has been truly inspiring.

Volunteers have provided food, shelter, and emotional support to evacuees. Firefighters from Northern California, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Utah, Colorado, Idaho, New Mexico, Canada, and Mexico have joined forces, sending crews and resources to protect our communities. Their bravery and dedication remind us of the power of unity and compassion.

The therapist community has also been incredible, with many colleagues offering free crisis sessions, support groups, and resources to those in need. I‚Äôm so grateful to be surrounded by such a generous and caring network.

Horse owners and animal lovers have come together to evacuate animals, ensuring their safety when it matters most. Rescue teams, volunteers, and neighbors have shown courage and compassion every step of the way.

This city‚Äôs strength lies in its people‚Äîand in those who come from afar to help. Together, we prove that kindness and unity will always prevail.

If you need therapeutic support during this time, I‚Äôm happy to help or connect you with resources. Please don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out.

THANK YOU again to everyone making a difference. Los Angeles always rises because of people like you.

From the rubble, new life springs. 

One of my favourite places in Altadena also seems particularly prescient right now. 

At the top of Echo Mountain, via the Sam Merrill trail, sit the ruins of the hotel and mountain railroad, part of a Victorian resort named White City, built by Thaddeus Lowe in 1893 above Altadena.

From its grand opening through to its eventual abandonment in 1936, fire and wind ravaged the resort several times, but they continued to rebuild. 

Today, standing up there among the ruins feels simultaneously inspiring and cautionary. It would be understatement to say I can't wait to get back up there again soon.

My beautiful city of Los Angeles, the city of dreams, endless opportunities, and hope‚Äîthe city where I was born and raised‚Äîis burning in flames.¬†üíî While I am grateful to be safe in Glendale, my heart aches for the countless victims who have lost everything. Once upon Rainbowüåà over Los Angeles 
.
.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
A Rainbow Above the Flames

Amidst the hills where fires roar,
And ash falls soft on the city floor,
Los Angeles stands, fierce and true,
Hope gleaming bright in skies of blue.

The winds may howl, the embers fly,
But courage rises, reaching the sky.
Firefighters brave, with hearts of steel,
Battling the blaze, their wounds to heal.

Above the chaos, a rainbow appears,
A bridge of hope through smoke and tears.
The air-tankers soar, a dance in the air,
Graceful and bold, with strength so rare.

Pilots weaving through the fiery haze,
Defying odds, their spirits ablaze.
With every drop, the flames they tame,
Heroes unknown, yet earned their name.

Through the trials, the city stands tall,
A testament to the courage of all.
The fires may scorch, but life renews,
Los Angeles, bathed in radiant hues.

So look to the rainbow, let hope take flight,
Through darkest days, there comes the light.
Together we rise, together we strive,
In the heart of the flames, we keep dreams alive.-VFP

My heart is with you, LA. The fires are still burning at 17% containment (Palisades) and 35% containment (Eaton). So many have lost all possessions. First responders continue to battle. The people of Los Angeles and all of Southern California have truly shown up for their neighbors. But, there is still work to do and there will be for years to come.
‚Ä¢
When the Tubbs fire took entire neighborhoods in my hometown of Santa Rosa, CA - the shock and pain was immense. The effects are still very much felt and seen in those neighborhoods 7 years later. Witnessing that fire through the eyes of my Dad, a fire captain, was so scary. Witnessing it through the eyes of many friends who lost everything, was heartbreaking.
‚Ä¢
So, let‚Äôs continue to show up and help our neighbors in any way we can. They need us now more than ever.
‚Ä¢

This is the last photo I took of our dogs in my bedroom and Altadena two days before the house was burned down. The dogs are all safe, thankfully and people are generously helping. We have a lot of rebuilding to do and we will get our dogs back into a home soon. If there‚Äôs any support you can offer the residence Altadena that would be incredible. I have included in my GoFundMe, which will go towards a future home for me and Rose. Absolutely no pressure. I just thought I would share.  https://gofund.me/b0c00949  #eatonfire #altadena #dogsofinstagram

Some other things I‚Äôve learned:

We do not yet know the cause of these fires. Investigations are ongoing. 

The City of Los Angeles is one of 88 cities in Los Angeles County. These cities each have their own mayor. Karen Bass is the mayor only for Los Angeles and is not responsible for what is happening in the other 87 cities. 

Firefighters have knocked down at least 10 other smaller fires since beginning the battle against the two biggest fires (Palisades and Eaton). 

The fires have burned over 45 square miles, which is double the size of my college town, Ruston, LA. 

Firefighters did not run out of water. The fire hydrants (and their tanks) are made to fight fires from a few houses, not hundreds. The tanks could not be refilled quickly enough. 

The reservoirs in L.A. County are full (except one which had been drained for repairs since this is typically a wetter time of year).

These fires could not be fought from the air for days because of the constant high winds. We are still experiencing winds a week later. 

Please guard yourself against misinformation. And don‚Äôt judge things you know nothing about. We can‚Äôt all be experts in everything.

As we begin the new semester, we understand that the wildfires have created significant challenges for many in our community. We want to assure you that support is available. If you or your child need assistance navigating the challenges of this situation, please contact our Student Support team at studentsupport@ileadcalifornia.org.

We also want to remind you of the additional resources available to those impacted by the fires. Visit ileadschools.org/emergency-resources (link in bio) for information including shelters, food assistance, medical care, utilities, mental health support, financial assistance, and more.

We understand that the impact of these wildfires will be felt for some time to come. Please know that we are committed to providing ongoing support to our community as we navigate the road to recovery.

caption:
This cutie is Roscoe. He and his family lost their home in the Palisades fire this past week. While that has been very hard for him and his family, he is deeply concerned for his furry friends who have not yet been reunited with their families in the Palisades and Eaton areas. He wants to share the support he has received, and we at Metro Sessions are here to help him

Tonight at #TurntableTuesday we are helping Roscoe raise $1,000 for the @pasadenahumane and @bfas_la emergency fund! ‚¨ÜÔ∏è donate at the link in our bio & you can sign up EARLY for #openturntables and #karaoke üé§ any amount is helpful! 

@theoffbeatbar is also hosting a 1-week pet item donation area from Tuesday, January 14th - Tuesday January 21st. Donated items will be taken to the @spcala. Items that are needed include: 

Blankets (NEW or gently used & recently washed)
Canned kitten & dog food
Dry adult dog food
Kuranda beds

Come see us! #losangeles #highlandpark #hlp #ladjs #fundraiser #benefit #lawildfires #lafires #palisadesfire #eatonfire #petrelief

BOOTS ON THE GROUND
-been a rollercoaster week round these parts. from what was a a joyous trip to Tahoe with some buds ending in our eyes glued to the television as the Palisades fire began with our families back home, then seeing and hearing of friends lives go up in flames, to a precautionary evacuation ourselves from the Kenneth fire, followed by a round trip to San Jose in rememberance of the life of my wife‚Äôs 101 year old grandmother. We‚Äôve not had time to think about anything much but rather, simply react. 

-we are back now, boots on the ground here in LA and still trying to process everything and figure out a way we can help. 

-first, will be transitioning our one for one everyone campaign funds from 2025 to benefit those personally affected. So know 5% of every purchase will be used to this effort. I‚Äôll personally match the 5% as well. 

-second, we‚Äôd love to be some boots on the ground in our local West Valley/Topanga area to help anyone who may need some support. 

-third, I‚Äôm still thinking. 

Sending love and our condolences to everyone out here in the Los Angeles area who has suffered from these horrendous fires. Please let us know how we can help. 

And an incredible thank you to all those firefighters, first responders, air attack pilots and every soul who has showed up to help fight these flames. Yall are heroes! 

Yours truly.
The Arbour Family
Stock Tank Supply & Co. 
‚Ä¶.

I had a really great conversation with a regular last night, where he said: ‚ÄúWho do you want to be? Do you want to sit and watch or do you want to be someone that does something?‚Äù

In something that feels like it would come out of a movie script, people have virtually lost everything that mattered or made sense to them. Seeing how so many are dropping everything to help others is what being a part of society should mean ‚Äî the selflessness of ‚ÄúI got you‚Äù when you‚Äôre not really sure what else to do. 

If you‚Äôre local, swing by and make a donation to help rebuild the lives of these people and aid the first responders that have been helping since the fires broke out. These boxes will be up throughout the week, depending on how they fill up, we‚Äôll make trips to donation centers. ü´∂

Check @mutualaidla for updates on supplies needed/volunteer opportunities available. 

Swipe to the end for some light-hearted Artemis & friends video. üê∂üíó

Watching this video and seeing that all that is standing is the 3080 sign was devastating. My dad spent the last 10 years restoring the interior of the house while dealing with serious health issues. this past Christmas 2024, for the first time in over 12 years we spent it together at home. First time my son ever seen the first house we bought after moving from Pasadena in 98. I was so happy seeing what my dad had done to the house. Two weeks later everything is gone. Words can‚Äôt even express the love and support from those watching and those within our community.  Link in bio  #altadena #eatonfire #pasadena #denalove

The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health has issued a Windblown Dust and Ash Advisory in response to strong Santa Ana winds expected to affect the region through¬†Wednesday, January 15, 2025, at 7:00 PM. According to the South Coast Air Quality Management District (South Coast AQMD), the gusty winds may disperse ash from recent wildfire burn scars and generate dust, potentially impacting air quality across Los Angeles County.

It‚Äôs been a heavy week here in LA. We‚Äôve had our fair share of wildfires, but the loss and devastation this time around is unfathomable. 

It‚Äôs been humbling to receive so many ‚Äúare you okay?‚Äù text messages from so many of you, and terrifying to send out my own round of messages to the people we love. Even worse hearing news of what people in our community have lost. We get pretty desensitized to natural disasters in the news, but when it happens in your backyard it hits different. Makes me want to respond with more care, action, and compassion when it happens elsewhere. 

I love this city so much. I‚Äôve spent most of my adult life and most of my career here photographing its beauty. It is gut-wrenching to watch it burn. 

What has been deeply encouraging to me is watching our community rally together to care for each other. My prayer is that we don‚Äôt lose steam and that we keep our arms reached out to the ones who need us right now and for the long road ahead. 

Here are just a few ways you can reach your arms out: 

Master list of wedding industry creatives who were directly impacted (direct GFMs) - https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1m1QU_3-uokeRNksHxD5c1wCbuntUZXoyFv7QlksyyT0/htmlview

@xokateevents and @rosieecheeeks are gathering $ on Venmo (KateWright-726 and rosie-spindel) and buying up supplies and gift cards and delivering them to local fire teams in different parts of the city.

Donate to @wckitchen and @redcrossla 

Vendors, if you can, send work and inquiries to the vendors who have lost their homes. They want to keep working and be part of their rebuilding efforts, too. 

#palisadesfire #eatonfire #losangeles

These are my amazing friends who‚Äôve lost their homes to the Eaton fire. My birthday fundraiser for them is still up and running and you have plenty of time to contribute. Anything helps and is so so appreciated. Link in bio.
A little bit more about them:
Morgan and Kenny are animal lovers who contribute a ton of their time and space to @angelcitypits, which is how I know them. They recently got engaged and purchased their first home last year in Altadena.
Audie is an incredibly talented curly hair stylist who has been dealing with my rat‚Äôs nest since 2008. We have developed a beautiful friendship over the years thanks to her huge heart and endless compassion.

Thank you to everyone who has donated so far, it means the world!!

Honoring LA‚Äôs Architectural Legacy: Historical Homes Lost in Fires

The recent Palisades fires in Los Angeles have claimed not only community landmarks but also pieces of the city‚Äôs rich architectural history. Iconic homes, each with a unique legacy, have shaped modern design and continue to inspire architects today.

Zane Grey Estate (1902): A Spanish-Mediterranean revival icon that influenced California‚Äôs love for terracotta roofs, stucco walls, and courtyards.

Andrew McNally House (1887): A Victorian masterpiece known for its craftsmanship, shaping Bay Area Victorian styles.
Keeler House (1990): A modern ‚Äú‚Äùtreehouse‚Äù‚Äù blending architecture with nature, showcasing innovation in harmony with the environment.

Janes Village (1924): European-style cottages fostering charm and community, emphasizing architecture‚Äôs role in lifestyle.

Gregory Ain‚Äôs Park Planned Homes (1948): Mid-century modern designs pioneering cost-efficient, functional prefabricated housing.

Bridges House: A cantilevered marvel blending bold engineering with the natural landscape.

These losses highlight the resilience of design, urging architects to integrate historical influences into modern homes, ensuring LA‚Äôs architectural legacy thrives.

#EatonFire #ArchitecturalLoss #AltadenaArchitecture #timelessdesign #historicarchitecture #historicbuildings #la

The evacuation notification woke me up at 4am on Wednesday January 8th, I walked outside to see my whole city up in smoke. My street and my house was still fine.  I got a call from a friend who wanted to go check on his two family houses in Altadena, so he picked me up and we started driving up Lincoln. It was like a scene out of a movie or something you see on social media. Flames on both sides of the street, homes, apartments, and businesses were all on fire. As we turned onto Loma Alta Dr it was 10 times worse. Everything was on fire or was next to a fire. We had to swerve out the way of power lines and trees that‚Äôve fallen down. We drove about 5 mph because u couldn‚Äôt see anything in front of you because of all the black smoke. We went to both of his family houses and they were both lost to the fire, smh. We drove around a lil longer and just couldn‚Äôt believe everything that was on fire. We even stopped at a friends house to give him a hand. I eventually told him to take me back home so I can wet my house and try to stop anything from happening to my home. I arrived to my street around 6am, surprised only one house was on fire. I began to water everything down, I mean everything! I started with the roof, then I sprayed the front of my home, then the yard & plants, and the driveway & cars. I did the same thing to the backyard as well and the sides of my home. I kept doin this until the water ran out around  7/8 o‚Äôclock. At this point I knew my chances of saving my home were very low. So I backed my lil foxbody mustang into the driveway and began to take stuff out of my home. As I was looking for stuff to grab I heard my neighbors yelling and honking for me so I ran outside. As soon as I got outside I saw my neighbors bushes on fire, it started to engulf my cars in the driveway. I only had enough time to jump in my mustang while I felt all the heat from the flames and move it down the street. As I walked back in disbelief, the whole right side of my home was in flames. I felt hopeless and it was all gone in a matter of mins‚Ä¶ If u would like to help me, my gofundme is in my bio. My last slide has other options for helping me. 
#altadena #eatonfire #fire #alta

üí° Wildfire Insurance Tips: What to Do After a Devastating Fire üí°
Navigating insurance after a wildfire can feel overwhelming, but these steps can help:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Contact Your Insurance Company Promptly üïë‚Ä®Don‚Äôt delay‚Äîget the process started ASAP.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Document the Damage üìù‚Ä®Take photos/videos of what you can. If everything is lost, it‚Äôs okay. For the future, record a video walkthrough of your home, including closets, drawers, and valuables‚Äîit‚Äôs a lifesaver for claims.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Communicate Openly with Your Adjuster üí¨‚Ä®Understand your coverage, including ALEs (Additional Living Expenses), which may cover temporary housing, meals, and storage. Check if your policy includes debris removal and rebuilding.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Keep Receipts üí≥‚Ä®Save receipts for housing, clothes, food, essentials, and mileage‚Äîthese may be reimbursable under ALE coverage.
5Ô∏è‚É£ Hire Professionals, if Needed üõ†‚Ä®Consider hiring a public adjuster or licensed pros for repair estimates, and ensure documentation is detailed.
6Ô∏è‚É£ Review Offers Carefully ü§î‚Ä®Don‚Äôt rush to accept the first settlement. Negotiate with additional documentation if needed.
7Ô∏è‚É£ Seek Professional Help for Disputes ‚öñÔ∏è‚Ä®If claims are undervalued, consult an insurance attorney or public adjuster.
‚ú® Stay prepared and proactive‚Äîit makes all the difference! Need more tips or have questions or you just need to talk we are here to help. Send me a message! üè°

Our hearts ache for those who have been affected by the LA wildfires and we feel it is our duty as life long Angelenos to do something to help our community. Not one of us at @furtownpetspa or @west_coast_grooming_academy has been left untouched by the fires, not.one.of.us. We have grown up here, we have hiked in Eaton Canyon, we have family and friends in Pasadena and Arcadia, we work and live in the areas affected by the Palisades Fire, the Sunset Fire and the Eaton Fire. We have cried with our customers who have lost everything. It affects us all. So we want to do our part and help in the best way we know how‚Ä¶ by helping your pets get back to feeling like themselves again. If your pet has been affected by the wildfires in any way, please head to our website and apply for a free groom. We will continue to offer our services for as long as our bodies and our supplies will last us. If you are a fire fighter or first responder, we got you too. üíñ Stay LA Strong üå¥ We are with you!

üåü Standing Together After the Fires üåü
In the wake of the devastating wildfires that have swept through Malibu, Palisades, Calabasas, Altadena, and beyond, our hearts are heavy with the loss experienced by so many in our community. These fires remind us of the power of nature and the importance of coming together in times of crisis.

To my neighbors, clients, and friends: whether you‚Äôve lost a home, faced evacuation, or felt the heartbreak of seeing familiar landscapes forever changed, please know you‚Äôre not alone. üñ§

In times of adversity, we‚Äôve seen how strong our communities are. Neighbors helping neighbors, strangers offering a hand, and countless acts of kindness are what define us. We are all here for one another, ready to help in any way we can. Let‚Äôs continue to come together and rise even stronger.

As a local realtor, I‚Äôve had the privilege of working in these beautiful neighborhoods, and I‚Äôm committed to helping rebuild, support, and guide anyone navigating the challenges ahead. Whether it‚Äôs connecting you with resources, discussing rebuilding options, or just lending a listening ear, we are here for you.

We are stronger together, and I truly believe that our communities will rise from this with resilience, hope, and unity. üí™

What help do you need? Please reach out if you need to talk, or if there‚Äôs anything else I can assist with. We‚Äôre all in this together.

The Deep Fried Dog Team is coming together to support those affected by the L.A fires. Every donation makes a difference! Here are organizations accepting donations and seeking volunteers:

Donation Opportunities:
	‚Ä¢	American Red Cross ‚Äì Los Angeles Region: Provides shelter, food, and emotional support to evacuees. Monetary donations are preferred to address immediate needs. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	Los Angeles Fire Department Foundation: Supports firefighters with necessary equipment and supplies. Donations can be made to their wildfire emergency fund. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	Los Angeles Regional Food Bank: Distributes food and essentials to those impacted by the fires. Accepts both monetary and food donations. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	California Fire Foundation: Provides financial assistance to families of fallen firefighters and supports communities affected by wildfires. Donations can be made to their disaster relief fund. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	World Central Kitchen: Delivers meals to evacuees and first responders in disaster areas. Monetary donations help fund their efforts. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	Pasadena Humane Society: Cares for animals displaced by the fires and seeks donations to support their efforts. Ôøº

Volunteer Opportunities:
	‚Ä¢	CaliforniaVolunteers: A state agency coordinating volunteer efforts during disasters. They can connect you with various opportunities to assist those affected by the wildfires. Ôøº
	‚Ä¢	YMCA of Metropolitan Los Angeles: Offers free childcare for children of first responders, essential workers, and families displaced by the fires. They may have volunteer opportunities available. Ôøº

Dear Los Angeles, I hold you in so much love. As we move through this incredibly heartbreaking time I recognize that basic needs are being tended to by the many volunteers who have shown up and I love how everyone is showing up for one another. 

I want to offer my support to anyone who has lost their home as well as those of you who are safe and have your home, but are still experiencing this collective trauma. 

If you have lost your home, contact me via email or DM for a free full length session. This offer does not expire. I recognize that you may not be able or ready to receive a treatment and so when and if you are, I am here for you.

For those of you who live in LA and would like a place to move out some emotions and stress and balance your nervous system, I have reserved Thursdays in January for you. With a pay what feels good pricing on 30 minute sessions so that I can support as many of you as possible. You can schedule these sessions directly through my website. 

Sending you love üíï 
We are strong, we are caring, and we are not alone! 
I have felt the presence of angels so palpable over the past week. The next time you feel overwhelmed, invite them to hold you in a healing cocoon. 

#loveforlosangeles #ilovela #lafires #palisadesfire #eatonfire #losangeles

Our morning walks will be forever changed. These homes are just a mere block north of us right on the Altadena border. Had the winds and fires raged on just 15 minutes longer in this direction‚Ä¶our own home would‚Äôve been engulfed as well. It‚Äôs an unsettling truth and reality that I, along with my remaining neighbors, are wrestling with right now. 

I don‚Äôt have much to say right now other than that I am heartbroken and devastated for all my dear friends and neighbors who have had their lives completely upended. There is no consolation for the memories lost and their sanctuaries destroyed. 

In the meantime, I want to help the best I can. I am running a print drive to build an artist and fire relief fund. 100% of all proceeds will go toward the fund. Anyone who is of need and are impacted can apply - there are no barriers to entry. If you are in the position to donate, the link is in bio. Thank you for being here and holding space for us. We are so grateful. 

#eatonfire #lafires #firerelief #altadena #pasadena

Hey NOMies, hope everyone is safe and warm and protecting your lungs. In case anyone has missed it, we've been non-stop sharing resources on Mutual Aid. It's a lot. And it can be overwhelming--I know...

We are trying to organize resources by categories in our highlights and our Link tree will have a handful of links to extensive lists that provide everything from shelter and free meals to daycare and animal boarding... There are also lists of individuals impacted and their respective GoFundMe's.

We will continue to update our lists as well as share resources through our newsletter.

With that said... It's been a crazy few weeks, but we will now be resuming pop-ups starting with @allisonsgoods on Saturday, January 18 from 12 pm - 3 pm.

815 N Harbor Blvd Fullerton, CA 92832

10% of all January and February sales will go towards the LA Fire Mutual Aid.

And since we are a mobile pop-up and typically have very tight stock, we still want to offer free meals for those impacted by the Fires...

We'll be fulfilling individual requests for Bentos and will make sure they make it to you. We know it's a lot and many who are still grieving do not have the capacity or means to travel around town for free food.

Pre-orders for Saturday open NOW and will close 1/17. As stated in our monthly schedule post, we are reducing hours and cooking equipment for an indoor pop-up like this, and trying to focus a bit more on building our frozen dumpling business, so a limited amount of frozen packs will be offered for pre-orders.

And with all the recent chaos, I am a bit disoriented too and split between commitments... So if I make a mistake or take longer to make orders, please bear with me... It's just me here at team INOMONI so far..
.
.
.
.
.

In the face of unimaginable tragedy, resilience grows strong‚Ä¶ But that does not heal the pain concerning the devastation incurred by the fires raging across Southern California right now. Beloved friends, family, teammates, and community members have been enduring the worst sorts of tragedy and loss so soon after the season of joy and giving‚Ä¶ Precious memories, lives, and places have been altered inextricably. Grief is one of the most complex human emotions, and our hearts mirror the scarred landscape of what was just so recently the image of stability and beauty. As bitter realization sets in, we urge everyone not to forget the unstoppable strength and beauty of life, no matter how difficult these parallels are to grapple. There is so much love, community, and courage in the face of the unthinkable. Our prayers and love are especially with the Carley, Hatchman, Mishkin, Bunn, Mu√±oz, Quigley, Malm, and Simone families right now. We hope more than anything you and yours are all safe and sound. Our hearts and minds are heavy with love and worry in equal measure for everyone affected and displaced in the Eaton, Pallisade, and Hust fires. 

‚ÄúThe most beautiful people I‚Äôve known are those who have known trials, have known struggles, have known loss, and have found their way out of the depths.‚Äù - Elizabeth K√ºbler-Ross

#landscape #eatonfire #PrayforLA #gardenview

Looting during a local emergency would become a felony punishable by a state prison sentence and make it a strike under California‚Äôs Three Strikes Law under proposed legislation by Los Angeles County District Attorney Nathan Hochman and Orange County District Attorney Todd Spitzer, sending a strong regional message to opportunistic thieves that these crimes will not be tolerated, and that justice will be swift and it will be decisive.
 
District Attorneys Hochman and Spitzer are calling on California Governor Gavin Newsom to amend his prior proclamation to convene special session of the state Legislature in order to enact urgency legislation that would increase the punishment for looting, send defendants convicted of looting to state prison, require suspected looters to go before a judge instead of being allowed to be cited and released, and make looting ineligible for diversion, which under current law allows defendants to have their crimes erased from their record as if the arrest never occurred.

Click the link in our bio to read the full press release.

Both sides of my family lived in the Altadena and Pasadena area since the end of World War II. They lived about 7 minutes apart from each other. The neighborhoods created during this time were  hard working families who cared about love and the American dream. Neighbors became lifelong members of your own family and over the years these homes would be passed down to their children. Generations of families who never left these homes.

My mom and dad grew up in both Pasadena and Altadena. My father attended Pasadena High School and my mother attended John Muir High School. Even though my parents moved away from the town, they worked in Pasadena. When I was a child, they would drop me off at my grandma house or a host of my aunts houses five days a week. My mom worked at Huntington Hospital and my father coached the Varsity football team at John Muir for years and then Pasadena High. I grew up being able to see all my family on the same day whenever I was in town.

My grandmother‚Äôs house (the family house) is gone where all of the White family memories (photo albums, bibles, past down heirlooms ect) were kept. My Aunt Tommie‚Äôs home and my cousins‚Äô homes are also gone. shFaith and I were just recently at my grandmother‚Äôs house a month ago. She took a picture on the steps where I played. Never thinking that was the last time we would see it. 
 
The memories of my family lived in the walls and dirt of the earth of these homes. The air, the streets and the trees are reminders of their legacy, hopes and dreams for us. But last week we could have lost our entire family all in one night. That is not lost on me. My family is alive.
 
Lord Jesus please cover Los Angeles County and Southern California with your holy protection. Every person & every responder.
 

#eatonfire #LA

It is with a heavy heart that I write this. As many of you know, Los Angeles, my home, has experienced an unimaginable disaster. Countless people I know have lost everything. The sense of disbelief, displacement, shock, sadness, and even anger is palpable‚Äîand anger, I‚Äôm sure, will surface for many as they process this tragedy.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Yet, amidst the devastation, there is a glimmer of hope in the resilience and kindness of the human spirit. Angelenos have come together in remarkable ways, organizing support on the ground and offering help from every direction.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
On a personal note, during the week I was under a mandatory evacuation order, I felt anxious, scared, sad, and paralyzed. I can‚Äôt begin to fathom the depth of loss for those who‚Äôve not only been displaced but have also lost their homes, their communities, and the physical history of their lives. It is devastation in its truest sense‚Äîbeyond what words can capture.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
So many of you have reached out to ask how you can help, and I am deeply grateful. I will share resources as they become available. In the meantime, know that your prayers, thoughts, and simply checking in on people make a difference. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Thank you for your kindness and support.‚†Ä
With so much love and gratitude- Laila üôèüôèüôè‚†Ä
‚†Ä

We know that following the devastation of the LA wildfires, many children are without their school or normal routine. Maintaining a sense of normalcy and consistent support system is paramount in times of trauma. To help fill this need, our three campuses are welcoming students aged 2 through 6th grade who are seeking temporary or long term schooling. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Anneliese Schools is offering our whole child education at a special rate to families impacted by the Southern California wildfires. Our administration is here to help you get your child back into a supportive routine as soon as possible. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Contact Wendy Bana for assistance in applying, or for additional details, by emailing w.bana@annelieseschools.com ‚Å†
‚Å†

Patrick O'Neal sifts through his home on January 13 after it was destroyed by the Palisades Fire. "I'm trying to figure out where I am in the house... I think i'm standing in my dad's bathroom. To be honest, I don't even know what I'm looking for I guess I'm just trying to make sense of it. There's nothing left, just ash and bricks - there's nothing," he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Palisades and Eaton Fires erupted hours apart one week ago during an unprecedented wind event that brought hurricane-force winds to the greater Los Angeles area. Both fires spread at a critical rate, with the high winds pushing embers into homes and raining down into neighborhoods miles ahead. Since starting, the fires have collectively charred nearly 38,000 acres, and an estimated 16,500 structures have been destroyed. Twenty-four people have died and more than 180,000 people are under an evacuation order or warning, according to published reports. In Altadena, California,¬†I spoke to Black and Latina women from the community who shared¬†the personal toll of the Eaton Fire and the destruction it brought to their community.¬†

Story and images for @19thnews ‚ú®üôèüèΩ *Each four women have their GoFundMe page linked in their sections. 

During the civil rights movement, Altadena was one of the few areas offering home loans to Black families, boosting the Black population from 4% in 1968 to 27% by 1970. Before the fires, Black homeownership in the area was 81.5%, nearly double the national average.¬†

Today, Altadena remains a working-class, multicultural community, with 58% of residents being people of color.¬†Rebuilding homes, many of which were fully paid off and passed down through generations, will be much more difficult for Altadena residents than those in surrounding affluent neighborhoods.

Anniah Baynes.¬†
The fire destroyed the home Anniah Baynes, an 18-year-old high school senior, shared with her grandmother, aunt and three younger siblings.

Now staying with her mother just blocks from where she lived, Baynes has struggled in the aftermath of the fire. ‚ÄúI feel traumatized,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want to be somewhere far away from the smell of the smoke, where I can‚Äôt see the mountains on fire.‚Äù

A week before the fire, Baynes proudly showed her classmates her hair, which she had done herself over the holiday break.Now, returning to school feels impossible. As the eldest of seven, she has taken on the responsibility of staying strong for her siblings. ‚ÄúI try not to cry in front of my younger siblings. I want to show them I‚Äôm strong and that we‚Äôre going to be OK,‚Äù she said.

Despite the challenges, Baynes finds comfort in the support she‚Äôs received from friends and family. Her friends created a GoFundMe page to help the family recover, and relatives in the area have stepped in to offer assistance. And yet, she yearns what she lost. ‚ÄúAll the support that I am getting is great,‚Äù Baynes said. ‚ÄúI love it and appreciate it, but I just really want my home back.‚Äù¬†

#altadena #eatonfire #women

The massive destruction, the fear about which direction the wind will blow next, the concern about arsonists and looters, the sadness about the loss of property and life, as well as the guilt we feel if our homes were not harmed. 

‚ù§Ô∏è Please share if there‚Äôs a feeling that I have not listed that you are experiencing.

Here are a few ideas that can help you check in with yourself and with your child. And remember, if you need more support, just reach out at the link in our bio.

* Long post as I have a few Updates *
 
Thank you for all the concern‚Ä¶. üíô
@therealjeremymiller and I are safe at this time. 
We are staying at a home close to one of the volunteer evacuation areas. 

Today, it's been a week of fires everywhere! üò¢üò≠ So much lose I can't even put into words. üò≠üò≠
The winds have been kicking up even more again yesterday and today. 
More fires popping up all over but our AMAZING firefighters and first responders have been Killin it!!! 
GOD BLESS ALL YOU WHO ARE FIGHTING THESE FIRES! üôèüôèüôè
(and  those that are fighting evil people taking advantage of this situation! #looters ü§¨ #pricegouging üò° #arsen etc... )
Also many thanks and blessings to those coming from various states AND countries!! üíôü•∞üíãüòçüôèüíôüôè THANK YOU ALL FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS!!! ‚ô•Ô∏è
( Even 4 from my brother's unit, from out of state, are here helping.) 

So far, that we know of, 2 of my babies ( newborn specialist jobs) have completely lost their homes.... some of our good friends have lost everything and many others we know of. 

These fires, this yr, have horribly impacted so many people All OVER in the Los Angeles area. 
Our hearts break for those, that have been in the heart of these fires for days now üò¢üò≠üò¢
It is so horrifying to even have to drive past these fires, let alone run through them! üò≠ ( and these #FireTornado OMGOODNESS!!! I had to ask my brother and get more details on these cause that is even more panicking to me. See video from ABC attached in my pics on  this post)

A few yrs ago Jeremy and I had to drive through fires that were on BOTH SIDES of the freeways!!! It was like driving on  a road threw a volcano. Lava looking fire on both sides... almost what I imagine HELL might look like. 
 It was the one of the scariest anxiety filled emotional times of my ( and unfortunately I have been through alot of death defying circumstances üò¢). 

Praying and praying for all our friends ( and everyone)  who have had to evacuate from many areas already,  and even lost their homes . 
Praying for all! üôèüôèüôè

*LA FIRE FUNDRAISER* 

Much gratitude and thanks to everyone who has reached out this past week. Many of you know my residence is near the Eaton Canyon trail head. My home is still intact, but uninhabitable without gas, electricity, or clean water at the moment. I‚Äôm deeply saddened by the amount of loss that has occurred in my neighborhood. Words can‚Äôt express the heart break, but simultaneously, I‚Äôve been moved by the power of community and resilience that has unfolded despite the tragedies.

Starting today, I‚Äôll be conducting a fundraiser where 100% of ceramics sales will go out to the families who have lost homes in the Eaton fire and across Los Angeles. There are countless friends and loved ones who still need funds to get back on their feet. 

The conditions for the fundraiser are, just select the pieces you are interested in by scrolling through my post and I‚Äôll message you with pricing & dimensions. I have a select number of sculptures and pottery. I‚Äôll be posting more throughout the week.

Comment below or message me the letter of the piece.

A second option is - If you have a specific family or fire relief organization you‚Äôd like to support, just donate the price of the piece to the family or organization and send me a screenshot of the confirmation.

Local pick-up & shipping options are available for those who aren‚Äôt nearby the Pasadena area.

Thank you for supporting our communities that have been affected by these fires.

Wildfires like the Eaton and Palisades fires highlight the devastating power of nature‚Äîand the immense pain and loss they bring to communities. As we see the destruction and heartbreak in Los Angeles, we‚Äôre reminded of our own experience with the CZU fire in the Santa Cruz Mountains in 2020. That fire destroyed many homes and lives, including those of our friends and neighbors. The memories of that time have deeply shaped how we approach fire safety in design.

During the CZU fire, a 1,000-acre property we worked on was devastated, yet the only structure left standing was the one we built with fireproof materials like Corten steel and CMU blocks. This experience profoundly impacted us, and it continues to guide our efforts to design with resilience and fire safety at the forefront.

In Los Angeles and other fire-prone areas, the opportunity to rebuild is also a chance to prioritize fire safety. Simple yet powerful strategies like defensible space, ember-resistant vents, and fire-rated materials can make a life-saving difference. These measures, while sometimes overlooked, are essential to creating homes that are not just beautiful but built to endure.

To everyone affected by these fires, we stand with you. We understand the loss and uncertainty that follows such devastation, and we believe in a future where smarter, safer building practices can help protect lives, homes, and memories from the threat of wildfires.

Fireproof design can be beautiful, and we have had the incredible opportunity of designing thoughtful homes for our clients that provide invaluable peace of mind for their families and safeguard their irreplaceable memories. 

#PalisadesFire #EatonFire #LosAngelesFire #LosAngeles #RebuildLA #LAFires #FireproofHomes #FuseArchitects #MalibuFire #FireArchitects

LA‚Äôs Wildfires Compared to New York City

The Palisades Fire, Eaton Fire, and Hurst Fire in Los Angeles have burned through a combined 38,629 acres as of January 14th. This is an area equivalent to roughly 93% of the total land area of the Bronx and Manhattan, which together cover 41,510 acres.

This map is intended to help those unfamiliar with Los Angeles better understand the scale of this active wildfire. By comparing the fire perimeter to a city like New York, we can get a clearer sense of its size. If you‚Äôre curious about seeing LA fire perimeters over your city to grasp the magnitude of these wildfires, feel free to DM me.

The fire perimeter is as of January 14th, 2025 at 1:00pm.

If you are outside of LA, the best way you can help is with monetary donations to underfunded organizations. There is currently an overabundance of commonly donated items like clothing.

Help Greg & Michael Rebuild: https://gofund.me/5d3a4b59

Today marks one week since the Palisades and Eaton fires engulfed our city. Yesterday, fire officials guided me through a survey of the damage. Even after seeing photos and videos, I wasn‚Äôt prepared for the sheer magnitude of what‚Äôs been lost.

I spoke with our first responders about what worked and what didn‚Äôt in the days running up to the fire and ensuing fight. The information I received dispels any notion of simple solutions‚Äîbut it‚Äôs clear that with certain reforms and investments, we can be better prepared in the future. 

There‚Äôs a long road ahead, but we will rebuild together. As the dust settles, I hope to share more concrete updates on how the government is responding to this disaster and preparing for future fires. Stay tuned. #palisadesfire #eatonfire

My heart goes out to my community during this difficult time. It was an emotional last couple of days hearing about 
everything going on in people‚Äôs lives that were affected by the fires. It was a pleasure sharing laughs and some emotional conversations with these amazing people. I had the opportunity to build connections and friendships. It‚Äôs a beautiful thing to see everyone come together when sometimes all we feel is loneliness and like maybe there is no more hope left in humanity. The world needs more of this. We all need to stick together to make change. If it is one thing I did in the last two days, it‚Äôs that I hope I was able to make someone feel loved and cared for. To make a difference in these crazy times. I know I couldn‚Äôt ‚Äúfix‚Äù anything but seeing everyone‚Äôs face light up in the mirror‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a feeling that I will never forget. When I close my eyes at night they will forever be in my heart. Heads high LA. We‚Äôll come back stronger. Much love to The City Of Angelsüíô

Our Lancer Support Drive is still welcoming both donations and essential pick-ups, thanks to the community‚Äôs unwavering support. Open to anyone in the local community affected by the wildfires, we‚Äôre here daily until January 17th, from 12 PM to 4 PM at our campus Dining Hall. Please enter through the Lower Parking Lot gates off Michillinda Ave. Your continued generosity allows us to maintain this vital initiative, ensuring we meet the needs of all impacted by the fires.

Hot meals are available every day from 12 PM to 4 PM in the Dining Hall. A big thank you to @smpizzaco @elportal @nothingbundtcakes @hummuslabs @wckitchen @jjbakeryusa @wingstop and parent/family volunteers for supporting our hot meals this week! School counselors are available for student support, alongside art and prayer stations for those seeking solace.

Therapy puppies will be on campus in the Atrium from 12 PM to 3 PM on Thursday, January 16, ready to offer comfort and joy.

Lastly, if you are able, we invite you to give to the Lancer Support Fund which will provide support to current La Salle students and families directly impacted by the fires. Donations are tax deductible and can be made at lasallehs.org/lancersupportfund or via the link in our bio.

Thank you for your continued support of La Salle and one another. Together, we will get through this as a community.

Artist and longtime Nonaka-Hill employee Jeffrey Sugishita lost his home in the Eaton Fire.

Jeffrey is a Los Angeles native who has studied tea ceremony since age 9, a discipline which contributes to all other parts of his life and work. When he‚Äôs not at work, he‚Äôs often camping in the wilderness around Los Angeles, exploring his physical capabilities climbing trees and rocks so that he can observe a new vista. Jeffrey converts these experiences into his art practice, for which he recently graduated with honors from the Art Center, Pasadena.

Jeffrey has applied his skills and fortitude to his work with the gallery as our main installation technician for each of our exhibitions over the past five years. If you‚Äôve enjoyed exhibitions at Nonaka-Hill, it‚Äôs been Jeffrey, behind the scenes, reliably keeping pace and high standards. We are grateful.

The gallery team supports Jeffrey as he responds to this challenge. Having lost almost everything, a public GoFundMe campaign is set up for Jeffrey Sugishita to receive community goodwill. Contributions of any amount will help Jeffrey rebound and get back on track with his emerging art practice.

https://www.gofundme.com/f/kssra
