My beloved Cali is in deep misery! 

I‚Äôve waited a while to actually write something because I have been so consumed and deeply saddened by all the destruction the Palisades & Eaton Fires have caused. I have been trying to even figure out what to say as I know words do not give comfort at times like this. 

I have also been processing my own PTSD as fires have and will always greatly affect me. As a kid I went through a great deal of trauma due to the Santa Barbara Painted Cave fire 1990 and again with the Thomas Fire and Mudslide in 2017/2018. So many of my memories have been placed along side fire events. The rest of the US and World thinks this is all normal for us. It may happen a lot and more and more often now but it is not and will never be normal. Fires don‚Äôt discriminate, they don‚Äôt care if you are rich or poor, black or white, gay or straight. They crush the things you hold dear. These fires have killed 25 people. 25 loved ones! 

I think about how deeply affected I have been and I haven‚Äôt even lost a home or loved one. I think about how sad and heavy hearted all those are who have and how the loss of a home is so massive, the loss of a loved one even greater but the trauma of it all is longer lasting. This will last for years! 

As a designer we help people create these well loved and cherished sacred spaces and to have something so quickly destroy it all is beyond devastating. If we can bring some happiness, relief or even help make some people laugh through this we will.

With that Designology will be giving a free 1-hour design consultation to those who have lost a home or business. If you have or know someone who has been affected and they need help trying to rebuild we are here. Please email us at info@designologystudio.com. You are not in this alone! 

All our love! 
The Designology Studio Team

Simple moments at TopangaüèÑüèº‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è‚òÄÔ∏è

This photo was taken on New Year‚Äôs Day‚Äîa day filled with hope and excitement for the year ahead. The sun was shining, the air was crisp, and I couldn‚Äôt help but feel so grateful to call Los Angeles home. There‚Äôs nothing quite like a sunny, 72-degree day in January, and moments like this remind me how special Southern California truly is.

Just days later, devastating fires swept through our beautiful coastline and across LA, leaving so much heartbreak behind. Growing up here, I‚Äôve seen wildfires before, but this one feels heavier‚Äîit‚Äôs hard to put into words.

My heart is with the families and individuals who have lost so much. If you‚Äôre able to help, I‚Äôve added a link in my bio to support those in need.

Let‚Äôs come together to help our community heal‚Äîplease feel free to share this post to spread awareness and encourage support for those impacted. Every bit makes a difference.

FULL STORY IN BIO: The devastating Eaton Fire ignited, extreme winds blew, flames raged, and smoke swallowed the sky of Altadena, California. Hiding the destruction that would soon ravage homes and land. Small embers, carried by the gusts, sparked spot fires, setting off a chain reaction that ultimately destroyed at least 7,000 structures and killed 16, with that number expected to rise.

It was a windy Sunday, with forecasts predicting hurricane-force winds up to 100 mph. The KeyNews team was on standby, one photographer already reporting from the Palisades on the widespread damage. Winds in the San Fernando Valley hadn‚Äôt been severe yet, so I headed to Altadena to cover a tree that had fallen on a house. I arrived just after 6 p.m., when a fire engine and sheriff‚Äôs unit pulled in. As the alert tones sounded, the first responders turned and raced toward the growing fire which would soon be named the Eaton Fire. I followed close behind, and as I rounded the corner, the sky glowed bright orange.

Being one of the first on the scene, I knew the situation was dire. The wind howled as I quickly set up, battling gusts while trying to put on my fire protective gear and film the advancing flames. It was a race against time.

Reports came in of people trapped, homes burning, and roads clogged with evacuations. I made my way to North Altadena and New York Drive. As I arrived, I was choked by hot, smoky air, attempting to find my respirator. Embers flew and power lines arched overhead. Then I heard a man screaming, ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the fire department? Help, my house is burning.‚Äù

I tried to locate him, but I never could. That cry for help became all too common as the fire spread. There weren‚Äôt enough resources, not enough water, and visibility was near zero. Spot fires ignited everywhere, one feeding another in a deadly chain reaction. Firefighters were exhausted, and their resources were draining while the wind blew water away as they fought to save what they could‚Ä¶photos by @bennydavisphoto #EatonFire #altadenafire #firefighterheros #staysafe #verdugomountains #wildfire #wildfireseason
Important info for our community #pasadena #pasadenahumane #eatonfire

I am at a loss for words for what our communities, friends, and family have experienced this last week. It is hard to know where to start and what we can do to best support each other. 

I have been thinking almost non-stop about how Trilogy Design LA and my family can support each other and, most importantly, those affected by the fires. Home is a special place to me and is the mission behind my business. It is a place of comfort, retreat, healing, and safety, and so many of my friends have lost that. 

As people begin to find places to relocate, we are asking for donations of furniture and home goods.  If you know of anyone who needs furnishings or home goods as they relocate, or if you have something you would like to donate, please let me know. We are working on compiling a donation list as well as a ‚ÄúNeeds‚Äù Google sheet. 

We also need storage space for the items donated. If you know anyone who would be willing to donate a storage unit or space for the next few months in the Pasadena area, please let me know. We would even take an unleashed storefront to use for a month. We are also looking for temporary use of a delivery van or truck. Other ways you could help are by organizing donations and retrieving/delivering donations.

If you would like to donate money to support these efforts, you can Venmo me @Amy-Guthrie-2. We will use the money donated to directly support pick-up and delivery. Any leftover funds will be used for purchasing sheets, towels, and other home goods. 

A friend of mine who lost her home shared this quote this morning in an email. It is so beautifully written by Octavia Butler who lived and is interred in Altadena. 

‚ÄúParadise is home. Home as it was or home as it should have been. Paradise is one‚Äôs own place, one‚Äôs own people, one‚Äôs own world, knowing and known, perhaps even loving and loved. Yet every child is cast from paradise - into growth and destruction, into solitude and new community, into vast, ongoing change.‚Äù
~Octavia E. Butler, Parable of the Talents

I look forward to seeing how we can join together as a beautiful community to support one another.

locationName: The Bass House Case Study House #20
caption:
‚ö°Ô∏èSAVED from the Eaton Fire‚ö°Ô∏èCase Study House No. 20, also known as the Saul Bass House in Altadena, California, remarkably survived the devastating Eaton Fire, preserving its place as a cornerstone of mid-century modern architecture. Designed by architect Buff, Straub & Hensman in 1958, this experimental masterpiece embodies the Case Study House program‚Äôs ethos of integrating modern design with functionality. Its survival highlights the importance of safeguarding historic homes that reflect architectural innovation and cultural significance. Let‚Äôs continue to celebrate and protect these iconic structures that tell the story of 20th-century design.

So today while volunteering at Santa Anita #donationcenter for the #eatonfire, I noticed on the way in that one sign was knocked down and some signage was missing.
I went to the volunteer area and got supplies to make signs.
Most needed were the signs leading people to donation drop off and pick up, but I was informed by a ConEd employee doing security that people were getting lost trying to exit the vast parking lot, some ending up in the staging area for some emergency vehicles (gas/electric) - it got worse after sundown. üò©
So I ended up spending a ridiculous amount of time making posters and fighting with cheap packing tape to get the signs up, but was able to help people get where they needed to go.
I noticed the ConEd people were not being fed so I went back to grab them food.
It was then I realized there were so many LESS people at the ‚Äúcenter‚Äù.
APPARENTLY, the organizers have wised up to the fact that a vast amount of people coming I. For donations yesterday weren‚Äôt actually victims of the fire. Yep, a ton of people yesterday were just there to basically steal from people that lost their homes.
So now people will have to bring ID.

Not gonna lie, it seemed obvious yesterday not everyone had just lost a home, but I think no one wanted to admit people would just straight up take advantage of the circumstances. Some people are obvious, they act like they‚Äôre on a shopping trip and are HAPPY. Some people are nervous when you look at them. Some people act guilty, but was I going to challenge people? Not my job.

But tons of people were taking video and pictures, I wonder if some people will be found out. It‚Äôs disappointing.

Malibu was once home. When we moved back to Cali from the East coast in 2011- I bee-lined straight for the ocean. 

The beach has always been my happy place and over the years, I‚Äôve found solace in being so close to it. Though we no longer live in Malibu, I‚Äôd always find a reason to go back there at least once a month‚Ä¶driving PCH vs taking the 101 to/from LA was always such a treat! Anytime I had friends in town, I‚Äôd make reservations at my favorite places to ensure they got to experience my little slice of heaven. 

Now, many of those places are gone and I‚Äôm saddened by the fact that so much is lost. However, I know that Malibu is a strong community and they will rebuild.  I can‚Äôt wait to attend the (re)openings of the new and fabulous @moonshadows_malibu and @malibubeachinn 

Praying for everyone affected by the LA fires and trusting that He will comfort and provide in this time of need.üôèüèΩ

On January 8th, 2025. My auntie and uncle had to evacuate at 3am due to the Eaton fire.They only loaded the car with the necessities for my auntie's mom, who is under their care full-time. Not knowing it would be the last time in their beloved home, everything else was left behind.

My auntie and uncle have been residence of Altadena, CA for over 35 years. My auntie is a local teacher of over 18 years, and my uncle is a retired electrician. Like many others in the community, they are now facing a completely unforeseen financial situation. Their home and  their peace of mind they worked so hard for is now gone.

Please help them in any way you can. Financial donations or a quick share can go a long way.

Today, Engine 43 was assigned back to division T of the Eaton Fire. They are expecting extreme Santa Ana winds tonight through Wednesday night.  If the fire activity picks up, it could take the fire towards NASA JPL facilities.  Today, JPL firefighters walked E43 crews along with other task force members to recognize hazards associated with these JPL facilities.  It's crucial that the crews understand that the fire could end up once the fire activity picks up.  They also surveyed homes around JPL as well.  The brush in socal is as dry as it would be during the height of the fire season.  We are still in active fire season. 

Information 
A lot of people have asked what firefighters need.  We will tell you that we are taken care of well on these fires. The fire camp for the Eaton Fire is at rhe Rose Bowl.  In camp we have everything to meet our needs.  If anybody needs anything, it's the people who have lost everything. Please consider donations to people who lost their jobs in the Eaton Fire.

Some of you may already know, but for those that don‚Äôt, our dear friend, Alain lost his home and all of the contents in the recent and ongoing Eaton Fire here in California. Most importantly, he and his children are safe and unharmed.

The fire destroyed the home he lived in and he has lost everything except a few instruments, his music library and the clothes he was wearing at the time of the evacuation. He is basically starting over... completely.

We have received several messages asking about his well-being and he is eternally grateful. Apologies for being unable to reply to each message directly.

As a means of helping him and his family get back to some sort of ‚Äúnormal‚Äù life, there is now a GoFundMe account set up for donations. If you can help at all, with any amount, it would be appreciated more than you know. It‚Äôs a big request, as there are so many other people already affected by the fires and there will likely be many more, but even a small donation in order to help him and the kids get a start would be wonderful üôè‚ù§Ô∏è

Please read more at the attached link and donate there if you can. Any excess donations will be reapportioned to others in the community that need additional help.

Eaton Fire, ùí´ùí∂ùìàùí∂ùíπùëíùìÉùí∂, CA‚Äì January 8 & 9

This is post about the Eaton Fire. In it, I captured a hawk perched on a light post‚Äîa fleeting moment that has stayed with me ever since.

I took the photo through a 40-year-old window, part of the structure I sheltered in as the storm raged. The wind howled with such force that the glass seemed to crackle under the strain, and I feared it might shatter. That night, I couldn‚Äôt sleep. I watched the fire grow, my heart weighed down with fear‚Äînot just for myself, but for my neighbors near the flames.

The second photo, taken a day earlier, shows a sky smothered in dark, ashen smoke. It loomed over Altadena and Pasadena, and I knew then that parts of the town had been consumed by fire. Yet, knowing didn‚Äôt prepare me for the scale of the devastation that followed.

Now, as I reflect on these photos, I think about that hawk. Perhaps it was fleeing the fire, seeking refuge from the polluted air and the chaos below. Even amid the destruction, it found its way to a light post‚Äîa small, unwavering beacon in the storm. Hawks are often seen as symbols of change, wisdom, and protection, and I can‚Äôt help but see a reflection of our community in that bird‚Äîsteadfast, adaptable, and enduring.

The hawk‚Äôs flight reminds me of the strength and resilience I‚Äôve witnessed in those around me. In the face of fear and loss, we have come together‚Äîlifting one another up, healing, and rebuilding what was taken. This is the spirit of our community: a testament to hope, courage, and unyielding resilience.

üåπ #denarestored #eatonfire

It‚Äôs been one week since the Palisades fire broke out. While we‚Äôre still actively covering everything that‚Äôs been impacted by it, just taking a moment to reflect back on those hazy/chaotic first 24 hours.

We knew the wind was going to be bad that day, and producer @jimseida and I had our fire gear ready to go in case anything came up, but we obviously never could have anticipated this. 

I‚Äôll never forget getting stuck in gridlock traffic that day on Sunset Blvd, brush fires on either side of the road. Firefighters putting them out, assuring us we were okay. Then getting out and seeing so many abandoned cars from people who gave up and walked, followed by a massive bulldozer that came through to push them out of the way to clear a path.

When we finally made it to the Pacific Coast Highway, I‚Äôll never forget the moment @jimseida saw an ember fly onto a palm tree on the beach. Within five minutes - as we reported live on @topstorynbc - the cluster of trees was up in flames. Looking back now, that was the moment things really took a turn. Police told us to leave that beach and drive south. The winds were like nothing I‚Äôve ever experienced growing up in Southern California. 

Just hours later, when we came back in the middle of the night for our @todayshow hit, it looked like basically all of PCH was on fire. In Malibu, home after home of beachfront properties up in flames. 

In the week since, we‚Äôve spoken to a countless number of people whose lives have been upended. So, so many who have lost their homes or businesses. We spoke to a woman whose grandmother died in her beloved Altadena house because she didn‚Äôt think she really needed to evacuate. We spoke to a teacher who lost his home but instead of worrying about himself has been nonstop texting/checking on his students. We talked to high school girls who have already had so many years of school disrupted by covid, only to be preparing for remote classes yet again after their campus in the fire zone was largely destroyed. And of course, we met Casey and sweet Tika Tika Tika & Oreo, who gave me - and I‚Äôve gathered many others - a little bright spot in all this sorrow. ‚ù§Ô∏èüíî #palisadesfire #eatonfire #losangeles

üåø A Week to Remember üåø

This past week, I experienced firsthand what it‚Äôs like to face a sudden evacuation order. It‚Äôs been a whirlwind of emotions‚Äîfear, uncertainty, and heartbreak. So many in our community have lost their homes, their safe spaces, and their sense of normalcy. My heart is heavy for those displaced and for the land we all call home.

But even amidst the ashes, hope shines. I‚Äôm praying for restoration and healing‚Äîfor our neighbors, our wildlife, and our beautiful community. Together, L.A. will rebuild stronger than ever.

To everyone impacted: you are not alone. We‚Äôre with you. üíõ

#AltadenaStrong #EatonFire #CommunityHealing

RIP #Mariposa 1904- 1/7/2025
I can‚Äôt believe our home withstood over 120 years, through so many different timelines, different families, different stories, but we were the last to enjoy your last moments. We weren‚Äôt ready to let you go. It‚Äôs really a death. A death of your lifetime before us and how many stories you held secret in your walls. I mourn for your demise and mourn for all the friends and family who have to say goodbye. Thank you Mariposa, you made childhood so much fun.  @darleneyvonneleyba @luzform @marisaxalina @adriansuniverse @jms_romero #altadena #eatonfire

I‚Äôm honestly overwhelmed with emotion as I sit here thinking about the donations that have come in, the supplies that have been dropped off at my house, and the kindness people have shown. It‚Äôs hard to put into words how much this means. For everyone who has contributed in any way whether it‚Äôs been through a donation, a message of encouragement, or physically showing up to help‚Äî please know that your kindness is not going unnoticed. It truly feels like a lifeline, especially when we are all trying to make sense of the devastation caused by the fires here in LA. 

Seeing so many people come together to help those who‚Äôve lost everything reminds me that, even in the toughest of times, there is still so much good in the world. It gives me such a powerful sense of community and hope, knowing that there are people out there who care, who are showing up for others, and who are doing everything they can to support those in need. I don‚Äôt have the words to express how much your generosity has touched me.

Thank you for trusting me with your resources, I can‚Äôt wait to deliver these very essential supplies to our community. You‚Äôve not only made a tangible difference but also uplifted spirits in a time when they needed it the most. Thank you, from the bottom of my heart. Your kindness means everything.

#losangeles #losangelesfire #la #eaton #palisadesfire #eatonfire

The outpouring of love is amazing to see, but the sheer amount of physical donations are causing delays.

Mayor Karen Bass has issued an Executive Order to fast-track the rebuilding process for Los Angeles homeowners affected by the devastating wildfires. The order promises to be the first step in speeding up home reconstruction by cutting red tape and bureaucracy.

Key highlights include:

- Coordinating debris removal with city, county, and federal agencies

- Expediting Certificates of Occupancy for 1,400 dwelling units currently in the pipeline

- Streamlining permitting of "like for like" reconstruction up to 110% of the original size‚Äîno standard permitting process required

- A centralized permit center will be open 7 days a week, staffed by city, state, and federal agencies for expedited support

- Permitting exemptions to include the all-electric building mandate, demolition permits (with prior notice), and certain coastal and specific plan reviews

- Property owners can live on-site in RVs or temporary residences during construction

To read the full Executive Order from @mayorofla visit: https://mayor.lacity.gov/news/mayor-bass-issues-sweeping-executive-order-clear-way-angelenos-rebuild-their-homes-fast

#LosAngeles #DisasterRecovery #MayorKarenBass #WildfireRecovery #PalisadesFire #EatonFire

Today, I joined my fellow City Council colleagues and our City Manager as we were briefed by the Incident Management Team on the Eaton Fire. Accompanied by our Fire Chief, we visited ground zero in the affected areas of Altadena.

The devastation is overwhelming‚Äîso many homes destroyed, and countless families now facing unimaginable loss. It‚Äôs hard to put into words the pain and uncertainty these families must be feeling in this moment.

But amidst this tragedy, I am deeply moved by the extraordinary efforts of those working tirelessly to protect lives and contain the fire. Our firefighters‚Äîmany of whom have traveled from across the country‚Äîfirst responders, the National Guard, public works teams, and countless others are showing us what true dedication and resilience look like.

To those impacted by this fire, know that you are not alone. Our community stands with you, and we will do everything in our power to support your recovery. My deepest gratitude goes out to everyone working around the clock to keep us safe. Your bravery and commitment remind us of the strength we have as a community when we come together.

Stay safe, and let us keep those affected in our thoughts and prayers.

About 1.5 years ago we rented the basement of @thebunnymuseum as our warehouse. Steve did the best he could to defend the building but it was destroyed. No one knows what happened to the basement. We reached out to multiple government agencies for help. Our local LA County fire inspector Brad Sizemore was able to help and shared these photos with us today. While we expected the worst, it still hurt a lot to see üò≠. Everything inside was burnt to dust. A few hundred thousands worth of equipment and inventory is a lot for our small business. In the mean time, we are doing our best to get our crew working safely elsewhere to minimize the impact to their livelihood during this challenging time. Thank you to all the neighbors, friends and customers who reached out to us, we appreciate you all. It means a lot to hear from you during this difficult time.

Hello everyone,

Thank you for your patience as I‚Äôve been pushing to get an update out amidst power and internet outages.

Tonight marks one week since the Eaton fire and the evacuation from our precious home in the now decimated shire of Altadena.

With the overwhelming outpouring of love, support and mind blowing generosity, it has allowed us to move mountains in just one week.

With every task, a new set of tasks. Hours on the road pulling all of the pieces together. Lists and lists. Small patches of sleep. Lakes of coffee. Oreos and crying.

Like so many others in LA struggling to restart and rebuild their lives as a result of the devastating wildfires, we have been navigating layers of resources and tools, staying close with our community, and supporting where we can. Everyone has been breathtakingly supportive and awesome. So so so many incredible people in our lives.

Some days start with a good cry, other days kick off with a hyperactive burst of energy to conquer the world to offset the darkness of loss.

The path ahead is long, but fantastically hopeful.

Our families, friends, colleagues, neighbors and the vibrant, incredible community around us have swooped in to support us.

We are so grateful, so honored, so humbled.

We are safe and still currently based comfortably well outside LA and Altadena in Perris (CA).

We are navigating back and forth from our base camp in Perris into LA to look for housing, acquire donated clothing and basic supplies and connect with friends who are sharing the same experiences and who have also lost everything. The winds are still very strong out in the desert, so we are getting as much done as we can in between outages.

We are making gradual progress and are slowly putting the pieces of our lives back together and planning‚Ä¶ all the while, trying to remain grounded, positive, kind and thankful amidst some notable adversity. Some days are harder than others.

We are fortunate to have each other.

We are fortunate to have YOU.

More updates forthcoming.

Wishing all of you safety and health.

Respectfully,
Chris, Monica and Kes

As of Tuesday evening, in coordination with the State Water Resources Control Board and Los Angeles County Department of Public Health, the city of Sierra Madre are advising residents on and north of Grandview Avenue that were in evacuation order zones NOT TO USE THE TAP WATER FOR DRINKING AND COOKING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE. 

The City of Sierra Madre never lost system pressure and did not suffer any damage to its critical water infrastructure during the Eaton Fire. The city has conducted an initial assessment of the water system with routine bacteriological samples taken throughout the system. All samples were analyzed by a third-party certified lab and found no coliform bacteria. 

This measure is out of an abundance of caution to prioritize resident's health and safety. 

Follow @cityofsierramadre for more updates. 

Thank you to the city staff for their continued hard work to keep residents safe.

#Californiafires #SanGabrielValley #SGV #SierraMadre #Pasadena #EatonCanyon #EatonFire #EatonCanyonFire

Looking down on 'dena. 

One of my favourite places in Altadena also seems particularly prescient right now. 

At the top of Echo Mountain, via the Sam Merrill trail, sit the ruins of the hotel and mountain railroad, part of a Victorian resort named White City, built by Thaddeus Lowe in 1893 above Altadena.

From its grand opening through to its eventual abandonment in 1936, fire and wind ravaged the resort several times, but they continued to rebuild. 

Today, standing up there among the ruins feels simultaneously inspiring and cautionary. It would be understatement to say I can't wait to get back up there again soon.

This past week really had me thinking about emergency preparedness. 

If I only had a few minutes to grab things, what would I grab first? What would I have to leave behind and potentially have to say good-bye to?

Naturally, when I start to feel anxious, I‚Äôll lean on a checklist. 

So I put together a checklist that lists the things you‚Äôll want to try and grab in case of an emergency evacuation. I tried to group the items so you could have things stored together to grab easily in a hurry. 

I hope that you never have to use this checklist, but if you do, I hope it gives you peace of mind.

I grew up minutes from Altadena, higher up the mountain above a brush filled canyon, where the trees on either side of the surrounding streets grew so tall their branches would reach over and form a canopy, sometimes not letting light in. ‚Å£The fire danger there was high. ‚Å£
‚Å£
I was reading my insurance documents last night, and the fire danger score at my current house was zero. Maybe that‚Äôs why I find myself so woefully unprepared physically, mentally, emotionally, financially, to handle something like losing my entire neighborhood. ‚Å£
‚Å£
That said, I‚Äôd like to send a massive thank you to the firefighters and first responders who I don‚Äôt feel are getting enough credit for risking their lives to save ours. ‚Å£
Reality really hits you hard after the first week, I guess. If you‚Äôre looking for ways to support I have a gofundme link in my bio, and I‚Äôll put links to other orgs in my stories. ‚Å£
‚Å£
#Altadena #EatonFire #RebuildAltadena ‚Å£

Delva Gibson ‚ú®
As a group of supporters prayed for the family, Delva Gibson, 82, held her husband tightly. The Gibsons lost their home of nearly 52 years in the fire. It was the only home she has known since immigrating from Brazil.

Married for over 50 years, she and her husband raised their two sons in the house. The couple is currently staying with their son in San Bernardino. The loss is profound, but Gibson is finding clarity amidst the tragedy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a new beginning for us this year,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThe material things are not important. What is important is that we, as a family, are OK.‚Äù

Rose Hayes‚ú®
Rose Hayes sits at the Habit Burger & Grill in Hastings Ranch, reflecting on the destruction of her Altadena home of 20 years.

The house belonged to her husband‚Äôs family for over five decades, passed down through generations. Its history is part of the broader story of Black homeownership in Altadena, which was seen as a haven during the Great Migration, when Black Americans moved from the South to find safety and jobs in other parts of the country. 

It‚Äôs a tight-knit Black community that‚Äôs been here for a long time, Hayes said. ‚ÄúEverybody knows everybody,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe look out for each other.‚Äù

Now the future is uncertain for the 66-year-old, who also lives with her granddaughter. Her family is staying at an Airbnb for nine days for free, and then they have a week paid for by their rental insurance at a hotel. After that, they are unsure of where they will go. Like many others in Altadena, Hayes‚Äôs family is leaning on community support to begin rebuilding their lives.

‚ÄúEveryone keeps telling me to have hope, but I don‚Äôt feel it. I can‚Äôt see it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI loved opening the door of my home and seeing the mountains. Now it‚Äôs like a bomb went off.‚Äù

Story and Images for @19thnews

Eaton Fire (01/08/2025)

A week ago today on Tuesday, January 7, 2025 in Altadena, California the Eaton Fire causing the loss of human life and multiple structures in the cities of Altadena,Pasadena,Sierra Madre. As of Wednesday January 15, 2025 the Eaton Fire remains at 14,117 acres and 45% contained. The Eaton Fire has destroyed over 7,000 structures in Altadena,Pasadena and Sierra Madre. The Eaton Fire has tragically claimed the lives of 16 people. Agencies from throughout the United States have been assisting on the ground in the Eaton Fire. The cause of the Eaton Fire is under investigation.

caption:
‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©πWhen unexpected events affect our community, it‚Äôs natural to feel overwhelmed.
Here are some ways to care for yourself and others during difficult times:

üôèüèªAcknowledge your feelings: It‚Äôs okay to feel anxious, sad, or even frustrated. Giving yourself permission to process these emotions is an important step toward healing.

üì≤Stay connected: Talk to friends, family, or neighbors. Sharing experiences and checking in on one another can provide comfort and strengthen bonds.

üïπÔ∏èFocus on what you can control: While some things may be out of your hands, small acts‚Äîlike helping a neighbor or organizing your space‚Äîcan create a sense of stability.

üì∫Limit media consumption: Staying informed is essential, but constant exposure to distressing news can heighten anxiety. Set boundaries to protect your mental health.

üß†Seek professional help: If feelings of grief or anxiety become too much, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to a counselor or therapist for support.

You‚Äôre not alone in this‚Äîlean on your community, and remember to take care of your heart and mind. ü´Ç #LAStrong 

Galit Fuller State Farm Insurance Agent (818)387-6998

We are hearing that governor Newsome & mayor Bass are issuing executive orders to ease the permitting process, however there are many ordinances in place specific to hillside properties that hinder the allowable buildable square footage and this can potentially affect what you are allowed to rebuild. 

Let‚Äôs discuss your options, again I will be waiving my initial consultation fee to all of those affected by the wildfires whose homes were damaged or destroyed. You don‚Äôt need to do this alone, I‚Äôd rather you focus on you, your family and your well being. No matter what, we will be seeing better days ahead. üå∏

There are no perfect words. No quick fixes for this kind of loss. The truth is, when someone is grieving‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs their home, their community, or the places that made them feel safe‚Äîwhat you say can either help them breathe or make it harder for them to hold on.

As parents, we‚Äôre tasked with the impossible: showing up for our children when we feel broken ourselves. Answering their questions when we have none of the answers. Trying to rebuild their sense of safety while we‚Äôre still grasping for our own. And in the midst of this, we‚Äôre surrounded by well-meaning words that sometimes help‚Äîand sometimes hurt.

This is why I created this guide. To share what‚Äôs been truly supportive during this unimaginable time, as a human being, and also as a behavioral scientist‚Äîand what hasn‚Äôt. My hope is that it helps you find the words to show up for someone who‚Äôs grieving, whether they‚Äôve lost everything or feel lost in what‚Äôs left.

Because in moments like these, it‚Äôs not about having the perfect thing to say‚Äîit‚Äôs about being there, with compassion, presence, and the courage to simply sit with their pain. Together, we‚Äôll take this one messy, overwhelming step at a time.üíî

üì∏ @eclipseschool_la

Southern California‚Äôs wildfires are tearing through diverse landscapes, transforming the habitats within many state parks. Learn how these critical ecosystems are facing immense challenges in the wake of the flames. ‚û°Ô∏è

üåµ Chaparral
Chaparral dominates parks such as Topanga State Park and Will Rogers State Historic Park, providing shelter for coyotes, bobcats, quails, and more. While chaparral is fire-adapted, frequent, intense fires can prevent full recovery, leading to erosion and habitat loss for these species.

üåø Coastal Sage Scrub
Coastal sage scrub, found in parks like Topanga State Park, is one of the rarest and most endangered habitats in California. Fires can devastate this ecosystem, destroying native plants like California sagebrush and buckwheat, which take years to regenerate. Without these plants, the habitat loses its ability to support specialized species.

üê∏ Wetlands
Wetlands, like those at Malibu Lagoon State Beach, serve as vital habitats for amphibians, fish, and migratory birds. Fires can dry out these water-rich areas, destroy vegetation that provides cover and nesting grounds, and disrupt the delicate balance that keeps these ecosystems thriving.

üå≥ Oak Woodlands
Oak woodlands, like those at Malibu Creek State Park, are critical for biodiversity, offering food and shelter to countless species. Wildfires can weaken or kill mature oaks, making it difficult for new trees to grow. This long recovery process impacts the entire ecosystem, from pollinators to larger mammals that rely on these trees.

üçÉ Grasslands
Grasslands, like those at Chino Hills State Park, are highly flammable and burn quickly during wildfires. While these ecosystems can recover, repeated fires deplete native grasses and open the door for invasive species like mustard plants, which further increase fire risks.

For updates on parks impacted by the fires, please visit parks.ca.gov/Incidents 

üîó Learn how you can support relief and recovery efforts: calparks.org/climaterelief2025

#PalisadesFire #EatonFire #LosAngeles #SouthernCalifornia #CAStateParks #California

Altadena was an amazing place to visit. It was a community of dreamers, hikers, adventurers. It was a place you could visit to get outside, enjoy some amazing views, and still have the conveniences of being close to the city. It had the most accessible hikes, and it was amazing to have this gem.

It was a place @tayste5000 and I frequented because of its close proximity to Pasadena. It‚Äôs where we did some of our first LA hikes together after I finally moved to LA. It‚Äôs where I woke up extra early to go on a birthday hike on my 30th birthday. It‚Äôs where we would go if we woke up late but still wanted to do a quick hike. And now, these hikes, as well as the community and businesses around it, are gone, and it‚Äôs absolutely devestating. My heart goes out to those who lost everything in the fires.

To honor this amazing place, here‚Äôs some memories from hikes that we did in the past. Locations showcased: Echo Mountain, Mount Lowe, Eaton Canyon, Sunset Ridge, Inspiration Point, and Rubio Canyon (and its waterfall).

Wondering what you can do to protect your health when smoke is in the air? Here are some tips. ‚¨áÔ∏è

Stay Inside ‚Äì Stay alert on air quality conditions with the AirNow Fire and Smoke Map. If you are in an area with poor air quality, stay inside as much as possible. Close windows and doors. 

Wear a Mask ‚Äì If you must go outside, an N95 respirator will provide the best protection against wildfire smoke. Cloth masks will not help. 

Use an Air Cleaner ‚Äì Use a portable air cleaner or make your own using filters and box fans. Check out our website for instructions to make your own DIY air cleaner to reduce smoke indoors.

Take it Easy ‚Äì If you must be outside, in addition to wearing a mask, take frequent breaks indoors and avoid activities that cause heaving breathing, like exercising or mowing the lawn. This will reduce how much smoke you inhale. 

After the Smoke Clears ‚Äì When the air quality improves, even temporarily, open doors and windows to air out your home. If you are near a recent fire, our website has tips to safely clean up ash and debris if necessary.

Keep alert with AirNow‚Äôs fire and smoke map (made by the U.S.Forest Service) at the link üîó in our bio.

It has been a truly devastating week here in Los Angeles as we‚Äôve experienced the worst natural disaster in our country‚Äôs history. Homes and lives have been lost, and the damage is truly unbelievable and absolutely devastating üíî

But there is hope. The helpers are out in force volunteering, donating, and delivering for all who need it. 

I have compiled a list on the following slides, as I have several out-of-town friends who have asked how they can help and where they can donate funds. These are all amazing charity groups and non-profits who have stepped up and are working tirelessly and around the clock. Thank you.

Also, an army of friends, our school community, and brands have come together to make it possible for us to deliver help to several of these families in need directly. We are currently working with four displaced families who lost their homes in the fires, delivering necessities such as clothing, toiletries, children‚Äôs supplies, and more and the list is growing. It was a memorable visit to the Rotary Club of Simi Valley : Club President Coleen Colman McIntyre told her members that I was a foodie and we got to make our own pizza; courtesy of owners/members, Tony and Evelyn Garfield! We had such fun kneading the special dough, spreading the sauces and adding our own toppings while listening to pizza jokes. It‚Äôs more memorable to the club as I put up another‚Äôs club PowerPoint (a district Governor‚Äôs nightmare), recovered quickly and we all had a good laugh. The club is the oldest among the three clubs in Simi Valley : is very strong in peacebuilding; supporting youths - the club helps with building bikes and providing toys for kids; feeding the seniors; supporting other non-profits; and is very proactive in conducting flash fundraisers to help victims in various disasters. Presently, the club is collaborating with the city, Optimists, and various service groups to collect gift cards to send to help the victims and residents who lost their homes in the Palisades and Eaton fires. Club President Coleen McIntyre shared in her Rotary minute that ‚Äútogether, we can turn adversities into opportunities‚Äù. We can help!  I was also endeared to visit with Rotary District 5240 Past District Governor Anil Garg. PDG Anil Garg was my Governor when we started Rotary Club of Cayucos in 2008-2009.  Thanks you Region 2 Executive Assistant Governor Don Martin and Group 5 Assistant Governor Laura Jen Kin Berger for joining me, and Laura, for the fun intro. #rotaryislove #RotaryDistrict5240 #Rotary #simivalley #simivalleyrotary #PalisadesFire #EatonFire #pizza

I was really holding off looking but having my family history burn in the Altadena Fire is hitting me kind of hard. 

Only when I moved away, my mother and I learned that we grew up next to the first home of Andrew McNally at Neff Park in La Mirada, California. He gifted that house as a wedding present and moved to Altadena. 

My understanding is Andrew McNally, co-founder and president of the Rand McNally publishing company. My family McNally were map makers and started in Ireland before coming over to the USA. 

There‚Äôs a McNally house in Chicago, Illinois where the Mapping company started and Neff park, Mr McNally‚Äôs second home in the US but the most impressive home was the Altadena house. 

I‚Äôm still going to try to learn as much as possible about my family. I do know that it has been many many many years since my family actually resided in any of these houses. 2 are historic houses meant for visiting only. And one was still livable with conditions. 

This is so terribly heart breaking. I was holding onto hope that maybe the fire just missed it ü•∫

I‚Äôm still watching the wildfire news. If anyone needs assistance, dm me and I‚Äôll see what I can do. Reach out if you need to talk. Reach out for anything my ghouls and baby bats. Stay safe out there

#californiawildfires #eatonfire #altadenafire #mcnallyaltadenahouse #byebyefamilyhistory #devastating #altadena #malibu #pacificpalisades #sanfernando #sylmar #riverside #losangeles #california #battygonebatty #familyhistory #storytime #stilllearning

Moments after he arrived at the burned out ashes of his own home, he checked in on his neighbor's home that was being threatened by fire. He found father and son attempting to fight back raging, horizontal flame with a garden hose. Dad sprung into action.

I heard his account of what happened later the same day, but it was mixed in with several other anecdotes. My cousin also called to say he had driven past my parents home to see that it was destroyed but didn't stop, both because the whole neighborhood was aflame and also because my dad was being interviewed by a news crew.

"Hmm," I thought, "Dad didn't mention that part in his telling of it to me." Then the news clips started being shared. You may have even seen one that was being shared here on IG.

But even more surreal was somebody sending a picture of the OC Register with my dad, embracing the neighbor's son, after having helped save his home from certain destruction. 

Here's a man who has given his entire life to lift up his family, right down to his grandkids, my kids and my niece. Then at the moment disaster struck, and knowing that his own family were all safely evacuated, applied that same love, care, helps, heroism, compassion - I don't even know what to call it!!! - to his community. My dad.

I believe Pic 1 is the last film photo I took of the front of my parents' home. It's from 2020, and my dad posed at my request. The color digital image is from 2019.

Many have reached out to ask how might they help my mom and dad. We had a family meeting, four households, last night to answer that question ourselves. My sisters and I have discussed several ideas, and if you would like to find out more please DM directly. Particularly if you know my parents personally and have visited the Sinaloa house, please reach out to me directly. 

FYI - some of you have asked, and we have no intention of starting a GFM campaign at this time, in part because Mom and Dad are getting bombarded by scammers who are attempting to do so in their name. 

#eatonfire #altadena #35mmfilmphotography #ocregister #mydad #daddyo #hesordinary

After any disaster, I see two things on my social media feed. The first is a huge number of people coming together to share resources, gather donations, check on their neighbors and help each other. 

The second is unhelpful internet comments that lack empathy for fellow human beings and their experiences of suffering.

Just a friendly reminder that we can care about more than one thing at once, we can feel multiple things at once and these truths are what make us human. Let‚Äôs hold onto our humanity.

I honestly don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôd be without the Lanzarotta family and their home. Their house wasn‚Äôt just a place I spent time‚Äîit‚Äôs where I made most of my early music. Trevor‚Äôs studio in their home is where my artist project began, and without their love and support, I wouldn‚Äôt be where I am today.

Unfortunately, the Lanzarottas, along with many others, lost their home and all their belongings in the devastating Eaton Fire. On top of that, the Palisades Fire has also affected countless families, and it‚Äôs hard to truly grasp the scope of the damage and the heartbreak these communities are facing. My heart goes out to each and every family navigating this unimaginable loss.

To support the Lanzarottas, I‚Äôm releasing a new flip. To download it, I‚Äôm asking for a donation‚Äîevery dollar will go directly to their family to help them through this challenging time.

If my music has ever meant something to you, this is an opportunity to give back to the family who made it all possible for me. Every bit of love and support counts, not just for the Lanzarottas, but for all the families impacted by these fires.

Thank you for showing up for them, and for everyone who‚Äôs struggling right now. Your kindness and generosity mean the world. - Connor

Los Angeles/Nature City üå±üèôÔ∏èüíô pics of the Altadena/Tongvaland past so we remember how to regrow into the future.

From my queer ecology hike with @chaney.trail.corridor last August. üåà

People get this idea of LA as fake, dirty, traffic, and smug. And it kinda is all those things (nobody‚Äôs perfect), BUT it‚Äôs also THIS. 

Or *was* this.

And *will be* a version of this again soon. 

1* verdant vibe views above the Altadena.
2* summer buckwheat rust looking back up.
3* endangered bumblebee persists and resists.
4* community of strangers turn friends on each trail bend.
5* the foothill forest from above, my heart, my love.
6* rare San Gabriel oak Altadena bespoke.
7* don‚Äôt follow the leader, the community leads together.
8* give to each other, all the same Mother.
9* trail to a old/new future.
10* I‚Äôll miss these foothills for the next few years. 
11* but she‚Äôll resprout, have no fear.

Most career firefighters have seen dozens of wildfires, but everyone I‚Äôve spoken to about the Eaton Fire says the same thing‚Äîit‚Äôs the most devastating fire they‚Äôve ever witnessed.

I am incredibly fortunate. My family‚Äôs home, just a short walk from Eaton Canyon and closer to the fire than most of the homes destroyed, is still standing.

The destruction is beyond words‚Äîlike a bomb was dropped, leaving behind toxic ash and heartbreak. Altadena feels forever changed, but in the midst of the devastation, there‚Äôs been an outpouring of kindness and support.

I want to thank everyone who has stepped up to help‚Äîespecially the restaurants we work with. You‚Äôve been feeding evacuees, first responders, and families in need, offering not just meals but a sense of hope and care during this unimaginable time.

To anyone looking for ways to help, please support these incredible local businesses‚Äîthey‚Äôve been there for the community when people needed them most.

Thank you to everyone who‚Äôs reached out, supported, and shown up for our community. Your kindness means everything.

The Eaton Fire burned up thousands of acres and buildings in Altadena and Pasadena, killing at least 16 people. A dozen schools in Southern California were damaged or destroyed in the Los Angeles fires, and according to teachers union leaders, nearly 20% of the teachers living in Altadena and Pasadena had their living situations were impacted by the Eaton Fire alone.

Now, those educators are left navigating both how to rebuild their own lives while helping their students rebuild their own.

‚ÄúA lot of our members have responded that they just, they can‚Äôt imagine how they could possibly come back to work and care for these students emotionally, at this exact moment,‚Äù Jonathan Gardner, the president of United Teachers of Pasadena said.

AQI (Air Quality Index) in Los Angeles is improving, but Angelenos could still be exposed to harmful materials through inhalation in some areas.
¬†¬†
The AQI measures particulate matter in the air, but it doesn‚Äôt measure their toxicity. The particles and gases in the air right now are much more toxic than normal because they are from burning houses which have all kinds of toxic materials like asbestos, plastic, copper, lead, which we don‚Äôt usually have in our air.
¬†¬†
Around 90% of wildfire smoke is made up of PM2.5 particles.
¬†¬†
PM 2.5 are fine particulate matter smaller than 2.5 micrometers in diameter, 30 times smaller than a human hair. Such fine particulate matter is particularly harmful to our health because they can travel deep into the lungs and enter our blood stream, causing everything from inflammation to asthma attacks to sudden cardiac death.
¬†¬†
A recent study smoke exposure from California wildfires between 2008 and 2018 estimated that up to 55,710 premature deaths were attributable to wildfire-related PM2.5 in the air. A link to the study published in¬†Science Advances Journal can be found below.
¬†¬†
As a Los Angeles based herbal company, Dragon Herbs is here to support Angelenos through this unprecedented natural disaster.
¬†¬†
We are giving away 2 free KN95 masks per Angeleno in our West LA/Beverly Hills store. No purchase needed.¬†

KN95 masks¬†are specifically designed and tested to filter out at least 95% PM 2.5¬†particulates in the air.
¬† ¬†
Sources:¬†
EPA, Science Advances Journal, LAIST.com, South Coast Air Quality Management District https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sciadv.adl1252

As Mr. Rogers famously reminded us, ‚ÄúLook for the helpers. You will always find people who are helping.‚Äù We‚Äôre happpy to share timely resources from a few of the helpers. 

üíõ @institute4girls is offering a free webinar to support parents as they help their young children navigate confusion, fear and strong emotions as they make sense of the devastation around them. The webinar will cover how to explain the fires and evacuations in a way that is comforting and developmentally appropriate. Their therapists will also explore the common emotional and behavioral responses children may have to disasters like this and provide practical strategies to help children feel safe and supported during this time while mitigating the effects of trauma.

The Altadena Historical Society archives have survived the fire. We have not yet been able to return to check their condition. Most of our volunteers have lost their homes, however. We plan to be active in the very near future as Altadena rebuilds and restores. For the time being, we will be posting (as time permits!) archival images that I have stored on my laptop about 50 miles away from Altadena. We will try to find images of places where we know the current status. By the way, a fraction of our archives have already been digitized and our database is in 'the cloud.' 

This image is of Easter Rock, taken in 1902. Easter Rock looks down on Altadena from high upon the ridge next to Inspiration Point. The fire reached this point, but granite does not burn and the rock still stands. The wooden shelter at Inspiration Point did not survive, unfortunately.

REQUEST:

Hello R2R & Podcast Community,

As many of you know, my wife and I lost our home in the devastating #eatonfire in #altadena last week. 

Along with our home, all my podcasting gear was destroyed in the fire. I‚Äôve been podcasting since 2014 and it has been such a vital aspect of my life. I‚Äôve met incredible friends through podcasting. I‚Äôve had unthinkable experiences like interviewing childhood heroes of mine through podcasting. Podcasting is more than just a hobby, it‚Äôs been the way I‚Äôve been able to creatively express myself through storytelling.

I‚Äôm reaching out to anyone here who might have a spare podcasting mic that they wouldn‚Äôt mind me borrowing/using for the time being.

Over the last few days, I‚Äôve had this internal charge to use my podcasting skills and experience to tell the stories of people from my beloved community of Altadena. 

If there‚Äôs anyway you‚Äôd like to help in this effort, feel free to DM.

You are loved and I feel that same love back at me,

-Max

A week of rising above adversity, not as the west side or the east side, but as one community. As we take a couple of days to process and regroup, we look forward to another weekend of giving back to the community in LA we love so much. We will be cooking up a storm for @thedreamcenter ‚Äî they are out there doing Gods work üíô

It‚Äôs always been instilled in me to cook with love, but I don‚Äôt think any meal I‚Äôve ever made had more love in it than the meals that went out to fire evacuees and front liners last weekend. I think I can speak for @ongsupernovaong @andreasagx & @jodylu_ who have been volunteering their time to help LA. Love you all. 

Thank you to our donors, you know who you are, who have contributed to making this happen. We‚Äôre excited to partner with a couple vegan protein brands to get as many meals out as possible in the next run so that evacuees and front liners can have access to plant-based food. If you‚Äôre a vegan brand or farm that wants to donate product to us to cook for LA evacuees and front liners, DM meüôèüèº

Thank you to Natalie @sugarpirates for reaching out to me on behalf of @forbes & @forbesadvisors so that insights from the ground can reach 300,000+ more people  who want to direct their money to the tragedy happening in our dear LA. Evacuees want our focus on monetary donations like gift cards of all kinds including Visa gift cards! Newsletter in linked in bio. 

For those of you interested in volunteering, I have linked a couple of resources in my bio: the LA Fire Volunteer Squad on a What‚Äôs App group which links 200 and counting Angelenos dedicated to assisting our community from ways to volunteer on the ground, from home, with donations, animals, housing, etc. 

There is also a google form in my bio where you can sign up to volunteer, right now we need people who can shop for donations needed and dispatchers. Great way to stay informed and involved long term!

Despite the green map from the South Coast Air Quality Management District, showing air quality in Los Angeles County is ‚Äúgood‚Äù in some areas, people should continue to take precautions outdoors, as a windblown dust and ash advisory remains in effect until Wednesday evening.

‚ÄúIn most situations (the AQMD map) provides the whole picture. This is sort of a unique situation where we have a lot of ash down at levels where people live that could pose a health issue and won‚Äôt show up on our AQI map,‚Äù said Dr. Scott Epstein, air quality assessment manager at AQMD.

Get your tickets today at 1500Day.com!

Week 2

The second week of 2025 brought a stark shift from what felt like a smooth start to the new year. Just as we were settling back into life after the holidays, our home of Los Angeles was turned upside down.

I‚Äôm endlessly grateful to be safe, but my heart is with the hundreds of thousands who have been displaced. Many of them are friends, neighbors, and familiar faces in our community. It‚Äôs overwhelming to even imagine the heartbreak of losing everything in an instant.

In times like these, all we can do is show up‚Äîto help, to give, to lift each other up in every way possible.

And that‚Äôs what this city is doing. People from every corner are coming together, as countless heroes continue risking everything to fight these devastating fires.

Los Angeles is resilient. And together, we‚Äôll get through this. 

The first seven slides are photos I saw over the last week. I take no credit for those.

#losangeles #palisadesfire #eatonfire

Update 1/16/2025: Organizer Chelsea Kirk started the rent-gouging spreadsheet on her own. SAJE and ACT-LA are not formally collaborating on the price gouging spreadsheets.

We‚Äôre already seen widespread reports of landlords price-gouging ‚Äî raising the asking rent on apartments by more than 10% during a state of emergency. This is illegal in California under Penal Code Section 396.

LA Tenants Union organizer and attorney Jacob Woocher joined LA Public Press audience director Mariah Casta√±eda (@papayathemariah) for a live Q&A on Instagram to talk about what people can do in response.

Swipe through for some tips on how to report and organize against rent-gouging after the LA fires. Read the conversation via the link in our bio or at LAPublicPress.org. üóûÔ∏è üîó üëâ

| ùìóùì∏ùìπùìÆ ùê¢ùê¨ ùêõùêûùê¢ùêßùê† ùêöùêõùê•ùêû ùê≠ùê® ùê¨ùêûùêû ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùìµùì≤ùì∞ùì±ùìΩ ùêùùêûùê¨ùê©ùê¢ùê≠ùêû ùêöùê•ùê• ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêùùêöùê´ùê§ùêßùêûùê¨ùê¨.¬†

üìç Los Angeles County, California¬†
üóìÔ∏è 2015-present day¬†

I think most of us have felt the same way this past week. We are grieving the loss of our beloved trails, (some) homes, and sadly the loss of life as well. I have kept you all affected by this massive tragedy in my thoughts and prayers. I‚Äôve loved these places now reduced to ashes fiercely and will continue to do so beyond rebuilding and restoring. I whole heartedly pray the road to recovery and rebuilding isn‚Äôt a painful journey but rather a journey filled with hope and light.¬†

Californians this past week have been a light for those who have had to face darkness in this time. I hope that light continues to shine through in the next few days, weeks, months, and years to come. It won‚Äôt be easy but it won‚Äôt be impossible - if you have been affected know you are not alone. There is a community of people doing good and helping hands ready to shine that light. ¬†

‚ô°Ô∏é Will Rogers SP: a place mom and I used over the last 10 years as our retreat from life, a sanctuary to our mental health, and a place that brought us so much joy and peace over the years;¬†

‚ô°Ô∏é Eaton Canyon (Echo Mtn)/Inspiration Point: One of the first hikes that conditioned my legs, my lungs, my mental health before doing peaks;¬†

‚ô°Ô∏é Parker Mesa, Pacific Palisades: where my love for Coastal Hiking grew more intense and where I found friends that helped shape the next few years in my outdoors journey;¬†

‚ô°Ô∏é Mt. Wilson Trail (both via Santa Anita/Sierra Madre Trail and Chantry Flats): The trail that has thought me so much‚Ä¶ frm believing in myself to breaking me down with one of the worst news one can possibly get; 

‚ô°Ô∏é Escondido Canyon: one of my early hikes when I was wearing cute cotton dresses and Keds (I‚Äôve done a whole lot of learning). Later morphing to a beautiful place to bring friends and family for an enjoyable getaway.¬†

These are just a few of the places that have shaped and strengthened me over the years. My heart is with you Los Angeles.

"It takes a village."

A disaster of this magnitude requires a team effort, and we are immensely grateful to everyone who has stepped in since the fires began last week. We‚Äôre working closely with local officials, government agencies and other nonprofits to coordinate relief efforts and make recovery plans. Red Crossers from across the country are on the ground helping and truckloads of supplies like cots, blankets, water and relief items are available to support thousands of additional people if needed. Donors and partners have given generously to ensure our support of people in need can continue for as long as we're needed. The work is not easy, and demands long days and much effort. But thanks to the many people, partners, agencies and organizations we are privileged to work with, our mission not only continues, but thrives.

Photo by Mimi Rogers/American Red Cross

It is incredible to see the amount of support victims of the fires are receiving üôè A big thanks to all the #jornaleros from the @pasadenajobcenter who are taking leadership roles, even those who don't speak English. 

Their motto, "Solo el pueblo salva al pueblo," truly shows their commitment with labor and long hours of paid and unpaid work. 

Many of them also lost their jobs because they used to work in the burned areas. However, instead of ignoring the issue, they are helping clean and rebuild the cities of #Pasadena and #Altadena 

Volunteers are also amazing. Just to give you an idea, the center started with 57 volunteers last Thursday and went up to 1,500 volunteers on Saturday and more than 400 volunteers on Tuesday. 

A big shout out too to all the restaurants and organizations that are sending lots of food for these volunteers. I have been there a few days and now I can truly share the sentiment of many. By seeing these efforts, we realize there is so much good in people, and that gives us hope for what comes ahead. 

Do you want to help or need help? Visit them at 500 N. Lake Ave in Pasadena.

Today, a fellow first responder, an LAPD officer, visited Barton heliport. He was looking to personally thank the crew working on Copter 15 on 1/8 during the early afternoon of the Eaton fire. His neighborhood and home was immediately threatened by the flame front in his hometown of Sierra Madre. With resources stretched thin, Copter 15 made a few critical drops that helped save it. We appreciate the support and gratitude by all in the community during these tough times. Our thoughts and prayers are with all who have been affected. It‚Äôs crucial for workers to know our rights. 

Given the continuing climate crisis we‚Äôll be pinning a summary of some of the tips our members have found useful from our allies and other organizations. Be sure to check back as we may update our pins!

CAL/OSHA requires employers to reduce workers‚Äô exposure to wildfire smoke and follow certain protocols.

Senate Bill 1044 prohibits retaliation from employers in the case of an employee refusing to work due to an emergency condition (such as an evacuation order). Not all classifications of employees are covered by SB 1044*

Protect your health by staying updated on air quality in your area with airnow.gov.

 Tips for when there is Bad Air Quality:
Limit vigorous physical activity.
Keep windows and doors closed.
Use an N95 or P100 mask outdoors.

More tips at bit.ly/airqtips

Check out @uclalabor, @center4workersrights, @ca_dir, @chirla_org, @senatormed, @legalaidatwork, @uclalosh, @bettzedek for more information and resources

A huge thanks to @therealhuntergreene and his dad Russell Greene for providing new spikes to the kids in the program affected by the Altadena Eaton fire. Hunter is New York doing work with @nike before heading down to report with pitchers and catchers for spring training in Arizona. It was awesome to talk the man who help develop one of the best players all time to come out of the LA area. He gave my boys such great insight and advice on their development as ball players but also as men off the field. He is all about competition and playing against the best. Russell shared stories how he and Hunter would hand pick tournaments that the top players were going to attend. They did this not just to compete against the best players but to crush them üí™. He is very open and nice so the 2 hours we talked was easy and went by in the blink of eye. My heart is always with the boys in blue down at Chavez Ravine, however I definitely now have a second team in the big red machine ‚ù§Ô∏è. Once again a huge thank you to the Greene family for showing our kids love and support!

It was just before my live report on another story last Tuesday morning on the 7th when @old_nate spotted a plume of smoke over my shoulder off in the distance. In less than an hour, we were in Pacific Palisades reporting on an epic disaster. We‚Äôve been on the go ever since, also reporting on the tragic losses in Altadena. It‚Äôs been dangerous (thanks to Nate for risking fiery close calls with me), heart stopping and heartbreaking. I‚Äôm too exhausted to reflect or write anything eloquently. Sincere thoughts and prayers for those impacted. Thank you, first responders. ‚ù§Ô∏è #palisadesfire #eatonfire #socalfires #lastrong

Everyone who dines at Bone Kettle knows or will come to find out that our dining room is an unofficial shrine to Cleon Peterson‚Äôs art- his large golden painting is the glorious centerpiece of every Bone Kettle dinner. 

When we built the restaurant about 8 years ago, never in our wildest dreams would we have the honor of being the custodian of a Cleon Peterson masterpiece in our restaurant. 4 large metaphorical warrior figures ferociously guarding our dining room, filling the space with magic. It is a privilege to know and consider him and his family ‚Äì our friends.

Cleon, Kelly, Aubrey, Coco, Huxley and Pepper unfortunately lost their home in the Eaton Fire. This weekend, we spotlight and support the Peterson family as they rebuild their lives. We will be donating a portion of our weekend sale to help their fundraising efforts.

Cleon is also selling a limited edition print (link available on our bio) to fuel their rebuilding efforts. As a current collector of Cleon‚Äôs prints, I can attest that his prints add a lot of substance to any room. 

If you have the capacity to help this incredibly deserving artist get back on his feet- come & dine with us this weekend, we are back open even for brunch and lunch üíï

The Petersons also have a Gofundme where you can contribute directly. Thank you for your support and kindness #denastrong #cleonpeterson #eatonfire #bonekettle

Through challenges and uncertainty, our community shines with resilience and gratitude. The road ahead still holds challenges, but hope is in the air and progress is being made!

We are endlessly grateful to the firefighters and first responders who have worked tirelessly to protect our town. Thanks to their courage, the Sierra Madre Playhouse stands ready to welcome you back when the time is right.

Live arts have always been a source of connection and healing, and we‚Äôre eager to play our part in bringing light back to our community. In the days ahead, we‚Äôll be exploring ways to support those affected by the fires, including the artists who enrich our lives with their work.

Together, we endure. Together, we rebuild. And soon, together, we‚Äôll create, laugh, and be inspired once more.

Historically, Altadena and Pasadena were rare places where, in the decades after segregation, Black families could buy homes and put down roots.

Many residents have lived there for decades in homes passed down for generations from parents to their children.

Now, some fear the fire will change that way of life in the neighborhoods.

Read more at the link in our bio.

üì∑: Victoria Ivie, Pasadena Star News/SCNG

‚ÄºÔ∏èüö®üëâüèæ @hawkinshob Mattie‚Äôs (Cynthia Hawkins sister) house was one of the many that tragically burned in the Eaton fire. Over 40 years ago, she and her late husband physically built that house in Altadena with their own hands. 

They originally built it because she dreamed of starting a group home for foster care children üíñ

For many years, she fulfilled that dream, providing a loving and supportive family environment to young men who had little or no connection with their biological parentsüôèüèæ

Her home wasn‚Äôt just a house‚Äîit was a safe haven, a place of love, and a foundation for so many cherished memories. From celebrations and family gatherings, and it was always filled with warmth and joy. Recently, she mentioned wanting to host the next family reunion thereü´∂üèæ

Now, that home is gone üò¢ ‚Äîburned to ashes. The family pictures collected over the years, her clothes, her many wigs‚Äîeverything has been lost. 

While we are so grateful for her safety and the memories we hold in our hearts, it‚Äôs heartbreaking to know that the place where she raised her children and grandchildren now exists only in their hearts and minds.

To support visit @hawkinshob bio üôèüèæ

Carlos Garcia Salda√±a drove past block after block of homes, businesses, and churches ‚Äúwiped off the face of the earth.‚Äù The Eaton fire that had consumed large parts of Altadena was still burning in the San Gabriel Mountains. The charter network leader needed to see what remained of his schools.‚Å†
‚Å†
Over the past week, wind-whipped wildfires reshaped wide swaths of Los Angeles, claiming at least 25 lives and destroying more than 12,000 structures. A dozen or more schools have been damaged or destroyed. The danger is not yet past, with fires only partially contained and high winds forecast through Wednesday.‚Å†
‚Å†
Hundreds of thousands of students were out of school last week as more than 1,000 schools across 19 districts announced temporary closures due to poor air quality, shifting evacuation orders, and the many educators, school staff, and student families who had lost their homes.‚Å†
‚Å†
As Garcia Salda√±a approached Odyssey Charter School South, the facade and main entrance appeared intact. But as he looked left and up the hill, he saw a heap of twisted metal and charred rubble where, two days earlier, there had been classrooms, offices, lunch tables, play structures, and an after-school clubhouse. The tree stumps where students used to sit and eat and dream were still smoldering.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just jarring and heartbreaking,‚Äù Garcia Salda√±a said.‚Å†
‚Å†
Now Garcia Salda√±a‚Äôs days are consumed with checking on the many families and staff who lost their homes and looking for a space where students could return to school as soon as possible.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio. ‚Å†
‚Å†
üì∏: Courtesy of Carlos Garc√≠a Saldana/Odyssey Charter Schools

My dear friend Maria and her husband lost everything in the Eaton Fire. Maria has held my hand and lifted my spirit many, many times at my absolute lowest points. I can safely say she is one of the people who helped make it possible for me to serve the way I do today. 

This the gofundme set up for Maria and Mike https://gofund.me/a6dd70c9 and it is legit. Please ONLY use this link for them as, sadly, there are individuals who are exploiting this terrible tragedy. 

As part of the devastation, Maria lost the sacred Sage Spirit Farm which she established in 2020 in the backyard of their home. Browse her website (sagespiritfarm.com) and you will see the extraordinary devotion she brought to the space. Her respect for indigenous history, plant medicine, and practice made her a worthy steward of the task, which she performed with deep reverence, humility, and joy. It‚Äôs so painful to know how much my friends have lost. So many people are hurting and afraid. 

Please consider donating AND sharing. Any amount is most appreciated. Amid this hideous catastrophe, it is so comforting to see the outpouring of support, regardless of the size of the contribution.

When designing the Armcandy for a Cause bracelet to benefit those affected by the wildfires in California, Oriana chose the red howlite bead as a symbol of strength and resilience. Red, a powerful and passionate color, represents the unwavering courage of the communities affected by these devastating events. The fiery hue echoes both the intensity of the wildfires and the indomitable spirit of those who rise from the ashes to rebuild their lives.

The howlite stone, known for its calming properties, complements the boldness of red, signifying balance and hope amidst chaos. By pairing these elements, Oriana created a meaningful piece that embodies not only the struggles faced by these communities but also the strength and solidarity of those coming together to support them. Each bracelet is a reminder that even in the face of devastation, resilience shines through.

The bracelet is adorned with a Pav√© Rainbow charm and an ‚ÄúI‚ù§Ô∏èLA‚Äù / California state charm. The rainbow symbolizes beauty and hope after the storm and serves as a reminder that even after the darkest moments, light and renewal can emerge. Grounding the design in purpose and serving as a heartfelt tribute to the affected region. The charms act as a reminder of the connection between the wearer and the resilient spirit of California‚Äôs people. Paired with howlite beads, known for their calming and grounding properties, the design represents both the perseverance needed to endure challenges and the promise of brighter days ahead while the bracelet becomes a symbol of balance and hope amidst chaos.

Through this thoughtful creation, Oriana crafted a meaningful piece that not only supports recovery efforts but also celebrates the strength, unity, and perseverance of the California community and gives hope to those affected by the wildfires. #HopeForLA  #PrayForLa

Meet Emily. She‚Äôs 16. Emily and her family lost their home last week in the Eaton fire. Today Emily took the courage and shared her story with me. She told me how her family of 9 had to evacuate and leave their home in a matter of minutes during the late night. She told me how they have a little baby in the family and her brother couldn‚Äôt save his belongings because he was focused on saving the babies. Emily told me how her mom was still wearing the same shoes they evacuated with. My heart breaks for them hearing they lost everything. Emily had the courage and strength to share her story with me at only 16 years old. She told me she couldn‚Äôt afford to fall into depression and she has to stay strong for her mom. Emily started their families go fund me page and it is linked in my bio. To some it‚Äôs nothing but to one it‚Äôs everything. I‚Äôm really grateful Emily shared her story with me and I haven‚Äôt stopped thinking about her since. We decided maybe together if I share her story, we may reach someone who can help their family sooner than later. So here we are coming together as a community and asking yours for help ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π please don‚Äôt film in the areas if it‚Äôs not for charities. Unfortunately a known YouTube group was pretending the houses burnt around them was theirs and we witnessed the heartbreaking exchanges as neighbors fought for privacy. Any content shared of Emily‚Äôs story is with mutual consent by her and her family. Thank you for reading and together we can seed hope and love into one person at a time. #eatonfire #nonprofit #donate #community

Managing stress during times of uncertainty, grief, loss, and or a crisis, like many have faced this past week with the California wildfires, can be extremely challenging, especially when you are trying to hold space for yourself and your child simultaneously. 

So we (@drrachelnyc and @theparentologist) have teamed up to share some professional mental health advice as parents ourselves. We first want to remind you that it‚Äôs ok to not be ok and that you are not alone. In these circumstances, remind yourself to take a day at a time and that you are doing your best. 

If you have any questions about any of these tips, please let us know. Please share this post or tag loved ones who may need this support!

Thank you to friends and family near and far for the check-ins amidst these devastating fires in Los Angeles County. I am thankful that I and my immediate family live and work in the City of Los Angeles which has remained largely unthreatened. But like everyone in the region, I know half a dozen people and counting who have lost their homes, businesses, pets... My magical elementary school, The Pasadena Waldorf School (Altadena), burned. 

So did my former art studio on Boston Street at Lake in Altadena (photos 1-2). ("Former" because I moved out in 2023 and have been working from home since. I shudder to think of losing my artwork to fire.) This delightfully quirky complex was built by the landlord's father in the 1930s! I found my way there thanks to the ever-generous Shannon @shannonosullivantattoo, director of the Secret Land residency that I enjoyed for the month of October 2021, also in Altadena. SECRET LAND SURVIVED!!! But Shannon and her daughter Rose‚Äôs tattoo studio, SHANGRI-LA TATTOO, was in the Boston Street complex. If you came to my reception at Secret Land, then you can imagine Shangri-La‚Äîit was a transportive den of colors, textures, incense, and walls covered with artwork. (Photos 2-3 from Shannon's IG.) Now Shannon and Rose must find a new home and supplies for their business.

For the month of January, I WILL BE DONATING 40% OF ART SALES TO SHANNON AND ROSE'S GOFUNDME. (40% is the cut that typically goes to a gallery.) To this end, I would especially love to sell art I made at Secret Land and Boston Street. I will be posting those pieces in my stories for the next while, so stay tuned and DM if interested. You can browse other work on my website (link in bio). And of course you can donate directly to the GoFundMe (link in bio). The GoFundMe is 85% of the way to the goal. Let's put it over the top! Thank you
