In the aftermath of the Los Angeles wildfires, abandoned cars sit silently in the streets, reduced to haunting shells like creatures gone extinct. 

The fossil fuels that once powered this vehicle (and still fuel tens of thousands more) are a major contributor to climate change and the intensity of the wildfires. But drivers have had few alternatives in a world dependent on gas powered vehicles‚Äî and some are now left victims to the effects.

Out of destruction, beautiful things can take shape. 

Through the tears, my heart catches in my throat with gratitude. I had just moved to New York when 9/11 took place, and the unity of that community was something I never thought I‚Äôd experience again. It‚Äôs happening now in Los Angeles. My WhatsApp chats are full of people coordinating volunteer and donation efforts. People are welcoming strangers who have lost everything into their homes. Differences that might cause people to avoid each other are falling away. 

The country has been crying with us, and we‚Äôve felt your love and support and fervent prayers for the wind and the flames to stop.

Firefighters from all over the world came to defend our city; the last count I heard was 5000.

On #thisisthewaywednesday, I want to say thank you. And I want to highlight just a few of the ways you can help, whether you are local are far away. I also want to ask you to remember the people who are still struggling from events of 2024 including Hurricane Helene. I am thrilled to hear that my home church in Los Angeles, @cornerstonewla , will be a staging ground for the next few months for @samaritanspurse, an organization that provided tent hospitals in New York City during Covid, remains on the ground for Helene victims, and makes a commitment in all their efforts to stay until the work is done.

Let‚Äôs not forget this feeling of community. We can rise above, soften our hearts, and endure.

I‚Äôm not great at promoting myself in the best of times, and this past week has not been anything we could confuse with that. 

But, I will be performing with my genius friend @jasonrobertbrownstagram at the @segerstromarts in Costa Mesa this Thursday 1/16-Saturday 1/18. 

If you live out that way, or don‚Äôt mind the drive and need a break, we‚Äôd love to have you there to interject a little joy into a week where it‚Äôs been literally (asthma and this air quality) and figuratively hard to breathe.

I kept thinking we might cancel, but that‚Äôs not what artists do in times of crisis. We create, and we hope to be able to shift the air with what we do- even when we ourselves are struggling. 

Now, I‚Äôve been blessed to be safe during this wild week, but SO many are living an active tragedy. The only way I could share the info about our show with a clear conscious is also to highlight someone who really needs assistance. 

 So this post is also about the beautiful spirit (please forgive the taciturn looking screenshot) that is @blairimani. ELEVEN of her family members have lost their homes and are now living with her and her husband. This includes 5 children, and several sets of parents. Her 85year old aunt has also lost her home.  All of them from Altadena and Pasadena. They have  lost everything to the Eaton fire. What remains is love, each other and a spirit of perseverance. But they need our help. 

Please visit Blair Imani‚Äôs page, learn more of her story and those of the extended families that moved in with her. And if you have some left to  give after all the giving you‚Äôve already done, please click her go fund me link.

After that, if you want to see an asthmatic and a genius defy the odds this weekend, it would be our great joy to have you at the Samueli theater in the  Segerstrom Arts‚Äô Center. 

With love, blessings, and hope. ‚Ä¶and a few nerves.

~ANRüåπ

‚ö°Ô∏èLOST ‚ö°Ô∏èWe‚Äôre heartbroken to share that 1366 E. Palm in Altadena, a historical treasure, has been mostly destroyed in the Eaton fire. Built in 1915, this stunning example of Churrigueresque architecture was more than just a home‚Äîit was a piece of living history. Its ornate fa√ßade, inspired by the intricate Spanish Baroque style, still stands, but reports confirm that the rest of this architectural gem has been lost.

This home wasn‚Äôt just admired for its beauty‚Äîit was a star in its own right. It first appeared in the 1921 Max Linder silent film Seven Years Bad Luck. Over the decades, it became a favorite filming location for TV and film productions, appearing in Knots Landing, Ratched, and most recently Palm Royale.

Do you know more about the history of this home? Maybe a story, a connection, or even a memory? Let‚Äôs honor its legacy by sharing what we can. Drop your thoughts in the comments below.

It's been one of the scariest, most stressful last weeks here in Los Angeles. Pieces of our city are missing and it just hurts to even think about it. But it's also beautiful to see people banding together and caring for each other whatever ways they can. I met a man and the group of special needs individuals he was taking care of today while volunteering at Santa Anita Park, Their group home in Altadena burned down and so several of them are living in a hotel room not knowing where their next meal is coming from. People are navigating incredibly difficult challenges right now, and there are so many ways to support them not just now but the coming months. I have some resources linked in my bio for where to get help and where you can continue to donate/volunteer. also huge thank you to everyone who checked in or offered me and my family a place to stay, I hope its safe to say the worst of the fires are over now.?! its been exhausting and I hope all are getting rest and stress relief who need it.. one thing I can say is now we gonna stay ready üôè  much love L.A. ‚ù§Ô∏è

*GOOD NEWS*

Multiple sources say that the exquisite Casa Andalusia defied the odds and survived! 

Every little bit of good news is greatly appreciated right now, and this is particularly wonderful because this property is stunning and so special! Apparently the house right next to it burned down, but somehow this survived, much like the blue Volkswagon bus! Did you happen to see that? Right in the middle of thousands of houses burned to the ground in Altadena, somehow a Volkswagen bus survived! It seems to have some sort of magical properties that protected it, or so they say. I'm going to look for more information on it but that seemed miraculous, as does this!

Here's to miracles! More about this house: This is the 1926 Casa Andalusia, Spanish Colonial Revival villa with Moorish influences designed by Maurice Swetland, the son of a New York publisher responsible for American Architect magazine. Boasting 5BR/5BA, the half acre estate features original details and period finishes such as Saltillo tile flooring, original wall sconces and original bathroom tile and cathedral-beamed ceilings.

Hi everyone, it has been a very sad, scary, stressful and devastating week in Los Angeles. First, I want to thank @losangelesfiredepartment @lapdhq @us.nationalguard and all the #firefighter that came here from around the country and the world to help our city. Luckily, Alex and I have our home and have had power. Our town has been covered in smoke and the air quality has been borderline hazardous. We‚Äôve been sweeping ash off of our cars and balcony. Other communities only 10 miles away have been leveled from the fires. We were just by Sunset and Topanga beach 2 days before the #palisadesfire started and luckily able to enjoy our favorite seafood restaurant @reelinnmalibu one last time. I brought my parents to see Christmas lights in the Upper Hastings Ranch community this last December whose houses are no longer there after being burned by the #eatonfire . If you are able to, please donate to help the families who have lost everything and whose communities are very dear to our hearts which make living in Los Angeles so special.

I will post organizations for donations and updates on the fires in my story and they will also be in my story highlights.

‚ù§Ô∏èHEAR ME OUT: Read through all the posts before you comment. 

‚ù§Ô∏èOur hearts have been devastated by the California wildfires this last week. We know so many who have lost everything. It is devastating and heartbreaking. So many of us long to help. Help is a beautiful thing and I think it‚Äôs even more beautiful when our help is helpful to those we are helping. 

Pain is pain. Some may have lost everything. Some may be displaced from their home. Some may have witnessed the devastation. All are valid and traumatic in their own right. All must be dealt with tenderly. 

There‚Äôs so much goodness and love in the world. Let‚Äôs make sure that message lands as we serve our communities with just some minor tweaks. I myself have been guilty of donating used items over the years, simply because side I no longer want them‚Ä¶ but very few others would have likely wanted them too. This has changed me. Let‚Äôs give our best. Thank you to everyone who is pouring their time, hearts, closets, logistics, prayers, money, and expertise into helping LA fire victims. We stand with you. 

#cafires #palisadesfire #eatonfire #donatenow #loveheals

It‚Äôs hard to put into words what it has been like here in LA this past week. Devastation beyond measure. Heartbreak. Lives, homes, dreams destroyed in flames. Lifetimes of investment gone in a moment. So much loss. I can‚Äôt process it all, but I do know the deep sadness I feel. I am so fortunate to not be directly impacted, so I wonder if I‚Äôm even allowed to be sad. But I do love this city, and the people in it. So I am sad. For the thousands of people who are facing this tragedy, trying to figure out how to move forward and resurrect a life from the ashes. It‚Äôs overwhelming. Of course so is the response. The gratitude for the firefighters and first responders risking their lives to keep us safe. The people who have flown in across state and country lines to help. My industry, my colleagues, working around the clock for days on end to keep people informed. The volunteers. I am amazed and fascinated at the hundreds of ways people are showing up. How vastly different each individual is, with unique talents and capabilities. And how beautiful and powerful  it is when everyone contributes in their own way. Some are cooking, some collecting, others donating, organizing, taking photos, taking in animals, raising funds, sharing stories, driving loads, providing aid, offering childcare, there are SO many different ways that our city is showing up. And each of us crafted in a different way to contribute. I can get overwhelmed by the magnitude of destruction, and feel powerless to stop it. I saw a quote that said something along the lines of doing for one person what you wish you could do for thousands. And I think that‚Äôs a powerful idea. No act of kindness too small. Help one person. Connect someone else that can fill a need. Do what you can with what you have. Small steps, move us forward. I hope and pray that together we will. #lastrong #palisadesfire #eatonfire #abc #abcnews 
üì∏: @ricardo.monteroh

Eaton Fire Informational Town Hall 

Date: Jan 16, 2025 10:00 AM PST

Zoom Link: https://bit.ly/4hgoQqy (or link in stories) 

Walkup Shareholder Michael Kelly will be one of the speakers at an informational town hall about the Eaton Fire.  This virtual town hall is intended to serve as a resource for Eaton Fire victims seeking guidance on any questions they may have as well as provide an opportunity to discuss upcoming challenges facing our communities. Topics for discussion will include recovery and insurance issues ‚Äì how and when to make a claim, what to do about your mortgage if your home was destroyed as a result of fire, concerns of erosion and landslides when the rains return to our region, and possible recovery of uninsured losses.

A #GoFundMe has been set up to support displaced Black victims of the  Eaton Fireüî•. üîó to give in bio.

Physical donations are also being accepted in South Los Angeles at Prince Hall, 9027 S. Figueroa St., Los Angeles, CA 90003. Items needed include blankets and pillows, clothing of all sizes, undergarments, toiletries/essentials, children‚Äôs toys and games, phone chargers, extension cords, and adult and children‚Äôs diapers. 

Attorneys for California‚Äôs two largest Black firms have united to create a fund to help displaced Black victims of the Eaton Fire.  The Cochran Firm and Ivie McNeil Wyatt Purcell and Diggs, along with The Most Worshipful Prince Hall Grand Lodge Free and Accepted Masons State of California Inc., have established an official and trusted GoFundMe campaign where 100% of the funds raised will be used to assist the victims impacted in the Pasadena/Altadena Community.

The impact on these Black residents has been devastating as a large population of these families has lost everything. Furthermore, many of these homes that were burned in the fires were not insured for fire disasters, whether it be due to insurance companies who recently canceled thousands of fire insurance policies in the past few months, or owners who simply did not have fire insurance as it was not required because the property did not have a mortgage. 
 
A large portion of the nearly 20,000 Black residents are displaced, with nowhere to go other than temporary shelters. Due to the fact that a number of the older residents were on fixed incomes, whether they were homeowners, renters, or living in one of the assisted living facilities, that were destroyed, this sensitive population is left completely at risk.

In my last post, I let everyone know I want to donate my services to individuals and families who foster or adopt a pooch from any of the LA shelters or rescue organizations taking in displaced animals from the recent fires. Please check out my previous post to read more, including some of the shelters you can contact üêæüíï

For anyone who FOSTERS, I would love to offer you my 2-hour ‚ÄúConnecting Parents & their Pooches‚Äù first-time bonding session. The first session is on me, and additional teaching sessions (up to three) will be significantly discounted ü©µ

For anyone who ADOPTS, you‚Äôre a literal savior and I want to do everything I can to ensure that you and the newest member of your family live the fullest and happiest life together‚ù£Ô∏èI‚Äôd love nothing more than to offer you the following on me (100% discounted):
- my 2-hour ‚ÄúConnecting Parents & their Pooches‚Äù first-time bonding session 
- a 1-hour ‚ÄúPack Walk Wednesday‚Äù with my pooches & me
- a day at ‚ÄúPooch Camp‚Äù with my happy pooch campers & me (you will be required to join your pooch in camp üòò)
***In addition, I will offer significant discounts on future services for the first 365 days with your pooch! 

Please DM me for more details and with any questions. I will only ask that you provide the paperwork verifying that you recently fostered or adopted from an LA SHELTER or RESCUE ORGANIZATION who is actively taking in animals from the fires üôèüèΩüôèüèΩüôèüèΩ @pasadenahumane @laanimalservices @spcala @lacoanimals @bfas_la

I have been evacuated, as have many of my family and friends (our homes are full of toxic dust), and my aunt lost her home, along with many others in the foothills of LA. This is my grandfather's watch on top of the remains of the fire safe I kept it in. I'm so grateful my wife Bridget saved it before I got back from shooting the Palisades Fire as it wouldn't have survived, even in that safe. I inherited it from my father when he passed last year and neither of us felt comfortable wearing it - it's the exact same watch Tony Soprano wore after all -  but right now I feel the safest place for it may be on my wrist. It also gives me a sense of connection to a man I barely new, but who also lost his home to wildfire in the 1961 Bel Air Fire. #eatonfire #palisadesfire #lafires #belairfire 

thank you to @losangeleswatchworks for helping me get the band back on so I don't misplace it in the midst of all this chaos.

When in Santa Barbara‚Ä¶no matter the reason‚Ä¶Enjoying what there is to enjoy. Day 9 of evacuation. Actually, this was the first time we‚Äôd eaten here. Seems there are 7 other locations, even Westlake close to home. Really good seafood, nice atmosphere. I recommend their unique specialty, the charbroiled oysters. The calamari was good and so was their signature wild caught sand dabs with light herb crust and lemon caper sauce. The sweet potato fries really good too. DAY SHELTER INFO FOR JANUARY 16

üïô Our hours are 10am-6pm at Pasadena Foursquare Church, 174 Harkness Avenue, Pasadena 91106. All are welcome!

üì± We have free Wi-Fi and a place to charge your devices. Feel free to come by for a few minutes or to stay all day.

üì¶ We have an updated donation list! We are ONLY accepting the following items: duffle bags + small suitcases, laundry detergent, air purifiers, *new* pillows, *new* pacifiers, toiletry items

üé® Your mental health matters! We will have a space to rest and create during the day.

üôè We have pastors and chaplains on site if you need prayer or someone to talk to.

If you have other needs, please reach out. We want to be a support however we can! Feel free to SHARE this with anyone who needs it.

Dr. Newman opened his office in Beverly Hills to those who have been burned by the fires. Using his Stem Cell Technology, he is able to begin healing the skin and treating the burns. 

Dr. Newman and the team at Stem donated our Stem Cell cream in a supply bag handed out by @jamiemakeup. 

We appreciate the tireless efforts of the LAFD and the volunteers who are giving back to this community in this time of need. We hope to help anyone who may need the regenerative care.

a n g e l e n o  is how i first identify, always and forever. a second generation local from los angeles is a source of pride and my terroir, and as i watch the devastation across my hometown i feel it now more deeply than ever.  after experiencing so many natural disasters, 9/11 and the pandemic, still nothing prepares you for something like this that touches every person in your birthplace so profoundly. 

sharing here the limited images i have taken since the new year. still in shock at how quickly life can transform.  plus a tribute to one of my patron saints - joan didion - from her book where i was from ‚Äúwe have seemed capable of almost anything in california. these unusual people in this extraordinary place come equipped with vitality and with dreams. in california it is not yet too late.‚Äù 

community is everything to me and watching our city rise up for one another immediately, even while everyone pieces through their own lives is an inspiring lighthouse through this darkness. countless big companies have remained silent, shockingly so, while the heroic efforts of countless individuals, community organizers, and companies has been astounding. we have shown up.  my trauma response is to get to work, to keep moving, to help every human that i possibly can. that‚Äôs the activist spirit of my core being and what i will continue to do. thank you to the incredible, generous humans - those that i know and total strangers and brands - who have answered every call, text, and dm at all hours of the day for my endless requests for relief and donations, big and small.  life takes a village, and ours has shown up in ways that i never imagined. the love brings tears to my eyes every single day. 

we have a long road ahead, so this will be a regular practice that we need to collectively stay engaged and connected.  live your life with intention and think about how you can support los angeles makers, creatives, restaurants, businesses, and parents - every single human in our city needs you.  not just today, but for the weeks and months and years as we emerge from the rubble.

#losangeles #ilovela #angeleno #lafires #palisadesfire #eatonfire #wildfires

On today‚Äôs episode: a throwback to üé∞ Vegas 2022 and in honor of supporting all who‚Äôve lost everything in the LA Fires, here are some resources where you can support local families to rebuild their lives:

Here are five reputable organizations actively involved in relief efforts, along with their websites and Instagram handles:
	1.	American Red Cross Los Angeles: Provides emergency shelter, food, and support to those affected by disasters.
	‚Ä¢	Website: redcross.org/local/california/los-angeles.html
	‚Ä¢	Instagram: @redcrossla 
	2.	Los Angeles Fire Department Foundation: Supports the LAFD by providing essential equipment, training, and public outreach programs.
	‚Ä¢	Website: supportlafd.org
	‚Ä¢	Instagram: @lafdfoundation
	3.	World Central Kitchen: Founded by Chef Jos√© Andr√©s, this organization provides meals to communities in need during disasters.
	‚Ä¢	Website: wck.org
	‚Ä¢	Instagram: @wckitchen
	4.	Los Angeles Regional Food Bank: Distributes food to those in need across Los Angeles County, including disaster victims.
	‚Ä¢	Website: lafoodbank.org
	‚Ä¢	Instagram: @lafoodbank
	5.	California Community Foundation‚Äôs Wildfire Relief Fund: Provides intermediate and long-term support for recovery efforts in the aftermath of wildfires.
	‚Ä¢	Website: calfund.org/wildfire-relief-fund/
	‚Ä¢	Instagram: @calfund 

Before making any donations, it‚Äôs advisable to visit these organizations‚Äô websites or contact them directly to understand their current needs and ensure your contributions are utilized effectively. Monetary donations are often the most flexible and can be used to address immediate priorities. Thank you and pass it on!

Former Doo-Dah Queen, Alternative Rock
recording artist, and beloved piano/voice
teacher, Maryjean Shaffer ran out of her
home in her pajamas clutching her favorite
coat. Now disabled, she had only been able
to load a light box and one banjo into her car.
After previously being knocked under a
vehicle, run over and dragged in an accident
caused by the same malfunction that killed
actor Anton Yelchin, Maryjean still struggles
and couldn't physically lift and carry more to
her car. Except that single banjo, all musical
equipment and rare music books were lost,
including 2 grand pianos - one a recently
purchased Steinway she saved for her whole
life. Also lost was her medical equipment
and the '79 Corvette her late brother
designed. Maryjean once taught music at
now burned Eliot middle school, to hundreds
privately and her influential all female 80s
band Holy Sisters of the Gaga Dada was
featured on MTV, but now, she is without
family and can't work. Please help Maryjean
#eatonfire #disabledmusician #gofundme

Part II: damaging particulates in wild fires & structure fires that can also be found in your home.

we know that taking in a lot of this information can absolutely be overwhelming, because a lot of it is new information to you guys.
And for some of it, looks like an entire overhaul of ‚Äúlife.‚Äù

Many of the contaminants found in the fires can also be found in your homes, just through different objects and home furnishings.

Some exposures are completely unavoidable, but how we handle them and support our bodies along with our dogs, is the key.

antioxidant supports that combat free radicals (all of our supports), what we‚Äôve shared before about calcium bentonite clay, and natural every day daily practice of healthy living, is where the micro makes the macro.

Daily investments are the micro actions that create the macro of healthy cellular protection in a world that is loaded with environmental toxins, we can ‚Äúescape‚Äù from.

if you haven‚Äôt taken a look at part one, make sure you go do that. It‚Äôs in yesterday‚Äôs post.

Out of Part I & Part II, and the list that we‚Äôve provided, is there anything that really flags you as the most alarming?

We can absolutely understand how carpet & bedding could be alarming for so many people‚Ä¶

WE ARE SAFE. We live in the northeast corner of the San Fernando Valley Los Angeles, near the Hurst Fire, but it wasn‚Äôt close enough for real concern. Our electricity was out for 2 days though. We are so heartbroken about all the families displaced, homes lost, wilderness destroyed, and wild animals affected. We have many doggy pals who don‚Äôt have a house anymore. So many of our favorite hiking trails are burnt. The mountain ranch in Altadena where our Pawrents got married is destroyed. The list of losses keeps growing‚Ä¶ 

We extend gratitude to all the firefighters and first responders, and everyone helping eachother. We hope these fires will be completely put out soon, and the healing and rebuilding can begin. We are staying indoors besides short walks. We hope you all stay safe and healthy. Sending love and doggie kisses to everyone. üêæüêæ

I just realized that I haven't posted on my feed since Austin's birthday 10 days ago! I guess I sort of froze when the LA fires broke out the next day. I've been glued to my TV and phone just trying to make sure all of my friends are okay. It's been so horrifying to see the destruction and loss of life, my heart is broken üíî 

We are about 80 miles from the #EatonFire and 100 miles from the #PalisadesFire, so we were never in danger from those thank goodness. We did have several fires pop up closer to home during the Red Flag Warnings, but they were all extinguished quickly. The firefighters have done SUCH an amazing job, we are forever grateful. 

To all who have lost a home, a loved one, a school, a business, my heart goes out to you. Los Angeles is made of strong, resilient, determined people, so if anyone can get through this, it's LA. You will all continue to be in my thoughts. 

If you have the ability to donate, I'm including a fundraiser for @wckitchen to help feed victims and fire crews in the affected areas. #LAstrong #California #CaliforniaStrong

Seeing the destruction of the fires in Los Angeles has me heartbroken. I keep looking at the photos in my camera roll over the span of the last 2 & 1/2 years and I feel so grateful for all of the spontaneous trips to socal and for all of the pictures that I took along the way. 
For some reason, I have found so much healing in being able to skip town for a few days to be able find beautiful little pockets of peace throughout the city. 
This was, by far-my favorite trip. We were supposed to go to Mendocino, but plans changed. We found the most magical beach in the Palisades and I captured the cutest photos of my girls. They look like little coppertone babies. I am so grateful for these memories. 
My mind keeps thinking about all of the young children and teens that have been impacted by the fires. 
@altadenagirls was started by a teenage girl to raise awareness of the importance to keeping self identity and self care a priority amongst the chaos. Having a sense of control of one small thing can help maintain focus and positive healing in a child‚Äôs life.
As a mother who shares custody of her children, I understand how important it is for children to have structure, routine and consistency during a time of crisis, change and rebuilding.
Please follow their page and consider donating what you can.
The children are our future. ‚ÄúTeach them well and let them lead the way‚Ä¶‚Äù

The link to donate to the Altadena girls is in my bio

It‚Äôs what we do now that matters. 

Earth, Air, Fire, Water. The Ancients named and worshiped these 4 Elements, as Gods, great Forces of Nature. Sometimes they show us how powerful they are. But we keep the faith, and no matter what, our Fifth Element is Aether. The Transcendent All, the Nature of Nature, and That Is Love. 

You Are What Remains. 

It‚Äôs What We Do Now That Matters. 

Our Heart Goes Out to all those affected by the fires. 

There has been such poignant sadness disappointment and loss. Our news is often focused on moving from one tragedy to another; we feel compassion, still the near ceaseless immensity of suffering and rote presentation can be numbing. Gaza, the Congo, Tibet just had a devastating earthquake. Plus, every day homes are lost to fires that receive far less attention, yet the impact for the individuals affected is just as profound. Yes, there is something extra felt when it hits close to home, or even perhaps home. We resonate with what we identify with, sympathetic magic. The Ancients also say‚Ä¶. 

Life is for Learning and Every Lesson Ultimately is About Compassion and Sympathy and bridging the illusion of division with Love. Ethereal. Let this tragedy continue to allow us to open our eyes and hearts to those around us. To life, to what really matters. 

We pray for easy lessons and grace. May the forces of nature have mercy. Take it easy on us all; and LA could use a break. Yet we are all still so lucky. Life is a blessing and a journey. 
We wish you well. The Awoken Space is open again, and here to help.

Please stay tuned, we have many exciting offerings in store. 

Life is still beautiful, the Sun will Rise, the Moon will Shine, things will keep getting better, and better. 

Peace,

¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†the Awoken Space

My first major in college was photojournalism. I loved writing so much I‚Äôd enter essay contests, speech competitions, write poetry‚Ä¶but eventually I convinced myself I had to do something that made more sense. Something where I could make my work and my impact more linear.

20 years later, I look at this photo, unedited, and I‚Äôm reminded of the fact that when I started to pursue photojournalism, it was a glimpse of me pursuing my gift. Over the past few years, I reignited that passion through telling the stories of local businesses and connecting with families and neighbors for my real estate business. 

On one of my hikes through Chaney Trail in December, it became so clear to me that my platform needed to become a neighborhood time capsule, but I wasn‚Äôt sure where or how to start. 

Then the wind came. Then the fire came. And our lives were forever changed. This devastation has made an imprint upon history and we‚Äôre at the center. 

The story can be told as a whole, but the story would be incomplete. Like a painting, each intricate stroke is what creates the masterpiece. Like a tapestry, each thread is just as important as the next. And so are our stories. The story of Altadena cannot be told and our history cannot be preserved without acknowledging the people, the details which make us whole. 

And so, we have reached the climax of our story, where the future can be uncertain. But the resonating sentiment that lives inside each member of our town is that we will rise from the ashes and what was gone will never be lost. And we will tell our stories. 
üåπ 
To join the Altadena timescapsule and tell your family‚Äôs story, email modernarroyo@gmail.com with your name and phone number.

It‚Äôs been tough to process everything that‚Äôs happened these past few days. Seeing the devastation caused by the fires and hearing the stories of those impacted has been truly heartbreaking. Like many of you, I‚Äôve been feeling a mix of emotions ‚Äì sadness, anger, helplessness... and a deep sense of gratitude for the firefighters and first responders who are working tirelessly to keep us safe.

This experience has really driven home the importance of community and the power of human connection. It‚Äôs been incredible to see how people are coming together to support each other, whether it‚Äôs through donations, volunteering, or simply offering a shoulder to cry on.

I‚Äôve been pretty quiet on social media this past week. I recognize that all of us process things differently, but posting my work amidst such loss and grief, initially felt insensitive and tone deaf. But then I realized that sharing beauty and joy is also a way to offer comfort and hope. And, let‚Äôs be real, keeping my business going means I can continue to donate and support the relief efforts.

In the meantime, if you or someone you know has lost their home in the wildfires, please reach out. I‚Äôd love to offer a complimentary portrait session.  While there is no way to replace the memories lost, I would love to play a small role in helping you create some new memories. 

Sending love and strength to everyone affected. We‚Äôll get through this together.

Boyle Update #2 ‚Ä®‚Ä®
It is hard to believe that today already marks 9 days since we had to evacuate from the #eatonfire, and 8 since we lost our home in #altadena. 

During periods of loss and trauma, the concept of time is immensely elusive; the time between now and those moments mentioned above both seem like decades apart and as if it happened only 5 minutes ago. ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Good NEWS! ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Max, Jasmine, Tim and of course Charlie, currently have a short term living situation that is more than ideal! ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Thanks to our friends who pastor a church in Burbank, we are staying in a dorm-style-living apartment in the heart of Burbank on their campus! The living situation is absolutely perfect because we have our own rooms, own dining and living space, shared kitchen AND Charlie can be with us too! ‚Ä®‚Ä®

The love and hospitality from this church congregation has been added to the large bucket of overwhelming support we‚Äôve experienced so far in this journey.‚Ä®‚Ä®

The Ongoing:‚Ä®‚Ä®
Every day thus far is spent on the phone, computer or in person searching for resources, receiving benefits and inquiring about next steps for how to recover from our loss. We visited the Disaster Relief Center, connected with FEMA and all the county resources. ‚Ä®‚Ä®

All to say, the services provided have been incredibly helpful in navigating our next steps! ‚Ä®We‚Äôre so thankful for all who have emailed, texted and DM‚Äôed us on valuable information. Keep them coming! ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Next Steps:

We are still in need of a long term stay as we look to rebuild. As hard as it may be, our desire is to be within 15 miles of Altadena. We are hopeful and optimistic that this will materialize. ‚Ä®Looking for a 3 bedroom, 2 bath that allows a large dog. ‚Ä®‚Ä®

Thank you for your love, support and prayers!

-Max, Jasmine, Tim & Charlie‚Ä®

Godspeed to California‚Äîthe suffering people, pets, animals, wildlife. Such loss. The unprecedented fire disaster, tragic evacuations and rescues, brings back emotions of Hurricane Katrina days. I evacuated the French Quarter late; my friends couldn't leave at the same time. My second car for them to escape in got locked down at the closed dealership, where I had taken it in for service. After the storm, NOLA cell phones towers were dead and people couldn't communicate, to find one another. This Palm Beach Daily News (Shiny Sheet) article and photo shows the exact moment many days later I learned my friends were safe. A Good Samaritan got them and their dog out before epic flood swamped our city, and they were sheltering in Texas. 

Having had a second home in the French Quarter of New Orleans during Hurricane Katrina, I have a unique understanding of the horrific loss of one's home and neighborhood and town, the emotional toll of such a tragedy, and how it also feels to be "one of the lucky ones" whose house is left standing amid ruin. 

Rebuilding California post-fires is expected to top $250 billion. It will be an exhaustive and long process, sadly, over the course of many years. Many Los Angeles residents may initially or ultimately relocate to other areas, by choice or by circumstance. 

In terms of the costliest US "natural disasters" ever, the most expensive to date have all been hurricane events. The most expensive by far was Hurricane Katrina, the devastating 2005 tropical cyclone which led to massive loss of life, levy breaks, flooding & economic damage, particularly in the southern city of New Orleans, Louisiana. The Gulf Coast of Mississippi was also wiped out. Estimated insured losses alone for Hurricane Katrina were just shy of $200 billion and 1,833 fatalities. With that said, those who went thru Katrina, and the years afterward, rarely agree with the death count.

Black families in Altadena are speaking out, determined to recover their generational homes after the devastating Eaton Fire. Altadena, one of the few historic Black communities spared from redlining, deserves racial equity in recovery efforts. Yet families are left pleading for help as insurance companies deny claims and government aid remains absent.

The #EatonFire highlights the urgent need for reparations for Black Californians. Without meaningful action from state and local governments, our communities must rely on solidarity and mutual aid instead of systemic justice. Black families have fought to preserve their generational homes, but systemic failures continue to strip them away. The victims of the Eaton Fire in Altadena have received far less media coverage and donations compared to those impacted by fires in Palisades. Many Black Altadena families are now turning to GoFundMe, desperately seeking support after being abandoned by their insurance providers.

We‚Äôve linked verified campaigns in our LinkTree (in bio üîó) so you can directly support Altadena families who have lost everything. In times of crisis, we take care of each other and prioritize wellness during these moments of need. Join us in rebuilding, demanding racial equity in recovery, and ensuring no one is left behind.

This cannot go unnoticed. Together, we will rebuild and rise. #CaliforniaStrong #ReparationsNow

If you‚Äôre like us, you are probably wondering how to navigate conversations with your children about the devastating wildfires in LA County. Our team has compiled a list of resources and ideas of how to support our students in times of crisis, especially in their own community.

When beginning to navigate these conversations, acknowledge your children‚Äôs feelings and your own. Reassure them that it is natural to feel what they are feeling.  Let them know that they are cared for and safe.

Keep the language simple and age-appropriate. Avoid extraneous details and focus on the heroic efforts of the helpers and first responders. Highlight how neighbors are working together to make things better. If you are in the position to do so, talk about ways your family can join in these community efforts.

Maintain routines wherever possible. A sense of normalcy can be calming for everyone in times of crisis. 

We are sending so much love and support to our LA community. If you need support, please reach out. Remember, you can‚Äôt pour from an empty cup.  Take care of yourselves and your families, and let us know how we can assist you.  We are here to help.

As a writer, the loss of Altadena‚Äôs Zane Grey estate has been especially difficult to process. ‚Å†Born in Zanesville, Ohio in 1872, Grey would help spark an interest in the Western literary genre that would define his writing career. Among his best known works is Riders of the Purple Sage, a novel complete with gun fights and horse thieves that would set the tone for Westerns to this day.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Zane Grey estate was designed by the prolific partnership of Myron Hunt and Elmer Grey, and first completed in 1907 for Arthur Herbert Woodward, a wealthy Chicago business man, and his wife, Edith, in the early Mediterranean Revival style. Edith, a survivor of the deadly 1903 Chicago Iroquois Theater Fire, ensured that Hunt and Grey designed home was completely fireproof, making it the first fireproof home constructed in Altadena. Sadly, the home‚Äôs concrete construction could not save it from the flames of the Eaton Fire. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The Grey family would purchase the home in 1920 and add a third floor studio and library for Grey‚Äôs creative endeavors. I‚Äôm especially saddened by the loss of this aerie, with its massive beams and intricately carved woodworkings. ‚Å†This would have been a perfect writing place, and I hope a similar space can be recreated in the future.‚Å†
‚Å†
Head over to @etandoesla and @saveiconicarchitecture for more great insights into this historic home. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Source: USC Libraries, Wikipedia‚Å†

Tomorrow will rise again.

When the evacuation order for the Eaton Fire was issued, I didn‚Äôt pack much except for a framed photo of my partner and me, as well as my two most prized possessions, my cameras, and with Chloe, our tortie cat in tow. 

As we drove away, I quickly glanced up at the burning sky and captured this photograph. It made me contemplate the fragility of our existence. Tomorrow is not a guarantee; everything we know may and will disappear one day. So, what do we hold onto? What do we make space for? That‚Äôs what this photo is meant to highlight. Tomorrow will rise again only if we believe in it. That persistence and perseverance start with us. This is a reminder to not lose our hope and fight, against all odds.

Well shit‚Ä¶
One morning, you wake up, go through your usual routine, and drive your child to school. On the way, you get a message that school is canceled due to high winds. If you have kids, you know how frustrating a last-minute cancellation can be.

In the next 24 hours, our town, my daughter‚Äôs school, our house, everything we owned‚Äîincluding our car‚Äîwould be gone. This was my family‚Äôs reality on January 7th.

Asking for help is deeply uncomfortable for me‚Äîit goes against my nature. I think many people, especially in our community, feel the same way. But if I‚Äôve learned anything from @QueerEye (my daughter Isa‚Äôs favorite show), it‚Äôs that asking for help when you need it is vital for growth, healing, and moving forward.

My family doesn‚Äôt know what the road ahead looks like, but we do know this: we will dream new dreams. We will move forward with strength, laughter, grace, and above all, love.

If you‚Äôre able to help, I‚Äôve included links to support our next-door neighbors, an amazing family who have been the heart of our street, and my daughter‚Äôs school (Aveson). The school‚Äôs story was also featured in the Wall Street Journal‚Äîlink in my bio. Thank you for your kindness and support.

#Avesonstrong #altadena #eatonfire #californiafires #palisadesfire #altadenastrong

We‚Äôve been evacuated from our home in Altadena for 9 days now, no clear path back yet. Things I wish I had packed: my glasses, more than two pairs of socks, the chicken enchiladas I had just made that night. Things I don‚Äôt care about anymore: everything that isn‚Äôt the absolute devastation around us and how to help our neighbors and friends repair and rebuild. We are still so grateful to be safe, together, and by almost all measures unscathed. Altadena is so special, filled with an inordinate amount of composers, dancers, luthiers, painters, musicians, and otherwise creative people. It‚Äôs our home for sure and we are heartbroken to imagine how changed we all will be. There are more than 200 GoFundMe pages set up for Noah‚Äôs classmates who lost their homes; if you are looking for ways to help, I can send you direct links. Thanks to everyone for checking in, for sending us treats, for supporting our friends - we feel it all. ‚ù§Ô∏è#eatonfire #altadena

We can thankfully share that the Life After Birth team and their families are safe, and yet as a Los Angeles-based organization, our hearts are breaking alongside our neighbors and friends who‚Äôve lost their homes, schools, neighborhoods and communities. This moment is time is meant for collective care and community aid, in whatever ways we are able to provide it.

Over the last 9 days, XST 4200C units have been working in 24 hr rotations starting with in the city of Altadena and rotating up to the Mt. Wilson Observatory(built between 1913-1917), as well as the Sierra Madre area.  Their duties have consisted of structure defense, line reinforcement, and mopping up any heat sources around the communication facility and observatory.  While the weather is improving, and all the crews assigned to the fire are making progress increasing containment, but there is still work to be done.  The crew is in good spirits and back on the line for another 24hr shift.  #EatonFire

Southern California is a second home for me. I moved there as a young teen from Ohio and had to create my own tribe from the ground up. The first time I ever flew in my life was to her shores, and the first ocean water I ever saw was along its coast. Some of my deepest, most valued human relationships and experiences have happened on that soil, so it‚Äôs been heartbreaking to watch it burn the last week. I spoke to multiple Altadena residents about how the destruction has impacted their life and community, with hopes that by platforming their brave voices, more resources can pour into their lives during this great time of need. Generations of Black wealth are tied up in properties and land in Atltadena. In the days ahead, it will be crucial for us all to support these families as they file insurance claims and salvage the wreckage to keep ‚ÄòDena strong and Black. 

Thank you to everyone who took the time to chat with me, including all of the survivors, Co-Founder of Fractal @fractalstrategies Strategies @bnicc and education activist @blairimani, and for all of the workers and helpers on the ground doing everything they can to save and rebuild this city. I love you, L.A. Please read and donate to the GoFundMe‚Äôs of the folks I interviewed. Story link in bio. As always, thank you to my editor @kathleennb for the opportunity to cover this moment in history üôèüèæ‚ù§Ô∏è#altadena #denastrong #denastrong #eatonfire #lafires

I grew up in Los Angeles and spent much of my life in the Pasadena/Altadena and San Bernardino areas, which have recently been affected by the Eaton Fire. Although I now live and practice in Temecula, my parents still reside in the Pasadena/Altadena adjacent communities. These places hold a special place in my heart, and a part of me will always consider Pasadena my home.

So many people I know have been impacted or displaced by the fires. While I‚Äôm grateful my family is safe and well, my heart goes out to those who weren‚Äôt as fortunate.

I‚Äôm honored to support the recovery efforts and offer help where I can. If you or someone you know has been affected by the fires, I invite you to visit Tao of Wellness in Pasadena for complimentary acupuncture. Let us help you find some healing and relief during this challenging time.

Poppi joined us in heading north to spend Christmas time with family. Our visit was full of puppy fun - walks, wrestling, homemade treats, and new toys! üß∏üéÑ

Hi Friends ~ Just an update as I've gotten so many emails from people checking on me, sending love, asking how I am...

So many different feelings and thoughts‚Ä¶ waves of grief. Friends in Altadena, sending me pictures once their house shows up on the recovery page and they can see the actual remnants of what was their home.¬†

Amazingly the place I lived for over 10 years when I first moved here in the Altadena Meadows I thought would‚Äôve burned, but it has not. Maybe because it‚Äôs close to JPL/NASA, there has been tremendous protection. A lot around it has burned, but that little no outlet road that was my first home in California on Canyon Crest is still standing. Even though I don‚Äôt live there now for some reason, I feel relieved.

I‚Äôve been feeling more and more comfortable back at my home and then last night coming in with Lily I came in the back way and I looked down at the pool. And some part of my brain went, ‚ÄúOh ‚Äî that‚Äôs the debris from the fire that hasn‚Äôt been cleaned yet. Oh, this is really happening.‚Äù And I noticed I just felt numb. And that I noticed that I was noticing this. So I think that‚Äôs progress from just being swept up in everything.

I‚Äôm not feeling the adrenaline I had yesterday, but I am noticing how quickly my body just zones out, goes numb, which tells me it‚Äôs still overwhelmed. I‚Äôm still overwhelmed.¬†

So‚Ä¶I‚Äôm resting and rebuilding the momentum of peace and appreciation and love that is my normal mode of being while, keeping my heart and energy field open and doing what I can to not numb out and when I notice I have, to come back to the present moment. And look for things that confirm that I am safe. (Continued)

Altadena is a place for dreamers. Funky Junk Farms was the home of Yipsy and Johnny. It was a magical place, full of history and love. They‚Äôre collectors, Yipsy and Johnny ‚Äî vintage trailers, jewelry, sculptures, memorabilia ‚Äî and @funkyjunk1961 is special. Now Funky Junk Farms is gone; the fire took it all. Johnny‚Äôs a third generation Altadena resident and a proud film veteran with over a quarter-century in @teamsterslocal399 as a Teamster union member. A place like Funky Junk Farms can‚Äôt simply be replaced. It‚Äôs an extension of its loving owners. And no amount of apartments or condos can ever capture the magic of a place like Funky Junk Farms. Please help Yipsy and Johnny figure out their next steps by donating here: https://www.gofundme.com/f/rebuild-funky-junk-farms-help-johnny-and-yipsy Thank you. #altadena #eatonfire #eatoncanyonfire #losangelesstrong #lastrong

üî•üöí *Together we face the flames.* üöíüî•

Standing here with my partner Aarya Kapoor, we are reminded of just how fragile life is. The wildfires of Los Angeles are not just a disaster; they're a fight for survival, a battle for everything we hold dear. Today, the Eaton fire has already claimed the lives of at least 17 people, and thousands of families are being displaced as the flames continue to spread. üå™Ô∏è The fire has already become the deadliest in California this year, and the destruction is only growing.

üíî As firefighters, we don‚Äôt just put on our gear because it‚Äôs our job; we do it because we believe in saving lives, protecting homes, and standing tall when everyone else might run. Right now, the winds are howling at speeds of over 70 mph, and temperatures are dangerously high, pushing us to our limits. Yet we continue because the stakes are too high.

The international support has been incredible‚Äîfirefighters from Canada and Mexico have joined the fight alongside us. üåç They‚Äôve helped us create a united front, showing that in times of crisis, we rise together. The fire may be destroying everything in its path, but it cannot destroy our will to fight.

This battle is far from over, and every day brings new challenges. But I want to remind all of you that there is hope in the darkest moments. We may face destruction, but together we will rebuild. üåü Aarya and I, alongside all first responders, are here doing everything we can to protect Los Angeles. We‚Äôre in this together.

To everyone out there who has supported us‚Äîyour messages, donations, and words of encouragement keep us going. üôè Thank you for your unwavering belief in us. Stay safe, stay strong, and remember‚Äîhope is always on the horizon. üåÖ

I‚Äôm just so grateful that her and her family are safe with a safe place to be but they‚Äôll slowly start to begin rebuilding and shuffling through all the paperwork but in the meantime wanted to share her family‚Äôs gofundme link if you like‚Äôd to help in anyway you feel comfortable.

I know a lot of people are doing everything and anything they can to help between volunteering, fostering pets, rescuing pets, donating supplies and everything in between to bring our communities back but if there‚Äôs anything left in your well of empathy, I know Gwen and her family will pay it forward should anyone need an assistance in a crisisüôè‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

As a behavioral scientist and author of a book on resilience, I‚Äôve spent years studying what it takes to navigate life‚Äôs hardest moments. But if there‚Äôs one thing the devastation of last week‚Äôs Palisades fire and the collective trauma and grief we‚Äôre living through has reminded me, it‚Äôs this:

Resilience doesn‚Äôt bloom in isolation. It‚Äôs in the hands that catch us when we fall, the arms that hold us when we break, the hearts that rise together from the wreckage.

Share this. The world needs to remember: our strength is in the way we carry each other. ü´Ç

I've posted about @henryrjonesii before and the amazing collaborations we've done with him at Forever 21.

Him and I have had the opportunity to work on some pretty epic projects together from Black History Month to Black Fashion Week in San Diego and beyond.

This time around is our most important collab yet. 

Henry was born and raised in the Altadena/Pasadena area. 

His extended family has lost 3 of 5 of their family homes to the #EatonFire

Being the incredible activist that he is, he rose to the occasion and from day 1 has set up a resource center for families impacted.

His grassroots action is serving approximately 300 people per day.

Hot meals, clothes, hygiene kits, water, masks, and the list goes on.

Grassroots activism will always have my heart and it will always be the way.

Community is going to save the planet.

Community takes action long before government does.

I've been doing what I can to resource and supplement his efforts. 

Organizing various food vendors, suitcases, hygiene kits, etc from my community to support his.

I've also donated money and I'm encouraging others to do the same, if you can.

Altadena is a historically Black community.

Supporting these grassroots efforts is essential to seeing this community restored.

Friday will be one of the most epic days yet of this labor of love.

We will be partnering with @feherlawapc , LA favorites @bartz.barbecue and @sprinkledcookie 

This will be an opportunity for those impacted in the area to get vital resources, eat a hot and delicious meal,  get a sweet treat, share in community 

AND

we will be raffling off FOUR Los Angeles Dodgers  tickets!

What do we need from you?

Any and all hands to show up and volunteer!

Financial donations (link in bio)

suitcases and tote bags

Water and Hygiene Kits

If you're seeing this post, please interact with it. Please consider sharing. Please consider donating or passing on to someone who you think will donate.

If you are a vendor or know a vendor that would like to tag on and contribute, please message me! 

And if you're in the LA area, please consider showing up to volunteer.

Yesterday we did our first free consult for a local family affected by the fires.  It was shocking to see the damage in person, but there were some really hopeful takeaways I‚Äôd like to share.  The home is located just over 2 miles from the origin of the Eaton Fire, and luckily survived the blaze(a newly reshingled roof may have been a big contributing factor) while sadly many of their neighbors homes were destroyed.  Fire tore up from the hillside in their backyard and sent projectiles soaring across the sky raining down on the neighborhood.  This hillside was densely populated with invasive species, which quickly burned‚Ä¶however, the native trees and shrubs that made up most of the canopy survived! Coast Live Oak, Toyon and Elderberry were all scorched, blackened around their bases, the leaves shriveled and sad‚Ä¶but, GREEN.  These plants will more than likely recover.  So stoked to see this small but significant example of the resilience of native plants among all the devastation.  #hardycalifornians #eatonfire

A Home That Stood Strong üåüüî• On January 7, the Pacific Palisades wildfire tore through Los Angeles, leaving devastation in its wake. But this home, designed by architect Greg Chasen, survived thanks to smart design choices and fire-resistant materials. üè° üí™üèº

Here‚Äôs how it withstood the flames:

‚úÖ Fire-Safe Materials
* ü™µ Fire-resistant wood: special heat-blocking layers behind the walls and heat-treated siding helped prevent flames from spreading.
* üõ°Ô∏è A metal roof with fire-resistant underlayment stopped embers from penetrating.
* ü™ü Tempered glass windows didn‚Äôt shatter under extreme heat, keeping fire and smoke out.
* üåæ Defensible space: No vegetation near the house + concrete garden walls.

‚úÖ Smart Design
* üö´ No eaves, overhangs, or attic vents that could let sparks in.
* üîí Airtight construction stopped embers from sneaking inside.
* üå¨Ô∏è Special ventilation systems filtered out smoke, keeping the air safe to breathe.

This home shows what‚Äôs possible with thoughtful home design and a focus on resilience. It‚Äôs also inspired me on my own journey to build a wildfire-resilient, solar-powered home in San Diego. üå±‚òÄÔ∏è

After seeing wildfires devastate my hometowns of Sonoma County and Lahaina, I‚Äôve spent the past three years learning how to design a home that can withstand the challenges of California wildfires. It hasn‚Äôt been easy, but it‚Äôs going to be worth it. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

Let‚Äôs build homes that protect lives and communities. üí™üèºüè°‚ú®

üì≤ Follow @californiahomedesigns for more tips on wildfire-resilient design, sustainable building strategies, and creating safer, stronger homes! üè°üî•üå±

üì≤ Connect with me on LinkedIn where I have more information on how this Passive House survived the Palisades Fire: www.linkedin.com/in/lauren-michele

For many in the Pasadena Unified School District, the experience is similar: A dual loss of home and school. 

The Eaton fire devoured five campuses, including Eliot Arts Magnet Middle School, Franklin Elementary (closed in 2020 but slated for future use as swing space under the district‚Äôs bond plan) and three charter schools ‚Äî Aveson, Loma Alta, and Noyes. It also forced 1,383 PUSD employees, or roughly half of its workforce, to evacuate. 

As those affected look forward, general uncertainty and questions about learning disruption linger. There‚Äôs hope, too. To read more or to find resources on how to help, tap the link in our bio. 

üì∏: Trevor Stamp, Contributing Photographer, Keith Birmingham, Orange County Register/ SCNG, Sarah Reingewirtz, Los Angeles Daily News/SCNG and David Crane, Los Angeles Daily News/SCNG

Dozens of dead palm trees on a state lawmaker's private land, viewed by neighbors as a dangerous fire hazard, have sparked urgent calls to clear the mounting piles of tinder-dry fronds in light of the ongoing wildfires in Los Angeles.¬†

Rossini Canyon, a property in Cardiff-by-the-Sea owned by state Sen. Catherine Blakespear (D-Encinitas), has drawn several complaints in recent years about potential fire hazards posed by more than 40 dead palm trees and mounds of dried fronds on the site. 

In a statement sent to The Coast News, Blakespear said a community effort was planned this weekend to address the fire hazard and clear years of withered palm fronds and deadfall.

‚ÄúWe recognize this creates a fire danger, and we‚Äôll be working Saturday to remove them,‚Äù Blakespear said. ‚ÄúWe encourage participation from surrounding neighbors to work together collectively to reduce risk in a space that has been enjoyed by many neighbors for years.‚Äù

Neighboring residents like Lance Cummings, whose home borders Rossini Canyon, have described the dead palms and up to 20-foot high piles of brown, desiccated fronds as "Roman candles waiting for a spark," posing a severe fire risk to the surrounding 50 homes in the densely packed neighborhood.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been nothing done at all, and those fronds just sit there and dry out,‚Äù Cummings said. ‚ÄúThe palm trees don't get a lot of water. They have a lot of oil in their fronds and probably burn quicker and easier than any other tree, especially after sitting around for two years.‚Äù

Story link in bio. Photos courtesy of Lance Cummings.

This is Elly or Ellƒì (I‚Äôve never really been sure how to spell his name). We‚Äôve been friends for a very, very long time.  My sister and some of my aunties (who won‚Äôt be named üòâ) used to tease (and torture) me by holding him captive, hiding him, and I‚Äôm pretty sure he got tossed onto a roof at some point. 

About 40 years ago, he was the only thing I grabbed when I ran out of the house fire that destroyed my parents‚Äô home. A week ago, he was one of the first things I put into a bag before we left our home in Altadena. What a lucky little shit. 

I haven‚Äôt posted a lot about my personal feelings on what‚Äôs happening. I‚Äôll get to that at some point. I mainly just wanted to post a picture of my raggedy, cute-ass stuffed animal to say thank you, THANK YOU! Also, keep the kids who have been affected by this in your thoughts, some probably didn‚Äôt have time to grab their favorite one. Please give them a big squeeze from me and Elly. ü•∞ü©∂ #eatonfire #wewillgetthroughthis

Los Angeles is where I am from originally. In my early 20‚Äôs, I worked and lived in LA from 1997-2002 before I moved to Bay Area to get married. So, this sad, tragic disaster is felt deeply.
.
Learning and seeing the devastating destruction of Palisades and Eaton Fire really shook me and I‚Äôve been feeling so helpless. I‚Äôve talked to my close friends and families, and for most of them are doing fine, and I‚Äôm grateful they are safe and sound.
.
So, here‚Äôs how we can help those in need. Offering our prayers isn‚Äôt enough... So, please share this post, or donate if you can. 
.
I believe Clover + Maven will be putting together something shortly to donate and we would love your help. üôèüèª
.
Xoxo

To help and support the families displaced by the LA wildfires, Our Lady of Fatima Academy is offering full-tuition scholarships for the remainder of the 2024‚Äì2025 school year to students in grades TK‚Äì8 for any displaced family staying or relocating to South Orange County.
 
Our Lady of Fatima provides a supportive and safe Catholic school community that welcomes families of all faiths. We are committed to delivering rigorous academic and religious learning experiences tailored to meet students‚Äô social, emotional, and academic needs while fostering the whole child‚Äôs development. Our approach includes engaging and meaningful learning experiences, with differentiated instruction across all main content areas and in special areas of Spanish, STEAM, music, art, and PE. 

We are also seeking individuals and families who would like to sponsor a student scholarship or donate to the scholarship fund. If you are interested in sponsoring a student or contributing to the LA Wildfire Victims OLF Scholarship Fund, you can donate via the link below or by mailing or delivering a check to the OLF office. Please label all donations with ‚ÄúOLF Scholarships for LA Wildfire Victims.‚Äù 

Please reach out to Mrs. Jennifer Jukic, Principal of Our Lady of Fatima Academy for more information at jjukic@olfschool.net or 949-492-7320.

From 1/13-1/31, LA County Parks is offering Care Camp for kids who are displaced, deeply affected by the fires or have school closures. After many attempts, we are thrilled to bring STEM to these children.

This week, we dove into slime-making (chemistry), catapult challenges (engineering and physics), balloon blow-ups (chemical reactions), and bristle bot battles (electricity, circuits, simple robotics) ‚Äîall huge hits for the campers! They beamed with pride at their catapult launches, found comfort in their handmade slime, and put their bristle bots to the test in epic battles. We also shared about our @firstroboticscalifornia @firsttechsocal robotics journeys (Rock N Roll and Wolfpack FTC teams), sparking more excitement in robotics. ü§©ü§ñ

Many campers ask if we‚Äôd come back with more activities. ü•π We can‚Äôt wait to bring more WOW! That‚Äôs STEM projects to them! This turned out to be one of the highlights of our school closures amidst sad news and losses. ü´∂ 

If your child‚Äôs school remains closed next week, sign up for Care Camp!  They also get to go on field trips. Thank you @lacountyparks for offering these camps for children out of school. ‚û°Ô∏è https://parks.lacounty.gov/care-camps/

Today, Tanya discusses the devastating Los Angeles wildfires with New York Times reporter Ivan Penn. They dive into how power grid issues may have contributed to the fires, ongoing investigations, detected electrical faults, and the complexities of power line infrastructure. They also unpack the city‚Äôs efforts to upgrade the grid and, in turn, respond to increasing wildfire risks amidst climate change. 

Listen wherever you get your podcasts today.

Are we chopping onions or is this community care? üò≠ Shortly after the L.A. Eaton fire broke out, my home lost power. We could see the flames from our front doorstep, the air turned thick, and we began rounding up the kitties.

But my initial displacement and subsequent safety is as much as I‚Äôd shared publicly before @instituteforanimalhappiness surprised me with a grocery gift card. They had no way of knowing that in addition to our property damage from the strong winds, all of our groceries eventually spoiled due to power loss, or that I was actually feeling quite stressed about it all. I certainly wanted to avoid making myself the main character in a city-wide tragedy that affects everyone in a multitude of ways, especially as the ripple effects of health complications, competition for housing, rising rents, ‚Äústrained resources‚Äù, and an increased unhoused population emerge‚Äîespecially for Black and Brown communities.

So I‚Äôm just here to express gratitude. Immense gratitude. The type that any words fall short to capture.
.
This definitely isn‚Äôt the first time @instituteforanimalhappiness has come thru like real ones. They‚Äôre truly extraordinary ‚ù§Ô∏è
.
Thank you, all of you who‚Äôve reached out. I don‚Äôt want or need anything. I just hope the mutual aid funds for the Black and working class communities in this area are met. I hope @m.ib89 ‚Äòs campaigns are met and that we continue to fight for Palestinian liberation. Until total liberation. Until all beings are free. 
.
#MutualAid #CollectiveLiberation #EatonFire

üî¶üöíSEARCH/RESCUE DEPLOYMENTüî¶üöí In the midst of the devastating wildland fires in Los Angeles, Firefighter/Paramedic Matt Knowles deployed with FEMA USAR CA-Task Force 8. The Task force is made up of multiple agencies around San Diego County including @sanmarcosfirefighters @sandiegofiredept @coronadofirefighters_l1475 @vistafirefighters and @chulavistafirefighters. FFPM Knowles is currently deployed as a Rescue Specialist on the team and is working to search homes, provide structure assessment and damage reports. The task force has been working on the Eaton Fire for the last week and is now transitioning to the Palisades Fire to continue their mission. We are so grateful to be able to participate in these rescue efforts. #team #teamwork #palisadesfire #eatonfire #taskforce #firedepartment #usar #searchandrescue

Walkup Melodia Kelly & Schoenberger, Cotchett Pitre, and McCarthy LLP, and Panish | Shea | Ravipudi LLP have represented victims of every major California fire in the last 20 years. In Los Angeles, we are working together to help those who have lost their homes and businesses. Our firms have served in leadership roles appointed by the judiciary, in litigation against Pacific Gas & Electric (PG&E), Southern California Edison (SCE), and Southern California Gas Company.

The legal and insurance issues in wildfire claims are complex. If you feel the need to retain counsel, make sure you do your homework. Find an advocate who is experienced, honest, skilled, and trustworthy. Make sure you and your lawyer ‚Äúconnect.‚Äù You will be working closely together for years. Make sure your lawyer‚Äôs number one focus is you and your family and that you believe your lawyer will make sure that your best interests are adequately protected throughout the progress of your claim.

Standing shoulder to shoulder with my partner, Aarya Kapoor, amidst the relentless wildfires in Los Angeles, we're reminded of the fragility of life and the strength of community. The Palisades Fire, now the city's most devastating wildfire, has tragically claimed at least 27 lives, with 36 individuals still unaccounted for. Over 170,000 residents have been evacuated, and more than 10,230 structures have been reduced to ashes.

üíî Each loss is a profound reminder of our mission's importance. The challenges are immense, with hurricane-force Santa Ana winds reaching up to 100 mph and severe drought conditions fueling the infernos. Yet, our resolve remains unshaken. Firefighters from Mexico, Canada, and the Navajo Scouts have joined us, exemplifying international solidarity in the face of disaster.

Recent weather forecasts bring a glimmer of hope, predicting improved conditions that may aid our firefighting efforts.

üôè To our community: Your unwavering support, from heartfelt messages to generous donations, fuels our determination. Together, we will rebuild, heal, and emerge stronger. Stay safe, remain vigilant, and hold onto hope. üåü

The Los Angeles County District Attorney‚Äôs Office is joining several federal and local law enforcement agencies to create the Joint Regional Fire Crimes Task Force to investigate and prosecute fire-related crimes as Los Angeles County recovers from devastating wildfires. The Task Force will focus on investigating and prosecuting criminal actors seeking to exploit the wildfire crisis.

The Task Force will meet to discuss case leads, develop and share crime intelligence, and facilitate the efficient prosecution of crimes related to the Los Angeles County wildfires. The Task Force will primarily focus on four areas: looting, burglary and impersonation offenses; crimes related to arson; illegal drone activity; and financial fraud targeting both disaster victims and those wishing to make charitable donations. 
 
The Joint Regional Fire Crimes Task Force includes representatives of the Los Angeles County District Attorney‚Äôs Office; United States Attorney‚Äôs Office; the FBI; the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF); Homeland Security Investigations (HSI); the Los Angeles Police Department; and the Los Angeles County Sheriff‚Äôs Department.

Click the link in our bio to read the full press release.

In the face of destruction, there is a bittersweet duality: the undeniable beauty of resilience and the profound pain of loss. These photos are a reflection of that ‚Äî a reminder of the impermanence of things and the strength we find in coming together.

Carolina ‚ú®

Carolina Ramirez-Sanchez stands in the rubble of her home of 21 years, a house her immigrant parents worked tirelessly to purchase so their children could grow up with stability.

The 34-year-old lived there with her parents, husband, two daughters, three siblings and two dogs. ‚ÄúWe never wanted to leave our parents,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy father would always say to me, ‚ÄòI help you, and one day you will help me.‚Äô‚Äù

Now, her father‚Äôs words resonate more than ever. As the caregiver for her 63-year-old parents, Sanchez has faced the heartbreak of seeing her family of nine split up to live with relatives and friends while figuring out next steps. Her father has returned to see the ruins of their home, but her mother cannot bring herself to face it.

‚ÄúI feel numb at this point,‚Äù Sanchez said. ‚ÄúI keep coming back, wanting to see it one last time. I just want my bed, my books, the comfort of my home.‚Äù

The photograph was one of a few that kept me up at night and ultimately set me on a flight to Los Angeles. In the image we see a firefighter hosing down a home with one hand while comforting a frightened dog with the other. I‚Äôm sure you know the one. 

Let me introduce you to Slater Lee from Oceanside San Diego, who has been working with his crew to help contain the Eaton Fire. Rest assured, Max the dog is doing well, thanks to @klutch_k9 and other good people. 

On Monday night, @thomasmachowicz and I were in the Altadena neighborhood when we met another firefighter and told him we were documenting animal rescues. He led us to the edge of a ridge and pointed to bright lights in a field below and said, ‚ÄúYou want to tell a story about animal rescue? The guy in the photo with the dog is right down there giving an interview.‚Äù He showed us the way on a map, and thirty minutes later we were meeting Slater and his crew. I interviewed Slater on the fly, and we all shared some laughs and heartfelt conversation. Everyone was excited to hear that our storytelling focus is compassion for animals. 

Over the next few weeks, I‚Äôll be posting images from my three full days on assignment with @sanctuary_doc - most likely at a slow pace. Taking time to process the experience and reflect on the extraordinary efforts of those on the ground feels essential right now as I work on a longer form story.

I hope the images take you there and offer you hope amidst the heartbreak. 

Stay strong LA, and thank you Slater for offering not just one helping hand, but two.

#eatonfire #dogrescue #losangeles

My brother‚Äôs family was first hurt by the earthquake in Haiti, and now they have been hit hard by the Altadena fire.

My brother (from another mother), Stephan,  and I have been connected for generations. Our grandmothers (his paternal and my maternal grandmother) both moved from the South to Pasadena/Altadena and became best friends. Three generations later, we became inseparable. Stephan‚Äôs maternal grandmother is Haitian and his mom (who I call Mama McGrue), was born in Haiti has been focused on supporting her family in Dena AND Haiti her entire life. 

THIS MONTH marks 10 YEARS since the Haitian earthquakes which were devastating for this Haitian family. Mama McGrue expanded her non-profit to do more mission work in Haiti. In 2011, I joined them on a mission trip to Haiti which changed my life. We helped thousands of people, from children to elderly, local people working hard to those incarcerated. This was truly Gods work. 

This is family and they need your help. 
https://gofund.me/48fa9e1d

We continue to be blown away by the incredible generosity shown by our family of partners in the eyewear and eye care community.

Today, Barb from @optaseus brought an actual armload of samples of their HYLO Relief eyedrops, a preservative-free gentle formula that contains hyaluronic acid and glycerin to soothe irritated eyes and help retain the natural moisture in the eye.

We are excited to share these with our fire victims, as well as those who are suffering from the effects of the unhealthy air in the wake of the fires, and we would like to express our deepest gratitude to @optaseus and Source Health (and Barb!) for their immediate support and kindness. Thank you all so very much!

the #palisadesfire and #eatonfire started nine days ago. angelenos immediately started disaster relief efforts: evacuation centers, donation drives, animal rescue, meal distribution, and much more.

while the palisades fire was burning out of control, i didn't dare leave home, lest an evacuation order -- a REAL one, not a false alarm -- requires me to leave my place in #santamonica üò±

now that wildfire containment has given me room to breathe, stress-wise and air quality-wise, it was time for me to help out where i could. and thanks to a friend who posted the need on her fb page, i made my way to @smcedu, where i spent the day sorting clothes that had been donated. which necessitates this public service announcement:

please donate gently-worn clothing ONLY. no used underwear, no white shirts with yellow pit stains. i actually found a shirt that looked like a favorite that had been worn to death. and now it was supposed to be someone's new favorite rag???

thank you to all those who have donated so generously! and more thanks to all those who've been organizing the volunteer effort! i'll be back soon, assuming i'm excused from jury duty next week! ü´§ü´§

The devastation is profound as we witness the loss of Jane‚Äôs Village in Altadena during the Eaton Fire. This cherished neighborhood, known for its rich history and unique architecture, has been a cornerstone of our community for generations.

Jane‚Äôs Village, named after Jane Bardwell, was a collection of quaint, English-style cottages built in the 1920s and 1930s. These storybook homes, with their steeply pitched roofs, arched doorways, and handcrafted details, were not just houses‚Äîthey were works of art, lovingly preserved by residents committed to maintaining their historic charm.

This neighborhood represented a tangible connection to a bygone era, where craftsmanship and character were paramount. Its loss is a sobering reminder of how fragile history can be. As we move forward, let us honor the memory of Jane‚Äôs Village by advocating for the preservation of other historic landmarks in our region.

Together, we can rebuild, but the soul of what was lost will live on in our hearts.

Tomorrow, Friday, January 17th, marks the last day of our Lancer Support Drive, and we remain incredibly grateful for the unwavering support from our community. While we no longer accept physical donations, gift card contributions are still welcome. Anyone in the local community affected by the wildfires is encouraged to visit our campus Dining Hall from 12 PM to 3 PM for essential pick-ups.

Hot meals will be available tomorrow from 12 PM to 4 PM in the Dining Hall, courtesy of our generous community partners and volunteers. School counselors, along with art and prayer stations, are also ready to support those in need.

We encourage those who can to support the Lancer Support Fund, which aids La Salle students and families directly impacted by the fires. Contributions are tax-deductible and can be made at lasallehs.org/lancersupportfund or via the link in our bio.

Thank you for standing with La Salle and our community during these challenging times. Together, we are stronger!

For today‚Äôs most important updates and additional resources, please visit lasallehs.org/eatonfire or click the link in our bio.
