My heart breaks for our beautiful city and the vibrant communities within. I hope that I can add just a little to the good work that‚Äôs being done by the sincerest Los Angeles community right now, through this fundraiser. I‚Äôve pulled together a variety of photos taken throughout my years in LA, including many taken in the Palisades and Dena areas, and 100% of proceeds will be donated to the GoFund Me Wildfire Relief Funds, for distribution to those people or charities who need it the most right now. You can shop at https://tinyurl.com/LAprints now through Valentine‚Äôs Day, or find the Shop tab on my website.

If interested in my personal experience this week as a Pasadena resident, you can read on below.

‚Äî‚Äî

From a distance, I watched the tragedy of the Maui fires unfold in August of 2023, shook to my core. Feeling helpless for the locals and the island‚Äôs beauty. While it wasn‚Äôt my own family on Oahu fleeing their homes, it hit just as close to home‚Ä¶ 

Up close last week, I experienced the Eaton Fire, evacuating with my new family from Pasadena when they received a mandatory order on Tuesday evening. Packing like we‚Äôd perhaps never have the opportunity of returning home, too. The wild winds unlike anything we‚Äôd ever seen or felt before ‚Äî making any type of destruction seem possible, and making it feel like a true MIRACLE when we woke up the next morning to find my in-laws‚Äô home was spared while others in their neighborhood burned. Their direct neighbor‚Äôs, the grandparents, and our home all safe too. We stayed glued to the news, seeing each of our street names highlighted in live footage of burning homes and businesses. Holding our breaths. Crying (personally).

On television, Alex and I watched as the fire broke out at Runyon Canyon ‚Äî my sisters‚Äô street name also plastered across the screen. Frantically calling and urging them to evacuate from Hollywood. Tracking their location closely until they were safely at a distance. Then, returning to our neighborhoods this weekend to the sobering reality of the loss and devastation. The landscapes forever changed. The businesses we‚Äôd frequent. The people who lost their physical everything.

Update 2‚Ä®‚Ä®
It is hard to believe that today already marks 9 days since we had to evacuate from the #eatonfire, and 8 since we lost our home in #altadena. 

During periods of loss and trauma, the concept of time is immensely elusive; the time between now and those moments mentioned above both seem like decades apart and as if it happened only 5 minutes ago. 

Good NEWS! ‚Ä®
Max, Jasmine, Tim and of course Charlie, currently have a short term living situation that is more than ideal! ‚Ä®

Thanks to our friends who pastor a church in Burbank, we are staying in a dorm-style-living apartment in the heart of Burbank on their campus! The living situation is absolutely perfect because we have our own rooms, own dining and living space, shared kitchen AND Charlie can be with us too! ‚Ä®

The love and hospitality from this church has been added to the large bucket of overwhelming support we‚Äôve experienced so far in this journey.‚Ä®

The Ongoing:‚Ä®
Every day thus far is spent on the phone, computer or in person searching for resources, receiving benefits and inquiring about next steps for how to recover from our loss. We visited the Disaster Relief Center, connected with FEMA and all the county resources. 

All to say, the services provided have been incredibly helpful in navigating our next steps! ‚Ä®We‚Äôre so thankful for all who have emailed, texted and DM‚Äôed us on valuable information. Keep them coming! ‚Ä®

Next Steps:

We are still in need of a long term stay as we look to rebuild. As hard as it may be, our desire is to be within 15 miles of Altadena. We are hopeful and optimistic that this will materialize. ‚Ä®Looking for a 3 bedroom, 2 bath that allows a large dog. ‚Ä®

Thank you for your love, support and prayers!

-Max

See their page for hours and items available as well as volunteer and donation opportunities.

We also picked up a sizable amount in good condition of men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs tees, sweats, and thin sweaters for anyone looking for some comfy clothes to stay warm in. We also have 2 beautiful long puffer jackets. If anyone is interested, DM me. I can have it sent along with your free bentos.

WEBINAR: Navigating LA Fire Insurance Issues

Date: Jan 17, 2025 10:00 AM PST

Who should attend: Homeowners and insurance policy holders impacted by the fires in the Los Angeles region

Zoom Link: üîó Link in Stories 

Mike Bidart and Riccardo Echeverria at the Shernoff Bidart firm in Claremont are the gold standard as far as property coverage and making insurance companies fulfill their obligations under the bad faith laws is concerned. Rahul Ravipudi of Panish Shea and Ravipudi,  Frank Pitre of Cotchett Pitre and McCarthy,  and Mike Kelly of Walkup Melodia Kelly and Schoenberger,  are doing an informational zoom tomorrow with Mike and Riccardo that focuses on dealing with your own insurer and also deals with rights and liabilities as far as third parties are concerned.

We have great people in this world like first responders, firefighters and animal rescuers. All of them out there saving innocent animals in California as I write. This first slide is a 5-day-old puppy found alone under a collapsed building during a fire evacuation in Pasadena during the Eaton Fire. The puppy sustained burned ears and was put in a incubator. This lucky little baby already has foster care.‚ù§Ô∏è
See full story on their page. 

The Pasadena Humane quickly mobilized their resources and boots on the ground went into action. They saved hundreds of pets and wildlife in the Eaton Fire area. They have an incredible record as a compassionate facility and highly recommended for donations. I used to live right next-door to Pasadena in Glendale where I went to college.Great city.

All of these images are Eaton Fire animal victims brought to Pasadena Humane. I apologize for any sensitivities to the slides after 11 with severely burned cats but this is real time animal emergencies and the fires are not over. Forced myself to see the magnitude of injuries to know what I'm praying for and concentrate on the devastation to visualize love & harmony. Something I signed up for a long time ago.

I feel like we have a responsibility as people of this world to take necessary steps on preventing these disasters on soft targets. These animals can't speak but we can!‚ù§Ô∏è

~CALIFORNIA PEOPLE~
PSA: If you live anywhere near the fires, please be aware that wild animals are fleeing the fires and they may show up in your yards.
The California Board of Forestry and Fire Protection is urging you to bring your domestic animals in at night and let the wild animals pass through.
Please put out buckets of water for them.
They are scared, exhausted, and have also lost their homes. They need to refuel. 

May the Creator bless all animals, animal rescuers, vets, first responders, firefighters and all the good samaritans in California.üôè

Guess what I don‚Äôt know what to do, I just write‚Ä¶ 

Balzac

Hugs from behind
Arms 
Wrapped around 
As you sit at your desk shades 
Resting on their 
Sills 
I‚Äôd kill to inhale you 
Hold you 
In 
Until I‚Äôm weak 
Dabbing cheek to cheek 
Keeping tears
Tamed
With eyelashes
Flashes of long quiet
And then it‚Äôs 
‚ÄúOk? Are you ok?‚Äù
Sound more like a squeaky
Slurp slips out 
A mouth of cool coconut oil 
Lips 
A cornet of a city‚Äôs 
Break hearts 
Shuddering under another 
Unwelcome tone defense
Deafening 
Devices 
Collected from our haunted habitats
Play
Littering this LA one room
With its og 1920s molding 
And rags 
Holding wall holes 
(Not)
All together 
And whether 
Our towel protectors 
Provide safety at all 
Is all probably placebo
Anyway 
I guess 
The flesh and the bones 
And the virus and the plastic 
And Asbestos and cheap clothes 
Particles 
Provide acid for our lungs 
Razor blades for tongues 
Noses caked with dry blood
This fire feels like the flood 
And the trope is 
Noah‚Äôs in LA,
But he‚Äôs behind the velvet rope
If your whole world burns down
Before 
You know if they can build it back 
‚ÄúBehind great fortune is great crime.‚Äù
Today
The States all scream 
Balzac 
‚ÄúAre you ok?‚Äù
I whisper head on shoulder 
Speaking into your hair knots
Because I know that you‚Äôre 
Not 
Ash falls from the sky like
Dust
CNN will soon stop it‚Äôs coverage 
Will you still remember us?
Not all of us are criminals 
Or fashion whores 
For fame 
Most of us are just down bad
And want to bring our children
Home
Again

Today we were again assigned to the November division which is in the heart of the hardest hit area of Altadena. After arriving at our work location my crew located a residents pond that still had live koi fish. We provided bread from our sac lunches as they likely hadn‚Äôt eaten in over a week. We also came across an injured hawk with severe burns to its tail and talon as well as inhalation injuries. A call was placed to division and an animal control expert arrived to take the injured bird for treatment. My engineer was able to grab the injured bird and hand it over to the experts. In the midst of saving the hawk we located an aviary with finches and their eggs. We provided fresh food and water and animal control will come back to take care of them. #eatonfire @losbanosfire

At Nudge Kids, Los Angeles isn‚Äôt just our headquarters‚Äîit‚Äôs where our mission to empower children and families truly came to life. In recent weeks, our community has endured unimaginable loss due to the devastating wildfires. While we know nothing can replace all that‚Äôs been lost, we‚Äôre committed to doing our part to help those affected begin to rebuild. 

We launched two special ways to give back:

1. Until March 1st, 2025, 100% of proceeds from all subscriptions will be donated to the families, neighbors, and first responders who need it most.

Through March 1st, when you purchase a new Nudge Kids+ subscription, we‚Äôll donate 100% of our net proceeds to an organization directly supporting the families and first responders affected by the fires.

How It Works

Pick Any Plan: Monthly, Quarterly, or Yearly‚Äîany new paid subscription qualifies.

We Donate: 100% of net proceeds goes to an organization that supports the families and first responders affected by the LA fires. 

2. Donate Directly, Get a Free Year of Nudge Kids+

Prefer to donate on your own? No problem. If you donate to any organization or verified GoFundMe benefiting LA fire victims, we‚Äôll thank you with a free year of Nudge Kids+.

How It Works

Donate to a relevant organization or GoFundMe campaign helping families affected by the fires.

Show Proof: Email a screenshot of your donation confirmation to eric@nudgekids.com by March 1st.

Receive Confirmation: We‚Äôll send you an email with instructions on getting (or upgrade your existing account) your one free year of Nudge Kids+.

Are you a family affected by the fires?

Let us help you and your children get back to some sort of normalcy. Reach out to us at eric@nudgekids.com and we will use the Nudge Kids app to help you and your children back into a routine totally free.

I‚Äôll end with this image tonight, it‚Äôs haunting me a little because there are so many layers of information and the tones of this in that morning light were incredible.  I looked up the home on Zillo, a 1947 2 bedroom one bath cottage with an insane view.  I‚Äôm very mindful that much of what I‚Äôm photographing now, powerful images for me, are documenting someone else‚Äôs loss and pain.  I have a lot more to do up there, I have had some great content with people, and I have often been photographing in a different style because of what I‚Äôm dealing with.  The blog posts will go deeeper.  More to Come.

#LAFire Victims, your St. Philip Fire Response Team, over 400 strong, have been hard at work to provide for the needs of our community in light of the recent #LAFIRES. We will be concluding Phase 1 of our services with a full day on Saturday January 18th to serve those who have lost their homes, businesses, or are displaced!

WHAT TO EXPECT: basic necessities + ‚Äúsecondary needs‚Äù on a first come, first served basis. 
üÖøÔ∏è Public parking will be on Holliston through the back entrance into the school parking lot. 
‚ÄºÔ∏èWe expect a large crowd, so we will be doing our best to maintain traffic control. We ask that all recipients respect the personnel who are prioritizing your safety throughout your visit.

151 S. Hill Ave. 91106

Meghan, Los Angeles'ta ki yƒ±kƒ±cƒ± orman yangƒ±nlarƒ±nƒ±n ardƒ±ndan bu hafta ba≈üƒ±nda Altadena'da ki gen√ß kƒ±zlarƒ± desteklemek i√ßin sessizce g√∂n√ºll√º oldu. D√º≈ües, memleketi olan California'daki √ßƒ±kan orman yangƒ±nlarƒ±ndan dolayƒ± yardƒ±m √ßalƒ±≈ümalarƒ±na destek vermeye devam ediyor. 
Altadena'da ya≈üayan 14 ya≈üƒ±ndaki Avery Colvert  tarafƒ±ndan yeni bir topluluk olu≈üturularak bir organizasyon ba≈ülatƒ±ldƒ± " Altadena Teen Girls Fire Recovery". Los Angeles Times'a konu≈üan Avery, bunu √∂zellikle Eaton Canyon yangƒ±nƒ±ndan etkilenen ve evlerini kaybeden kƒ±zlarƒ±n, kendilerini hissetmelerine, kendilerine g√ºvenmelerine ve √∂zg√ºvenlerini yeniden kazanmalarƒ±na yardƒ±mcƒ± olmak i√ßin ba≈ülattƒ±ƒüƒ±nƒ± a√ßƒ±kladƒ±. "Her≈üeylerini kaybettiler ve hayatlarƒ±nda hi√ß bir≈üey normal deƒüilken bir normallik hissi ya≈üamalarƒ±nƒ± istiyorum" dedi. 
Meghan ise pazartesi g√ºn√º sessiz sedasƒ±z, elinde √ßantalarla kƒ±zlara; g√ºzellik √ºr√ºnleri, kƒ±yafet, temel ihtiya√ß malzemeleri, ki≈üisel bakƒ±m √ºr√ºnleri ve √∂ƒüle yemeƒüi getirdi. Archewell vakƒ±flarƒ± aracƒ±lƒ±ƒüƒ± ile baƒüƒ±≈üta bulunmu≈ülar. Altadena Teen Girls ise Instagram sayfalarƒ±ndan destekleri i√ßin Archewell Vakfƒ±na te≈üekk√ºrlerini ilettiler. Ve payla≈ütƒ±klarƒ± reels videosunda Meghan'ƒ±n √ßantalarƒ±yla geldiƒüi an ve kurucu Avery Colvert ile konu≈ütuƒüu andan bir kesit yer alƒ±yor. Meghan orada ge√ßirdiƒüi s√ºre zarfƒ±nda kƒ±zlara alƒ±≈ü veri≈ü yaparken yardƒ±mcƒ± olup ihtiya√ß duyduklarƒ± konularda fikirler vermi≈ü, oraya gelen aileler ile sohbet edip zaman ge√ßirmi≈ü. Orada Meghan ile kar≈üƒ±la≈üan bir ba≈üka g√∂n√ºll√º ise fotoƒüraf √ßekinmi≈ü Meghan ile ve fotoƒürafƒ± ki≈üisel sosyal medya hesabƒ±nda " "Hayƒ±rseverliƒüin krali√ßesi" notu ile payla≈ümƒ±≈ü‚ù§ Bu tabiri ger√ßekten √ßok sevdim. Meghan'ƒ± kraliyet √∂ncesinden beri takip edenler onun yardƒ±m ve g√∂n√ºll√ºk ser√ºvenini √ßok iyi bilirler. Meghan'ƒ± ancak "hayƒ±rseverliƒüin krali√ßesi" tabiri tanƒ±mlayabilirdi. Aslƒ±na bakƒ±lƒ±rsa Meghan'ƒ±n herhangi bir yerden √ºnvanƒ± olmasƒ±na l√ºzum yok g√∂r√ºyorsunuz. Onunla tanƒ±≈üma fƒ±rsatƒ± bulanlarƒ±n ve halkƒ±n taktƒ±ƒüƒ± √ºnvanlar diƒüer her ≈üeyden √ßok daha deƒüerli ve anlamlƒ±üòâ

üåø Post-Disaster Mental Health: Knowing When to Seek Helpüåø

During this time, many folx are just trying to get their feet on the ground, focusing on where they will sleep, how they will shower, having enough socks, and of course, where are they going to live. 

In a few days, weeks, or months, things may resolve themselves. Or‚Äî- they may not. It‚Äôs okay to not feel okay. You don‚Äôt have to face this alone.

Mental health professionals as well as many other people in your communities can provide tools and strategies to help you heal, rebuild, eat, get dressed, pray, move your body and much more. 

üí°Community support groups, hotlines, I.e @211lacounty @mutualaidlosangeles @mutualaidla can guide you to the right resources.

You‚Äôre worthy of care and compassion. Reach out if you need to. We want to hear from you. 

#MentalHealthMatters #PostDisasterRecovery #lawildfires #eatonfire #disasterpsychology #disastertherapy

I barely did any art whilst in London for the 2 months around Christmas and was looking forward to getting stuck in back in Pasadena. I arrived on 5 Jan and the horrors of the fires 3 miles up the road from us put pay to that wish: OBVIOUSLY. We didn't suffer any loss but so many friends and work colleagues have lost homes - i feel devestated for them and also bizarrely guilty that we got off scott free.  I am now in NYC and have bought a few basics (took nothing from home) and am tentatively absorbing my surroundings and finding my mojo again. Here are some doodlings from this week#art #mixedmedia #mixedmediaart #mixedmediaartist #penandink #acrylicink #senelierolipastel #lyragraphitecrayon #eatonfire #pasadena

These past 2 weeks have been harrowing. It‚Äôs impossible to fully grasp the terror and devastation experienced by the Angelenos who have lost everything in the fires. From 2500 miles away, I‚Äôm fixated on the news, constantly seeking updates. I feel helpless and overwhelmed with anxiety, dread, and panic. Could such a catastrophe strike where we live? Would we be prepared (we‚Äôre lucky if we have a full tank of gas at any given time)?
My heart goes out to all those displaced, jobless, or still missing. The unimaginable suffering will endure for a long while.
üö≤

Have a safe weekend, Everyone.

There are many schools that burned down in the #eatonfire . Some of these children also lost their homes. Some children are struggling with the idea of losing their school and worry for their friends. All lost a way of life.

This week we talked about the upset of losing their pencil cases with a special pencils that burned in the fire . We talked about their treasures and memories, how it will be different . 

I listened as they talked about how they feel a little guilty about their  friend‚Äôs homes burning down but theirs is okay. 

What  I am hearing  from the children is deep empathy, they are trying to hold it in because they don‚Äôt want to  add any more worry to their parents, a sadness over loss of all the memories attached to the small things that were burned, and worry how things are going to be in the future. 

We have been doing lots of art this week. On their own, they drew their pencil boxes on fire, drawings of their school a blaze  and their frustration and fears with hearing the news.

But yesterday, we decided to look ahead. I gave them the task of drawing the possibilities of what the rebuild of their school could be. So, with great detail, they started to design their new version of their old school. They made sure to keep the parts of their school that didn‚Äôt get hurt in the fire, like the library, and then they added a lazy river, a treehouse in the middle of a horse riding ring and a garden.

This little boy added a news area so the teachers could always know what was happening, and there will always be a police officer stationed out front to protect the school so this can never happen again. 

More than anything this week, I am just listening and letting them know whatever feelings they are experiencing- it‚Äôs okay to have them. 

But we are shifting. I am encouraging them to not give up and to look at the possibilities of rebuilding the future. Because, in my classroom the rule on my wall is #wenevergiveup

To my beloved families in Altadena . I hope you stay. I hope you rebuild. It is communities like Altadena that make the fabric of Los Angeles. I wish everyone hopeful possibilities. As Octavia Butler says, ‚Äú so be it, see to it.‚Äù

The Los Angeles fires have deeply affected our community across the entire LA region, and I‚Äôm heartbroken by the loss many have suffered. As we continue to heal, we want to come together to support one of our own, James Lemos, and his family.

James and his wife, Lisa, tragically lost their family home in the Eaton fire, along with James‚Äô treasured plant collection. A longtime member of the San Gabriel, Long Beach, and Los Angeles Cactus and Succulent Societies, James also served as the former president of the Long Beach Cactus Club. The home they lost had been in their family since 1976, holding almost 50 years of memories, and it was a multi-generational home that meant so much to them.

To help James and Lisa recover from this devastating loss, we are hosting this fundraiser auction. All proceeds will go directly to support their recovery as they begin to rebuild their lives from this total loss. 

Please join us in showing our community spirit and offering support to a family who has given so much to our local Succulent Societies.

100% of the auction will go to The Lemos Family and I will also cover shipping anywhere in the USA.  Please bid in increments of $10 and please tag the highest bidder when you bid.  Biding starts at $0 when posted and will end Sunday January 19th 8pm.  If a bid comes in in the last 5 minutes the bidding will be extended by 5 minutes to ensure the person out bid has an opportunity to counter.  Please bid high and please bid often - let‚Äôs support our fellow community member.

Update Friday Jan 17 7:45 AM. As a friend said: Insanity continues. Last night the world‚Äôs largest Lithium-Ion battery storage farm was (is)on fire, uncontrolled and uncontrollable, in Moss Landing. üì∑ Cred KSBW8

A Lithium-Ion battery fire releases hydrogen fluoride gas, which is a very toxic corrosive used to etch glass. A fire like this cannot be put out with water. Water makes it worse.This facility is also next to a Tesla battery farm.

Moss Landing is Central Coast, CA, by Monterey and Santa Cruz for reference. Not by us, but still awful. 

For us, the #palisadesfire it's 31% contained- huge progress overnight, and has not grown. #eatonfire is 65% contained. 8 of the evacuated zones on the NE side of the Palisades fire were able to go home last night ‚ù§Ô∏è

EPA now has teams on the ground, at the Palisades and Eaton fires, beginning FEMA-assigned work to address hazardous materials from burned properties, structures and vehicles. 

This effort is the first phase of the broader cleanup and recovery, in which EPA will remove hazardous materials that are harmful to residents and the environment and that need to be addressed prior to removing ash and debris.

Burned properties still pose a risk to residents, and appropriate protective equipment (masks, gloves, coveralls, and boots) should be worn once people are authorized to enter a property.

As we continue to process the shock and devastation caused by the fires in our beloved City of Angels, our hearts are heavy with sadness for those impacted‚Ä¶ and we are determined to support those in need.

This Monday, we‚Äôre supplying 250 meals to the SoCal Salvation Army to feed first responders and evacuees in West LA. üí™ You can help by SPONSORING A MEAL NOW!

üëâ Just $10 per meal‚Äîno taxes, no delivery fees, no extra charges. The link is available on our e-shop or through our daily restaurant order online‚Äîit‚Äôs quick and easy to contribute.

We are fully mobilized to support our city, putting smiles on faces and providing energy and courage to those who need it most.Our deepest gratitude goes out to the incredible firefighters who tirelessly protect our lives.

This is only the beginning of a new chapter for LA, but we‚Äôll keep pushing. Together, we‚Äôll rebuild stronger, one bite at a time.
We love you, Los Angeles ‚ô•Ô∏è.

It‚Äôs a war zone‚Ä¶ so unreal. 

Rivers of melted aluminum left behind from the rims and hubcaps of cars. 

Sump pumps & hoses left in pools, the nozzle still rolled into the hose, where they planned to fight the fire but realized it was coming too quickly. 

A ‚Äútake one leave one‚Äù neighborhood library stand in front of a burnt down house. 

Unexploded ammo and melted guns. 

What blows my mind is what survived‚Ä¶ Statues and ceramic art, cars that were somehow skipped. One house burnt to the ground while it only got part of the backyard and the garage of another. 

Fire is crazy. Firefighters have learned how to read it but it‚Äôs still so unpredictable. 

If a fire is ever coming your way, JUST GET OUT. Your basement/root cellar will collapse in on you, no room is safe, your bathtub and pool full of water WILL NOT save you. Grab the irreplaceable items (photos, etc) and important documents, a couple of changes of clothes for you and your family, your pet & food/shelter for them, and get out. 

On a side note, we were fed very well‚Ä¶ so thank you to everyone sending food, thank you for whoever packed that massive 24 hour pack of food, and thank you to the inmates who made an incredible breakfast and dinner. 

#fires #lafires #eatonfire #burnedhome #survivors #whatsleftbehind #firstresponders #sarlife #kask #kasksafety @kask_safety

Los Angeles has been my home for the last 17 years. I love this city. I don‚Äôt want to live anywhere else. I don‚Äôt have the right words for what our city has just/is still enduring. Fire and wind are truly phenomenal forces. From our Los Angeles headquarters, the start of this year has shown us just how powerful those forces are. The images of the destruction to our home city are heart wrenching. Yet, like the many layers of this rammed earth wall we designed for a recent project, we see beauty in nature's dichotomous strength and delicacy. Neighbors helping Neighbors. Strangers from other countries saving our homes. A City that holds itself up, from its sandy beaches of the #palisadesfire to its rocky mountains of the #eatonfire, evoking the strength, grit and refined character of this rammed earth wall. 

üì∑: @timaawbell

caption:
Huge thank you to all the firefighters and first responders during one of the worst natural disasters in history. Seeing our LA community connect and give back has been such a joy during a devastating time. 

Since we are located in close proximity to the Eaton fire, we did close for two days for the safety of our staff and patients. We deeply appreciate everyone‚Äôs patience and understanding during this time. 

Thank you to all our patients that reached out to make sure our staff and office were safe.

Our thoughts and prayers are with our many patients, family and friends have been directly affected by the fires. Please know we are here to support you in any way we can.

Please be vigilant and stay safe. Be kind. ü§çüôèüèΩ

Mariposa and Olive

This is one of the last if not the very last surviving wood A-Frame house in Altadena that looks exactly how it did when it was built in 1924 by famous author, Kyle Onstott. Kyle was also a competition dog trainer. Prior to the construction of these houses the lot was used as his dog kennel. Outside of the four house houses subdivided on his lot, nearly every other house in the area was destroyed. This house is significant because it sits dead center in the historically Black area of Altadena and represents what many of the houses looked like at its peak.

Overnight, we‚Äôve all become unwilling experts in wildfires, safety, and survival. The influx of information feels like a flood‚Äîtexts from loved ones, endless to-do lists, and support groups buzzing around the clock. It‚Äôs overwhelming, and yet there‚Äôs no pause button. Somehow, we‚Äôre supposed to juggle it all while anchoring our kids and holding space for grief that comes in waves.

I‚Äôm sharing this post not because I‚Äôve figured it out, but because I know I‚Äôm not alone in feeling like this. If you‚Äôre here too‚Äîtrying to hold it together while it all feels like too much‚ÄîI see you. Let‚Äôs take it moment by moment. Together. ü´Ç

I‚Äôm so deeply thankful to all who have sent support, messages, offers for places to stay, funds, belongings, and more. Big thanks to everyone at JAX @jax_film for your understanding and support. Thank you to my bandmates for checking in, puttting us up and offering assistance.
We are taking this day by day. This is all incredibly difficult but we know how very lucky we are.

Hello,

On the morning of January 8, 2025 my family and I lost our home to the Eaton Fire.  Thankfully we are safe however, the loss has left us in a very difficult situation. As we work to rebuild our lives, we are in need of your support. 

We kindly ask to share our story and raise awareness. Any resources or guidance would help us tremendously. My coworkers surprised me by starting a gofundme to help cover immediate expenses of temporary housing, essential items, and long-term cost of rebuilding our lives. If you would like the link will be in my bio.

Thank you for taking the time to read this and for considering how you might be able to help. Your support during this long journey of rebuilding our home means the world to us.  #eatoncanyon #eatonfire

That is why we are offering Free adjustments to our first responders in our office. I am also planning to go to their resting camp in Malibu area on Sunday to volunteer our services whatever we can do to make them feel better. If you are a chiro or any healthcare specialist who wants to help let me know. This is a very small gesture compared to the amazing work of the fire fighters first responders and the community. #sabetchiropractic #eatonfire #pacificpalsades #firefighter #firstresponders

We continue to send our love and prayers to all of LA county as we continue to fight through and rebuild from this devastation.

Lord Gane≈õa stands amidst the ashes of a home in Altadena, often known as the remover of obstacles and the one who presides over thresholds. This m≈´rti caught me by surprise as we wrapped up our first day documenting areas affected by the Eaton Fire. We had just seen a coyote searching for food, put out water for her, and climbed the hill to take in the view from above. Wandering around a corner, I came across a completely destroyed house. At the entrance, it was clear that there had been an altar, with Gane≈õa presiding over the threshold.

I don‚Äôt know if the residents of this home have returned to see what remains of their lives here, and I wonder what will happen to this statue when the bulldozers come to clear the debris. This scene was hard to leave, especially as the full Wolf Moon rose over the hills, owls hooted in the distance, and sounds of chainsaws and helicopters filled the air. I felt like I was abandoning Gane≈õa in this burned landscape.

From what I‚Äôve seen through the lenses of other photographers, many gods, goddesses, and Buddhas held their own as flames tore through everything they were meant to protect. Yet, perhaps what they were truly meant to protect is more subtle: courage, kindness, and hope‚Äîall of which remain abundantly visible in the individuals and communities across Los Angeles.

#eatonfire #losangeles #photojournalism

Introducing our Squirrel Recovery Journal! - Just like squirrels stash away their most precious treasures, this notebook is designed to help you organize and safeguard every step of your recovery. From journaling your feelings to keeping track of critical details, it‚Äôs your all-in-one tool for healing and growth. 

Why a squirrel???
Squirrels are nature‚Äôs masters of preparation and resilience, and they play an essential role in rebuilding too! By burying seeds, they help new trees grow and contribute to the restoration of forests‚Äîjust like this journal can help you rebuild your life, one thoughtful page at a time. 

All proceeds go to Eaton fire recovery efforts, supporting families and communities as they heal and regrow, just like the forest. Let this journal be your reminder that small actions‚Äîlike a squirrel planting a seed‚Äîcan lead to incredible growth.

There‚Äôs an article going around about a home in the Palisades that didn‚Äôt burn down while other homes around it did. The owner, also an architect credits saving his home by using fireproof and fire resistant materials. He also landscaped around his property using block walls, fire safe vegetation and reducing the amount of shrub that can grow around the house.

I think it‚Äôs a great topic on how to use these ideas and implementing them onto your own property.
The materials he used can be on the pricier side, however there are other options that can be used in lieu of the ones he describes that can also help mitigate any potential fire damage.

Lucky that several Pasadena PD units were in the area giving evacuation notices and stopped to handle several spot fires.  Funny side note one of the officers recognized me from a call for service at my mom‚Äôs house a while ago where I introduced myself and in the midst of all this he told me he had looked at my website after we met and he loved my Pasadena PD portfolio. 

I was really impressed by the Officers that responded on mutual aid the first night of the fires.

#documentalphotography #nikon #photographer #photographyüì∑ #photooftheday #eatonfire #pasadena #altadena #california #californiawildfires #pasadenaphotographer

Pt. 5 - 1/14 evening drop off. Not only did @dannyboysfamousoriginal @chefholzman provide us with the 5 Pizzas for lunch, but they also provided 15 more large pizzas for our National Guards for dinner!! There was also another surprise for the Guards, as @madisonbrodsky brought her adorable Gracie to tag along & provide some love to everyone!! 

Aside from the pizzas, we had 1000 sandwiches that were also provided by another party where we were able to leave some boxes with the Guards and continued making several more drops to different locations, including the final stop where I got to meet these amazing guys that are all on duty!! 

One thing I‚Äôve been very grateful for so far this past week, is all the amazing people I‚Äôve got to meet & all the new friends I‚Äôve made with those who are serving. Along with all of those that have joined to volunteer & help out wherever they can

Stay tuned for Pt. 6 as we give you a peak of something we got to witness‚Ä¶!

LA this month sure is reminding us of 2020, the parts we‚Äôd like to forget and the ones we hope never to. The fires are still burning. The shock has not worn off. The land has started to slide. The work has barely begun.‚Å†
‚Å†
Thank you for donating to our @LACommunityMeals fund to keep first responders, evacuees, and volunteers fed. The link will continue to live in our bio and our ordering apps.‚Å†
‚Å†
Thank you for eating out and ordering in. This city desperately needs to stay employed.‚Å†
‚Å†
Thank you for focusing more on what brings us together than what separates us. Everyone is doing their best.

Getting a haircut is probably the last thing on your mind during a traumatic time. Especially if a huge fire just uprooted your whole life and you‚Äôre trying to figure out how to even begin rebuilding a new life.

In an effort to give you some comfort & normalcy, I would love to offer 1/2 price haircuts to Women displaced from the fires and first responders helping our community. $65 for a wash, haircut and blowdry ‚ù£Ô∏è

I wished so deeply that opening that safe would bring her relief, maybe even a smile‚Äîbut instead, it brought sadness. One of the homes that were lost to the #eatonfire that we've previously cleaned.

This was author Zane Grey's estate in Altadena, built in 1922. It was acclaimed as the first fireproof home in Altadena and was listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

When we cleaned this a few years ago before it went on the market, it was fascinating listening to stories from his descendants who grew up on that large property.

The fire has hit the community hard. Three homes that were scheduled to be cleaned the week of the fire burned down, and a handful of homes we've cleaned in the past month burned also. Thankfully the homeowners are safe. 

#altadena #altadenarealestate #zanegray #pasadena #pasadenarealestate #compassrealestate

Helping Our Community Heal 
 
As we face the devastating impact of the Palisades and Eaton fires, our thoughts are with all of those who have suffered losses and those who have spent countless hours helping others. Here are three opportunities to lend support for our local area: 

Eaton Fire Relief and Recovery Fund: The Pasadena Community Foundation has established this fund to provide flexible support to local nonprofit organizations as they respond to the Eaton fire disaster. https://lnkd.in/eYzm4t8e
 
üåü California Community Foundation Wildfire Recovery Fund: Supporting immediate and long-term recovery efforts. Their disaster and recovery efforts support an array of critical recovery services, including housing, case management, mental health, and medical care for displaced residents. They also aid in rebuilding essential infrastructure like emergency communication systems and offer financial disaster assistance, labor law education, and immigration services to low-wage workers and immigrant families.
https://lnkd.in/gPY-uGU3

 üî• California Fire Foundation: Offering aid to firefighters, their families, and communities. The California Fire Foundation has a range of programs that support firefighters, their families, and the communities they serve. 
https://lnkd.in/gsK24RB
 
Here at The Oaks of Pasadena, we have provided temporary housing for individuals who have been displaced by the Eaton fire as well as expediting our move-in process for new long-term residents. For more information, please contact: info@pasadenaoaks.com or call 626-356-2702.

#oaksofpasadena #EatonFire #pasadena #altadena #exploremore

Los Angeles County District Attorney Nathan J. Hochman today announced that charges have been filed against eight additional individuals in connection with eight alleged crimes committed during LA County‚Äôs devastating wildfires. The charges encompass a range of offenses, including felony arson, felony possession of ammunition by a felon, felony looting during mandatory evacuations, and misdemeanor impersonation of a firefighter. These alleged crimes occurred across the county, including in the cities of South Gate, Brentwood, Hawthorne, Huntington Park, Compton, Santa Monica, and Malibu.

Click the link in our bio to read the full press release.

This Black History Month, we‚Äôre coming together to¬†heal, celebrate, and give back¬†to families impacted by the Eaton Fire in Pasadena and Altadena.

üíå¬†We‚Äôre looking for 9 families¬†to help and support during this fundraiser. Applications are open now. The form to fill out is in our bio¬†if you are a family in need of assistance.

Get Involved:¬†If you‚Äôve already heard from us and confirmed your participation, mark your calendars! If not, we‚Äôll be reaching out within 24‚Äì48 hours. DM us if you‚Äôre interested in being part of this beautiful day.

Important Info:¬†Every single transaction the day of the event will go directly to supporting our cause. There will be a¬†QR code linked to our fundraiser¬†for all purchases. If you want to support anyone participating, vendors, artists, or performers, you‚Äôll do so by making a¬†donation¬†directly through the QR code. This is about¬†community and giving back, it‚Äôs not your typical pop-up.

What to Expect:
ü¶ã Black-owned vendors
ü¶ã Visual artists showcasing their work
ü¶ã Live performances by poets, musicians, and DJs
ü¶ã Food vendors serving up delicious flavors
ü¶ã Guest speakers
ü¶ã A raffle
ü¶ã A potential short film screening
ü¶ã Black joy, Black love, and the magic of our community

+SPECIAL GUEST PERFORMANCES üåπ

After the event, within the following two weeks, we‚Äôll hold a special¬†ceremony to honor the 9 families chosen, where we‚Äôll present checks and resources to help them rebuild.

If you can‚Äôt make it but want to contribute,¬†the link to donate to our cause is also in our bio. Every dollar counts, and we appreciate your support in helping us serve our community.

This event is¬†rooted in love and unity‚Äîa day for us to show up for Dena the way only we can. Let‚Äôs pour into our community, celebrate Black excellence, and make something magical happen. We have so much in store for our people this year!¬†üíôü¶ã

ProPublica Diamonstein-Spielvogel visual fellow @sbmaneyphoto moved back to her native California on Jan. 4 after living in Detroit for a number of years. 

Three days later, the wildfires that have engulfed Los Angeles began. 

As an investigative newsroom, ProPublica doesn‚Äôt usually cover breaking news, but SB knew she had to document what was going on and knew there were many stories of impact to tell.

Her first stop was Altadena, the historic town just northeast of LA that wasn‚Äôt subject to redlining back in the 1960s. Black families in Altadena have passed those homes down for generations. And today, the Black homeownership rate in the community exceeds 80%, nearly double the national rate.

This is what she saw.

SB and ProPublica will continue covering the aftermath of the fires.

If you live in Altadena and have information that can help inform our reporting, please reach out to us at propublica.org/tips.
 
üì∑: Photos by Sarahbeth ‚ÄúSB‚Äù Maney; Hood family home photos courtesy of Kim Hood.
üé•: @josesepulvedatv

Smoky skies and heavy hearts, is what describes LA lately.

It has been so devastating to see these fires destroy so much. 
Although we don‚Äôt live in the Palisades now, we spent 12 beautiful years there. It‚Äôs such a special place, and to see both homes we lived in now gone, breaks my heart.
Our kid‚Äôs schools, our dog‚Äôs vets, our attorney‚Äôs house, friends homes and so many amazing businesses all gone. 
We‚Äôve met so many displaced people on our dog walks here in Marina, and where so many are staying now. Everyone has such different stories to tell.
Last week we donated clothes and essentials at Moss Venice and Venice Family Clinic in Santa Monica. This week we‚Äôll be donating more.
I‚Äôve been sharing resources on how to help on my stories, and created a highlight under LA Fires.
It‚Äôs been so amazing and uplifting to see so many people get together to help, donate and volunteer. 
As a transplant Angelino, moving to LA 18 years ago from Miami was the best decision. I Love LA!

A day after we lost the house to the fire, I had a sudden pang of sadness that we didn‚Äôt give it one last look. A real LOOK. But a few days after that, we remembered that we did look. When we left, we weren‚Äôt thinking that we would not have a house to return to. We thought it would be still here, maybe damaged somewhat. We gazed quickly as we evacuated. We looked at the house and decided to leave our LED Christmas lights on so we can see if electricity was on. That was our last time to see the house, and that last look gave us comfort for we got to appreciate our home, in that fleeting moment, together.
Photo from Dec 1, 2024 after we set up the tree for the last time, from basically the same spot.

Tacos, Water and ‚ÄòHomies‚Äô: A Gas Station Becomes a Uniquely L.A. Relief Site‚Ä®
Out of desperation and a need for social bonding, volunteers have banded together to help Altadena residents.

Four lowriders, parked alongside gas pumps, gleamed in the afternoon sun. Carne asada sizzled on a grill at a pop-up taco stand in the corner. A group of old friends sat on camping chairs and passed around a freshly rolled blunt, cracking jokes and showing each other photos on their phones. Hip-hop played on a wireless speaker.‚Ä®‚Ä®Just feet from the taco stand were a dozen tables piled with donated shirts, blankets and toiletries that were meticulously organized. A moving van loaded with cases of water, boxes of chips and crates of diapers backed into the gas station.‚Ä®‚Ä®The filling station, perched across the street from one of the most destructive wildfires in California‚Äôs history, had suddenly become the vibrant hub of a traumatized neighborhood, a harbor for residents desperate for food, clothes and, especially, community.‚Ä®
Photographed for @nytimes‚Ä®Article by @mac_ryan_ and @kenbensi

I carry Altadena in me still. The old house was the first place fully my own. The longest stretch I‚Äôve stayed in one place. I remember vividly, twenty plus years ago, my ball-busting former LATimes journalist turned real estate agent called during my lunch break. ‚ÄúCome see this house NOW.‚Äù As soon as I got out of the car and stepped onto that sidewalk, I felt it. This Was The One. I‚Äôve come to realize in my time there- that feeling- it wasn‚Äôt just the house. It was also Altadena. 

My Altadena friends are lifelong friends- ones who‚Äôve circled around me countless times. I cried for my friends. Thanksgivings together. Birthdays at Farnsworth Park. Deep fryer dinners. Sunset hikes to Echo Mountain. Backyard tiki cocktails. And I cried for Altadena because I got to know Altadena. I can‚Äôt fathom the emotions of friends and neighbors who have lost homes. I only mourn my past. What has been. What will never change. My friends and neighbors grieve their today and their future. What was recently lost, and what‚Äôs still to come.

I don‚Äôt know if the Eaton firestorm extinguished Altadena‚Äôs magic. I do know this resilient community will pull together. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs enough to restore the magic. But you should know the Altadena we knew.

#eatonfire #altadena #beautifulaltadena

locationName: LACMA Los Angeles County Museum of Art
caption:
::: Ôº¨Ôº°  Ôº≥Ôº¥ÔºØÔº≤Ôºπ :::
After 10 days I‚Äôm still trying to fathom what LA has experienced in the form of total destruction, devastation and heartbreak for both our city and all its Angelino residents ‚Ä¶ no adequate words!

So I thought that a little levity is needed after witnessing the remarkably sad and incredible photos and videos shared by everyone ‚Ä¶

Thus ‚ÄúLA Story‚Äù is a quick reminder of how wonderful, charismatic and whimsical the greatest city on the planet is all about ‚Ä¶ Steve Martin‚Äôs screenplay for 1991‚Äôs fanciful satire, L.A. Story, in which Martin plays the lovelorn weatherman trying to navigate the idiosyncrasies of Los Angeles. 

Martin‚Äôs character has a penchant for roller skating through LACMA while his friend Ariel (Susan Forristal) videotapes the antics for a private, amateur video series called Harris K. Telemacher‚Äôs World of Art.

The director (Jackson) says it was imperative to film at LACMA, but getting permission to roller skate around priceless pieces of art would have been near impossible but for the fact that Martin served on the museum‚Äôs Board of Trustees from 1984 to 2004.
Jackson remembers a meeting with the museum‚Äôs management. ‚ÄúJackson said, *We‚Äôd like to have Steve roller skating down here and just zooming in and out of these sculpture busts. They went, ‚ÄòMmm hmm,‚Äô and you could see the look of terror start to dawn on their faces. And they said, ‚ÄòWill it be the trustee who is doing the skating?‚Äô We said, ‚ÄòYes, yes. Steve.‚Äù The museum acquiesced.

The image of Steve Martin appearing in shoes with retractable roller skate wheels is one that adorns the film‚Äôs teaser poster.

UPDATE on the #lawildfires response: 

Our HRD (Human Remains Detection) teams continue working tirelessly alongside our USAR team and partnering agencies to locate and identify those still missing. 

The toll is devastating: 

Eaton Fire: 17 lives lost, 24 still missing. 

Palisades Fire: 10 confirmed fatalities, 7 unaccounted for.

Our dedicated K9 teams, which include K9 Clifford and K9 Prentiss, are working all day in challenging conditions to bring closure to affected families. 

They will continue this critical mission until every effort has been made to find those still missing. Our hearts go out to the victims, their families, and all those impacted by these tragic wildfires.

#LACountySearchDogs #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #catf2 #usa2 #usar #hrd #lacofd #lastrong

Yesterday was a meaningful day of cleaning, repairing, making baskets, raking, washing, planning, and coordinating efforts like heated portable shower units and drinkable water service. Donors like Jonathan, Diego, and Neal¬†of @realitycenter brought pallets of supplies like space heaters and blankets because we did not have heat due to the gas shut off, which was cold in our buildings. 

#EatonFire #altadena #fostercare #Children

Missing waking up here to the sounds of the birds and squirrels. My family joked that I was like Snow White in my little cottage. It really felt like that. I had been lost for so long across the city and suburbs and had finally found my own safe haven that truly felt like home here in magical  #Altadena. I remember the first time I drove up that hill into our neighborhood 7 years ago and I had this deep knowing that I was ‚Äúhome‚Äù. In my life I have experienced deep bouts of depression and often times I would describe it as feeling homesick. This past week I have been thinking about what it means to be ‚Äúhome‚Äù and how to find that feeling again. 

Sending love to all those who are mourning and to those who have shown our family and community so much compassion. 
ü§ç

Xx
Yahaira

#grieving #beautifulaltadena #eatonfire

I had a chance to get a little personal time today, so spent it with my dear friend and fabulous Deacon @jimfrog818 at Cindy's Restaurant to support The Fox's Restaurant, destroyed by the #EatonFire.

The Fox's holds a special place in my heart.  It was just around the corner from the home I spent the first few years of my life in, also razed by the fire, and family legend has it that The Fox's was the first restaurant I ever went to.  I was last there just a few years ago and thought I would have a chance to go back....

Some imagery I made during the fires is up on @natgeo, link in profile. Huge thanks to photo editor @allisonrosehess ‚ú® As a former New Yorker and current Angeleno, this story by writer @rosecransbaldwin resonated with me:

‚ÄúOne of the few moments that I‚Äôve laughed in the past two weeks was when I saw a post on social media suggesting that confused New Yorkers, to grasp the conflagration, might imagine Central Park on fire. With around 40,000 acres burned and 12,000 structures destroyed, make it more like 47 Central Parks.‚Äù

This was the first time I covered a natural disaster of this scale and devastation while at home. So many friends lost their homes and we are extremely fortunate that our neighborhood was spared. Sending love and strength to all those impacted by the fires.

As we wrap up our Lancer Support Drive and prepare to reopen our school next week, we want to express our heartfelt gratitude to every member of the La Salle community. Your incredible generosity during these challenging times has truly shown the spirit of Lasallian compassion and unity. Together, we have stood by those impacted by the wildfires and shown that we are an undeniable force of compassion and resilience.

Our community has collected thousands of essential goods, distributed countless meals thanks to our generous partners and volunteers, and provided hope to many. As we prepare to welcome our students back on Tuesday, January 21, we are reminded that we are Lancer Strong!

Thank you for standing together and making a significant difference in many lives. We are grateful for your support and compassion, which continue to make La Salle College Preparatory a special place to learn and grow. üíô‚ù§Ô∏è

For the latest updates on our school‚Äôs reopening next week, please check your emails and visit lasallehs.org/eatonfire or click the link in our bio.

If you cut through the bone fragments and salted sinew of my chest, a photograph of Cindi and Greg Hilfman of Topanga Canyon would be glued to the globular mass you call my heart. My fairy godparents, the Hilfmans, ARE my heart. Their home, my home away from home, was a vast extension of their own hearts. The true love they share for eachother and their community was literally planted by their own hands in the Santa Monica Mountains. They put everything into their sanctuary. Greg took his land in Topanga (where he was living in his van as a young keys player in LA) and painstakingly built his dream estate with his dream girl over the course of many, many years. Overlooking the Pacific Ocean, their garden and the chateau had reached peak magnificence. Each tile and ivory key in the recording studio, installed by Greggy himself. When Greg gave Cindy his spare kidney to try to save her precious life for all of us, he suffered a heart attack at home, only to be brought back to life by his wife (and her new kidney). They LOVE each other. They love their family. They love their home. They love their friends, and we can‚Äôt imagine a world without the Hilfmans‚Äô and their home in Topanga. I grew up doing the most legendary Jewish-ish Topanga Christmas at The Hilfmans‚Äô each year. Our ping pong competition and our yearly Tom Petty singalong was an event I always circled 20 times on the calendar. In my teens and twenties, I never hesitated driving up the canyon and laying all of my worries and fears on the doorstep of The Hilfman‚Äôs home. It had always been such a safe place for my spirit. 
I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôve been watching the news and know what‚Äôs been happening in our beloved city of angels. The Hilfmans evacuated like most of us, but I‚Äôm heartbroken to say that their home did not survive the fires. 
I know so many have lost so much, but if you wouldn‚Äôt mind taking a moment to share or donate to their GoFundMe, my family and I would be so grateful. 

I hope that wherever you are, you are safe and know that you are loved. 

Link to The Hilfmans‚Äô GoFundMe in my bio‚Ä¶

This is Mario Estrada, the long time groundskeeper at my parents‚Äô house and the person who may have saved it from burning down! Last Tuesday the 7th he heeded the evacuation warning and took my two dogs to pick up my brother‚Äôs dogs and help my cousins‚Äô family evacuate to my house. He got all those people and animals to safety!

The backyard along the property line (pictured) burned almost completely, but was putout before reaching the house. When Mario returned the next day to check on the house, the fire line had receded but there were still embers burning in some trees that he doused (last video)!

We love Mario, and are endlessly grateful for his efforts ‚ù§Ô∏è

Today marks 3 years with NBC News. I never imagined it would look like this ‚Äì covering unprecedented wildfires fueled by Santa Ana winds, all of Los Angeles collectively experiencing the same nightmare as everything the flames touched incinerated, and not knowing the extent of the devastation that tomorrow‚Äôs light would reveal. 

The last 11 days have not been easy witnessing the destruction and immense hardships for those impacted by the blazes. But as immense as that is, so are the recovery efforts of countless communities and neighbor helping neighbor. I could not be prouder to call LA home, to live in a place where Angelenos show up to support one another in a time of great need, and to work alongside these fearless journalists ‚Äì the only people I‚Äôd walk through fire with and whose dedication to telling the story never wavered after 11 days straight in the fire zone.

@nytimes just published a video piece about Bethany Martinez, a single mom on the Altadena/Pasadena border who also cares for her 94yo, wheelchair-bound grandmother. Bethany and her daughter evacuated their house due to the Eaton Fire, and the home filled with smoke and currently has no heat. Bethany‚Äôs grandmother is still in the house. 

I obtained Bethany‚Äôs contact info directly from the filmmaker @gilad_thaler. I then chatted with Bethany on the phone, and while she didn‚Äôt have a GFM yet, she decided to create one after we spoke. I‚Äôm posting a link to the GFM in my bio. 

Please consider donating. They were able to get temporary housing with the help of a nonprofit but their housing runs out in a few days. I do not know the status of Bethany‚Äôs grandmother, but if anyone knows of any orgs or agencies that could help her, please share! THANK YOU.

The skies for the most part are the usual SoCal bright blue and the smoke is billowing only here and there. We have settled into this strange place where overwhelming majority of the people, although terrible shaken, have resumed normal lives, but there are areas of this beautiful city that look like black gaping holes, like mangled and tortured versions of their prior selves laden with toxic ash, debris, and chemicals otherwise seen in war zones. Those who have not experienced evacuation or loss of a home consider themselves lucky, but we all know at least one relative, friend, colleague, or classmate who have not been lucky. How to move forward, how to reconcile the ‚Äúas if nothing has happened‚Äù and ‚Äúcompletely devastated‚Äù coexisting and dealing with all different kinds of emotions the events of last week bring?

Help LA fire victims directly if you can. Donate to Nate & Molly Perkins via the GoFundMe link in my bio. They escaped their home with their 5yr old daughter just hours before their home burned to the ground. 

The devastation is unreal. In many ways, giving money directly is best once a victim is safe. They packed the essentials. What they need is the money for a mortgage they still pay for, for a home that isn‚Äôt there, for groceries, for every single item that we take for granted. A clothespin for an opened chip bag, scissors, a spatula. 

It‚Äôs like a tragic death - except there is no funeral. 

There is no handbook. You are left with nothing but the few things you took with you in the car while embers are flying in the wind. There is nothing else. Refugees in your own city slowly putting the pieces back together. 

Be kind to one another, you never know what someone is going through. I was born in Mississippi, live in NYC, and love family in LA. Let‚Äôs melt state borders and show love ‚ù§Ô∏è

@molly_inla @nateperkins #eatonfire #pasadena #pasadenafire #lawildfires #wildfire #la #donate #supportla #tupelo #nyclove

ü™ΩMeet The Squadü™Ω

Name: Tania Rashid
Location: Los Angeles, CA

üìÅ What I do in real life: I‚Äôm a journalist and documentary filmmaker, bringing light to important global and local stories.

ü´∂üèΩ How I got involved with Volunteer Squad: Seeing the devastation caused by the fires, I felt compelled to step in and support those affected. Joining Volunteer Squad has given me a way to channel that into action.

‚õëÔ∏è What I‚Äôve been doing with The Squad: Today, I had the opportunity to help one person who lost their home, providing them with food and clothing. It was a small but powerful reminder of how much a little kindness can mean. I look forward to contributing more in the days to come.

ü´Ç What I want to share: Every act of service counts. Meeting someone face-to-face and being part of their journey toward recovery is deeply humbling. This experience is a powerful reminder of the resilience and strength within our community.

#losangeles #mutualaid #volunteer #altadena #lafire #eatonfire #palisadesfire

you'd be hard-pressed to find a local business that HASN'T been affected by the #palisadesfire or #eatonfire or both.

residents don't have the bandwidth to shop, eat out, or go about their usual routine while they're trying to recover from a major loss or while they're working to help those who did.

i stopped by @lalalandkindcafe on montana in #santamonica. all the seats inside the coffeeshop were taken, which seemed like a sign that the regulars continue to stop by for a place to sit and work, chat with friends, or be distracted from the bleak new reality. but the order line was shorter than i've seen it to be. was it the time of day (just before lunch on a weekday) or were people just spending less money? or is it because a good chunk of the business in the area comes from the palisades, and they've evacuated elsewhere?

this shop has a higher than average price point, which is one of the reasons i don't frequent the place. $12 pre-tax for an iced americano and a croissant is something i can't afford to spend on a regular basis. although i do have to say the warmed #pistachio croissant with #pistachiobutter and a dusting of chocolate powder from @farmshopca was a new (for me) treat! 

my dining choices for the day went from that breakfast luxury to an affordable meal provided by @foreverytable at the @smcedu #disasterrelief event. my choice from the variety offered the volunteers was a #salmon #superfood salad, which was a healthier option than my brunch, although not as decadent üòâüòâ

i've included info about the donation drive i've been volunteering at. right now, we're sorting items that have been donated; they will be distributed jan 22-24 at the santa monica main campus at 1900 pico. please bring ID.

#neighborshelpingneighbors #losangeles

Saturday Jan 18 8am: Final update unless things progress unfavorably. #palidadesfire is 43% contained and has not grown in acreage. The weather for the weekend will be pretty good for the firefighters. Low winds, cool temps, and higher humidity. We are expecting high winds again Monday Tuesday, but ü§û the fire teams get a solid handle over the weekend. The #eatonfire is 73% contained and actually relieving visiting fire teams of their duty and sending them home üòä I am sure they miss their families --Thank you for coming out to help‚ù§Ô∏è
I will be focused on volunteering. My sister is coming up this weekend to do a shift with me in Santa Monica to help locally, and a shift at the Rose Bowl to help more LA broadly. 
Thank you to everyone who has reached out, sent messages, donated time or money, sent prayers or good wishes, offered places to stay, and kept us all in your thoughts. 

And for my SJ peeps, the @sanjosesharks has a donation drive through Sunday at Sharks Ice. I may be in LA, but I still love my #sjsharks üß°üß°

Thank you all for your concern about the YMB team here in LA with the fires. We are all safe‚Ä¶ 

Meredith and her sister were evacuated from the Palisades, but their houses were spared. 
Kenzie was evacuated and her home is untouched. 
Doug and his sister were evacuated from Altadena and they both lost their houses in the fire. 

Our lives are forever changed. We are all still in shock and will be processing the devastating loss around us for quite some time. But we are doing our best to move forward.

While we focus on immediate needs, the podcast will be on hold. Doug‚Äôs house was also home to the YMB recording room including our gear and memory cards with audio files. We are grateful for the support of our community and we appreciate your understanding, caring, and kindness as we regroup and rebuild. 

Thank you for your continued support of the podcast. There is a link in bio for Doug‚Äôs GoFundMe if you are inclined to help in that way. And Doug is adamant that we add to this statement: ‚Äúthe compassion you show to yourself and others is the most healing thing you can practice right now.‚Äù 

Love you all,
YMB üß†ü§üüèºüíñ

I lost my home on January 8th in the Eaton Fire. We had a beautiful 1939 farmhouse that we painstakingly renovated over the last five years. We had just finished our kitchen remodel 4 months ago and are still paying it off. It was our dream home. Not a week went by that I didn‚Äôt tell my husband how much I loved our sanctuary. And now it‚Äôs gone. Our community is gone. Our funky little town with Christmas Tree Lane, the Bunny Museum and all of its historic Tudors and charm is gone. Altadena has come out fighting. The community is rallying to keep out big builders who will want to change Altadena. And more than 75% of residents and businesses are planning to rebuild. PLEASE support local Altadena businesses who will be trying to stay in business during the rebuild. Links of info will be in my Highlights

HELP ME HELP LA FIRE VICTIMS // The loss of homes and entire neighborhoods is beyond devastating. Rebuilding will be a lengthy arduous process with many unknowns. Currently local designers and realtors are working towards helping fire victims settle into temporary housing and provide furnished rentals or work to get them essentials like beds and sofas so they have a soft landing as they get back on their feet (see tagged resources below). For my part I‚Äôd like to coordinate small styling packages to folks once they are more settled. These would be curated packages that could include things like rugs, artwork, pillows, lamps, vases, curtains etc and all those finer details that help a space feel like a home and not like a hotel. Many people lost those little trinkets that were their grandma‚Äôs, the vase made by their aunt, and all those small but meaningful items we pass down through generations. My goal is to ease some of that loss by helping make a place that is not their home feel at least a little bit more reflective of who they are and what they lost. These will be small treasures they can take with them when they do rebuild as a reminder of their strength and resilience. I‚Äôve included examples in the next slides.

HOW TO HELP // Are you a brand or know one willing to donate or heavily reduce the cost for styling items and accents pieces for the home? Have you already seen posts you could send me? Do you own a thrift shop items you could pass on? Are you an artist with a printshop? A designer who has some styling items? If so please drop your/ their handle in the comments, send me a DM, or email to connect us. I will gather a list of vendors from which I can pull from to give these styling packages to some folks when they are feeling more secure in their temporary housing in the coming months.

RESOURCES For rentals: @pardeeproperties @brockandlori @sandandstonehomesla @samarnesonhome For furnishings @houseofhoney @adamhunter

locationName: Eaton Canyon Natural Area and Nature Center
caption:
Seeing the initial burn pictures of Eaton Canyon is definitely shocking, but the good news is that many native California plants are well-adapted to regenerating after fires. Some seeds stored in the soil will have their germination activated by fire. Other plants are crown sprouters; their roots are still alive. @theodorepayne has posted some wonderful information about this, so go check out their page for more information!

Although it will be a while before Eaton Canyon is as lush as that second picture (2024 had a long rainy season), nature knows what to do!

Less fun: Our common invasive plants like castor bean, black mustard, and crofton weed are also well-adapted to fire üò≠

I haven't managed to be on social media much since the fire for a few reasons that might work for you even if you haven't been affected by the fire.

1. I've been walking the fine line between getting things accomplished to transition us to this next phase of our lives and listening to my body and my emotions for when I need to grieve, be angry, be grateful, and be present for my wife.

2. I'm there for others as I have the energy to do so. This is an extra expenditure and I give myself grace when I need all the energy I have to do what I need to do for my family.

3. I'm taking action and pivoting as needed when I get informed guidance that I need to iterate on what I'm doing.

4. I'm allowing myself grace over all the 'shoulda, woulda, coulda's regarding what I didn't save from the fire.

5. I'm allowing myself grace to not know exactly what comes next. Right now, there are urgent tasks, so I'm focusing on them and my family.

But again, thank you to everyone who had offered support in any fashion.

It means the world to us.

And on that note, here's a photo of the mountains that I look at every morning from where we're temporarily staying.

Aren't they beautiful?

#eatonfire #altadena #altadenastrong #resilience #mindsetmatters

Beverly Hills Temporarily Suspends Short-Term Rental Restrictions to Support Wildfire Victims:

Thursday night, the Beverly Hills City Council unanimously approved a 90-day urgency ordinance to temporarily lift restrictions on short-term rentals. 

This temporary measure ensures assistance to wildfire victims while maintaining fairness and compliance.

Violations, on price gouging, can be reported to the City‚Äôs ask BH customer service team at (310) 285-1000 or askbh@beverlyhills.org.

This Black History Month, we‚Äôre coming together to¬†heal, celebrate, and give back¬†to families impacted by the Eaton Fire in Pasadena and Altadena.

üíå¬†We‚Äôre looking for 9 families¬†to help and support during this fundraiser. Applications are open now. The form to fill out is in our bio¬†if you are a family in need of assistance.

Get Involved:¬†If you‚Äôve already heard from us and confirmed your participation, mark your calendars! If not, we‚Äôll be reaching out within 24‚Äì48 hours. DM us if you‚Äôre interested in being part of this beautiful day.

Important Info:¬†Every single transaction the day of the event will go directly to supporting our cause. There will be a¬†QR code linked to our fundraiser¬†for all purchases. If you want to support anyone participating, vendors, artists, or performers, you‚Äôll do so by making a¬†donation¬†directly through the QR code. This is about¬†community and giving back, it‚Äôs not your typical pop-up.

What to Expect:

The Deeper Than Color Disaster Response Support Group facilitators aim to provide a safe and supportive space for individuals aÔ¨Äected by the fires in Altadena, California, to share their experiences, process their emotions, and receive peer support. This group is designed to help participants navigate the challenges posed by disaster-related stress and trauma (i.e., loss of home and property, grief, fear & uncertainty, feelings related to emergency response inequities, unfair media coverage, predatory real estate oÔ¨Äers, and unethical/discriminatory insurance company interactions) while fostering a sense of community and understanding.

I‚Äôve been silently stepping away from Vintage Redeux. Call it denial or not wanting to realize a closing to a BIG chapter of my life but it is what it is. I stopped doing the @melrosetradingpost in October and transitioned to a full time career. The market and my customers were my everything the last 14 years. I‚Äôll miss my community, my loyalists, the happiness I brought to people through my curation and creation. THANK YOU ALL, from the bottom of my heart for all the good times. 
In a final bittersweet act, after being deeply affected from the #eatonfire I packed up my car one last time with all my inventory; men‚Äôs, women‚Äôs and children‚Äôs clothing and donated it to @andreammcinnes of @1rhythmsofthevillage to give back to the beautiful community of Altadena and all that they lost. May my pieces bring some smiles to new faces as I bid farewell to Vintage Redeux üíï

Which older restaurants have you not been to in a while because you‚Äôve been chasing what‚Äôs new and exciting ‚Äî but you‚Äôre looking forward to visiting again soon?

(Please share your thoughts in the comments about places that have been in the #805 for 20 years or longer.)

üëãüèº I asked myself that question late last year as I stopped to take this sunset photo of the Hi! Let‚Äôs Eat! sign in #Lompoc (üì∑ 1). The restaurant where it originally stood for more than 55 years was torn down in 2017 to make way for a Starbucks (because OF COURSE), but the sign was saved and restored and in December 2022 reappeared at its new home: the parking lot at American Host Restaurant, a breakfast-and-lunch spot that opened in 1982 and is still going strong. 
üí°@americanhostrestaurant owner Dennis Block happily welcomed the #HiLetsEatSign even though its newly installed LED lights are visible only at night, hours after his own restaurant has closed for the day. Block‚Äôs decision helped save a piece of #Lompoc history. And at the time, I vowed to eat at his restaurant ‚Äì where my late mother and her friend Kathleen were semi-regulars ‚Äî more often as a show of thankful support. But there I was, two years and zero follow-ups later. 

ü•û I‚Äôve since rectified the situation, stopping by American Host last week for a breakfast (üì∑3) of #pancakes, #sausages and #sunnysideup eggs served with the traditional American flag pick on top. üá∫üá∏ I‚Äôll return again soon, either for breakfast or a replay of the Ortega / Swiss burger I ordered when Kathleen and I last met there for lunch in April 2022 (üì∑ 4 & 5). But I‚Äôm leaving the Garbage Pail omelet ‚Äî so called because it includes all 14 items from the list of optional/add-on ingredients ‚Äî to those with super-sized appetites. üòâ 

üìç American Host Restaurant, 113 Noth I Street, Lompoc
‚è∞ 7 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Mondays through Fridays, 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays.
‚òéÔ∏è 805-735-5188

LA FOREVER üåπü§ç 200 meals for evacuees! ü•π I got a reply to my story the other day from a mutual friend saying they know of a couple staying in a hotel who lost their home and could use a nice meal. The LA Angels Volunteer Squad reached out to the hotel and it turns out there are 102 rooms booked there with 2-3 people in each room, all who have lost their home because of the fires. 

My friends @ongsupernovaong @andreasagx @jodylu_ and I got together this morning - desde la madrugada - cooling 200 lunches to bring straight to the hotel! Thank you all for volunteering to feed people truly in need of some food made with love ü§ç

Busy week at KW Eagle Rock.  Earlier in the week we had a delivery of N95 masks for all of our Agents since we are so close to the Eaton Fire.  Then yesterday an 18 wheeler truck showed up in the region at 9 am to deliver several hundred air purifies for the office.  Got them set up yesterday afternoon and the office is ready to go!

KW Cares once again did NOT disappoint when it comes to taking care of our Agents.  Glad to be back with an organization that goes above and beyond for its Staff & Agents.

Our office is open to ANYONE who was affected by the fires.  If you need WiFi, a quiet and safe place to work or print, stop by.  There is plenty of free parking.  We have cold refreshments as well!

On Tuesday, January 7 around 9pm, we were forced to suddenly evacuate due to the Eaton Fire with a dog, cat, ornery cockatiel, and an impractically-packed suitcase. 

Amidst this all, Hadley lived in bliss and had a fun vacation and really embraced the ‚Äúresort‚Äù lifestyle. She enjoyed ice cream, restaurant-prepared dog food, a field trip to Bass Pro Shop (more pics soon), and plenty of time exploring hotels & their grounds. 

We‚Äôre grateful to come home to a clean-ish & safe home but heartbroken for so many of our friends and community. Altadena & Eaton Canyon will always be special to us and will be back better than ever.

Wednesday morning when the winds were calm but fires moved though the area North of New York and West of Allen Avenue.  I returned to this area two more times and the house on the left eventually burned to the ground.  Without Firefighters there was only so much people could do.  I learned the person with the hose didn‚Äôt live there and a neighbor said he had never seen him before.  There was a second person with him that I saw when I walked up to that fire and when I turned around he disappeared.  It is possible they were Good Samaritans, thrill seekers, or possibly looters.

After a long day working in areas devastated by the LA wildfires, K9 Clifford and Handler Munguia take a moment for their important decontamination routine.¬† This critical step removes ash, soot, and other harmful debris Clifford encounters while searching for those still missing. 

Wildfire zones can be full of toxic materials, sharp objects, and irritants, which is why decontamination is essential for protecting our K9s‚Äô health. It also gives us a chance to check for injuries and ensure they‚Äôre ready for whatever tomorrow brings. 

These incredible dogs work tirelessly to help bring closure to families and communities. Keeping them safe and healthy is the least we can do in return.

Starting over after the Eaton Fire is overwhelming, but you don‚Äôt have to face it alone. If you‚Äôre unsure where to begin, we‚Äôre here to help with FEMA claims, understanding your rights, and taking the first steps toward recovery. Southern California Edison must be held responsible for their role in the devastation.

We‚Äôre taking on property damage claims related to the Eaton Fire pro bono. Even if your property was not physically impacted, suffering emotional distress or dealing with ash and soot can also qualify for compensation.

Lady Legal is proud to partner with some of the nation‚Äôs top wildfire attorneys, who have recovered over $1.5 billion for fire victims, including cases from the Maui and Paradise fires. Let‚Äôs work together to rebuild your hope and future

Got back home yesterday. Our neighborhood, close to the start of the fire, was untouched, but it‚Äôs still eerily empty. Here are a few photos from the periphery of the burn zone, which covers 2/3 of Altadena. Its intense. On one side of the street, armed troops keeping people out. On the other side, mutual aid groups, kids cooking up free hotdogs, and all the things that make this such a beautiful, vibrant community. The word community cannot be overemphasized. I hope it can withstand greedy speculators preying on people who have lost everything. What is happening right now in Altadena is how this country will withstand the next few years. 
.

‚ö°Ô∏èSAVED ‚ö°Ô∏èAmid the devastation of the Eaton Fire, the historic Balian Mansion in Altadena stands as a beacon of hope and resilience. This architectural gem, renowned for its unique design and rich history, has miraculously survived the flames that claimed many neighboring structures.

Built in 1922, the Balian Mansion reflects a masterful blend of Mediterranean Revival and Beaux-Arts styles. Its grand arched windows, intricate detailing, and stately columns evoke the opulence of early 20th-century design, while the tiled roof and stucco exterior showcase Mediterranean influences. The expansive grounds and elegant landscaping have made it a centerpiece of Altadena‚Äôs architectural heritage.

This mansion has not only stood the test of time but has also been a beloved community landmark, especially known for its extravagant holiday light displays that have drawn visitors from all over Southern California.

The survival of this historic home preserves a vital piece of Altadena‚Äôs cultural and architectural legacy. It serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of protecting our landmarks and the resilience of our communities. If you have stories or memories of the Balian Mansion, please share them as we celebrate its endurance.

Appreciation post for the home I loved so deeply. She was comforting, she was kind, she was open to all. If you know me, you know I loved being there. I loved hosting. I loved leaving my keys with friends so they could enjoy the space I adored so much. This year I had big plans: spend a lot of time at home. 2025, Mother Nature, the universe, fate, whatever you like, had other plans. It‚Äôs eleven days after evacuation and what I think is ten days after the house burned down. I keep thinking of the little details, the touches, the memories, the things lost in the fire, and I don‚Äôt know if that will stop for the foreseeable future, but that‚Äôs ok.  It‚Äôs still unbelievable, but with every day reality sets in more. Sending strength to all of my fellow Angelenos who have all been impacted in some way by the devastation over the past week. And to the place I looked forward to waking up in, the place I looked forward to coming back to, thank you, home. I love you. #palisadesfire #eatonfire #losangeles #2025
