ABA 1st Day Back
With kids scattered all over the LA County, a few even even in San Diego & NorCal. We were able to still get 12 kids all displaced 4 of which lost everything to come out today on one day notice. Some came from as far as West LA & Harbor City just to get on field and be around their comrades again. It was a really great time to get them back into the flow and bring some normalcy back into their lives. Max C. shared a story during practice that very 1st thing he grab we told to evacuate was his bat, not some video game system. That is definitely a sign of a real ball player. I was also able to return home and meet the firefighter in charge of public information for the Altadena Eaton fire. He is from up north near Redding, CA. Our neighbor Charlie R. got a chance to take a pic after his victorious AYSO all star soccer game, in which @aysoregion13 Pasadena defeated Arcadia üí™. ABA‚Äôs Owen O.‚Äôs Pasadena AYSO all star soccer team also won their matchup 2-1 today. During that game there was an absolutely awesome moment when the very 1st goal scored was by an Altadena kid who lost his home in fire. Man, you got to love that, it gave me goosebumps when I heard it. Moments like that is the reason why I love sports. It was great to get back on the field today as we had been on a break and had been scheduled to return the Tuesday the fire broke out. We will be back on the diamond this Tuesday at Jackie Robinson Park and I can‚Äôt wait. 

Restore, Rebuild, Renew!

Save A Life (Foster or Adopt), Part II:

For everyone who read my last two posts, you know I‚Äôm donating many of my services (100% discounted) to anyone who FOSTERS or ADOPTS a pooch from any of the LA shelters or rescue organizations taking in displaced pooches from the recent fires. A huge THANK YOU to @montecitojournal for spreading the word within our wonderful and caring community. Even if we can‚Äôt all foster or adopt, at a minimum let‚Äôs spread the word about the pooches who need us‚Äîand let‚Äôs encourage anyone thinking of bringing a pooch into her or his family to please consider fostering or adopting üôèüèΩüêæüíï

Almost all of the animal shelters and rescue organizations in LA desperately need the community‚Äôs help to relieve the dire overcrowding at their facilities from the hundreds of displaced animals (not just dogs) taken in since the fires began. Many shelters can‚Äôt accept any additional animals, including dogs, because they simply don‚Äôt have anymore space. By fostering or adopting one dog, you are not only saving this dog but you are helping to create the space to save another dog.

Perhaps the only thing greater than creating a life is saving one, which is why I‚Äôm donating my services, including my 2-hour ‚ÄúConnecting Parents & their Pooches‚Äù first-time bonding session, at a 100% discount to anyone who saves a life during this time ü©µ

Today was one of the hardest days I have ever lived. No one ever imagines they will one day be sifting through the ashes of their brother‚Äôs beloved home. But somehow I found myself here, standing in the ruins of it all, only able to picture how beautiful it was the last time I was here. 

Thank you to everyone who came out today to help us sift through the wreckage for any glimmer of hope we could find of memories past. 

Thank you to everyone who has shared posts and sent encouraging messages to our family. 

Thank you to everyone who has donated funds to help my brother and sister in law find stability again. 

Thank you to all the firefighters, doing everything they can to save lives and the homes of so many.

My heart sinks when I come to work in Pasadena where I helped 3 folks who lost their homes in the fire. Just 3 miles north of us is my former hood in Altadena. An elderly man told me, ‚ÄúI guess I‚Äôll just have to start over.‚Äù I smell the devastated land of the home where I used to live and paint in which burned down last week. Altadena was my old hood, living there from 2006-2009, & Pasadena from 2009-2010 & back to Altadena in 2019. 
  I used to love to go to the Mountain View cemetery; to the Coffee Gallery & The Rancho. We filmed my 1st music video at the bottom of Angeles Forest for the song ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Say that‚Äù. Altadena has always had a special place in my heart. It is where my Art & music bloomed and flourished. It is where I made my 1st Self Portrait in a painting. I‚Äôd only made pen and ink and pencil self-portraits in the past: These 1st 2 were paintings based on photos. Taken inside my bedroom studio by my friends and I, which turned into a few paintings. These are the good old days. 

Self-Portrait (Window on Santa Anita), 36‚Äù x 24‚Äù Acrylic on Canvas

Self-Portrait (Open Window to My Soul), Acrylic on Canvas, 30‚Äùx 24‚Äù

Happy Sunday ü§ç

Very early in the morning of January 7th I woke up to the smell of smoke and the sound of howling wind.  I looked out the living room window to see that the normally-vast view was completely obscured by smoke.  I threw on clothes, ran outside into the sunrise, and saw that everything was covered with ash.  I‚Äôd pick up a large piece and think, ‚ÄúWas this from someone‚Äôs house?‚Äù ü§ç  It turned out I was living between two fast-moving fires and the ash was probably blowing from Altadena.  The fire was getting closer to jumping a freeway and if it did, my hill could be in its path. ü§ç  It‚Äôs an interesting experience to quickly inventory exactly what you‚Äôre going to take with you if you have to leave with the threat of losing everything. (First on my list: my cats and my journals.) ü§ç  This first exhausting day was spent constantly checking the news while also heeding some kind of animal instinct for survival, should it come to that. ü§ç  As news of the L.A. fires spread around the world, I received concerned messages from my ‚Äúspace friends,‚Äù which were extremely heartening to me. ü§ç  These photos were taken a few days into the drama when I absolutely had to go outside for something.  I thought the smoke was creating an interesting effect, so for only the thousandth time in my life I took a risk for art ( or ‚Äúart,‚Äù as the case may be), since the air was considered unhealthy to breathe. ü§ç  For now the fires are gradually coming under control, though the devastation is hard to fathom.  The human spirit is unbelievably tough, but, as they now say, this is ‚Äúa lot.‚Äù My heart goes out to those who lost loved ones, homes, businesses ‚Ä¶  The postmortems will be endless. ü§ç  Weather experts are saying the fire danger returns this week.  I have my cat carriers, my journals, a ton of alerts on my phone, but these events seem to send one down an existential path. ü§ç  Smoke gets in your eyes. 

#lafires #lafire #eatonfire #smokegetsinyoureyes #lastrong

This discussion covers essential tips for documenting damages, avoiding common pitfalls during the claims process, and understanding your insurance policy and rights.

Reed Smith LLP has also compiled expert advice into a great article, to help simplify the claims process. 

Additionally, the California Department of Insurance is hosting workshops and offering wildfire-specific resources to guide residents through this challenging time.

I realized I had not yet gotten around to posting a single photo of our time in Altadena‚Ä¶I mostly have photos of sunrises, lighting, gatherings, dolls on the roof, a few Christmas , hiking. So I just thought I should add some visuals from our time there because it was glorious and showed us what a special community it is a little more each day. And for that we will be forever grateful. Our first date night since losing our home to the #eatonfire. I realized after we had arrived at the @astraluminaexperience, that this is the only Christmas gift to survive the fire.

As we journeyed from one experience to another, breathing in our escape from the rigors of our daily ritual of recovery from our loss, it also became clear that this excursion into the landscape of the night sky was part of our healing process.

It was a declaration that we are more than our belongings and that part of the rebuilding of our lives will be an understanding that these next chapters we live out will serve us best if we interject intermissions of experience that connect us meaningfully to who we were before the fire took so much of us.

My wife and I have always had an affinity for the stars, visiting observatories and marveling at the misty haze of the Milky Way from a lava field.

We're also avid visitors to botanical gardens, drinking in diverse naturescapes along manmade paths.

Astra Lumina gave us back a sense of ourselves and served as an unexpected salve for two souls who needed a bit of stardust to remind us that all is not lost and that the lights in the sky still hold power if we only dare to hold our heads high enough to keep them in our sights. ‚ú®Ô∏è

Resting After a Unified Recovery Effort

Today, our team, along with all eight search teams from across the county, is finally getting some much-needed rest after many intense days of search and recovery efforts at the Eaton and Palisades Fires. During these operations, we had the honor of working alongside incredible Urban Search and Rescue (USAR) teams from across the state. Together, we searched burned properties, supporting families and communities impacted by these devastating fires. 
 
This model of collaboration between the fire service and volunteer SAR teams is rare, typically reserved for large-scale incidents like these. The teamwork, dedication, and professionalism displayed by everyone involved were truly exceptional and played a vital role in recovery efforts.
 
We extend our deepest gratitude to the USAR teams for their hard work, hospitality, and camaraderie throughout this mission. Though we never hope to face such tragedies again, we stand ready to serve our communities whenever called upon. 
 
Stay safe, everyone, and thank you for your continued support. Together, we make a difference. üí™ #Teamwork #SearchAndRescue #MontroseSAR #community #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #LASD

Parents, it‚Äôs instinctive to fix, to shield, to make it all better. But sometimes, the most profound act of love is to sit with them in the rawness of their ache‚Äîto hold their heartbreak without searching for silver linings or offering quick fixes. Just love, steady and unshaken, in the midst of their pain.

To every parent navigating the depths of unimaginable loss: you are not alone. We will move forward, not by leaps, but by the smallest of steps‚Äîone tear, one breath, one heartbeat at a time. Together.

‚ö†Ô∏è @southcoastaqmd - As smoke and ash is blown from the #EatonFire and #PalisadesFire, it‚Äôs important to take precaution if you see ash or smell smoke.
Windblown ash particles may be too large to be detected by air quality instrumentation and not reflected in the Air Quality Index (AQI) map. However, they are typically visible to the naked eye either in the air or on outdoor surfaces. Although the AQI may show green, hazardous ash may be present in the air.
 
If you smell smoke or see ash, please take precautions: https://bit.ly/42mv9nY
More #wildfire and #ash #airquality tips: http://aqmd.gov/wildfiretips

Well, I haven‚Äôt posted to the grid in years, but I feel like I need to share this. This is what climate change looks like. This is what is left of my mom‚Äôs house. Her house would have had its 100th birthday this year. And no one in this neighborhood ever thought their house would burn. Yes, they are near the mountain, but so many other houses would have to burn first. And unfortunately, they did. They all burned. The level of devastation in the Altadena community is enormous. And its effects are far-reaching. Thankfully, so many in the LA area have come together to help! And I‚Äôm trying to remember that it‚Äôs going to be a marathon, not a sprint. If you have the means, please donate to someone‚Äôs GoFundMe. Every little bit helps and so much is needed! This can happen anywhere. This can happen to you or your family. Please prepare for the worst - go bags, photos/video for insurance, evacuation plans, etc. Climate change is real. #altadenanotforsale #eaton #eatonfire #altadena

Los Angeles/Nature City üå±üèôÔ∏èüíô scenes of the Millard Canyon/Tongvaland past so we remember how to regrow into the future.

This is a tribute to one of my favorite, easy nature escapes from the city.

I‚Äôve spent countless hours there.
I‚Äôve taught kids there (pic 3).
I did my naturalist training there (pic 4).
I‚Äôve gone there with friends and family (pic 7). 
I was last there September to escape a heatwave with my dog Zuzu (pic 9). 

Particularly in my @uccalnat certification study through @pcclancer, I tracked the plants in a specific area of the canyon for weeks on end. To this day I say hi and give hugs to the coast live oaks and laurel sumacs that were part of the foundational study of what I do today. 

The fire map looks like the whole campground area and half way up into the canyon was burned. Maybe not the waterfall itself? Maybe my plant friends were spared? Time will tell. 

But this is a tribute to a place I love, that has suffered an injury that saddens me, but a place I know will regrow anew that gives me hope. 

#LAfires #millardfalls #sangabrielmountains #losangeles #waterfall #angelesnationalforest #eatonfire #altadena #natureisamazing

The devastation from the Eaton and Palisades fires has been overwhelming.  It really has been so hard to wrap our heads around this disaster. But if we all do as much as we are able, to help the people and pets in need, then we can accomplish great things.  John and Angie are volunteering at the Pasadena City College Community Education Center.  FEMA has set up a Disaster Recovery Center there for people who have lost their homes or are not allowed back into their homes.  They can apply for resources to assist them there. Angie has been more than happy to provide hugs and receive belly rubs over the last week from all these wonderful people who so desperately need a distraction from this catastrophe.  She has already been volunteering with Barks for Books at libraries in the area‚Ä¶. Helping shy kids come out of their shells when reading.  There are still cats and dogs that have been displaced and we are still looking for Bella, the cat that got out of the only house still standing on this Altadena street a few days before the fire started on Tuesday night. They are letting some people back into the area now ‚Ä¶ like me to feed lost animals.  I set up a food station and a bed on the porch in case she can make her way back home.  #eatonfire #fema #therapydog #barksforbooks #goldenretriever #angierocks #hugyourdog #hugyourcat #wigglebuttwalkers

Added some more images from the first full day of the Eaton fire along with a few more from my second visit to the area last Sunday. Having grown up on the east side of Altadena, and where I spent most of my time on the first day of the fire, I wasn‚Äôt prepared for what I saw on the west side of Altadena last Sunday. The east side was bad, really bad, but the west side from Lake Avenue to Lincoln Avenue and EVERYTHING above Mariposa Street/Altadena Drive is literally gone. Not hundreds of homes, but thousands of homes. It‚Äôs coming up on 2 weeks now, and still can‚Äôt believe the destruction from this fire. #altadena #eatonfire #myhometown #photojournalism

I spent the week back home in Los Angeles reporting on the aftermath of the #EatonFire in #Altadena and the other fires that completely devastated parts of the city. Though there were horrific scenes of destruction, I also encountered so much resilience, bravery and kindness from neighbors, first responders, rescuers, and volunteers.
‚Ä¢
Photos 1-3: FEMA first responders carefully scour destroyed homes in #Altadena.
Photos 4-6: The Cal Fire firefighters who battled the #PalisadesFire from the sky.
Photo 7: a therapy dog greets #EatonFire survivors at an evacuation shelter
Photos 8-9: Rescued animals at the LA Equestrian Center

Santa Ana Winds *Tomorrow* (Yes, again, for the 3rd time this month) - Winds will ramp up rapidly Monday and last through Tuesday evening in the greater Los Angeles/SoCal region, with ‚Äúdangerous high end red flag fire weather conditions‚Äù and ‚Äú70-80%‚Äù chances of gusts up to 80mph (Sun morning model runs). There‚Äôs also solid potential for ‚Äúmountain waves‚Äù leading to localized gusts that are even stronger, a phenomena we saw during the firestorm the first night of the Eaton Fire. Relative humidity will drop to the single digits, and fuels are at or near record dry levels in many areas under the Red Flag Warning, even drier than the beginning of the previous fire siege. The dangerous combination of extremely dry fuels, bone dry humidity, strong winds, existing fires, all create conditions for ‚ÄúFOR VERY RAPID FIRE SPREAD AND EXTREME FIRE BEHAVIOR.‚Äù (Quotes from the @nwslosangeles forecast). 

We are not out of the woods yet, and hopefully we don‚Äôt have any new ignitions that get established or any control issues on existing fires. Crews have been using infrared aerial mapping to tackle any latent pieces of heat within 300 feet of current firelnes, and hopefully that will mitigate risk. 

At the very least we are going to have blowing ash from these fires and AQI issues. TODAY is the time to get an N95 or P100 mask, pack a GO bag if you‚Äôre in a Red Flag area, and have your car gas tank filled, etc. etc. 6 P‚Äôs - People/Pets, Papers, Plastic (cards wallet ID) Pills (meds), Photos, and PC/computer. Drink lots of water, tell your neighbors about the incoming winds, and be safe out there. - SP

People have asked me about my experience covering the LA fires and my answers have been pretty short because I really am at a loss for words. But I was asked to give a quote about my experience for a newsletter and it really forced me to sit down with my thoughts. Here‚Äôs what I shared -

‚ÄúNothing prepares you for covering a catastrophe like the Eaton Fire. The second our KCRA crew got into the evacuation zone, my eyes started burning - I couldn‚Äôt tell if it was from the lingering smoke or from holding back tears. All we could see was devastation in every direction. As a born and raised Californian, my heart breaks for the people who lost everything. For many LA families, decades of memories were gone in an instant, but their hope and resilience is awe-inspiring. Piece by piece, Los Angeles will come back stronger than ever with help from ALL Californians.‚Äù

I have this book of reminders I wrote myself next to the door on the way out, held open by a crystal rock my dear friend gave to me. It‚Äôs turned open to a page that feels most comforting to me. Out of anything I have ever written, I go back to this again and again because it speaks to the impermanence of circumstances and the duality of the nature of life. Light and dark, ebbs and flows, tragedies and triumphs. Life is mysterious but we know for certain that no one thing lasts forever. Not the good experiences and not the bad experiences. Life would not exist without both. Life would not be life. We just experienced a historical disaster in California (a tragedy I wish with all of my heart did not happen) AND the we in the LA and greater LA community are already rallying together to help rebuild. We, as a nation, are about to experience a major change tomorrow AND we will experience another one in 2028. Take it from me, 2025 has already been a long four years in California I can‚Äôt imagine more chaos, but we must continue trusting in the nature of life ‚Äî her demand for balance ‚Äî and never let the bad bury us so when the good comes we are able to see it. I hope this supports anyone feeling the weight of it all right now. The flows, the swells‚Ä¶they will come ‚ù§Ô∏è and the swells, the good waves, we have to ride them with all of our hearts when they are here.

Totally forgot to post anything about the night but I found the pictures again and wanted to show them as I was wearing a dress of my very own design. @eric_storlie and I spent a wonderful new year's eve celebrating at the Langham hotel party dancing, eating, drinking, and generally having a fantastic time. I authentically love getting dressed up fancy and acting crazy. The music was a hilarious cross section of over 50 years of hit songs, and everyone was having a wonderful time. I remember thinking how blessed I felt to have such a beautiful city and community to be a part of.

These are the sentiments that reverberate in my head after the shock of evacuation. So many beautiful places that have come to be a part of my home and landscape are now gone, and it leaves the spaces where they were filled with echoes. I miss my running route, now mostly filled with burnt homes and debris. I miss my grocery store, and wonder what happened to the people working there, if they have jobs now. I feel so lucky that our home wasn't burnt, but also feel angry that so many weren't so fortunate. It can be horrifying to realize that random chance is the thing keeping so many things you love intact. The only thing to be done is to love and be grateful for the things you have.

If I had known the strife in store for my community and loved ones a week later I would have spent more time talking to my neighbors. I would have taken more walks. I would have tried to sacrifice more of my time to connect and be kind to others, and I wouldn't have been so hard on myself. I hope these words bring some love to you on a Sunday afternoon. To those who I know and those I don't yet know: I am grateful for you, you deserve love and connection.

#newyears #2025 #gratitude #eatonfire #positivity #love #fashion #pasadena

I went to Los Angeles on January 10th, to see close friends and family, many of whom have been deeply impacted by the devastating fires. As a UCLA graduate, much of my crew is in LA, and I felt a deep need to be there in person‚Äîto hug them, support them, and remind them they are loved and they are not alone. While there, I brought my 35mm camera and walked the streets of Altadena, Pacific Palisades, and Malibu, for four days straight, photographing the destruction these fires had on homes, communities and lives. Block after block, my heart fucking broke more and more, but as I spent 15 years of my life making documentary films, it has been foundational to me as a human to bear witness to the world. At times I questioned why I was even taking photos, but I felt compelled to document what I saw through my lens and share it for all to see. Capturing these images felt like a way to preserve the history of this moment, to honor those we lost, and to hold space in my heart for everyone whose lives have been irrevocably changed by the fires. Los Angeles, we love you.

When I met @jonbarocas and his team at @k9globalrescue - I knew they meant business - and their business is rescuing animals from precarious situations, including wildfires, the dog meat trade, and conflict zones. From what I observed, every opportunity to help an animal in need was taken seriously. During our ride-along, their mission was to check  on two cats left alone, and to assist an elderly man and his canine companions who couldn‚Äôt leave their Altadena home. 

Yet, even for this seemingly routine operation, the team conducted a thorough briefing, gathered supplies, and approached every moment with skilled logistics and hearts full of compassion. Each member of the team struck a remarkable balance between professionalism and kindness.

K9 Global Rescue‚Äôs pop-up basecamp housed chickens, turkeys, turtles, lizards, and dogs. Even as you read this, they continue working tirelessly to find foster or permanent homes for all the animals in their care. 

Working alongside them restored my hope that we, as humans, can navigate the challenges ahead - responding to increasingly frequent weather and fire events while striving to dismantle the systems of oppression that harm animals and keep people unaware of their suffering.

Like other teams we accompanied while on assignment for @sanctuary_doc in LA - these people are angels on earth. 

#eatonfire #losangeles #animalrescue

To Our Beloved Family & Community; The Village:
I‚Äôm writing to you from our AirBnB in Arcadia on behalf of Mazi, I‚Äôke and I.
We Thank God first, last, and always. 

*support: to prop up, lift, hold, help, to provide foundation, to keep from falling apart‚Ä¶to bolster..*

Mazi, I‚Äôke & I are deeply touched by your thoughts, prayers, messages, phone calls, and contributions.  We are wrapped up in your embrace and we feel it. Thank you to our common, ordinary, everyday, folks who shared our posts and stories with your followers and friends, thank you to our heavy hitters‚Äîour celebrity, well known &/or public figure friends‚Äîwho lent us your light to illuminate our trouble. Abundant thanks to our family & friends who set up the GoFundMe campaigns & told folks who we are to you.  Thank you to the supporters we‚Äôve never met, to those who we‚Äôve known all of our lives, and thank you to everyone in between. I would love to hug each and every one of you who has dropped a heart or a care, everyone who has shared our posts and GoFundMe‚Äôs, every single donation despite the dollar amount, every. single. one. touches our hearts and feeds our souls. And even though I don‚Äôt have the capacity to respond to each of your comments on our page, I DO READ THEM and love every one. So for all of those, ‚ô•Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è‚ô•Ô∏è‚Äôs infinity. 

We are forever grateful to y‚Äôall for coming together to support our family through this horrendous disaster.  You have brought the sugar to a bitter moment.  We know we are not alone in this‚Äîinside and outside of our immediate and local community. And your support of us also pours out to others in our Altadena community who may not belong to a village such as ours.  We are paying it forward, the currency flows. 

*Deep belly breath* 

So I don‚Äôt just go on and on‚Äîbecause I can and will‚Äîabout how much you mean to us and how much we appreciate everything you‚Äôve done for us and for our community‚ÄîI‚Äôll end with this: 
We thank you.  Thank you, thank you, thank you.  It takes a village & we are so glad this is ours.

With Deep Love & Appreciation,
üôèüèø
Staci, Mazi, & I‚Äôke

I had to see it for myself. After covering the fires from the studio for nearly 2 weeks, watching our crews do their incredible reporting, I wanted to see it firsthand. This is a slice of the devastation from the Palisades Fire. Entire streets decimated. The smell of smoke as strong as if the fire was today. Charred vehicles, standing door frames and chimneys, Christmas lights still visible. The hop-scotch nature of the flames apparent. A single home left untouched here and there‚Ä¶ surrounded by ash. The National Guard, fire and utility crews really the only signs of life. There are no words. My heart goes out to the thousands impacted here and in Altadena ‚ù§Ô∏èüíî‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

Hello! I wanted to original start "Sole Food Gamer" shorts with sonething fun, but unfortunately with the beginning of the new year with Los Angeles burning. I felt it a little crass to talk about relating to food, games, sneakers, or fun in general ( don't get it twisted, those articles are primed and ready to go.) Still I wanted to talk a bit about some of the consequences of the fires. Even though smoke is in the immediate milage around Pasadena, Altenda, Palisades, and Eaton. There is still lots of fallout, chemicals, ash still in the air. Being a Long Beach native I am about 40 miles away, but I still am affected especially since I suffer from allergenic rhinitis. As mentioned online and in the news; if you have to be outside for any considerable amount of time. Make sure you have a N95 or P100 mask. There was a small shortage the first week, but they are in stock again at Home Depot and on Amazon. The mask help a lot. As an example; once I am exposed for more than an hour outside. I get nasal congestion and a cough. Also when driving use the recycled air button in your AC so you don't breathe in the toxins. While the main Palisades fire has reached the 50% mark and Eaton is 80% mark. We aren't out of the woods yet for air safety. So stay prepared and be safe out there! #fire #palisadesfire #firesafety #eatonfire #badair #poorairquality #N95 #P100 #filteringmasks

No words.

The devastation wreaked by the Eaton and Palisades fires in my hometown has me shaken and grief-stricken to the core. I struggle to find words of inspiration, although I am grateful to be alive and for the first responders who are fighting these fires. But for my community, my heart is broken. 

The house above is not ours. Although we evacuated, the fire did not reach our neighborhood‚Ä¶this time. 

The same cannot be said for many close friends in Altadena, Pasadena, the Palisades, and Malibu; for their friends and neighbors‚Äîentire communities that have been destroyed and will never be the same. 

This house belonged to our dear friends Marcus and Shawna Beer in Altadena. They evacuated around 4am in the dark on Jan 8 and lost everything, along with all their neighbors. Everything has been reduced to chimneys and ash. 

It is impossible to replace all that has been lost, and the road to recovery is going to be long and hard.

If you can, please consider a donation to help those who lost everything such as via GoFundMe (you can find the Beers GFM in Bio @saucela ) or to a vetted organization providing wildfire relief. Every little bit will help.

We were spared but I have no words and my heart is broken üòû 

#eatonfire #palisadesfire #nowords

We are creating a pet retention relief program for those impacted by the Eaton Fire. We‚Äôre here to assist for the long haul and will need helpers, resources & donations for the many challenging months ahead for those displaced by the fires. Want to help? Let us know! 

This is an expansion of our community assistance programs to offer more robust help with supplies, resources & most vitally, housing issues which will be essential to keeping families together. Please stay tuned for the roll out of our program and consider joining our efforts. Southern California people have been amazing in coming together to help those impacted by the fires. But this will be a marathon, not a sprint, and we want to make sure to offer sustained help to people navigating multiple challenges. 

Impacted by the fires and need support for you and your pet? Reach out. Know a rental that has no pet restrictions? Let us know about it. Interested in helping track down housing with no restrictions for pets? Contact us for that too. We will need all kinds of helpers, our community members and partners to step up with us in order to provide a safety net for people and their pets during this devastating time. As we connect  to those who need assistance, we will  communicate their needs so we can come together to help. Thank you all for your support and your amazing sense of community. More details to come.

Spent a lot of today prepping for another predicted wind event starting early in the morning. It was nice to pull up at the shop on a cold LA night to find lots of people out supporting our local restaurants. Please keep it up! It might seem like the right thing to some NOT to shop or eat out--I've heard comments like wanting to give us space and time to process--but what we small businesses need is you! 

We need to work, and we need to re-order product from our small brands, and we need to support the many local brands, factories and services connected to what we all do.  Because behind every store, brand, factory, etc. are humans trying to provide for themselves and their families. And we're all so connected. 

Thanks so much to everyone who's supported our small business communities since the fires began. If you're at all able, please support small independent businesses in NELA no matter where you are. If you need recs, we've got them. 

Finally, to everyone out there who has supported victims, firefighters, evacuees, and pets, there aren't sufficient words ü´∂üèºü´∂üèºü´∂üèº. Hoping this community-minded support we're seeing from all over the world becomes a model for how we care for each other in times of crisis.

My heart goes out to everyone impacted by the recent LA fires, as well as anyone who has previously had to deal with devastating wildfires. This hit particularly close to home‚Ä¶literally. I consider myself incredibly lucky that we had a house to go back to after we evacuated, but my heart breaks for those who didn‚Äôt and/or lost lives in the process. I wanted to do a little something to help, so I designed a limited edition shirt that people can wear as a signal of support & encouragement for everyone involved. 100% of the profits will be donated to Watch Duty, a nonprofit that was instrumental in keeping people informed & safe during this devastating time. I truly don‚Äôt know what I would have done without their app during this surreal & terrifying time. I want them to be able to help anyone who may have to deal with wildfires in the future, and this is the little way I can contribute. ‚ù§Ô∏è Please consider purchasing this shirt from my Etsy shop (link in bio), donating to a cause of your choice, volunteering, reaching out to someone you know, or simply sharing this post. Thank you so much, and stay safe! 

Sincerely,
Kat

This map says so much. I‚Äôm in tears for my community- so much loss and the impact will be longstanding. Neighbors whose homes survived have felt guilt when celebrating that fact around those of us that lost everything. However, I mourn for those community members as well. Yes, they have their homes- and I celebrate that for them, but I can‚Äôt imagine the loss they may feel when they are allowed to return and they have the daily reminders of the loss around them. All that to say‚Ä¶Altadena grieves together, whether your house is standing and habitable or completely gone, we will all feel this for years to come and need to lean on each other

#EatonFire

@piabaroncini facilitated a donation drive for Altadena fire victims to come rebuild their lives one item at a time. Thousands and thousands of donations were shipped from across the country, pallets of brand new products delivered by the truckload and over 30 volunteers a day arrived for 4 days straight to individually unpack & sort through donations in order to turn a restaurant into a shoppable space & then back again within mere hours. All of this & more achieved through a quick call to arms on Instagram‚Äî anything we were short on, Pia &co would put the word out on stories and by the end of the day things would show up, fulfilled by brands or random strangers on the internet or people who would just appear with donations in hand, like the elderly man who drove from Ontario to Pasadena after seeing Pia on KTLA, stopping along the way for brand new clothing to drop off. It‚Äôs been very inspiring to see someone use their platform for so much good, and an honor to be a small part of the operation. We have assisted countless people from all walks of Altadena with stories of loss to share‚Äîeach tragedy differing from the other but united in their collective grief‚Äîholding their hands as we guided them through the overwhelming amount of product, stocking them with bedding and toiletries and shoes and clothing for themselves, their neighbors, a friend, their grandchildren. Curating bags for individuals who submitted requests online or texted and dm‚Äôd us with their needs. Making quick decisions for those still in too much shock to think about whether or not they could use a hand towel or cleanser or an extra pair of socks; holding babies & tending to children so their mothers could efficiently make use of their much needed visit. The scale of this drive was far greater than anything I imagined possible when I signed up to help. The number of people who have been positively impacted from this in the midst of such vast devastation is‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know? I have no words for it. Just this post of appreciation for the person who made it all happen & who won‚Äôt accept the credit she so very much deserves‚Äî BRAVA PIA, you should be so proud! ü§ç #lafires #eatonfire

On my way home from visiting my son in Pasadena yesterday, I drove through #altadena and pulled over to take in what I was seeing, smelling, hearing, feeling. A man talking quietly to his children as they looked at the destroyed neighborhood in front of us. The stench of thick toxic air. A burned down elementary school. Military outposts on every corner. Burned oranges hanging from burned trees. Streets lined with tables put up by volunteers offering food, water, clothing to their neighbors. Hillsides stained with pink fire retardant. The incessant screaming of chainsaws and jackhammers. A woman came and stood next to me taking pictures. She asked if I had lost my home. I said no, and she said she hadn't lost hers, either. She said the fire had stopped a few feet from her house. She had just gone to Costco and bought as much water as she could fit in her car and then dropped it off with the volunteers across the street. We gave each other a hug and she left. Another woman marched up to me and asked angrily if I'd lost my home. When I said no, she said you're taking pictures  of our grief, and I have a problem with that. I got in my car and drove away. #eatonfire #lafires

Florida Urgent Rescue, Inc. - FUR traveled across country and is now in LA ready to help with animal shelter transports. They reiterated the animals pulled will be those that have been in the shelters as adoptables prior to the fires. We have also been informed that help with and for livestock is the biggest need. The shelters have not been as inundated with small animal intakes as was predicted. We understand The Humane Society of the United States is providing emergency aid to veterinary clinics and local animal welfare organizations.

Petco teams are working with various LA shelters, including LA Animal Services to help get shelter animals either adopted or fostered to open up shelter space. The teams are also helping with trying to reunite pets with their families using the Petco Love Lost app.

Organizations like FieldHaven Feline Center are working hard to set up water and food stations within the burn areas for misplaced pets. Critical as this mission is to saving lives, it has been a tough to accomplish. Law enforcement is not allowing animal rescuers (aka ‚Äúunofficial organizations‚Äù) into the burn areas to search for and get the animals out, or allowing teams in to set up the water and feed stations. ‚ÄúPet owners begging for someone to go to their houses to check for pets are being ignored,‚Äù wrote Joy Smith of FieldHaven Feline Center. ‚ÄúRescuers have a curfew of being out of the fire zone by dark. Very, very few cats will be found in the daylight.‚Äù

Who is in charge? This is not meant to be a judgmental question, but an effort to help and connect. It is a question we keep seeing. There are organizations willing to help. Who should they connect with to receive orders and direction to proceed?

My mother's name was Katie Roach (RIP), and my father's name is Bobby Roach. Katie was an RN and Bob was a General Contractor who built so many houses in Altadena and Pasadena back in the 80s and 90s. They were married in this church 48 years ago. My siblings and I were baptized in this church. I performed my first Christmas play at this church. My brother (@dbeatss1) and I hid in every wall, hiding space behind the pew and even snuck into the kitchen and drunk the adults' coffee we were told would stunt our growth. We had potlucks, Pilgrim Pine camping trips, and bus rides to the beach every summer. Damn Man this was my families Church all my life, and now look at it. I am soooo heartbroken for my city. But we will hurdle this strom...üôèüèº‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©πü•πüò¢üôèüèº üì∏: @cpizzello #altadenastrong #altadenarebuild #altadenastrong #healaltadena #heart #love #rebuild #eatonfire

My beautiful town under military occupation after Edison‚Äôs faulty wiring sparked in a Santa Ana wind and burned it down. National Guard, LASD, and a guy on the phone at his house, which mostly appears to have survived. 

I don't like have the place under military lockdown. At the same time, I don't care for a bunch of influencers, lookie-loos, and souvenir hunters wandering through the remnants of a part of LA they'd never even heard of 3 weeks ago, scavenging through what's left of other people's lives for trinkets they can take home from the fire, and this is what I understand is happening in areas where the National Guard has pulled back.
.
#altadena #eatonfire #militaryoccupation

Today, as we honor the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., we are reminded of his words: ‚ÄòLife‚Äôs most persistent and urgent question is, ‚ÄòWhat are you doing for others?‚Äô

In the aftermath of the Eaton and Palisades Fire, we reflect on the loss and devastation our communities have experienced. But even in the face of adversity, it is imperative that we are steadfast in protecting and rebuilding our communities.

Dr. King‚Äôs call to serve others will be evident in our actions. Let‚Äôs come together as a community to support one another, just as Dr. King envisioned‚Äîa legacy of unity, resilience, and service. The healing and rebuilding begin now. Be kind to one another.

#MLKDay #CommunityStrength #Gratitude #FirstResponders #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #Resilience‚Äù #Altadena #Pasadena #pacificpalisades #courage #ihaveadream #service

Just wrapped up my assignment on the Eaton Fire in Southern California‚Äîa tough start to the year with two devastating fires already causing heartbreak in January. The destruction and loss remind us how unpredictable and intense these fires really were. 

Now, I‚Äôm making the long drive north to the Shasta-Trinity National Forest and then finally heading home to spend time with my family. Grateful for the moments ahead and keeping everyone impacted in my thoughts. Stay safe out there. #EatonFire #AngelesNF #FireYear2025

Our hearts go out to all the families affected by the recent fires, including those caring for beloved animal companions. üíî Beyond being of service in the community, we want to also provide helpful information to all of those who may be concerned about the effect that the secondary particle pollution will have on the health of their pets. The effect on air quality from the fires poses a serious risk not only to people but also to pets. These tiny, unseen particles can cause long-term health effects.

For those in need of an air filter, here‚Äôs a guide on how to make a DIY Box Fan Filter (costs less than $100 to build): cleanaircrew.org/box-fan-filters.

Stay tuned for our next post‚Äîa detailed review of a dog mask to help you decide if it‚Äôs the right choice for your pet‚Äôs protection. We‚Äôll also be sharing some thoughtfully chosen products to help support your pets‚Äô health and well-being during this challenging time for our community.

#Altadena #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #LaPets
#LosAngelesPets #CatsOfLA #LosAngelesDogs

"The Justice Department has concluded the 1921 Tulsa race massacre was a ‚Äúcoordinated, military-style attack‚Äù as the agency released the findings of its investigation, announced last fall. On May 31 and June 1, 1921, white rioters murdered an estimated 300 Black residents of Tulsa, Oklahoma‚Äôs Greenwood neighborhood, known as Black Wall Street, and looted and destroyed their homes and businesses.

The report also states there are no living perpetrators for the Justice Department to prosecute. The last two remaining survivors of the Tulsa race massacre, Viola Fletcher and Lessie Benningfield Randle ‚Äî both 110 years old ‚Äî have been seeking justice and reparations for years. Last year, the Oklahoma Supreme Court dismissed their case."

üö®Here are a few key things you should to protect your properties and your rights üö®

As the fires have started to calm down, many people are beginning to navigate the beginning of this long journey with insurance. Knowing the difference between first party and third party claims will help you navigate the next steps.

If you may have a case for a third party claim, we are working in partnership with Fox Law, a local wildfire specialist firm boasting over $1 Billion in recoveries for victims. 

Together, we will ensure detailed legal work to hold negligent parties accountable and help our clients receive the needed support to rebuild.

January 7, 2025 üíî a story in screenshots

 #eatonfire

If you find yourself in shoes like mine, you may feel overwhelmed trying to navigate the torrent of emotions stirred by the devastating wildfires in LA County. Because of this, I‚Äôve woven together a tapestry of ideas to help you through this trying time.

First, acknowledge your emotions. Take comfort in the knowledge that it‚Äôs entirely natural to feel what you‚Äôre feeling, and remember that you are cherished and safe. Remember, you cannot pour from an empty cup. This important step must be completed before moving on to anything else.

Next, turn your focus toward the helpers, volunteers, and first responders. Illuminate for yourself the ways neighbors are uniting to foster healing. If you are able, consider joining these noble community efforts. Strive to steer clear of conspiracy theories, tales of looting, and unverified information.

Keep up your normal routines wherever possible. In times of upheaval, a thread of normalcy can weave a calming effect. Treat yourself to a small delight, listen to your favorite music, or indulge in a soothing face mask. Small joys can make a world of difference.

I‚Äôm sending endless love and support to our beloved LA community. Should you need assistance, please don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to a professional. Take care of yourselves and your families, and let us know how I can help. I am ready to support you.

#LAFires #LAStrong  #PalisadesFire #EatonFire #LAWildfires #WildfireRecovery #LAFireAndRescue #ThankYouFirefighters
#CaliforniaWildfires

A little over a week ago, I met a client who had just experienced something unimaginable‚Äîher home was destroyed in the Eaton Fire. She needed a place to live immediately, and I knew I had to step up and help her find a fresh start.

After hearing her story, I got to work right away, searching for homes that met her needs. We toured a few places, but as soon as she saw this one, she fell in love.  We wasted no time submitting her application.

Fast forward to today, and I‚Äôm thrilled to share that she‚Äôs now holding the keys to her new home‚Äîa beautiful 3 bed, 3 bath house with over 1,300 sqft of space. üè°

If you or someone you know is in need of a new home‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a move, an upgrade, or an urgent situation‚Äîdon‚Äôt hesitate to reach out.

Today, Move & Shake‚Äôs Dr. Joanna had the privilege of treating firefighters and first responders from across the country. They left their families to sleep in tents and carry heavy gear, all in service to others. I spent 6 hours with the men at Fire House 36 on Sunday. Was supposed to just be a ride along, and we did do that, but after the first call, Holloway (who you might remember from my last post about 36) offered to drive me along the route that they took those first 48 hours of the Eaton fire. We drove up past the National Guard, and they walked me through their firefight, neighborhood by neighborhood, house by house‚Ä¶the ones they saved, the ones that were lost, and told me how it all went down. In one of the neighborhoods that was mostly intact, residents wearing N95 masks who were outside in their yards clearing fallen branches and debris waved and blew kisses as the firetruck passed by. It was incredibly moving. 

The mountainside in the background of this photo is where the Eaton fire began, around some massive power lines that you can just see if you look very closely.

I should note that it‚Äôs not safe to go up there, and I wasn‚Äôt expecting to. It‚Äôs blocked off for a reason. Most of what I saw, I saw from the firetruck. We only stopped and exited the truck twice, and we kept it brief. I didn‚Äôt go traipsing around through burned out structures, that‚Äôs a great way to catch a nail in the foot. Also, the air is toxic, in case you haven‚Äôt heard. So consider yourself discouraged.

I‚Äôm still processing everything, after stepping into their world at Fire House 36 yesterday. When I got home last night it felt like coming back from another planet, washing toxic moon dust off my boots... I‚Äôm still going through the photos. 

More on this soon. 

#LAFires #Eaton #Altadena #Pasadena #LosAngeles #DMZ

After natural disasters like wildfires, it‚Äôs normal for people to feel overwhelmed, scared, or even act out in ways that are hard to understand. While most will health and return to their usual routine, the journey is different for everyone.

For teens, these events can be even harder to process. It‚Äôs normal for them to feel scared, confused, or uncertain. But here‚Äôs the good news: teens are resilient! Even those affected by trauma can recover with the right support.

Create a safe, open space for teens to ask questions and share their feelings. There‚Äôs no ‚Äúright‚Äù way to have these conversations ‚Äì just listen, be honest, and offer reassurance.

For teens, distress may last longer, and that‚Äôs okay. If feelings anxiety, sadness, or fear don‚Äôt subside after a few weeks, reaching out for support is key.

At Neuro Wellness Spa and Clear Behavioral Health, we specialize in tailored mental health care for teens and their families. Together we can navigate tough times and help your teen heal.

Click the link in our bio to learn more about our specialized care and resources.

This past weekend, we were privileged with the opportunity to serve those affected by the Eaton Fire and provide to our first responders. Our prayers go to all those that were affected and feel hopeless in the midst of this tragedy. This experiences itself was one that will forever be embedded into our hearts. Not because of its mark left in history, but because of the impact a group of people can do. Giving out hotdogs and beverages for free may have seemed like a small gesture, yet to many it was received as a huge unexpected Blessing. We thank God for guiding us through the remainings left behind, for making a way to move forward with this plan, and most importantly for giving us his grace to make an impact in these individuals lives. 

Isaiah 43-19: 
‚ÄúSee, I am doing a new thing! Now it springs up; do you not perceive it? I am making a way in the wilderness and streams in the wasteland.‚Äù
God will always make a way to those who genuinely seek him and give him an opportunity in their hearts.

Happy cats =  happy campers! üò∫

One of the biggest miracles from the fire was that my three cats survived! The fire captain said my home was 5 mins from succumbing to  the flames.üòµ‚Äçüí´For hours afterwards, we searched the smoldering rubble with no signs of Kit Kat, Burrita and Miley. üíîJust as I was about to give in to despair, by some miracle all 3 of them emerged from the chaos after all the firefighters had left!üòªüî•ü•π

In the aftermath of the fire, everyone kept telling me to surrender my fur babies due to the instability of my living situation. But how could I? My fur family were living reminders to me to have hope and be grateful, no matter how dark the circumstances. Everything else is replaceable except human life- and the lives of our fur babies. üêæ 

While the stories and images of loss in So Cal have been  unimaginable, the stories of all that were saved miraculously by brave firefighters and compassionate non-profits serving in the front lines have been heartwarming amidst the tragedy. 

ü¶ã‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©πIf you‚Äôre looking for a tangible way to help, consider adopting OR fostering a cat from these rescues in LA, Santa Monica and Pasadena  @bfas_la @kitty.of.angels @pasadenahumane who are doing all they can to save animals in danger from the recent fires. ‚ù£Ô∏è

Our friends at Pasadena Humane stepped up in a big way during the Eaton Fire, and in its wake are still doing so much to support animals and families affected by the disaster.

They‚Äôve been providing shelter and medical care for pets, coordinating evacuations for large animals, offering emergency pet boarding for displaced families, and even setting up feeding stations for community cats in fire zones.

How can you help?

üì∏ Post lost pets: [petcolove.org/lost](http://petcolove.org/lost)

If you‚Äôve found or lost a pet, or know of animals in need of help in evacuated areas, please call the Eaton Fire Animal Rescue Hotline at 626-577-3752.

Together, we can ensure animals and their families get the help they need. Please share this post to spread the word!

We choose the reason why things happen to us.

Whether we choose to believe that it is the mystery of a benevolent God, or the universe punishing us for some karmic slight-it is a choice.

I myself, haven't decided what I want to choose yet, because  on top of all the personal belongings that burned, my recording studio with all my music equipment was lost, all the artworks I was going to display for the immersive art events I was on the verge of creating were lost, all the display gear, and creative gear, like cameras, tripods, reflectors and lighting, was lost.

Basically, all the big goals I was working for in 2025 is now gone.

I'm not in a place to decide how to proceed yet because my wife and I need to first finish procuring and settling in a new home.

But make no mistake, I will choose a reason this all happened to us, and whatever that choice is, it will empower me.

There's a lot of time left on the 2025 clock, and I still plan on hitting some big goals.

I say this especially for those affected by the fire. I am consciously not using the term victim.

This isn't easy, and I'm not positive 24/7, but I am resilient and that's enough to keep me in the game for now.

And if you're fire affected and don't know how to go about choosing the reason why this is happening to you, DM me.

I'm happy to help you use intention in how you move forward from this traumatic event at no cost with no obligation or selling of anything.

If my ideas resonate, use it, if it's not for you, that's okay to. Either way, your mindset will help or hinder your moves going forward.

Take great care of it to take the best care of you and your loved ones.

#eatonfire #mindsetmatters #mindsetmagic #AnthrotonikArtist #AnthrotonikAlchemy

We‚Äôve been quiet for a while, for good reason. On the evening of January 7, the Eaton fire broke out about 1.5 miles from our front door (in this photo). Within a couple of hours, my son and I were evacuating with our dog and cat and as many belongings as we could think to grab. A couple of days later the National Guard allowed me to return for a brief visit, and I discovered that while our fence had burned down, our house was still standing and all the snakes were fine. I added shipping heat packs to their enclosures since overnight temperatures were cold and we would be without power for several more days, and repeated this again days later on another visit. Eventually, we were allowed to return and clean up the messes that awaited outside. Other houses on our street above and below us in the foothills of Sierra Madre (near Altadena) burned down, but we were fortunate to only lose our fence and lots of our food and rodents that spoiled without power. I want to give a big shout out to Big Cheese Rodent Factory for offering to replace all the rodents we lost at no cost and another shout out of thanks to Showcase Serpents @showcaseserpents for their willingness to refund me in full for a snake I had just paid for so that I can redirect those funds to more urgent needs for now. To everyone else, we are still in business and our babies are doing great! Thanks for all the love and support. ~ Lindsay and Will

Intense couple of days in Eaton Fire country. We delivered a car load of pet and people supplies. We visited with family & friends. We were relieved to see important places from my wife @daenapetersen‚Äôs first 2 decades had survived. Shocking to see destroyed homes and houses of worship, some right next to houses left standing. This was hard to fathom before and seeing it even more sobering. Recovery will be slow and long, as it is for every disaster. 

But this mural‚Ä¶etched into a wall at the Pasadena Jewish Temple & Center‚Ä¶this hidden mural emerged. No one knew it was there. Now it adorns the only wall from that part of the center still standing.

Seeing all the devastation in person - there are few words to accurately describe the intensity of it all. As of today, the #EatonFire is 87% contained but many roads are still blocked and there are still fire engines, power company trucks and construction equipment going in and out of every street. Many residents say their immediate needs are temporary housing and financial assistance. It‚Äôs going to be a long road for the people of Altadena (and the Palisades) ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π
#lafires #palisadesfire

Yesterday was harrowing.  It was the first time we were able to get up to Altadena and see our property. Our neighborhood is unrecognizable. The initial, heaving sobs that took my breath away quickly turned into a numb feeling and disbelief at the devastation. But despite all this, it still felt like home. 

The walls of our house collapsed inward and took everything. Books, a 26 year old vinyl collection, Tom‚Äôs tremendous studio, instruments, gear, my lovely plant babies, years of collected crafts, wool, thread, beads, my jewelry making supplies, trinkets from everywhere, friends‚Äô artwork, and the best nap taking couch in the world. Amid the ash there are a few recognizable items: a soapstone statuette on the mantel, that ubiquitous IKEA tea light lantern in the fireplace, a WWI helmet from my Grandfather‚Äôs hat collection, a mixing bowl, and my cheese grater! 

We were so in love with our little home. It was cozy, warm, and hopefully welcoming to everyone who walked through our door. We will collect again, we will replace, and we will rebuild. We are STILL in love with Altadena. It is a magical place and we are heartbroken for our friends, neighbors, and community. We are so incredibly lucky to have the support network that we do and better means than most, but this will still be a very long and arduous road for everyone affected. To the folks of LA and beyond that have stepped up, thank you!! Please keep telling people‚Äôs stories, keep mobilizing, and keep being kind to each other. Help will still be needed in the weeks and months from now. We are eager to find a semipermanent place to settle soon and start helping our community rebuild.  #beautifulaltadena #wewillgethroughthis #eatonfire #altadena

@redcrossla: If you‚Äôve been impacted by wildfires in Southern California, the American Red Cross is here to help you recover. We‚Äôre currently reaching out to wildfire survivors to discuss their eligibility for financial assistance. 

If you received a message or call from a Red Cross representative, please follow the steps outlined in that message or visit redcross.org/gethelp to learn more.

Assistance from the American Red Cross is not considered a duplication of benefits for insurance or a government agency. The Red Cross is only part of the recovery solution.

Please be aware of scams or people posing as Red Cross representatives. You will receive an invitation via email & text based on the contact information we have for you. If you‚Äôre unsure whether the Red Cross has reached out, please call 1-800-RED-CROSS (800-733-2767).

We encourage people who were affected by the recent wildfires to apply for federal Disaster Assistance at disasterassistance.gov or by calling 1-800-621-3362. FEMA approval is not required to be eligible for Red Cross financial assistance.

The Andrew McNally House and The Zane Grey Estate, two of Altadena‚Äôs most iconic architectural masterpieces were lost in the Eaton Fire, leaving a profound void in this community's heritage. I was fortunate to photograph both of these homes for @teresafullerrealestate in their full glory, capturing their beauty and history before this heartbreaking loss. 

The Andrew McNally House, built in 1887, was an architectural masterpiece and a symbol of grandeur. Commissioned by Andrew McNally, co-founder of Rand McNally, this Queen Anne Victorian home was a marvel. My favorite features:
‚Ä®‚ú® A Turkish Room, an aviary, and a third-story turret offering views from the San Gabriel Mountains to Catalina.
‚Ä®‚ú® Intricate carved woodwork, stunning stained glass, ornate bronze radiators, and a breathtaking grand staircase.

See Zane Grey Estate photos in a separate post.
.
.
.

The Zane Grey Estate, a sprawling 12,000+ sqft Mediterranean Revival designed by Myron Hunt and Elmer Grey in 1906, was a sanctuary of creativity and history. Purchased by prolific Western novelist Zane Grey in 1920, this estate featured:
‚Ä®‚ú® A library and studio framed by massive wood-beamed ceilings. Check out the photo of Zane Grey‚Äôs original moving trunks.
‚Ä®‚ú® Hand-painted Kachinas, Batchelder tile, custom cabinetry, and exquisite ironwork throughout the home.

Photographed in 2020 for @teresafullerrealestate. The 2025 Eaton Fire tragically claimed this historic gem, leaving an irreplaceable void in Altadena‚Äôs heritage.

1/20/2025:  We‚Äôre still displaced and living in a hotel. Fortunately, our neighborhood is no longer blocked. Now the cleanup begins. Again, we‚Äôre extremely fortunate that our house is still standing. Today we drove through western Altadena, where the most destruction happened. I will not post images of people‚Äôs burned homes because that would be insensitive. These are pictures I took of businesses in that area. It was shocking to see the devastation in person. Based on an LA County Recovers map, it appears that at least 60% of Altadena was wiped out, if not more.

Join us this Friday, January 24, at 10 AM PST, for an emotional and powerful HSC&A / IG Live with artist Camilla Taylor (@camillataylor), who is mourning ‚Äúover 20 years of artmaking‚Äù that was lost in her West Altadena home studio. üíîüî•

We are humbled for this opportunity to virtually visit one of the thousands of properties lost to the Los Angeles wildfires and to give those of you outside of L.A. a sense of the new and difficult reality many artists are now facing in our city. 

Camilla will share what it means to navigate such an immense loss while continuing to work. From their early days as an artist to the profound challenges of rebuilding their life and studio, this conversation underscores the strength of a creative spirit in the face of adversity.

We‚Äôll also explore the importance of place, the role of community support, the impact of artmaking in difficult times, and the importance of disaster preparedness for artists and art workers.

üóì When: Friday, January 24, 10 AM PST

üìç Where: Live on Instagram / @sloanprojects

my heart hurts, yet I feel hopeful. the last few weeks have been I've been trying to find the right words to put together with these unforgiving fires.

physically, I'm okay. yet it's still affecting my mental and emotional so much.

it hurts to know people you know are impacted, it hurts to see some of my strongest friends hurting. I'm coming up on 9 years living here and even though I wasn't born here, it feels like home and it's so hard watching your city be reduced to ashes. I wish I could give back to the places what brought me so much memories and peace.

LA is made up of so much more than rich people and celebrities. if anything, there's more people that are in or closer to poverty than to being a millionaire.

LA is made up of educators, grocery store workers, bus drivers and folks working multiple jobs to get by, just like any other city. but the most beautiful thing about LA is it is such a melting pot of so many diverse generations who grew up here or chose to move here to fight for their biggest dreams.

and just like that we saw an overflow of love. unity in communities of people with open arms doing anything they could to provide and stay strong for those who couldn't.

los angeles, I love you and I will always remember you this way.

I wanted to say a massive thank you to everyone who has helped us help our town. The outpouring of support we have received is beyond anything I could have ever imagined and we are truly so thankful to each and every one of you. We couldn‚Äôt have done this without you ‚ù§Ô∏è

For anyone who missed it, on the excel spreadsheet whenever it says ‚Äúmisc supplies‚Äù those were drop offs of requested items that people in our community needed like masks, flashlights, gloves, work goggles, toiletries, etc. For a full list pls check out our last update post!

We will still be continuing our aid efforts as we start to set up our lives and new temporary workshop out in Eagle Rock. While the fires have almost stopped burning, there‚Äôs still an extremely long road ahead for the families and businesses affected by the fires. Ones that burned need help rebuilding, and the ones that are still standing are currently unliveable due to toxins and ash and will need help with clean up. We want to continue to be as helpful as we can to our community up in Altadena. Going forward we will continue to collect and distribute donations and with sales of our hats and totes (+ maybe more designs for Altadena in the future). As for sales from our earrings for now we have to stop donating those and start working towards making enough money to set up our new workshop and get our operations back in order. If we can help more in the future after that we def will!

Thank you all again so much for everything you‚Äôve done for us and for our community. The amount of love and emotional support we‚Äôve received from you guys these past two weeks has honestly been the thing keeping us going, thank you for getting us through this ü•∞

Meet Avery Colvert, a remarkable teen from Los Angeles who turned tragedy into action. After her community was devastated by fires, Avery launched the Altadena Girls Recovery Fund (@altadenagirls) to support those impacted. What began as a small effort has now turned into a powerful movement, rallying people together to rebuild and heal. 

Avery's school, Eliot Arts Magnet Academy (@eliotartsmagnet) in Altadena, Calif., burned down in the Eaton Fire. Though her family home in Pasadena fortunately survived, most of her friends lost everything. ‚ÄúThere's maybe a small handful of people I know whose houses are spared,‚Äù she says in an interview with Time Magazine. Most of her friends evacuated in the middle of the night with only the pajamas they were in. ‚ÄúI envisioned my own bedroom and I was thinking about how my clothes, makeup, and shoes‚Äîeverything‚Äîis my identity and it's my sense of self. And it's the same thing for all of my friends and all these girls who lost everything in the fire.‚Äù Colvert wanted her friends to be able to feel normal again. ‚ÄúI was like, okay, Pasadena Civic Center has the necessities, but I want specific items for these girls so they can feel like themselves again and get their confidence back,‚Äù she says.

Avery organized donation drives, collecting essential supplies like food, clothing, and hygiene products but also items like makeup, clothes reflecting current teen trends, and other cherished teen memorabilia that many lost in the fires.

Avery is yet another example of how girls, no matter their age, can spark change and create a lasting impact. Support Avery's movement at the link in our bio.

In the wake of a catastrophic wildfire that destroyed the Pasadena campus of Sahag Mesrob Armenian Christian School, up to 190 students from Kindergarten through 8th grade will temporarily relocate to the AGBU Vatche and Tamar Manoukian Cultural Center through the end of the 2025-2026 school year. This extended period will allow the school to regroup and rebuild while ensuring minimal disruption to academic instruction for the year.

‚ÄúAs soon as we heard that the school had perished, we knew we had to step in and lend support,‚Äù stated AGBU Western Region Chair Kevork Zoryan. ‚ÄúWhile we are on edge with the regional fires, not knowing where the next emergency will arise, we know that, as AGBU, we cannot sit idle. We reached out to our friends at Sahag Mesrob Armenian Christian School within the early moments of this tragedy to assure them that they can count on us for support,‚Äù he added.

In a public statement, the Sahag Mesrob Armenian Christian School board affirmed its determination to rebuild, and its Chair, Arlin Titanian, expressed profound gratitude to AGBU for the partnership it forged overnight.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs rare to encounter such a strong and compassionate partner, and AGBU‚Äôs commitment to supporting us has not gone unnoticed. We are incredibly fortunate to have you by our side; in unity is strength,‚Äù said Titanian.

üîó To read the complete statement and press release, visit the link in our bio.

Amid the chaos of the Los Angeles fires, one story stood out: the bravery of the ‚Äúinmate firefighters‚Äù that make up 30% of the firefighters in California.  Social media and news outlets erupted in applause‚Äîand rightfully so. These men risked their lives to save homes and lives for about a dollar an hour. üßë‚Äçüöíüî•

But as the smoke clears, a harsh truth emerges: these same men‚Äîpraised for their heroism‚Äîwill soon face rejection. They‚Äôll struggle to find jobs, housing, or basic acceptance in the very communities they just helped protect. üè†

If we, as a society, can celebrate someone‚Äôs redemption in a moment of crisis, why can‚Äôt we extend that same grace and opportunity once the crisis is over? The same voices applauding them today will deny them tomorrow. The same networks praising them now will vilify them later. üíî

As a business owner (www.saywt.com) and ministry founder (brand316.org), I challenge you: extend the second chances you‚Äôve been given in life to others. ‚úÖ When hiring, look beyond someone‚Äôs record and see the whole person. As a landlord, consider their humanity before dismissing them. As a fellow human being, remember they are someone‚Äôs son, daughter, father, or mother. üí°

We all make mistakes. We all need second chances. Let your first assumption be that they are one of the firefighters üí™ who saved a community. Everyone deserves the chance to rewrite their story. ‚úçÔ∏è 

Most business owners and landlords (including myself) that have taken this chance have realized it was well worth it.  People with records tend to be better employees, more appreciative of the chance you extended and more loyal to your company. 

#lafire #inmate #firefighters #SecondChances #eatonfire #palisadesfire #incarceration #Redemption #wildfires #reintegration #fairchance #socialjustice #justice @_saywt @brand316_ Say What Marketing & Consulting

When a fire steals what you once believed was unshakable, you‚Äôre left standing in the ashes, questioning everything. Who are we without the walls that held our laughter? Without the streets that mapped our lives? It‚Äôs not just about rebuilding structures; it‚Äôs about rediscovering ourselves in the aftermath of what‚Äôs been lost.

In Los Angeles, and in every place where devastation has carved its name into the landscape, we carry a shared ache‚Äîan ache that whispers of everything that once was. But loss is not the final word. We rise, not because it‚Äôs easy, but because we must. Recovery isn‚Äôt built in grand gestures, but in the quiet, intentional choices we make, one step, one breath, one small act of courage at a time.

The fire may have taken what we had, but it cannot take who we are. We are more than what we lost. We are what we choose to become.

Fires burn in Los Angeles. From oceans and canyons to mountains and valleys. Kinship Circle soon departs for animal rescue in the Palisades area. We‚Äôve helped coordinate aid remotely for a few weeks now. 

Despite windblown flames, animals survive. They hide, terrified and alone, in wreckage. Cats, especially, stay in charred homes to wait for their families. Access is tricky, with residents and animal orgs still denied entry in some evacuated communities. But rescuers won‚Äôt give up and continue to work with authorities. There‚Äôs a link in our bio to a recent news story.

The STRIPED CAT in photo was recently trapped in a Pacific Palisades, CA neighborhood where all residents evacuated.

üì¢ CALLING ALL VIPERS üì¢

Central Altadena Little League (CALL) was severely impacted by the Eaton Fire that began on January 7.

The @playcentralaltadena Board estimates that between 1/3-1/2 of their families have lost their homes, and their home fields are inaccessible. But these amazing families are still doing what they can to put on a Spring season for their players ‚Äî and we are calling all Vipers to do what they can to help out!!

CALL is looking for the following to help players AND coaches to have the best season they can in spite of these tragic circumstances:

‚öæÔ∏è Gift Cards to Major Sports Stores (Dick‚Äôs, Big 5, Play it Again, Amazon). These can be used to fill in specific gear needs for either players or coaches that get missed in donations or are more niche (e.g. left handed gloves, clothing needs, etc.).

‚öæÔ∏è Coach Gear: Many of their coaches were also impacted and lost both their personal gear as well as their league bags.¬†Specific equipment needs include:
* Baseball Nets
* Baseball Tees
* Baseballs (T-balls, Level 5 Safety Balls, Little League balls)

‚öæÔ∏è Monetary donations are welcomed as well, and can be made via the CALL GoFundMe ‚Äî https://www.gofundme.com/f/support-callkids-affected-by-eaton-fires. These funds give the league flexibility to help support scholarships for impacted players or repairing infrastructure that may have been damaged in the fires. The league is a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit.

We will be coordinating and collecting donations and ask that all items/gift cards be donated by Saturday, February 1.

For questions or more info on how to help, please DM us or email us at coachjlo@villaparkvipers.com.

üì¢ We‚Äôre Back

The recent Eaton Wildfire in Los Angeles County forced many to evacuate, with some losing their homes. We were among those affected, spending 5 days in evacuation and 5 more without power.

We feel incredibly lucky to have returned to work and fully recovered our production speed. There are no more delays, and we‚Äôre back to creating your personalized gifts with the same passion and dedication.

üß°We truly appreciate your support, patience, and understanding during this challenging time. Every order means the world to us, and we‚Äôre grateful for this amazing community.

Stay safe, and thank you! ‚ù§Ô∏è

When the LA County wildfires ignited on January 7, 2025, I know I wasn‚Äôt alone in feeling that overwhelming urge to help, yet almost feeling helpless at the same time. What can I possibly do to make a difference in the face of such devastation? ‚Ä¶ They need nutritious, fueling meals while fighting these fires for days and WEEKS at a time. What can I do to ease the burden for those who lost EVERYTHING? At least feed them.

Over 1,000 healthy meals were prepped and hand-delivered to over 40 fire stations, police departments, state troopers, and shelters for displaced residents affected by the Los Angeles wildfires.

I‚Äôm beyond grateful to the hardworking front-liners who continue to protect and serve us, and to the incredible LA community for coming together in the face of tragedy. 

Thanks to the generosity of hundreds of individuals who donated. Your kindness and support made this possible.

This is why I started B Fit Meals‚Äîto help others when it matters most. As LA rebuilds, we‚Äôre committed to fundraising weekly meals to support families in need. This is just the beginning.

My thoughts and prayers are with all those impacted by this national disaster. Stay strong, LA ü´∂

HELP LAPP ARTIST RED-TAIL AND THE LOLLIE FAMILY THRIVE AFTER THE EATON FIRE. üíù

Red-tail is an Indigenous dancer, ritualist, and longtime member of the LAPP artist community. They are emblematic of the artists from our programs, beginning with dance residencies as part of our RESEARCH + DEVELOPMENT (R+D) program in 2017 and 2021,  followed by ‚ÄúDance for the Hawks: Observing & Dancing in Nature,‚Äù an LAPP WORKSHOP they led. Most recently, Red-tail participated in our ACCELERATOR program to resource an ensemble dance performance at REDCAT.

In January of 2025, Red-tail‚Äôs Altadena family lost their home and all their belongings in the Eaton fire. They are now facing the enormous challenge of rebuilding their lives, while Red-tail is also currently recovering from breast cancer surgery. Our hearts are with the Lollie family, and we encourage you to donate to their GoFundMe, send gift cards as requested, and share their story with those who may be able to help.

All members of our LAPP community who are facing hardships as a result of the January 2025 wildfires are invited to fill out the Artist Survey linked in our bio, with which we are gathering information to fill in gaps in artist relief and support. Please forward your GoFundMe links so we can share to our stories, and don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out to let us know how else we can help.

As I aimlessly wandered through the streets filled with remnants of people's homes, I found myself wondering about those who have just found themselves in unimaginable situations.  I looked for something, anything that was identifiable. And most of the time, I couldn't find a single item. Nothing but ash. 

When I was able to find something, I discovered that one person loves the color yellow - especially lemons. Another is extremely whimsical and loves fantastical creatures. Another is devout. Another absolutely loves animals.

Every single one of these homes you see in the vast landscape of destruction represents lives forever changed... it's very easy to become numb to it, oftentimes as a coping mechanism.  At one point, I even felt myself becoming unable to cry any more. 

But, in the eerie silence of the evacuation zones, these are all small moments that gave me pause - stirring up emotion and serving as a reminder that there is a person to whom these objects matter, and will most likely serve as one of the only memories that remain from what they've lost.

#palisadesfire #eatonfire #pacificpalisades #altadena #photojournalism
