I am so grateful and relieved to share that the Palisades fire is now 63% contained and the Eaton fire is 89% contained.üôåüèæ I want to extend my deepest thanks to the courageous firefighters, first responders, volunteers and shelters who are working tirelessly to help Los Angeles. My heart aches for those who have lost their homes, their memories and their sense of safety. The devastation is unimaginable. Seeing the love, care and unity within this city has been such a beautiful thing to witness.ü•πü´∂üèæ

A heartfelt thank you to everyone who has reached out to check on me. Your love and thoughtfulness means more than words can express. Things got scary during the evacuation as we seen the fires closing in (next slide). In that moment of panic, I was unsure of what to do, just praying for guidance. Right before getting on the freeway to San Diego, a friend I will cherish forever offered a safe place for me, my friend and our dogs. I give God all the glory for His protection and for placing such amazing people in my life.üôèüèæ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

In times of uncertainty, finding small moments to be grateful for can be our greatest strength. As I look at this photo of Muffie and I, taken on January 1st, 2025, I‚Äôm reminded of the love, hope and peace we can still cling to even in challenging times. My smile reflects the gratitude I feel for what truly matters - the gift of life. This past week has been emotionally overwhelming but it‚Äôs important to try staying positive and remain faithful. Trust and believe that brighter days are ahead for all of us.

To those of you impacted by the wildfires, please know you‚Äôre in my thoughts and prayers. Let‚Äôs continue to lean into each other, offering support however we can and trust that together, we will rebuild a stronger Los Angeles. Please look below for resources and various ways you can help.üëáüèæüëáüèæüëáüèæ

We are in the together.

Our history is part of our future. Several teachers and alumni have reached out to us about a commemorative stone carved years ago by an artisan to honor Gael Blair, a beloved teacher who passed away. It was placed where the liquid amber tree used to be, near the lawn in front of historic Scripps Hall.

We are blessed to have found it, and our recovery team brought it to the Mendocino campus where it was washed and placed with the recovered St. Francis statue, where it will be safe until we can return it to Mariposa Street.

These small keepsakes are an important part of our history, and will become a piece of our future.

Thank you to everyone who has supported our recovery from the Eaton Fire. We are grateful for your support. Please share our GoFundMe with your network if you can to help us reach our goal. Link in bio.

The kids volunteered for the evacuated horses at @thelaec last Sunday. Since all of the usual tasks of feeding, cleaning, watering, and walking were all taken care of, they were given their bracelets and tasked with the simple, but important task of ‚Äúcomforting and loving‚Äù the horses. Something they did naturally. It was so beautiful to see the horses light up with curiosity in their presence, and as soon as we got in the car, each kid knew the name of the horse they fell in love with. That is the magic of horses. They are reflective and the love and comfort is always reciprocated. üôèüèºüê¥ 

There are still over 120 evacuated horses at LAEC, with more coming in as other evacuation sites shut down.

Last film drop from the recent fires in the Palisades and Altadena.
I met some amazing firefighters who drove down from Portland, Oregon to fight the fires in the Palisades. 
Photograph several blue vehicles that made it through the infernos. 
Saw a beautiful statue of a winged goddess that was the only thing left at someone‚Äôs beach home.

Photographed with a Leica M6 using 21, and 50mm cron lenses. 
Film used was Portra 400, 160, and Kodak 100 pro.

You don't need money to support those affected by the fires.

You can surround them with their friends.

You can listen to what they're going through.

You can send them jokes, memes, or photos you know will make them laugh, even if it's coming through tears.

And you know what?

Simply saying, "I'm here for you has a healing touch even if they don't take you up on the offer. 

Just like a person can feel alone in a crowd, so to can a person feel held in a room alone.

Yes, we may need 'things', but tending to the mental health of the affected?

That's no small thing.

In fact, without that, all those 'things' aren't likely to have the desired affect anyhow.

#eatonfire #mindsetmatters #altadenastrong

On the morning of Wednesday, January 8th, our friends and wonderful local business owner,  Cody Wellema had his Hat Shop in Altadena,  California burn in the Eaton Fire.  They lost their entire business... vintage hats,  vintage hat tools,  merchandise, vintage hat blocks, and about 99% of everything inside his small business that he's built from the ground up.
.
We at RVP want to help his cause, hoping to assist him with restarting his business, or even getting something else going, while taking care of his family in the meantime.  We are looking to provide ANYTHING HAT related....whether it be hats themselves, vintage and new, tools, blocks, flanges, trinkets, antiques, signs, hat bands, vintage pins, etc.  Besides donations of hat items specifically,  we will be accepting, cash and digital payments on behalf of the Wellema's that 100% of the proceeds will go directly to the family...PLUS, a portion of RVP sales on this day will also be presented to the Wellema's.
.
Come out and support local small business and the Wellema's hat legacy as well as their family. 
.
If you cant make it and wouldn't mind sharing your love on their Go Fund Me...the link is here:
.
https://gofund.me/728c7db8
.

Quello che vedete nel video √® uno dei miei pi√π cari amici, Alessandro. Ci siamo conosciuti nel 2006, in Accademia, quando eravamo ancora due ragazzini e abbiamo condiviso gli anni pi√π spensierati delle nostre vite; da allora non ci siamo mai persi, nonostante 15 anni fa io mi sia trasferita a Roma e lui a LA, entrambi con il sogno di sfondare nel cinema.
Be‚Äô dieci giorni fa Alessandro ha perso tutto quello che aveva negli incendi che hanno devastato LA. 
Mi ha scritto: ‚ÄúSIAMO VIVI. Ma abbiamo perso tutto‚Äù. 
Non riesco nemmeno immaginare cosa significhi ‚Äúperdere tutto‚Äù. 
La tua casa. I tuoi vestiti. Gli oggetti che ti porti dietro da sempre. I ricordi. La foto di tuo fratello o quel biglietto di auguri che ti fa piangere ogni volta che lo leggi. Tutto quello che faceva di te quello che sei, quello che sei stato e quello che speravi di diventare. Spazzato via. Distrutto. Ridotto in cenere.
Ora. Perch√© questo messaggio. Perch√© Ale e la sua famiglia hanno bisogno di aiuto per comprare beni di prima necessit√†, vestiti, oggetti, mobili, oltre che di una casa in affitto. Per questo hanno lanciato una campagna su Go Found Me per avviare una raccolta fondi. 
Quindi io mi rivolgo a voi, che siete amici, o conoscenti, o sconosciuti, e vi chiedo con il cuore in mano se potete contribuire a questa raccolta. Anche in modo piccolo, anche in modo simbolico, perch√© ogni singola goccia, assieme ad altre gocce, pu√≤ diventare un immenso, meraviglioso oceano di solidariet√†. 
In un mondo attualmente devastato da guerre, morti, macerie ed eventi climatici terrificanti, ci tengo a ringraziare dal profondo del mio cuore tutti quelli che vorranno contribuire a questa raccolta fondi o che avranno voglia di condividere questo messaggio. Perch√© l‚Äôunico modo per sopravvivere a questo specifico momento storico, fatto di guerre, morti, macerie, e cambiamenti climatici devastanti, √® non lasciarci soli l‚Äôun l‚Äôaltra.

Ale ti voglio bene. Siete fortissimi. Viva la resilienza.

https://www.gofundme.com/f/support-alessandro-and-aarons-recovery-journey

This Black & White Wednesday chronicles the week of January 6, 2025. Monday started out a normal mundane week, working out of our L.A. offices. By Wednesday morning my colleagues and I were giving strict instructions to work from home due to dangerous winds and brush fires. By Friday morning, one of California‚Äôs biggest fires was fully ablaze. These photos were taken throughout that week and as recent at January 19, 2025. Showing the first days of the Palisades fires and the aftermath of the Eaton fires. I took these on my Minolta SRT101 35mm film camera. I used my Soligor 135mm f/3.5 and Minolta MD 50mm f/1.7 lenses. Shot on Kenmore Pan100 film.

Hope is a strategy. 

Wonderful article about rebuilding after megafire, and the necessary joy found in community. 

We love this one, for many reasons. It includes some wondrous humans, like Gabe Osburn with the City of Santa Rosa, and Brad Sherwood, Community Leader, and his family.

"Fire wasn‚Äôt supposed to do what it did that night. No one had predicted the flames would move so fast, or consume so much of this city of 175,000 and surrounding communities. No one could have predicted, either, that Santa Rosa would manage to build back so quickly, or that residents would say that, in some ways, their communities emerged stronger: safer from fire and more closely knit.

Just more than a week into Los Angeles‚Äô ordeal by fire, the neighbors of Coffey Park were gathering in Tricia Woods‚Äô rebuilt kitchen to raise funds to send to fire victims in L.A. They also wanted to send a message: You can‚Äôt imagine it now, but it is possible to recover from this."

You can recover, rebuild, and reimagine

For anyone that has been affected by these fires, we‚Äôre offering 35% off all rugs, valid through June. This offer is meant to be used in store only, although if you had to evacuate out of the city/state, please DM us and we can provide you with a discount code and arrange shipping. If you still haven‚Äôt found housing by june, but would still like to take advantage of this offer, please reach out. We got you. 

It‚Äôs taken me 2 weeks to wrap my head around the firestorm that just enveloped our community. the grief and sorrow comes in waves, hovering in the background, and emerging when you least expect it.

It‚Äôs all been said already, but suffice it to say, my heart is broken at the destruction, loss, and the shattering of our neighborhood. 

I feel lucky that my home is still standing, however it is currently uninhabitable until it is remediated for smoke and ash damage. I‚Äôm safely evacuated, and staying close by to help with recovery efforts. 

Another bright spot is that the shop is still standing and is safely outside of any evacuation zone. I‚Äôm planning to have the shop staffed at the very least Sundays 10-3pm, and also by appt. There may be some drop in Saturday hours as well, but that‚Äôs TBD. 

In the meantime, reminding myself that rest is radical and grief tending is essential. I‚Äôm sending so much love to all our friends and community as we start down the long road of repair üôåüèΩ #eatonfire

üåø‚ú® A Backyard Full of Magic ‚ú®üåø

Growing up, my mom had a way of turning our backyard into a wonderland. She filled every corner with love, laughter, and creativity. For me and my sister, it was a world of endless mornings full of adventure, picnics, and the kind of magic only a mom can create.

That same magic came alive again when her grandchildren stepped into that space. Watching them explore, play, and dream in the backyard my parents built with their hands and hearts was like reliving my own childhood.

But now, that magical oasis is gone. The place that held decades of memories and joy has been taken away. My parents poured so much love into that home, and it‚Äôs heartbreaking to see them have to start over.

We‚Äôre asking for your support as they search for a new place to call home‚Äîa place where they can create new memories, where the magic can live on. Whether it‚Äôs words of encouragement, a kind gesture, or simply keeping them in your thoughts, it means everything.

Thank you for being part of our journey. üíï https://www.gofundme.com/manage/support-clark-and-julie-after-fire-loss

#FamilyLove #NewBeginnings #FindingHome #eatonfire #BackyardMemories

I‚Äôve been at a loss for words. Watched the city burn in flames. It‚Äôs one things to hear about history or live it, but to actually be part of it, has been life changing. 
Everyone we knew growing up, has lost their home, some have lost everything. Almost everything we ever knew as home is gone. 
The simplicity of everyday life has become a struggle. What I lost doesn‚Äôt compare to how I feel for our community. To my family, to your family, to our family. 
I pray for the strength to endure, the ability to access the necessary resources, and the opportunity to rebuild. Thank you to all the people that have come to our aid,  assisted and support us. 
The best way to continue to help is donating to any one of the verified Gofund me pages.
#eatonfire #altadena #denastrong

This media offers clarity and support to those impacted by the 2025 Los Angeles fires, helping residents assess the devastation. Amidst ash-filled skies and shifting fire lines, my goal was to create a visual archive that could aid in community reflection, future policy discussions, and broader climate change awareness‚Äîtransforming tragedy into a call for meaningful change.
.
Discover how you can help. Access resources, donate, and make a lasting impact on those affected by the 2025 Los Angeles fires in the link below.
.
https://frameworkfilms.net/socal-fires-2025
.
Our thoughts are with all those affected by the fires, and we extend our gratitude to the brave firefighters and first responders working tirelessly to protect the community. Please continue to prioritize safety and abide by local, state, and federal guidance when returning to areas of impact.
.

If you are #gardening in #LosAngeles this week, MAKE SURE you are wearing #PPE!  In fact, I would say if there's a significant quantity of ash in your area, talk to an environmental health professional prior to gardening AT ALL.  I'm in a less severely impacted area, so here's my kit:
.
.
üå± P100 respirator with OV/AG filter (removes 99.97% of particulates larger than 0.3 microns, plus SOME VOCs)
üå± Durable safety goggles that can stop dust from contacting your eyes
üå± Long-cuffed leather work gloves (kevlar works too)
üå± Long-sleeved pants and shirt
üå± OUTDOOR ONLY work boots
.
.
Avoid working outside until we get a major rain event, if possible (I can't avoid it, it's my job!). I'll be posting a video later this week with more precautionary tips.  Stay healthy, y'all! üåªüò∑
.

My favorite memories are made at the campground. ‚õ∫Ô∏è So when I had no choice but to move inside my camper with my two dogs and three cats after the fire, I found a way to make the most of it! 

I didn‚Äôt have electricity at the property for over 2.5 years while dealing with the insurance paperwork and fighting for the release of funds, but with the help of solar panels and a @jackeryusa it worked (sort of!). Cold showers in the summer, and hot water at the gym was better than no shower at all. I gutted the closet shelves in the trailer and made space for a tall cat tree, made a cat door for the storage benches where I put the litter box, and built an outdoor canopied living space to call home. 

If you‚Äôre looking to give back to support all the displaced families and pets, would you consider supporting our fundraiser for @gonetothedogsrescue as they prepare to save more dogs from local shelters to make space for displaced animals from the recent fires? Check out the LINK IN PROFILE for more info!

A Heartfelt Thank You from Ms. Romero's 3rd Grade Class üíô 

We were so touched to receive a beautiful thank-you poster from Ms. Romero's 3rd Grade Class at @ileadaguadulce! The children created the poster to express their gratitude to all the first responders who worked tirelessly on the #eatonfire and #palisadesfire. Along with the poster came some delicious cookies‚Äîthank you! üç™ 

Since the poster came to us through one of our employees whose child is in the class, we wanted to make sure it reached as many first responders as possible. We brought it to the Incident Command Post at the Eaton Fire, where our colleagues returned the favor by signing a map of the Eaton Fire area for the kids. 

From there, the poster traveled to @lacountyfd Fire Station 11 in Altadena, @aldlasd, @altadenamountainrescue, Fire Station 82 in La Canada Flintridge, and finally, our station. Each stop brought more signatures and heartfelt appreciation for the class‚Äôs thoughtfulness. 

Thank you, Ms. Romero's class, for your kind words and support. It means the world to us, and we hope you enjoy the signed map as a token of our gratitude! üßë‚Äçüöíüöì #thankyou #CommunitySupport #firstresponders #lasd

Our hearts go out to all those impacted by the devastating wildfires. Students will now have extra time to apply for financial aid during this challenging time.

The California Student Aid Commission (CSAC) is extending the state priority deadline for submitting the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) and the California Dream Act Application (CADAA) for these impacted communities. The priority deadline is now April 2, 2025 for Los Angeles and Ventura Counties. The deadline for all other California counties continues to be March 3, 2025.

Pt. 6 - 1/15 As you can see the other 300 meals prepped and boxed up on the 5th slide, thanks to @annielcampbell & her team, We were able to get those delivered to the Emergency Operations Center (different from Bureau). 
Again, the constant gratitude and appreciation from those receiving these meals.. I had gone back the following day to drop more & the response from just a few of the officers that had the meal, ‚Äúwow, they were soo delicious!!‚Äù 
They went on to say how helpful it has been for them to be receiving all these meals.. 

It‚Äôs been amazing to see everyone coming together in all different aspects to help in whichever way possible..
And a thank you to @davidbzand for pulling through extremely last minute to help make this delivery/drop happenüôè

Not only did we deliver meals, we also put out a fire on the way back!!üßØüë®‚Äçüöíü¶∏‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
Yes, it may look small in the video, but was bigger as I was driving by before I made a U-turn. And yes, it may have been for a homeless for warmth, BUT THESE ARE HOW THE COUNTLESS BUILDING/STRUCTURE FIRES START IN DOWNTOWN!! IT SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED!!

I wasn‚Äôt allowed to take any photos/videos in the command center at the Bureau, but they allowed us to here! What a sight, seeing many different departments & agencies working together, working 12+ hr shifts, all day and all night. 
Not something you get to witness everyday!!

Stay tuned.. Pt.7

Finding beauty after destruction üíî

We ventured back to our house in Altadena yesterday, where we spent a few hours digging through the ashes of a lifetime of memories. We learned that almost nothing survives a wildfire of this magnitude‚Ä¶. besides pottery‚Ä¶. I was ecstatic to find about a quarter of my pieces were still intact, and ironically (and morbidly), the heat of the #EatonFire created some beautiful glaze and material combinations. I‚Äôll share more later, but this was the largest vase I made back in September 2023, that I wanted to use for flower arrangements  @perle_restaurant but never liked the original glaze. Now it‚Äôs no longer waterproof ‚Äî it had been sitting on a glass shelf awaiting a refiring with a new coat of glaze. When that shelf inevitably melted from the heat of the flames, the vase and glass, along with sediment from the earth when it fell, became one.

.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

If you or anyone you know was affected by the wildfires, please share this. Our home was in Altadena on Altadena Dr and my friend/coworker was right around the corner, his home complete ash. We were right in the thick of it and the first thing they tell us to do is get a mailbox for insurance and benefits, etc. They are not cheap and it‚Äôs another thing to add to our plates. This could be really helpful for a lot of people.

This location is also doing free faxing, scanning/emailing, and computer rental for wildfire victims.

Please spread the word!

The Nazarian family Jennifer, Anthony, Giannella, and myself have tragically lost our home along everything we owned to the devastating Eaton Fire in Altadena. After 15 years of living in Altadena growing up and going to school there was the I met my best friends, loving neighbors, and amazing families. Now with all our hard work and sacrifice, we had just rebuilt our new home, in a little gem city, only to watch it and everything inside it consumed by the destructive flames. My home was a place of kindness, if you knew or already been to our home it is filled with countless memories and love, truly because of all of YOU. Sadly, this loss isn‚Äôt ours alone. 

Anthony‚Äôs (my dad) brother, along with his family, also lost their home in the fire.
As we navigate this overwhelming hardship, the Nazarians are filled with gratitude for the love and support we‚Äôve received from friends, family, and our community. While our hearts are heavy, we are determined to staying strong and  moving forward with whatever God has next for us, knowing that with the help of those around us, we all will get through this difficult time together.

With sincere appreciation, the Nazarian family asks for any donations, big or small, as we begin the process of rebuilding our lives. Every gesture of kindness means the world to us during this challenging time. With love and support, we know that we all will rise from this tragedy stronger than before.

Our gofundme link is in my bio 
Again we want to send love, and thank everyone who‚Äôs helped us through an unseeing time. It doesn‚Äôt go unnoticed. 

You will be missed 933 poppyfields dr‚ù§Ô∏èüòû

With much respect and love 
-The Nazarian family‚ù§Ô∏è #denastrong #eatonfire

LA Public Press spoke with or surveyed more than 30 Altadena residents, most of whom said they never received Wireless Emergency Alerts from Los Angeles County ordering them to evacuate.

For many residents, warning of the approaching firestorm came either very late, or not at all.

Those who lived west of North Lake Avenue said they didn‚Äôt get evacuation orders until about 3:30 a.m., and received no electronic warnings. At that point, as residents frantically tried to evacuate, fire embers were already sweeping across homes.

An investigation by The Los Angeles Times published on Sunday found that all of the 17 Eaton Fire deaths currently recorded by the LA coroner occurred west of Lake Ave.

To learn more, read the full story by Amber X. Chen via the link in our bio or at LAPublicPress.org.

DOG RESCUE: we had just arrived in Altadena Tuesday when we ran into this woman who said she was trying to rescue a dog from a burned out property. She‚Äôs a healthcare worker and had been working nearby, watching the dog all day wandering alone and refusing to leave the ruins of a property. She says animal rescue workers tried to wrangle it, but could not connect. As a dog owner, she could not leave without giving it a try. She succeeded by offering the dog a little bit of chicken‚Ä¶ and then tried to call the phone number on his tag, but the voicemail was full. She‚Äôs going to keep trying. The dog‚Äôs name is Henry! @kcalnews #altadena #losangeles #eatonfire #fire #californiafire #dogs #firefighters #californiafires

caption:
This is the LA Sherriffs Dept unit that has been on the Eaton fire detail for almost 2 weeks they told me that the whole Town is gone, they were keeping guard over the town and busting looters and unsavory characters, allot of people hate the cops, can u emangin everyone u meet in most cases lies to you, what a dreadfull job it can be, but when u can save someone's life there's the other side of the coin, when my son Shane was very young we were on our way to Sano at 430 in the morning and I ran a red light, a motorcycle cop pulled me over and asked me do u know what you did I said yes sir I ran the light, I told him the sky was so clear and it looked like the east star was shinning so bright I started telling my son the story about the star of Bethlehem,  and by the time I realize what I did it was to late, he looked surprised at what I told him and then said don't do it again and have a good day and he left no ticket I was so happy and very supprised, there's good and bad in every walk of life, I think it's a hard job to do, I don't think I could do it. Hats off to these Brave Men and Woman that put there lives on the line to save us from bad people and keep our neighborhoods safe everyday! Thank You so Much !!!

Esquina Bicycle Shop continues to work tirelessly to sustain itself during these tough times, navigating the economic impact of the LA fires. Despite averaging just $0-$30 a day, we remain committed to taking donations and supporting fire relief efforts.

Today, we received an incredible in-kind donation from @luminaid , who generously provided hundreds of solar-powered lanterns and phone chargers to help those affected by the fires. These lanterns are lightweight, waterproof, and collapsible, making them perfect for emergencies. They charge during the day using solar power and provide hours of bright light at night, with a built-in phone charger to help people stay connected when it matters most.

These invaluable tools will bring light and connection to our community and are heading straight to the front lines in Altadena, where residents are beginning to repopulate and clean up after the devastation.

We‚Äôre deeply grateful for this support as we continue to stand together during this challenging time.

Thank you so much @luminaid !! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•

The Hughes Fire erupted in Los Angeles County on Wednesday, with the blaze coming at the same time that county officials are battling the Palisades and Eaton Fires, both of which started on January 7.

The Hughes Fire, just like the ones that ignited before it, exploded in size in the high winds of Southern California, spreading to more than 5,000 acres in just two hours after it was first reported near Castaic Lake.

The Palisades Fire, which has burned more than 23,400 acres, remains at less than 70% containment, while the Eaton Fire, which has burned just over 14,000 acres, is just over 90% contained, according to Cal Fire.

Get the latest at the link in our bio.

There has not been much to celebrate here in Los Angeles over the last two weeks, but I‚Äôm proud to say that I officially started my career in real estate last week ‚ò∫Ô∏è

While we have all been watching the Palisades and Altadena communities suffer immeasurable loss to fires, my heart and head have been a mess, as I grew up in Northwest Pasadena , and my childhood was filled with magical Altadena memories.

I literally learned how to use the MLS one week ago, and within days I was scrambling to help families find rental homes. 

I did my first deal this weekend, and got an amazing family who lost everything in the #Eatonfire into a great rental house in Highland Park, they get keys on Friday! ü§ó

What a week to start this journey. I feel so grateful to be able to help and support these people through such an unimaginable time, and get some folks the housing they need to start a new chapter.

I am forever an optimist , and I believe that communities will always come together to make things right - we have all seen it unfold before our eyes already! 

I have high hopes for the future, and I am grateful to have this new journey of my own, with an amazing mentor @msmarydix  and all my fiends and family cheering me on! 

Let‚Äôs go!!! ‚ú®üè°

Words, photos, The Fairy House.

The Los Angeles fires started on January 7th. Imagine, 11 days later after tireless days of fighting fires, experiencing over two dozen casualties, as you‚Äôre walking the street, you see looting taking place. These fire fighters weren‚Äôt having it. I can‚Äôt even imagine how exhausted they must‚Äôve been. Mad props to these fire fighters for not only doing what‚Äôs right, but for giving somebody who lost everything, a beautiful memory of their tremendous accomplishments from what was once the place they called home. 

#foxla ‚ÄúNO WAY, YOU‚ÄôRE NOT DOING THIS!‚Äù Firefighters were quick to step in when they saw someone they suspected of looting one of the homes from the #EatonFire. ‚ÄúWe tried to save the homes of all these people, you‚Äôre not stealing from them‚Äù one fire fighter said. 

Deputies learned the suspect had stolen an Emmy award and a 2016 Sharp Award with the  victim‚Äôs name.

Altadena in Mourning: We were finally allowed back into Altadena on Sunday, and what we‚Äôve seen has taken some time to fully process. Which is why I haven‚Äôt posted images until today. Altadena is a very tight community‚Äîwhere you may not know everyone‚Äîpersonally, but you surely recognize familiar friendly faces that you see everyday. Which makes it doubly difficult to see everyone in pain‚Äîtrying to put on brave faces. My heart goes out to everyone impacted by this tragedy, and my hope is that everyone stays here, and rebuilds their lives and homes as quickly and painlessly as possible. #eatonfire #eatonfire2025 #altadenacalifornia #beautifulaltadena #rebuildingaltadena #altadenastrong #eatoncanyonfire2025 #altadenafires2025

Fires across the L.A. area have killed at least 28 people, destroyed more than 15,000 structures and charred some 63 square miles since Jan 7. Gail Cashburn‚Äôs house in Altadena burned completely to the ground but her Jazz bar, located at 1881 E Washington Blvd, Pasadena has been the oasis for her homeless neighbors.  Today with the help of our small business owners, the William & Stephanie Foundation, California Investment Forum, LA County Assessor Jeff Prang, United Policyholders, Altadena Mountain Rescue Team, Dr Romina Ghassemi, John JD Liu, US Small Business Administration, and LA Sheriff‚Äôs Department, we collected and gave out $500K+ of essentials to the residents of Altadena including my Wildfire Recovery Resource Guide (treasurer.ca.gov/STO-Wildfire-R‚Ä¶). We will rebuild. We are California. If you‚Äôve lost your home in the Los Angeles Fires then you definitely feel like you are stuck in Edvard Munch‚Äôs The Scream 1893 painting. This painting is part of Munch‚Äôs semi-autobiographical Frieze of Life series, which explores themes of love, death, and angst. However, I decided to flip the switch at the @mrbrainwashartmuseum and paint my own version of this painting. This truly depicts where I‚Äôm at after my home burned down. I feel like I‚Äôm living in a dream and a nightmare all at the same time. Along with the anxiety and angst which is what this painting usually represents, I also feel excitement looking forward into the future, blessed for the present, and a knowing that what‚Äôs in the past, should be left behind. 

One of my favorite quotes in Latin and the only thing I learned in my two years of taking Latin in high school:

‚ÄúCarpe diem quam minimum credula postero‚Äù

Seize the day trusting in the future as little as possible‚Ä¶ 

Everyone is in this together üí™ #losangelesfire #palisadesfire #eatonfire #hughesfire

Announcement: Following a conference with a global change agent team, air quality readings surrounding a Southern California wildfire revealed elevated levels of arsenic, lead, and asbestos. Residents in the surrounding area are urged to wear P100 or N95 masks. Over 50,000 people were under evacuation orders or warnings as a massive wildfire swept through rugged mountains north of Los Angeles, fueled by strong winds. The Hughes Fire, which started in the late morning, burned over 15 square miles of trees and brush, sending up dark smoke plumes near Lake Castaic. LA County Sheriff Robert Luna reported that 31,000 people have been ordered to evacuate, with 23,000 under evacuation warnings. Firefighters are gaining ground in containing the blaze, which remains challenging. Parts of Interstate 5, previously closed, will be reopened shortly, according to Luna.  #eatonfire #southerncalifornia #wildfire #breakingnews #airquality

There will be no video update today. I‚Äôm tired physically and emotionally from our memory hunt yesterday. I‚Äôm guilt-ridden and saddened that I couldn‚Äôt find the most meaningful things I went to look for yesterday- my grandparents urns and my grandfather‚Äôs navy retirement door knocker. I had repeated nightmares about the Hughes Fire somehow making its way to where I am. I‚Äôve been keeping myself so busy with the almost insurmountable to do list and keep putting off the thing I probably should do much- return the call to Care Solace that they found therapist options for me. I look at my calendar of to dos everyday and feel like I‚Äôm working with how jammed it is. 

Today I get to go to the dentist, an appointment I made 6 months ago and am actually keeping even though my world is topsyturvy. I need something normal to do- something not related to replacing foods, attending fire-related events, memory searching, or filling out neverending forms. 

Love to you all!

Cristina and Cinco share a moment of connection at the Los Angeles Equestrian Center, less than a week after escaping the Eaton Fire. Alongside her courageous 16-year-old son, Cristina drove toward the inferno to evacuate their three horses, while her husband evacuated their three dogs, two cats, and gathered belongings from their home in Hastings Ranch. 

The ten-acre brush fire spread rapidly through Eaton Canyon. Cristina and her son arrived just in time, and as they loaded the horses into the trailer, her husband faced a lawn full of embers and 90-mph winds. Miraculously, the house was spared, but their barn burned to the ground.

Blondie, Cash, and Cinco were temporarily housed elsewhere until space became available at the equestrian center, where we caught up with Cristina. She shared details of the evacuation, describing her thoughts as she led the horses to safety. She noted how calm three-year-old Cinco remained during the intense situation and knew she had to stay steady as well.

At @sanctuary_doc mindfulness is a core value that strengthens our ability to document animal rescues while also finding sanctuary within. As we stood with Cristina and reflected on her experience, we asked what sanctuary meant to her. Cristina described sanctuary as a place of peace, silence, and renewal.

After leaving LA, I followed up with Cristina. She shared how a long-standing meditation practice helped her navigate that harrowing night:

‚ÄúMy practice SAVED me that night... I felt like my consciousness was trying to shatter that night as I was evacuating horses, and my practice kept me intact!‚Äù

After the barn burned, Cristina received a note from her meditation teacher containing a haiku by 17th-century poet Mizuta Masahide written after his own barn was destroyed:

‚ÄúBarn‚Äôs burnt down, now I can see the moon.‚Äù

This week, the family picked up two cats from @pasadenahumane who had been rescued from the barn and will foster them for the time being. Their three dogs and two cats have been with them since the fire. 

‚ù§Ô∏è We send our heartfelt wishes to Cristina‚Äôs human and nonhuman family as they heal and rebuild.

FIRE UPDATE: It‚Äôs now been 14 days since the Eaton Fire and 100 mile an hour winds swept through our community destroying the majority of it, including more friends homes than I have been able to count, and 2 of my kids schools. 9,418 strucutres burned in our little neighbourhood alone. 6,662 more in the Palisades fire. Our house, and my studio, sit just a couple of blocks below the border of Altadena, in Pasadena, and we were extremely fortunate our little pocket did not burn. 

But our property did sustain pretty major smoke and ash damage due to the proximity to the fire, and our very old, uninsulated louvre windows. The wind also blew open doors, and covered everything in toxic house fire ash, full of arsenic, titanium, lead & other heavy metals, making the house unsafe to live in without major rehabilitation. 

We evacuated that night with our best friends, and after spending a couple of nights at my mother in laws house, we went and camped at the beach. Our best friends were sadly one of the many who lost their home and all that they own and the slow realization of that was devastating. 

The past couple of weeks have been a chaotic gathering and sorting of information, full of deep grief for our community, scrambling to support everyone we can while figuring out our own living situation and the kids schooling, and overwhelmed by confusion and fear for our health as to whether we now go back and live so close to all that toxic devastation. 

Our house is currently being restored and deep cleaned which will take a few weeks, and we are staying in an air bnb. The kids schools have found new locations and will be reopening at the end of the month. 

I have personally been having a bit of an existential crisis. I know there are always silver linings, and can already see so many. So much generosity, strength and community bonding. But the panic planning, exhaustion and stress has been real. And my heart just breaks over and over for those in our neighbourhood who have lost all of their belongings, despite my deep knowing that there are always reasons for everything.

‚Ä¶ Caption continued in comments ‚Ä¶ 

#eatonfire #altadenafire #ceramics #altadenastrong

The fires keep raging, and with them, so much of what once felt steady is slipping away. Homes, routines, the simple comforts we took for granted‚Äîit‚Äôs all changing faster than we can process. Some days, it feels like the ground won‚Äôt stop shaking beneath us.

But even in the unraveling, I‚Äôm learning to hold onto the smallest things‚Äîthe quiet moments that remind me I‚Äôm still here. A deep breath. The warmth of a loved one‚Äôs hand. The steady beat of my heart, whispering that somehow, some way, I‚Äôll find my footing again.

If you‚Äôre feeling lost in it all, I see you. We don‚Äôt have to carry the whole storm, just the next drop of rain. One moment at a time.

So hard to believe I had it all just a couple weeks ago. I started my illustration business from the ground up during the pandemic and eventually earned enough to renovate a backyard studio. That was my sacred place to create, it was filled with artwork, one of a kind products, a brand new laser cutter and screen printer I never got to use‚Ä¶ I was so proud of it, loved that space. 

In less than 2 hours the Eaton fire completely destroyed my home and studio. I went back to the site to see if anything was worth salvaging but it‚Äôs all powdery ash. 

We are fortunate enough that my husband found us housing and we were able to move in quickly. It‚Äôs eerily similar to my old house and includes a separate ADU I will use as a studio space. We have been blessed with so many donations and kind, thoughtful people have stepped in to help us. I hope to be up and running and creating art again very soon. Starting all over again is like staring at a blank canvas. It‚Äôs daunting and overwhelming but I did it before and I‚Äôll do it again #eatonfire #lastrong #altadenastrong

A Beacon of Resilience üè°‚ú® Amid the devastation of the Pacific Palisades wildfire, this remarkable home stood as a testament to the power of thoughtful design and fire-safe construction. Designed by architect Greg Chasen, it weathered the flames with materials and strategies built for resilience. üåüüî•

Here‚Äôs how it withstood the flames:

‚úÖ Fire-Safe Materials
* üß± Solid concrete walls blocked flames and provided a strong foundation.
* üõ°Ô∏è A metal roof with fire-resistant underlayment stopped embers from penetrating.
* ü™ü Tempered glass windows didn‚Äôt shatter under extreme heat, keeping fire and smoke out.
* üåæ Defensible space: No vegetation near the house + concrete garden walls.

‚úÖ Smart Design
* üö´ No eaves, overhangs, or attic vents that could let sparks in.
* üîí Airtight construction stopped embers from sneaking inside.
* üå¨Ô∏è Special ventilation systems filtered out smoke, keeping the air safe to breathe.

This home shows what‚Äôs possible with thoughtful home design and a focus on resilience. It‚Äôs also inspired me on my own journey to build a wildfire-resilient, solar-powered home in San Diego. üå±‚òÄÔ∏è

Yesterday I met with a family in LA who lost their home and their entire community of Altadena in the wildfires. Their kids school burned down as well üíî They want to build a climate-resilient home that is wildfire-safe and net-zero energy. We also hope to help the entire community build back more resilient. üè°üíö

üì≤ Follow @californiahomedesigns for more tips on wildfire-resilient design, sustainable building strategies, and creating safer, stronger homes! üî•üè°üí™üèº

Dear Community of Los Angeles,

You may know my wife and I in person but if you don‚Äôt, my wife and I are builders and we have renovated and build homes in Los Angeles for years. Right now we are stepping back and writing to you not as general contractors but as your neighbors and residents of the same city who are absolutely heartbroken for our community. 

Our hearts go out to our beloved cities of Altadena, Pacific Palisades and everyone affected during these tragic times. We‚Äôve been working behind the scenes, assisting in any way we can, but it‚Äôs time to put our expertise to use. 

Rebuilding the cities of Altadena and Pacific Palisades won‚Äôt be an easy task and for many it will be the first time building something from ground up, as well as, dealing with insurance companies. Please do not rush into anything and talk to experts. We would love to help you and your families make rebuilding process as worry free as possible and offer some major discounts to help during this tragedy. Our goal is to provide any assistance whether it be discounts, working with insurance, simply answering questions or anything else our community may need when rebuilding. 

We also want to warn the community about possible price gouging and scams that might take place and we are keeping our lines open for any questions. If something seems off please double check with another credible source and don‚Äôt get scammed by any unlicensed or untrustworthy ‚Äúcontractors‚Äù. When in doubt - reach out. 

If you or someone you know, needs assistance, please reach out. My wife and I are here for you. 

We are with you, Altadena! 

We are with you, Pacific Palisades!

We are with you, Los Angeles! Together we can rebuild and restore üíõ

Altadena was the first community in Southern California to return native land back to the indigenous Tongva people. It was one of the first places in LA County where Black people could own property at a time when redlining and segregation were widespread in the California real estate market. It grew into a multicultural town on the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, a place where historically underrepresented people could live and thrive. Altadena chose not to incorporate as a city, as well as not to be annexed by Pasadena, because they prefer a lighter political oversight. They are a community with the amenities of a city, a haven of integration and creativity. And they have been completely overwhelmed by the recent Eaton Fire that destroyed nearly the entire town.

Some of the longstanding businesses¬†that have been impacted by the fire include (check their IG for links to donate):

Stairs to nowhere. #Altadena #EatonFire

Firefighter Keith Williams of Station 36 stands on the front steps of one of the homes that was lost in the fire. They managed to save three houses in a row on the other side of the street, but this house, the one next door, and another across the street perished. 

Williams showed me videos on his phone of the inferno as it played out on this block. One video, taken of the backyard of this very house, showed thousands of burning embers, darting around on the wind like a hail of fireflies. 

I‚Äôm in awe of the bravery of these guys. But if you say that to them, of course, they shrug and say ‚ÄúJust doing my job.‚Äù 

The slogan you find all over Fire House 36 is ‚ÄòNot For The Weak‚Äô. 

Ain‚Äôt that the truth.

#firefighter #firstresponders #pasadena #losangeles #lafires #dmz #notfortheweak

UPDATE, this seems to have been saved! 

Hello dear friends, how are you holding up out there? Hopefully things in other parts of the country are not quite as stingy to the eyes as they are here. We continue to go up in flames, but our spirits remain. 

Among the many historically significant architectural sites I feared was lost in the Eaton fire was the beautiful Theosophical Society Estate. 

I tripped upon it while on one of my many walks in the area, and couldn't help but sneak in, despite the fact that I felt I was, perhaps, trespassing. The gate was wide open, the impressive winding long driveway beckoned to me, and, well, I just couldn't help myself. 

Here you can see the various views that I was able to capture without ruffling feathers. It definitely had an elevated and important feel to it. Here are some things I found out:

From Altadena Historical Society, published in 2014:

Altadena‚Äôs best kept secret is the Theosophical Society. The organization has been headquartered in Altadena since 1951, housed in two local historic buildings. 

Founded in New York in 1875, the non-sectarian organization went through more than a few hostile schisms, too numerous to mention here, but definitely interesting reading if you like gossip. 

According to the society‚Äôs literature, today the organization is a ‚Äúworldwide association dedicated to uplifting humanity through a better understanding of oneness of life and the practical application of brotherhood. Unsectarian and nonpolitical, the objectives are:

to form an active brotherhood among mankind;
to promulgate the essential unity of all that is, and to demonstrate that this unity is fundamental in nature;
to promote the study of ancient and modern religion, science, and philosophy;
to explore the hidden side of nature and mankind.‚Äù

The Society‚Äôs International Headquarters is located in a grand old house at the northeast corner of Mariposa and Santa Rosa Avenue. It‚Äôs the last of three significant homes built on the same millionaire‚Äôs row."

I thought it was gone, but re-examining the maps, I think not! Their library on Lake sadly burned - a great loss of books and archives, but this estate seems safe! :)

KRISTIN CROWLEY has been Chief of the LA Fire Department since 2022, a position she earned rung by rung. She entered the LAFD in 1998, when she "placed among the top 50 scores out of 16,000 applicants," the dept. told City News Service. She rose "through the ranks as firefighter, firefighter paramedic, engineer, fire inspector, captain I, captain II, battalion chief, assistant chief," CNS continues, becoming LAFD's 1st woman fire marshal and 2nd woman deputy chief. She is now LAFD's 1st woman and 1st openly queer (lesbian) chief. 

Crowley's appointment to chief came amidst alarm about hazing and other harassment of women firefighters in the LAFD and across the nation, with women quitting rather than reporting abuse, for fear of retaliation. "A highly anticipated survey of the LAFD's workplace culture released in November [2021] found that more than half of female firefighters reported bullying and harassment as sources of conflict,‚Äù The LA Times summarized. "Just 13% of female firefighters believe the LAFD is interested in their well-being, the survey found." As of Jan. 2022, the dept only had 117 women firefighters, making up just 3.5% of the LAFD. 

Like any minority in a given field, those few women have persevered by being extra good at what they do #burdenofrepresentation, such that their 3.5% holds 10% of leadership positions, according to then-Mayor Garcetti upon his appointment of Crowley. Unfortunately, such success makes it very easy for detractors to chock up their leadership to tokenism, as we have heard directed at Crowley during these fires. 

The media-hyped anonymous letter from alleged ‚Äúretired and active LAFD chief officers" particularly took issue with Crowley speaking out against LAFD budget cuts made by City Hall--that she spoke out while fighting these major fires, as if she was politicking rather than focusing on her work. Crowley's "outburst" has actually brought her further respect within the LAFD, as previous chiefs have been shy of criticizing their own boss, the mayor. It showed that she is not, in fact, interested in politics. It also brought public attention to the LAFD budget, especially in contrast to the LAPD‚Äôs. #priorities

They say a picture is worth a thousand words, but it would take more than a thousand words for my good friend @natalytavidian to describe what her childhood home meant to her. A home, not a house, that her parents poured their hearts into. A home filled with decades of memories reduced to ashes in minutes by the Eaton fire.

Standing on top of rubble today where Nataly once shared her most precious moments with her family, she told me of her late father‚Äôs love for their home, the love of the mountain views pressed against the Pasadena sky‚Ä¶and looking up at that sky, she tearfully said, ‚ÄúDad, we will rebuild in your honor.‚Äù

As reporters we cover tragedies daily‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs rare that we become part of the tragedy. To have to tell the stories of devastation while your own home is burning takes courage, strength, and dedication to duty.

Sifting through the ashes this afternoon, she found her dad‚Äôs harmonica-slightly charred but still recognizable. His spirit was the foundation of that home and the foundation she will use to remember, reconcile, and rebuild. #eatonfire @knxnews #lastrong 

To help Nataly‚Äôs family, you can visit

Once on the ground, the crews will install emergency protection measures, or EPMs, with the guidance of experts from @cal_oes, @cadepartmentofwaterresources, @officialcaltranshq, @calconservation, and @calfire. THANK YOU FOR YOUR DEDICATION TO THE PEOPLE OF L.A. AND ALTADENA @WALKGOODLA ‚Ä¶WE WILL AMPLIFY THE WORK. 
-
Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @walkgoodla LA, it‚Äôs time to take charge of your health now. 

We are in unprecedented territory as the burn zone has well surpassed the size of San Francisco. It‚Äôs important that we are all aware as a community that urban fires bring different challenges. It‚Äôs also important that we stay collected. We look to 9/11 and the Lahaina fires as examples of how smoke and ash exposure can lead to long term health consequences within the affected population. Think of all of the material in a home, on a car, in a business or old building. Those chemicals and components are now in the ash that we see collecting on surfaces in LA. 

And while we have a human urge to return to normalcy so quickly, we should first ask ourselves if it is safe to do so. 

Slide 5 contains current best practices that we know of so far. There is a public webinar occurring tomorrow 1.24 at 3pm PT from the Coalition of Clean Air. They will have new insights on air quality, water safety and hazardous waste, with a panel of experts to answer your questions. The panel includes representatives from South Coast Air Quality Mgmt District, Dept of Toxic Substances Control and the Natural Resources Defense Council. Link in the bio to register for the webinar. We will also be taking notes and making them available for the community ‚ù§Ô∏èüíõüíö

If you must go outside, use your best judgment and take the necessary preventative health measures currently available ü´Ç

source: Coalition for Clean Air 
special thanks to @soyyomelanie for taking notes on their first webinar. You can find those notes at the link in our bio as well under HEALTH.

We deeply loved our home, neighborhood, neighbors and entire community. 

All the donations people have been generously giving really give us a glimmer of hope that we will be able to get through this and get back to a place of comfort and sanctuary one day. 

Thank you from the bottom of my heart.üôèü©∑ü•π

I‚Äôm been at the anger stage since Day ‚òùÔ∏èknowing that this was definitely the case. I experienced it from both sides of the coin. Evacuating from the east side with plenty of notice to the west, where I received no alerts the morning of the fire. All deaths including my Aunt Evelyn were west of Lake Ave. Suspicious to say the least ü§îü§îü§î. A lot of questions need answers by those in positions of power. Our Los Angeles landscape has forever changed. In the face of monumental destruction our city is hard at work; organizing to support those in need. We commend the heroic first responders who continue to fight the fires and protect the communities we love. For those that have lost everything the long road to rebuild has only begun.

Just today we were able to return to our Malibu HQ to continue to move our operations forward. Our small team has been diligently and passionately keeping our doors open as we prepare for the @cabanashow in Miami next week. We are proud of the evolution of our brand and despite this recent challenge we are excited to present our SS25 and R26 collections to the world. We recognize how hard it is to continue to work in times like these, and we are grateful for our Dos Gardenias family as we keep each other afloat with levity, kindness, and dedication. 

As a team we have made the decision to offer the gift of Dos Gardenias to our friends and loyal customers who have lost their belongings in the Los Angeles fires. Simply send us an email at info@dosgardenias.com and share your situation to start the process. In addition, we will donate all profits from the sales of our Resort 2025 collection from now until May 1st¬†to @formosafirerelief, a grassroots local community-based fire relief organization, facilitating ongoing efforts to assist LA Fire victims and evacuees.

Pandemics, fires, division, unrest‚Ä¶ can we catch a break?

Well, the world is going to keep throwing curveballs at us whether we like it or not. It‚Äôs our own responsibility to ground and recharge so we don‚Äôt fizzle away. 

Take a look around. It‚Äôs not 2019 anymore, and there‚Äôs no going back to the world we once knew. (Keep an open mind now‚Ä¶)

The structures, systems, and beliefs that once felt solid are shifting beneath our feet, asking us to evolve alongside them. 

The energy of transformation is everywhere‚Äîfrom the way we work and connect to the way we view health, technology, and even the planet itself. (Hello AI, medical ‚Äúadvancements,‚Äù and crypto). 

Will you resist and struggle, or will you embrace the flow and allow growth to unfold? 

The choice is yours. But remember, nature still wins. You aren‚Äôt an AI robot. You are nature. Don‚Äôt venture too far away from it.

üíó Claudia Gilani @healingthesource

Did you know your pet‚Äôs natural detoxification system is their first line of defense against environmental toxins? üêæ

From wildfire pollutants to everyday exposure, our pets face invisible challenges that don‚Äôt just affect their lungs‚Äîthey can enter the bloodstream, fuel inflammation, and strain their overall health.

Here‚Äôs the good news: their bodies are designed to detox, and with the right support, you can help optimize those processes! üå±

Supplements like curcumin, sulforaphane (from broccoli, check out our past reel on broccoli and how to prepare it for your pet), chlorella, and milk thistle strengthen liver function, while NAC promotes glutathione production (the body‚Äôs master antioxidant) and supports lung health by breaking down mucus.

When you can take a breath, find your light.

For me, the way light enters a room can reset my mood.

It's a way to keep me in the present moment and I usually use it as a time to remind myself that I am loved and I am safe.

Sometimes, I consider how far I've come along in life from my teenaged years where I figured I'd be dead or in jail by now.

I didn't anticipate a future with the luxury of sitting in a room and making its natural light my biggest concern.

The light you need will most likely be different.

Look for it when you can.

About ten minutes ago is the first time since the fire I've been able to indulge. And it has been a battle to get here.

So give yourself grace if you're not there yet. Just keep it as a loose goal that when you get that space, you'll give yourself a few moments with whatever light you have at your disposal.

I completely understand if your normal light burned with your house.

Mine did too.

This is the first time in my life since 1984 I don't have an instrument to process my emotions with.

And I'm dealing with that, by using the what I have available to the best of my ability.

I'm asking you to do the same.

Because the question no one has asked (at least me) yet, is am I going to rebuild my life like for like, or am I going to reimagine who I can become and rebuild my life with upgrades.

Maybe take your time with your light to consider that.

As for my answer to that question, I'm reimagining my life--with the upgrades. And those upgrades are entirely dependent on the choices I make in moments like these when all feels lost at least once a day.

But for now, all I need to do is spend a little time with my light and just breathe.

The rest is in the future and my concentration is on the present.

#eatonfire #AnthrotonikAlchemy #mindsetmatters #mindsetmagic #altadenastrong #altadena

This month has been extraordinarily difficult for all Angelenos. Whether you‚Äôve faced evacuation, lost your home, school, or place of work, or have been sitting on the edge of your seat wondering if you‚Äôll be next, January has been full of unwelcomed surprises and unexpected challenges for so many neighborhoods in our community. 

This week, @childnexuscommunity shared a helpful link with her professional community. I found it so useful that I wanted to share it with you here. In my bio, you‚Äôll see a link to a Google Doc that is updated daily with active volunteer and donation opportunities.

Mr. Rogers encouraged us to ‚Äúlook for the helpers‚Äù in difficult times. If you‚Äôre in the space to be able to be a helper, check the doc for opportunities.

#CaliforniaWildfires #WildfireSeason

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt interest me who you know or how you came to be here. I want to know if you will stand in the fire with me and not shrink back.‚Äù ‚ú® The Invitation, Oriah Mountain Dreamer

LA, my home of 11 years ‚Äî forever changed, yet unbroken ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

These past few weeks have been a whirlwind of emotions: devastation, resilience, fear, and unmeasurable hope. Witnessing the wildfires‚Äô destruction has been heartbreaking, but seeing our community‚Äôs incredible solidarity has been beautiful.

I‚Äôm safe ‚Äî but ‚Äòsafe‚Äô feels complicated. For over a week, I‚Äôd fall asleep exhausted and wake up with tears streaming down my face. I know I‚Äôm not the only one carrying this weight. Processing, and learning that it‚Äôs okay to feel everything at once. Sad. Inspired. Scared. Determined. Our city is hurting, but we‚Äôre holding each other up to heal togetherüôèüèΩ

LA is my dream. And no wildfire can extinguish that. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π 
.
.

United for Recovery.

Yesterday, I joined Governor Newsom, Senate President Pro-Tem Mike McGuire, emergency personnel, first responders, local officials, and my Assembly colleagues in Pasadena to sign a $2.5 billion wildfire recovery package. This bipartisan effort will provide critical aid to Angelinos who lost so much. as a result of the devastating wildfires. This aid will help rebuild schools, homes, and communities. Together, we‚Äôre standing strong with Los Angeles, every step of the way. This is just the beginning...

#PalisadesFire #EatonFire #altadena

I was 16 years old when my home burned down in a wildfire. It was one of the most devastating events of my life. 

The fires in California have only intensified since then. I‚Äôve spoken with quite a few people this month for have been impacted by the wildfires in LA. My heart goes out to you. If you have lost your home or not, there are so many symptoms related to wildfires and natural disasters that make it difficult to continue with ‚Äúlife as normal‚Äù. It will never be the same ever again and that grief is REAL. 

Right now we are a community in shock. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms, as a survivor and therapist who has come out the other side I would recommend you get in community (even if you don‚Äôt always feel like it). Grief is not meant to be experienced alone. 

Need more support? Seek out a mental health therapist with experience in trauma. 

If you are a mental health therapist who is available feel free to comment a little about yourself below. Let‚Äôs connect and remind each other the struggle is real but we aren‚Äôt alone. 

#traumahealing #mentalhealth #palisadesfire #eatonfire

In the last two weeks, #CCCstaff have mobilized from across California to serve our neighbors in need in Los Angeles County. So far, 28 Conservationist 1s have led 25 fire crews on the fire lines in LA, Ventura, Riverside, and San Diego counties, as well as on staffing patterns. Another 25 C1s mobilized their Corpsmembers to support base camp operations. This week 25 more C1s arrived in Los Angeles to help with watershed recovery work on the #PalisadesFire and #EatonFire. Another dozen-plus Conservationist 2s have managed base camps and are working watershed assignments. In total, more than 110 CCC staffers ‚Äî from office technicians to district directors ‚Äîhave deployed to these emergencies. As an emergency response agency, the #CaliforniaConservationCorps takes pride in the skills and abilities of our staff to help with the response and to serve our fellow Californians. #ServeCA #CCCcareers

although news coverage has decreased , these fires are still burning throughout southern CA . many have lost everything they worked hard for & others have lost things given to them to support with everyday living . let us not forget those who are disabled & how difficult this time may be for them as well . medical equipment , sensory friendly items , emotional support items & more now are gone ! 

i started my career working with individuals with developmental disabilities & physical disabilities in the pacific palisades , CA . i worked in many of those burned down homes . i supported children in palisades elementary , marquez elementary & palisades high school . i had a few families that i worked w in the palisades lose everything . their children no longer have a home nor a school to return to . devastation is insurmountable . 

please continue to pray for LA . please continue to share resources as the ones posted & tagged here . and please , be kind . kindness goes a long way . 

if anyone wants any support with finding resources for individuals with disabilities , please feel free to reach out to me & send me a private message . 

stay strong LA ü´∂üèΩ

Hi Friends,

Thank you all who donated to my Pasadena Humane Society and who have donated to the victims of the fires in LA. 

I also want to show my appreciation for all the firefighters and police officers who put their lives on the line to fight these fires and make sure our community is safe. The Eaton fire is only 95% contained, and the Palisades fire is 77% contained. It moved to the other side of the mountains and is no longer in our communities. We feel terrible for the animals that don‚Äôt understand what‚Äôs happening. Please keep them in your prayers. We are supposed to have rain this Sunday. 

Thank you to @everything.doggo for creating this beautiful bandana. The profits went to the victims of the fires. 

Stay safe, friends, I hope to be back to regular programming‚Ä¶ somehow it feels wrong to post knowing the fires are still happening. Especially since the Eaton fire burned our favorite hiking place, burned homes in our city, injured lives, and took lives.

found this in the yard of my old place in Eagle Rock: a charred page from a book on 1940‚Äôs fashion. is it possible that it could have traveled the 7 or so miles from Altadena, and is a somber remnant of the Eaton Fire? it is quite plausible. 

the Eaton Fire started on the evening of Tuesday, January 7th. by the next morning, a significant part of the town of Altadena had been decimated. more homes, businesses and structures would be lost as the morning progressed. 

over at my place a few miles away, the sky was dark and orange with the smoke from the fire that had drifted over the area. it was dark at 7 am when i woke up - a strange realm between daytime and nighttime. the smoke cloud was massive and thick, like a colossal serpent slowly dragging its belly across the region, blocking out the sun as it soundlessly slithered overhead. 

i went out in my back yard and immersed myself in the uneasy stillness of that morning; an anxious silence of despair as an entire town not far away was being wiped from the map. and standing out there, something caught my eye: a snowflake gently falling, but one made of ash. and as i saw more ‚Äòsnowflakes‚Äô falling around me, i couldn‚Äôt help but notice the contradictory beauty of the strange, orange-hued scene. 

and then i saw the larger pieces of charred tree bark gently falling as well. one piece, about the size of this book page, landed delicately at my feet, like a dark gift from a malevolent fire spirit. i picked it up, held it in my hand, and took in the significance of the journey it made and what it represented. 

so while i am not one hundred percent certain this page came from the fire, my heart imagines a time when this book was in someone‚Äôs collection, sitting on a shelf in some modest Altadena living room, surrounded by other keepsakes and memories that made up this person‚Äôs home. artifacts that are forever gone. 

a friend suggested i frame this. perhaps: this scorched memento is currently in my living room. 

#eatonfire

President Donald Trump, who has criticized state and local leaders over water policies and forest-management practices, landed in Los Angeles County on Friday afternoon, Jan. 24, en route to survey the massive damage from recent wildfires.

Trump, newly sworn in this week as the nation‚Äôs 47th president, got a first-hand look at the staggering toll of the Palisades fire, which broke out on Jan. 7 amid extreme winds in the region. The visit did not include a trip, at least by ground, to see the devastation of the Eaton fire in Altadena and Pasadena or meet with residents there. 

To read more about Trump‚Äôs trip to LA County, tap the link in our bio.

Thanks to World Central Kitchen @wckitchen, who generously sponsored all the delicious hot meals during the @smcedu Foundation‚Äôs Disaster Support Distribution event.

That‚Äôs when I paused for a moment, looked at Mel‚Äôs shirt with the WCK logo on it and realized that I‚Äôve seen @chefjoseandres‚Äô WCK team feeding and supporting communities during disasters all over the world‚Äîand now, here they were, in our own backyard in Los Angeles area. 
I teared up, thanked Mel deeply for being here, and shared why I was so emotional.

The green cottage stands. Yesterday I had the privilege of photographing Caroline and David, whose beautiful century old ‚ÄúJanes Cottage‚Äù was the sole survivor on a block of total devastation after the Eaton Fire tore its way through the community of Altadena, California. It was my first time in the neighborhood since flames consumed over 6000 homes on January 7th and 8th. How Caroline and David‚Äôs home was the only one to survive on their block will most likely remain a mystery, but a firefighter‚Äôs boot print can still be seen on the front door as he gained access to the house to make sure flames didn‚Äôt enter the attic. Three backyard trees were also cut down in an obvious battle that claimed the detached garage. It looks like Caroline‚Äôs beloved orange tree will survive. I was struck by the way the plastic pail used to collect the oranges was melted around them. Very little remains of neighbors‚Äô homes, but one had put out cat food and water in hopes that family pets had escaped the fire and are still in the neighborhood. Altadena is a beautiful community with so much rich, important history. I‚Äôm wishing them the best as they begin the journey to rebuild. 

#altadena #eatonfire #eatonfire2025 #lafires #esmithimages #losangelesphotographer

When life takes everything, sometimes it gives back just one thing to remind you of what you‚Äôre made of. 

After years of dreaming, training, and then running (sometimes crawling) 100 of the toughest miles, my @hardrock100run finish was everything. 

Then the fire came and left nothing of that race behind‚Ä¶ or so I thought. Digging through the ash, I found it, my favorite Hardrock mug, intact. 

A little charred, a lot tougher‚Ä¶ just like me.

This week, my firm and the California Fire Attorneys have been on the ground, handing out donations to survivors of the Eaton Fire. But it wasn‚Äôt until yesterday, when a lifelong resident and homeowner took me through the devastation, that the full scale of the loss hit me. Homes, schools, stores‚Äîfamiliar landmarks are now nothing but ash. It‚Äôs heartbreaking. This fire was avoidable, and it didn‚Äôt have to happen. My team is working relentlessly to hold SoCal Edison accountable and ensure they pay back every family for this tragedy. There‚Äôs hope, and we‚Äôre on a mission to make sure justice is served. #EatonFire #HoldThemAccountable #FireSurvivors #JusticeForFamilies

We‚Äôre working with the surfing community, led by Flow Surf Academy, as well as the Los Angeles area CrossFit communities, to make waves, not in the ocean, but in an ice bath! Join us for an invigorating plunge to awaken our spirits and channel the power of love and resilience.

This special event is dedicated to supporting survivors of the devastating fires in the Palisades and Altadena, helping them rise again with strength and hope. Your donation will directly benefit Project:Camp, Help California, and the Oak Park - CrossFit Relief Aid. These organizations provide essential resources, including pop-up camps to keep children active and engaged while their families rebuild their lives and communities, one neighborhood at a time.

HOW TO PARTICIPATE:
‚Ä¢ Register, schedule, and donate to reserve your tub time at the following link (can also be found on our profile page): https://www.flowsurfacademy.org/plungeforla

‚Ä¢ Choose a $20.00 solo plunge or gather your friends, co-workers, or teammates for a $140.00 group plunge (up to 8 people).

‚Ä¢ Plunges are scheduled in 8-minute intervals, with 20 participants plunging together during each time slot.

‚Ä¢ Each participant will be challenged to a 180-second plunge, symbolizing the 180-degree pivot from tragedy to recovery.

WHAT TO BRING:
‚Ä¢ Wear clothing suitable for the plunge.

‚Ä¢ Bring two towels, water-friendly shoes or flip-flops, and warm, dry clothes in a bag or backpack.

BY TAKING THE PLUNGE YOUR DONATION AND ALL DOLLARS RAISED WILL HELP THESE ORGANIZATIONS TRANSFORM LIVES AND REBUILD OUR COMMUNITY!

With a broken heart for our neighborhood and the larger community of Altadena, we wanted to share that Midwick Manor was impacted by the Eaton Fire. While we are considered ‚Äúlucky‚Äù compared to many of our neighbors, unfortunately every single item of our Midwick Manor Halloween display was destroyed in the fire. In the smoldering debris we discovered remnants of our ‚Äúthinking skeleton‚Äù (swipe ‚û°Ô∏è for photo), which we hope will inspire us to decorate again during another Halloween season. For those of us impacted by this disaster, the road to recovery is filled with much uncertainty. But no matter what the future holds, we will always take great pride in Midwick Manor, and the pumpkin orange joy it brought to our neighbors and the @socalhauntlist community. Until next time, stay safe and aways slightly sinister like our pumpkin patch. üéÉ 

#midwickmanor #altadena #socalhauntlist #halloween #eatonfire

Hey All,
@artcenteredu and #altadena mean so damn much to us and our fam here at #corrovisvecomplexproject and it hurts to witness the devastations to so many friends lives from the #lawildfires 

We lost 30 homes of faculty members and dozens of homes/studios of students and alumni/creatives, it‚Äôa gonna be a long journey to recovery.
 When things get heavy and to much to bear, We witness, We step up, We help our brothers and sisters, Boots on the ground, then we Create Create Create in the studio!

We teamed up with @ecoresearchlab and got crazy in the corrosive complex studio 
And created this powerful Tee. This one is totally handcrafted with love 
Inspired by the orange dot we #handpainted an intense total eclipse, which represents a time of profound introspection, transformation and a deep reflection on a moment to reset, rethink and start fresh, then we freestyle screened the mantra for our #ecoresearchlab and #artcenteredu friends #ArtCenterStrong an acknowledging the city of our amigos. The front of the tee is simple and powerful with the iconic artcenter dot and the city we will rebuild
We used our staple hi quality permaset inks made in Australia for the hand painting and screenwork, which give the finish a soft vintage feel.

We wanted this to be for everybody so we used a hi quality 1301 tee that has a standard athletic fit, so if you want a full or oversized fit just size up, we made limited amount in all sizes.
We made two options on the front, the iconic orange dot, and a crescent dot version, which we feel represents movement, transition , let us know which one you like when you order
These are available in our #etsyshop or DM and we can hand deliver to you.

You don‚Äôt have to buy anything to help our amigos that lost everything, just donate.
But if you want our super sic  tee 100% of the price goes to artcenter faculty and fam that lost everything, not ‚Äúa portion of proceeds‚Äù we mean every penny of the sale goes to our fam 

#Axellives #prayfordena #eatonfire #artsupport #teachersupport #devastation #wildfires 
#altadenastrong #artcenterstrong

Spent some of the day at the #eatonfire in #altadena yesterday helping residents with repopulation and searching the wreckage. I met up with @calfire_butteco strike team that I was out with during the USAR and @lasdsar operation to assist. We helped residents dig and sift thru the ash to find possessions. We were able to recover: coins, jewelry and a few other things that meant a lot to the residents.

I am settled back into my place after a 2 week long evacuation due to the #eatonfire . I am extremely fortunate that my home is ok. Have had a number of things to do and another big project that has demanded much of my attention, along with work and just the general stress of things has really prevented me from getting into an art headspace, but here we are. 

The world of scorn depicts industrialization of the very body itself, and therefore a reduction in meaning associated with the powers of the body. Here the "queen" of my chess set is modeled after clusters of artificial wombs. The once intimate and personal experience of pregnancy and childbirth has been reduced to a process step in a megafactory. The industrialization of the body in this way represents the loss of personhood, taking who we are and replacing it with nothing more than what we are constructed from and our functions. The self becomes a product and we enter a biological caste system where the form we are engineered with decides everything. 

The entirety of the world of scorn is one of a closed loop recycling system, where the only resource that remains is us. When we are the only thing left we are forced to consume our very selves in an endless loop, reducing every piece of our existence down to a system of basic parts to be reused and reformed. 

#scorn #scorngame #zbrush #zbrushsculpt #sculpture #digitalsculpture #digitalart #3dmodeling #design #3dart #3dartist #alien #hrgiger #beksinski

Feeling more grateful than ever to call LA home after the past few weeks we‚Äôve had ü•≤üíû

For a moment, it felt like we might lose the magic of this city that inspires people to come here and create their own. My heart goes out to everyone affected by the fires. Seeing the loss is heartbreaking and I‚Äôm hoping for the healing and recovery for everyone impacted. Losing what you love is one of the hardest experiences to face and a reminder to live fully. Carrying that reminder with me into this year to approach each day with a little more gratitude and make the most of each moment. Super excited to share the magic I‚Äôve been working on and resume collaborating with my amazing friends to create even more. 

Hollywood Forever üí´

UPDATE on the #lawildfires response:

Our #LACountySearchDogs, K9 Clifford and K9 Prentiss, have been tirelessly searching through the devastation caused by the Palisades and Eaton Fires. Their determination and skill are instrumental as we continue working to locate those still missing amidst the wreckage.

The toll as of Jan. 25, 2025:

Eaton Fire: 17 confirmed fatalities, 18 still missing

Palisades Fire: 10 confirmed fatalities, 8 still missing

Our mission is clear: to bring closure to families and help our community begin to rebuild. Each bark, alert, and search is a step closer to that goal.

Thank you to everyone who has shown support for our teams. Your words of encouragement fuel them during these long days. Please continue to keep the impacted families, our first responders, and these resilient dogs in your thoughts.
