21 days ago Tom and I were driving home, remarking how much we love our neighborhood. The beautiful trees. The old houses and within their walls every sort of family that called them home.

What we drove through this week was a wasteland. 

Couples standing in front of what remained of their lives, holding each other in silence. National guards standing around their hummers, assault rifles in hand. Utility employees and firefighters working hard to stabilize poles and cut down trees. Families in masks and hazmat suits, digging through rubble for just a piece of themselves. 

The second we got to our street, tears rolled down the sides of my respirator as I clutched my chest. My heart has been in pain every second since we evacuated. Nothing looked the same, I was disoriented‚Ä¶ Then I saw it. 

For the past 2 weeks it‚Äôs like my heart was working on a puzzle that my mind wouldn‚Äôt let me finish. When I saw the house, the final pieces snapped into place, revealing an image that was too much for my heart to bear. I collapsed to the ground, sobbing. I opened my eyes to find I was crying on a bed of ash, nails and shattered glass. Every inch of the streets were covered.

Our house was built in 1950. The first bathroom still had the original tub, vanity and pink tiles. The house was never ‚Äúflipped‚Äù, and it only had 2 prior owners. That‚Äôs the kind of place Altadena is. A community where people stay, grow and take care of each other. We were so lucky we got to call it home for even a little while. Thank you Altadena. 

Thank you every single person who has reached out, donated, sent clothing and groceries. I can‚Äôt imagine how helpless it would feel to watch this happen to people you love, but you should know that every bit of it is like an embrace and we will never forget it ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π #eatonfire

We lost our house in the Eaton Fire. Everything we had is gone. We are devastated and still in shock but working through it.

We spent four and a half years on construction, and it all went away in an hour. My wife Leila poured her heart and soul into this place. She was the designer and project manager for the whole thing and oversaw multiple subs and builders to create a beautiful forever home for us and a photography studio for her business. It truly was a magical place.

A good portion of Altadena is gone. Our daughter Stella‚Äôs school is reduced to rubble. We were so excited to find Altadena and make friends there and experience the close community. So many people in Altadena and the Palisades have lost everything and our hearts go out to them. 

Most of the things we lost were just stuff, not really a big deal ultimately. It‚Äôs the memories that are gone ‚Äì photos, videos, letters etc. ‚Äì that really get to me. I‚Äôll definitely be reaching out to friends to collect copies of photos from the past. 

This feels very odd to do, but we‚Äôve been encouraged and urged to accept the kind gesture of a friend to start a GoFundMe account on our family's behalf, to help with rebuilding our lives, when insurance money is covering only a portion of it. Here‚Äôs the link:

https://gofund.me/4d633f30 

I‚Äôm also posting it in my bio.

There is no expectation on our part, but please pass it on to others. For a lot of people, money is tight. The last 5 years have been insane to say the least. We appreciate the love and support from people who have been reaching out and if I‚Äôve learned anything from this so far, it‚Äôs that nothing is certain, and I need to try harder and connect more with my friends and family. They are the most important part of our lives.
#altadena #eatonfire

I had the opportunity to visit the distribution center organized by the @dodgersfoundation and the @cityofpasadena , and I‚Äôm grateful for the support they‚Äôre providing to the members of our community who are in need. #AD41 #Altadena #Eatonfire

I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs been over two weeks since the fire. I‚Äôm just doing my best to stay positive every day. So many changes in such a short time. I miss my little bungalow and all my stuff. So many memories and good times there. 

The kitty‚Äôs and I are adjusting to our new place. I went back to work and have been doing my best to organize our new home. So grateful to my mom for letting us stay with her. 

I‚Äôm still hoping to find my sweet kitty Hoku Angeles. I feel so bad for leaving him behind. I search daily thru pictures of found cats. I just hope he made it and we can find him. Luna, Sol, and I miss our star man so much. 

I really appreciate all the love and support from my family and friends. 

The link to my gofundme is in my bio.  #altadenaca #eatonfire #lostcat #altadenastrong #catmom #catsofinstagram

Eaton Fire Update ‚Äî Our beautiful Altadena community has been devastated beyond belief. Over 9,000 structures were destroyed, not including the thousands damaged. Tyler captured this photo the next day, Jan 8. 

Our home and water supply are both contaminated. We are currently unable to live there or feel safe using items from inside.

There had been warnings of high winds and planned power outages, but on the morning of the fire the winds started earlier than expected.

When the power went out that evening we were able to go off grid with our solar/battery system. The fire started to the east of us, and hit 10 acres by 7:15PM. The wind gusts had the potential to reach 100mph and they were going strong outside. As the fire spread it started burning houses. A neighbor was following LA Fire Dept. scanner reports to map out the houses that burned. We threw some of our belongings by the door just in case we needed to leave.

We later walked outside and could see the mountain side LIT up. I took the video of the palm tree swaying and it felt apocalyptic‚Äîlike something referenced in the show Extrapolations. We were expecting to go to sleep with Watch Duty app notifications on around midnight, knowing that evacuation warnings (and then orders) were being given to the east side of Altadena.

Oddly enough, Marina woke up around 3AM. I fed her a bottle and looked at my phone. There was a single burned house on the scanner map that was now on the west side of Altadena, not the east‚Ä¶ and just as I was about to say ‚Äúlet‚Äôs go‚Äù our phones started blaring with the evacuation order alarm. We had never received a warning ‚Äî just suddenly an order to get out. 

I grabbed Marina‚Äôs first footprint and my brass rat box, then Roo‚Äôs leash because she hates smoke. We decided we would try to make it to Shawn and Danielle‚Äôs house, but we had no idea if there would be traffic or obstacles. We decided to leave a car and drive together. 

Once we made it to their place, now known as ‚Äúthe fortress,‚Äù we regrouped. Shortly after, Tyler drove back to our house around 5am. Thus began the journey of gas line shutoffs and hoses, knowing Marina was now farther from the flames #eatonfire #altadena

‚ÄúLA, it‚Äôs time to take charge of your health now.

We are in unprecedented territory as the burn zone has well surpassed the size of San Francisco. It‚Äôs important that we are all aware as a community that urban fires bring different challenges. It‚Äôs also important that we stay collected. We look to 9/11 and the Lahaina fires as examples of how smoke and ash exposure can lead to long term health consequences within the affected population. Think of all of the material in a home, on a car, in a business or old building. Those chemicals and components are now in the ash that we see collecting on surfaces in LA.

And while we have a human urge to return to normalcy so quickly, we should first ask ourselves if it is safe to do so.

Slide 5 contains current best practices that we know of so far. There are public webinars from @cleanairca. They have new insights on air quality, water safety and hazardous waste, with a panel of experts to answer your questions.

If you must go outside, use your best judgment and take the necessary preventative health measures currently available

source: Coalition for Clean Air

special thanks to@soyyomelanie for taking notes on their first webinar. You can find those notes at the link in @walkgoodla‚Äôs bio as well under HEALTH.‚Äù

#lafire #lafires #publichealth #preventativehealth #eatonfire #palisadesfire #california #losangeles #airquality #airqualityindex #smokeinhalation #losangelescity

Went back up to @sarahhartzog‚Äôs house in Altadena today and finally allowed to drive in vs walk. Looters dug through the ruins and found her safe pulled it out and opened it. We dug through the ash looking for anything.. I found some coins from a holiday she took years ago. A handful of metal tools that didn‚Äôt melt, but are really in rough shape, chips of ceramics.. literally nothing left and nothing whole. 

We drove through the neighborhood a bit for the first time. It‚Äôs really sad. It‚Äôs also wild seeing an occasional house that *seems* untouched and the citrus trees also seem untouched and baring fruit. Her neighbor already has fresh grass coming in, and we found a big and very active ant hill in her old carport.

No words. 

This morning I returned to Big Rock where I once lived many years ago. The devastation is beyond comprehension. The house that David and I bought six months ago nearby is miraculously still there, but the majority of my neighborhood is burned to the ground.

My friend @elle.sue.bea saw what‚Äôs left of her home today after the #palisadesfire. She ran her nonprofit, @deityanimalrescue from there and saved the lives of so many sweet dogs, many of them special needs. 

The destruction of both this fire and the #EatonFire is hard to fully grasp until you see it in person. Thousands have lost their homes and businesses and every single person has a unique and important story to share.

Please follow Ellen and Diety here on IG to learn more about her story. üôèüèº

Our first reunion ‚ù§Ô∏è Sesame was lost when the Eaton fire quickly engulfed Altadena, but she is a fighter, like so many cats, and was able to find a safe place until she could be with her family again. Sesame‚Äôs rescue couldn‚Äôt have happened without @wufaw_official and @del.gato.rescue who are so amazing to provide us with trail cameras. It is scary to set a trap without being able to monitor it. 

Here is how we‚Äôve been able to catch now 3 pets and 2 ferals from the burn zone. 

Step 1. ADDRESS. We need an address, kitties are staying on their properties from our experience so cross streets and general areas are not easy to work with. 

Step 2. FEED! Sesame already had a feeding station set up, so we added wet food and other distinguishing foods so when we returned the next day it would be obvious someone had dinner. 

Step 3. CAMERA. Now that we have proof that something or someone is eating food at this location, we can set up a trail camera to see who is eating. On our trail cameras we‚Äôve seen cats, crows, coyotes, raccoons, and skunks eating from feeding stations. 

Step 4. TRAP! Bingo, the camera shows that a cat is eating the food and no other outside friends, so now we can set up a trap. Dusk and night are the best times to catch a cat, so setting up a trap with really good bait (thank you #costcorotisseriechicken) at these times is ideal. 

Step 5. Wait. Be patient. Kitty might come and not go in the trap the first couple times you see them on camera; but most of the time, eventually they will go in either out of curiosity or hunger. AND sometimes you might catch a kitty you didn‚Äôt plan for, surprise cat! 

We‚Äôre tired. We work full time jobs and have our own cats at home. But we won‚Äôt stop trapping, these cats survived a fire, they deserve to be reunited with their family. 

Thank you to everyone who has supported us so far, for those of you who have been asking and wanting to help with supplies, my Venmo is linked on my link tree in my bio and so Amy‚Äôs in hers. Right now we‚Äôre estimating we‚Äôve spent around $200 buying a godforsaken amount of batteries and activating and running these trail cameras. Thank you.

Per Sac Metro:

‚ÄúMetro Fire is proud to announce that our regional OES Type 1 and Type 3 strike teams have returned home safely after 16 days on the front lines battling the devastating fires in Los Angeles County. These teams worked alongside agencies from across the state and beyond, protecting countless lives and properties in the face of the most challenging and dangerous conditions.

Our returning firefighters have shared stories of the incredible community support they encountered during their deployment. Meals prepared or donated by neighbors, signs of gratitude along roadways, and heartfelt words of encouragement from those they served. To the families of our deployed personnel, thank you. Your support and sacrifice during these challenging weeks have made it possible for your loved ones to answer the call to serve. We are deeply grateful for your partnership in this mission. Metro Fire remains committed to serving our region and beyond, bringing hope and relief wherever it‚Äôs needed most. Thank you for your continued trust and support.

It's Spanish Sunday and you may not want to scroll past the third or fourth photo here if you want to keep it happy. Just thought I should warn you‚Ä¶ 

I chanced upon this lovely Spanish style abode today when I went on a mission to see the truth of what has happened in Altadena with my own eyes.

 I don't recommend it, by the way. It feels extremely toxic, quite scary. And it's still not open to everyone. But as is evidenced by this feed, I document, especially when it comes to houses, so I needed to document this as well. And I have found through this experience that I should always follow my gut when it comes to that.

It's one thing to see one house in a neighborhood burned to the ground, that's upsetting enough.  It's quite another to see one house still standing when the others are all gone.  And it's much more shocking and chilling to see it in person than on the TV screen. 

You'll see here that I found this beautiful house, and across the street a wonderfully preserved vintage car, but just a few blocks away, things, the houses and cars, looked heartbreakingly different - almost as though there had been a cyclone or a hurricane, or tornado or even a tsunami! The destruction is so extreme‚Ä¶

And to be honest, I think I sort of went into shock. I noticed that I wasn't really feeling much of anything. It was like I instantly protected myself, turned off all emotion, because otherwise I would've completely fallen apart. 

I truly don't know how the homeowners are coping.

Yet I felt compelled to continue, to give you a real sense of it, from me, so you know it's as real as it can be, lest anyone doubt the media‚Ä¶ and because there's been some misinformation, not so much, I don't believe from the major media outlets, but from some smaller sources, and even unwittingly from me because of them. And I apologize again. But that's also why I wanted to go, because I needed to see the truth of it and understand the scope. The maps just aren't clear enough for me. 

So if you scroll, as you can see, the situation is as dire as it could possibly be.  And this is just such a tiny bit of the damage. 

#altadena #eatonfire #spanishsunday #firedamage #lafires

So happy for this family who will begin their post-fire life in a new lease/rental home next week! 

Please know that with so many looking and so little inventory, it can be challenging, but it is doable!! ‚ú®

From my experience these last 2 weeks, here are my tips: 

* Know exactly how your insurance company will handle your rental before you begin the process.

* Of course, use your Realtor but in this case ALSO use Zillow, Realtor.com, etc so that you have access to ALL rental inventory available. Those sites have more than we have access to.

* If jobs and school 
distance permit, be willing to also look to rent in cities away from the fire area, it can afford you more options, often for less $. 

* Once you find a place you like, submit right away! Especially, if you‚Äôre intent on renting in the area, you will likely be competing against others, so act quickly!

* Don‚Äôt set your sights on one home. You may have to apply for more than one before you find your home away from home. 

Sending my love and support to everyone affected by the fires. I have so many loved ones, family, friends, friends of friends & colleagues affected, I see/hear how overwhelming it is. I hope this helps! ‚ù§Ô∏è

I've said it a few times, but it's not really the 'stuff' that I'll miss. What I'm sad about, but also most proud of is all of the things that we did together in our home. 

When it was time to tile the floors and walls, my mom was right there to teach me how to do it correctly. I‚Äôm so proud of my mom, she‚Äôs one of the most talented people you‚Äôll ever meet, and truly modest. 

We had found a bunch of bricks from the 1890s under the deck that I removed last year and decided to use them to make a pathway to the back yard. Ariane‚Äôs attention to detail made everything come together, and Theo did a great job sweeping sand into the cracks. It didn‚Äôt matter which of us was more skilled on a given day.. we did so much together. 

Inspired by Ariane‚Äôs dad, I also built a compost tumbler. Theo loved that machine. All of the soil in every garden bed was sifted to take out the rocks which we then used as ground cover around the fruit trees. 

I also included a picture of Theo using his butt to make sure that the countertops I made were properly glued in place. My mom‚Äôs friend gave me a whole day of his time to teach me how to fabricate corian countertops, and sent me home with all of the materials I needed. 

Gardening, cooking, and building are these last few pictures. This is what we do. Like I said before, the 'stuff' isn‚Äôt what made our home what it was‚Ä¶ It was all of the things that we did together, all of the daily patterns that we were forced to take a break from. I look forward to getting back to that life.
#altdena #eatonfire #altadenastrong

The watershed protection process for #CCCDelta and #CCCSolano Corpsmembers starts with PPE. That‚Äôs personal protective equipment. The crews are using Tyvek suits to keep ash and possible toxins off their clothing. They‚Äôre also using N-95 masks to prevent breathing anything in. Once fully in PPE, they dig trenches for silt socks, and use rock bags and stakes to secure the socks and straw wattle around burned structures and vehicles. The goal, keep toxins from entering watersheds if and when it rains on the #PalisadesFire and #EatonFire burn scars. #WatershedDebrisFlow #WatershedDebrisFlowTaskForce
‚Ä¶
Task Force partners: @cal_oes, @cadepartmentofwaterresources, @californiaconservationcorps, @calfire, @officialcaltranshq, @calconservation, @lacorps @thecclb

Some days, it feels impossible. Other days, I see the quiet strength in the small moments‚Äîthe hugs, the deep breaths, the love that refuses to crumble.

If you‚Äôre in this too, I see you. We‚Äôre doing it, one day, one step, one breath at a time. And in the midst of it all, we‚Äôre teaching our kids something we never planned to‚Äîbut something that will shape them forever: how to bend without breaking.

This is our story, and we‚Äôre writing it with resilience, love, and the unwavering belief that we will rise.

Let‚Äôs keep holding on, together. ‚ù§Ô∏è

-Dr. Z

I knew January was going to be momentous‚ö°Ô∏è
But never ever did losing my Community cross my Consciousness. 
That would be, and I am learning now, unfathomable. 
Most of us in the Collective felt this. And knew big changes were coming. All the signs pointing to 2025 welcoming massive shifts. 

I spent all of the Christmas Holiday having a major Detox. Which is what I call ‚Äúsickness‚Äù. I had multiple days of a high fever, could not eat for a week, could barely sip liquids. I wasn‚Äôt scared. I knew it was a purge. A die off. My family was off skiing having a great time which was wonderful. I could sleep and be alone in my home and heal. Everyday I kept saying to myself, I am so grateful to have this still and quiet time alone in my Home. I was taking it all in. I was very nostalgic. This was such a blessing. 

When my family returned, we did a beautiful deep clean. All of the closets looked and felt amazing. I had 4 bags of clothes to donate (they were in my car when we evacuated). That Sunday night we all discussed how amazing our Home felt. The best it ever had. 
Who knew that only two days later, it would all be released. 

Our Home was a Sanctuary for us. She loved and protected us well. 
Our neighbors looked out for us as we did for them. 
This Community gave us so much that will always live on in our Hearts. No matter what happens, if people rebuild and come back, or move on, Pacific Palisades will always be the most precious place and Community. A Village within a big city. A gem nestled in the Hills. 

I know that thousands of us are taking it hour by hour right now. As is right. Please allow whatever you feel to BE felt and seen. Let it all come and wash over you. And leave again. You do not have to have any answers now. You do not have to have your plan. You do not owe anyone a call back or explanation. Protect your peace. Dwell in the Silence to hear your answers when you can.
I love you.

Anna Babayan, the school‚Äôs chairlady, shared, ‚ÄúWe are absolutely thrilled about the bears! I can already picture the joy on our babies‚Äô faces‚Äîthey are going to be over the moon. This has been such a difficult time for our SMACS family, and yet, the kindness and support from incredible people like you have truly made all the difference in our healing journey. ‚ÄúPut some ice on it, you‚Äôll feel better‚Äù It‚Äôs what you‚Äôre supposed to do when you get a burn. And Mother Nature did just that. 

I can‚Äôt explain how disorienting it is to see snow on our foothills this morning. To see snow coating our community‚Äôs horrific burn from our guest room window. My mind just can‚Äôt compute.

Incredibly thankful for precipitation and the relief it will bring, but can‚Äôt help but feel angry, too. Angry it didn‚Äôt come earlier and prevent such horrific devastation. Angry we can‚Äôt go home. Angry at the constant emotional whiplash. 

‚ÄúPut some ice on it, you‚Äôll feel better‚Äù. I really hope that starts to come true. #eatonfire #altadena

WE NEED YOU @ ORANGE CITY COUNCIL MEETING, TUESDAY, 1/28/2025, 6PM, 300 E Chapman Ave, Orange, 92866.

Please attend and speak about how you have been affected by any of the wildfires that have ravaged OC and the rest of SoCal over the past decade at the Orange City Council meeting this Tuesday. Wear your No Orange Heights shirt, if you have one.

We know we‚Äôve been hearing the same repetitive reply from our city leaders, that everything is out of their hands and there‚Äôs nothing they can do any longer ‚Ä¶ but that‚Äôs not true! The sad news of the recent wildfires jumping outside of wildlife corridors into neighborhoods, has strengthened our argument that developing anything at all in the Orange Heights open space is a terrible idea. 

The short sighted idea of building homes for a short term tax revenue gain will be met with untimely irony when multi millions (if not billions) are spent to mitigate a wildfire disaster. 

The whole area burned down in 2017 and with Southern Californians weather conditions getting progressively windier and drier every year, it‚Äôs only a matter of time before it happens again ‚Ä¶ and as heartbreaking as it is to see animal homes destroyed - if the development continues - it would be peoples homes, lives, stories, futures, destroyed along with the homes of the animals.

After weeks of devastating fires (#EatonFire, #PalisadesFire, #HughesFire, #SepulvedaFire) Los Angeles FINALLY received rain yesterday. This isn‚Äôt just water; it‚Äôs a symbol of hope, renewal, and the beginning of healing. 

At MY Legacy House, we believe that everything starts at home. Just as rain nourishes the earth, our community can nourish one another through challenges. Together, we can rebuild, restore, and rise.

If you or someone you love has been impacted by the fires, we‚Äôre here for you. üå±Free therapy, mental health support, and resources are available. Let‚Äôs heal, together.

DM US today.
#RainAfterFire #HealingStartsHere #MentalHealthSupport #MYLegacyHouse

PLEASE SHARE REGARDING CLOSURES AND THE DANGER OF CURRENT TRAIL CONDITIONS.

The team had its first post Eaton Fire rescue call on Saturday. 01/25/25

The individual called for help while attempting to hike the Lower Sam Merrill Trail to Echo Mountain. After ascending a short distance from the trailhead, he discovered the trail was no longer there. 

Initial attempts by the hiker to retrace his steps down the mountain had him realize there was no clear path down. At that point, he called for help.

By the time team members arrived, he had been able to scramble down from his position. Team members drove him down to his vehicle, after a brief conversation with an agent from the U.S. Forest Service regarding the closure of the area.

The Eaton Fire not only decimated the town of Altadena, it also destroyed most of the trails in the mountains above. 

With very little vegetation or trees remaining, there is nothing left to hold back the earth. Most trails and roads have been severely damaged or destroyed, making them unsafe for use, by both the public and our team. 

Do not place yourself in unnecessary danger, do not enter the burn area in the mountains above Altadena and obey all posted closures.

i‚Äôve spent the past two weeks covering the fires and the carnage of what happened here in Los Angeles, in Altadena, Pasadena, The Palisades and in  Malibu and our city has a  long way to go before it is whole again. The scope of the destruction is mind blowing even for me - someone who has covered many natural disasters over the years. I hope you don‚Äôt forget about the people quietly suffering here after losing everything they owned in the fires.  LA may not be leading the news  on CNN anymore but I can tell you - it is catastrophic what happened here. I hope journalists from around the country will continue to tell stories about our city and what is happening here. We need you too.  #LA #LosAngeles #California #wildfires #fire #climatechange #altadena #palisades #malibu #pasadena #eatonfire #palisadesfire #palisades #photo by @photospice #barbaradavidson

In the 1950‚Äôs, Racecar driver Ralph DePalma lived down the street from me in Altadena. Driving by his old house always made me smile because it was so unchanged from his day.  In the top photo, Ralph is sunbathing in the bottom left and his wife is getting dressed up for an outing with the Horseless Carriage club. A club they were both very active in. 

  I‚Äôll miss seeing that little house.  Sadly, another small piece of Altadena history that‚Äôs gone forever. 

 I‚Äôve been driving around the neighborhood this week and the devastation is hard to comprehend. It looks like a home graveyard and the standing chimneys are the headstones. ü™¶. 
  And so many vintage cars!. I can‚Äôt even bring myself to photograph them as I don‚Äôt want to remember what I‚Äôm seeing. 
.
 #eatonfire #altadena #altadenastrong #ralphdepalma #indy500

this month has been one of the most devastating times LA has seen, but so many people have come together to support our community.. I‚Äôve had hundreds of conversations & my heart aches for the people who are struggling right now after losing everything.

2 weeks ago - we made a post wanting to provide free therapy to help, and today we‚Äôve connected families in need to hand-picked therapists from our network of 1,000+ licensed providers.

thanks to you, those families have seen our posts & yesterday was the first time we‚Äôve been at an event in LA since the fires started. @riselafest brought so many people together to support LA fire relief. shoutout @musicares 

being back in the world, seeing so many people call someone they love to check in & connecting with people who need help right now means everything.

I love what we do. I love the people we do it with. I love helping wherever we can.

it‚Äôs been a dark month, but we‚Äôre gonna get through this together + @callyourfam is here for you if you need someone to talk to.

I love you. thank you for being here.

- J

Like so many in Los Angeles, I continue to struggle to comprehend the devastation from the #eatonfire and #palisadesfire Both fires have forever changed Southern California and everyone who lives here. Whether you lost your home, job, school, community or are connected to someone who has - we‚Äôre all hurting. It hasn‚Äôt even been three weeks and I‚Äôm inspired by the commitment to rebuild and the strength and desire of those in our city/county to not let this tragedy lead to abandoning the places we love, but rather use that love to write the next chapter. Thank you to everyone who has trusted @abc7la and our reporting through this difficult period and reached out to check on my family and I. Please continue to send your story ideas as our commitment to covering what‚Äôs next couldn‚Äôt be stronger. Here‚Äôs some photos I‚Äôve taken since January 7th and thank you to @variety for highlighting our work #socalstrong #palistrong #altadenastrong #askabc7

A heartfelt thank you to the compassionate friends, talented fashion designers, and amazing strangers who have so generously helped us fire victims rebuild our wardrobes with such style, speed, and thoughtfulness. ‚ù§Ô∏è Your kindness has truly made this journey brighter.

Special thanks to @rossmorestudio for these fabulous sunnies, @dlashes for the chic leopard stole, @sloanbella for my gorgeous new boots, and @debbie.bean for my absolute favorite new trousers. ‚ù§Ô∏èüôå

As a fashion designer, one of the hardest things to accept after losing our home in the fires was realizing how much of my life‚Äôs passion disappeared with it. It wasn‚Äôt just about having clothes to wear‚Äîit was about the beautiful pieces I had been collecting for over 25 years, gone in an instant.

Fashion has always been more than just clothes to me‚Äîit‚Äôs self-expression, it‚Äôs art, it‚Äôs escape. It‚Äôs my story, stitched together through decades of memories.

In the midst of this loss, something extraordinary happened. Friends, strangers, acquaintances‚Äîpeople I never expected‚Äîreached out in the most incredible ways. Invitations to fashion gifting suites. Suitcases filled with designer clothes, shoes, bags, and jewelry showed up at the door. Gift certificates to my favorite stores. Vintage treasures sent with love.

It felt like a whirlwind of kindness and generosity flooded into my life. And through this outpouring of support, I was reminded of the joy fashion brings‚Äîthe thrill of putting on something beautiful, the comfort of feeling like yourself again. These gifts weren‚Äôt just about the clothes; they gave me a sense of normalcy, excitement, and a renewed spirit.

To every person, designer, and company who is helping outfit those of us who escaped these fires, thank you from the bottom of my heart. Your generosity has given us more than just clothes on our backs‚Äîyou‚Äôve given us hope and the courage to dream again‚Ä¶ and most important, a sense of normalcy again ‚ù§Ô∏è

#FromAshesToRunway #FashionIsArt #Gratitude #MovingForward #TheFutureIsBright #OnlyUpFromHere #palisadesfire #eatonfire

UPDATE JANUARY 2025
This is a painting I commissioned of our home called #KitCatCottage. The artist who painted it lives a few doors up from us. She's @lynnenora : Lynne Fearman. She and Ed lost their home in the Eaton fire. And all of her beautiful paintings burned in her studio as well. This painting is so precious to us, all the more so now!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Here's a response I sent to my @TravelStore clients who reached out to me with concern: 
"We evacuated January 7th a Tuesday. Sierra Madre -our village is part of the #EatonFire.
(FYI: this is my 5th fire since 1992 in this house) - we are just yards below the Mt Wilson trail -the national forest.

We arrived home 12th, Sunday -after 6 nights of evacuation. 
We have smoke damage, a scorched hillside back yard; lots of ash inside the house - but grateful that ours is still standing. Evidence shows that embers and hotspots were just a few feet from the house. #AFewFeetAway

Sadly, some of my TravelStore colleagues lost their homes, and many of my high school friends too. Devastating! We've been doing our best to help out.

I'm involved in our "neighbourhood watch" (75 homes) and have been "What's apping" - Kit and I have been busy as liase between our city officials to our neighbours: answering concerns about water, waste and mud cleanup. We're so sad for families in our town and all across LA county who have lost everything. Nerves were frayed again as winds picked up once more, we did not unpack in case of another evacuation.

As a Commissioner for the Sierra Madre Public Library I recommend that one checks their library's website for information. Because on January 7th, we evacuated with NO food, hotel had NO power, no stores were open. Thankfully our library had box lunches, power and wifi available on the 8th. 
~Once home on 1-15-25, we had a FLARE up - had to call 911 and the Elko, Nevada Fire Dept came up to douse a smoky patch behind our house. ( PTSD again)

THANKS to our brave canyon neighbours who saved our homes before responders arrived. THANK YOU first responders from all over the USA and the world for coming to our aid. 

We dodged a bullet! We pledged our support to help those who didn't.‚Äù

Erosion mitigation trail work for the City of Sierra Madre. A group of us worked on the trail to try and limit the mudslide damage that will be caused during the rainy season. We found one area that was still smoldering from the fire.  It‚Äôs going to take a lot of work over the next few months as the dirt was very loose in some areas and there were multiple areas that had some damage despite the work done by crews earlier in the week.  Hopefully, the work will help keep the slides from reaching the residential area below and keep the trails intact. #trailwork #eatonfire
We are open and looking forward to being able to help all of the fire survivors. #palisadesfire #eatonfire #palisadesstrong #californiastrong

Please take care of your mental health! It‚Äôs the only way to get through this. In my story is a link to the app ‚ÄúPTSD Coach‚Äù. It is a great way to track symptoms and progress and identify immediate strategies to use when experiencing trauma related symptoms. This is also a great tool to use when discussing your mental health needs with a professional.

We will all get through this, but it will be hard and exhausting.

Today we drove up for the first time to where our apartment once stood. To say I was completely devastated to see it in person would be a total and complete understatement. My heart feels heavy and the usual calming quiet of our beloved town, has now taken a much more somber and disheartening turn. Our city that my son grew up in, the streets we would drive on every day, are 90% destroyed and totally unrecognizable. Altadena, sadly, is gone. It‚Äôs going to take many years for things to go back to how they were. Unfortunately, my family and I will not be moving back to Altadena. There is nothing left there for us. We will be using the GoFundMe money to relocate somewhere else. We want to personally thank everyone again for your continued support. Thank you to those who still reach out and ask how we‚Äôre doing and to those who keep on sharing and reposting our story, I am forever thankful to you all. To my beautiful Altadena community, you will forever hold a special place in our hearts. 

#eatonfire #altadena #eatoncanyon #pasadena #california #californiafires #losangeles #lacounty

Another round of beautiful homes. 

Each one was the most important to someone out there tonight. 

I can tell by the potted plants, the porch chairs, manicured lawns, hanging lights and bells. Things we all have to give us a sense of calm at the end of a long day. 

I care about these details the most as it really makes it feel lived in.

DAY SHELTER INFO FOR JANUARY 27

üïô Our hours are 2pm-5pm at Pasadena Foursquare Church, 174 Harkness Avenue, Pasadena 91106. All are welcome!

üì± We have free Wi-Fi and a place to charge your devices. Feel free to come by for a few minutes or to stay all day.

üö® This week, we will shifting elements of our day shelter to provide a more long-term sustainable response to and care for the needs in our community. Stay tuned for updated hours and location on our campus.

üì¶ We have an updated donation list! We are ONLY accepting the following items: duffle bags + small suitcases, laundry detergent, air purifiers, *new* pillows, *new* pacifiers, and toiletry items. I made the decision to return to work today but decided to stop by Terrace before I made the drive up. While home, I had been trying (and failing more often than not) to keep it together for my family, and needed a private moment to grieve. Grieve the loving home where I learned to walk, how to catch, how to tie a water balloon, how to cook shrimp fried rice, how to download songs from LimeWire, where I met my sister, and where I learned that laughter is the only sound my parents won‚Äôt be upset at being awoken by. 

And amongst all the charred devastation, I saw little sprouts of grass that weren‚Äôt there last week. New growth after the rain. A symbol of hope and proof that we can rebuild and move forward. I‚Äôm thankful to still have my family so we can make more memories, share more laughs, and keep getting on each other‚Äôs nerves. #eatonfire #beautifulaltadena

Our Day Shelter is closed, but our Resource Center will now be open 9am-3:30pm Tuesday - Thursday. Last week we saw a huge decrease in people coming into the church for a day shelter, but we saw an uptick in non-profits coming to the church that needed resources. So, we are now a resource distribution center to help other non-profits with supplies. Please fill out a ‚Äòrelief contact form‚Äô on our website or reach out to the church office to get assistance. We have already helped 16 other non-profits!! We are still collecting these donations: hygiene products, non-perishable food and kids toys. You can drop those off at the church. We still need volunteers to help us sort and organize resources for distribution Tuesday - Thursday 9am-3:30pm. Thank for being a part of our fire relief efforts here at Vintage Faith + Love the City Center. Let‚Äôs love our city together!! #update #firerelief #disasterrelief #palisadesfire #eatonfire #resourcecenter #lovethecitycenter #lovethecity

Support for Those Affected by the Wildfire ‚Äì Community Relief Distribution

The recent wildfires have brought significant challenges, and we want you to know that you are not alone. To support those affected, @abilityfirstla, in partnership with the @ymcala, is hosting a Community Relief Distribution event, offering essential supplies to help during this difficult time.

üìç Location: AbilityFirst, 789 N. Fair Oaks Ave., Pasadena, CA 91103

üóì Dates: Wednesday, January 29 & Thursday, January 30

‚è∞ Times: 8:30 a.m. ‚Äì 11:30 a.m. & 3 p.m. ‚Äì 6 p.m.

üöó Drive-up and walk-ins welcome

Items available for distribution include:
‚úî Water
‚úî Care packages with non-perishable foods
‚úî Household essentials
 
Please feel free to stop by and pick up any items you may need. Our goal is to provide some relief and reassurance as you navigate recovery. If you have any questions, do not hesitate to reach out to Lana Mseryan, director of development, at info@abilityfirst.org.

Altadena burned and took our home of 17 years and almost all our belongings with it. These pictures are from the day we returned to look at the destruction. The final picture was the day in 2008 we received our keys. We were so young then.

Over the years, we have had so many dinners and gatherings and we have had family living with us at times. We loved our neighbors and the kids and the dogs and the park and the hiking and the parts, peacocks, bears, deer, possum, squirrels, coyotes. We will miss it. And though we remain hopeful, for now, we grieve.

1/17 - I was out running an errand, and as I was pulling up to a traffic light, I had seen this group of Firefighters hopping out of their truck, holding their laundry bags on the way to do some laundry.. As I always say to do, I pulled down my window and Thanked them for their service..
The immediately waved with smiles and thanked me and I could genuinely feel the great sense of appreciation they had for me saying that. 
I ended up pulling over to chat with them, and found out they had all come down from Oregon to help with the fires. They dropped everything back home, their day to day, their families, all to come down here and help with this chaos. They had been here a week, and were here for at least another week.
As usual, nothing but kind and gentle souls and good humans. These are the faces of true heroes.. 
I felt truly grateful to be able to look each one of them in the eyes and shake their hands thanking them. 
And by the end, their deep gratitude and appreciation had made me a bit emotional as I really wasn‚Äôt the one who had done anything, and they were the ones that were doing Everything. 

God Bless each and every one of you üá∫üá∏üë©‚Äçüöíüë®‚Äçüöíü´°‚ù§Ô∏è

P.S. I have not & will not forget, I owe you some gifts ü§ùüôÇ

PDA has made several visits recently to the impressive new Disaster Recovery Center now open in the former Westside Pavilion Mall building at Pico and Westwood Blvds here near our office.
The center is staffed by a wide range of federal, state, and local officials, all of whom are able to provide general guidance and specific information about the recovery and rebuilding processes. We have found short lines (or no lines) and very helpful representatives of the various agencies.
Overall, the facility is a welcome and much-needed resource for us and our clients and neighbors who now need help. Please let us know if you have specific questions for us or any of the agencies involved. We would be happy to get back to you. Policies and practices are obviously still taking shape, but the overall picture (how everything will work in the various jurisdictions) seems to be clearing.  We have also been in touch with staff members who are receptive to email follow-ups and other continuing communication, especially for Malibu projects. Good luck out there! We find it heartening that the authorities are so focused and available.

It‚Äôs impossible to have not been impacted by the fires in LA County in some way if you‚Äôre a resident of SoCal. We were very close to the Eaton Fire just 8-10 blocks south of evacuation warning zones that remained in place for 1.5 weeks during the peak of the fire. We lost power and wifi for several days, and had our vehicles packed for a possible evacuation order until the second wind event finally subsided and we felt like we could breathe a little. It was very hard during that stressful time to function with ‚Äúbusiness as usual‚Äù attitudes for Max, who of course couldn‚Äôt comprehend what was going on at 2.5 y/o. @zooghq kept Max entertained, and the company is giving back to victims of the LA County fires! üôåüèª For anyone affected by the fires who is interested in receiving the app for free for a year, please email: support@getzoog.com! Everyone who doesn‚Äôt live here thinks LA is full of ‚Äúfake‚Äù people, but the way we‚Äôve seen the community come together after these fires could not paint more of an opposite picture about our city. ‚ù§Ô∏è #Zoog #LAFires #EatonFire #PacificPalisadesFire #LA #LosAngeles #LAStrong #YumsOfDisney

Old photos of one of the places most affected by the fires in Los Angeles: Eaton Canyon. This has been one of my favorite hikes in the LA area for many years, but it's gone now. Consumed by fire, along with the homes of many, many people.

Adam and I honestly don't know what to say. This is our city. Our home. We are okay, but a lot of people are not. We are grateful to the firefighters who have kept us safe and that they fought so hard to keep the fires from spreading into our area. And no matter what, we are grateful that we get to call Los Angeles home.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Did they fail to meet safety standards?

Hour fifteen of the Eaton Fire ‚Äì the morning after the fire began.

Standing in the center of the catastrophe, it felt like being in a movie ‚Äì unreal, like a real-life nightmare. I was standing in the middle of N Lake Ave and the city was leveled, with only some bare bones of buildings, single-standing chimneys, everything scorched black and gray. Multiple fires were blazing on both sides of the street, there were people everywhere, firefighters and trucks all around and yet not enough to cover the amount of flames littered across the town.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

The night of the fire we lost all power and our house gradually filled with smoke. Even though we were in the evacuation warning zone, the smoke was so thick that there was no sleep or rest that night. To be safe, I packed a bag with all my treasures and what I‚Äôd practically need. I looked at that one suitcase and saw how strangely my life fit into that bag and how easily I was able to say goodbye to everything else I owned.

My family and I, the house we live in ended up being safe, but incoming texts and calls would notify us one by one who just lost their house and which significant buildings were burnt down. Anxiety and worry and gloom accompanied the smoke in the air, and that was all only the first 24hrs.

#eatonfire #altadena #lafires #firerescue #pasadena #canonphotography

Visited the ruin for the first time and got some much needed closure. We also were interviewed by CBS for a piece on Altadena musicians, airing this Thursday morning before the Fire Aid concert. These have been the most bizarre times we‚Äôve ever lived through. A few highs and many lows. No other way to move but forward. Though the ruins of the city were devastating, the soul of the town is still there somehow. Something about standing on the ground there still feels right, even among the destruction. Altadena will be back ‚ù§Ô∏è #eatonfire #altadena üì∏: @rebeccacastagna

üè†Temporary Housing: Rental assistance or reimbursement for hotel costs while your home is unlivable.

Motivation usually comes from within,
but sometimes seeing others do things that inspire you is the vitamin that will nourish your own efforts. 
This last week was all about continuing to support our community to recover and partnering with SoCal Gas to feed volunteers at The YMCA Foothill, who were running both a huge donation center and a beautiful space providing affected families a safe heaven for children to play while parents could either work or gather their goods. 
We feel very grateful to have been part of it, and of course, Arepas were filling tummies and hearts. People for a moment took the conversation towards food and culture and that also helped us heal. 
They loved this Avocado, Eggs & Cheese Arepa and we wanted to give you a little extra push to try it with 15% OFF until this Friday 31st. 
My hope for you this week is that you can also find something that fuels your purpose and inspires you. Oh! Also I wanna share a little background on how this happened‚Ä¶
It all started with a wonderful partnership that the Latino Restaurant Association and SoCal Gas did back in 2020 during the COVID pandemic to help bring joy to first responders by providing food to the fierce nurses and volunteers at Huntington Hospital among other places, and at the same time bringing business to small Latino restaurants like ours that were struggling and connecting us through food. 

That‚Äôs when I met Trisha Muse (pictured with me this last week) and Lilly Rocha who now during the fires have reactivated their team called Food Hug and called us to be part of it. How wonderful it is to continue being together during difficulties, can‚Äôt think of a better way to serve others. Abrazos

Count your blessings, they say.

Not bad advice, but when my mood has no room for gratitude,  I do something no one recommends.

I count my hardships.

Which sounds counter-intuitive, but hear me out, because while there's great power in gratitude, we're emotional beings and there will always be times where we won't feel like being positive. . .

. . .and counting hardships is way to harness that negative energy in a constructive way.

This photo was taken this past weekend at the site of our burned down house.

It's a cherry tomato plant from the garden my wife and I planted during the pandemic -- a multi-year hardship.

There's a certain comfort that can be gained in reflecting on previous hard times that were weathered. It's a reminder that we have depths of personal strength and the aid of community to face unimaginable tragedies and come out on the other side feeling whole and loved.

So yes, there are other photos I'll share of the ruin of our home, but I felt it important that the first area of focus be of something that survived that horrible night.

Something that will always hold a place in my heart because when my wife and I planted that garden, it was part of our defense against the virus -- taking better care of our bodies to naturally build up our health.

It was also a bonding experience that strengthened our marriage in ways we couldn't have imagined.

And let's not lose sight that it's a sneaky path towards finding light when the dark makes all the best advice sound like silly platitudes meant for feeble-minded children.

So the next time someone tells you to count your blessings and you have to restrain yourself from telling them where they can put their advice, consider counting your hardships and remember that you've survived them all, even the ones that scared the hell out of you and left you feeling weak and alone.

#eatonfire #AnthrotonikAlchemy #mindsetmatters #mindsetmagic #altadenastrong #altadena

On January 10th, the @nationalguard was deployed to the perimeter of the #eatonfire to assist the Los Angeles Police Department (@lapdhq) in preventing looting in the affected areas. In a highly controlled environment, residents were barred from re-entering their neighborhoods, creating tense scenes at military checkpoints. Evacuees, who had already left their homes, pleaded for permission to return in order to safeguard their properties. Meanwhile, those who remained within the evacuation zone faced the difficult dilemma of relying on family and friends to bring them essential supplies like food and medicine. Leaving the area, however, meant they would not be allowed to return without an LAPD escort, forcing them to choose between basic necessities and protecting their homes.

#losangeles #altadena #lafd #wildfirephotography

The first two photos are c. 1975 at the house where I was born, 2260 N. Maiden Lane.  The last picture is the same house on Jan. 9, 2025.

Along with my preschool, Children's Country House on Santa Rosa, and countless restaurants and businesses of my childhood,  including @foxsaltadena, were left as piles if rubble after the #EatonFire swept through the foothills. We moved in 1977, but a piece of my heart will always be in Altadena.

I want to pontificate about rebuilding and overcoming,  but grief and loss cloud that right now.

#AltadenaStrong
#Recovery
#AltadenaMemories

This is Dahlia, Adrian, and Ava on the porch of the Crick Family home in Altadena. The girls were making sunflower bouquets for the senior class so they would have something to hold when they walked for graduation from Sequoyah. It was the first time we visited the Cricks at their new home. We bought our houses around the same time, and Windy and I shared kitchen remodel ideas and butter bean recipes, and Ian showed Ben around the backyard. The porch was new; it was in the front. Windy and I talked about a historic Black graveyard in Altadena, where abolitionists, anti-slavery activists, and civil rights leaders are buried. Octavia‚Äôs final resting place is in Altadena.

The Cricks evacuated in the early hours of January 8. West of Lake Avenue, they didn‚Äôt get any official evacuation instructions but instead got a notification from Watch Duty, which Windy downloaded the night before, like most of us. We could see the Eaton Fire from our driveway, so we also left at dawn when the Palisade Fire and Eaton Fire were both 0 percent contained. 

Dahlia told me the next day that the Cricks‚Äô house was gone. 

Windy calls the site of their former home ‚ÄúThe Stoop,‚Äù because she‚Äôs real and matter-of-fact, and she still has humor. The reason why she‚Äôs calling it ‚ÄúThe Stoop,‚Äù is because the cement steps are all that is left. She told me that she bought a colander ‚Äî a colander! ‚Äî because that‚Äôs how much is gone, and she‚Äôll need a sieve to salvage the precious from what is charred. 

When we asked what we could do to help, friends told us to share their GoFundMe. **LINK IN BIO and in comments below** I have had some real success in utilizing this platform to help change loved ones‚Äô lives, and I am kindly asking my friends and family to please help in small and large ways ‚Äî in whatever amount feels feasible, whether it is $5 or $500 ‚Äî because I have witnessed the gamechanger that crowdfunding can be. You can‚Äôt imagine the things that need to be bought ‚Äî everything, literally everything ‚Äî from hazmat suits to new clothes to dish towels and furniture and all of the things that make up a home for a family of four and a dog.

#MUTUALAID #FAMILYFIRST #EATONFIRE #ALTADENA #gofundme

200 degrees. That‚Äôs where I was happiest‚Äîsandwiched between my workout and my cold plunge, sitting in the sauna where I got my best ideas. It was my sanctuary, my place of peace, within a home that‚Äôs now ashes. Somehow, the sauna was one of the only things that didn‚Äôt completely disintegrate in the fire. Here are the last remains, built to withstand over 250 degrees.

This month has been a world on fire for me. The day before the fires, I took my last sauna in my happy place. 200 degrees. That night, I discovered a devastating betrayal from someone I deeply cared about‚Äîan anger and heartbreak so intense it kept me awake all night.

The next morning, running on no sleep, I looked out my window, still adrenalized from the night before, and saw smoke rising over the hill. My world was literally on fire. A friend from Florida called, and through a mix of tears and laughter, I said, ‚ÄúMy entire world is literally burning down right now.‚Äù

The first 48 hours were some of the hardest of my life. The first wave of grief hit during that time, accepting an unforgivable level of betrayal and having to flee my house running on 24 hours without sleep. The second wave came when the fireman texted me photos of The Day House reduced to ashes.

Rage consumed me in those early hours, followed by hours of tears that felt like they could extinguish the flames. Tears for my home, for the life I‚Äôd built, for the betrayal I‚Äôd faced. But then, something shifted. After grieving so many losses at once, I began to look forward.

To everyone grieving the loss of their home, their sanctuary, or their world as they knew it: allow yourself to feel it all-the anger, the fire, the rage, the sadness, the emptiness‚Äîlet it out. The harder you release it, the sooner it‚Äôs over. Tears ran down my face for 5 hours, and then I was done. 

It became time to accept the present and start looking forward. To dream of new beginnings, new people, new places, and new joys. Sometimes, life has to burn everything down to clear the way for something radically new. It‚Äôs a chance to grow, to meet new faces, to see the world, and to build a new life‚Äîand the home‚Äîof your dreams.

#palisadesfire #eatonfire

We're only barely in The New World.

(Part of the #AnthrotonikArcs series where we use the power of storytelling to aid us in our quest to reimagine what our lives can become after the wildfires.)

What I mean by this, is that the Inciting Incident of the #eatonfire and the #pacificpalisadesfire has only just happened.

At this point of the story, we've been thrust into a brand new world and because this level of existence is uncharted for us, we're going to:

1. Make mistakes
2. Miss cues
3. Try and bend this new world into the shape of the old world we're used to and we will fail at that.

But here's some things that can help you navigate this new path we've been set upon.

First, understand that you've entered this world with certain bits of information driving your approach to the problems you face.

The first type of information is insidious because it's a lie that previous traumas in your life has taught you about your capabilities and your place in the world.

In my case, I was immediately faced with one of my greatest fears, which is homelessness. Being abandoned around the age of five to live alone with a physically and emotionally violent father while my older brother and younger sister were taken by mother, was a brutal lesson in itself, but when I pleaded for my mom to bring me too and she said there wasn't room for me, had left me believing if I ever did become homeless, I would surely wind up in the streets.

But this was a lie taught to me by that trauma that I may have understood logically to be false, BUT WASN'T ABLE TO ACCEPT EMOTIONALLY as not being true. 

Read that again because it's important.

Now, my experience has proved this to be a lie, and I'm leveraging my emotional response to my stepmother immediately taking my wife and in to help me internalize that this core belief is false.

You too have a lie that's working against you from previous hardships that are giving you a fundamental limiting belief.

The problem is identifying it, but once you do, you can intentionally use this with the next bit of information I'll share in a future post to serve as a proverbial North Star to aid you in decision making.

#mindsetmatters

Chris and Heidi have a very long road ahead of them, and I (Elisabeth) am just trying to strike while the iron's hot, so to speak. Thank you to everyone‚Äôs help so far! 

I'm reaching out on behalf of my amazing brother, Christopher Higgins, and his wife, Heidi. On January 8th, their home was tragically lost in the Eaton Fire in Pasadena.

In the early hours of that morning, Chris and Heidi evacuated with just the clothes on their backs, a duvet, and their cars. Later, they watched their home burn live on the news. It‚Äôs a devastating loss, especially as their neighbourhood was never considered fire-prone, and they hadn‚Äôt prepared a ‚ÄúGo Bag.‚Äù

Chris and Heidi have been a part of the Pasadena/Altadena community for 13 years. They‚Äôve lost their home and many meaningful possessions‚Äîirreplaceable photographs, Chris‚Äôs lifelong music collection, and much more. They‚Äôre currently staying with our parents and are safe, but rebuilding their lives will be a long road.

They are also working with their mortgage lender, FEMA, and their insurance company, which is quite overwhelming on top of everything else.

Both Chris and Heidi work for Jacob Maarse Florist, Chris as a delivery driver and Heidi as a designer. They live simply and humbly, but the immediate expenses‚Äîclothing, food, and securing housing‚Äîare overwhelming.

If you‚Äôre able to help, any donation‚Äîbig or small‚Äîwill go directly toward supporting their recovery. Together, we can help them move forward and rebuild the life they‚Äôve lovingly created.

Thank you so much for your kindness and support.

With love and gratitude,

I visited my home for the first time since the fire, and mourned the loss of my 1972 Volvo 1800ES in my burned down garage. My wife held me as I cried for it and so much else that was lost.

The burning roof of the garage collapsed onto the car, crushing it from above. Then all that material burned away leaving the damaged shell of my beloved classic. The metal garage door lay across its hood covering its face like a funeral veil. 

The ‚ÄúSun Wagon‚Äù, as I called the Volvo, brought me so much joy with its yellow, bright disposition, and smiling grille that caused everyone to smile back at it. But the real happiness it gave was from the driver‚Äôs seat, shifting its mechanical gears and steering the large wheel with the view of the long hood guiding the ride. 

And now it‚Äôs gone.

I nearly lost everything 3 weeks ago. My entire collection of oil paintings along with all the art I've personally collected through out my life. For some 30 hours I had no choice but to accept everything was gone. There was no reason to believe that I would be spared when 98% of my town was not. None of it felt real until my neighbor sent me a picture of my studio engulfed in flames. I evacuated the night before with just my dog and the clothes I was wearing, my computer and my journals. The second image in the slide is what my town looked like when I drove away, palm trees bending in 100mph winds, fallen trees and debris all over the streets and a massive red orb glowing behind me. I passed by all my neighbors who were packing up their cars, all those homes now gone. It was the most apocalyptic night of my life. There is an undeniable clarity that comes through when running for your life, a line in the sand separating what matters from all the things that weigh us down day to day that don't really matter so much. In the chaos of it all, I knew that if there was any chance of returning, and if my tiny wooden matchbox of a house survived, I would first rescue this painting- "Saint Alok" 24k gold and oil on panel- a piece that took nearly 2 years to complete and won top 50 in an international art prize a couple years ago, a piece I invested the last of my savings into the custom frame, even as I went completely broke and lost my art business- I still poured everything I had left into this masterpiece. And yet, for those days I had no choice but to surrender, even hope, which can be such a heartbreaking feeling. So I did, I let go. 
By some miracle, my paintings survived one of the worst climate disasters in California history. It's been a bit burdensome figuring out how to keep these pieces safe while I'm navigating houselessness for the second time in a year, it's also a great gift from the universe, one that I plan to do something meaningful with. Whatever the future has in store, I'm remaining open and humbled and grateful for each person who has helped me during this unfathomable time. Let it all be for our highest liberation ü™î

The reason we‚Äôve seen so many chimneys survive is, of course, because they are made of bricks. So if they‚Äôre so fire resistant, why not build with bricks in CA, you might wonder? Earthquakes. Brick buildings are considered unreinforced masonry, which means they lack a skeleton and are held together by mortar, making them vulnerable to seismic activity. During an earthquake, mortar breaks down, causing the bricks to fall out and the roof to collapse. Before the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, most buildings were brick and most of them were destroyed. CA restricted building with bricks in the 1930‚Äôs following the 1933 Long Beach earthquake. Los Angeles was one of the first cities in CA to require retrofitting of any unreinforced brick buildings.

At first glance they look like concrete, but if you zoom in, you‚Äôll notice that the standing walls of this house are made of bricks. 

#TheMoreYouKnow #LosAngeles #CA #LA #LAFires #Eaton #Pasadena

@nytimes was in Altadena and a reporter asked for my opinion when the President came to Los Angeles last week to survey the fire damage at Palisades but didn‚Äôt come to Altadena. 

I‚Äôve been disappointed many times as a citizen of this country by both political parties. Having seen many disasters from afar, that to politicians, these calamities are just an opportunity for them to push their agendas. I don‚Äôt rely on them to fix my or my communities‚Äô problems but I do expect my local government to do their jobs as their decisions will shape what my beloved Altadena will look like in a year, 2 or 6 years. I don‚Äôt really want to even talk about politics because that‚Äôs the least of my concerns as a person who has to deal with this disaster. 

Between insurance claims, the devastations of loss and the aftermath, we are too busy as a community to simply get by and we don‚Äôt have room for hyperboles or debates. 

I wanted to give you all an update as to where we are today. It‚Äôs been over three weeks, and we still can‚Äôt find a semi permanent place to stay. Our insurance company has given us $0 for all the living expenses we‚Äôve incurred since and we‚Äôve stayed at hotels, friend‚Äôs couches and airbnb, having to load up our cars every week, uncertain of where we are going to stay next. We are grateful that our walls are still standing, but they are unlivable spaces covered in toxic smoke and ash. The smell is like burnt cigarettes and melted plastic. It gives me a headache going back even with a mask. 

I applied for 1 art grant yesterday through @cci_arts - ü§ûI‚Äôm hoping to try and find more as I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôd be able to salvage from these damages. I am so worried that being without a studio will set me back so much. But I am also hopeful that once we find a place I can park for a bit and actually start to create again.

üåü Proud to be Part of a Team üåü

I am incredibly proud to be part of Berkshire Hathaway Home Services, a team that has shown unwavering commitment and compassion in supporting the victims of the California Wildfires. Our collective efforts have made a meaningful impact in the lives of those affected by these devastating events. Together, we are not just real estate professionals; we are a community dedicated to helping our neighbors rebuild and recover.

Let‚Äôs continue to stand together and support each other during these challenging times. Every little bit helps, and I encourage everyone to contribute in any way they can. üí™‚ù§Ô∏è

Now that the fires chilled out and everyone outside of LA is done having an opinion on the fires I took time out to see what was happening on the ground..

and what I caught was depressing. 

There was a big spotlight on the Palisades fire but Altadena was a place I could nearly call home. In my high school days me and the old crew would sneak into the ‚ÄúEnchanted Forest‚Äù in the middle of the night to look for ghosts and Satan worshippers lol. too bad we didn‚Äôt find any but it was still a place I would  take hikes up to Echo Mountain.. and now its all gone.

What‚Äôs left of Altadena looks like a warzone.. and it still smells like one. Even if your house held up you‚Äôre still living in an area thats pretty much uninhabitable for years.

I find it weird how you can drive 15 min from Altadena and the world moves like nothing‚Äôs happened. Everyone‚Äôs on the next ‚Äúthing‚Äù while there‚Äôs people out here still picking up the pieces. The amount of virtue signaling around the fires has been insane. You have people outside of LA calling out people who live in LA for being silent about the fires in LAüòÇ

Like bruh. Most of us (myself and fam included) were packing our shit and getting ready to move in case we got the evac warning. If the winds picked up any longer that Wednesday night my fam‚Äôs home would‚Äôve went up in smoke too. 

If there‚Äôs anything that hasn‚Äôt changed through all that‚Äôs happened in Altadena its I still get stopped by the cops tho üëÆ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü´°üòÇ

TLDR: yea the world‚Äôs going to keep moving, but there‚Äôs still going to be people unpacking their shit. Not everyone moves on the same timeline. üåéüëÅÔ∏è

Palisades fire, January 2025

Three weeks ago, the Palisades fire started and tore through entire communities here in West Los Angeles. I had never seen anything like this in my entire life. Nor had most people here in SoCal. Unfortunately, this was the perfect storm. It has been the driest winter on record since 1964, and this particular Santa Ana wind event was the strongest since 1997. 

Everyone on the Internet has someone to blame for this tragedy, and while I agree, people need to be held accountable, once this fire started at 11 AM on Tuesday there was no amount of water that could have stopped it.

Thank you to the firefighters, first responders, and people of LA who have stepped up when its mattered most. You are our heroes üôå

As a naturalist I often encourage people to zoom in on nature because that's what really gets people hooked... so let's do it now! You can see that even right after the Eaton Fire, some trees and shrubs in the park still have a little bit of green. This tells us that though the fire was very hot, it did move through relatively quickly, which is great news for the oaks and sycamores. Oaks are also fairly resistant to fire thanks to their thick bark!

Today is three weeks since the fires in Los Angeles started and Sunday‚Äôs rain was a blessing upon the city of angels, my birthplace. I continue to pray for more precipitation to come quench the seared seeds holding memories of relations to LA‚Äôs cherished places in ashes. May the pollinators retrace their ways when the seedlings become blooms this spring and the lands get a chance to sing songs of what was so nothing is forgotten.

Look at Lahaina as an example of island tribes coming together as one lƒÅhui (nation) in a similar disaster. Through cross-pollination and benevolent intention, regeneration is gradual yet absolutely possible as a tight-knit species within sustainable subcultures.

In support of LA‚Äôs beekeeping community, I have been in touch with my friend @kasia.and.bees. Three days prior to the fires, she was in her La Crescenta apiary with a new student that lost everything. Ife Sangode-Olaitan (Pasadena native and holistic mental health therapist) and her daughter were living in a home built by her grandparents over 40 years ago until the Eaton Fire took it. To assist in fundraising efforts, Kasia and I are collaborating during these last days of Virtual Beelieve University‚Äôs open application window...

Apply for Cohort 5 of ‚ÄúIntro to Ethical Beekeeping‚Äù until 2/5/25 and $100 of your tuition will be donated to Ife and her daughter once you get accepted into the course. As a Cohort 5 student in the Los Angeles area, you will have the opportunity to purchase a nucleus colony of honey bees from Kasia when you receive a letter of acceptance from VBU. 

Link to apply to Cohort 5 of Virtual Beelieve University‚Äôs ‚ÄúIntro to Ethical Beekeeping‚Äù course is in bio!

Add code: KASIABEES to your application if you were led to this post because of @kasia.and.bees

Link to Ife‚Äôs story and gofundme:¬†https://gofund.me/a65e4db5

pasadena after the fire...

i've biked through #pasadena and #altadena a number of times, either on group rides or solo errand runs like today, but this is the first time i've been here since the #eatonfire. i wondered if i'd be able to catch a glimpse of the burn area from the @metrolosangeles lake station (i couldn't). i considered venturing farther north, but it seemed too early; i'm still processing what happened to the neighborhoods where friends once lived üò≠üò≠

i was in pasadena to buy gift cards and ended up buying small things for myself, too. retail therapy has a way of calming the mind. at least it worked for me this time.

- the original @traderjoes on arroyo parkway. despite having biked by it many times, i can't believe this was the first time i'd ever stepped foot inside!

- @tenthousandvillages on lake, a shop featuring #fairtrade products from around the world. their business has dropped since the fires, mainly because many of their clientele lived up the street üôÅ happily, i found a pair of #bicycle earrings that needed to be mine! üíôüö≤

January 10th: #altadena is left in ruins after the #EatonFire tore through the town, destroying homes and businesses. Thousands of residents were forced to evacuate, many losing everything but the clothes on their backs. On the ground, survivors moved through the wreckage in shock, unable to fully grasp the devastation. ‚ÄúIt hasn‚Äôt hit me yet. This feels like a dream,‚Äù one said, echoing the numb disbelief felt by many as they confronted the aftermath of the disaster.

This is the first night @pioerikscott and many other LAFD firefighters‚Äô have been off the fire lines in 21 DAYS, and they spent it at a benefit concert for wildfire survivors in Augora Hills. He called the event a ‚Äúbeautiful example of human helping human‚Äù and it truly was‚Ä¶thanks to @get2gethernow, dozens of LA-based musicians who donated their time and talent, and our ever-supportive community.

Our firefighters are true heros‚Ä¶please continue to thank any you meet. I‚Äôve worked with Erik for years and I‚Äôve never seen him out of uniform before tonight‚Ä¶it was so nice to see he and his colleagues enjoying some much-needed downtime. Thank you for all you have done and please get some well-deserved rest! üôå

Posting here brings me joy and I‚Äôm trying to get back to it a little as we bounce from air bnb to air bnb waiting to be able to go back to our house after the fires. It‚Äôs going to get restored. But I do wonder how life will be different now. So much change. And the toxins now in the air and environment surrounding us concern me. My youngest two kiddos finally start school again tomorrow. Their schools found new locations. It‚Äôs all one day at a time for now. 

I‚Äôm pondering the alchemy of the luster glaze process a lot right now and calling on it to bring its magic into my life.

This in-between is strange, isn‚Äôt it? One foot in the past, aching for what‚Äôs gone. The other moving forward, not because we‚Äôre ready, but because life insists.

The roads we once knew are closed, yet we still find our way. The walls that held our history are gone, yet we are still here.

Grief and resilience aren‚Äôt opposites‚Äîthey are intertwined. We grieve because we love. We rebuild because we must. And in this unfamiliar landscape, we are learning that home was never just a place‚Äîit was the people, the moments, the invisible threads that still hold us together.

This is the griefscape. The space between what was and what will be. And though we are forever changed, we are not lost.

We carry it all. And we go on.

-Dr. Z

A recent class assignment by my eight year old ‚ù§Ô∏è we are okay, but countless people are not. My heart breaks for those who have endured such a harrowing ordeal and have experienced so much loss.

The past few weeks have presented a barrage of information for both those affected and those wanting to help. I wanted to share two local resources in the Foothills in the hopes that they might be helpful to someone needing assistance, or provide a place for people wanting to get involved and help.

‚Ä¢ @maeveofthefoothills - I am a proud member of this group of moms, who have been working to directly help people impacted by the Eaton and Palisades wildfires. Our chapter has put together an ever growing list of resources. We are also working on something special this spring to raise funds for wildfire relief efforts ü§ç

‚Ä¢ @neighborsofaltadena - a community of volunteers with many varying skill sets on standby to help every Saturday from 12-4pm in La Canada Flintridge, the city directly west of Altadena. Walk in and receive immediate support, a place to recharge and childcare is provided.

Both groups‚Äô sites are linked in my bio ‚ù§Ô∏è

üö® Price Gouging in LA After the Fires üö®

Following the recent Palisades and Eaton fires, some landlords and businesses are illegally raising prices on rentals, hotels, and essentials‚Äîthis is called price gouging.

üî• What‚Äôs Happening?
With many displaced, demand for housing has surged, leading to rent hikes and inflated hotel rates.

‚öñÔ∏è Is This Legal?
No! In California, raising prices over 10% after a state of emergency is illegal and punishable by fines or criminal charges.

üí° Know Your Rights
If you spot price gouging, report it to the CA Attorney General or local authorities. No one should profit from a crisis.

It's Wednesday and I am providing you with a combo of a What The Heck and a Wowza. However, I just want to rip the Band-Aid off right away and say that this is, heartbreakingly, one of my many favorite Altadena homes which was probably lost in the recent fire.

I normally save it for Valentine's Day, but I felt compelled to present it sooner. And this fits in perfectly with what I do on Wednesdays, posting unusual, artistic, wacky and weird homes or just utterly spectacular places. This counts as both. 

I would see the owner of this wonderful art project out there, working hard to keep the garden perfect. Imagine how many hours it took for him to decorate the house like this, and he would switch it up a bit for each holiday. 

I know I've said this before, but I'm going to say it again, this one hits very very hard. 

If anyone knows anything about this home or the owner, please connect me. I would like to express my condolences and see if there's anything I can do to help, and perhaps he would like these photos.

I'm not posting as frequently at the moment because I've come down with one of the many crazy viruses hitting our city. Please forgive me‚Ä¶

While I'm in bed, I'm going through all of my Altadena photos, trying to determine which houses are there and which are not. 

We have lost some historic landmarks, like the Zane Grey Estate and McNally Mansion, but just as important are the residential architecture losses, homes that may not have landmark status but that were still meaningful, homes that people took a lot of pride in, homes that people put a lot of effort into. And that's mainly what this feed is about, so I want to honor as many as I can.

Again, any additional 2025 calendar sales will go towards relief efforts, Link in bio.  And I have a lot of resources so if you or your friends need something, please let me know. 

Finally, I am gathering stories from homeowners, planning on photographing them either with or without the remainder of their homes, or providing them with the photos I have of their lost houses. Please keep that in mind, any connections would be greatly appreciated. 

#eatonfire #whattheheckwednesday #wowza #altadena

The Eaton Fire that hit our community this year was truly devastating. Living near the evacuation zone, I witnessed firsthand the terrifying power of nature, as flames were visible from my driveway. For days, we lived in uncertainty, bombarded by constant alerts, and endured a four-day power outage.

 It was a rollercoaster of emotions! I was afraid when I saw the flames and anxious about whether the fire could be controlled. but when I saw the community come together, donating and supporting each other, it was incredibly moving.

I‚Äòve been volunteering for over a year now, and let me tell you, there‚Äôs nothing quite like seeing someone get the help they need. Now, it‚Äòs my turn to give back in my own way.

To every firefighter, every police officer, every first responder who stood between our community and destruction, this is for you all.

‚ù£Ô∏è50% off tattoos for all of the heroes‚ù£Ô∏èThis deal‚Äôs good for all of 2025, with no limit on visits, no rush. 

Whenever you‚Äòre ready, just hit me up and send your ideas to madderlaratattoo@gmail.com
