##eatonfire #wildfirerelief #firstresponderappreciation #tattooforheroes #firefightersupport #policesupport #communitystrong #givingback #latattooartist #supportfirstresponders #californiawildfires #inkforbravery #appreciation #firefighter #firefighterlife #Pasadena #altadena
Our very own Carrie Kowalksi, PA-C was quoted in an LAist article about how the wildfires have affected people experiencing homelessness in Los Angeles.

The Eaton Fire that hit our community this year was truly devastating. Living near the evacuation zone, I witnessed firsthand the terrifying power of nature, as flames were visible from my driveway. For days, we lived in uncertainty, bombarded by constant alerts, and endured a four-day power outage.

It was a rollercoaster of emotions‚ÄîI was afraid when I saw the flames and anxious about whether the fire could be controlled. but when I Saw the community come together, donating and supporting each other, it was incredibly moving.

I‚Äôve been volunteering for over a year now, and let me tell you, there‚Äòs nothing quite like seeing someone get the help they need. Now, it‚Äôs my turn to give back in my own way.

‚ù£Ô∏èTo everyone who had to evacuate from Pasadena and Altadena‚ù£Ô∏èSo many people are thinking of you. I believe art can be a form of therapy, and I hope this helps in some way as you rebuild and return to normal life.

üíõ50% off tattoos for all evacuees. This offer is good through all of 2025, no limits, no rush. Whenever you‚Äòre ready, just hit me up and send your ideas to  madderlaratattoo@gmail.com

Not the most flattering pic, but I wanted to give a little insight into this whole assistance process. I have always been a proud, stand on my own two feet kind of person (well, with some help from mom and dad here and there). But, I‚Äôve always adulted well, compartmentalized well, and cared for others well. I‚Äôve been privileged in that I have never needed to rely on any sort of public or agency assistance. 

This has been humbling, exhausting, and enlightening. Disaster can truly happen to anyone. Feeling overwhelmed by all the systems can happen to even the most educated. Figuring out which box to check on all the forms can be confusing for even those of us who love filling out forms.

I have never felt so supported and assisted, yet overwhelmed and unprepared for this process. I watch people around me in awe, navigating this process with little to no English, difficulty reading, or any number of challenges. We are truly a community, relying on others to help us through. I met some of the most amazing people in line today. People I probably would not have met outside of this situation. I am privileged, but even the most privileged can be humbled in an instant. We are no better than anyone else. In one moment we are all placed in the same situation, relying on the same services and resources, and needing help from each other. For someone who is not a people person, I can, surprisingly, be great with connecting with people of all walks of life. Today was the day that came in handy. This is not the community I ever thought I‚Äôd be part of, but it‚Äôs one of the most supportive I‚Äôve ever seen.

SAVED: The only church architect Wallace Neff designed and the first house he built for himself.

St. Elizabeth of Hungary Catholic Church has been a gateway to Altadena since its dedication in 1927. Flames came within a block of the sanctuary.

A budding career in Pasadena allowed Neff to design a charming home in a Euclayptus grove for him and his wife in 1923. The house survived the fire, but its detached garage, as well as the house next door, burned down.

Image 1: Google, 2: Jim Staub via Facebook, 3: Google, 4: Wallace Neff: Architect of California‚Äôs Golden Age by Alson Clark, 5-7: Huntington Digital Library

Updated Forest Closures Through December 31, 2025! 

Attention outdoor enthusiasts, hikers, and nature lovers! 

Angeles National Forest Closures: Due to critical fire danger and ongoing recovery efforts from the #eatonfire, the Angeles National Forest, including parts of the San Gabriel Mountains National Monument, will be closed through at least December 31, 2025. 

 Affected Trailheads in Our Area:

‚Ä¢ Mount Lowe Trail
‚Ä¢ Mt. Wilson Trail
‚Ä¢ Gabrielino National Recreation Trail
‚Ä¢ San Gabriel Peak Trail
‚Ä¢ Bear Canyon Trail
‚Ä¢ Winter Creek (Lower & Upper) Trail
‚Ä¢ Ken Burton Trail

 Why This Matters:

‚Ä¢ Public Safety: These closures are in place to protect you from the hazards of fire-prone areas, ensuring that emergency services can respond efficiently if needed.
‚Ä¢ Resource Protection: The forest needs time to heal and recover from recent fires. Continued human activity can degrade the recovery process and increase the risk of new fires.
‚Ä¢ Emergency Access: Limiting access helps keep essential routes clear for firefighting and rescue operations, which could be critical in emergencies.

We urge everyone to respect these closures. Not only does this ensure your safety, but it also aids in the forest's natural rehabilitation. Plan your adventures elsewhere for now, and let's give our beautiful natural spaces the time they need to recover.
 
Stay safe and stay informed. For updates on when the forest might reopen, keep an eye on official forest service announcements and our updates. For the current closures, visit: 
 https://www.fs.usda.gov/alerts/angeles/alerts-notices/?aid=93079&fbclid=IwY2xjawIIgjBleHRuA2FlbQIxMAABHf8rW674HgRtGXLFRMU2ZNMv1KEcVqUskaJj10zJ0m3ftgPF01ZnQudkdA_aem_xbNKRMB0ZPiyDfQy9xoxzA

Please share this information to help keep our community informed and safe!

‚ÄúRebuild‚Äù is a word that always unsettles me in the wake of catastrophic weather events and wildfires. It comes too soon, feeling reactive rather than making space for grief, fear, despair, and anxiety‚Äîemotions society is often so uncomfortable with. The urgency to set things right again takes priority, bypassing the depth of feeling that naturally follows such loss.

Questioning whether rebuilding makes sense in a climate crisis won‚Äôt stop the impulse to do it. But what if some far-flung outposts or deep canyons were left alone, so wildlife could reclaim them‚Äîfree from roads, mansions, and the resources required to build them? That radical thought is rarely brought to the table.

Just as judgments fly about how people did or didn‚Äôt care for their pets in the fires, harsh words were also directed at those with the privilege to navigate disaster with relative ease. Yet as I walked through the ashes of homes in the Pacific Palisades and the hills of Altadena‚Äîpast broken dinner plates and melted board game pieces‚ÄîI felt the echoes of lives lived there.

Family gatherings, growing children, music, prayers, the joy of pets welcoming their person home. Sitting on the stoop of a house that no longer stood, I realized: losing one‚Äôs home, no matter its size, must be terrifying. The strangeness of standing at a doorstep before its residents even knew their home‚Äôs fate was haunting. The remains of lives laid bare felt vulnerable and tender.

I thought of my own father, unwilling to leave his island home in a hurricane after my mother passed, because it was where he belonged. Maybe rebuilding isn‚Äôt just about walls and roofs. Maybe it‚Äôs about keeping the flame of hope alive‚Äîthat there will be a place to belong again, with loved ones and community. That isn‚Äôt reactive - it‚Äôs human.

If we rebuild in places prone to extreme conditions, we must do so with wisdom. Yet, before any physical rebuilding, there is an invisible one: the internal foundation laid at just the right time, in just the right place.‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

Southern California leadership has launched a fundraiser to address the needs of those affected. These funds will directly assist Compass colleagues as the aftermath is navigated together.

Your support can make a real difference. Stay tuned for more updates on how these efforts will help rebuild and restore.

We are so excited to announce that @reginayhicks will be joining this month‚Äôs Black History Month Edition of Pilot Season! üñ§‚ù§Ô∏èüíöüíõ

From Sister, Sister to Girlfriends to Insecure to The Upshaws (and a whole lot in between), Regina Hicks has been a defining voice in Black-led television, shaping culture and paving the way for authentic representation on screen. And now, she‚Äôs about to take on the most important moment of her career‚Äîpitching a brand-new pilot and watching LA‚Äôs most chaotic improvisers attempt to bring it to life with absolutely no regard for story structure, character arcs, or even basic scene continuity üôÉ

This Sunday @ 7pm come watch this TV icon, along with incredible writers Karen Joseph Adcock, Ester Liu, and Cameron Johnson, have some laughs, and support a great cause‚Äîall proceeds go to Black families displaced by the Eaton fires.

My heart and thoughts are with the families of our Pasadena and Altadena community as our kids at PUSD get to return to school today. It‚Äôs been an uncertain time of concern for so many, and our kids are no exception.

Sending support to the teachers and administrators especially as they navigate this return to normalcy amongst a shared trauma that will no doubt take time to move through. I know the coming days and emotional impact will be heavy as we learn new stories and experiences of loss and a diminished student population.

Our collective support, volunteerism, donations, and outreach is still very much needed through the coming months. I will continue to share resources and give time in the ways I can.

Check out my wildfires page (in bio) for info on free mental health support services for kids and teens and how the nonprofit I serve, @composedgiving, can deliver essentials to those who need them (in just 3 weeks, we‚Äôve supported over 230 families ‚Äî and over half being in the Pasadena area).

If anything can be learned from the wildfires this year, it is that our community is resilient, compassionate, generous, and strong.

If you have questions, want to get involved with Composed Giving, or need support, you also can DM me and I‚Äôll put you in touch with who I know and what I have.

Sending love,

Eaton Fire, Altadena CA

A full day of extreme wind, then many days of unstoppable fire.

Some people left their houses and possessions simply because the power went out from the winds before knowing a deadly fire would take their home. They expected to return to their houses as is, maybe a little messy from the winds, but not expecting to return to a leveled and scorched neighborhood.

Others left their houses within twenty minutes of hearing about the fast moving fire after being alerted to evacuate. People going door to door to tell their elderly or unknowing neighbors; some going outside to check on their wind-blasted backyards and surprised to see a fire moving towards them. The confirmation came with a citywide text to evacuate.

We Californians are used to the seasonal smell of smoke in the air from a brushfire nearby. But the time crunch and panic is wildly traumatic when you have to ask yourself in realtime the cliche question, ‚Äúwhat would you grab if your house caught on fire?‚Äù

#eatonfire #altadena #pasadenacalifornia #lafire #canonphotography #canon

Just making sense of all that I saw last week when I photographed the aftermath of the devastating Los Angeles wildfires, two weeks after they tore through Altadena and the Pacific Palisades, leaving 29 people dead and 16,000 structures burned to the ground. It was utterly heartbreaking to see such destruction. Very grateful to all of the people I met who told me their stories, including homeowners, volunteers, first responders, and last but not least my cousin Milena for driving me around all week just after her mother lost her home in the Eaton Fire. 
First set of photos in Altadena, Ca. More to come.
Photos at @reduxpictures

As the Eaton and Palisades fires subsided, many of you reached out to ask if the ash and residue falling across LA was hazardous to fruits and vegetables in backyard gardens. And TBH, we didn‚Äôt know.

So we reached out to Julia Van Soelen Kim, who is a Food Systems Advisor for the University of California. In 2017, she led the studies assessing backyard gardens after the Sonoma Complex Fires. She helped give us a bit of clarity + these 5 tips to follow when handling produce dusted by wildfire ash:

‚û°Ô∏è Protect yourself from smoke and protect your skin against ash. Wear an N95 mask outdoors and wear long pants & sleeves, gloves, hat and closed-toe shoes when harvesting.

‚û°Ô∏è Always wash your hands before and after harvesting and rinsing produce. If produce is completely covered in ash so no color is visible, discard it.

‚û°Ô∏è Gently pre-rinse your produce outside with a hose or bucket of potable water to remove visible soil and ash.

‚û°Ô∏è Before entering your home after gardening, remove your shoes and change into clean clothes. Bag smoky clothes and wash them as soon as possible to avoid tracking ash into and around your home.

‚û°Ô∏è Remove outer leaves. Rinse and rub produce under cool running water to remove soil, grit and ash. Wash your hands and peel produce before cooking or serving.

Hit the üîó in bio to learn more üè°

üì∏: Kazi Pitelka

TLDR: SIPA Loves LA - and not even a fire can take that away. ‚ù§Ô∏è
‚Äî
Over the past two weeks, SIPA has served 755 individuals affected by the fires, and: 

‚Ä¢ Provided PPE, hygiene kits, groceries and other essential items to clients and residents of SIPA‚Äôs affordable housing communities, 

‚Ä¢ Supported community members with crisis response counseling and support groups, 

‚Ä¢ Partnered with organizations including @swirlsclub , @whimsy.pasadena , and @lavcoutreach to provide clothes and necessities to impacted communities, 

‚Ä¢ Collected donations to be distributed to communities throughout Los Angeles County, directly to those impacted, 

‚Ä¢ Shared accurate and relevant resources and navigated community members to appropriate agencies for support and information,

‚Ä¢ Established a Crisis Relief Fund to purchase hard to procure items,

‚Ä¢ And will continue to work in coalition with advocacy organizations on promoting just and equitable recovery that centers those most vulnerable. 

We do this work no matter the season, no matter the crisis because we fully believe in community care.  Maraming Salamat from our volunteers and donors for all of your support - let‚Äôs keep going.

Project Highlight : A Fire Resilient LA¬†

Join Jamie (@jambaloney) and Christiahn (@christiahn) on a mission to heal and rehabilitate Los Angeles‚Äô natural environment.

The recent wildfires have left behind widespread ecological devastation and severe soil erosion. Invasive species are making matters worse by fueling these fires. But Jamie and Christiahn¬† are determined to change the narrative. They are using their creative talents to inspire a fresh, public perception of what a fire-resilient ecosystem can be.

By championing the rehabilitation and resilience of our landscapes, they are paving the way for a stronger, greener Los Angeles.

Be part of the change‚Äîsupport Christiahn and Jamie on their journey towards a more resilient LA. üåøüå±

In the month of January, the NASA/JPL Fire Department responded to the Eaton Canyon fire. Along with the help of other agencies, our firefighters worked tirelessly to ensure the safety of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Santa Ana winds promptly began blowing at speeds of approximately 70 mph with gusts of 100 mph, triggering a red flag warning in the area. Our firefighters were ready for any challenge that presented itself. We are proud to serve JPL and its community.  #eatonfire #firedepartment #firefighter #nasa #pasadena #altadena #lacanada #lastrong #santanawinds #2025

The Eaton Fire closure order has been posted by the Angeles National Forest this week. Unsurprisingly, it closes much of the front range for at least a year. This is certainly the correct thing to do in areas impacted by the fire, for both ecological reasons as well as public safety. However, I‚Äôm confused why several trails that are miles away from the burn activity are being closed (the Northwest corner of the map). Closing down Switzer Falls, Bear Canyon, the Gabrieleno, Ken Burton, etc seems unnecessary and heavy handed, given they‚Äôre in a totally different watershed disconnected from the region of the fire. You can check it out in detail at a CalTopo map I put together here: Eaton Fire Closure https://caltopo.com/m/C5G1V41

Either way, hopefully the land heals quickly. I‚Äôm already eager to get back out to the trails!

Photo 1: ANF closure order.
Photo 2: My Strava heatmap of where I run.
Photo 3: Photo taken of ANF this week.

Closure order: https://www.fs.usda.gov/alerts/angeles/alerts-notices/?aid=93079

The wildfires that tore through Pacific Palisades and Altadena are expected to intensify the housing crisis in Los Angeles. Renters are likely to feel the impacts, with soaring rental prices after the Lahaina, Maui wildfire in 2023 acting as a cautionary tale for LA.

Many LA renters are already struggling, and tenant advocates say more action is needed to prevent a potential wave of evictions in a city where housing is among the most unaffordable in the nation and more than 70,000 people are unhoused. 

Here is a round-up of the few measures leaders in the city and county of LA are taking to strengthen laws in favor of tenants, along with a few they have rejected or delayed. We've also included measures that tenants advocates are currently rallying around.

Read the full story by Elizabeth Chou (@reporterliz) via the link in the bio or go to LAPublicPress.org.

The first-grade class is currently in FIRST PLACE ü•á, and our school is just $5,000 away from reaching our goal of $80,000! üôå If we reach it, the kids get a food truck, and something else.. 

This year‚Äôs Jog-a-thon is about more than just running‚Äîit‚Äôs about rebuilding lives. We are raising funds for St. Elizabeth of Hungary Catholic School in Altadena, whose property was miraculously spared, but whose community has suffered devastating losses. Many families have lost everything, and now, we have the chance to help them rebuild.

Through this fundraiser, we are standing in solidarity with St. Elizabeth‚Äôs to provide relief, support, and hope to those who need it most. üíõ

Tomorrow‚Äôs kickoff will begin with a First Responder Lap üöíüöî‚Äîparents and community heroes leading the way. I can already tell it‚Äôs going to be an emotional and powerful moment. I feel honored to photograph this event and capture the strength and unity of our community.

Every dollar counts. If you can donate $5, $10, $100‚ÄîANYTHING helps. Let‚Äôs come together as an Angel family and make a difference. Eaton Strong: Run to Rebuild ‚Äì United Against the Flames. üî•üíô

*Good News Post*

I am 99.9% certain that all of these lovely homes are safe, despite being right where the Eaton Fire hit.  It's pretty incredible‚Ä¶ Some of them were either next to or just across the street from many homes that perished.  Some of them seem to have lost their garages. But as far as I can tell, these are standing.

I'm not saying 100% because I've been wrong before, and even though I do my best now to check very carefully, sometimes it's not easy to tell from the maps. 

If you know otherwise, please let me know. 

I was just told number eight is gone. üòû

PS one of the main maps that I used to determine these things, the LA County recovery map, is no longer working. Does anyone know anything about that? I really loved that map and it really helped.

Me: "I can't wait to do my thing in 2025!"

2025: " GIT DOWN ON THE GROUND NOW! SHUT UP! GIMME YOUR PURSE! GIMME YOUR SHOES! GIMME YOUR DRESS! GIMME YOUR DIGNITY AND EGO! YOU BET NOT MOVE! DON'T FUGGIN MOVE! I SWEAR TO GOD I'LL BLOW YOUR LITTLE  BALD HEAD CLEAN  OFF YOUR SHOULDERS!"

My looks from the 1st week in January! The rest of the month, I was running for my life, starring out the window, estate planning, and wondering if I have enough money for my sister and family to bury me properly. Like, how much would it cost to get my body from LA to Pennsylvania to get me in the ground with my Dad. I need better insurance. What insurance did my Dad have? Let me call my sister. Omg! All these fires and earthquakes here in LA!  I want my funeral in a real church; not a "Christian Center" I hope my family can get me in Calvary. 
Googles: Dead body shipping costs!

 I should eat today and bathe..Instead I slept til 4p almost daily. My God. The revenue loss! The people in #Altadena, the little baby ice skaters, must have been so cold! Omg will my Mom have social security. Hurricane Helene was brutal in her neck of the woods. I deserve this shot of whiskey. Oh, wait. Let me read the book Revelations again! Maybe I'll grow my hair out this year. Nah It's probably white! Get it together. Nina Simone would not be happy with you right now! FIGHT GRANT! FIGHT

Last night while watching FireAidLA, I had a lot of feelings and decided now is the time for me to go back through texts and pics and recreate a timeline starting with Jan 6, it‚Äôs a work in progress and I just found more texts to fill in my timeline. This was very healing for me to see how surreal the events were as they unfolded and some of the funny comments we made. If you were part of this tragedy, I encourage you to do this, but at your own pace, chunk it out and feel the feels as they come. Share your timeline with those around you so they can begin to understand how truly quickly this unfolded. I kept looking back and realizing wind was my only concern throughout the texts, even right up to the time we left. NEVER did I think the fire would hit us

The other important reason for doing this timeline is that trauma significantly impacts memory and if you plan to go through a process of healing with some sort of professional, this timeline can help aid you. It‚Äôs painful and exhausting, but in the end, I promise you- it is worth it

#EatonFire
#MentalHealth
#HealingFromTrauma

Eaton Fire in Altadena, CA 1/17/25

The Eaton fire that engulfed the city of Altadena as the Palisades Fire was raging dealt a catastrophic blow to historically Black neighborhoods, destroying over 7,000 structures and leaving at least 16 people dead. With redlining and other discriminatory practices making homeownership difficult to attain for Black families throughout American history, Altadena was a beacon for generational wealth building for those who faced restrictions due to their heritage. That makes the destruction even more tragic. 

For many of these families, the task to rebuild is insurmountable as everything they owned was in those homes that are now reduced to rubble. Insurance companies have dropped fire coverage for over 100,000 LA homeowners, including many living in Altadena. Despite a moratorium requiring the insurance companies that recently dropped fire coverage to pay out for those homes affected, the fight to rebuild and maintain coverage in a world where these horrific blazes are becoming more common, is only beginning. 

#photography #altadena #eatonfire #photojournalism #photographer #journalist #journalism

I don‚Äôt know how to be this person. The one who needs help. The one who doesn‚Äôt have it all together. The one who has to say yes instead of I‚Äôve got it. And I know I‚Äôm not alone in this.

We build our identities around strength, around being the one others can count on. But when life shifts‚Äîwhen we‚Äôre the ones who need support‚Äîit feels disorienting, even wrong. The instinct is to resist. To prove we‚Äôre still capable. But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm learning:

Accepting help isn‚Äôt a loss of strength. It‚Äôs an expansion of it. True resilience isn‚Äôt about standing alone‚Äîit‚Äôs about knowing when to lean.

So if this feels hard for you, too, I see you. And maybe the real work isn‚Äôt in holding it all together‚Äîbut in learning that we don‚Äôt have to.

-Dr. Z

This piece of art which hangs above where I‚Äôm temporarily residing‚Äîfeaturing 1,000 pencils‚Äîfeels like the perfect reflection of my life right now. After losing everything in the fires‚Äîmy home, my belongings, even the feeling of being grounded in my own city as an evacuee‚Äîit feels like I‚Äôm truly back at the drawing board. Not just rebuilding a house, but redesigning every piece of my life from the ground up.

Thousands of people in Los Angeles are facing this same reality. It‚Äôs overwhelming, but the only way forward is to take it one step, one decision‚Äîone pencil‚Äîat a time.

If you‚Äôve lost everything, remember: you don‚Äôt have to redraw your entire life in one day. Pick up one pencil, make one mark, and trust that piece by piece, line by line, a new masterpiece is waiting to unfold.

#BackAtTheDrawingBoard #OneStepAtATime #RebuildingFromTheAshes #StartingFresh #StrongerTogether #palisadesfore #losangelesfire #eatonfire

When the LA fires broke out and all of these GoFundMe accounts popped up it was overwhelming to try to figure out where to put your time and resources, and who to donate to and how much. 
My friend Alex and I decided to go out and meet some families who we felt could really use some help in getting their story out there and raising more money for them to be able to get through this unprecedented time. We‚Äôre going to be sharing these videos around as much as we can, with a link to their GoFundMe page. 
Right now, the goal is to raise money so that these displaced families can cover things like rent & essential every day items, while they slowly work on rebuilding their homes. Eventually, the goal will be to replace some more specific items like computers, cookware, furniture, etc. If anyone is interested in sponsoring a family directly and has the means to give substantial amounts, please reach out to us so we can talk.

Meet Amaya Philps, a 15 year old California School of the Arts student who‚Äôs lost her home due to the Eaton fires. Even before the fires, Amaya and her parents, who worked in film, were in a vulnerable housing situation due to the Hollywood production strikes. Amaya and her family moved ten times in the last two and a half years before finally settling in Altadena, where they found a community to be a part of and love.  Donating to this GoFundMe will help Amaya continue to attend school in person for the rest of her Sophomore year and find a home for her and her family to stay.

My Altadena. 

Thank you to @_jenmelchor , @guesssiu , and @noahklabin for volunteering with me at @pasadenajobcenter this past week. 

Friends and Family, what happened in Altadena is tragic. It‚Äôs one thing to watch it passively through our phones or TVs. It‚Äôs another to see it in person. To smell burnt structures, hear the clatter of circling helicopters, and see the heartbreak of those who lost everything. 

While processing the destruction of an entire community has been hard, volunteering and seeing Los Angeles show up and support Altadena has been amazing. If you‚Äôre looking to volunteer I highly suggest swinging by @pasadenajobcenter. If you‚Äôre looking to donate @outwardboundadventures and @altadenamountainrescue are doing fantastic work within the community. 

I took several photographs documenting my old neighborhood. I‚Äôll develop and post those over the next couple of weeks. Thank you to @lumentation for providing me film for my trip. 

#altadena #eatonfire #lastrong

Wildfires can take homes, but they do not have to take the places we love. Recovery should not mean displacement. It should mean families returning, neighbors staying together, and communities rebuilding stronger than before.

ARC is a volunteer-led movement of architects, designers, and builders working on real solutions. Fireproof homes. Resilient neighborhoods. A recovery that makes sense for the people who live here.

If you believe in rebuilding better, in making sure no one has to start over somewhere else, in a future where wildfires do not mean losing everything, then join us. Let‚Äôs get to work.

A huge thank you to @oltreehui @morganvicki @joannandrews @attaboycowboy @ccamarena for the branding design and support. Your work is shaping this movement.

The fabulous apple tree. Trying to keep the apples safe from squirrels; didn‚Äôt really keep it safe from the fire. 
The number one thing I can recommend is to get a public adjuster! 
After I lost my house in the Woolsey fire, I tried to just deal with my insurance. Keep in mind, I was 3 months pregnant with a two year old. My insurance agent suggested that while we wait for our cleanup and rebuild - I should buy a trailer and live next to all the toxic chemicals and ash of my burned down house and my neighbors burned down houses. With my dog, cats, my two year old, and very pregnant belly. 
Get a public adjuster! They will fight for you to get what you deserve. Your insurance representative fights for your insurance company, not you. I know it‚Äôs overwhelmed. This will help make it manageable.

3.5 weeks has passed since our collective lives were turned upside down here in Pasadena/Altadena. The communal pain, loss, and devastation is unfathomable and yet the love, kindness, generosity, and community organizing has been astronomical üí´ We truly are love in the midst of all the chaos around us. The first photo was taken 2 hours before the Eaton fire broke out. My anxiety was so strong I thought I was going to have a panic attack so I went out foraging all the beautiful branches that were falling down everywhere. I had no idea how bad it was about to get. I won‚Äôt post any fire pics. I won‚Äôt post Lake burning down, or all of our favorite local spots, or the beautiful burnt down homes of all of our friends and neighbors. I‚Äôve seen enough for a lifetime. What I will leave here is just a tiny sliver of how I‚Äôve experienced the last 3 weeks. I wish I would have gotten more photos of the 100‚Äôs+ people that have come through our doors that we‚Äôve hugged, cried with, and held. It has been an honor of a lifetime to be able to give folks high quality sustainable clothing to begin to rebuild their wardrobes. We couldn‚Äôt have done it for this long or served this many people without the help of friends. Thank you @ladywhite_co @firstriteclothing @claggie @cecilia.cecil and @persephonevint for your incredibly generous donations. Thank you @thisrepairshop and @dadgenre for your help getting this started and of course thank you @callmecesco for being my partner and supporting in every which way all the time ü§ç The last slide just hit home hard when I read it today, written by a woman who lost everything. The future is uncertain, but one thing I am certain of is that I love this community with all my heart ü§ç #DenaStrong #AltadenaIsNotForSale #EatonFire

Altadena, California is devastated. Over 9000 structures destroyed in 12 hours of high winds on January 7th and 8th. This unprecedented destructive event occurred at the same time as other major fires around LA, including the 23k acre Palisades Fire that destroyed over 6000 structures. The Eaton Fire eventually burned over 14k acres into Angeles National Forest. Wildland urban interface and many more diversely populated neighborhoods are completely altered, whole blocks in ruins. After weeks of valiant efforts from fire fighters, including inmates, along with much needed rain these apocalyptic fires are fully contained. 29 people lost their lives, with more missing. Sadly as the rumble is gone thru, the death count rises. The Altadena community is strong and will rebuild. #eatonfire #palisadesfire #altadena #Pasadena #fire #calfire #californiafires #altadenastrong #wewillrebuild #blackandbrownlivesmatter #blackandbrowncommunity #peopleofcolor #wildlandurbaninterface #santuary #sanctuarycity #sanctuary #historicla #history #racialjustice #racialequality #freedom #justice #inmatefirefighters #firefighters #nationalguard #firstresponders #heroes #communitysolidarity

It's fairytale Friday, so here's a story about a fairytale mansion!

Altadena's Balian Mansion - SAVED!

In Altadena, the name Balian is synonymous with Ice Cream, and apparently it was quite delicious.  Like the Helms trucks of my childhood, delivering baked goods to the neighborhood, the Balian trucks delivered ice cream throughout the area‚Äôs schools and grocery stores, and the success led to the purchase of this house, The Balian Mansion, famous for the most outrageously brilliant, bright and magnificent christmas display, featuring over 10,000 lights.

George Balian‚Äôs father purchased the magnificent mediterranean mansion (built in 1922) during the mid 1950‚Äôs. By 1955, the elaborate  displays started to appear.  From mid-September each year, the lights would start going up, to be ready by December, and stay up through the year‚Äôs end.  In later years, though they wouldn‚Äôt always be lit, the lights would just stay up.

Viewing the light show became a tradition for generations of families in the area and beyond, and along with Christmas Tree Lane, and St. Albans Road in San Marino, there was always lots of Christmas fun to be had in the area.

This ‚ÄúHouse of 10,000 lights‚Äù was also a popular film and TV location, starting as early as the 1920‚Äôs when they used it for filming the silent ‚ÄúSeven Years Bad Luck.‚Äù She also appeared in Knots Landing, Ratched and Palm Royale.

Sadly, the lights were turned off for good in 2010, and George died in 2019.  Later that year, there was an estate sale, liquidating old Balian signage, chistmas decorations, and other items associated with the legendary abode, including 6-foot-tall crystal chandeliers and other momentos of the luxurious life the inhabitants had once known.

The house and joy that it brought to kids young and old for decades will never be forgotten. Rumor has it that relatives of George, who now own the home, are trying to decide what to do with it.  The proceeds of the estate sale were intended for its restoration. I certainly hope they will do their best to ensure it is preserved. Thankfully, it escaped the fire! Does anyone know anything else about it?  Please let us know!

I will share photos of Altadena after the Eaton Fire over the next few days. These photos and my experience taking them, walking on these demolished streets, is for anyone who feels grief after what happened. Thousands have lost their homes, everything that anchors them, makes up their identity over years or decades of life in their home. Others, like me, are hurt from the fact that this beautiful, familiar area that *is* home, has been so brutally changed and knowing that so many are struggling to rebuild their lives and homes. But - there‚Äôs also so much love, strength, and community bond that‚Äôs happening. And I‚Äôll say again what so many have said already. Such deep gratitude for our firefighters‚Äîcareer, incarcerated, and community‚Äîalong with all first responders and everyone working tirelessly to keep our communities safe. 100% containment in LA üôè‚ù§Ô∏è Let‚Äôs continue to hold one another, support those affected, and stay prepared.

üåß The rain is a blessing, but experts say the air, water, and land will remain highly toxic for the next 1-2 years. This isn‚Äôt over.

ü§≤ This is a marathon. We have the opportunity to create a new normal‚Äîone rooted in kindness, volunteering, and collective care in a way that is long-term and regenerative. Follow accounts like @iolovesyou for education and @the_kindnesshub for support, services, and community.

ü´∂ FOLLOW WIND PATTERNS & WEAR A MASK. Toxic gases and heavy metals are still present and will be until proper remediation is complete. There is no safe distance. Keep windows and doors closed for the foreseeable future. Detox regularly, run an air filter always, and advocate for tech that can measure air toxicity countywide.

This is our new normal, but we don‚Äôt have to accept generations of health issues and cancer. Let‚Äôs stay aware and take care of ourselves. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Wildfire survivors are invited to join us this Wednesday, Feb 5th at 5pm for a webinar on your options and insurance considerations for replacing your wildfire destroyed home. There is no rush to make the decision to rebuild or buy elsewhere; this webinar is intended to help frame the conversation you may already be having. Register for this webinar at: uphelp.org/feb5

Some wildfire survivors choose to rebuild, some buy elsewhere, some build elsewhere. There is no one path for everyone. Our nonprofit helps you make the best decision for you and your family.

I evacuated from the #EatonFire. This was my experience.

#altadenacalifornia 
#altadenastrong

@afterthefireusa
Los Angeles Fires
January 2025

We met with leaders from Eaton Fire and toured the Palisades Fire and parts of Eaton. These fires are sisters, not twins, and will require specific care for each.

We met with California State Senator Ben Allen + staff and the District Director of Assemblywoman Jacqui Irwin to answer questions, listen to concerns, and plan delegations.

We next spent a couple of amazing hours with the clergy of Kehillat Israel Synagogue, the same wonderful folks who hosted us for a webinar last week and included other faith-based communities. Faith communities play a critical role in communities post-disaster. 

When the houses are gone, having a circle of humans encompassing and sharing your collective grief and providing solace is a guiding force for recovery. 

We spoke a long time together. It was very moving and full of humanity and tears. This is a club no one chooses, but is full of the best of humanity. 

We treat every event with the respect and care it needs and deserves.

We are grateful to be included in the #FireAidLA event and sat with fire survivors and Team Rubicon. 

Many thanks to the team at SnapChat for taking amazing care of us throughout. ‚ù§Ô∏è

The Altadena Mountain Rescue Team would like to thank @directrelief for the very generous donation of $25,000 in addition to several first aid kits and much needed Nomex wild-land firefighting shirts and pants. 

A big thank you to Staci Richard from Rescue Direct who was in Altadena in the early stages of the Eaton Fire. She and her team were instrumental in assisting not just AMRT but many other volunteer organizations to get the supplies needed in a rapidly growing disaster zone. 

‚Äî-

The Altadena Mountain Rescue Team was established in 1951, it is one of the oldest organization of its kind in Los Angeles County. 

AMRT is also one of the founding members of the National Mountain Rescue Association 

The Altadena Mountain Rescue Team is a 501(c)3 nonprofit volunteer organization dedicated to saving lives through mountain rescue and safety education.

So I attended the FireAid concert on Thursday night. It was a wonderful way for the benefit to raise money for the families who lost everything. One thing about this city is how so many people rally to help each other. 
So many legendary performances and collaborations that blew my mind. From Greenday and Billie Eilish performing Last night on Earth, Anderson.Paak bringing out Sheila E. To drum solo, and then he brought out Dr. Dre to sing Still D.R.E and then California Love. Another amazing moment was when The Black Crowes brought out Slash to perform Going to California.¬† 
Then Joni Mitchell graced us with her voice. Steven Stills and Graham Nash sang Teach your children well.
But my favorites were No doubt, Stevie Nicks, Pink¬† and the Nirvana reunion. Listening to Stevie Nicks perform Landslide as a tribute to the fire fighters had me in tears. And Pink's acoustic set was amazing! And my all time Fav No Doubt's energy was contagious! And the Nirvana performance of All apologies with Violet singing while her dad played drums was perfection. This entire night was so iconic LA and one I will not soon forget!!
This is why I adore This city! #Lastrong #LA #fireaid #wewillrebuild #musicisgoingtosavemysoul #palisadesfire #eatonfire #nodoubt #Pink #greenday #nirvana #stevienicks

I‚Äôm so grateful to have been able to help families celebrate the birthdays 20+ little ones who have been displaced by the Los Angeles wildfires. All we wanted to do is spread love, offer a little joy in the middle of tragedy and support our fellow Angelenos. I‚Äôm so thankful to have these baking superstars (and now friends!) that joined in the effort with me that collectively became known as ‚ÄúThe Birthday Cake Project‚Äù. We saw a handful of other bakers start their own projects like this and we couldn‚Äôt be happier that the baking community showed up like this for our communities. We‚Äôre also super thankful that @amoderndetail offered to make beautiful custom cake toppers, @confettiandsprinkles offered to make as many fun balloon bouquets as she could and @tehachapigrainproject offered to support with ingredients if needed. @wiltoncakes even said they‚Äôre sending us a box of goodies to use for these cakes and we can‚Äôt wait to see the fun stuff they‚Äôre donating! 

We have met so many lovely people through this project. Los Angeles might be one of the biggest cities in the world, but it sure does feel small in the best way sometimes. 

Please continue to spread the word about The Birthday Cake Project - we‚Äôd love to continue supporting families in celebrating their kiddos during all this. 

@nicolebakescakes @toptiertreats @getting_caked @cakesbyholly @maegsbakescakes üíú

Last year I created a coloring book inspired by the wildlife and natural beauty of The San Gabriel Mountains, a place that has always been my home. Since the devastating Eaton Fire, which has deeply impacted our community and the landscapes we love, it feels like the right time to share this project. The San Gabriel Mountains A-Z Coloring Book was meant to celebrate the mountains, but now it feels like a way to honor and give back to those impacted by this tragedy. I‚Äôm committed to donating a portion of sales to support victims of the Eaton Fire. It‚Äôs my small way of fostering healing, offering hope, and celebrating the resilience of our community.

Meet Lucy and Mandy (@artistsforfire), two passionate artists on a heartfelt mission to support wildfire relief and recovery efforts. They‚Äôve united their creative forces to launch Artists For Fire, a vibrant collective of artists and illustrators. This initiative focuses on crafting Los Angeles-themed drawings and paintings, transforming them into beautiful prints and postcards available for purchase on their web platform.

By purchasing these unique artworks, you‚Äôre not just adding to your collection‚Äîyou‚Äôre making a tangible difference. Every penny of the proceeds is donated directly to the LA Wildfire Emergency Fund (@lafdfoundation) and the Wildfire Relief Fund (@gofundme).

It's storybook Saturday and, sadly, as we all know, not all stories have a happy ending. This is one of those sad ones... 

In my neighborhood explorations, there are certain houses that just stand out to me, certain ones that touch my heart deeply. This was one of those houses, and I'm very sad to say that it's another casualty of the Eaton fire.
 
When I heard this news, I was devastated. 

It's one thing to admire a house from afar, or from the sidewalk, it's quite another to actually meet and talk to the homeowner, learn a bit more about the home, and express my appreciation for it. All of that happened with this house. 

In fact, I first saw it when I would be driving by, without time to stop. But eventually, I pulled over, and ended up doing so several times.

It was the last time, back in October, when I visited the Zorthian Ranch, also lost to the fire, that I not only stopped, but I spent a little more time and lucky for me, the homeowner came out! 

Brian couldn't have been more friendly, and told me all about their resident monster Wolfie, how they used to just bring him out for Halloween, but ended up leaving him year 'round for all occasions, dressing him up for each one. I'm pretty sure I have him as Santa as well, but couldn't seem to find that today. If I do, I'll put it in stories. But he's dressed for Halloween, for Fourth of July‚Ä¶ He became a welcome symbol of this lovely 1927 Dutch colonial abode and the family living here. Please see that 10/19/24 post. 

If the family is reading this, please know how much my heart is with you and how sad and sorry I am. I know you took pride in your home, and you brought so much joy to those of us who had the pleasure of seeing it every year and for every holiday. 

Please let me know if there's anything I can do to help. 

#storybooksaturday #storybookhouse #dutchcolonial #sadending #sadstory #eatonfire #deserve2preserve #holidayhouse #altadena

Imbolc. February. 2025. We land on this sabbat that venerates fire and water just as there are finally no active fires in the region. As of last night, the final night of this very long experience of January‚Ä¶No more active fires in Los Angeles. (I needed to type it again just to read it again, to try to take it in.) I feel mournful relief. 

Needless to say, I do not feel called to light a candle or anything that burns in honor of this midway point between the winter solstice and vernal equinox. But I‚Äôm taking a moment to think about the Celtic celebration of this time, and how it marks the beginning of healing, of moving out of darkness, toward the light.

Moving forward is going to look so different for each person who has lived through this time here. It‚Äôs going to look different across the country as we begin to deal with the very real and dangerous repercussions of that person being sworn in on the 20th. 
There is so much work involved in moving forward in any way, and I just want to remind you, in case you need it, that there is room for your hope and your sorrow in the same moment. They are not at odds with one another - they honor your existence and experience in this world. 
I‚Äôm sending Love to each of you, tonight and always. 
üß°

The LA Fires were devastating. We can‚Äôt simply forget, and just move on. So many friends and clients that I know personally lost everything. My dear friend @glambylisalopez who took me in when I first got into my accident lost her beautiful home that I stayed in {Altadena} #eatonfire This was one of the homes in the area I visited not just for a photo op, but I knew I wanted to keep this tragedy top of mind. These people deserve not to be forgotten, in all the other crazy phenomenons that have been happening so far this year, we can‚Äôt just forget about LA. So many people are displaced and have to fight the red tape to rebuild. The recent concert #fireaidla raised a lot of money for all these people who really need it right now. These are a few of my favorite moments from that concert. #lafires #2025 #fireaidlaconcert #concert #music #musicheals

One last gratitude post of the day and it‚Äôs a big one-

I have been blessed with the most amazing friends as you can see from previous posts. They know me inside and out, with all my neuroses and the good parts too (I got jokes and can bake). 

But these two- they‚Äôre my saviors during this crazy time. I don‚Äôt do well with change, I get anxious, grumpy and depressed. I avoid change at all costs and when change is forced on me, I freeze. Niki (@scubaxtravel ) and Rusty (@rusty.berry.ssa ) saved me from going out of my mind trying to figure out a place to live and manage all the other things that have taken over my mental and emotional energy. I see other fire refugees bouncing from place to place, living in hotels, on couches, in shelters, relying on insurance and assistance to get them through. I know I‚Äôm strong, but I really think this would have shattered me. These two made me a cozy place in their home. They‚Äôve made me feel welcome and like it‚Äôs my home too. Rusty makes delicious lattes in the morning, Niki cooks delicious meals and keeps my shopping in line and gives me chores and makes me laugh and literally occupies my brain with tasks- which I absolutely appreciate. AND THEY HAVE CHICKEN‚ÄôS Y‚ÄôALL- WE‚ÄôVE GOT EGGS! 

All this to say #MyFriendsAreTheBest

#EatonFire

Seeing our message juxtaposed with the destruction is a symbol of hope. It means we PLAN to pull through. That we believe in our strength to rebuild. We believe in each other to get through this and call these plots home again!

#altadena #altadenastrong #eatonfire #californiawildfires #altadenanotforsale

Just kidding‚Ä¶I lied, I can‚Äôt sleep and I need to squeeze in one more gratitude post‚Ä¶I‚Äôm really feeling it today.

This woman (I‚Äôm sure she‚Äôs going to kill me for the pic I chose) is one of the most giving, generous people I know. Karen (@superjoose ) was my partner in crime when I worked at the high school, continues to be one of my besties in and out of work. We‚Äôve got the same humor and share some good grumpy times. When I first learned my home burned down and started panicking, I reached out for support because I was at a loss of how I was going to be able to move forward. My first panic was holy sh*t, I have NOTHING! (Now mind you, I am privileged in that I have a great job that supports me, but the thought of rebuilding my life was more than I could handle). This magical woman recognized that my typically well functioning brain was not braining and jumped in without being asked to set up a GoFundMe. I can‚Äôt tell you how much I cried when she did that and you all jumped on board to make rebuilding just a little bit easier.

Again #MyFriendsAreTheBest

#EatonFire

Eaton Fire Damage in Altadena, January 27, 2025

I was in California last week and spent a short time looking at the devastation. With no power, there was silence; except for the power crews on every street working to string new lines to get some energy back to the area.

I had debated whether to post the few shots I took (and if any of these are your property and you prefer they not be here, please, please let me know). Then my friend and fabulous artist, @stephanieclairfineart, posted a new painting yesterday symbolizing a rebirth, a growing, and the strength from within, and I think the hope and prayers we all have for those that suffered in this catastrophe. 

I thought I would share; to document and grieve with those that lost, and look toward the rebirth....

Thankful for a new day and for the challenges ahead that I pray I will learn and grow from. 

As PCH reopens to the general public this morning, I hope people remember that thousands of residents here are mourning the loss of their homes and neighborhoods. Please be respectful when driving through Malibu. Yesterday I saw a couple sobbing in the middle of an empty lot and another elderly man just leaning against his car, staring at what used to be his home. Locals were only allowed back a couple of days ago and are still processing the loss. 

I‚Äôm happy that the local businesses we know and love will get a much needed boost from the opening. I understand how crucial this is to the healing journey for everyone. Hoping this can coincide with keeping everyone who lives here safe, secure, and with a sense of dignity while grieving their losses and beginning the long road back to rebuilding or repairing their homes and lives. 

Sending peace and love to all my friends, coworkers and neighbors who‚Äôve been affected by the #FranklinFire, #EatonFire & #PalisadesFire. üôèüèº
You can‚Äôt win if you aren‚Äôt even willing to get in the ring. Si se puede!  #housingisahumanright #southpasadena #91030 #eatonfire #rentfreezenow #evictionmoratorium

Said goodbye to Studio Maison DeMille yesterday. Not much left but the carcass of the chainstitch machine, some hoop wire, boning and dress form stands. WELCOME, WOOD SNAKE
For myself and surrounding friends - plant, animal, land and human - this Dragon/ Snake transition has been defined by stormy, fiery destruction. Our skin has been forcibly shed in an epic and traumatic manner. 

Neighboring hills are lonely, raw and bare, nearly devoid of their plant and animal companions.*
Scraped clean by Fire. 
The feeling echoes inside. 
And yet, I can feel the land breathing.

Wood nourishes Fire. Fire nourishes Earth.
The nature of Nature and the Elements is unapologetic. They simply Do as they Are. 

This can be tragically destructive for humans, resulting in toxic rubble for All, ashen memories, and exceptional grief to navigate amidst massive overwhelm.

We have been shocked into a state of transformation and renewal, as Snake represents.

Learn from Snake. Spending much time in stillness, it deeply senses and waits before acting. Curl into your Self and listen. To your Nature, the Land and Sky. Protect your tender, freshly exposed skin, allowing space for both loss and change as new layers reveal. 

Much love to all in Altadena, the Palisades and throughout Los Angeles as we navigate this complex process of loss, and growth, supporting others as best we can.

Please consider donating to those most vulnerable in the Altadena community who have been displaced. Links in bio. 
Thank You.
üíñ‚ú®‚ö°Ô∏è

*While cradled by hills scorched from #EatonFire, our home and most nearby were spared. Grateful for our luck, I am viscerally gutted for the many friends - plant, animal and human - who suffer so very much.
This comes from that cleaving mix of emotions, hope garnered from traditional knowledge and ancient wisdom, and relationship with the surrounding nature, now charred, that I have been communing with for over a decade.

#EatonFire #PalisaidesFire #LosAngelesFires #LAFires #YearOfTheSnake #healing #landhealing #wuxing #TEK #traditionalecologicalknowledge

My mother left Haiti in the 70s during the Duvalier regime. She eventually landed in California and was able to buy the house we would call home in Altadena 37 years ago. It was a feat; my mom as a single mother worked multiple jobs throughout the years and we hopped around Altadena, Pasadena and wherever else we needed to in order to keep our home. I‚Äôm blessed and privileged, thanks to my mother, to have been able to have a roof over our heads that housed many dreams, many experiences, many gatherings‚Ä¶it housed many people who needed a place to stay to get on their feet.

I used to say I‚Äôm from Altadena and no one would know where it was so I would just say Pasadena or LA. I never knew how describe this place economically and culturally - the fact that we‚Äôre Black of varying classes, riding horses and having chickens (well at least we did for a while) living at the base of a mountain. I didn‚Äôt think the world would know about Altadena in this way but it‚Äôs been beautiful to share in the magic of it with others who know it intimately.

I know so many people impacted and we‚Äôre really just getting over the shock and now into the years-long reality of what it means to come back from this. Yall came through - I appreciate every call, text, email, donation. The amount of love me and my family has received inspires hope.

We‚Äôre wrapping up the gofund me in the next couple days and sorting through all that needs to be done. Thank you deeply for all the acts of love. It‚Äôs been powerful to also see the determination around keeping black families in the area ü´∂üèø We got this.

1) I donated my kidney to my mom almost 2 years ago - we prepped and recovered together at home
2) My mom doing her vision board for the new kidney chapter in the dining room
3) Walking up our street and a sad attempt at twerking during my recovery
4) It‚Äôs been who knows how long but I asked my mom to cornrow my hair in December. It was so sweet and nostalgic, especially now
5) Late teenage years at the house
6) My mom in the 80s - We definitely lost some photo albumsüíî
7 + 8) The new generation repping Altadena ‚Äî my niece and nephew
9) Family time together 
10) The house

üö® Air Quality Monitoring in Fire-Affected Areas üö®

The South Coast Air Quality Management District (South Coast AQMD) has begun air monitoring efforts in the burn scars and surrounding communities of the Eaton Fire and Palisades Fire. This initiative, in collaboration with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board (CARB), aims to assess air quality during debris removal and cleanup.

üî• Why is this important?
Debris removal can cause hazardous dust and ash to become airborne, potentially affecting air quality and public health.

üî¨ Monitoring will occur in two key stages:

üìç Stage One: Mobile Air Monitoring (4 weeks)
üöõ Two mobile units will measure toxic metals & volatile organic compounds (VOCs)
üìå Identify potential hot spots near the burn zones
üîç Help determine locations for temporary air monitoring stations

üìç Stage Two: Stationary Air Monitoring
üì° Air monitoring stations will track particulate matter (PM), lead, arsenic, and asbestos
üè° Placement will be based on mobile monitoring data, cleanup activity, and proximity to homes & schools
ü§ù Ongoing coordination with federal, state, and local agencies

‚ö†Ô∏è Important Reminder:
Residents should not attempt to clean up fire debris (burned structures, vehicles, furniture, etc.). The Los Angeles County Department of Public Health (LADPH) and Pasadena Public Health Department (PPHD) have prohibited unsafe removal of fire debris to protect public health.

üåé Stay informed:
üîó South Coast AQMD wildfire response: www.aqmd.gov/lawildfires
üîó Wildfire smoke & ash safety tips: www.aqmd.gov/wildfiretips

Stay safe and take precautions! üí®üíô #AirQuality #WildfireSafety #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #Altadena

üî• GUARDIANS: Stories of Courage & Resilience üî•

This is his story.

üë®‚Äçüöí Chien Yu has been a firefighter with the Pasadena Fire Department for 18 years. His family lived in Altadena, where they built a life together‚Äîuntil the night of the Eaton Fire changed everything.

üå≤ "I saw the glow through the trees. Kim and I got our kids out when we got orders to evacuate. After they were safe, I went to work. We fought the flames for sixteen hours, but the winds were unlike anything we had ever seen. When we finally got a break, I checked on my house‚Ä¶ it was gone."

üíç A few days later, as Chien sifted through the ashes, he found something he never expected to see again‚Äîhis wedding ring. He always took it off for work, never thinking it would survive the fire. But there it was, a symbol of love and resilience among the ruins.

üî• Despite everything, Chien keeps showing up, giving back, and pushing forward. When he saw his portrait for the first time, he said he was "REAL CHEESIN!" üòÅ That's the spirit of a true Guardian.

If you'd like to support Chien and his family as they rebuild, please visit his GoFundMe page (link in bio). 

Every bit helps. üôè

üî• Nominate a firefighter to be featured in this project! Drop their name in the comments or DM me their story. Let's make sure their sacrifices are never forgotten.

üî• Proceeds from this book will go directly to a fund supporting firefighters‚Äîthe specific fund will be chosen with input from the firefighters themselves to ensure it has the most significant impact.

I spent a lot of time on this block of Mendocino, I just ended up that way as I was photographing, I had no connection to this block versus others it could have been any block up in Altadena the new landscape is so similar. The images were easy because of the devastation but the process was hard because of the moral factor. For me I was constantly thinking of the people who lived there, the intense graphic image was someone's home not just subject matter for my camera frame. It was a situation unlike anything I had ever experience because I know this area so well. I know people in this Jane's Village area that lost homes. I have a lot of relatives buried three blocks away from this street at Mountain View Cemetery so there is a connection. I am comfortable documenting it, I know it is important for me to develop this portfolio, but I can't photograph it like a press photographer. I need more layers; it has to be deeper. Some images as documents can be more like a photojournalist but overall, I have to craft different images if that makes sense. It will be a long-term task with lots of responsibilities, but it could end up being one of my most important portfolios. I was at the right place at the right time with a camera for a reason.

A couple posts tonight to highlight the after with the before to help comprehend the intensity.

#documentaryphotography #documentary #photooftheday #photography #photographer #nikon #eatoncanyon #eatonfire #pasadena #altadena #altadenastrong #californiawildfires #california #pasadenaphotographer #streetphotography

My dear Pasadena and Altadena communities have experienced such colossal loss this last month. As of January 31st, the Eaton fire has been contained and we are so grateful to all of the first responders who fought for 24 grueling days. What remains is the unimaginable rubble left in its wake. 

My friend Maddie‚Äôs home was completely destroyed along with everything in it. She was able to evacuate having only a few minutes to get out safely with her dear pup, Benny. She‚Äôs now facing the overwhelming task of starting over. 

For me, Maddie‚Äôs home was more than just a place‚Äîit was one of the first spaces that truly made Pasadena feel like home. It‚Äôs where countless friends and groups gathered, where community grew, and where so many meaningful moments were shared (inflatable obstacle course included). Now, she and her sweet pup are displaced with no clear timeline for recovery. 

If you‚Äôve ever been without a place that made you feel safe, welcomed, and cared for, you know how much it means to find that hospitality. If you‚Äôve ever had a person that embodies the feeling of that place, then you get the gist of how much Maddie means to all of us. I‚Äôm asking for your help to give that feeling of unreasonable hospitality back to this incredible woman and ray of sunshine. Even in the midst of so much chaos and paperwork, Maddie is still finding ways to look out for other survivors and take care of her beloved Altadena. 

Even a small donation to her GoFundMe can make a huge difference in helping her get back on her feet. Please don‚Äôt underestimate the impact any amount can make! If you‚Äôre unable to donate financially, sharing this post, a gift of yours, or keeping her in your prayers means just as much. 

Link is in our bio‚Äôs üíõ Thank you one and all for your love, kindness, and generosity.

#eatonfire #gofundme #unreasonablehospitality #HelpMaddieRecover

This home had a number of powerful elements so I will post them in groups. This cactus drew my attention because it looked like it was already in recovery with the green showing. The needles were burned off and other parts were singed, and it almost looks like ash and debris embedded in the damaged part of the plant‚Äôs exterior. If that was the case it memorializes the power of the fire storm. I could definitely see ash had blown up into the plant. I am going to have to research it more to find out more about this cactus to understand the damage, it just seems there is a lot of scientific information here.

I was shocked to see the flamingos made it until I realized they were concrete. Still, they came through it pretty well. These images are powerful enough as they are but when I saw the before image it really showcases the power of the firestorm. Except with these small little landmarks and the foundations I would not be able to match the before images with the present. Such a good little neighborhood that is forever changed.

#documentaryphotography #documentary #photooftheday #photography #photographer #nikon #eatoncanyon #eatonfire #pasadena #altadena #altadenastrong #californiawildfires #california #pasadenaphotographer #streetphotography #pinkflamingos

I spent a lot of time on this block of Mendocino, I just ended up that way as I was photographing, I had no connection to this block versus others it could have been any block up in Altadena the new landscape is so similar. The images were easy because of the devastation but the process was hard because of the moral factor. For me I was constantly thinking of the people who lived there, the intense graphic image was someone's home not just subject matter for my camera frame. It was a situation unlike anything I had ever experienced because I know this area so well. I know people in this Jane's Village area that lost their homes. I have a lot of relatives buried three blocks away from this street at Mountain View Cemetery so there is a connection. I am comfortable documenting it, I know it is important for me to develop this portfolio, but I can't photograph it like a press photographer. I need more layers; it has to be deeper. Some images as documents can be more like a photojournalist but overall, I have to craft different images if that makes sense. It will be a long-term task with lots of responsibilities, but it could end up being one of my most important portfolios. I was at the right place at the right time with a camera for a reason. A couple posts tonight to highlight the after with the before to help comprehend the intensity.

Eric and Aimee were my neighbors for many years‚Äì the fun ones on the block. A few years ago they moved with their growing family to Altadena to be closer to her job as a teacher and to a neighborhood more easily accessible by kids. On January 7th, the Eaton Fire roared down the mountain while the family was watching Wicked in the local theater. They never made it back to the house and unfortunately were unable to salvage anything including their beloved hamster. Aimee invited me to photograph the family with the remains of their home as they looked for anything meaningful. It was a privilege to document this important moment in their journey yesterday. 

They are close to their emergency fundraising goal. If you are so inclined, I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôd greatly appreciate it.

https://gofund.me/89e35030

Our current hotel has covered parking in a garage, so that‚Äôs nice. 

Every hotel we‚Äôve been to has been booked with displaced families from the fires, mostly Altadena. Like us, many families evacuated in two cars. So now the hotels have to accommodate for more cars per room than they are used to, and the parking lots get full fast. 

Furthermore, there are insurance adjusters, relief organizations, utility workers, etc. from out of state staying at hotels. Many will have their own rental vehicle. The other night, I couldn‚Äôt find parking at all when I was in my wife‚Äôs car.

It‚Äôs a strange thing to return to something that no longer exists. To sit in a place that isn‚Äôt yours.

Today, I sat in a chair while a friend ran her hands through my hair‚Äînot just a haircut, not just routine, but something deeper. A quiet offering of care, of comfort, of familiarity in a life that feels anything but.

And I felt it all at once, as tears rolled down my cheeks‚Äîthe sting of what‚Äôs missing, the weight of what‚Äôs changed, the strength and beauty we‚Äôve found in each other, and the quiet pull of what comes next.

We grieve the places that made us. The routines that held us. The life that we wore like a second skin.

But we don‚Äôt stay there.

We step forward. Into unfamiliar spaces. Into lives that don‚Äôt quite fit yet. Into whatever is waiting.

Maybe home isn‚Äôt a place at all.

Maybe it‚Äôs wherever love refuses to leave.

-Dr. Z

To our dear friends. We see your texts, your DMs, your IG & FB GFM shares, we hear your VMs and if Junaed and I have not responded; our sincerest apologies as we're still catching up. The outreaches from every one of you from every corner of this world has been beyond what we could've imagined. Never in a million years we'd fathom this would happen to us, but it did; we lost our beloved home; the home we built & renovated with our very own hands (literally), our beautiful town, every shop, every tree, our children's preschool, our place of worship; our masjid (mosque) all burnt to ashes. We are still processing it all, we find ourselves feeling many emotions but amongst all the chaos, we see the blessings. 

We evacuated, we are safe, we are secure and most of all, we are surrounded by you all. The outpouring love and support from our friends, family, communities, mom groups from each of our kids' schools, our professional communities, our childhood friends whom are practically family-- all have come through to help us any and every way possible...everyone has been so incredibly kind and thoughtful as to going above and beyond for us that it has quite literally changed the state of our lives and getting us back on our feet so swiftly. 

We are hopeful that we will rebuild our beautiful Altadena, our home, we will replant every tree, the parrots and peacocks that often wandered by will return Insha'Allah. Please continue to keep us in your thoughts and prayers so that we could navigate through this all. 

We are #Altadenastrong #beautifulAltadena
#eatonfirerecovery #EatonFire #altadena

Neatly tucked inside the far right corner of my bedroom closet is a plastic container the size of a small trunk. It‚Äôs heavy, too heavy for me to lift on my own. It was placed there 17 years ago by two burly men, when I moved to LA and into my apartment. Its contents are very precious to me. It‚Äôs a lifetime of memories held in paper and printed form. It‚Äôs albums of photos I haven't yet digitized, it‚Äôs playbills of my sister‚Äôs theatrical performances since she was in college, it‚Äôs thick journals I wrote during my angst-ridden, passionate, coming out years; and it‚Äôs saved images from fashion and travel magazines that have awed and inspired me since I was child, sparking my desire to become a photographer. 

None of it has any material value. But its content and the container‚Äôs immovability have always been what I worry about first when I imagine a fire engulfing our building, or an earthquake turning that closet to rubble.

When the fires hit our city, I was in Florida with family. All I could do was watch in horror and anguish how in a matter of hours, entire communities and their individual histories were wiped off the face of the planet. Their own precious containers of photographic memories and decades of heirloom treasures, gone forever.

You can‚Äôt replace the irreplaceable.

I don‚Äôt expect any of the families affected by these fires to have the bandwidth or the desire to take family portraits in the coming months or year ahead. I certainly would not. 

But I believe someone like me can use my business resources and my time to support our community and support local funds that are helping them rebuild. To help them find ways to create new memories and to celebrate their resilience and hope.

So I will continue doing what I can through direct outreach and donations, in the sharing of resources and offerings from across our city. 

For the rest of the year, I can donate 10% of all business proceeds to the California Community Foundation.

CCF‚Äôs grant making prioritizes rehousing wildfire survivors, providing relief for displaced workers, reopening small businesses, and restoring essential community infrastructure.

To learn more @calfund

Yesterday, I helped my parents dig through the remains of their home, searching for anything that might be worth saving. Mostly, I found melted fragments of metal and the ash of loved books. In the end, it‚Äôs a time to let it all go‚Äîthe childhood memories, the unique art and furniture my parents collected, the life that once filled those walls. Now comes the hardest part: waiting. Waiting for the debris to be cleared, for the next steps to take shape, for whatever comes next.

I received the biggest box of love from Paper Source Palo Alto.  It was filled with the most beautiful cards, file folders, planners, office supplies- all the things I would need in the coming weeks after the fire.  When everything is gone you don‚Äôt think of things like pens, scissors, tape, until you don‚Äôt have them.  Of course it was beautifully wrapped, tied with colorful ribbons and filled with thoughtful love (and candy). The attention to detail in picking useful items and things I would be excited about blew me away.
.
I started working at Paper Source in 2018. I thought it would be fun- visiting the store always made me happy. Who knew that those ladies would become life long friends. Because it is directly across the street from Stanford it was a mix of young and ‚Äúnot so young‚Äù but everyone was so interesting, caring and you wouldn‚Äôt believe the creative talents. The ‚Äúbreak room‚Äù birthday celebrations we would throw for each other were legendary and continued during Covid in socially distanced soir√©es. Those little parties were some of my  best memories from the pandemic. 
Swipe through to hear their stories! ‚¨ÖÔ∏è

Hi friends! As many of you know‚Ä¶ my 91 year old grandmother lost her home in Altadena of over 60 years. 

Sadly, she was not the only one. Thousands of homes and business are completely gone because of the Eaton fire and the Palisades fire.

As heartbreaking as it has been‚Ä¶ we‚Äôd like to provide some help, love, and joy to others that are still suffering.

We are LA STRONG.

We at @artofinkla are donating 100% of the proceeds to rebuilding efforts and to the @pasadenahumane 

That‚Äôs right‚Ä¶ 100%‚Ä¶ ALL OF IT.

So many of my friends have come together to support my family‚Ä¶ I thank you endlessly‚Ä¶ and we would like to help give back to the entire community.

We are not alone.

Together‚Ä¶ we are LA STRONG. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Our hearts go out to everyone affected by the devastating fires. In an effort to help our community rebuild, we are donating our time to plan and strategize the restoration of homes for families in need. Additionally, we are offering an exclusive discount to those impacted by the fires.

We are deeply committed to rebuilding the city we love and supporting those in need. Together, we will rise stronger than ever. We are here for you every step of the way.

Feel free to reach out to me directly at (562) 340-5975 for assistance.

Joseph Machul
President | Joseph Construction Builders LLC

This is a mansion for your Monday, but one that is, sadly, no longer with us, as far as I know.

I remember walking by this particular place and noticing how there seemed to me so much life going on inside‚Ä¶ And I couldn't help but wonder what life would be like here, it seemed so warm and inviting, but was also very very large as was, or so it seemed, the family enjoying it.  I had the impression there was something interesting going on in every room downstairs. Believe me, I'm not one to do a lot of peering into windows, it's actually something my companions on my walks always point out to me, things that they say, I never even go there, but in this case, that was the feeling. 

From my research, it seems there might have been a flower business here, perhaps run out of a home office.

A wonderful house in a wonderful setting, I'm so sad and sorry that it's gone.  Almost everything in this neighborhood was completely destroyed.

#altadena #mansion #mansionmonday #beautifulhouse #eatonfire #firedamage #sadstory #memories #neighborhoodwalk #foundonmywalk

As a fellow Angelino and Californian, I know how devastating wildfires can be. To provide even a glimmer of hope for my community is essential. That‚Äôs why I created Stay Golden LA‚Äîa candle that does more than just glow; it gives back.

Altadena was built for a different time, with homes and neighborhoods never designed for the wildfire risks we now face. 88% of destroyed homes were built before fire-resistant codes existed.

Should we rebuild as before, or create something safer, stronger, and more resilient?

‚û°Ô∏è Swipe through to explore how history, policy, and design will shape Altadena‚Äôs future.

üî• Should fire retrofits be required for older homes?
üè° Can we add housing without increasing wildfire risk?
üå± How do we rebuild a fire-adapted community together?

Drop your thoughts in the comments, how should Altadena be rebuilt?

The EPA tagged my poor Volvo. All burnt cars slated for removal were tagged as an EV or not.

When EV batteries are compromised by damage or heat, they become highly volatile. Exposed elements of the power systems can cause electric shock. Heat damaged battery packs can be susceptible to combustion, even after a fire is out. EV fires burn so hot that the current method of attack by firefighters is to let them burn out. Burnt EVs have to be removed with special care.

I‚Äôm not an EV hater like many classic car enthusiasts. But it hurts a little to see my car tagged by government because of EVs. It‚Äôs a process letting this car go. For now, it rests in the wreckage of my garage. Someday I‚Äôll show up at my home and the car and debris will have been taken away. And that‚Äôll be that.

Devastated that this is the aftermath of my childhood home. My childhood home, school, park and entire neighborhood burned down in the Eaton Fire. It‚Äôs taken me a while to post about it because it‚Äôs truly heartbreaking to see so many cherished childhood memories turn to ash. The birthday parties with the incredible ice sculptures, the 30 girls from my class that would come over for sleepovers (yes all at the same time bless my parents lol), the neighbors that would pile onto the driveway to watch the cities 4th of July fireworks, the walks to school in the morning and hikes in the mountain in the evenings, the dance recitals at the park around the corner. Our house in the hills that held so many very dear memories in my heart. However it‚Äôs been incredible to see how the community has come together across Altadena, Pasadena and all of LA. I‚Äôm glad all family and friends are doing ok. The LA and Dena communities are strong and will rebuild. If you‚Äôre looking for organizations to donate to visit FireAidLA.org 
.
.
.
#EatonFire #Altadena #AltadenaCalifornia #LAFires #WeWillRebuild #DenaStrong #CaliforniaStrong #PalisadesFire

Our hearts are with those who have lost everything in the Palisades and Eaton fires. As local residents and members of the communities affected, we at Dejaun want to provide some type of relief to the wonderful people that make our towns so special. We will be donating engagement rings to those whose rings were destroyed in the fires. While we wish we could support everyone who has suffered a loss of their engagement ring, we can only choose a few couples to gift a new engagement ring to replace the one lost in the fire. Please follow the link in our stories and bio to apply for an engagement ring replacement. We will notify those who have been selected on February 14, 2025.
