Took a little stroll in our Most Beautiful Altadena.

Couldn‚Äôt help to think how many people I knew/know above Altadena Dr., and Altadena. All the faces and funny moments, great conversations, knowing about new borns, folks telling us about family members who have passed on, which family member is getting married üôèüèΩ. Conversations people who wouldn‚Äôt  speak about in front of their own family members lolol The trust you build up with people for them to talk you their most intimate thoughts.  Knowing they wouldn‚Äôt ever move beyond the doors at Ace. Some folks would look at us as ‚Äújust another shady Smoke Shop‚Äù but I tried to be different and lift the veil and show a different side to smoke shops. Tried to bring people together and end the stereotype. That was my goal. I remember every person who came and went. And I don‚Äôt forget about our amazing staff and how we were and are truly family, customers had their own favorites who they‚Äôd love to see and converse with; felt more comfortable dealing with. That‚Äôs what I loved most about being at Ace. 

Watching TV and seeing people who I knew on a level some didn‚Äôt know. But the conversations they would have with a news reporter is; We Will Not Sell and We Are Going To Rebuild. Resilience, is what I love about the good folks in Altadena. 

But I promise, WE WILL BE BACK. Stronger than before and these recent events is going to bring us all together. 

You guys and gals fed my family and helped pay my staff; was never about gimme your money and get lost. Never. We wanted you there, with us. 

Like I have always said, I know the history of Altadena, knowing who was there before we arrived. So I always felt like a guest in your house/city. I love you all.

This morning, we announced bipartisan legislation to Fight For Firefighters. CalFire has been the cavalry to our communities during the Eaton and Palisades Fires. It‚Äôs clear there is no ‚Äúfire season‚Äù anymore. We need CalFire fully staffed 12 months a year working to protect CA and prevent these deadly megafires! Thank you to pro Tem Mike McGuire for caring for our communities and for his leadership on this legislation that will add 3,000 CalFire firefighters. And a deep, personal thank you to @CalFire and all the firefighters for your heroic actions and sacrifices during the Eaton Fire in my district.

Assessing the Aftermath of the Eaton Fire. 

Today, I visited the Eaton fire burn areas for the first time, inspecting concrete foundations to assess their condition after fire exposure. One of the homes I designed in 2003 was still standing in its own way‚Äîstucco walls towering 8 feet high with no studs left to support them, and steel twisted from the heat.

We also met with past and potential new clients‚Äîneighbors affected by the fire‚Äîto evaluate their foundations and discuss their vision for rebuilding. Each homeowner created a wishlist of goals for their new home, marking the beginning of the next chapter.

Rebuilding after a fire is tough, but it‚Äôs also an opportunity to reimagine and create something stronger. 

#EatonFire #FireRebuild #ArchitectureAfterDisaster #StructuralResilience #RebuildingStronger #architecture #structuralengineering #civilengineering #peck_architecture_struct_civil

The City of Angels, lonely as I am together we cry üåá‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π it‚Äôs been exactly 4 weeks since we got evacuated when the Palisades Fire broke out, Jan 7. I still can‚Äôt fully wrap my head around what happened and while I‚Äôm obviously extremely grateful that our neighborhood was saved by real life superheroes, it‚Äôs been difficult to feel happy when others so close to us have lost everything. üíî one thing I‚Äôve learned through this rollercoaster of emotions and hard ache though is that LA truly consists of the kindest people and communities. It‚Äôs not just dreamers, it‚Äôs doers, makers and organizers. It will take a long time to rebuild the historic neighborhoods we‚Äôve lost both in the East and in the West but this city gives me hope that it can be done. ‚ù£Ô∏è
Thank you @losangelesfiredepartment @lacountyfd our incarcerated fire fighters and all the fire fighting personnel that came to help from other counties, states and even countries and put their own lives on the line to save ours. üë®üèΩ‚Äçüöíüë©üèº‚ÄçüöíüöÅüõ©Ô∏è

The California Animal Response Emergency Support (CARES) program @cdfa_cares under @cafoodandag, partners with local agencies to ensure animals‚Äîsmall pets, livestock, and large animals‚Äîare cared for during emergencies. CARES actively assisted in the response to the Los Angeles wildfires.

Update: As of February 3, 2025 - 1,041 pets have been reunited with their owners, and 70 animals remain in shelters in the Los Angeles region. Efforts are ongoing to reunite these animals with their owners.

For more information, visit www.CDFA.CA.GOV/FIRERECOVERY and click the CARES Animal Shelter Resources link, or head to our LINK IN BIO.
.
.
#LAFires #Wildfire #LosAngeles #SouthernCalifornia #PalisadesFire #EatonFire

The Department of Insurance, Deputy Commissioner of Community Relations & Outreach, Julia J. speaks on new insurance increases. Says that some people will see increases more than the stated amount. 22% would be just the average of increase. Some people insurance will decrease which will cause others to pay higher premiums. Let say the average increase is 20% then if half of the people only pay a 10% increase that means the other half would have to pay a 30% increase. This should definitely not be allowed. The county is complicit in allowing any increases to happen. However, they are so concerned insurance companies will leave California they will end up bending to their will regardless if it hurts the residents dealing with this horrific event. Kathy Barger needs to not allow this happen. However. When it comes to big business she falls silent. She has yet to have criticism for SoCal Edison, the insurance companies, or the emergency system. We have to push back against these type of predatory practices. Please don‚Äôt  remain silent and let your voices be heard. 

RESTORE, REBUILD, RENEW!

#altadena #altadenafire #eatonfire #denanatives #insurance #scam

Didn't get that limited edition TJ lunch tote you wanted? Looking for ways to help families affected by the wildfires?

I was able to purchase two of the limited edition lunch totes today. I will be auctioning them off to the highest bidder. 100% of the winners purchase price will go directly to a GoFundMe of a family I personally know (and you will receive a link showing the donation.)

1. Comment on the post of the tote you want (this post is for the purple one) with your highest bid
2. Bidding will close on Thursday at 5pm PST
3. Tote can be mailed to winner anywhere in the US, postage paid by me
4. Payment can be made via Venmo or Zelle

Feel free to share this post.

Fire relief Donation Drive Announcement:

‚Äì A tale of two towns¬†‚Äì

For the past two weeks, at the United Methodist Church in Venice, we have been loving inspecting and sorting through over 10K units of generously donated and gifted new and like-new garments that are just about ready to find their new homes in the hands of deserving survivors and persons affected by the LA Fires that have torn through their home towns.

Over the past weeks, dozens of boxed have appeared at our partner school, Little Dolphins Pre School, and brought over to this graciously donated space for our tireless volunteers and @bymadre team to make sense of the inventory and merchandise it in a way that it would provide an experience of ease, delight, and hope for survivors preparing for this next chapter of their lives. 

We are happy announce the dates of the first of our a free & curated
shopping experience for survivors & *those affected by the LA Fires.

First up: Pacific Palisades.

Due to proximity and a fire relief concert happening at the same time at Little Dolphins by the Sea, we are hosting Palisades Fire survivors first and then next weekend Altadena residents and Eaton Fire survivors on Feb 15-16th.

All inventory has been sorted and separated equally before any distribution takes place, in our efforts to serve each community equally in the best way we can. 

Featuring lovingly inspected new & like-new
clothing for ADULTS & CHILDREN from brands like:
Petite Plume
Hill House Home
The Who Shirt Company
Felicity & Coco
Citizens of Humanity
Industry of All Nations
...and so many more.

We look forward to greeting you!

1812 Stanford Street, Santa Monica, CA 90272, 12pm-5pm Saturday and Sunday February 8th & 9th, 2025. 

xM and team

#EatonFire #PalisadesFire #LAFires #AltadenaStrong #PalisadesStrong

Seeing this map of Altadena, marking the homes lost in the fire (red) was a shock. My mom‚Äôs former house was one of them. 

While I‚Äôm BEYOND grateful she had long since moved, my heart is with those who lived there now‚Äî praying they got out safely and that they find the strength to rebuild. üôèüèª

Sharing a glimpse of her backyard and kitchen from 1997 that my husband took as a small reminder of what once was.

The star-studded FireAid concerts raised $100 million for wildfire relief efforts last week while the Grammy Awards weekend brought in $24 million for similar efforts, organizers announced Tuesday.‚Å†
‚Å†
FireAid, which featured more than 30 acts including Lady Gaga, Billie Eilish, Stevie Wonder, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Stevie Nicks, and a surprise Nirvana reunion, took place at the Kia Forum and Intuit Dome in Inglewood on Thursday.‚Å†
‚Å†
In addition to fans inside the arenas, FireAid was seen by about 50 million viewers on 28 different streaming platforms, all of which offered viewers a chance to donate as they watched.‚Å†
‚Å†
The $100 million estimate announced Tuesday included sales of tickets and merchandise, sponsorships, large donations by artists such as the Eagles and U2 who did not perform, and contributions from the Irving Azoff family, Andrew Hauptman and Ellen Bronfman Hauptman, and more.‚Å†
‚Å†
The Los Angeles Clippers, whose home is Intuit Dome, covered operating costs. Steve and Connie Balmer, who own the Clippers and their arena, matched every pledge made during the broadcast of FireAid.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†

It's not you, it's me.

How many relationships of yours have changed under the umbrella of those words, even though you knew full well it was them?

I feel like I'm in the throws of a bad breakup. I'm constantly reminded of all these things I had a relationship with that were lost in the #eatonfire.

Saying that it was just stuff is well meaning, but it's still like someone telling me that the person in the casket is in a better place despite that person having been a proud unrepentant sinner. It's meant to shift perspective into somethingpositive, but doesn't always track.

Yeah, some of those things I don't care about.

Other things cut deep. Because it isn't replaceable. It was an integral part of the story of my identity. It's like losing an organ I can live without, but one of enough significance I imagine I'll have phantom limb sensations for at least the foreseeable future.

And each of those phantom limbs prick and tingle, impairing my concentration.

But I've had a lot of conversations recently that weren't all about me or the fire.

I won't put any one else's business in the streets, but I'm seeing others suffering right now with recent tragedies of their own.

And if you're reading this and we commiserated in the past few weeks I see you. And I have no words that can provide adequate comfort, but it isn't for lack of seeking them.

I came across this self-portrait called "The Rain Again" that I took one night with my smart phone of my reflection in the kitchen window.

That phone pretty much stowed away somehow and was saved from the fire even though I've had two phones since.

I don't remember grabbing it, but the three rings I didn't take that were next to where I remember leaving it are all phantom limbs now.

Part of me wants to go back and clean this post up from all my mental meandering. But this is my real-time state right now and I think it's as important to show my current struggles as it will be to publicly celebrate my future triumphs.

Because as platitudes go, "this too shall pass" is one I can get with. I'll recover phantom limbs or no.

Because there is a significant difference in this heartbreak, and I'll explain what that is soon.

I still don't know how to put it into words.

This family photo was taken three days before the Eaton Fire.

The large park, once a symbol of peace with its constant bird songs, children climbing trees and running around, and the weekend farmers' market, is now changed.

Fortunately, my own home and family were safe, but friends lost their homes, and cherished places like parks, supermarkets, and cafes we frequented are gone.

It's been less than a month since it happened. Amidst the sadness, everyone is supporting each other, and I feel a strong sense of unity.

Having experienced the Kobe earthquake and knowing that recovery was achieved, I believe that, although it will take time, with everyone's cooperation, we can surely rebuild and look forward to a brighter future.

Had to head to Malibu today to check on a few of our listings and chose to take PCH instead of going up and around through Kanan which we‚Äôve had to do since they shut down the road. This was my first time making this drive since the fires tore through last month.

The devastation along the coast is absolutely staggering. Seeing the aftermath firsthand was heartbreaking‚Äîcharred landscapes, homes reduced to rubble, and a silence that felt as heavy as the grief in the air. At one point, I almost turned around because it was just too much to take in.

My heart goes out to everyone who has been displaced, to those who lost their homes, their memories, and so much more. LA is hurting, and today‚Äôs drive was just a small glimpse of that pain.

But through the ashes, there is hope. This city, these communities, and the people who call them home are resilient. We‚Äôve seen it before, and we‚Äôll see it again‚Äîrebuilding, coming together, and rising stronger than ever. The road to recovery won‚Äôt be easy, but light always finds a way through the darkness. Malibu, Palisades and Altadena will heal, and so will we.

.
.
.

I finally was able to make into Upper Hastings Ranch on Monday which was one of the first areas to lose houses in the Eaton Fire, but it has been somewhat overlooked because of the total devastation in Altadena. This image shows how randomly the fire moved through Upper Hastings Ranch, burning some homes to the ground while leaving others with minimal damage only from smoke.
Growing up I had a lot of friends in lower Hastings Ranch which is the Eastern most part of Pasadena. Upper Hastings goes right up into the San Gabriel Mountains and as a teenager we liked to go up there at night for the view of the city lights. 
The Eaton Fire started around 6:15pm. When my buddy and I went to In-N-Out to eat at 11:40pm the guy in line behind us told us he had already lost his house in Upper Hastings. The Eaton Fire moved in three general directions after it started. The fasted part moved straight South along the East side of Altadena drive. At the same time the Eastern flank went along the mountains. It miraculously seemed to burn the mountains above Kinneloa Mesa before travelling further East and eventually into Upper Hastings Ranch. When Upper Hastings started burning the winds were high and it looks like the topography had a lot to do with which homes burned and which were spared. I am not sure how long Upper Hastings burned, the fire on that side burned along the mountain and eventually took out a few homes in Sierra Madre and Arcadia from what I know. All of Eaton Canyon burned and the third direction the fire moved was West along the mountain and sporadically down into the residential area. There were a few homes lost here but I think the wind direction had a lot to do with so few since it didn‚Äôt seem consistent in direction. Sometime after midnight the winds seemed to head mostly West and it was then Altadena got hit with a firestorm. The area between Allen and Lake, North of New York, burned well into Wednesday morning but the loss was sporadic since the winds had subsided.

Our hearts are with everyone affected by the Eaton Fire. In difficult times like these, we are reminded of the power of community and the importance of coming together to support those in need. Our longtime partner, Boys & Girls Club of Pasadena, is stepping up in a big way to help local families recover.

üíô Family Assistance Fund ‚Äì BGCP is offering financial assistance (up to $500) to BGCP families most impacted by the fire. Apply at https://www.bgcpasadena.org/family-assistance-fund-application

There‚Äôs a kind of exhaustion that doesn‚Äôt just live in the body‚Äîit lives in the mind, in the nervous system, in the space between who you were before and who you‚Äôre becoming now. It‚Äôs not just about needing rest. It‚Äôs about how grief rewires us, how loss fractures focus, how even the smallest tasks feel insurmountable when nothing feels certain anymore.

If you‚Äôve felt this, if you‚Äôve found yourself forgetting simple things, feeling drained by decisions that used to be automatic, struggling to keep up with a life that no longer moves the way it once did‚Äîyou are not failing. Your mind is working harder than it ever has to process change, to make sense of what no longer fits, to rebuild the instincts that used to guide you without thought.

Right now, even if it feels impossible, even if you don‚Äôt recognize yourself in this version of life‚Äîyou are adapting. Your brain is learning new rhythms. The weight you feel isn‚Äôt a sign that you‚Äôre breaking. It‚Äôs proof that you‚Äôre still here, still holding on, still finding your way forward.

-Dr. Z

‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π We got a house! Now we can begin the process of making it a home. This week was highs and lows. 

It‚Äôs been a long month. We are meeting with our lawyers, adjustors, claim agents and everything in between which takes up a lot of time. We‚Äôve gone back a few times and found a few items, most just crumble in your hand but it‚Äôs still a bit of closure. Each time ‚Äúhome‚Äù we see neighbors and connect even more about this travesty. It‚Äôs such a beautiful community.

They have started the process of removing vehicles, propane and hazordous items off the property then comes the major clean up including inches of soil.

Everyone is in full white hazmat type suits as you drive around, it feels like we are living in the ET movie. Entering Altadena (and Palisades) it feels like time has frozen, my breath is taken away every time.

üê¥ Cali is good, safe and loved. I‚Äôm slowly rebuilding some riding clothes and hope to be back galloping hills soon together. 

üè† Link to our Amazon list for items for our home in my bio. 

Grateful for everyone that has checked in, come to visits, got us meals, sent us links, called us, donated, stored our stuff, got our mail, housed us, got items off the list and everything in between. We really do appreciate you ü•π.#Altadena #altadenastrong #eatonfire

Day #29 (?) of Grief - Raw pic of my current status since I evacuated and lost my home from the Eaton Fire. I‚Äôm tired so tired. Emotionally exhausted. I‚Äôve cried more in a month than I have in years.

Trying to figure out whats next. Everything is a priority and everything is not. Sometimes I just wanna lay down and sleep for days but I don‚Äôt have that luxury right now. The ptsd is real. Reached my breaking point yesterday. What a mess. I look a mess lol.

Probably going to start documenting the process of grief and trauma. Losing my pictures and momentos and cards and notes from over the years really fucked me up. I love physical media. I love physical reminders of love and friendship and memories. But that‚Äôs all gone. How will I remember people now? My memory is foggy nowadays. I forget a lot. All my collections over the years. How will people remember me? What can I pass on to future generations for people to know who I am? For someone who fears being forgotten, losing it ALL has really done a number of my person. So maybe using social media will help me navigate that problem. Idk. Idk what to do anymore.
#eatonfire #altadena #lafire #pasadena #grief #trauma

This is one of those days. I‚Äôve shared lots of smiles. But this is most mornings. Tired, massive bags under my eyes and not wanting to get out of bed. Usually I have some place to be- but not today. Still have things that need to get done, but I just don‚Äôt want to. I‚Äôm getting lots of advice from well meaning people, but also- for anyone going through trauma and grief, sometimes the well meaning thoughts just add to the exhaustion. Sometimes we just need to sit and be still and maybe sleep a lot of hours since sleep isn‚Äôt happening at night. 

So for those of us out there- take it at YOUR pace, day by day. Listen to YOUR body. Your body has physical, mental and emotional healing to do and if we avoid it long enough, your body will smack you in the face and let you know!

#TraumaHealing
#EatonFire
#MentalHealth

It's going to be such a fun day, and we cannot wait to see you!

When you understand the power of your stillness, you will realize that the clarity you seek emerges not from chasing answers but from allowing them to arise in the quiet spaces between thoughts. 

Chaos thrives on reaction, demanding urgency and noise, but it will never offer the wisdom that waits patiently within the calm. 

In stillness, intuition speaks, solutions unfold, and a deeper truth reveals itself; one that no amount of rushing or striving could ever uncover.‚ú®

Hope After Wildfires üå±üî• Lahaina‚Äôs iconic Banyan Tree, standing tall for 150 years, is sprouting new growth‚Äîa symbol of resilience, renewal, and the strength of community. 18 months after the town‚Äôs devastating wildfire, this tree continues to recover, reminding us that even in destruction, life finds a way forward.

Just like this tree, rebuilding after wildfires requires patience, strength, and thoughtful design. A fire-resilient future means homes and communities that can withstand extreme conditions while honoring the past. Sustainability isn‚Äôt just about materials and energy‚Äîit‚Äôs about creating spaces that endure. üåøüè°

I was born in Lahaina, and my family has lived there for generations. The impact of the devastation strengthened my commitment to designing and building wildfire-resilient homes. Rebuilding isn‚Äôt just about recovery‚Äîit‚Äôs about creating communities that can withstand future challenges while honoring their history. My work continues to focus on resilience, sustainability, and ensuring that what we build today can endure for generations to come. üí´

üì≤ Follow @californiahomedesigns for more on wildfire-resilient home design and building sustainable communities. üè°üåç

Altadena Family Files Lawsuit Over Eaton Fire Devastation

Lawsuit Filed Against Southern CA Edison.¬† 

An Altadena family is seeking justice for the extensive damage and catastrophic losses caused by the Eaton Fire. The Wildfire Consortium‚Äîa powerhouse legal team from Walkup Melodia Kelly & Schoenberger, Cotchett Pitre & McCarthy, LLP, and Panish | Shea | Ravipudi LLP represents the Seetal family. Our team alleges SCE‚Äôs negligence in maintaining and de-powering high-voltage equipment contributed to the fire and underscores SCE‚Äôs failure to address wildfire risks, despite nearly 300,000 acres burned in LA County wildfires since 2016.

Wildfire Debris Removal

What LA County Property Owners Need to Know

To insure a swift & safe recovery after the recent wildfires. Here‚Äôs how the debris removal process will be achieved.

Phase 1: EPA handles hazardous debris (No signup needed!)

Phase 2: Property owners must choose:

‚úÖ Opt In - Free cleanup by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
‚ùå Opt Out - Hire an approved contractor & cover costs

Important: You must complete Phase 1 clearance before getting a Phase 2 permit for cleanup.

Need more details? Visit LA County Recovers for official guidelines.

locationName: Mary W. Jackson STEAM Multilingual Magnet Elementary
caption:
This one is personal. 

Four weeks ago today, Frankie‚Äôs incredible first-grade teacher, Maestra Georgina Sanchez, lost her home of 30 years in the devastating Eaton Fire. After evacuating to San Gabriel, she and her family of five are now working to rebuild their lives in Alhambra.

Despite everything, Maestra Sanchez returned to her Jackson Elementary classroom just days ago, showing the same warmth, dedication, and resilience that make her such a beloved teacher. Frankie and her classmates missed her so much - least we can do is support her and family through these incredibly challenging and uncertain times and show her how much she means to the kids at Jackson.

We are asking our incredible NS community far and wide to come together for a public school teacher who gives so much to our children.  Please share, spread the word, and help us make a difference. Every donation, big or small, brings her family closer to stability. 

Let‚Äôs get Maestra Sanchez fully funded üèÅ

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @ktla5news Berry or Victor as known affectionately by locals, barely survived the wildfires. 

A homeowner forced to evacuate due to the catastrophic Los Angeles wildfires returned home to find a massive 525-pound black bear hiding in his crawlspace.

Samy Arbid said that the huge unexpected visitor was found when utility workers called  to restore power to his Altadena home after the Eaton Fire found their access point blocked. ‚ÄúI think during the fire he pretty much stayed in there,‚Äù Arbid said. ‚ÄúI think he was scared.‚Äù

Berry was too big to tranquillize and drag out,  so wildlife experts baited him into a trap with tasty food that included apples, peanut butter and rotisserie chicken. Within minutes, the bear walked into the trap and triggered the door. Berry was transported to the Angeles National Forest where he was given a welfare check and strapped with a collar before its safe release.ü•πüíó

üì∏ California Department of Fish and Wildlife

#bearsofinstagram #bear #eatonfire #survivor

Project Highlight : The Disaster After the Disaster

Join Christiahn (@christiahn) on a mission to inform and protect our community against the toxic waste created and dispersed by the fires. 

Not everyone is aware of the invisible danger created in the wake of the fires. The burning of asbestos-filled drywall, PVC pipes, and lead paint along with various chemicals and plastics has created toxic waste that poses long-term extreme health hazards. Generous volunteers helping to remove debris are being exposed without the appropriate personal protection equipment. Even those adjacent to fire-affected areas are exposed to this waste from toxic particulate carried by the winds. 

How can we insure that all of LA‚Äôs communities, including those most vulnerable, are informed and protected? This collaborative effort aims to do just that. 

This project is currently seeking help in these areas:
- Artists
- Copy Writers 
- Subject Matter Experts
- Designers 
- Native Speakers / Translators

Reach out directly or join our community by:

Filling out our form. Link in bio.
Emailing us @  designfordisasterresponse@gmail.com
Joining our FB Group :  Design for Disaster Response

Federal and local agencies tasked with fire cleanup said on Wednesday that they are expecting to haul away over four million tons of contaminated debris ‚Äî with much of it slated to end up in an increasing number of local landfills, as well as out of state.

Some of the most hazardous items from phase one of the cleanup are likely to end up in Arizona and Nevada, according to Michael Montgomery with the EPA, who is overseeing the cleanup effort.

Last week, Mark Pestrella, the director of county public works, announced that four local landfills would take in some fire debris, though exactly what is still unclear. But on Wednesday, he upped that number to 17 landfills across LA County and Ventura County, including in Simi Valley and Azusa, where material from five schools in Pasadena will go. An LA County Public Works spokesperson did not provide LA Public Press with a requested list of the landfills slated for use.

Montomery also did not answer LA Public Press‚Äôs question about where exactly the toxic waste from phase one of the cleanup will permanently end up. An EPA spokesperson also declined to provide LA Public Press with a list of the facilities. 

Read the full story by Ashley Orona (@oronash) via the link in the bio or go to LAPublicPress.org.

From the moment I woke this morning, I was all about managing my energy. 

And the effort was worth it. It carried me through multiple setbacks and allowed me to keep relative peace until I got the email announcement for this.

My entry in the Circle Foundation for the Arts Artist of the Year competition was put in barely two days before the closing date due to the #Eatonfire and all the scrambling and disruption that immediately followed.

But I got it in regardless, and out of 500+ artists, got a little bit of shine out of it.

So about those plans for 2025, part of it is raising my profile and this was the first of several initiatives I'm setting in motion in response to the losses and a recapturing of the potential I originally saw in 2025.

I refuse to cede this entire year no matter how bad it started.

The hard days aren't over, but neither are the good days, I'll make damn sure of that.

üíõ If you or someone you know is experiencing survivor‚Äôs guilt or other strong emotions after a #disaster, it‚Äôs essential to recognize that these feelings are a natural response to an extraordinary event.

Here are some steps that may help:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Acknowledge Your Feelings.
Allow yourself to feel the emotions without judgment. Writing in a journal or sharing with a trusted friend or counselor can be helpful. Embrace and notice your tears.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Seek Professional Support.
Therapists trained in trauma and resilience can help survivors process their experiences.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Engage in Community Support.
Being part of a supportive community fosters connection and collective healing. As the rebuilding process begins, it can also give meaning and purpose to one‚Äôs life.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Practice Self-Care.
Activities that promote physical and emotional health, such as regular exercise, mindfulness practices, or spending time in nature, can help regulate stress and enhance resilience. A simple walk with a friend can renew one‚Äôs energy.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Focus on the Present.
While it‚Äôs natural to reflect on the past, grounding techniques‚Äîsuch as noticing sights, sounds, and sensations around you‚Äîcan anchor you to the present moment and reduce distressing thoughts.

Mindfulness practices like the Community Resiliency Model (CRM) provide practical tools for managing distress and reconnecting with a sense of well-being.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Participate in Faith Communities.
Many faith communities continue their ministries even though their church, synagogue, or temple may have been destroyed.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Engage in and Notice Acts of Generosity.
This engagement activates brain circuits that support well-being, whether witnessed, received, or given. 

Human beings can cultivate skills that directly influence the strength of the generosity circuit, so try to participate in acts of generosity.

üìñ Read the full article by Elaine Miller-Karas on @Psych_Today : https://bit.ly/3E6FHxw

@chefjoseandres and @wckitchen are ultimate heroes in my eyes. For the many of us who have been displaced with the fires in Southern California, for me, particularly with the Eaton fire, world Central kitchen has ensured that they are widely available for members of the community who were affected by the fires to access good hot meals for themselves and their families. It has been completely eye-opening to me to witness their presence all around the community. If you have the means, I strongly encourage you to donate or volunteer to this amazing organization. As soon as I get my wits about me and get a little bit more steadier on my feet, this is the first organization I plan to put my money and energy toward. They 100% support the community with no judgment, and with all the warmth and love people experiencing tragedy need in the moment and throughout the horrific process of trying to figure out next steps.

I have witnessed through social media, their work across the country in the world. But I have never seen something so amazing firsthand.

R.I.P. to my aunt Evelyn McClendon üïäÔ∏è who was the 1st confirmed victim of the Altadena Eaton fire. She üïäÔ∏è was so intelligent, beautiful, and gentle. She üïäÔ∏è was very private and reclusive person that kept to herself. I would call her the hermit of the family because Evelyn üïäÔ∏èwould rarely leave her house to show up for functions. However, every time I had a big event she would get out of her comfort zone and come show me support. I remember the entire family being in shock to see her at my high school graduation, my wedding, and kids birthday parties. What they didn‚Äôt know is I would go over, sit, and have talks about religion for hours. That was our thing to talk about different religions and spiritual beliefs and before you know it 2-3 hours had passed. It is truly a shame that her death will be used today by Al Sharpton, Ben Crump and his team of lawyers as a rally to score political points or capital. This is definitely something she would not want. Like I said she üïäÔ∏è was a very private person so to have a memorial and rally in her name with most people in attendance not even knowing who she üïäÔ∏è was while alive is a bit weird. In fact my sister and I use to joke with my parents that if we ever died and the police were involved whatever you do don‚Äôt call Al Sharpton. So I refuse to partake in this dog and pony show. I refuse to be a pawn for those individuals who live, profit, and thrive off of black pain and grief. If Crump and his team truly cared about my family they would have met us weeks ago instead of meeting for the 1st time today at the memorial. If they truly cared they would have attended my cousin üïäÔ∏è Chanell‚Äôs funeral on January 17th and met the majority of our family. I don‚Äôt want a penny from Crump. I want Kathryn Barger who claims she cares and is fighting for the people of Altadena, yet has not reached out to victims families to be held accountable. I want SoCal Edison who has ripped off the people of Altadena for decades to be held accountable. I want the county of Los Angeles and whoever is in charge of the alert system to be held accountable.

RESTORE, REBUILD, RENEW!

#rip #resteasyauntie #altadena #altadenafire #eatonfire #denanatives

Update on Burned Vehicle Towing & Resident Concerns 

We understand the concerns about notices residents have received regarding vehicle towing. Here‚Äôs what you need to know:

üî• Why were vehicles towed?
‚úîÔ∏è CHP was directed by Fire Command to clear burned-out vehicles from public roads to restore utilities & ensure access for emergency crews.
‚úîÔ∏è Tows followed California Vehicle Code 22669(d) & were conducted with CHP-authorized rotation tow companies (which have fixed rates).
‚úîÔ∏è CHP does NOT receive fees for these tows.

Need help?
üìå Concerns about towing fees? Contact CHP to report service issues.
üìå Insurance claims? If you received a tow invoice, reach out to your insurance provider for guidance.
üìå CHP assisted in identifying VINs so insurance companies can properly compensate vehicle owners.

We know this is a challenging time, and we‚Äôre here to help. Please share this info with affected residents.

Since we are getting inquiries asking about this effort, we will clarify. The main question is "How did they get it so right?" THEY LISTENED. 

They convened. They asked the community, and they listened. Our part is one small corner of a large universe of empathetic, intelligent listening.

Experienced megafire / disaster communities will recognize the structure and, like us, wish this was possible for everyone. It's what you all do or have done, with massive support.

We love this.

**************************
Our Approach

Provide project management support to ease the burden of rebuilding.

Facilitate community organizing to ensure voices are heard.

Connect communities to each other and to vital resources.

Invest in and support expert-informed solutions to shape our collective future.

Spent last week in Los Angeles, filming stories about the aftermath of the fires. We met some lovely, inspiring people who are doing their best to get back to normal, and preserve what they loved most about their home. More from them soon on @newshour 

Here‚Äôs some of what I saw in Altadena, CA. I‚Äôve covered so many different extreme disasters (hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes, fires) and each has a different fingerprint in the way it rips up and distorts the order we try to put on the world. Captions below. 

1. A group from the California Conservation Corps carry a large filter (it's basically a mesh sock filled with mulch). They ring these around burned homes and cars after a fire to try and prevent any additional toxic runoff from the sites ending up in the local water system.

2. The interior of a burned out car with the windshield glass melted down onto the steering wheel.

3. Inside a shipping container on a building site.

4. A rivulet of melted steel. These are all over the place. 

5. Besides various metal objects (washing machines, bedsprings, etc), dishes and pottery are often the only recognizeable household items left after a house burns. 

6. Ruined out home in Altadena

7. "NOT EV" is spray-painted on all the non-electric cars, to signal to clean-up crews that they don't need to remove a gigantic lititum-ion battery from the wreckage.

It has been about a month since the LA wildfires began in January. With now full containment the city tries to move forward. Yet, moving forward looks different for everyone. Some mourn the loss of their homes, others grieve loved ones. From massage therapists to labor workers, from the unhoused now further displaced‚Äîmany have been touched by the devastation. The city feels fractured, its wounds still fresh. Yet, the spirit of community, the pillar of Angelenos, holds strong. 

Meeting each person where they are physically, mentally, and emotionally, these are some portraits of Angelenos I have shared space with these past few weeks. I love you LA. üíú

Sogol Moshfegh and Daniel Clason Hook lost their home to the Eaton Fire in Altadena, Calif. The couple has temporarily rented a house in Monrovia with their two young sons as the family considers their next steps. @npr 

Kathleen McCalpin, a 62-year-old independent masseuse, lost her home in Topanga Canyon when the Palisades Fire. @wsj 

Dalyce Kelley lost her grandmother Dalyce Curry in the Eaton Fire in Altadena. @washingtonpost 

Denise Jones has been leaning on her family after losing their Altadena home to the Eaton Fire. @wsj 

Antonieta Lopez and her daughter Daysi Garcia Lopez in West Los Angeles have been out of work since the Palisades Fire. @wsj 

Antonio Miller at Central Park in Pasadena. Miller‚Äôs Altadena apartment burned in the Eaton Fire and he has been sleeping in public places since. @highcountrynews 

Robert Bullock outside the Robinson Park Recreation Center in Pasadena, California. Bullock has lived in the area his entire life. @highcountrynews 

Darren Myles outside the Robinson Park Recreation Center. Myles has lived in his car in the area for the last few years. For the past week, he‚Äôs slept while wearing an N-95 mask to avoid the wildfire smoke. @highcountrynews

Eaton Fire, Altadena CA

My efforts are to creatively and accurately capture the moment I‚Äôve stumbled upon as a photographer. But when it‚Äôs devastation to something so familiar, when they are my streets that have been destroyed, my town, the houses and shops I‚Äôm used to passing by, I can‚Äôt help but be paralyzed, stop and stare. 

I regret not capturing more that day, but the shock of this fire definitely took its toll. Sometimes silently staring at the devastation to process what has happened is all you can do. After viewing it all, I returned home smelling like dirty, toxic smoke from head to toe. I showered in a bathroom lit by a lantern and returned to an unheated bedroom to reply to concerned friends and check up on those who were displaced and in worse conditions than me

This is what community looks like! Making sure 272 displaced residents don‚Äôt get suddenly turned on to the street. 

The work isn‚Äôt done but we did spoil the Red Cross and City of Pasadena‚Äôs verbal and contractual plan to quietly close the Pasadena Convention Center by exposing them and holding them to account.

We need to push for long term, sustainable transitional and permanent housing solutions for all fire survivors and displaced residents. Our neighbors don‚Äôt want to move out of the county or state and they shouldn‚Äôt have to or have to go homeless. 

Let‚Äôs keep pushing to keep everyone safe and housed! Thank you to everyone who called, showed up and showed support for the displaced residents. Together we fought for more time and for more answers! 

We still have yet to see what the ‚Äúnew location‚Äù for the Red Cross shelter will be. We have yet to see real long term housing options. So let‚Äôs keep fighting for the response we want to see and the treatment that Eaton Fire survivors deserve.

Frozen in time. I was down to my last week of installing, lighting, and cleaning up for my first studio visit since before the beginning of the pandemic. The visit was scheduled for Jan. 15. The fire blew through Altadena on the 7th/8th. Too many people lost everything. My studio is still standing. I am not yet sure what I still have. I am determined to salvage my art. I am one of the lucky ones. My heart breaks for everyone. I cry every day on my drive to my studio. My drive takes me through a nightmare. My work for this ‚Äúproof of concept‚Äù is/was several years in the making. Work sits unfinished. Installation sits unfinished, lighting unfinished.. Cleanup can‚Äôt even get started. Waiting. Waiting for insurance adjusters. Waiting for a conservators. Waiting. The gallery side of my studio needs the least work. That art has the least amount of ash/soot‚Ä¶whatever. However, full remediation will still have to be done. The gallery feels/looks like a magical oasis in the middle of a war zone. My main work space, smells like a barbecue, and several areas have a layer of ash. In order to remediate the entire building, my options are few, and the logistics are a nightmare. I have collected a lot of materials that are heading to the trash. No need in keeping anything but that which is salvageable. No need in salvaging that which is easily replaceable. Meanwhile‚Ä¶waiting. The last picture is of ash on a couple of small proofs on a table, below one of the windows where some of the ash came in. #kiravollmanart #eatonfire #altadenastrong #kiravollman #mixedmedia #surrealism #laartist

On January 7th, 2025, the Eaton fire tore through the beloved town of Altadena, CA.

Many lost their homes and business, including my friend Jacob, owner of @acesmokeshop1altadena , who lost his sm0k3shop - a well-loved staple on the main street (Lake Street) of this beautiful town.

---

Not only did Jacob provide a warm and welcoming environment for his patrons, but he is a pillar of the community, allowing all sorts of small businesses to set up stalls in front of his shop.

üôèüèªüåπüôèüèª

In spring of 2022 (on my way back to Nor Cal from Las Vegas) I got the opportunity to visit Jacob at his shop, and walk along the scenic streets of Altadena. An unforgettable moment of my life.

From that day forward, up until this tragic fire, Ace Sm0k3sh0p had been the only store in Southern California to carry Herba Rosa botanical teas. Since my original post is gone, I thought it fitting to immortalize this moment in memory of this beautiful city.

---

I truly believe in the Spirit of Altadena and it's people - their ability to rise from the ashes and come back stronger than ever. Like a Phoenix. This spirit lives strong within Jacob, who has selflessly used his time and platform to provide help and service to the svffering people throughout the recovery effort.

---

Please follow his page @acesmokeshop1altadena
and if you want to help the recovery of this business and support the employees he had provided for, he has a gofvndme l1nk on his page.

Any contribution is appreciated, but I know many folks are struggling right now, so a simple like on this post will help spread the word.

Thank you! üôèüèª

Introducing our latest coffee drop: Super Scooper ‚Äì a bold tribute to the real-life heroes of the Los Angeles Palisades and Eaton fires.

Named after the legendary CL-415 ‚ÄúSuper Scooper‚Äù aircraft, this drop honors the fearless pilots and crews who battle wildfires from the sky. These amphibious planes can scoop up 1,620 gallons (6,140 liters) of water in just 12 seconds and drop it with precision over raging fires. Built for extreme conditions, the CL-415 is a symbol of resilience, agility, and unwavering courage‚Äîjust like the people who fly them.

For those who soar into danger when others seek safety‚Äîthis brew‚Äôs for you.

Now that the fires are 100% contained ‚Äî LA, I‚Äôm not sure I have the words. It‚Äôs been such a sad, heavy and confusing time. I‚Äôm just so sorry and deeply heartbroken for my city. It‚Äôs beyond comprehension and truly unbelievable how reality can shift so drastically, so quickly. The utter devastation from the fires, and implications for individuals and our city are unimaginable. While I‚Äôm grateful I‚Äôm safe, I‚Äôm heartbroken for those communities, people, animals, and wildlife who aren‚Äôt as fortunate. To those who have been affected or impacted, please know that you are in my thoughts and prayers during this incredibly difficult time.

I‚Äôm an LA native and I love my city so much. LA always has, and always will be, my home. I even have an LA tattoo; my very first tattoo that I got at 19. Pic two is little water baby me in Malibu, a city that is now unrecognizable. My heart has been so heavy seeing the devastation caused by these fires. There‚Äôs this element of grief because there are memories made in parts of the city, and in communities, which have been completely wiped. Neighborhoods just vaporized.

Thank you to the brave and incredible first responders who have been working non-stop on the front lines - firefighters, law enforcement, the national guard, paramedics, pilots, mechanics, DWP, etc. They‚Äôre the real heroes.

I‚Äôm deeply moved by our community coming together, uniting, and supporting one another through this time of hardship. The strength of our community shines brightest as we work toward recovery. When society inevitably begins to move on and focus on the next ‚Äúthing‚Äù, I pray people will continue to donate, volunteer, amplify victims‚Äô stories, foster displaced animals, share resources, and help rebuild communities. I invite you to lead with compassion, kindness, patience, and most importantly - love.

If you are looking for ways to help, I‚Äôve added a highlight where you can find all the resources I‚Äôve shared thus far.

I love you, Los Angeles ‚ù§Ô∏è Together, we‚Äôll rise stronger than ever ‚Äî because that‚Äôs the LA way.

It‚Äôs been a month. For real. 

The blue skies and birds have returned to their normal. What remains is a cacophony of sounds from gas companies jack hammering streets to close off lines to burnt homes, to trucks and cranes buzzing around carrying electrical poles, to EPA trucks removing hazardous waste. 

And if I weren‚Äôt so hyper-focused on not losing my job and going to every meeting and every zoom on wildfire toxins and home insurance declarations, I‚Äôd probably have a minute to appreciate the speed and intensity with which government officials at all levels are organizing the work in what‚Äôs left of our community. 

it‚Äôs been a month. A heavy month. 

#eatonfire #pivot #mentalhealthisinthetoilet

Tonight is more than a Friendship Friday post, but a trip around Altadena, discovering the destroyed structures caused by the Eaton Fire. I took a walk around Altadena on February 2nd, exploring the aftermath of the Eaton Fire, which has since reached full containment, and I've seen many structures either damaged or completely destroyed. I also brought Twilight Sparkle over at Charles White Park, where the majority of the park is still there, but the playground and a facility were involved by the fire. I also checked on Altadena Elementary School at Calaveras & El Molino (not pictured), and it was still intact. I then ended the tour of the Eaton Fire Burn Scar in Pasadena, where several structures were damaged or destroyed at Walworth & Highland. Hope everyone is safe inside the shelter during this difficult time.

#twilightsparkle #mylittlepony #friendshipismagic #eatonfire #altadena #AltadenaStrong

What's one thing I can do right now?

I have to ask myself this daily. At least once.

Overwhelm is seldom far away we were going through a difficult stretch before the #EatonFire. And when it hits, I come back to that question of one thing I can do right there in that moment.

Answers thus far have included:

* Making a call or sending a text sometimes to take care of some business that needs handling, but also sometimes to someone who can just lend an ear.

* Crying

* Resting/sleeping

* Tidying up something

* Making one of these posts

* Working on some of my 2025 objectives 

* Streaming something to make me laugh, wonder, or sit in suspense 

* Breathe

There are a few other choices I've made, but these have been regulars this past month.

I had my first therapy session yesterday and I found one idea particularly helpful.

She said that depression and anxiety are the common cold of mental health.

That tracked for me, because I feel like I have parts of grief inside me that are incubating. And my goal with therapy is address my mental health before this 'common cold' becomes pneumonia.

As hard as some days are and as badly as I want to curl up in fetal position, I refuse to accept that this my lot in life.

And it's okay that there's too much out of my control to resolve the things stressing me at any given moment.

I can always find one thing I can do right then at that moment, that may not affect the issue at hand, but still sustains me even if for the next ten minutes.

It's hard to believe but it was just one month ago, on this very night, when wildfires affected so many lives in our community. Since then, we've been thinking about what else we can do to help local families.

Save the Date for our FREE "Healing Through Art & Play" event, happening on February 22nd 9am-12pm. We're going to host a morning of arts, crafts, and music, specially for families affected by the recent wildfires. 

*Limited time slots available, reserve a spot to ensure entry- registration link in bio.

#goplaylab #playlabeaglerock #wildfires #eatonfire #palisadesfire #community #artsandhealing

One month ago today, we lost our home in the Eaton fire and life got turned upside down. I had only been back once, a couple weeks ago, for a brief search through the ashes. After rain the last couple of days I drove the neighborhood from top to bottom to see the extent of the destruction.  To see entire neighborhoods burned to the ground, giving a clear view from one street over to the next, was startling. Familiar landmarks and community hubs like the hardware store and neighboring bike shop were destroyed. My heart hurts for our town and the thousands of families and businesses who lost everything. I wasn‚Äôt sure how to write this post, but I wanted to put down a digital marker to look back at as we forge ahead and build something new. Grateful for the love and support we‚Äôve received from near and far, that helps us keep moving forward.  #altadenastrong #eatonfire

If God will send his Angels - Life changed for thousands a month ago today. My mom is day by day struggling with pain and with hope. I‚Äôm here to thank each one of you who directly reached out. Offering all that you can for my mom. Strangers stepped up.  Loved ones donating and giving what they could. LA is not how they portray it on tv.  True angels showed up. No words on how grateful I and my family are.  It‚Äôs gonna be a long haul for the recovery process.  We are all hands on deck in her life right now and her future. Shining light on her new home. It will stand proud on the foundation that my Dad built for his family of six in Altadena in the 1960‚Äôs.  Also in lock step with our neighbors who are working together to keep our family homes and enjoy our lives once again in such a beautiful place.  I will keep you connected to the process. I want you all to be part of the good news. Because of your direct donations. Continued support and encouragement and most of all your direct hugs and love to my mom. I love you for more than I can express. You are an integral part of this rebuild.  These photos are of what‚Äôs left of my mom‚Äôs home. It may sound cliche but we will rise from the ashes.  It is an emotional roller coaster. I never wish anyone to be forced to evacuate. I never wish for anyone to lose their homes. This is hard. This is heavy stuff.  But you all showed up. You have us in your prayers.  Never did I think I‚Äôd be part of the affected in a moment of silence at a Laker game. Or watching concerts on tv raising money for our burned homes. We never think it‚Äôs gonna happen to us.  I hope those from a distance come with me. I‚Äôll show you around Altadena. I‚Äôll show you blocks after blocks of nothingness.  But awaits for a rebuild full of love. Don‚Äôt separate yourself from this.  Keep thinking of ways to help. Not just my mom. The residents of your neighborhood are in need.  I thank you once more for all that you‚Äôve already have done. The song I chose is by U2 ‚ÄúIf God will send his Angels‚Äù. That he did. You showed up. All of my love üôèüèΩ‚ù§Ô∏è #altadena #altadenacalifornia #denastrong #eatonfire #hopeful #prayersup #prayerstillworks #pasadena #pasadenacalifornia

2 weeks before the #eatonfire destroyed our home, I gifted sets of bowls to my sister and brother for Christmas. I particularly loved these bowls and their glaze combinations of matte black with amber celadon rims, and remembered thinking selfishly if I should keep the set for myself, but I ended up choosing the worst one of the bunch as a keepsake and gifting the rest. 
I found that bowl in the rubble of our home the other day, with a patina of ash from its second firing, and felt immensely grateful my siblings had their sets tucked safely away in their cabinets. 
Pictured are the freshly thrown bowls drying in the sun, and ready for their glaze firing.

It‚Äôs a volcanic eruption to have ‚Äúhome‚Äù suddenly vanish. It cuts a hole in your chest and drops a bowling ball there that you have to lug around while you pick up the pieces and triage your life.

The update after the #EatonFire a month ago is that my head is constantly foggy. The rental market is hot garbage. I‚Äôm emotional, exhausted, distracted, irritable and worried about many others in our #Altadena community that I hear about.

I still can‚Äôt grasp that this also happened on the other side of LA in Malibu and the Palisades. I still cry looking at Google satellite images of our town. I cried in the car this morning. I guess this is grief.

Much of this month I felt like I was watching this all happen to someone else... my little brother taking me shopping at Target, nervously talking with FEMA at makeshift disaster centers, screaming on the phone with renter‚Äôs insurance, telling the Red Cross yes we need disaster assistance, and digging through toxic ash and twisted metal 3 different times for proof of our previous life.

I don‚Äôt know how me or Danny could have gotten through those frantic first weeks without the help and generosity of family ‚ù§Ô∏è friends and strangers. We‚Äôve cried over their generosity many times.

Even this week, more tears as I received a new turntable and vinyl records from a group of my friends who banded together to help us start over.

We didn‚Äôt do a fundraiser. Don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll realize how much stuff we need to rebuild until we move into a new place with pretty much nothing to move in. Maybe then we‚Äôll ask for help...uncomfortable as that will be.

Right now we‚Äôre trying to pay it forward by checking on and helping out neighbors (now friends) who lost much more than we did.

Thank you to our family for going above & beyond üíú

Thank you a THOUSAND times over to my cousin who has given us a comfortable place to layover in üôè

And thank you for reaching out over the past month. I may not have been able to respond but please know I saw you, I heard you and I appreciate you.

If you want to help fire survivors directly, DM me and I‚Äôll send you legitimate links to those whom I know need help. 

Long live #BeautifulAltadena. We love you.

This past week I returned to my home town, Altadena. It was a journey through time and many memories. The Eaton Fire destroyed most of the town including my dad‚Äôs home and damaged my brother‚Äôs home. I sifted through ashes to see if I could find pieces of my childhood. It was part of the grieving process, but also a realization that at the very end, you can‚Äôt take ‚Äòthings‚Äô with you. The school and church that I went to are still standing, but what does the future hold when there is no one around to fill the desks and pews. Altadena was a beautiful place at the foot of the mountains. Homes were known by the last names of the families that resided there. There were no track homes, instead individuality and architectural features were applauded. What will happen next? Who will rebuild? How long will it take before there is life in this town? So many questions and not many answers. #altadena #eatonfire #staystrong #mountains #memories @visitaltadena

Eaton Fire Aftermath

I am saddened that this had to be the first post of the year.
The LA County Fires of 2025 burned the livelihoods of so many down to the ground, leaving more than 40,000 acres, 16,000 structures and dozens of lives destroyed. It was by far the most destructive event the city has ever gone through.
I personally experienced a prolonged power outage and extremely hazardous air quality for days, but so many people had to abruptly leave their homes and belongings behind, and for some, for good. That‚Äôs a scary thought, I thought, and it can happen to anyone.
Much anticipated rainfall came after almost 9 months of drought, just 2 weeks shy of the start of the fires. It helped with containment of fires and lifted some of the road blocks, so the residents were finally able to return to their homes, now looking nothing like how they left it.
I had a privilege to volunteer in Altadena with @dj2high @parukaokay @yoshihiro_imae @ringdabingo thanks to generous support from @pocarisweatusa to donate and distribute #PocariSweat to the first responders in the burn zones and had an opportunity to document the aftermath.
My heart goes out to everyone affected, especially to those who stand up to do what they can in support of the community. The City of Angels really showed resilience and compassion in the wake of this unprecedented catastrophe.

Beautiful Altadena, we will never stop loving you. Joy that the corgis and I will be back to continue to steward this library. It‚Äôs been a month‚Äîa month filled with heartache, discomfort, chaos, and so many questions about the next step. But through it all, I‚Äôve felt an overwhelming amount of love and protection. The love and support from friends, my incredible team at @knxnews, my co-workers, and even ‚Äústrangers‚Äù who‚Äôve now become like family has been humbling.

This experience has taught me to release my discomfort with receiving and to truly embrace  receiving with gratitude. I‚Äôm doing my best to care for my heart, mind, and soul during this time. It hasn‚Äôt been easy moving from one short-term rental to another while searching for a more stable place to stay as we rebuild. But thanks to  angels and kind souls we‚Äôve found a home to move into soon.

To everyone who‚Äôs been there for us‚Äîthank you from the bottom of my heart. Your support means everything. And to those who‚Äôve lost their comfort, their homes, their memories, and their stability‚ÄîI‚Äôm sending you so much love. I hope the pieces fall into place for all of us with grace and ease.

Here‚Äôs to rebuilding. üåπ

Just an all-around all-star of a human being. No other way to describe @garysiniseofficial and the work he does with his @garysinisefoundation 

Today I got the exclusive invitation to join him in La Canada Flintrdige as he served appreciation meals to some 300 LA County firefighters and first responders - the heroic men and women who battled our recent firestorms. 

We talked about his commitment to those who serve, his iconic role as Lt. Dan in @forrestgumpfilm and his love for his late son, Mac, who tragically died last year at the young age of 33. 

Grateful to all the heroes I met today.

Nothing about the last month has been normal and its a scary place to be. About a week after the fire i personally feel like something clicked in me and I shut down. I am beyond the point of heartbroken over the 40 years of my life that I personally lost in the fire. I didn't grow up knowing anything but west Altadena, me and my siblings weren't allowed to go to parks because our front and back yard was big enough. The GR if you know you know everyone wanted to be able to come and hang out with us we WAS one of them houses, who don't have a memory on Glenrose and Acacia? There were three generations still living in the family home that my grandmother bought 57 years ago, including my 17yo who just lost her father in August and now she lost everything she had of him. What do you do when your just tired? What do you do when you just want to stay in bed and cry but you have to be strong for your child? What do you when the security you had has burned to crisp? Wait on a government to do something that it has never done before the right thing? How do I come to terms with saying goodbye to the only home MY FAMILY has ever known, never an apartment only a home.... I just needed a space today ALTADENA WAS SO BEAUTIFUL ALTADENA WAS SO BLACK #eatonfire #altadenastrong #grstrong

Relics:  Introduction to Memories

My plan was to kick off my series Relics on Substack on January 12, 2025.  I spent the month of December planning out my content schedule and compiled a list of music for upcoming writings and reels.  I sorted through boxes of pictures and old newspaper clippings, watched family videos and did a deep dive into my family tree. 

I was full of inspiration and felt the spark of creativity as I sat in different coffee shops around Cypress, Texas, preparing for this series even after a long day at the office. 

Then things took an unexpected turn.

üî•üá∫üá∏ I‚Äôve been sitting on this short essay since the election, and it applies now more than ever. As we witness extreme wildfire events like the Palisades and Eaton fires in tandem with our government seemingly going up in flames, I argue that the flammability of our socio-ecological systems are not all too different; both are at risk due to legacies of poor management and extractive capitalism, both endanger the working class, and both can be made to be more resilient to change - as long as we adjust our relationship to it. 

This is me trying out a different style compared to my typical scientific writing (psst: our recently accepted manuscript on my research will be available soon). As a scientist, I align with groups like Extinction Rebellion who argue that scientists can no longer afford to be complacent or ‚Äúunbiased‚Äù when it comes to the climate crisis or capitalism, things that touch so many of our lives and our study systems. 

I don‚Äôt really have the time for ‚Äúcontent generation‚Äù or crazy formatting, so enjoy this notes app stream of consciousness - after all, I‚Äôm just a girl!!!! üë©‚Äçüî¨üå≤üî•üìù

To our Los Angeles & Ventura County communities, if you‚Äôve been affected by recent wildfires, there‚Äôs important news for you! Executive Order N-10-25 has been issued, granting property tax relief to impacted homeowners.

Who Qualifies?
If your property is in one of the affected ZIP codes (90019, 90041, 90049, 90066, 90265, 90272, 90290, 90402, 91001, 91040, 91104, 91106, 91107, 93535, 93536), you may be eligible.

How to Get Help:
Visit gov.ca.gov or contact the L.A. County Treasurer and Tax Collector‚Äôs Office (https://ttc.lacounty.gov/) for more details

Stay strong, stay resilient, and know that your community is here to support you.

Been deliberating on what to share for the 50TH POST. The answer presented itself last night as I went where the wind blew me around town. Here's one L.A. Woman's Saturday night:

üåá1-2 An event at the Barnsdall theater proved a bore and a guy sat next to me reeking of pot, so I ducked out early and caught the sunset. Time at @barnsdallpark is never a wash.

üëó3-4 Motored from there to Pasadena for a clothing swap at Remainders Creative Reuse. This volunteer-run arts and crafts supply thrift store and maker-space is doing so much post-fire community work. Keep up with them @remainders_creative_reuse

üòû 5-6 I was a regular at Remainders a few years ago when I had an art studio a little further up Lake at Boston Street in Altadena. The whimsical 1930s studio building (built by the landlord's father) burned in the Eaton Fire. I decided it was time I visited the site. 

üñºÔ∏è I'm holding a benefit art sale for @shannonosullivantattoo who lost her business in the building. See pinned post on my art account for details @allisonstraussart 

üè°7-8 Also visited the bungalow court on nearby Maiden Lane where I'd once hoped to live. I hadn't qualified to rent there as the landlord understandably wanted someone with consistent income, not a freelance writer + artist.  Talk about a blessing in disguise! 

üìºüçï 9-10 Driving home, no one would let me over, causing me to miss my turn. This happened to be near my parents' house, and I was hungry, so I pulled over and called them to see if they wanted to have dinner nearby. They said they were eating pizza and watching Josie and The Pussycats and I should come join. Hadn't seen Josie since my sleepover days, forgot about the boyband "Dujour" plotline üòÇ (10)

What are you up to this weekend in L.A.?

Palawoo a month after the fire
Here were my clothes, records, camera bag, all my paintings, photos and prints by artist friends, here were my inexpensive but irreplaceable trinkets from around the world, film negatives and journals and creative tools and love letters and heirlooms and photos and little fragments of my soul outside of me -‚Ä®I guess I thought I‚Äôd find a trace of them, but anything that was left in that room was completely covered by roof shingles and other people‚Äôs remnants of home - there were three apartments upstairs and the ceiling caved in so - anything we had now shares the same resting place in a pile of roofing, melted glass, metal sludge, bits of tile, stone and ash. The whole neighborhood is kind of like that now - we all share the same pile of rubble - our individual homes and belongings became unrecognizable identical ash and debris, sharing the same pile of rubble and floating on the same gusts of wind

But I can‚Äôt stop thinking about the landlord‚Äôs library 
Tucked in a thin hallway and the only part of the home that still had a semblance of a post-fire roof coverage, this one little sliver of debris strangely preserved from wind and recent rain -
I never saw it in waking life (wow - I just wrote this automatically and realized what I implied - ‚Äúwaking life‚Äù as if this is a dream - üíî)
Anyway, I never saw the library before the fire, that‚Äôs what I meant -
But now without the walls separating our apartments I went inside‚Ä¶ there isn‚Äôt much left to determine that it‚Äôs a library except book-shaped ash piles with crisp edges of pages and even some words still legible (photo 9) - it‚Äôs all so surreal - I reached out to touch and turn a page and it dissipated into a puff of air - disappeared before my eyes - earth to fire to air and gone on the wind

Continued in comments -
#palawoo #altadena #eatonfire

Good news: ICYMI the Eaton & Palisades fires have FINALLY been 100% contained!! Since they started burning a few weeks ago we‚Äôve been donating & volunteering wherever & however we could. Seeing so many communities & places we deeply love + have spent endless amounts of time in across LA just decimated has left us (like so many others) sick w/grief‚Ä¶ just wanting to do anything we can to help. Being on diff sites we did multiple things & got to see + learn firsthand the do‚Äôs & don‚Äôts for donations. A lot of people have the best intentions & mean well but often we were seeing people donate things, seeing it as an easy feel-good way to get rid of what is often just trash, not considering the aftermath. It really creates a burden on the facilities¬†receiving them- most of these places like the Sanita Anita Race Track and YMCA are temporary setups- they rely on volunteers to sift through, sort & organize the donations. The amount of time we saw utterly stained, severely damaged (you know we love a distressed look but this was not it) clothing & random, unwashed intimate basics was astonishing. Yes, under garments & socks are highly requested items but your stained underwear is not needed, seriously. Just because you can, doesn‚Äôt mean you should!!

Since the fires have been contained, the immediate danger is subsiding so ‚Äúcrisis mode‚Äù across social media will be turned down, headlines are gonna fade & donations + volunteers will wean off. It‚Äôs crucial to recognize that the real work to rebuilding & recovering is just beginning though. The same energy when the fires first hit is needed more than ever-disaster relief isn‚Äôt a relay, it‚Äôs a marathon. Support, community, acts of service, donations - it‚Äôs all still needed. Being on the ground firsthand, we‚Äôve learned a few things + tips we want to share that we hope will aid people in how to relay their time, money & resources to make the most impact moving forward. Continue to give generously but with intent & def donate with dignity but don‚Äôt forgot to also consider the environmental & human impact of your actions ‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è

Tonight while laying in bed I randomly had a quick visual flash of MY bed and suddenly was struck all over again with- that‚Äôs not my bed anymore and then flooded with grief but also still feeling this isn‚Äôt real. 

I know I‚Äôm not alone in this and the images and feelings are quick and intense. I know it‚Äôs only been a month, but it feels like it could be forever for this to feel real. Even once I find my new permanent home- will it still feel like MY home or an imposter?

#FireRefugees

Warning, this is not a happy post!

For your Spanish Sunday, I'm paying tribute to the Spanish and Mediterranean style houses that were, I believe, destroyed in the Altadena Eaton Canyon fire. 

These are from my own library of photos of the area, and I continue to search through my archives to see what else I can find.  Of course there were many more affected, very sadly.  I wish I had documented the entire region, but alas, that is not the case.

I also want to make note of my disclaimer, because it's very difficult to tell about some houses on the maps. As far as I know, these have been lost, but I am more than happy to be proven wrong.

Please go back through my posts if you did not see those about chimneys, and particularly my post that is simply a statement. I am offering to photograph homeowners with the remains of their homes, or just their homes, or just them. I'm also happy to find my own photos of anyone's house if they would like me to look.

I will be doing some regular posts again, but that doesn't mean that this situation is forgotten in any way. I think I'll be thinking about and posting in memory and honor of our Los Angeles residential architecture fire losses for a very long time. 

#eatonfire #altadena #spanishsunday #spanishbungalow #spanishstyle #spanishstylehome #spanishcolonial #spanishcolonialrevival #mediterranean #mediterraneanstyle #mediterraneanstylehome

locationName: Saint Elizabeth of Hungary Catholic Church Altadena
caption:
In the midst of the devastation caused by the California #wildfires, one of our talented freelancers, Reese Cuevas, beautifully captured the emotional journey of family and friends who traveled from out of state to support their loved ones, who are parishioners at @saintelizabethschool in #Altadena. Together, they sifted through the remnants of a fire, uncovering the last remnants of cherished memories among the ashes.‚Å†
‚Å†
The haunting scenes of burned-out cars and charred belongings tell a story of loss, but amidst the wreckage emerged a glimmer of hope. A few precious religious items and pieces of jewelry were found, symbols of faith and resilience that remind us even in darkness, there is light.‚Å†
‚Å†
These striking images serve as a reminder of God's presence among us, the power of community, and the strength of the human spirit in the face of hardship. Let‚Äôs cherish the moments that bind us together and honor the journey of healing that lies ahead. üíñ‚Å†

Rebuilding Resilient concrete Homes After a Devastating Fire: What You Need to Know! 

Rebuilding after fires is not just about restoring what was lost‚Äîit‚Äôs an opportunity to create a home that‚Äôs safe, resilient, and future-ready.

Building for Fire Resilience

Concrete Type 1 Construction:

‚Ä¢Non-combustible: Concrete doesn‚Äôt ignite, offering unparalleled fire resistance.
‚Ä¢High heat resistance: Maintains structural integrity under extreme temperatures.
‚Ä¢Durable: A sustainable investment designed to last generations.

Advanced Fire Suppression Systems

‚Ä¢Automatic fire defense: Sprinklers activate instantly to stop fires before they spread.
‚Ä¢Dual protection: Deploys water and fire-retardant foam for maximum safety.
‚Ä¢Blue Roof Design: Integrates exterior sprinklers, fire-retardant coatings, and smart weather monitoring for real-time fire mitigation.

Exterior Fire-Resistant Coatings

‚Ä¢Acts as a barrier, preventing flames from penetrating the home‚Äôs exterior.
Metal Roofs
‚Ä¢Fire-resistant and durable, designed to reduce ember penetration risks.

Lessons from the 2018 Malibu Fires

The Malibu fires underscored the need for innovative solutions. During this time, we developed the Blue Roof Design, which expedited rebuilding by meeting safety codes and bypassing roadblocks.

Recognized by the AIA, our homes incorporated:

‚Ä¢ICF concrete for unmatched fire resistance.
‚Ä¢Integrated sprinklers for interior and exterior safety.
‚Ä¢Sustainable systems for long-term resilience.

A Safer, Brighter Future:
Rebuilding after loss is hard, but with the right materials and technology, your home can be beautiful‚Äîand resilient.

Contact us today to begin designing a home that protects your family and future.

There have been many significant and noteworthy African Americans that have called Altadena home, - including Clarence B. Jones pictured here receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Joe Biden at the White House on May 3, 2024 in Washington. (The White House/X). Clarence and his wife Ann Norton [daughter of publishing giant W.W. Norton) lived on Highview Ave. in a Gregory Ain house. When Martin Luther King flew to Los Angeles in early 1960 pursuant to an invitation from the World Affairs Council, he was under indictment for perjury in Alabama in connection with his filing of a supposedly fraudulent tax return. MLK‚Äôs lawyers in New York had identified Jones as the Lawyer they thought might be better employed in the civil rights movement than entertainment law. Dr. King asked to meet Dr. Jones who offered his home in Altadena as the venue. On a Friday night, MLK was ushered into the Jones‚Äôs home and shown the room with a living tree and a retractable roof the better to see the San Gabriel Mountains and the Milky Way, the lemon trees, flowers, and plants that were Ann‚Äôs avocation. ‚ÄòNice house‚Äô, said Dr. King. [Source: Altadena Neighbors, January 2022].

UCLA has released research from the Ralph J Bunche Center for African American Studies, on how the Eaton Fire has impacted the Black Community of Altadena which can be read here https://bunchecenter.ucla.edu/wildfires-altadena-black-community/. (Link in bio)

This past weekend, I had the honor of traveling to Altadena, CA¬†with my fellow Captain, Scot,¬†to¬†deliver gift cards and a donation from our community to those who lost their homes in the recent wildfires.¬†We¬†met incredible people¬†-¬†fire victims who are standing strong, CERT¬†(Community Emergency Response Team)¬†volunteers who continue to serve,¬†Altadena Rotary Club members,¬†and community members bound by love and perseverance. We attended their Giving Day on Saturday and were so moved.

This is such a hard post‚Ä¶‚Ä¶
Last week I was hired to photograph the horrific destruction left by the #eatonfire in Altadena.

I sobbed, again and again, as we navigated the rubble. 

Altadena holds such a special place in my heart, we have so many amazing memories there; Countless incredible cortados from @highlightcoffee, brunches & lunches @amarakitchen, dinner & drinks with friends, hikes in Eaton Canyon, and so much more. 

Yet, LA has this weird way of dredging strength out of people, and they/we/LA will rebuild, stronger for it‚Ä¶ but goddamn this is really, really rough. Tens of thousands of people lost everything ‚Äî PLEASE DO NOT FORGET ‚Äî Our friends are struggling, their friends and family are hurting. Love, check-in, pray, give, donate, volunteer, and whatever else you can think to do to help. PLEASE continue to support this community that has been forever changed, physically, mentally & emotionally. 

I love you Altadena. I love you LA. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π
