The clock had just run out on the Super Bowl and the players, coaches, and media were crowding the field when the call came.

I saw the caller ID and knew before I picked the phone up that the call was going to be a difficult one to take, but I told my sister before that no matter what I was going through I'd always pick up the phone.

We were at a Super Bowl party, so I took the call off to the side of the room.

"Mom just died," my sister told me.

The call didn't last long after that.

I'm way past the point of counting the amount of things to navigate, emotions to process, and battles to fight.

I told my sister I would be out the next day, but gave a time I couldn't make because we had a plumber coming out to our new place to resolve three issues that had been dogging us for weeks.

We didn't stay on the phone long.

Somehow, as hard as everything is, and as hopeless as I felt this morning after waking to an email where I was disqualified from receiving aid from an artistic institution for fire victims over some arbitrary crap, I can't seem to just give in to it.

I spent the day with my sister remembering times with our mother while actively attempting to dodge around the events that fed and bred my traumas. We took care of what business we had the energy to face.

Tomorrow we deal with more.

In between I fought some of the other battles raging through emails and hoops to jump through.

But there's one thing that I keep coming back to--the communities I'm surrounded by.

Yes, I'm deploying every coping skill I've developed over the years and reinforcing those with therapy. . .

. . .but having the people I do around me provides me cover during the moments I need to just not be in the downpour for a few minutes.

And that's no small thing.

For all the things the #Eatonfire took, the one thing it's made crystal clear. . .I have the most amazing people one could hope for tucked into every nook and cranny of my life.

Since the City of Pasadena thought it would be a better idea to not let any Black Businesses sell products at this year's annual festival, please check out our website for official MADE IN DENA gear! With all the ways our community has been affected and with so few vending opportunities for our businesses at city events, the City of Pasadena - Public Agency needs to create MORE opportunities to strive during such a difficult time. For many, our businesses, side-business, and legit hustles play a huge part in supplementing income required just to stay a part of this community. MADE IN DENA has already donated thousands of dollars worth of brand new merchandise to those affected while almost half of our customers lost their homes, so not being able to vend at our own annual festival is definitely not the best idea by the City of Pasadena - Public Agency. However, we will continue to support wherever we can through donations, volunteerism, and providing work for those affected. Thanks to everyone who make a constant effort to support local business and much love to everyone affected by the recent tragedy. Filed under things I never thought I‚Äôd use a classic Mercedes for: stopping at a make-your-own-sandbag station to save my fire-damaged house from possible flooding. We‚Äôre going to get heavy rain in the next few days. The dangers of flooding and mudslides are high in the burn areas where there is no longer enough healthy vegetation to absorb water.

I had never driven with that much weight in the trunk. My 46 year old rear suspension held up but I could feel the pressure in the drive. Luckily it was only about a mile to my home. Driveway, protected.

Supporting @perrysjoint. They have some really filled and delicious sandwiches. We got the Hip Max (top) on rye and the Chef's Special (bottom) on sourdough. The Hip Max has turkey, roast beef, and avocado. The Chef's Special was a hot sandwich with turkey and chicken salad with cranberries. 

Their location is adorned with photos of jazz music icons. 

Their original location in Pasadena is just a couple blocks from the Altadena burn areas. From the early days after the fires, they opened their doors to be a place of refuge and assistance for the community. 

In addition to sandwiches, they have hot dogs, ice cream and smoothies. 

If you're in the area, I highly recommend!

‚ö†Ô∏è Potentially Hazardous Rainfall ‚ö†Ô∏è

There is an almost certain likelyhood that a very dangerous amount of rainfall is approaching the Eaton Fire area leading to dangerous conditions for debris flow and mudslides.
 
Edgar McGregor, the meteorologist who saved hundreds of lives with eerily accurate predictions of the storm that causes the Eaton Fire, just issued another warning in the Altadena Weather-Climate group: ‚ÄúThis evening, the PGE-WRF continues to put out rather alarming rain totals and rates for our area. I am concerned about this one, but again, forecasting for debris flows has not been my forte. The ECMWF also appears game for decent jet dynamics, ample moisture of 1.2 precipitable waters, and 40 - 50 MPH winds at 2,500‚Äô running head on into our mountain slopes.‚Äù

LA meteorologists are also echoing the warning, urging those in the immediate vicinity of the burn scars to consider short-term evacuation as the rain pours in overnight.

Be very careful Sierra Madre!

It‚Äôs been a month since the Eaton Fire devastated our beloved Altadena, and it still feels unreal. Our hearts are heavy for our community, for the families who lost their homes, and for the deep scars left on a place we cherish.

Altadena is more than where we do business ‚Äîit‚Äôs home. For over 10 years, we‚Äôve been restoring and doing our best to honor the character of homes in Pasadena and Altadena, bringing them back to life with care and craftsmanship. We‚Äôve been fortunate to work alongside talented, hardworking people who pour their skill and heart into every build.

Losing several of the homes we‚Äôve loved and invested in has been heartbreaking. Seeing our community in pain is even harder. We are devastated‚Äîbut we are also determined.

For now, we‚Äôre back to work, currently restoring a beautiful home in nearby Eagle Rock. But our commitment to Altadena remains steadfast. We vow to be part of the rebuilding effort, to stand with our neighbors, and to help our community rise again.

Altadena, we‚Äôre with you! #AltadenaStrong #EatonFire

Grief doesn‚Äôt just take‚Äîit reveals.

Who shows up. Who stays silent. Who tries to fix what can‚Äôt be fixed.

And sometimes, the hardest part isn‚Äôt the loss itself, but the way it reshapes the people around you. The way absence ripples outward, leaving unexpected empty spaces where support should have been.

If you‚Äôve felt that loneliness‚Äîif you‚Äôve looked around and wondered who‚Äôs still standing beside you‚Äîyou‚Äôre not alone.

Not everyone will get it right. Some will say the wrong things. Some won‚Äôt say anything at all. But somewhere in the quiet, there are people who won‚Äôt turn away. The ones who see your pain and don‚Äôt try to erase it. The ones who don‚Äôt need you to be strong to stay.

Those are the ones who will walk with you through the wreckage. And when you‚Äôre ready to rise, they‚Äôll still be there.

-Dr. Z

The spotty trees are a phenomenon that occurs when extreme heat from a fire rapidly heats the moisture in the sapwood under the bark. Expansion from superheated steam causes the bark to pop off in this random pattern that some have named ‚Äúcheetah‚Äù or ‚Äúleopard‚Äù trees.

The wildfire that developed in Jasper in July 2024 took over 80,000 acres of forest and a large part of the townsite. 
The LA fires in January 2025 came within a few blocks of our family‚Äôs home in Altadena. Luckily their subdivision was completely spared and they are safe. 

Forest fires are happening all over the world and are becoming far too common. 
Please lend your support as these cities rebuild from the devastating fires. 
Also make sure to check out the fascinating trees in Jasper next time you visit.

If your #insurance company is trying to cut you a check for a lesser amount than what it actually costs you to repair or replace your property, remind them of California Insurance Code Section 2051.5, 2060(b), and Insurance Code Section 10103.7

Not only do these sections of the insurance code protect homeowners from tricky insurance tactics like ‚Äúdepreciation,‚Äù but it also provides that after a declared federal disaster, such as the Eaton Fire, (#lafires ) they must provide additional living expense (ALE) coverage for policyholders for a minimum of 24 months. This ALE coverage may be extended for up to 12 additional months.

You can thank attorneys like our very own Robert Jackson for getting legislation like this passed into law!  Robert has played lead roles in wildfire litigation for over twenty years. If you lost your home to the #eatonfire you want Robert on your side.

Robert, Scott and Eric are all heavy hitters when it comes to fighting insurance companies! These three have a combined 100 years of experience with insurance bad faith lawsuits, and they are offering LA fire victims help with their insurance claims FREE OF CHARGE.

Meet them in person at one of our upcoming meetings (link in bio) or DM us to set up a free consultation.

I just had a well-intentioned person say to me, ‚Äúby now we are all adjusted to life after the fires‚Äù. Ummm‚Ä¶no thank you. I‚Äôm still in shock and grieving my loss. I still have sleep disruption and mild depression. So, no, I have not adjusted or totally accepted. You take your time! For those who feel they have adjusted- that is wonderful- for you. But don‚Äôt expect that for everyone. Some people still haven‚Äôt found a place to land, some are still trapped in the whirlwind of insurance/fema/bureaucratic red tape which is overwhelming when we‚Äôre fully functioning. This isn‚Äôt a lecture, just a reminder to take it at your own pace and know that not everyone is at the same pace or even the same path.

Love to you all!

#EatonFire
#TraumaProcess

Altadena Street Runner
Airbrush Pigment on Upcycled  100% Cotton Rag Runner/Rug
72‚Äù x 27‚Äù (6 feet long) 
No two alike‚Ä®Made to order in Gr8r Los Angeles

Link in bio for purchase(profits going to GoFundMe)

My Uncle and Auntie bought their first home in Altadena in 1972. They went on to raise a literal village there and they had ‚Äúthe house‚Äù we went to celebrate anything. Birthdays, funerals, pool parties, Tyson fights, etc. I almost drowned in their pool, but I also learned to swim there. My Uncle Leo has since passed and my 97 year old, Auntie Dottie, was still there until the AM hours of of 1/8/25 and had to be forced out the home she‚Äôd spent 53 years. By mid day it was confirmed that the house had burned to the ground, a total loss.  1 of 9,400+ that were taken by the winds of the Eaton Fire. 

It‚Äôs really impossible to understand the loss of this community until you see it with your own eyes. Social media, phones and television doesn‚Äôt capture the scale of destruction. I went to witness it for myself and to do what I‚Äôm best at to help. The profits from the sales of the ‚ÄúAltadena Street Runners‚Äù will go towards the GoFundMe of my Auntie Dottie. This is just the start of where I can help and lend support, in the present. This is going to be a long journey to rebuild this community. 

.

.
.
.
.
.

A month after the fires, the smoke has cleared, but the loss is still raw. I‚Äôve walked through the remains of homes I spent years designing‚Äîplaces where families celebrated life, where carefully curated details turned houses into homes. Now, they exist only in memory and scattered fragments of what was left behind.
In some cases, those fragments were eerily intact‚Äîpottery vessels, blackened but unbroken. Metal barstools, still lined up at the ghost of a kitchen island, the kitchen itself reduced to rubble. Objects meant to be lived with, loved, and passed down through generations, now standing as the last evidence of spaces that no longer exist.

Losing my work this way has been emotional in a way I wasn‚Äôt prepared for. But that pales in comparison to the heartbreak of watching people I love lose everything.

The devastation is profound, yet so too is LA‚Äôs resilience. If there is one thing Angelenos do well in the face of catastrophe, it‚Äôs help our neighbors. I‚Äôm proud of the way my colleagues and friends in the design industry have come together to help. I know we will all have an important role to play in the rebuilding of beloved communities. My hope is that our heartbreak and deep respect for LA‚Äôs landscape and the character of its diverse communities will guide our efforts in the years to come. 

#lastrong #eatonfire #palisadesfire #lawildfires #lacountyfire #losangelesinteriordesigner #californiainteriordesigner

I‚Äôm so proud of how this book came out that was spawned from a tiny idea I had to help celebrate my home. 

Link in bio:

Last year I created a coloring book inspired by the wildlife and natural beauty of The San Gabriel Mountains, a place that has always been my home. Since the devastating Eaton Fire, which has deeply impacted our community and the landscapes we love, it feels like the right time to share this project. The San Gabriel Mountains A-Z
Coloring Book was meant to celebrate the mountains, but now it feels like a way to honor and give back to those impacted by this tragedy.
I‚Äôm committed to donating a portion of sales to support victims of the Eaton Fire. It‚Äôs my small way of fostering healing, offering hope, and celebrating the resilience of our community.

Please be prepared for the upcoming storm. ¬†The National Weather Service is expecting the time of impact for road flooding and debris flow from 1:00 PM Thursday to 4:00 AM on Friday.

CalFire and the California Geological Survey have identified post fire risk to life, property and infrastructure, outlined in the first image. 

Guidance from CalOES (California Governor's Office of Emergency Services)

The incoming storm could bring an increased risk of power outages, flooding in small streams and low-lying areas, and debris, rocks and mudslides on roadways.

Residents are encouraged to not drive through flooded roadways, prepare in advance for power outages and reduce injury risks from falling limbs and trees by staying inside during high wind events.

Residents are urged to stay informed and listen to local authorities about actions they should take including evacuation orders or safety recommendations. In burn scar areas, officials recommend preparing for possible sudden debris flows by having a go-bag packed and knowing evacuation routes.

For more information on winter storm preparedness visit¬†ready.ca.gov.

It's Wednesday, the day when I usually post strange, unusual and oftentimes funny homes and yard art. The idea is to celebrate creativity and have some fun. But this is quite different.

Admittedly, I first photographed this house because I was fascinated by the formations that have been created by the way the hedges have been cut. I especially noticed that the lower one looks kind of like a fish or a whale, it's almost topiary! But not quite‚Ä¶ 

And now, sadly, I have to report that this house is gone. And it's particularly strange and sad, and deserves a giant  What The Heck?! Because it is the one house that burned in a neighborhood that was pretty much completely saved otherwise.

This is an example of an ember flying through that horrible wind storm and just happening to land in this place. At least as far as I can tell‚Ä¶ 

So what the heck to that! I really feel for these homeowners. There are so many different situations that one can find themselves in when it comes to this disaster. Some people lost their home and everyone around them did as well.  That's devastating because you've lost your home and your community. But you're not alone in it‚Ä¶. Some people find that their's was the one house that was saved in a neighborhood that is otherwise destroyed. In that case, they usually can't go back and live in that home because there's nothing around them and it's completely toxic. So, much as they are able to get their things, a lot of them have to be destroyed as well due to toxicity. That must be an extremely frustrating situation to be in, and they have also lost their community. And I think there's probably some strange guilt feelings that some of those people may experience, sadly.  And then there's this situation, where everyone is fine, I don't even know if there is a toxicity issue because there are several blocks here that were completely saved, and yet there's this one house that burned to the ground.

Of course my heart goes out to everyone in all of these situations. Each one is difficult and tragic and heartbreaking. 

#whattheheckwednesday #whattheheck #altadena #eatoncanyon #heartbroken #eatoncanyonfire #eatonfire #firedamage #firerestoration

We are trying to reunite this drawing with its owner. Please get in touch if you know who may have drawn this. The drawing will be kept safe until the owner is identified.

Case Study House # 20, Altadena ‚Ä¢ Buff, Straub & Hensmen, 1958.

Case Study House # 20, also known as the Bass House, was built for famed graphic designer Saul Bass by Buff, Straub and Hensmen. The Case Study Houses were known for steel frame construction, but the Bass House was notably made of wood. Unlike other post-and-beam designs by the firm, the structure has no overhangs due to the number of trees around it, among them the deodar cedars that line the stretch of Santa Rose Avenue nicknamed ‚ÄúChristmas Tree Lane.‚Äù In a stroke of luck (for some), the property and Christmas Tree Lane, which are both listed in the National Register, survived the Eaton Fire unscathed, while two structures across the street were destroyed. 

Photos taken on 02/10/25.

Who needs the help of a #wildfire #lawyer?

- Homeowners who suffered fire or smoke damage.
- Landowners who suffered property damage.
- Business owners whose businesses were impacted in any way.
- Anyone who sustained any personal injuries due to the fires.
- Anyone who was forced to flee the fires.
- The heirs of those who did not survive the fires.

Sadly, even properly insured victims are coming to a shocking realization. Their insurance may not provide enough coverage to compensate for all their damages. Damage to fencing structures, irrigation systems, and expensive landscaping could very well not be covered by many insurance policies. In addition, claims for emotional distress and fleeing the zone of the danger can only be recovered against the utility company and/or its subcontractors.

Why does a fire victim need a lawyer now?

If the fire victim has insurance: 

- A lawyer will help a person put his or her best foot forward in making his or her insurance claim.
- Insurance only covers a small part of the losses.
- Insurance companies often cheat.
- Most losses will be recovered from the power company and its contractors.

IF WE REPRESENT YOU, WE WILL NOT BE TAKING A FEE ON ANY MONEY THAT YOU RECOVER FROM YOUR OWN INSURANCE COMPANY.

If the fire victim does not have insurance:

All of the losses will need to be recovered from the power company and its contractors.

I will never forget this

Sahag Mesrob Armenian Christian School, my school of ten years from pre-k to eighth grade, burnt down by the Eaton Fire.

My first steps onto the campus and I couldn‚Äôt comprehend what I was looking at, I was experiencing denial and disbelief. I was looking at rubble. The buildings where I attended class, made friends, went to chapel, played music were simply not there. It was suddenly non-existent.

I stood where we would stand as children, facing the pillared structure in our plaid uniforms where our Principal Filian and teachers would lead us into the Pledge of Allegiance and the Armenian Lord‚Äôs Prayer. Where we would line up on the red lines of the square waiting to be picked up from school.

I walked the path down that leads to the front of the school, where I expected to find more destruction. What I saw next made chills run through my whole body, there in the rubble standing tall was our school‚Äôs khachkar. A fully demolished building behind it yet, there it was, strong and proud with its carved Armenian cross. That chilling moment I will never forget.

Strange to see in these photos, the juxtaposition of me as a child on a thriving school campus, then me as an adult on demolished school grounds. 

I‚Äôm proud of my resilient community that believes in this school, my schoolmates and old teachers who‚Äôve banded together. We will continue to support the current students and teachers as classes continue. We‚Äôll rebuild.

On January 7th, I left home with my camera on a whim that I might see something extreme, based on the high wind weather warning that morning on the news. As I drove down the 405s fwy, I saw a plume of smoke rising out over the Palisades. After turning on the radio I learned that a fire had just broken out on Sunset Blvd, so I decided to get off at the next exit after Sunset and head directly for the beach. I was not prepared for what I was about to see‚Ä¶ 

I have lived in Los Angeles my entire life. The last time I saw a fire that upset me as much was the Woolsey Fire in 2018, but from the get go, this was DIFFERENT. I parked my car and literally sprinted down to the ocean. My heart hurt, and so did my lungs, even with a mask. People were crowding down on the strand and the Santa Monica Beach in astonishment. I took some photos and hurried off to see my Dad in Torrance. By the time I arrived, he showed me a video of a bulldozer crushing abandoned cars out of the way on Sunset Blvd, where I had just been only a mile or so away. I was in disbelief. I think we all were. 

It‚Äôs been a little over a month and I still have my animal carrier by the door, my apartment is a complete mess, and my mind has not recovered, nor will our city ever be the same. So many people I know have lost what can only be surmised as priceless pieces of their lives. Everyday I think how I can live my life with more intention, how I can give back to my community in a valuable way, how we can work to prevent something like this from happening again. To those who have lost so much, and to even those who only watched in horror, we will rebuild, and while it will be different, what‚Äôs come to pass will not be forgotten. I stand in solidarity with my community at large, and I promise I will make more purposeful how and why I use my camera, because never before has truth needed a larger stage in which to be seen. Tomorrow is Valentine‚Äôs Day, but love isn‚Äôt all about gifts and candy, it‚Äôs about being a support, understanding the pain of others, and standing by those in need.‚ù§Ô∏è #eatonfire #palisadesfire

Utter devastation. 

The crumble of books, pages swirling like paste. Chimneys left standing, the lone remnant of a home, mocking the roof, walls, windows that have faded into mud. Burnt cars frozen in time - as if they were left behind decades ago. Entire neighborhoods vanished. Christmas decorations strung, frozen grey amid the void of color on a tree. The smell of ash and smoke lingering, hovering over the skeleton of homes and refusing to leave. 

‚ÄúTherefore everyone who hears these words of mine and puts them into practice is like a wise man who built his house on the rock. The rain came down, the streams rose, and the winds blew and beat against that house; yet it did not fall, because it had its foundation on the rock.‚Äù Matthew 7. 

It all fades away. Only Jesus does not.

We‚Äôve been asked by a few people about how the Radicle can help assess soil quality after the fires.  Well, we‚Äôre already using the Radicle at our site in Altadena, and here‚Äôs what the sensor will be doing at 8‚Äù below the surface:
 
Measuring Soil Carbon Loss & Recovery
üå±Detects reductions in soil organic carbon (SOC) due to fire.
üå±Tracks SOC increases as microbial activity and organic matter return. 

Monitoring Soil Respiration & Microbial Recovery
üå±Measures CO‚ÇÇ flux to assess microbial respiration and biological recovery.
üå±Compares pre- and post-remediation respiration levels to track progress.

Detecting Soil Contamination from Urban Debris
üå±Helps identify suppressed microbial activity from heavy metals, PAHs and dioxins.
üå±Helps determine areas requiring further soil testing.

Assessing Biochar & Fungal Remediation Effectiveness
üå±Monitors biochar retention and its impact on SOC.
üå±Evaluates whether fungal inoculation (mycorrhizal) enhances soil respiration.
 
The first post-fire measurement at this site in the photo (for which we don‚Äôt have a photo) was 972ppm.  A week later, there was an overgrowth of oxalis, and the measurement was 1285ppm.  Pre-fire measurements ranged between 1780 to 1831.  If we get persistent high readings, that may suggest continued decomposition of fire residues.
 
#soilhealth #soilcarbon #regenerativeag #eatonfire #urbanfarming

EVACUATION. DISPLACEMENT. These are words I had no experience of before the Eaton Canyon fire. But now, these are words that I say out loud at least once a day. 
.
Our life turned upside down on the night of January 7th when we evacuated from our home. Luckily, our home is still there, but it‚Äôs inhabitable because of smoke damage and (possibly toxic) ashes, which came in from every window and doors.
.
We had to move out and find a new place to stay. It was not easy but we made it (with some good help and good luck!).
.
Now, we are learning how to live with ‚Äì and bear ‚Äì this uncertainty. The uncertainty of not knowing what‚Äôs the best thing to do. The uncertainty of not knowing when we‚Äôll be able to go back home. The uncertainty of not knowing. 
.
We are learning. We are learning how to deal with the insurance, the contractors, the remediation and cleaning companies, the environmental hygienists. This has become our second job. It‚Äôs often frustrating and overwhelming all at ones. But it is what it is. We still need to deal with all of this unfortunately. We need to push through.
.
Our beloved Christmas tree is still at home with its decorations on. Time froze in there. It‚Äôs weird like my daughter said the other day. This is NOT how I envisioned this year. This is NOT how WE imagined this year. But this is our new ‚Äúnormal‚Äù now.
.
THANK YOU to everyone who‚Äôs showing up for us
THANK YOU for your kind words, for your virtual and real hugs, for your thoughts 
THANK YOU for the time and THANK YOU for listening
THANK YOU for taking care of us, for cooking for us, for offering your help, for offering clothes and shoes, for sending us toys and stuffies, for welcoming us in your home
THANK YOU for these beautiful flowers that I received from my child‚Äôs teacher today, unexpectedly.
.
These are the most amazing gifts. Every day, there‚Äôs something I am thankful for. And the warmth I feel when I think of my community made of new and old friends showing up for us really means everything to me. 
THANK YOU ‚ô•Ô∏è
.
.

Just as Maui gave a motivational speech to Moana, here is my motivational speech to Instagram. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúMay we Try‚Äù:‚ú®üíï

May we try(!) to believe in our ourselves. To believe in our inner strength, to believe we can sift through discouragement and persevere to something that is good.

May we try(!) to remember that we have gone through hard times before, to remember what helps us through the hardest of times. 

May we try(!) to cling to the people and things who support us, to cling to hope and to the possibility of hope. 

And may we also try (!) to let ourselves laugh, smile, and be lifted up‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs by Disney characters, a favorite song, or a movie that sparks joy. (Thanks, @therock, for this timely and hope-infused reminder from Moana 2!)

I invite you to share what helps you when you‚Äôre feeling discouraged or overwhelmed? Drop your go-to tips in the comments! üëáI‚Äôll go first. This song! My 5yr-old and I have been listening to it on repeat.ü§©

Let‚Äôs encourage and uplift each other, together. üíï

Sending you all warmth and care,
Robyn

PS my original post had the phrasing ‚ÄúNow is the time‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúMay we try‚Äù. I intentionally decided to change it because I realized 1.) MLK used that phrasing in his ‚ÄúI have a dream‚Äù speech and I wanted to give full honor to him and his words by not using the exact phrasing that he used and 2.) ‚ÄúMay we try‚Äù is more in line with me and what I was hoping to convey. :) I will post a reel soon on this same speech!!

Valentine‚Äôs Day is a reminder of love in all its forms‚Äînot just the romantic kind, but the love that holds us together when life feels unrecognizable.

What once felt effortless‚Äîgathering, celebrating, marking time with traditions‚Äînow carries a weight I never anticipated. Holding both joy and grief at the same time can feel dissonant, like trying to sing two notes at once. The table looks different. The celebrations feel different. And yet, love remains.

Maybe that‚Äôs exactly why love matters more now than ever. Because in the midst of loss, love is what rebuilds. Not in sweeping, cinematic moments, but in the quiet ones‚Äîthe way someone pulls up a chair for you in your grief, the way laughter still sneaks through the cracks, the way even fractured traditions remind us we are still here, still connected, still choosing each other.

Psychologists call this dual awareness‚Äîthe ability to hold both joy and sorrow, to acknowledge loss without letting it erase everything else. It‚Äôs not about forcing happiness; it‚Äôs about letting love meet us where we are, exactly as we are.

So if this season feels different, if absence makes celebration feel heavier, know this: Love is not in the perfection of the moment. It‚Äôs in the people who show up, in the presence we offer one another, in the quiet knowing that even in the hardest seasons, we are not alone.

And today, I just want to say thank you to this beautiful community, to the familiar faces who‚Äôve been here, to the new ones who‚Äôve joined. You are part of what makes love feel expansive, even in the hardest of times.

-Dr. Z

The routes do not go through D5, but for your situational awareness. Additional info from Pasadena Department of Transportation below:
‚Äî-
The City of Pasadena has been working closely with LA County, the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE), Caltrans, and other neighboring jurisdictions to determine haul routes for the Phase 2 Fire Debris Removal Program. As shown in the attached map, three haul routes have been defined for the Pasadena/Altadena area:
¬∑  West of Lake Ave: Woodbury Road to Arroyo Blvd to I-210 on/off ramps
¬∑  East of Lake Ave and west of Eaton Canyon Golf Course: New York Drive to Sierra Madre Villa Ave to Rosemead Blvd to I-210 on/off ramps
¬∑  East of Eaton Canyon Golf Course: Michillinda Ave to I-210 on/off ramps
 
Trucks hauling debris from the burn areas to the I-210 freeway will utilize local streets until they reach the haul route, and from there will utilize the haul route to access the freeway.
 
A significant amount of truck traffic will be utilizing these haul routes, and signal timing will be adjusted to accommodate the additional traffic. The City reminds residents to be patient and drive safely if they experience the additional truck traffic along these haul routes, as this is a critical part of the rebuilding process and recovery effort.

History Lost in the Eaton Fire üî•

The Pasadena Jewish Temple and Center (PJTC), a cornerstone of the community since 1921, was tragically destroyed in the Eaton Fire. Originally founded as Temple B‚Äônai Israel, this historic congregation stood for over a century, serving as a place of faith, culture, and connection.

On January 7, 2025, the flames took everything the sanctuary, chapel, classrooms but not the spirit of the people. Before the fire reached the temple, community members saved all 13 Torah scrolls, ensuring their survival. A powerful reminder that while buildings can be rebuilt, faith and resilience are unshakable.

#PasadenaHistory #JewishCommunity #EatonFire #HistoricLoss #TempleStrong #PasadenaJewishTemple #CaliforniaWildfires #NeverForget

#fairytalefriday #fairytale #storybookhouse #fairytalehouse  #storybookhome #fairytalehome #likeafairytale #straightoutofafairytale #prettyhouse #charminghomes #charmer #altadena #eatonfire #fire #safe #miraclehouse

This is a very special post for your Saturday. Nicole, a wonderfully warmhearted homeowner who lost the charming bungalow that she lived in with her partner and teenaged Daughter in the Eaton fire, was kind enough to give me the honor of photographing her with what remains of her home. 

She was with Disaster Relief California who help fire victims dig for buried treasure. And she found some lovely things‚Ä¶ Scroll to see the video showing what survived.

Nicole has the best attitude, she's so positive and appreciative of all the help. I know she'll get through this as well as one possibly can.

Most of the treasures that are left at these sites, especially at this point, are simple things, family heirlooms, possibly not of any great value monetarily, but extremely valuable in terms of the memories they hold and legacy they represent.

I want to emphasize that these areas are still being heavily patrolled, so anyone who has any thoughts about doing such digging on someone else's site best put a stop to that immediately. First of all, it's totally unacceptable, these people have suffered enough. 
Secondly, you will be caught and you will be thrown in jail and rightfully so. 

I'm pretty certain that most of my followers, if not all, would never think of doing such a thing, but just in case‚Ä¶ 

I have included information on my chimney project if you scroll to the end. Simply send me a DM. I'm spending the weekend documenting the area because the trucks are moving in and pulling things away, including these lovely chimneys that represent so much. I feel compelled to photograph as many as possible but it is truly daunting‚Ä¶ There are so many!

If you will be in the area and have a house you'd like me to photograph, with you or not, please reach out to me! 

I hope you all enjoyed your Valentine's Day and that you will have a beautiful Saturday!

As always, my heart goes out to all who are suffering from the fires, I'm always thinking of you.

First for the backstory‚Ä¶
When we got married in 2016 I had been introduced by a Haworth colleague to a hat/headpiece designer from California. Her name is Andie & her co. is called The Feathered Head.

She is such a talented designer, and also a chicken lover! She had her own little flock & would occasionally use their dropped feathers in her work. And although my headpiece didn‚Äôt have any of her chickens feathers she did send me 3 feathers from her flock in my box as a lovely little extra.

I‚Äôm a bit of a sentimental gal, so I‚Äôve kept these feathers all these years. ü™∂ ü™∂ ü™∂ 

A few weeks ago I saw a post on social media from Andie that on Jan 8th they lost everything in the Eaton fire in California. Their Altadena home, her studio for The Feathered Head, her husband‚Äôs recording studio, and all her beloved chickens.

Well my heart broke for them. So as soon as I started messaging Andie, I knew what I had to do. Send her feathers back to her, as she had nothing left of her beloved flock. And I couldn‚Äôt just send the feathers‚Ä¶I had to do a little more‚Ä¶

Adjusting to our new normal.

New walks, new smells, learning new sidewalks with unfamiliar bumps. In a neighborhood I never expected to live in, after a move I never planned for. We‚Äôre finding new favorite spots, but it‚Äôs hard. Really hard.

Everything familiar is gone‚Äîthe rhythm of our days, the neighbors I loved in @visitaltadena, even the little quirks of our old home. The customizations we did for us; that were so perfect. I miss waiting for peacocks to cross the road when I was in a rush. I miss Maggie sprinting out the back door, knowing she never will again. I even miss the coyotes that stole the neighbors‚Äô cats.

I sobbed in the parking lot of our new post office today. Every day, I realize more things we don‚Äôt have anymore. I miss the history of our old town, the comfort of my best friend being just a walk away for our dogs to play. I really miss the people. 

We‚Äôre ‚Äúfine.‚Äù We‚Äôre healthy(ish), we have the dogs, and we‚Äôll figure it out. But in so many ways, we aren‚Äôt fine at all.
Reconnaissance for our friends in Altadena. üòûüòû. We just did an emergency escape gate in the big fence the week before.  It‚Äôs unbelievable.  #eatonfire #malkoedesign #mrguate #altadenastrong

For those of you that know me best know I hold what is likely a minority opinion: that social media is, in the aggregate, a net negative for us as a civilization. That being said, I have been humbled by life this year in ways that will require faith and hope no matter which way you slice it going forward. My hometown is burnt to the ground. We are headed into 5th week of the trump Presidency and the news seems to be getting more horrifying with everyday that passes...Respite comes in different forms for people. I had a friend who shared that in the midst of losing everything in the Altadena fires, TikTok brought some modicum of giggles, and that indeed was a tiny daily respite for her.  It is in that headspace that I am going back to basics and asking myself: what is the one thing that has always been, no matter what, an expression of faith and has also provided respite for me? Easy answer, music. I maintain that songs are my tattoos. 

In 2021, when broadway was shut down, I decided to embark on a project inspired by one of my favorite creative minds, @mirandajuly , the #30day artist challenge, which I embraced as  #30days30songs. I know for a creative career we have to engage with SM, so I am picking #mirandajulys project back up again as a healthy means by which for me to engage, and to impose external growth when one doesn‚Äôt feel it on the inside. And I have to admit, it was actually a helpful accountability and encouragement tool the last time I did it, and it is my hope that it will be again. So, social media, it is with a deeply humbled heart that this analogue curmudgeon shares this project, be gentle with me! üíöüíöüíö (Insert bashful emoticon.) #30days30songs #30daychallenge #music #broadway #eatonfire #actor #actorslife #singersongwriter #folk #originalmusic #piano #guitar #acoustic #banjo #ukulele #practice #discipline #rehearsal #student #sadaltosongs

Serving the Eaton Fire Family in Pasadena
Finding Hope in the Ashes
Today, I had the privilege of serving a family affected by the Eaton Fire in Pasadena, California. Although the Eaton Fire area remains closed to the public, I had the incredible opportunity to get there with the help of friends and partners.

As we began our search, our focus was on reclaiming the precious jewelry and souvenirs lost in the burning ashes. It felt like we were gold miners, sifting through the remnants in hopes of uncovering hidden treasures. Incredibly, the mother found her son‚Äôs collection of crystals, which brought back beautiful memories of his childhood.

As I continued to filter through the ashes, my heart raced when I discovered a diamond ring amidst the debris. Friends around me also unearthed home decorations that the mother had lovingly gathered over the past 20 years. Despite the devastating loss, the family‚Äôs deep faith in God stood as a beacon of hope that inspired me to maintain joy, even in the toughest of circumstances.

Serving in disaster areas is more than just a task for me; it‚Äôs my passion. This experience reinforced my dedication to earning resources that allow me to help others in need. 

My wish for everyone is to remain safe and well, spreading love and support in challenging times.

Music: Near You Jesus
Lyrics: Levi Sap Nei Thang

Just when the world begins to look away, when the news cycles shift and the headlines move on‚Äîour grief remains. The fires may be out, but the weight of what was lost still lingers. And now, as floods wash over what‚Äôs left, it feels like devastation upon devastation.

But here‚Äôs what I know: we are not alone in this.

For the past five weeks, through the ashes, through the wreckage, through the unbearable, it has been your words, your presence, your unwavering kindness that have carried me. Every message, every comment, every moment of shared grief and quiet understanding‚Äîit has meant everything. It has been a lifeline.

Because grief does not live in isolation. Loss may be personal, but mourning is collective. And this city, this community, this vast network of hearts‚Äîboth here in LA and across the world‚Äîhas proven that even in ruin, something unshakable remains: each other.

So to those still standing in the embers, to those learning how to exist inside the after, to those who refuse to let grief be carried alone‚Äîthank you.

Thank you for reminding me that even in a world that often feels terrifying, at the end of the day, all we really have is each other.

And that? That is everything. üíõ

-Dr. Z

In-between fighting the fires in the Palisades, he ran home to Altadena to try and save his mom's house. Sadly, his mother, and both his sisters, lost their homes too. As we walk through this disaster together, we all have our stories to share. So proud of my little one for taking her favorite @sidecardoughnuts to @lafdstation69 this morning, where we met some of our extraordinary heroes, and the fire station dog, Chewy. She then helped a homeowner retrieve film from a garage filled with mud in her colorful rain boots, bringing just a bit of cheer to the sadness. We were able to transport a beloved chair from an unsafe home to a new location for the owners, and facilitate a few more sandbags for delivery. Home Sweet Home üè°‚ù§Ô∏è

After 30 days in a hotel, we are finally back home. The past month has been a whirlwind‚Äîphysically, emotionally, and mentally exhausting‚Äîbut stepping through our front door again feels surreal.

It took two weeks of intense restoration to make our home livable again, including:

‚úîÔ∏è Full insulation removal & replacement in the attics
‚úîÔ∏è Attic encapsulation to seal in safety
‚úîÔ∏è Air duct cleaning to remove any smoke & toxins
‚úîÔ∏è Textile removal‚Äîevery piece of clothing, shoes, rugs, and curtains sent off for cleaning (for months)
‚úîÔ∏è Deep cleaning‚Äîevery room, every cabinet, every drawer, every single spice jar!
‚úîÔ∏è Air scrubbers‚Äîrunning for days to clean the air 

Unfortunately we‚Äôre not done, all blinds and mattresses are a total loss and need to be replaced - this is likely why we still smell smoke in parts of the house. This process has been overwhelming, but we are beyond grateful to have a home to return to. Thank you to everyone who has supported us on this journey. üôè‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π One step closer to normal. #EatonFire #HomeAgain #Grateful #FireRecovery #AltadenaStrong

Pasadena - Senator Sasha Ren√©e P√©rez issued the following statement on the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers‚Äô decision to forgo additional soil testing following debris removal and topsoil excavation:

‚ÄúFire victims deserve to know their property is safe before rebuilding. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers‚Äô decision to reject the communities‚Äô calls for additional soil testing after debris removal and topsoil excavation is completely unacceptable. 

‚ÄúFrom past wildfires, we know that toxins and carcinogens can be found in soil deeper than six inches. It is incomplete and irresponsible to limit the remediation to six inches without checking for additional health hazards.

‚ÄúThe Eaton and Palisades fire victims must not be subjected to hidden cancers and illnesses from toxins lurking in the ground.

‚ÄúI call on the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to reverse its decision and truly fulfill its vital mission of helping fire victims recover and rebuild with confidence in a safe environment.‚Äù

@usacehq  @senatorsrp

üî• Los Angeles Wildfires: Facts & Figures üî•

In January 2025, Los Angeles faced devastating wildfires that led to significant legal actions. Here's a snapshot:

Eaton Fire Overview:

Start Date: January 7, 2025
Area Affected: Over 14,000 acres
Structures Destroyed: More than 9,400 homes
Fatalities: 17 lives lost 

Legal Repercussions:

Utility Company Lawsuit: Shareholders filed a class-action lawsuit against Edison International, alleging misleading safety practices. 

Insurance Claims: California's FAIR Plan requested an additional $1 billion to cover claims, highlighting the strain on the insurance system. 

Economic Impact:

Estimated Losses: Between $28 billion and $275 billion, potentially the costliest disaster in U.S. history. 

These figures underscore the profound impact of the wildfires on communities, legal systems, and the economy.

Stay informed and support those affected.

Every time I go home to Altadena, I drive down an old familiar street to see what‚Äôs standing or not. This was my local hardware store, a small, family-owned True Value franchise. Altadena Hardware had been around for 80 years in this spot. I bought many tools and supplies here, all of which burned in my garage. As I replace my tools, I‚Äôd give anything to buy them from the friendly folks at Altadena Hardware, and not Home Depot or Amazon, but that‚Äôs no longer my world. 

This building also held a small, locally-owned bicycle shop, Steve‚Äôs Bike Shop, where I took my son‚Äôs many bikes over the years when they needed new tire tubes or other repairs, or to pick up accessories like bells and kickstands. Several years ago, he and I stripped an old kid‚Äôs bike down to the metal and rebuilt it together for him. The bike shop was a wonderful resource for that project, in supplies and shared knowledge. 

Also housed here was the Wellema Hat Co., an old school hat-maker that made felt hats by hand using vintage tools. As a fedora guy myself, I‚Äôd stop in there to gawk at the artistry of the headwear and the charm of the store itself. I never got a Wellema hat as I was waiting for our home‚Äôs mold remediation to be over. I thought I still had time. 

There were other businesses in this old, brick retail building. They may not have been as meaningful to me but they were part of other people‚Äôs stories. They were all part of the heart of Altadena. 

As you can see, I have a history of photographing my cars with this building, all part of daily driving classics. Bonus photo of my former Porsche 944.

This Batchelder plaque fell about 10 feet once the wall it was mounted on burned to the ground in Altadena.  Shout out to Cliff Douglas who glued it back together‚Ä¶ Stanley and Cliff are heading up @savethetiles‚Ä¶. So humbled to be able to fix this historic artifact from the #eatonfire. Grateful to have the opportunity and saddened by the events that led to this. I think this might be the first historic artifact from the Eaton fire to be restored. Or one of the first at least. We‚Äôre living in the in-between‚Äîcaught between what was and what comes next. The grief is settling in now, but so is something else: a bond, unshaken‚Äînot just by tragedy, but by resilience. By something ancient, something untamed. We are Wildborn.

What tried to take everything left behind something even stronger‚Äîa community that refuses to fall.

This isn‚Äôt just about rebuilding. It‚Äôs about remembering. It‚Äôs about rising. It‚Äôs about standing shoulder to shoulder, knowing that when everything changed, we didn‚Äôt turn away‚Äîwe held the line for each other.

But where do we put all of this? The loss, the resilience, the heartbreak, the hope? A home for every story, every scar, every step forward. That‚Äôs why I created this space. A place to grieve, to heal, to rebuild‚Äînot just what was lost, but who we are. To navigate this in-between together.

We are more than where we come from. We are more than what we‚Äôve lost.

We don‚Äôt just survive. We grow. We rise. We stand. Together.

Dr. Z

Please meet the very special Mew, who was permanently displaced by the Eaton fire, and is now looking for his new family. Is it you?

Mew is sweet, friendly, snuggly, confident, loves everyone he meets,¬†and has never met a lap he didn‚Äôt like. He‚Äôll follow you around, chirping and purring for affection. And when you come home, he‚Äôs the welcome wagon, flopping on his side.¬†

Almost three years old, Mew is still very curious and loves to play. Some of his favorite¬†activities are leaping for the Cat Dancer, chasing lasers, and bouts of hide and seek with his human friends. As self-appointed chairman of the Neighborhood Association, Mew also likes to lounge by the window to watch birds and all the goings-on.¬†

Because Mew has star quality, he will do best as a solo kitty in a home without dogs, other cats, or young children. Ideally his new parents will work from home since Mew prefers not to be alone for long stretches!¬†

Mew is a tad¬†chonky so will need to be on a wet-food-only diet and have parents that can help him slowly trim down. Also, due to his curiosity, Mew has a tendency to be a door dasher so it is very important that you take precautions (and not have a door that faces a busy street. 
This wonderful boy has been through a lot. Let‚Äôs give him his Act Two. For all the love you give, he‚Äôll give back double.

We found a place to rent in Sierra Madre. Stopped by Sierra Madre Self Storage to see if anything was available, in case we recover anything from the ashes of our home. 

Jennifer Waldon, who runs the place, told me I'd be at the end of a long waiting line. But we got to talking about our shared love of Altadena, and the friends she had there who lost their homes. She pulled out a photo of Christmas Tree Lane in January 1949, dusted with snow. A much more beautiful January than we saw this year!

It was gifted by a friend who left Altadena and fires for Florida, only to find a different kind of climate danger. Even so, Jennifer, a lifelong resident in this area, is thinking Florida may be in her future as well. 

She may not have storage space for me, but I will definitely visit again when we settle in her town. #altadena #resilience #sierramadre #eatonfire

There's so much we love about this article. The reporter really really captured what we do, why we do it, how we do it, and the impact on the ground.

We are so proud to see Brad Sherwood highlighted alongside Jennifer Gray Thompson + Jenn Kaaoush + Casey Taylor and more.

This means everything:

"After the Fire were the first people that made me feel at all better about any kind of future that we might have, because they‚Äôve been through it,‚Äù said Rabbi Amy Bernstein, who lost her home in the Palisades Fire alongside hundreds of other families in her congregation. ‚ÄúTruly, it‚Äôs the first time that I felt any kind of hope that we will come through this as a community.‚Äù

üîµüîµüîµüîµ

Authentic Altadena Town Council Vice Chair Nic Arnzen had connected with After the Fire USA earlier in January at a webinar for reeling Altadena residents. His council census tract, including the mountain area of Altadena, suffered some of the worst destruction, with total destruction across up to 80% of the area. His family was among the 5,000 of the tract‚Äôs 5,500 residents whose homes were destroyed.

Arnzen had already led tours of the Altadena burn zone for others ‚Äî politicians, journalists, bureaucrats ‚Äî but the experience with the delegation of fire survivors was different.

‚ÄúSeeing in their eyes, ‚ÄòI know what you‚Äôre going through‚Äô ‚Äî there was a kinship that can only be forged through these terrible fires that was palpable,‚Äù Arnzen said.

Thank you to Emily Wilder.

#megafire #LAFires #afterthefire #EatonFire #pacificpalisades

Hello my friends, it is Tudor Tuesday and I am happy to report that one of my absolute favorite Tudor revival homes located in one of the most beautiful areas of Altadena has survived. I already had that indication from looking it up, but I felt much better seeing it right there in front of me. 

And yet the news isn't all good for this house. Scroll to the end for a little clip showing what it's like to live there now‚Ä¶ It was just one of the few that survived, when all around it there is destruction. I've seen that so often‚Ä¶ One amazing house surrounded by such sadness, I know I've mentioned it many times, forgive me if I am continuing to be ridiculously redundant!

Today as I tried to take advantage of the last vestiges of light as I documented yet another neighborhood in Altadena that has been burned to the ground, the thought came to me that this is a moment in life, and I suppose you have experienced them as well, when I wish there were three of me that could do different things at the same time, one of which would be sleeping, because there's definitely not enough time for that!

By now you may know that I am a ridiculous night owl, so I don't get to take advantage of every bit of daylight, and the days are short! So I'm racing with the sun, and racing with the bulldozers, trying to document everything I can before they take it all away as if it never was there, as if it didn't matter. 

If I am not being responsive, please forgive me, I'm just doing my best with the juggling right now. But know that I appreciate you immensely... ‚ù§Ô∏èüíî‚ù§Ô∏è

In search and rescue, it‚Äôs not about recognition - we do this because help is needed, and we show up. But when that dedication is acknowledged by those we respect, it means more than words can say.

This week, the @altadenamountainrescue presented our team with a plaque recognizing our support during the Eaton Fire. The truth is, we didn‚Äôt think twice about being there. That‚Äôs what this job is about - showing up for each other, for our fellow teams, and for the communities we serve cumulatively.

To our friends at Altadena Mountain Rescue - thank you. Not just for this honor, but for the way you lead, for the way you serve, and for always having our backs. It was a privilege to stand beside you. Know we‚Äôd do it again, whenever and wherever.

valentines day has passed, but my love for my friends persists year round üôÇ‚Äç‚ÜïÔ∏è @beenymph has continually been such a dear friend to me, and together we've embarked on so many creative ventures!!! 

unfortunately, during the eaton fire in altadena this past january, milena's family home and job have burnt down, and when i asked them what was the most helpful thing to do to support them, they said to book them! 

as milena is a professional photographer, having clients to shoot and therefore having work and an income is more important than ever- theyre such an amazing artist, and they would love to be able to create art with our community while supporting themselves financially. these are trying times for everyone, and being able to mutually support each other is something that is deeply important for myself and milena

shooting this set was an absolute delight, as most things are when i hang out with milena! our initial plans for a location didnt work out so they ended up coming over to my place, and armed with 15 dollars worth of fake roses, goth clompers, and a dream we COOKEDDDD 

im so excited to share this set of queer and disabled celebration and resilience, and if you or you know anyone who is hankering to have a photoshoot done, ples book my dearest @beenymph !!!!!

üö®URGENT: PLEASE SHAREüêæ‚õëÔ∏è

üî• WE ARE RUNNING OUT OF TIME ‚åõÔ∏è

As of today 2/21, the majority of rescue organizations have withdrawn efforts and there are only a handful left with support slowing down. In just a few small Palisades neighborhoods alone, we have 10 cats confirmed to be alive before the storm‚Ä¶ and there are countless more out there across these massive burn zones. Just last night WUFAW rescued one of these cats. It takes a lot of patience and effort to go out and re-bait/set new traps daily. With manpower and resources dwindling, our odds are stacking against us.

The rescue organizations are spread thin as is, and understandably they have to shift their focus back to the rest of the SoCal animals that desperately need their help. By next week there may be only a couple organizations out trying to trap and bring these animals home. My mission remains the same. With your help we don‚Äôt have to give up on our furry friends.

This was never about money for me. I had no idea how massive this operation was going to become, otherwise I would have asked for support when I first started this mission. Because we‚Äôve reached such a critical point in our efforts, we need to be out there around the clock before we lose our chance at rescuing the remaining survivors. In order for me to continue full time and keep my business closed, I need YOUR support.

Even $5 can make a difference. If you can‚Äôt donate, please share the fundraiser link. Every share spreads awareness and helps bring these pets home.

Let‚Äôs show these animals that they haven‚Äôt been forgotten. Donate link in bio üôèüèª

I‚Äôd be remiss if I kept posting here without sharing what the past couple of months have been like for us. I‚Äôve been on a roller coaster of emotions. There is life before January 7th‚Äîand then there is the after. And in this after, time has stretched and folded, each day feeling like a lifetime. We still have a house, but we can‚Äôt go back yet. 

I‚Äôve been in survival mode, living out of bags, holding it together for my babies. We will go home again, someday. For now, we are working to make it livable‚Äîsorting through what we‚Äôre keeping, letting go of what‚Äôs been damaged. Fire restoration crews come and go. 

The water is still unsafe. Patience wears thin, but ridiculous optimism keeps me steady. The days blur together. Weeks slip past.

Driving through Altadena, I feel the weight of it all‚Äîgrief, disbelief, the ache of a community forever changed. The healing will take time.

I don‚Äôt know about you, but I‚Äôve already lived through 2025 multiple times.

#eatonfire #altadenastrong #altadena #lastrong

A Moment We‚Äôll Never Forget ‚ú®üî•üé∂

Right after wrapping an unforgettable video shoot for a commercial that aired during the Grammys‚Äîa powerful moment that helped share our story with the world. After losing our business and community in the Eaton Fire, this was a testament to our resilience, culture, and the unshakable spirit of Altadena.

Grateful to have shared this experience with Rhythms Family Band, @anderson._paak , and our closest friends. The love and support we‚Äôve received has been overwhelming, and we‚Äôre more motivated than ever to rebuild.

Thank you for standing with us‚Äîthis is just the beginning! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ôæÔ∏èüî•

That cycling scene gatekeeping? Stops at the door. It doesn‚Äôt come in here. 

‚ö†Ô∏è NO DROP, NO RUSH: Road bike beginner‚Äôs Ride ‚ö†Ô∏è

üö¥ March 16, 2025
üìç Meet at Esquina: 8:00 AM
‚è≥ Roll Out: 8:30 AM
üìè 25 Miles ‚Äì Moderate Pace ‚Äì Social & Training Ride
‚ö†Ô∏è Beginner ride for road bikes (hybrids are ok) 
üó∫Ô∏è Riding through the city, catch the LA river north, and loop back through NELA 

We know there‚Äôs a lot of gatekeeping and ego in the road bike male-driven cycling scene. Too much road bike-shaming, too many people acting like they were never beginners. Not here. This ride is for those who have been pushed away by that culture‚Äîfor the road cycling-curious, the long-distance hopefuls, those on a health journey, for non-male riders, and anyone looking for a safe, ego-free space to learn and road ride.

Maybe you‚Äôre riding a vintage steel bike, a $10k dream build, or something you got secondhand. No matter what you ride, if you‚Äôre looking for an open and supportive cycling space, this is your ride.

What to Expect:

‚úÖ No egos. No bike shaming. No dumb questions.
‚úÖ A no-drop pace‚Äîeveryone stays together.
‚úÖ Seasoned riders to answer questions.
‚úÖ Social ride + space to learn road cycling basics.
‚úÖ Women, POC, non-binary, femme, lgbtq, cyclists encouraged to join.

üì£ Q&A can be asked privately to our seasoned riders or ask out loud! 

üö≤ All you need is a road bike, a helmet, and an open mind. Let‚Äôs build something together.

Tag a friend who‚Äôs been wanting to start cycling and let‚Äôs ride!

Look What Survived‚Ä¶ of course!!!

"There's no other place like this to me in the world." When she was little, Cienna Benn's mom taught her to stand barefoot in the grass outside their home in Altadena, California. Mom called it 'grounding,' a way to connect to her home, the land, and the multiple generations who came here before. Cienna's great-grandfather arrived in Altadena back in the 1930's, part of a larger migration that helped establish this small community in LA County as a haven for Black Americans.

But after the Eaton fire destroyed so much of this area last month, Black residents worry that developers will buy out the remaining multi-generational families who can't afford the long waits and the thicket of red-tape to rebuild what they've lost. 

The Benn's home was spared - the flames came right to their backyard, but no further. "Divine intervention," says Cienna's dad. Their house was still infiltrated by smoke and other hazardous debris, and they can't move back in yet. 

Cienna says they'll never leave Altadena, because the connection to her family is too deep. "I'm not interested in finding another [home]. I'm interested in growing everything that they planted here."

Her story, and the story of other Black families in Altadena, will be coming soon on @newshour. Produced by my tremendous colleagues @mikewfritz and @lane_sam and filmed by @devinpinckard 

#altadena #altadenacalifornia #altadenaisnotforsale #blackhistory #eatonfire #eatonfire2025 #fire #wildfire #pbs #pbsnews #pbsnewshour

When I first read that quote‚Äîgrief feels like fear‚Äîit hit me like a gut punch. Suddenly, everything made sense. The tightness in my chest. The way my body jolts awake at night, bracing for something that isn‚Äôt coming. The way even silence feels loud, heavy, unsettling. The way my mind feels foggy, like I‚Äôm moving through a world that no longer fits.

Grief and fear feel the same in the body. Both make you want to run, to fight, to brace yourself against something you can‚Äôt control.

But grief isn‚Äôt fear. Fear is about what might happen. Grief is about what already has. Fear screams escape. Grief whispers stay. Stay in the discomfort, in the longing, in the spaces they once filled.

And yet‚Äîgrief isn‚Äôt just an emptiness. It‚Äôs love, unspent. It‚Äôs proof that something, someone, mattered. And over time, it shifts. It doesn‚Äôt disappear, but it softens. It becomes something you carry, not something that carries you.

If you‚Äôre in it right now, just know this: You won‚Äôt always feel this way. Grief changes. And so will you.

Grateful to @taralipinski for sharing this C.S. Lewis quote. It‚Äôs incredible how words can find you exactly when you need them. 

Dr. Z

üèòÔ∏è Over the past month, I‚Äôve had the honor of working with families who lost their homes in the Los Angeles wildfires, helping them take those first steps toward rebuilding. Now, this effort is expanding as I begin to collaborate with multiple neighbors to rebuild entire streets ‚Äì creating a stronger, safer, and more sustainable community.

ü§ù Rebuilding after a wildfire isn‚Äôt just about homes‚Äîit‚Äôs about restoring lives, neighborhoods, and a sense of belonging.

üåø For nearly 20 years, I‚Äôve been dedicated to sustainable community development, and over the last three years, I‚Äôve focused on green building and wildfire-resilient home design. California Home Designs is committed to helping families navigate the rebuilding process with cost-effective, fire-resilient, and sustainable design solutions.

‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π I‚Äôve seen firsthand the devastation wildfires leave behind, both personally and professionally. With over 15,000 structures lost in the Eaton and Palisades fires alone, the need for thoughtful, resilient rebuilding has never been greater.

üí¨ If you or someone you know is facing this challenge in Altadena or Palisades, I‚Äôm here to help.

üì© Message @californiahomedesigns to start the conversation about rebuilding your home with wildfire resilience in mind.

OUT OF THE ASHES
Artist Talk and Reception 
Saturday 2/22 at 2PM
Bergamot Station F2 Santa Monica

Over 40 artists affected by the Eaton and Palisades Fires share their stories of loss and resilience through this powerful exhibition, where 100% of proceeds go directly to the artists rebuilding their practices.

In the wake of LA‚Äôs devastating wildfires, hundreds of artists lost more than just their homes and studios‚Äîthey lost lifetimes of work, memories, and irreplaceable creative legacies.

Curated by Craig Krull and Douglas Marshall, OUT OF THE ASHES features new and old work, some made while the fires were raging or directly in the aftermath. Personal reflections on what has been lost and first-hand accounts from each artist will accompany their work.

You are invited to hear directly from some of these artists at an Artist Talk moderated by Hannah Sloan on Saturday, February 22 at 2:00 PM with a reception to follow.

Amid the hustle and bustle of Frieze Week, your presence and support is appreciated. Come stand with these artists, listen to their experiences, and see the work that has emerged from the ashes.

The Eaton Fire. It‚Äôs hard to imagine the scale of the destruction until you see it first hand. I visited the site of my aunt‚Äôs home this week. I sifted through the ashes to try and find some of her treasures. It was a pretty tough day - so many family memories were made in her beautiful home. My 95 year old aunt is very resilient - Altadena strong - and it was a joy to spend some time with her and be inspired. #altadena #altadenastrong #eatoncanyon #memories #resilience #family #community #eatonfire

Dropped these off for a lovely couple I met while shooting a car.  This was last night and I hadn‚Äôt been that far up in it like that at night.  It was pitch black, no lights, no people, no nada.  I felt so at home in that space, a safe space as the kids say, and didn‚Äôt want to leave.  The opportunity to drop these off gave me the idea to capture at night, in the peace, in the stillness, in the cool Altadena evening air that I love so much.  When you give in to your calling there is nothing left to fear. There is just the calling that you hear.  I love you Altadena.  I love your dreams.

#altadena #pasadena #eatonfire #petersenmuseum #love

Full transparency: It‚Äôs been almost two months since the Eaton fires, two weeks since we reopened‚Äîand let me tell you, the devastation doesn‚Äôt get any easier. My once-beautiful morning drive up Lake blvd  to the gym is now a constant reminder of how life can change in an instant. My evening drive home feels like a ghost town. Some nights, I go to bed dreading the morning, waking up to a reality that still feels so unreal‚Äîlike a nightmare I wish we could all wake up from. I just want our beautiful community and our ‚Äúold‚Äù life back. üíîüò¢üò¢
I am grateful that we are back open again so that we can provide a place for community here in Altadena although my heart is still so broken for this town. Every day, I ache for my dear students and friends who lost everything. This disaster has left so many in limbo, uncertain about what the future holds.
Please know that it‚Äôs okay not to be okay. Give yourself grace, space to grieve, and permission to feel sadness. The road ahead will have dark moments, but we have to believe that light is waiting for us at the end of this long tunnel.
To all: I am here for you every step of the way. Please lean on me for support during this tough time. Everyone processes disaster differently‚Äîso let‚Äôs offer each other space, patience, kindness, and love. Hold on tight to the ones you cherish and remember what truly matters in life. Hugs to all ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©πüôè
Love Lila 
#eatonfire #disaster #heartache #friendship #love #kindness
Heartbreaking aftermath of the Pacific Palisades wildfire. My thoughts are with everyone who has to sift through the remains of their homes.

I went to visit Altadena today. beloved Altadena. What struck me was the silence. It was oddly peaceful. Nothing but birds chirping. I noticed the majestic trees that survived while houses right in front of them burned to the ground. Also, green lawns amidst complete fire devastation.  I was also struck by the randomness of it, entire blocks of houses burned to the ground and across the street a row of houses unharmed. The fireplaces remind me of gravestones. I am so saddened by this tragedy and I can‚Äôt imagine what it must be like for all the people that lost their houses. What I imagine is that it must be like losing a loved one or just losing your very soul. and there are so many of them. I pray for them all every day, and worry about people I know and people I don‚Äôt know. i have no more words.üíî
#AltadenaStrong
#altadenanotforsale
#EatonFire

A little get away up the coast for fresh air, heavy processing, and a fresh start. We‚Äôve got forest trails, ocean breeze, a laptop and a guitar - what more do I need? Nothing. Good, cause that‚Äôs what I‚Äôve got! #eatonfire #healing

I just wanted to give an update on what I have been up to lately. I am so appreciative of all the help you have given me to help start my life over.

I have been looking for new places to live for the last month. I was not able to afford anything on my own in the Los Angeles area. I had to get a bit creative, so I plan to move to the Las Vegas area on March 1st. I found a great 3-bedroom 2-bathroom Condo in the Centennial Hills area. It has everything I was looking for plus comes with a single car garage. It is about 30 minutes from the Strip. 

I am still actively looking for my kitten, Hoku, every day. I checked shelters and other sites in hopes we can find him. Animal rescuers have night cameras in the area and are also looking for him. I really hope we can find him and bring him home. I feel so much guilt about not being able to get to him in time with the fire.

#EatonFire #wildfire #staypositive #newstart

A hydroxyl generator is one of the many tools we use within our arsenal.

. A hydroxyl generator is a device that uses UV-C to remove odors, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), virus particles, bacteria particles, mold and pollutants from the air.

.Remove the smell of cigarette smoke odor from a room.
.Remove odors due to fire damage.
.Clean water damage and mold.
.Clean crime scenes.
.Eliminate pet odors.

#eatonfire #eatoncanyon #palisadesfire #pacificpalisades #wildfire #restoration #hepa #losangeles

‚ÄúHaving the solar and battery system allowed me to monitor the fire and help save lives.‚Äù 

As the Eaton Fire rapidly spread in early January, power outages throughout Southern California left many without electricity for days. Many were left without crucial appliances, and the lack of internet connection cut them off from the news.

Daniel, an Altadena resident, had a backup battery that kept his home powered for close to two days before the fire ultimately spread and damaged his system. During that period, he became the information center for his neighborhood, regularly providing important updates. This ultimately helped him and his neighbors to evacuate to safety.

The unfortunate truth is that extreme weather events, including fires and severe winds, will continue to affect Southern California. Having a backup battery to power your necessary appliances can quite literally be a lifesaver in these scenarios.

At Solar Discovery, we are committed to helping our local Southern California community through this difficult time. We are offering free site assessments for homeowners affected by the Eaton and Palisades Fires to evaluate damage to their solar systems and assist in the rebuilding process. If your home was affected, reach out to us to schedule an inspection and learn how you can restore your solar and battery systems as quickly as possible.

Link in bio.

I‚Äôve learned that 2 conflicting things can be true at the same time. 

We can grieve for what is gone...but, we can still be happy and grateful for what is good in our lives too.

Undoubtedly, this last month has been emotionally heavy and difficult for so many. All of us who have friends that have lost their homes have had immense survivor‚Äôs guilt, and I‚Äôve mentally struggled and felt weird posting happy and ‚Äúnormal‚Äù content.

For this post though, it makes me feel really good that I was able to help my friend find a new home: a place of stability, a safe space to start their healing process. 

I hope that slowly, the sadness of losing the home that had been in their family for generations can turn into a sense of peace and be replaced with happy new memories as they rebuild.

Congratulations to my friend and her family. I‚Äôm looking forward to lounging with you in the sun! xo ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

üê¶
Hopefully by this time tomorrow our back yard will be clear so we can start the pool clean up and permit process for garage replacement and interior cleaning! Yeah!

On National Caregivers Day, I want to honor Joan Nguyen, a former childcare provider, founder of Bumo, and an incredible female entrepreneur who like so many Angelenos, has been giving of her time, talent, and resources to serve members of the community impacted by the fires. 

Joan experienced an immense loss when the #EatonFire devastated her home and neighborhood. But in the face of tragedy, she took action, working to provide emergency childcare for families in need.

I‚Äôm so proud of Joan and all caregivers who step up in times of crisis, providing essential care and support when families need it most.

A tribute to resilience, renewal, and the unbreakable bond between animals and their guardians. With every flicker, this candle honors the spirit of survival and the journey toward healing.

‚ú® 100% of sales go directly toward the Pasadena Humane Society‚Äôs Wildfire Rescue Relief, providing lifesaving aid, shelter, and support for animals impacted by wildfires. ‚ú®

Eaton Incident 1-7-25. LACoFD Engine 8 firefighters direct hose streams into a fully involved house after the #eatonfire, driven by strong #santaanawinds, roared out of the Angeles National Forest and quickly impacted the homes along New York Drive in the city of #altadena. Photograph Copyright ¬©Ô∏è Ken Morris.
üòÑ

"What I saw was a skeleton of the entire town." Nigerian-born musician and local business owner Onochie Chukwurah, describing what the Eaton fires did to his community of Altadena, CA. 

His store, Rhythyms of the Village, which he owned and operated with his son, Emeka, is a complete loss. In the aftermath, Onochie and Emeka and friends set up a donation center in his driveway, collecting and dispensing free goods for those who lost everything. "This fire came here, devastated our community, [but] is turning us around too, from each one being mean to the other, to each one help[ing] the other. Everybody's helping."

He and Emeka hope Altadena will return to the diverse community it was before, and resist the economic forces that might try to displace them. "These are some resilient people," says Emeka. "They've been here, for some people - a century, you know? And they and their family have placed these roots here, and I don't think it's going to be an easy battle for them to come and take it."

More from them, and other residents of Altadena, later this week on @newshour - produced by @mikefritz and @lane_sam and shot by @devinpinckard

I‚Äôm still so overwhelmed by the damage of last month‚Äôs fires I haven‚Äôt been able to visit any of my regular haunts that burned in Altadena; the houses I‚Äôve spent hours admiring (over time) and businesses I used to visit daily that are gone feel like teeth that have been knocked out. And this pain is nothing compared to the pain felt by those who have actually lost their homes and businesses; a building is meaningless without its profound and well-worn connection to its inhabitants. 

So I was hesitant to post burn pics of my parents‚Äô house, since the damage is relatively minor. But seeing the garden I designed and help raise partially burnt to the ground is something else‚Ä¶

A huge shoutout to the firefighters who saved our whole neighborhood, even though it was 100% surrounded by fire at one point. And another to all the volunteers and donors who are still out there serving the displaced!! ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Altadena's Odyssey Charter Schools South Campus, a vibrant center of learning and growth for 372 students from our community, was tragically destroyed.

Why you need a post fire appraisal. The purpose of a post-fire real estate appraisal is to determine the exact pre and post-fire values of your property so you can make informed decisions. These values are needed for a variety of reasons. The reasons range from investment decisions, calculating an IRS casualty loss for your taxes, negotiating with your insurance adjuster, property tax appeal and evidence for a lawsuit. Below are just a few more reasons why you need a post-fire appraisal

Investment decisions to sell or rebuild
Pre listing market analysis
IRS casualty loss
Insurance settlement
Evidence for lawsuit
Property tax appeal
Short pay mortgage

The process begins with a physical inspection of the property to determine fire damage, specific location in the neighborhood and the view from the site. Some properties may only have interior smoke/ash damage, exterior soot staining, damage from heat while others are totally destroyed. Some damage can be remediated while other properties must be completely rebuilt.

See full article link in first comment. #marycummins #postfireappraisal #realestateappraisal #eatonfire #palisadesfire #prefireappraisalo #losangelesfires #altadena #pacificpalisades

All of these houses were shot in Altadena after the destruction. It's wonderful to see that there are still beautiful homes standing in the area, but also important to note that all of them are basically surrounded by destruction. Some of them have it right next-door, some of them have it right across the street and perhaps for some of them it's a couple of houses away, but it's there, it's everywhere. I'm very grateful to be able to gaze upon these homes but it's not enough.

Joe Sierra spent his childhood on the streets of Altadena. He attended St. Elizabeth Parochial School through eighth grade and graduated from Pasadena High School.

His father, Jesus, made the decision to settle down in the area decades earlier, in around 1967. He purchased a house displaced by the construction of the Interstate 210 through Pasadena, and he moved the home to the family on North Marengo in Altadena.

The father-son duo rebuilt it, and this new home, replacing the smaller, older house on the land. It was bigger, grander and the center of countless family gatherings all these decades. That is, until Jan. 7.

üì∏: Courtesy of Joe Sierra
