HSC&A / Out of the Ashes: Artist Talk Recap

On Saturday, we had the privilege of listening to the artists of Out of the Ashes as they shared their experiences of loss, resilience, and the long road ahead after the devastating Eaton and Palisades Fires.

The room was full‚Äîfull of grief, full of hope, full of artists who have lost lifetimes of work. Some lost their homes, their studios, their archives‚Äîeverything they had built. 40 artists, 40 stories. Not every artist had the chance to speak, but hands were raised solemnly throughout the audience signaling that their work is on display. The artists who spoke with Hannah offered deeply personal stories, recalling moments of profound devastation, and reflections on their identity as artists in the wake of unimaginable loss.

The feeling in the room was unlike anything we‚Äôve experienced before‚Äîan intense catharsis, a shared mourning, a collective attempt to process the unthinkable. 

It was a moment of deep connection in a week filled with high-energy openings and dazzling exhibitions across the city. In the midst of LA Art Week, this was a stopping point. A space for reflection. A moment that will stay with us forever.

Thank you to Craig Krull and Douglas Marshall for curating such a powerful, sensitive exhibition and for giving these artists a place to process, express, and find support in one another.

Most of all, thank you to the artists who bravely shared their stories‚Äîwe are in awe of your strength.

@craigkrullgallery @marshall.gallery @sloanprojects @bergamotsantamonica

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @pasadenahumane You may remember the gray cat we were calling Hope, who came to us with severe burns during the Eaton Fire. She is still slowly recovering in our ICU with treatment from our veterinary staff, but she is looking better every day. Her fur and whiskers are even starting to grow back and she continues to have the sweetest personality.

We are overjoyed to share that Hope‚Äôs family has been found. Hope, whose real name is Skinny Minnie, was a neighborhood cat in Altadena. Mark and Lisa had fallen in love with the outdoor kitty and decided to bring her into their family, working gradually to introduce her to their two indoor cats so she could live inside, too. Heartbreakingly, they had been so close to transitioning her to indoor life when the Eaton Fire tore through their neighborhood.

While Mark and Lisa were able to evacuate with their two indoor cats, Skinny Minnie was nowhere to be found. Severe winds pushed the fire into Altadena with little to no warning. As their home burned to the ground, they could only hope that Skinny Minnie had gotten herself to safety.

Mark and Lisa felt so many emotions when they were finally reunited with their beloved cat - including guilt for not being able to bring her inside sooner. However, no one could have predicted that such a terrible disaster would strike Altadena. Many were lucky to escape with their lives.

We look forward to the day when Skinny Minnie is able to finally go home with Mark and Lisa, who will be keeping her strictly indoors with their two other cats. Until then, these two loving cat parents are in our ICU every day, visiting with their sweet girl.

#feelgoodstory #pasadenahumanesociety #catsofinstagram #eatonfire

It‚Äôs been a little over a month since we lost our home to the Eaton Fire. I went to search through the rubble a few weeks ago and was pleasantly surprised to find some of my pieces were still intact. 

Among the pieces I found was the first mug I ever made (last picture).

Ceramics wasn‚Äôt accessible to me growing up. I had the opportunity to take my first wheel throwing class during grad school at @berkeleyartstudio in 2022 through a scholarship. I have been at it ever since. Although the pieces I found are not safe to use, I am grateful that I still have a physical reminder of the progression of my pottery journey so far. 

I am looking forward to continue creating, growing and experimenting some more at @notanotherpotterystudio ü•∞

We were just there 2 weeks prior for a piano recital. She had just rebranded to Altadena Piano School. It felt like the start of a new chapter. I had several dreams the first few weeks of Lady Gaga pulling Susie up to perform with her on stage. Maybe because of this article, that can happen.

Why you need a post-fire appraisal if your home has been damaged or destroyed in the recent fires. The purpose of a post-fire real estate appraisal is to determine the exact pre and post-fire values of your property so you can make informed decisions. These values are needed for a variety of reasons. The reasons range from investment decisions, calculating an IRS casualty loss for your taxes, negotiating with your insurance adjuster, property tax appeal and evidence for a lawsuit. Below are just a few more reasons why you need a post-fire appraisal

* Investment decisions to sell or rebuild 
* Pre listing market analysis
* IRS casualty loss
* Insurance settlement
* Evidence for lawsuit
* Property tax appeal
* Short pay mortgage
* Buy out family member

The process begins with a physical inspection of the property to determine fire damage, specific location in the neighborhood and the view from the site. Some properties may only have interior smoke/ash damage, exterior soot staining, damage from heat while others are totally destroyed. Some damage can be remediated while other properties must be completely rebuilt. Prices start at $450 for an average sized home for pre-fire and post-fire values.

With the help of a large donation from @gofundme, we surpassed our first fundraising stretch goal in only 10 days! We are totally blown away by the Gofundme‚Äôs support and their gracious offer to help our important mission. Their team is an absolute delight. To everyone who has donated, shared, followed, and messaged‚Äî thank you from the bottom of our hearts ‚ù§Ô∏è

BUT WE STILL NEED YOUR HELP!

We‚Äôve learned so much in these last couple weeks ‚Äî and we have a lot more expenses than originally anticipated. By our calculations, the resources our new stretch goal will provide can get us up to four tile rescue crews (skilled masons) in the field and we can save well over 100 fireplaces here in the burn zone.

So what do we need to win the race against the bulldozers? Skilled masons, who are the heart and soul of our operation and are working long days with us to try to save every tile. They want to volunteer their own time, but they are small local businesses who have very real hard costs ‚Äî paying their skilled laborers, acquiring supplies such as scaffolding, tools, boxes, packing materials, and providing food and water and PPE to the tile removal teams. Just one fireplace takes a day or more to remove. It is painstaking, highly skilled work that cannot be rushed.

We could not do any of this without YOU. This town is knocked down hard but we are coming back strong. Please help us save every last tile!

Dr. Wes here everyone, even though the California wildfires and the flooding destruction in Kentucky are probably out of the news as of late, been recently corresponding with some old friends, fans, and fellow jammers in those and other storm-hit areas, and the devastation really is worse than a firebombed war zone in some parts. These really are some of the worst natural disasters to ever befall the country. I know some of the reports were focusing a lens on the damage to e.g. luxury resorts but it's mostly working and middle class families and small businesses that are bearing the brunt of these calamities (especially in Altadena and across the Bluegrass State), and it's going to be many long and difficult years to recover. 

It's a pretty tough time for a lot of us right now but if you have the means and inclination, please take a moment to visit some of the donation aggregator sites like Charity Navigator, GiveWell or give dot org for some vetted and accredited organizations helping with the cleanup and recuperation efforts, and just helping the locals to get through things day by day. Every little bit helps.
.
.
.
.
.
.

I used to spend a lot of time in Altadena, whether it was visiting friends or hiking Eaton Canyon. The last time I had been there was the morning after the initial outbreak of the Eaton Fire. I spent most of that Wednesday preventing the fire from reaching my friend @scottgordonart ‚Äòs home. The houses behind his were already gone, and I did what I could to stop the flames creeping through his backyard.

I was curious to see the state of a town I had once frequented so often, but I also wanted to respect the devastation it had just endured. I didn‚Äôt want to photograph the remains of homes where families were now left with only chimneys and toxic swimming pools. But I did want to document the aftermath of the chaos that was the Eaton Fire.

After driving around, I came across what I assume was a used car lot‚Äîvehicles reduced to skeletal frames and corroded shells. Tires had melted into the ground, windows shattered, leaving behind jagged edges and warped blisters. The close-up shots revealed the textures of decay: flaking metal, charred paint, and the deep, corrosive wounds left by heat and time.

There was a heavy sadness while shooting these photos, a weight that settled with every frame. Standing among the wreckage, the sheer destruction was undeniable, forcing an acknowledgment of the chaos fire leaves behind. Each image holds the quiet devastation of loss, a reminder of how little survives when tragedy strikes. My heart goes out to those who lost their homes and belongings and to those now facing the immense struggle of having to start over.

#AltadenaFires #Aftermath #RustAndDecay #EatonFire #LostButNotForgotten #BurntRemains #PhotoDocumentary #VisualStorytelling #TexturesOfTime #UrbanDecay #TragedyAndResilience #Rust #Textures

Wildfire Contamination Won‚Äôt Go Away Overnight - But We Have a Solutionüíß

The effects of wildfires don‚Äôt end when the flames are out.

üí®Smoke, ash, and chemical runoff continue to contaminate water supplies, making tap water unsafe.

üí°The crisis isn‚Äôt temporary, but neither is our solution.

With Skywell 5, you can have a reliable source of clean, purified water - no matter what‚Äôs happening around you!

I only learned about the amazing Park Planned homes development after 20 of the 28 homes were lost completely in the Eaton Fire (Jan 25). Designed by the architect Gregory Ain and completed in 1948, from Dwell.com: ‚Äúthe Park Planned homes were forecast as ‚Äúminiature estates‚Äù, larger homes on more generous lots, but still incorporating the collective spirit, cost benefits of prefabrication, and design sensibilities that defined Ain‚Äôs pioneering work. With landscape architect Garrett Eckbo‚Äôs collaboration, the neighborhood feels like a park, with no front fences and continuous planting to unify the experience. Side-facing garages shelter individual homes from the street, and interior courtyards further buffer living spaces from public spaces, providing a sense of privacy within the larger community. While forward-looking and progressive, ahead of its time, the architecture is at once elemental and timeless: rooted in the earth, with walls of glass facing private gardens, responsive to the climate, with clerestory windows and skylights bringing natural light and cross-ventilation to the interior of every room.‚Äù Been messing around in real estate development for a few years now and this is exactly the kind of work that drew me to it in the first place. I aim to build, renovate and develop places that connect people and create the same tight-knit bonds as Ain‚Äôs homes. #design #eatonfire #light #space #pasadena #altadena #architecture

Our first meeting today was with the remarkable women of the Essie Justice Group, a nonprofit based in Pasadena. 

Essie is a "loving and powerful community of women with incarcerated loved ones" who have deep ties into the Eaton Fire affected community of Pasadena and Altadena. 

We sat together for two hours and talked story, listened, learned, and made plans for how After The Fire USA and our network can be of service.

A big part of our work is to listen and serve the community in front of us. We appreciate the time afforded to our delegation from the women at Essie.

Please support them if you can: https://essiejusticegroup.org/

Community Action Project LA (CAP.LA) ‚Äì Empowering Recovery After the Eaton & Palisades Fires
In the aftermath of the Eaton and Palisades Fires, disaster recovery experts from Loyola Marymount University, UCLA, and Purdue University, with funding from the R&S Kayne Foundation, have come together to support household and business recovery. CAP.LA is a data-driven civic action initiative that equips residents and business owners with critical insights to make informed recovery decisions.

üî¨ Soil Sampling ‚Äì Sign Up Today!
We‚Äôre asking property owners near the Palisades and Eaton Fires to allow soil and water sampling in their yards, gardens, and pools to test for wildfire pollutants. ‚úÖ FREE testing ‚Äì no cost to homeowners ‚úÖ Confidential results provided within 1-2 weeks ‚úÖ Community-wide data shared (without names/addresses) to guide recovery efforts

üîó Sign up for soil testing today: CAP.LA 
üì© Questions? Contact Brianne Gilbert, Managing Director at the Center for the Study of Los Angeles: studyLA@lmu.edu

#Altadena #CommunityRecovery #WildfireImpact #LARecovery #DisasterRelief #CAPLA #WildfireSoilTesting #SoilHealth #EnvironmentalSafety #EatonFire #PalisadesFire

Pool Sampling ‚Äì Help Us Understand Wildfire Water Contamination!
The Eaton and Palisades Fires left hundreds of swimming pools contaminated with fire debris, ash, and potentially hazardous pollutants. Rainfall runoff has likely spread these contaminants beyond the burn perimeters, yet no prior studies have tested pool water safety after a wildfire.

üî• We Need Pool Owners to Participate! üî•
‚úÖ FREE water & debris testing ‚úÖ Identify heavy metals & organic pollutants ‚úÖ Provide safety guidance for pool owners & officials

üíß If you have a pool, please consider signing up for testing! üíß
üîó Sign up at CAP.LA

üì© Questions? Contact Brianne Gilbert at studyLA@lmu.edu

#Altadena #PoolSafety #WildfireRecovery #WaterQuality #EnvironmentalHealth #CAPLA #EatonFire #PalisadesFire

*This is a sad one*

Back in 2021, as you can see by the masks, I was walking in Altadena and stopped to gaze at this charming Cape Cod home. These ladies were chatting in front, so happy to connect, and so open and friendly with me and my friend.  The owner of this home, and I believe it was the woman on the left, told me a bit about her achievement of purchasing it, and she really took pride in it. 

You can see how everything was pristine, the lawn, the landscaping, the sweet statue in the front‚Ä¶ So this is one of the ones that hit hardest when it comes to the recent fire. This house was among the casualties.

I would like to talk to her again. If anyone knows either of these people, please private message me so that I can connect with them and see how they're doing. 

I tried several times to post this and I just could not do it, it hurts my heart. I apologize if it hurts yours, too, but as you know, I feel it's important to tell these stories. 

#altadena #losthouse #eatonfire #homeoownerpride #capecodhouse #beautifulhouse #ighouses #houses #housesofinstagram #blackhomesmatter #housesofhollywood

Part of the long journey ahead for Altadena to rebuild is transferring lots from property owners who have no intention of rebuilding to buyers who will try to construct new homes as soon as the county will allow. I am so thankful to have helped my client sell their fire-impacted lot. They were planning on selling their home later this year, but due to the horrific events of early January they had little choice but to sell their fire-impacted vacant parcel as soon as practical. Prior to the fire their property was likely worth around $1.8M-$1.9M, we sold their land today for $603,077, or about $64 per SF. Despite the challenges and stress my client faced they were able to proceed with their goal of relocating out of state, closing escrow in a few weeks on their new home. Thank you for trusting me with your transaction and I wish you a comfortable and optimistic next step. Thank you!

Candace Frazee and Steve Lubanski built The Bunny Museum from a simple romantic tradition into a Guinness World Record-holding collection. But in 2025, the Eaton Fire destroyed it all. Why save these tiles? üëâ Ernest A. Batchelder, a pioneer of the Arts and Crafts Movement, began producing hand-crafted tiles in 1910. Inspired by Southern California's booming construction industry and the region's embrace of Arts and Crafts aesthetics, he built a kiln behind his bungalow on the banks of the Arroyo Seco. Initially, Batchelder's tiles were made using this portable kiln with a capacity for just 150 tiles per firing. His early designs drew on medieval, Renaissance, and Art Nouveau themes, often featuring intricate low-relief patterns with muted earth tones and blue accents achieved through a single-fire engobe process. 

These tiles are priceless to the homeowners and to the preservation of art. Thats why! 

Please help us save as many tiles as we can üôå 

Photos @megisaweirdo 

#savethetiles #sharingiscaring #altadena #eatonfire #batchelder #restorationproject #pasadena #tilework #tilelove #preservinghistory

Late Tuesday night, January 7, we put the finishing touches on 5 dozen custom sugar cookies, each one stamped with The Wright Exchange Network‚Äîa sweet treat for Val Wright‚Äôs (@verwright) multi-day event at @langhampasadena, where executives from across the country were set to gather for high-level conversations, networking, and collaboration.

By Wednesday morning, #Pasadena was a different place. The #EatonFire had taken hold, the air thick with smoke, and evacuation orders loomed. Before I evacuated my home and closed the shop for the day, I made one last stop at our kitchen to pick up the cookies and deliver them to @verwright .

But as the fires spread and the air quality worsened, she made the difficult but responsible decision to cancel the event‚Äîwhile many of her clients were already mid-flight to Pasadena. A surreal moment‚Äîmonths of planning disrupted in an instant. But in true Val Wright fashion, she found a way to turn the loss into something meaningful.

Instead of letting the cookies go to waste, she donated them to her daughters‚Äô school, where 76 families lost their homes in the #EatonFire. But she didn‚Äôt stop there. Val took action to support those affected, assisting families by gathering essential supplies and even opening her home to a displaced family.

Our hearts are with all the families impacted, and we‚Äôre grateful that everyone is safe. Pasadena is our home, and like Val, we believe in community first.

A little about Val‚Äîshe‚Äôs the powerhouse behind Val Wright Consulting, a globally recognized leadership and innovation expert and author who has advised top executives, from Fortune 500 companies to fast-growing startups. The global clients who have requested her help include Starbucks, LinkedIn, Amazon, Lenovo, Ingram Micro, Arrow, francesca‚Äôs, Microsoft, Avnet, Financial Times, Seagate, Gartner, Datto, and the LA Lakers. Val‚Äôs corporate experience includes tenures during dramatic growth periods at Amazon, BMW, Microsoft, Harrods, and Xbox. If you‚Äôre looking to take your business to the next level, she‚Äôs the one to know. Her daughter is also a valuable part of our team, and we love supporting this incredible family.

How important is "home"? There's no quantifying it. My painting subjects in the last ten years have basically consisted of "Home" and "Afar". 

So when I recently saw the massive destruction of homes in my childhood town of Pacific Palisades, I felt possessed by the idea of giving some of these vanished houses a second life on canvas. I was so very lucky to find @ashley_miller__ and @amybeemerlev, two visionary women who organized a database of homes, their former owners, and artists who had the same impulse that I did. They are @homesinmemoriam on Instagram.

A Los Angeles Times reporter, Jessie Schiewe @jessiewritesgood found us and sent the amazing photographer @emilravelo to take pictures. 

I hope to do many more paintings of homes. Each one has a soul, and something to say.

The grieving process is strange. Today it took me from tremors in my bowels and numb forearms to a feeling near elation as I set foot in my parents' home of 37 years - my childhood home - for the first time since the Eaton fire. 

The destruction is so complete that in these 7+ weeks of speaking about it, words have yet to really encompass the scale of what's happened in Altadena. Because I've already experienced the failure of words in this regard, I had no expectation that today's photo session would adequately document the loss of even this one house. And it was for that reason that I went with Polaroid.

The other reason I chose the Polaroid is that exactly three months ago (it's beyond incredible that it was that recent) I brought along this same SLR 680 - though with a couple packs of B&W instead of color - to photograph our family Thanksgiving. Sadly, a number of the photos from that set were lost in the fire. But the remaining ones I brought with me up to the house today.

So within this post there are two different sets of Polaroids taken at my parents' Altadena home: the B&W set is from this past Thanksgiving, Nov 28, 2024; the color set is from February 27, 2025 and is my contribution to #12monthsonfilmfeb

It would be impossible to know this without me saying it - but today's color photos (specifically Pics 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13) were taken from the exact spot as their counterparts from the Thanksgiving set (or as nearly as I could approximate it standing as I was in the crawl space, three feet lower than the non-existent floor).

At the beginning of this post I used the word "elated" and I meant it. I don't understand it, and I for sure wasn't expecting this (I'd been dreading this day since the house was destroyed), but I actually found this visit cathartic. I won't say healing - that is going to take a lot more time. But it did do something to improve my holding of this whole catastrophe, at least insofar as it has directly impacted my family. It was also very meaningful to have two close friends with me, for the experience and the support @apc_ortes @sailingdelilah üôèüèº

#12monthsonfilm #polaroid #slr680 #altadena #eatonfire #thenandnow

This night marked my first industry event in months, and I'm still processing the mix of emotions. The pandemic has left our industry uncertain, and personally, living in the Eaton Fire zone has been a heavy experience. I've witnessed friends lose everything, and our communities are forever changed. Los Angeles is still grieving, but I'm hopeful for the future. Thanks to @noelbraham @micheauxfilmfest for having me and for the important conversations we're having about rebuilding and supporting our communities.

This is Sean.  We met a three weeks ago when him and his family were looking for lost items in their ruins.  I saw his sister throw an arm up with an item in her hand, victory, God is good. The Harley you are looking at was his father‚Äôs, a father he never was able to meet as he was just three months in his mother‚Äôs belly when he passed.  Sean lived with his mother and sister in the house that burned, a home passed down by his grandmother.  I talked with Sean for a long time, he spent a good portion of it talking about her generosity to the grandkids and grandchildren.  Grandmothers are Gods greatest gifts to us all. The blessings they give and pass on know no end.  Sean needs help getting this bike out of its location and would like the frame restored and painted to the original color that his dad had so he can keep that memory close to him and his family.  You know what to do next. Let‚Äôs get this man the help he needs.  Gods watching.  I love you Altadena. I love your dream.

Lately, the ghost-traces have been hitting like lightning. Sudden, electric, inescapable. A scent, a shadow, a name spoken by a stranger‚Äîand just like that, absence turns into presence.

Grief isn‚Äôt just something you remember, it‚Äôs something you feel. In your bones, in your breath, in the way your body still expects what‚Äôs no longer there.

Some traces fade. Others stay, stitched into us, reminders of what was real, what mattered, what still echoes through us.

If you‚Äôve felt it too, this is for you.

Dr. Z

‚ù§Ô∏è Saturday March 1, there are 2 events offering resources to tenants, and members of the Altadena Tenants Union steering committee will be at both! If you are looking for help, community, and connection, please stop by!

üè† Stay Housed LA‚Äôs Tenant‚Äôs Rights Disaster Clinic runs from 10 AM‚Äî3 PM and will feature a tenants‚Äô rights workshop, Q&As with attorneys, and resources from organizations including PTU, the Pasadena Day Labor Center, and the Child Care Alliance of LA. The fair takes place at Friendship Pasadena Church, 80 W Dayton St.

üß± Civic Soul is hosting their Rebuild with Resilience Resource Fair from 9 AM‚Äî5 PM, featuring panels on insurance, rental assistance, and more, as well as booths hosted by FEMA, Habitat for Humanity, PTU, and more. This fair takes place at St. Philip the Apostle School, 151 S Hill Ave.

We recommend stopping by both events if you have capacity! Both events have stated they will have food and childcare available.

Wapello and lake ... At about 4:15 am ish there abouts. I was driving up lake from poppy fields . When I hit wapello there was a smoke wall you could not see past. Each time the wind blew you would see this bright orange glow in the complete darkness. Then smoke would blind you n seconds later we would be battered with embers and debris . I flipped a u turn in front of this House... I remember seeing flames billowing huge flames from the front window before being pelted with more debris that sounded like if we were hit with buck shot. I think that's when we went from property preservation to life cause thats we did we started saving sleeping neighbors... Announcements over my PA there's a fire coming is time to go... watching the fire department silently leave again for the 2nd time that night sheriff's driving away from us... it was like nothing I've ever experienced#apeshitinkphotography #adirtydream #ADirtyDreammedia #eatonfire #eaton #altadena #altadenaisnotforsale

So they put these signs about how you're entering a dangerous area affected by fire and to enter at your own risk . Well after the first rain the signs became ror shack ink blotches and have been left toppled over for the most part. We took it upon ourselves to assure everyone understands for the time being conditions are dangerous from the air to the surroundings. The first sign is next to norman and is in place as we speak. #project237media #ADirtyDreammedia #altadena #apeshitinkphotography #ADevilsDreams #eatonfire

This post is in honor of Save The Tiles (.org), the wonderful and very popular organization working to preserve the historic tiles that lived through the flames of the Eaton Fire.

From their site:
‚ÄúWe are a volunteer army of residents, preservationists, and heritage organizations in a race against time to help owners rescue their treasured original craftsman tiles from homes destroyed by the wildfires. We remove, preserve and store the tiles at no cost to the homeowners."

I love tile and applaud their efforts and want to do whatever I can to support them.  And by the way, I want to thank everyone who brought them to my attention - that was very thoughtful of you!

I met with Stanley Zucker, one of the TOP DOGS of the group, with his four-footed assistant/cohort/companion, Peggy!  They were kind enough to welcome me onto one of their sites to check them out in action. 

Unfortunately, when I arrived, they had already removed most of the tiles they were preserving, but I could see it‚Äôs a top-notch operation.  They‚Äôre engaging very skilled workers to do the removal carefully, and packaging the tiles and even storing them for the homeowners until such time as they have a place to put them.  And all this is done free of charge for those who lost these homes.  WHAT A GIFT!

I am personally grateful to them for all they‚Äôre doing to preserve these important parts of our artistic history.

Though many of the fireplaces of the region are decorated with the famous Batchelder tiles (no room to go into them here, but you can read up on him and his work on the Save The Tiles site), there were other pottery houses  which also created these classic rustic tiles, often incorporating nature motifs in their work. 

Scroll to see not only the home of Batchelder himself (which is private), but many examples of his tiles and others of the era. 

You can contact and donate to Save The Tiles through their site, or through me. 

Also, please remember my own Chimney project.  Sign-up link in bio and the best birthday present to me would be for each of you to please tell two friends (at least) so that I may help as many people as possible.

With gratitude as always‚Ä¶. Janet

Everything is gone. The homes they had, the streets they knew, the lives they built. Everything.

 But here and there, little things remain‚Äîa hoop with no basketball, a swing with no child to laugh on it, a washing machine with no laundry to clean, chairs with no one to sit, an elevator with no place to go.

All that remains are ghosts of a life that existed before the fire.

Proof that they were here.

The loss of a single home is not just the loss of the structure or its contents. It‚Äôs the loss of security, of memories, of community for the people who lived there and for the people who visited. It‚Äôs the loss of traditions and keepsakes.

The loss of one home is the loss of an entire world.

Approximately 5500 homes were lost in the Palisades in January, in an area larger than the size of Manhattan.

Approximately 9000 homes were lost in Altadena.

Every single one of them was a whole world.

#palisadesfire #palistrong #eatonfire

Mariposa and Olive

This is one of the last if not the very last surviving wood A-Frame house in Altadena that looks exactly how it did when it was built in 1924 by famous author, Kyle Onstott. Kyle was also a competition dog trainer. Prior to the construction of these houses the lot was used as his dog kennel. Outside of the four house houses subdivided on his lot, nearly every other house in the area was destroyed. This house is significant because it sits dead center in the historically Black area of Altadena and represents what many of the houses looked like at its peak. 

Restored by Tony Pruitt Sr in the late 90‚Äôs. 

#altadenastrong #altadena #eatonfire #palisadesfire

And yet those responsible or accountable have continued their lives of platitudes and photo ops, shirking even the decency to answer questions from those whose lives they ruined. We can‚Äôt let them ignore us.

They sang @hamiltonmusical in the car to their first date at @elcoyotecafe, then @dapoetrylounge_co & @surlygoatweho. They later took improv together at @ucbtla. Almost 2 months later, I had a chance to see my old neighborhood in Altadena. It‚Äôs crazy to see some of the random things that survived the fire storm that were in such close proximity to structures that suffered total destruction from the fire. Spring is around the corner, and new growth on the trees and plants have been blooming- there is hope that this city which lost over 9,400 homes and businesses will blossom again, too! #eatonfire #altadenastrong

The Refocus is here.

Life is full of thresholds‚Äîplaces where the old fades, but the new hasn‚Äôt yet come into focus. It‚Äôs in these moments‚Äîafter certainty unravels but before clarity arrives‚Äîthat we must decide: Will we cling to what was, or make room for what‚Äôs next?

The Refocus was born from that space. Not just to help us navigate change, but to emerge from it awake, attuned, and anchored in something more true.

Because resilience isn‚Äôt about pushing through at all costs‚Äîit‚Äôs about knowing when to soften, when to surrender, when to rebuild. Focus isn‚Äôt about productivity‚Äîit‚Äôs about presence. Growth isn‚Äôt a finish line‚Äîit‚Äôs a practice.

That‚Äôs what this space is for.
‚Ä®For those still finding their footing.‚Ä®For those holding both grief and hope in the same breath.‚Ä®For those ready to cut through the noise and return to what truly matters.

Inside, you‚Äôll find:‚Ä®‚ú® Guided meditations to help you steady yourself in uncertainty.‚Ä®‚ú® Downloadable resources to support you in processing, refocusing, and reclaiming what matters.‚Ä®‚ú® Articles that don‚Äôt just offer answers, but also the right questions.‚Ä®‚ú® A place where you don‚Äôt have to force healing‚Äîonly allow space for it to unfold.

This is more than a resource‚Äîit‚Äôs a recalibration. A way to step back, cut through the noise, and return to yourself.

And this is not just an offering. It‚Äôs my commitment.‚Ä®To meet you in the in-between.
‚Ä®To stand with you as you refocus, realign, and step into what‚Äôs next.

So take what you need. Stay as long as you want. The door is open.

We begin here.
(Link in bio)

Dr. Z

Trail maintenance work on the Mt Wilson trail above Sierra Madre. We carried materials that will help stop erosion and worked on rebuilding the trail in some damaged areas.  The trail is in good shape but is still very vulnerable and will surely have some significant damage if we get some heavy rains. We got about 7/10 of a mile short of Orchard Camp. Hopefully, the work that has been done will help minimize the damage. The debris basin in the canyon had a lot of material in it but there was a long line of trucks waiting to carry the debris away. #mountwilsontrail #trailwork #eatonfire

The lot folks.  The whole damn lot.  It‚Äôs a whole damn lot. What is it to be a good neighbor? What is it to look across the street and see what was taken and then taken from and then stare at the moon? And then to look in the rear view to see that they have always been taken from, and then still stare at the moon?  But for Tyreke and the Jackson‚Äôs, you can take the lot, you can take the cars, you can break the chains and take some more, but you can‚Äôt take their faith in God and the goodness in their fellow man. Because when times get tough, they stare at His Son.  God is good, even in the worst of times. And you can not take that away from them.  No sir.  Now are you going to stare at the moon or are you going to look at what is right here in Altadena, California?  This is for the Jackson‚Äôs. For Altadena.  I love you Altadena.  I love your dream. 

Jackson‚Äôs Gofundme in bio.

So many of you asked, ‚Äúis my garden/orchard safe post fires???,‚Äù that I turned to research and finding so little, then Honey Guy (my real life partner and an archaeologist), and we partnered with Duke University, for a post-fires soil study with urban and fires soil specialist, Dr. Daniel Richter. 

We have well over 100 and the list is still growing!

What have we learned so far? We‚Äôll publish preliminary data very soon, but here‚Äôs the answer to the question above from our soil scientist:
 
‚ÄúEvery home should know it‚Äôs lead number.‚Äù 
TEST!! üí©
Lead is an indicator for a host of other contaminants.
Your soil science doesn‚Äôt lie. üß´üî¨
If not safe‚Ä¶ call a professional in.

Burn zone: test and retest after ALL of your neighbors scrape (üí®they‚Äôll dust you, and 1/3 come up above EPA warning levels post scrape for this reason). 

IF your soil tests in multiple locations are well below EPA warning levels, do you need to grow anything or remediate your soil? 
No.

Should you add biochar and other amendments?
We do, but organic compost is truly the queen of all remediation and soil health.
üìùNote: We tested every single California available soil and compost in our commercial greenhouse, and one out of all of them repeatedly produced plants that were so much taller and healthier than every other, we no longer had to even look at the tags: @malibucompost @number2organics
You can find it  @aquaflosupply 
Neither of them asked nor paid me a cent to say this.

Where can you test?
Comment ‚ÄúSoil Test‚Äù and I‚Äôll message you a list!

I wanted to share that my house burned down due to the Eaton fires in California.  It has taken over 7 weeks to come to grips with this event. 

Since we are a small company, I do my development at home.  I lost everything including many new samples that were in development for our relaunch initially planned for April 2025 with new logo and brand new products. 

This set back will not stop my desire and commitment to relaunch my Ecogear brand of travel goods. 

The plan now is to have our new Carry on hybrid luggage launch in May or July.  Be on the lookout for posts on design and development.  Would love this community to provide feedback on the new products.  #eatonfire #devastated #rebuild #comeback #bestrong #ecogear

I was finally able to find a post fire aerial shot of the property I lived on for 10+ years. I wanted a side by side comparison because the loss is still so hard to process. It‚Äôs almost as if my memories of the property are false. It‚Äôs hard to believe the property really truly existed.

If any of my fellow fire refugees are having that same problem or are trying to still process the reality of what has happened, Altadena Rising has an amazing site to check out

I started this feed on Feb. 9th, with an idea, as my bio says, to document the Eaton Fire through the burned cars.  But at this point that premise feels tiny compared to the people I have met, experiences we have had and where this is headed. First, this is all for Altadena. Last, this is all for Altadena.  You are my North Star. Love you guys. I have over 5000 images of your cars, have shot them in a uniformed manner, up close and far away, including 4k 60fps video. There are stories of our beautiful neighbors that I have not released yet, but will, and more are being done every day.  Hit me up if you want me to swing by your spot. I‚Äôm doing darn near all of this on my own, all on my Apple Telephone. Grateful for a few friends who show up when Altadena needs them, usually at the drop of a hat. All that said, we are just getting started.  I have been cooking over here. A plan is taking shape. Stay tuned for the next steps, events, and more.  All efforts, projects, and energy is for the residents of Altadena.  All for Altadena. I ‚ù§Ô∏è You Altadena. I ‚ù§Ô∏è your dream.

Kevin and I were neighbors in Echo Park, I could have walked to his house in three minutes, didn‚Äôt know it though.  Ten years ago we both moved up here, a few months apart, didn‚Äôt know it though. This whole project has me wondering why it took the whole town to burn down for us to meet.  Maybe if Angelino Heights got cooked we would have met then, glad it didn‚Äôt though. 
This was Kevin‚Äôs mother‚Äôs 57 Chevy. She was a real estate agent, saw it at a property one day, bought it because she liked it. I love that. Life is short and she acted accordingly. I had a mother like that also, she did a lot of things like that right before she passed.  She bought a Model T and moved to Georgia, went back to where she came from, then passed. It didn‚Äôt make much sense to me until I went back there to see her place and saw the car parked against all that Georgia summer green.  When I met Kevin, saw his mother‚Äôs car, and heard his story, all I could see was that car in perfect shape, against a spring backdrop of our beautiful Altadena, California.  Kevin, I‚Äôm so sorry for your loss. Thank you for all the time we have spent together.  I sincerely appreciate you more than you will ever know. See you soon. I love you Altadena.  I love your dream.

#altadena #pasadena #eatonfire #classiccars #57chevy #vintagecar #petersenmuseum

#resilience gets thrown around a lot these days. I see the resilient nature in Altadena, rising out of the ashes like nothing happened. I remain hopeful that the neighbors who tended to it so carefully will rise up again as well. I also see too many reasons and signs for why this road will be full of obstacles and frankly not one that everyone should take. Are resilient people allowed to feel worried and disheartened?

This Refocus was created for the moments in between‚Äîbetween loss and rebuilding, between heartbreak and resilience, between what was and what comes next.‚Å†
‚Å†
And there is no better place to begin than here: The Weight of Grief. The exhaustion of carrying something that has nowhere to go. The way it lingers in our bodies, our minds, our daily lives. The way the world asks us to move on when we are still learning how to stand.‚Å†
‚Å†
In this first piece, we explore:‚Å†
‚ú® Why grief resonates so deeply‚Å†
‚ú® The things no one tells you about grief‚Å†
‚ú® How to actually move through it‚Äînot erase it, but hold it in a way that doesn‚Äôt drown you‚Å†
‚Å†
If you‚Äôve ever felt like grief is something you had to rush, fix, or carry alone‚Äîthis is for you.‚Å†
‚Å†
Read the full post at the link in bio and let me know what resonates with you most. üíõ‚ú®‚Å†
‚Å†

üö® New Single Out Soon: ‚ÄúPacific Coast Highway‚Äù üö®

Originally written by Courtney Love and Billy Corgan, first performed by Hole, Pacific Coast Highway was Courtney‚Äôs ode to loss‚Äîmissing someone who could never return. But for me, it speaks to something different: chasing someone who will never understand me, who can‚Äôt reciprocate.

I was in the Palisades Fire when it tore through the hills, surrounded by chaos, watching the world burn. But even then, I heard the voice of God on the Pacific Coast Highway‚Äîand that was enough to curb any loneliness I might have felt.

This song is about longing, surrender, and finding solace where you least expect it. My share of the royalties is going straight to the Palisades and Altadena neighborhoods. Hope you hear something in it too.

#PacificCoastHighway #NewMusic #HAIQEEM #IndieRock #Grunge #Hole #BillyCorgan #CourtneyLove #palisadesfire #eatonfire

Post- fire Regeneration. Not all plants die when they are severely burned.  Many plants, including Coast Redwoods and Coast Live Oaks (pictured here), survive below ground.  They will resprout and grow many times faster than any newly planted tree. It is a form of asexual reproduction, and it is an adaptation to wildfire that has evolved and existed for centuries. 

#Altadena
#eatonfire 
#oaktree 
#redwood

I fell in love with this house on first sight when I gazed upon it for the first time in 2021. Smack dab in the middle of some of the worst fire destruction in Altadena, I am so happy to say that she lives!

This beauty is located very close to the Tudor revival that I posted last week that also survived, but she's surrounded by some of the worst fire damage that I've seen, where entire cul-de-sacs went down together. 

Scroll to see bits and pieces that I found about a half a block away.  But beware‚Ä¶ It's very sad stuff!

I also want to say Thank You to everyone who has spread the word about my Eaton canyon chimney project, information about which and the sign-up sheet can be found through the link in the bio!

I have helped several people now to memorialize the home that they once had. It's a bridge between the life they had and the life they are creating bringing them into the future.

If everyone tells just two friends that they know who lost their home, I will be able to help so many more people. This is a free service that I am offering to Altadena residents  who lost everything. 

I'm in Altadena for the next several days, so if you're going to be there and would like me to take pictures of a certain site, or know someone who would appreciate that, please reach out! 

Let's just live in gratitude every single day‚Ä¶ We really do have so much to be thankful for. 

I'm ever so grateful for all of you!

üö® BREAKING NEWS: LA County Sues Southern California Edison Over Eaton Fire üö®

Los Angeles County has filed a lawsuit against Southern California Edison (SCE) and Edison International to recover the massive costs incurred due to the Eaton Fire, which devastated Altadena and surrounding areas. The fire burned 14,000+ acres, destroyed over 9,400 structures, and tragically claimed 17 lives.

When I met Junior, as I walked down his cul-de-sac during sunset, I said to him, ‚ÄúHi, my name is Dave. I take photos of all the burned cars, find the people, connect them to car, and tell their stories on a IG feed I created.  What did you lose?‚Äù He said, ‚ÄùTwo boats.‚Äù I said,‚Äù I now also shoot burned boats.‚Äù Junior told me about the night of the fire, how hard him and his wife fought, came back multiple times, until they absolutely had to leave.  Shit was crazy up there. His street only has one way out and with a heart full of God he left, and thank goodness, because a tree fell and blocked the street shortly after.  They would have been caught behind the enemies line. Not good. His son knows what that means more the me though. I‚Äôm just an a lucky neighbor, an observer, a guy with a home, a car, and all that jazz. Semper Fi, Eric. They fought so hard, for you, for your sister, for the family, for the place they raised you in. Your mom and dad are hard af. I watched that video your dad made of your graduation right when he sent it me. Thank you for your service. 
When you get stuck up delta, with one way out, you make your way by going as hard as you possibly can to get to safety and you fight like hell to get there. The proceeds of your parents victory was their lives. Although they couldn‚Äôt save the home, they saved themselves to keeping raising you and your sister and God willing, to spoil their grandchildren one day.  It‚Äôs an honor to have met you Junior.  You‚Äôre the real deal and you take amazing photos. Thank you for letting me tell your story.  I will see you soon. For the Rodriguez family.  For Altadena.  I love you Altadena.  I love your dream.

‚ÄúNever get out of the boat.  Absolutely goddamn right.  Unless you‚Äôre going all the way.‚Äù

In the weeks following the fires, I read too many op-eds and social media posts asking:
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúWhy would anyone build in these areas in the first place?‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúShould we really rebuild here?‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúMaybe this is a sign that people shouldn‚Äôt live there at all.‚Äù

Much of it was written by people who don‚Äôt live in Los Angeles and don‚Äôt understand its geography. The reality is that Los Angeles is a city defined by nature‚Äîmountains surround it, mountains cut through it, mountains shape it. Nearly every part of Los Angeles brushes up against wild, drought-prone, flammable terrain. That‚Äôs simply the nature of the place we call home.

Telling people not to rebuild isn‚Äôt just impractical‚Äîit ignores the reality of Los Angeles. The question isn‚Äôt whether we rebuild, but how. 

Head over to my blog to read my thoughts on how we can rebuild smarter in a smarter, more resilient Los Angeles.

üì∑ Aerial LA photo by @mikekelley_ via @welikela

Seven years ago, Ben Orrock was a CCC Corpsmember responding to the Camp Fire. Now he‚Äôs a Conservationist 1, recently dispatched to the #EatonFire, leading a #CCCTahoe fire crew. ‚ÄúThis was unlike anything I‚Äôve ever been to,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe crew immediately noticed a difference in smell. A city burning down smells a lot different than a forest burning down.‚Äù At the incident, he partnered with CAL FIRE captains to guide his Corpsmembers. Working 24-hour shifts, they created fire line, protected structures, and filled thousands of sandbags to combat post-fire flooding and mudslides. ‚ÄúI think this was an incredible experience not just for myself, but for my crew as well,‚Äù Ben said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so motivating to see these young adults come together with a common mindset and achieve the task at hand, no matter the obstacles in front of them.‚Äù

Thank you, Ben, for your incredible service during this time.

Introducing the Altadena Resilient Rebuild üåüüèòÔ∏è ¬†In response to the devastating Eaton Fire, I have been helping multiple homeowners in Altadena navigate the rebuilding process. Now, I am launching the Altadena Resilient Rebuild‚Äîa collective effort designed to help the entire neighborhood recover faster, more efficiently, and at a lower cost.

Through California Home Designs, I‚Äôve partnered with my builder to streamline the rebuild of up to 300 homes, creating semi-custom, high-quality homes that integrate fire-resistant materials, modern construction, and sustainable design‚Äîexceeding California‚Äôs latest wildfire and building standards.

With 20 years of experience in housing, design, and urban planning, I‚Äôve worked to create stronger, more livable communities. I recently became Wildfire Defense Certified with CAL FIRE & USGBC-CA, further strengthening my ability to support resilient rebuilding efforts. Now, I am applying that knowledge to help homeowners rebuild smarter and safer‚Äîstarting in Altadena, a community in Los Angeles County with modest lots and compact homes.

Rebuilding as a unified community offers key benefits:
‚úÖ Lower costs ‚Äì Bulk purchasing reduces material and labor expenses.
‚úÖ Faster timelines ‚Äì Coordinated permitting and construction accelerate rebuilding.
‚úÖ Wildfire resilience ‚Äì Strengthening homes together improves neighborhood safety.
‚úÖ More housing ‚Äì ADUs expand living space and housing options 

üè° If you or someone you know in Altadena is looking to rebuild, fill out the interest form (link featured at top of  profile bio @californiahomedesigns): https://altadenaresilientrebuild.typeform.com/quote

My boy Henry has insisted all week that I take him to our burned house to see if it has been fixed. I wish he could understand that it‚Äôs not that simple. I‚Äôve explained that the workers will take a long time to clean the rubble from the Eaton fire and build a new home, but he keeps asking every day after I pick him up from school because he really wants to believe that maybe I am wrong and our home is ready.

He also insists on going to the McDonald‚Äôs by our old home. Yesterday, he even told the drive-through worker that he was sorry about their sign being burned, which really touched the guy. Today, I reached my limit with Henry asking to see if his house is ready, wanting to check with his own eyes, so I agreed to take him. He asked me to call the builders to come quickly because he doesn‚Äôt want to be in a ‚Äúborrowed home‚Äù; he wants to return to his house. He wants to be in a home that is ours. ü•π

I took this picture to journal this day!

I finally got my hands back in clay yesterday! My studio is still in a bit of a disastrous state so I went to a friends gorgeous space for the morning and had a lovely little play! ü•∞

I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs two months today since the Eaton fire ripped through and took out our neighborhood. We are officially back in our house after a lengthy remediation process to fix the smoke and ash damage and replace a lot of our contents. We‚Äôre so grateful to be home but it‚Äôs also impossible not to heavily feel for the many many thousands whose houses were lost and can‚Äôt go back, as well as a huge number of people whose houses are miraculously standing, but they can‚Äôt live amongst the burnt out toxic destruction. So, people are still bouncing among air bnbs and friends houses. 

With that many people displaced, it‚Äôs created a crazy situation with finding housing. Coming back to the house was our 8th move since the fire. 

My studio got ‚Äòcleaned‚Äô but not sufficiently so I‚Äôve started pulling everything out‚Ä¶ which has led to finding drywall issues etc that I may as well fix now. It‚Äôs one of those things - once you pull the string on it, you have to just keep going! üí™üòÇ The third and fourth pic in the carousel show the current state! But it will be great once it‚Äôs all done. I‚Äôm thinking I will redo the floors also seeing as I have to take everything out anyway. Pink glitter floors?!? üíï 

So stay tuned for a bit of a makeover. I‚Äôm gunna make some silver (glitter!) linings to all of this. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ú®üåà

Grief is not something to fix. It‚Äôs something we learn to hold.‚Å†
‚Å†
Lately, I‚Äôve been reminded just how heavy it can be‚Äînot just the loss itself, but the exhaustion of carrying something that has nowhere to go. The way it lingers in the body, in the unexpected moments, in the spaces where the world expects us to move on.‚Å†
‚Å†
But grief isn‚Äôt about getting over it. It‚Äôs about making space for it. About finding ways to hold the love, the ache, the memories‚Äîwithout letting them drown us.‚Å†
‚Å†
This week‚Äôs blog post dives into how we do that. How we stop trying to erase what hurts, how we create rituals of remembrance, how we trust that grief will change‚Äîeven when it feels impossible.‚Å†
‚Å†
If you‚Äôre in it right now, I hope these words help. Read more at link in bio. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Å†
‚Å†
Dr. Z‚Å†
‚Å†

What‚Äôs that saying?  Fences make better neighbors? Huh, really? Why‚Äôs that when the fences all burned down I finally saw all the beautiful people of Altadena? Had the fences not been dropped I would never had met Rodney.  I take my kids to get ice cream, he cuts next store.  Never met him. I‚Äôll see if we can get a window installed from shop to shop so we can finally see each other.  They have candy in there as well, I‚Äôve slept on that. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Not anymore. Rodney hit me up early, but he‚Äôs hard to catch, he‚Äôs busy, he‚Äôs got a list of clients, a family to take care of. He‚Äôs a good man. When we finally met at his spot, he said he wanted to know what I was up to, the why and where of it all. I was honest, told him a few reasons, the injustice of the fire and how unfair it all feels. I also told him I‚Äôm out here working on my own issues, my own bullshit. I believe the people, the photos and the stories will take this someplace on its own. I write the copy not the destiny, God does, I just need to show up as a helper. Rodney‚Äôs family lost a whole list of classic trucks and a Harley.  This is just one of them, they just bought it a few weeks before the fire ate it.  I hate that fire, more and more each day.  Rodney had a legendary barber shop in the back up of the house, you know if you know, I didn‚Äôt because of the fences so he showed me a photo. Amazing.  He just finished a bike for his son, legit, fire ate that also.  See, why I hate the fire a little more each day?  But, but, but without those fences you see, you get to make more connections each day, more friends each day, friends like Rodney who I will work hard to not let down. But you need to show up to do that.  So show up.  See you at the car thing. I love you Altadena.  I love your dream.

The truck featured is a 1951 Chevy 3100. Fully restored. 235. Stick shift.

After exactly two months at this, which feels more like five minutes or maybe ten years, I have learned so much about what it means to be a good neighbor, what your lives were like before the fire and after, and what I am capable of if unleashed onto the barren blocks of Altadena. Through the looking glass of the destruction of Beautiful Altadena, I have, while doing my best to capture your lives, cars and passions, been polishing the mirror of my own life through the process. This is what I was talking to Rodney about. This is what I talked to most of you about as well.  In the midst of your terrible tragedy, thank you for taking the time to listen to my bullshit. I hope and pray I did you proper in my photos and words, and continue to do right by you as we rebuild Altadena and it‚Äôs beautiful car culture together.  I‚Äôd like to thank my amazing wife, who has put up with a lot of me lately. All that energy I put into this gets unwound when I get home. She‚Äôs seen a lot as well, maybe not the burned down homes and cars like me, but the mirror of them in me. It‚Äôs a whole lot to feel what I feel everyday, see what I see everyday. I can transmute that into work energy the best I can, but I‚Äôm human, and we humans make some mistakes. I‚Äôm grateful for being told when I make them, so I can change, be a better husband, father, and neighbor. Thank you @keniarts7 for your wisdom. I needed that. 
Well, all that said, when the sun comes up I need to get going and I just heard the birds chirp. So let‚Äôs get it at folks. I love you Altadena. I love your dream.  See you at the car thing.

üëã It‚Äôs been quiet here, and sorry for this late post. Since the California wildfires, I‚Äôve been navigating a lot of uncertainty about my small business and slowly processing what‚Äôs happened over the past two months. I felt uneasy when the pop-up events were postponed, as they have significantly contributed to supporting my business. I tried to figure out quick solutions to see how to pay bills, but I also had a deep desire to contribute to the community. As things have started to improve financially, I feel like it‚Äôs the right time to give back. It‚Äôs heartbreaking to witness what was built over time and lost so suddenly by forces beyond our control. Like these uncertain times, it reminded me of Covid, in which the essence of Mindful Cements began when I found peace in creating something new‚Äîalmost as a mindful practice and a way to cope with what was happening. Mindful Cements allowed me to step back into my world and create freely, without overthinking. I hope to bring a sense of calm and ease to your space with the pieces I create. So, I‚Äôm offering free (yes new) home goods and a 35% discount for victims to help them rebuild what was lost and hope it can help towards their healing üíùüè°

If you know anyone who has been affected and has lost their home, please share the link or tag them in the comments!

From the beginning, we knew a key part of our mission had to be paying our lessons forward and wrapping newly fire-affected communities into the "worst club with the best humans" -- something no one would choose, but once you are here, we gather together to support fire survivors all over the nation. Then we ask them to come with us to the next fire.

Our model honors the loss, respects the grief, understands the challenge, and holds the humanity we witnessed during our fires in 2017 at the center. We remain laser focused on listening, learning, sharing, and serving the community in front of us.

Many thanks to @kcalnews and Kristine Lazar for seeing the work and covering not only our part, but most importantly what is being done by Eaton and Pacific Palisades Fires to support their neighborhoods and the communities at large.

Thank you to Emily Kane Miller @ethos.emily and Reina Pomery @reinaandcompany for  sitting in with @jgt_707 to talk about recovery, the block captains system, and @afterthefireusa 

Together, you can recover, rebuild and reimagine. 

Full interview: https://www.cbsnews.com/losangeles/news/after-the-fire-usa-nonprofit-wildfire-survivors-palisades-eaton-fire-recovery/

Two months since everything changed. 

We wanted to do a quick check-in to let everyone know that overall,  we are doing okay. It‚Äôs still difficult - so very difficult - every single day. But we are getting though, thanks to the kindness we‚Äôve received in all manner of tangible and intangible ways from family, friends, colleagues, and even strangers. 

Thank you for your continued support of us through our still-active GoFundMe pages and other relief programs. Sharing these for us and with us has made all the difference. We‚Äôll never be able to thank everyone enough. 

We don‚Äôt know what the next steps will be for us, but we are incredibly grateful for the ability to take a moment in order to make those decisions. 

For now, we are safe and getting through, and always very grateful for each of you.

Today we moved my family‚Äôs 111-year-old Steinway & Sons grand piano to my house. This was the piano that I learned to play on when I was growing up. My dad grew up with it too ‚Äì my grandmother Esther used to teach piano in their old house in the Hollywood Hills. Back then, the Steinway was facing a Mason & Hamlin grand, so she could play four-hand duets with her students. After Esther died, the piano accompanied my parents to their house in Silver Lake, and three different homes in Altadena over a four-decade span. You can hear this piano on the lone jazz album my dad recorded as a leader, ca. 2000.

I always knew that this piano would be my inheritance, but I couldn‚Äôt have predicted that it would be sitting in my living room while my parents were still very much alive and well, still able to play. We have the Eaton Fire to thank for that. This piano‚Äôs arrival is one of the very few positives to come out of this horrible ordeal.

I have so many mixed feelings about this. On one hand, this is the finest thing I will ever own. It‚Äôs already a joy to play, even before it has acclimated to its new surroundings, even before I‚Äôve had it tuned. There‚Äôs a depth of sound, a dynamic range, and a sensitivity to touch that I forgot was possible in a piano. It has held up incredibly well despite its century-plus age. 

On the other hand it‚Äôs now my job to steward this family heirloom with the same care that my dad did, and his mom did before him. I don‚Äôt want to be the last generation of Rosenbloom to love this piano and discover the love of making music on this piano. That‚Äôs a huge responsibility that‚Äôs already weighing on me.

But I have a feeling this is all just first-day jitters. Once we clear some furniture out of the way and find a new home for the Kawai upright that has served me so well for the past decade, the Steinway will feel like it belongs. Like it has always belonged.

üì∑ 8: photo of my grandmother playing the Steinway (üì∑ by my grandfather), leaning against the Steinway

üôå Homeowners and renters who have incurred damage or losses from the Los Angeles County wildfires now have until Monday, March 31, 2025, to apply for FEMA Individual Assistance and Small Business Administration assistance (SBA). Go to DisasterAssistance.gov.

üí¨FEMA assistance can cover rental assistance, temporary housing, home repairs, personal property losses and other disaster-related needs not covered by insurance. FEMA grants do not have to be repaid. FEMA assistance is nontaxable and will not affect eligibility for Social Security, Medicaid or other federal benefits. 

‚ÄºÔ∏èSurvivors who have insurance are encouraged to file a claim for disaster-caused damage with your insurance company before they apply for FEMA assistance. Survivors do not need to wait for an insurance settlement to apply for FEMA assistance. FEMA may provide financial assistance to eligible survivors who are uninsured or underinsured. 

Source: gov.ca.gov

#FEMA #EatonFire #Altadena #Pasadena #LAfire #LosAngeles #WildfireLawyer #LosAngelesLawyer

The deadline to apply for the California EDD‚Äôs Disaster Unemployment Assistance has also been extended until March 31. DUA is for workers‚Äîsuch as self-employed people‚Äîwho are not eligible for regular unemployment benefits and lost their jobs or had hours reduced because of the Los Angeles County wildfires. Go to edd.ca.gov

Thank you to U.S. Rep. Judy Chu for attending Saturday‚Äôs well-attended International Women‚Äôs Day Unite and Resist Rally held in Kersting Court. The peaceful rally encouraged all individuals to demand action and stand up against a growing authoritarian threat by the current President and his administration. 

I took this opportunity to talk to Rep. Chu to briefly stress how difficult it is to operate a small business especially now in wake of the Eaton Fire. More than 90,000 people have been displaced since the fire, and so many of us lost a substantial customer base. There has been little relief to those of us still standing.

If you love a neighborhood small business, even if it‚Äôs not in Sierra Madre, please support them whenever possible. Businesses bordering West Altadena, Pasadena, those on Washington Blvd., Lincoln Avenue in Pasadena/Altadena, are struggling (and that‚Äôs if they are open), and may not be here for the long run. It‚Äôs a beautiful day so get out and drive, and shop all the neighborhoods! #sierramadre #altadena #westaltadena #pasadena #smallbusiness #internationalwomensday #icecream #pie #eatonfire #dogoodintheworld #spreadjoy

After devastating fires swept through Altadena, Malibu, and the Pacific Palisades, two USTA SoCal Adult League teams‚ÄîMalibu‚Äôs ‚ÄúLoosely Strung‚Äù and Altadena‚Äôs ‚ÄúBand of Brothers‚Äù‚Äîovercame adversity to compete at Sectionals. Despite losing their home courts and experiencing personal losses, both teams decided to press forward, using tennis as a source of resilience and connection. For Christmas last year, Chuck bought Kelly a @heylittlechonk backpack. Hashbrown was just starting to get used to the backpack when our house - and the backpack - burned down in the Eaton Fire. Chuck emailed Little Chonk to see if they would be kind enough to send us a discount code to replace the backpack - they said "don't worry about it, we got you" and generously sent us a new Maxine One. üçë  We are touched by their kindness.

The generosity and kindness of so many of you in our SoCal corgi community has truly warmed our hearts and helped us navigate these choppy waters. Thank you üôèüèªüêæ

Our new temporary home is in sunny South Orange County, and today we celebrated at the @festivalofwhales in Dana Point. Hashbrown had a ball in her Little Chonk. Thanks @thedoggiebarkery for the adorable whale-shaped cookies!

There are no presets in your phone that will allow you to capture and then edit what has happened in the ring of fire.  Each person, home and car comes with its own unique Eaton Fire signature.  From afar, there is a uniformity to the burn.  But from up a little closer you see that each one has been touched by the hand that built it. This signature also exists outside the ring of fire. Can you see it out there?  Can you hear it in the conversations?  Do you scroll it in your feed?  All for Altadena.  I love you Altadena.  I love your dream.

locationName: Smog City Brewing at Glendora Public Market
caption:
My family and I are finally back home together after spending five weeks apart while I managed the cleanup and aftermath of the Eaton Fire that devastated our community. Being home again is a relief, but we‚Äôre still without potable water. As we reconnect with our neighbors and friends in Altadena, we‚Äôre reminded of how incredibly lucky we are to still have a place to call home-something many in our community no longer have.

As we rebuild, countless families are still without permanent housing. Fortunately, many organizations are stepping up to help those in need. United Way has partnered with our brewery, @smogcitybeer, as part of Smog‚Äôs 1% for the Planet series to support wildfire relief efforts.

One way you can help is by picking up We Love LA, our delicious West Coast IPA bursting with tropical fruit aromas and a hint of peach ring sweetness. We just restocked at my taproom, @smogcitybeer_sgv, and all Smog City locations. This beer has been selling fast, so stop by, grab a pint and a four-pack and support this important cause!

#EatonFire #AltadenaStrong #WildfireRelief #CommunityRebuild #SupportLocal #DrinkBeerDoGood #WeLoveLA #smogcitybeer_sgv #smogcitybeer
If you have been affected by the recent wildfires and in need to replace your Cintiq to get back on track. Please email us at sales@machollywood.com and we‚Äôll do our absolute best to help you.

The wildfire was just the beginning. Now comes the long road to recovery.

Even if you‚Äôve received funds from your insurance, new questions and roadblocks pop up almost daily. Are you getting everything you‚Äôre entitled to? What happens if unexpected costs arise? The claims process doesn‚Äôt end with a check. It‚Äôs an ongoing battle.

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre here. Tugboat is free for anyone affected, helping you navigate every step of the way. No catch, just real support.

California, we‚Äôre with you for the long haul. 

#CaliforniaStrong #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #LAStrong #CAStrong #Wildfire #InsuranceClaims #WildfireRecovery

Check out the new sprouts on this Cork Oak! At first glance, the tree looks completely fried. Cork Oak has some of the thickest bark of any oak. It does a great job of protecting the cambium, a layer just beneath the bark, responsible for the growth of new tissue. This tree will make a full recovery.

The Eaton fire Chimney project has been catching on‚Ä¶ We've been mentioned in the LA times and now today another article has dropped, from the Local News Pasadena! 

You've already met our first participant, Nicole, and here are several others that I've had the great pleasure of photographing in the last couple of weeks. They are all such lovely people with amazing attitudes and tons of hope for the future. 

I'll be focusing on them individually in future posts but for now I wanted you to meet a few of them all together. 

Here you see, in order of appearance, Brenda and her daughter, Ivy, The Alvarados, Emma & Emmanuel, with their grandson, Tony, and Toni & Patrick, Jocelyn, and Vito!

They have all lost their homes and pretty much everything they owned, precious collections, priceless treasured items, yet they smile so brightly. It really has been such a special experience to meet and photograph them.

In the case of The Alvarados, I was too late‚Ä¶ Their property has already been completely cleared! It's a reminder that this is really important because one day, the evidence of their past is there, the next, it's gone! 

I hope you'll help me to help more people by telling a friend or two. 

More information and the sign up are in the link in the bio or I can send it to you directly if you DM me.

Here's to a bright and beautiful future for Altadena! With such wonderful residents, it will surely rise from the ashes and be incredibly beautiful and wonderful again. 

And thanks so much to everyone here for being so patient with me while I gather together all the photos for you. With communicating about the project, running around taking pictures, editing and organizing the photos and keeping up with posts, besides the other parts of my life, it's tricky to keep up right now. üòâ‚ù§Ô∏èüòÖ

#eatonfire #firedamage #afterthefire #altadena #altadenastrong #beautifulaltadena #altadena  #positiveattitude #fire #brightfuture #risefromtheashes #phoenixfromtheashes #ashes #destruction #chimney #chimneyproject #eatonfirechimneyproject #housesofhollywood #houses #homesweethome #homes #housesofinstagram #igpeople #amazingpeople

On January 26th, 2025 I read an article from the @latimes that set me on a course that, in result, created this feed.  It was the ending, in particular, that got me.  I didn‚Äôt like the ending then and I still don‚Äôt like it now. The phrasing ‚Äúlet‚Äôs rewrite history together‚Äù comes from my feelings about this article.  Because now, you can still read it, and the ending is still the same.  Nothings changed, yet.  The tag line that‚Äôs written at the end of each post, ‚ÄúI love your dream‚Äù is in direct reference to the ending of this article.  The gentleman in this story is real, just like you, me and the fire is real.  I have been talking to him in each post created, eventually knowing that I would one day meet him, as I did all of you, through the divinity of the fire.  Everything that has transpired to date, including @altadenacarsandcoffee is because of him and his dream.  Through me he did all of this, it was him this entire time. The story doesn‚Äôt end here but this post does.  More to come. Let‚Äôs rewrite history together. I love you Altadena.  I love your dream. 

#altadena #pasadena #eatonfire #iloveyourdream #classiccars

Grief doesn‚Äôt fade just because the world expects it to.

We‚Äôre told to keep busy.‚Ä®To scroll past the ache.‚Ä®To grieve quickly, quietly, and alone.

But loss doesn‚Äôt follow a timeline. It lingers. It reshapes us. And when there‚Äôs no space for it, it settles in deep.

So where do we put our sorrow when there‚Äôs no place for it to land? How do we carry what‚Äôs gone when we‚Äôre told to just move forward? If loss feels heavier now, maybe it‚Äôs because we were never meant to carry it in silence.

Let‚Äôs talk about it. Read more in this weeks blog post. Link in bio.

Dr. Z‚Å†
‚Å†

I‚Äôm incredibly honored to be named 49th Assembly District Woman of the Year by Assemblymember Mike Fong @asmmikefong. This award isn‚Äôt just about me‚Äîit‚Äôs about the power of community and the people who make change happen together.

I didn‚Äôt grow up with much, moving from home to home‚Äîespecially within District 49‚Äîbefore my family found stability through luck and my parents‚Äô hard work. My mother always taught me: ‚ÄúPut yourself in other people‚Äôs shoes‚Äù (no pun intended), and I‚Äôve lived by that mantra ever since.

No one accomplishes anything alone. 

This recognition reflects the efforts of over 200 volunteers‚Äîmany of them teenagers (our future)‚Äîwho showed up with open hearts, ready to serve over 1000 families the past few months. From spreading awareness to donating essentials alongside our shoes, their generosity and kindness were overwhelming.

A special thank you to Assemblymember Mike Fong for this honor and for his commitment to uplifting our community. His leadership is a reminder that change happens when people step up for each other. Thank you also for the special experience to witness and be a part of the vote to commemorate and celebrate Women‚Äôs History Month.

This experience reinforced what I already knew: community is everything. My hope is that we continue to look out for one another, lend a hand when needed, and lead with both wisdom and compassion.

From the bottom of my heart‚Äîthank you. ‚ù§Ô∏è

#Gratitude #CommunityMatters #WomanOfTheYear #TogetherWeRise #49thDistrict #LeadWithWisdom #ServeWithCompassion #ThankYouMikeFong #eatonfire

The @wilshirerotary has adopted a schoolhouse impacted by the #EatonFire and is making a difference one Amazon Wishlist item at a time for this local community service project.  @sagewoodschoolhouse THROUGHOUT ALL OF MARCH

Wilshire Rotary Adopts The Sagewood Schoolhouse 

Click on the following Amazon link to purchase requested school supplies lost in the fire:

https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/S8EG6BCIGI0I?ref_=wl_share

The Sagewood Schoolhouse in Altadena was more than just a preschool‚Äîit was the owners‚Äô home as well. When the devastating Altadena fire tore through the area, it destroyed not only their residence but also the heart of the small, loving preschool they built inside it.

Our fellow Wilshire Rotarian, Mindy Lake, has a personal connection to Sagewood‚Äîher granddaughter was one of the many children who thrived in its warm, nurturing environment. Owners Sasha and Lily poured their hearts into transforming their home into the perfect space for learning, filled with love and care.

Now, with their home and school gone, they face the immense challenge of finding a new location and rebuilding from the ground up. Wilshire Rotary is stepping up to adopt The Sagewood Schoolhouse, but we need your help.

They have an Amazon Wish List to replace some of the items that were lost‚Äîplease give what you can to help them start again.

Click on the link below. It will send you to Amazon. Place items in cart and  when you are ready to check out, you should automatically see the delivery address to the school:

https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/S8EG6BCIGI0I?ref_=wl_share

To give you a few examples of what happens to items after they have been exposed to intense heat . (1) Plastic ladder /intense consistent heat Likely for 30 mins or longer Santa Anita/marigold (2) Bolt cutters likely exposed to short term  moderate to extreme heat because it was in an obviously quickly extinguished area Lincoln just above fig east side of the street .(3) Aluminum mini kids baseball bat likely exposed to intense heat for 1hour or longer found in remains of car fire . Santa Anita Ave /marigold . #Altadena #eatonfire #ADirtyDreammedia #adevilsdream #apeshitinkphotography

‚ö†Ô∏è The fire burned 14,000+ acres, destroyed 9,400+ structures, and caused 17 deaths in the Altadena area.
‚ö†Ô∏è SCE has acknowledged possible involvement but hasn‚Äôt admitted fault.

üèõÔ∏è Why the lawsuit?
üî• LA County is demanding hundreds of millions in damages for lost homes, infrastructure, and environmental destruction.
üî• Investigators say evidence links the fire to SCE power lines.

üë©‚Äçüöí Meanwhile, former LA Fire Chief Kristin Crowley lost her appeal to get her job back after being dismissed over wildfire response failures.

Do you know this man (not Yoda, we KNOW you know him ‚Äì¬†the other guy)? 

The next few posts you‚Äôll see come from one collection of 268 photographs, dozens of negatives, and notebooks found by @jesspantaleon. Jess was volunteering at the Pasadena Convention Center shortly after evacuation, and she found these photos scattered in some shrubs by the parking lot entrance for the Paseo. 

These photos capture a family over the course of several years, from 1979 to 1985. We believe the men pictured here are brothers. They were likely in their late twenties / early thirties at the time these photos were taken, meaning that they‚Äôre likely in their sixties or seventies now. 

Based on the state of these items when they were found (see last photo), we believe that the owner evacuated to the convention center in the early aftermath of the fire, parked at the Paseo, and dropped these items as they were heading across the street. 

Here‚Äôs what we know about the owner based on what‚Äôs in this collection: they‚Äôre an electrician; they had a grey pet cat in the 1980s; they traveled to Massachusetts in autumn 1979; they hiked Havasupai in October 1983; one of the brothers was married around 1985; the groom or the bride was most likely Jewish; also in 1985 they went to the LA Zoo and The Huntington (with a woman who appears to be their mother).

All photos appear to have been taken in the Pasadena / Glendale / Burbank area.

We are trying to reunite these photos with their owner. Please get in touch if you recognize these people. These photos will be kept safe until the owner is identified.

#Altadena¬†#EatonFire¬†#LAFires
