2 months ago, Fires started in different parts of Los Angeles. With strong Santa Ana winds, and dry brush/tress as fuel, the fires devastated everything in it's path almost eliminating entire historic and beautiful towns off the map such as Pacific Palisades and Altadena.
I used to live in Atadena...where Family of mine also lost their entire home. This first picture shows what used to be the house.
As I was pulling into Altadena, I wasn't fully sure what to expect and as I was going around a curve, it turned from a beautiful neighborhood, to an apocalyptic scene. It's hard to drive around and realize that many people lost everything. All their memories, belongings, their home, cars, everything. And some don't have places to stay now, let alone, in the foreseeable future until things can be rebuilt.
But LA is strong and the people resilient. Things will be rebuilt, but it'll never be the same.

I just thought I'd share this with people who maybe haven't seen or as a reminder that there are people out there who still need help and resources to get through this. If you can help in any way, do so. It doesn't go unnoticed. Thanks for taking a moment to read this.

#prayforla

For Anabela, my Mustang friend.  I‚Äôm sorry for your loss, I‚Äôm sorry this fire came for your home and your beloved wild beast of a car.  I hope to see your card collection grow once more, your home filled with again Christmas love.  The pained joy I saw in your eyes is infectious.  I saw all of Altadena in your eyes.  All of our beautiful Altadena in your eyes. You must have sat up there on that perfect lot, so peaceful, to breathe the whole town in, day after day after day.  You breathed the whole town in. Inhale the gold, exhale the darkness.  Day after day after day. I can see that in your eyes.  God bless, God bliss. I love you Altadena.  I love your dream. 

#altadena #pasadena #eatonfire #fordmustang #ford #love

‚ÄúUnder normal circumstances, for LA County Parks to build a new park, it takes roughly 18 months, but due to the expedient measures taken by both the State of California, County of Los Angeles, and the tireless efforts of countless LA County staff, our partners, and volunteers, that timeline has shrunk to merely 2 months,‚Äù said Norma E. Garc√≠a-Gonz√°lez, Director of LA County Parks at a Wednesday ceremony at Loma Alta Park. ‚ÄúThe people devastated by the Eaton Fire need their community back, and LA County will heed the call. I am heartened to see how much support we‚Äôve already received.‚Äù

One of the coolest details about these historic tiles are the name stamps on the back. Handmade and personal, every single one. For preservationists like us, this is what it‚Äôs all about! Please donate, share, and follow for updates!

Andrew reached out to me after he got my number from Randy.  They were neighbors via the back wall, they‚Äôd jump that thing like it was nothing to hang out.  The inlet where they live feels tight-knit, connected, special. There is a lot more going on with Andrew in the neighborhood and how we met for the first time, the second time, and probably the third time.  Third is the charm though. I‚Äôve said it before but stories don‚Äôt start and stop, they develop and linger and then run off into oblivion, but they definitely don‚Äôt end. And the bookends that used to hold the books upright on the shelf, even the metal ones, burned in the fire so why let anything try to sit and behave like it‚Äôs still normal.  Altadena will get back to normal and there is progress everyday to get there.  I believe! There is also a 3rd generation truck we need to get at. We will get there. Stay tuned. But until then, thank you Andrew for the time we spent. Grateful. I love you Altadena.  I love your dream. 

#altadena #pasadena #eatonfire #mercedes #petersenmuseum #love

**God is still good, even in the midst of chaos!** My parents have found temporary housing, and I couldn‚Äôt let this moment pass without showering them in love. This Saturday, we‚Äôre warming their new space with family, friends, and gratitude.

If you‚Äôre coming, please bring gift cards to bless their new beginning. Thank you all for your love and support! ‚ù§Ô∏è #GodIsGood #FamilyFirst #HousewarmingBlessings #EatonFire #Altadena #BeautifulAltadena

At tonight‚Äôs City Council meeting, the El Monte Police Officers Foundation and the El Monte Police Officers Association were honored for our efforts during the recent LA fires, particularly the Eaton fires. Our officers played a crucial role in mutual aid operations, supporting the Pasadena and Sierra Madre evacuation efforts, property protection, and crime suppression.

During this historically destructive event, our officers demonstrated unwavering commitment, working tirelessly to safeguard the communities we serve, as well as the animals and properties at risk. The foundation and association ensured that not only the El Monte Police Department but also other agencies were well-equipped, providing essential meals and water to first responders on the front lines.

We are especially grateful for the incredible leadership of @chiefjakefisher , who leads from the front with integrity and commitment to public safety. His support of all our foundations ventures and initiatives has been invaluable.

We extend our heartfelt gratitude to the City Council and City Manager @citymanager.almamartinez for recognizing the vital role of first responders, including police foundations and associations. Your acknowledgment strengthens our resolve to continue serving with integrity and dedication.

#FirstResponders #LAFires #empd #empof #Gratitude #CityOfElMonte #PublicSafety #community #support #backtheblue #eatonfire #showup #poa #501c3 #bettertogether #heroes

I want to thank my follower, @alexiasaigh, who reached out to tell me about this lovely house that made it through the fire in Altadena. 

I had already noticed it because it's displaying such a sweet, positive, caring message on the fence, and it's located on such a prominent corner, standing out for all to see. 

Alexia told me it's her mother's house, and boasts a very long history, starting in 1913 when it was built for the founder of Balboa Island!

it's important to note that I took these pictures when I was photographing a house directly across the street for my Eaton fire chimney project. That house burned right to the ground‚Ä¶

I plan on trying to dig up more information about this pretty place, and would love to hear more from you as well, Alexia. 

Thank you for being so kind as to get in touch. I think it's important to celebrate the homes in Altadena, that made it through that destructive fire storm. This house is still standing and exudes a strong message of hope for the future of the community.

Enjoy the Silence üå¨Ô∏è
I just got the hit to put down my phone and tap out of social media for a bit. So that I can truly feel IN and then move OUT of this massive metamorphosis that I AM currently very much IN. When you lose everything, you have the opportunity to build from the ground up. Both literally and metaphorically.
And I am quite busy doing both of those while also being a very hands on Mom and wife. 
This life changing plot twist deserves a heightened level of respect and honor ‚öîÔ∏è 
This is such a gift even amidst the gutting heartbreaküêõ
And I want to fully embrace it all, not bypass any important steps or the exquisite silence with myself ü¶ã
Time is my most precious commodity. 
I no longer feel the desire to give it away so freely right now. I mostly do enjoy social media but it all feels very dull and boring to me at the moment (it‚Äôs me not you). And so I am not going to force myself. I always orient myself towards FREEDOM and this is no different. 
So I‚Äôll be back when I‚Äôm back.
There will be much to share soon enough. 
Love ya‚Äôll! 

*DM or better yet email me, hello@motherthemother.com if you need me I‚Äôm still working!

Ways to work with me right now:
‚Ä¢ 1:1 Coaching - one off sessions and packages available (online) or local LA.
‚Ä¢ Frequency Sessions - IN person hypnosis, energy work, nutrition, movement. 
‚Ä¢ Sound Baths - IN person gatherings 5-20 people. 
‚Ä¢ lifewave patch partner - email to learn more about this opportunity

Long after the national spotlight faded from Southern California‚Äôs devastating wildfires in early 2025, these communities and the people within them remain in a state of recovery.

As fires burned in January, organizations like @DirectRelief rushed in to help, and continue to help today. 

Amgen and the Amgen Foundation supported this effort through a donation of $10 million which went to wildfires relief efforts led by the @CalFund, the @launitedway, and Direct Relief.

Headquartered in Thousand Oaks, California, Amgen and its employees have called Southern California its home for more than four decades and its connection to the community runs deep.

As the road to recovery continues, we remain committed to helping these communities rebuild.

What I didn‚Äôt see coming was the disappointment. The quiet absences. The people I thought would check in but didn‚Äôt. The ones who did but said all the wrong things.

A few weeks ago, I shared a post about this, and the response was overwhelming. So many of you felt this same ache‚Äîthe grief within the grief, the loneliness within the loss. That‚Äôs why I created this guide‚Äîa resource for navigating the letdowns, the well-meaning but painful words, the people who show up and the ones who don‚Äôt.

If this resonates, COMMENT ‚ÄúGUIDE‚Äù and we‚Äôll send it to you. Because grief is hard enough‚Äîyou shouldn‚Äôt have to carry it alone. üíô

Some interesting changes regarding Altadena lot inventory compared to last week. Active inventory fell by 3 listings, the first decline in active listings since the first lot was listed for sale in late January. Also, the average sales price is up $24,000, and for the first time lots that have sold and that are in escrow exceed active lot listings (40 sold/in escrow versus 37 active). This suggests buyer activity is strong and demand is still high. Approximately 80 lots have been listed so far in Altadena.

In the ashes of the Eaton Fire. Claire Schwartz leads a community effort to recover keepsake images and return them to their owners.

Reuniting families with their keepsake images has taught her about Altadena‚Äôs categories of loss. ‚ÄúFor the folks who are really excited just to have anything back, that‚Äôs been a wonderful feeling, to just hand off this tiny bit of normalcy,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúFor the people who are, ‚ÄòOh my God, this is all that‚Äôs left?‚Äô That‚Äôs really hard.‚Äù

Yesterday we honored several individuals and organizations at our 137th Annual Board Meeting and Board Celebration. We had a surprise Five Acres Hero Award to one of our own: Five Acres Director of Facilities Jake Cashill. Our CEO Chanel Boutakidis shared how he worked around the clock to save the historic main building during the Eaton Fires, watering the roofs and monitoring the fires 24 hours a day. He repaired the damage from the windstorms and ensured the organization was safe for the return of the children in the Residential program and the staff, working with staff and volunteers during our Five Acres Snow White Cleanup Day. Thank you, Jake, for your big heart and being our hero!

locationName: John H. Francis Polytechnic High School
caption:
Tonight, neighbors from Sun Valley, Arleta, North Hollywood, Shadow Hills, and beyond came together for the Phase 2 cleanup hearing of the Eaton and Palisades fires and their impact on Sun Valley as it houses some of the city landfills. City and business representatives outlined the process, fielding community concerns‚Äîthough, as expected, responses felt scripted and lacked the depth and reassurance many hoped for.

Still, we recognize the importance of showing up. Town hall meetings can be uncomfortable for officials facing passionate residents, but their presence matters. More importantly, your presence matters. To everyone who attended, asked questions, and advocated for their health‚Äîthank you! Your voices remind us that our community does care about its exposure to toxins, and that fuels us to keep showing up, too.

As a health- and sustainability-focused coffee cart in a neighborhood with few clean food options, tonight reignited our hope. Beyond these hearings, we encourage all of us to reflect: How can we minimize toxin exposure in our daily lives? Fires are an unfortunate reality in our region, and the materials in our homes‚Äîplastics, synthetic fibers, and chemical-laden goods‚Äîcan release harmful toxins not just when burned but also when simply un packaging or worse, with daily use. Even if they don‚Äôt burn down, they still pollute our landfills and air over time.

As consumers, we vote with our dollars. Invest in natural, toxin-free products, avoid plastic-heavy goods, and choose organic whole foods when possible. Small choices add up. Because protecting our community isn‚Äôt just about cleanup‚Äîit‚Äôs about prevention.

.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.
.

#SunValley #EnvironmentalJustice #BeTheChange #CommunityMatters #EnvironmentalHealth #AdvocateForChange #SustainableLiving #ToxinFree #KnowBetterDoBetter #CD6 #LosAngelesCounty #EatonFire #PalisadesFire #WasteManagement

The Path Forward Series: Join us Thursday, March 20th, at 6 PM for a Live Expert Panel discussing today‚Äôs next steps in Eaton Fire recovery. Q & A with local experts in Real Estate, Insurance Claims, Mass Tort Litigation and Mortgage Finance. 

Teresa Fuller, Altadena‚Äôs #1 Agent ‚Äì will discuss the Altadena housing market including values of standing structures, lots, less affected area sales, rebuilding options and more. 

Hratch Ghazarian, Public Adjuster ‚Äì Navigating insurance claims, especially for homes with partial damage or smoke exposure.

Raffi Kassabian, Esq., Complex Litigation Attorney ‚Äì Next steps in the Edison mass tort and why it matters, even for those with insurance.

Daniel Arias, Sr. Mortgage Advisor ‚Äì Guidance on mortgage options and considerations moving forward.

We encourage you to join us in person at 680 E Colorado Blvd., 4th Floor. If you can‚Äôt attend live, the session will also be available on Zoom‚Äîlink in bio.

Q & A: If you have questions about the fire recovery process, we have answers. Please leave your questions in the comments.

COMING DECEMBER 2025!

Charlie James Gallery is proud to announce an upcoming solo exhibition by Mary Anna Pomonis opening in December of 2025. This powerful new body of work reimagines paintings by Mary Anna lost in the Eaton Fire, transforming loss into creation. Mary Anna had opened a solo show of new paintings in Altadena just days before the fires, all of which were lost. 

Pomonis is known for her airbrushed geometric abstractions, which explore the intersections of sacred geometry, feminine empowerment, and optical illusion. Her work bridges historical symbolism with contemporary technique, creating paintings that exist between dimensionality and flatness, meditation and movement.

This exhibition marks a profound return‚Äîeach piece a reconstruction, a new beginning forged from the embers of the past. 

#MaryAnnaPomonis #CharlieJamesGallery #EatonFire #GeometricAbstraction #SacredGeometry #ContemporaryPainting #OpticalIllusionArt #FeministArt #LosAngelesArt #LAArtScene #ArtAsTransformation #AbstractArt #Reimagined #ResilienceThroughArt #newbeginnings @maryannapomonis @ever.a.k.a.thegirlabouttown @csufcota @csufvisualarts

Do you know this woman?

These photos come from one collection of 268 photographs, dozens of negatives, and notebooks found by @jesspantaleon. Jess was volunteering at the Pasadena Convention Center shortly after evacuation, and she found these photos scattered in some shrubs by the parking lot entrance for the Paseo.

These photos capture one family over the course of several years, from 1979 to 1985. Based on the state of these items when they were found, we believe that the owner evacuated to the convention center in the early aftermath of the fire, parked at the Paseo, and dropped these items as they were heading across the street. All photos appear to have been taken in the Pasadena / Glendale / Burbank area.

Based on the significant number of photos taken in front of the Valentino store, we believe this woman's last name could be Valentino, or that she worked there. There certainly appears to be a reason they took photos in front of Valentino as opposed to any other store. 

Here‚Äôs what we know about the owner based on what‚Äôs in this collection: they‚Äôre an electrician; they had a grey pet cat in the 1980s; they traveled to Massachusetts in autumn 1979; they hiked Havasupai in October 1983; one of the brothers in the family was married around 1985; the groom or the bride was most likely Jewish; also in 1985 they went to the LA Zoo and The Huntington with a woman who appears to be their mother.

We are trying to reunite these photos with their owners. Please get in touch if you recognize these people. These photos will be kept safe until the owner is identified.

- Belle Vista Terrace, 1910, Sierra Madre, CA
Irving J. Gill, architect
 - In 1910, after ten years of experimentation with small but efficient worker housing, Irving J. Gill designed Belle Vista Terrace (aka Lewis Court). The project uses a single-bedroom cottage floor plan he had earlier developed in San Diego. Here, he assembled several cottages built around a landscaped courtyard as a collection of units. Each cottage is designed for both privacy and shared common space and incorporates many of his fireproofing design innovations. Belle Vista Terrace has been identified as the first courtyard housing project in Southern California to use a central shared garden, a layout that would become ubiquitous in Los Angeles and San Diego in the 1910s and 1920s. 
 - While the courtyard has since been filled in with insensitive additions, Belle Vista Terrace still stands today as an example of very early Los Angeles Modernism. In January 2025, just a block away, Belle Vista Terrace recently survived the Eaton Fire that ravaged the nearby San Gabriel Mountains, seen in the images, and destroyed much of Altadena, just west of Sierra Madre. 
 - Images:
1. Photograph, c. 1940‚Äôs
2. Site plan, as built, HABS 
3. Gill early elevation drawing, c.1910
4. Belle Vista Terrace postcard, c.1910

I met Johnny in Altadena yesterday. He has a knife sharpening shop very close to the burn line near where my house is still standing intact in appearance but uninhabitable due to soot, ash, smoke damage, and water contamination. Johnny took me by surprise with his stories of the merchant marines, the Philippines, and his impromptu knife training/disarming demonstrations‚Äîbut what really got me was when he showed me the knives that my neighbors are bringing to him from the ashes of their homes. I watched him hammer and expertly recondition the blades with master precision. In conjunction with a neighborhood woodworker they are giving new life to these objects and something that their owners can tangibly use as they rebuild their everyday world. If you are in Los Angeles I highly recommend paying a visit to Johnny Sousa to patronize his knife sharpening business at 370 E. Woodbury Road, Pasadena at the ACE hardware building.

This is the hardest post I have done so far and this is why. When you meet Brian you are instantly taken away to another world that has nothing to do with burned cars, homes, or our savaged Altadena.  It doesn‚Äôt make any sense to post the images of his bombed out Boss Hog Cadillac, the remnants of his insane whiskey bar with his (The Original) infinity barrel or the ashes of his Pulp Fiction inspired art works and memorabilia.  You know Brian about 30 seconds before you meet him for the first time.  His cheer, friendliness, and his humor is infectious and it arrives before you do.  He knows how to use the most precise words to express exactly how he and everyone in this situation is feeling.  If he happens to be a salesman for a living, I‚Äôll have everything in his portfolio, twice. I envy his spirit because in spite of all this bullshit, that he and his family have endured, he is still shockingly present, full of love and full of pure joy.  Thank you Brian, for showing up the way you do.  More of you in this world please.  Take care my friend, see you at the barrel.  I love you Altadena.  I love your dream.

‚ö†Ô∏è NO DROP, NO RUSH: Road bike beginner‚Äôs Ride ‚ö†Ô∏è

üö¥ March 16, 2025

‚ö†Ô∏è Beginner ride for road bikes (hybrids are ok) 
üó∫Ô∏è Riding through the city, catch the LA river north, and loop back through NELA 

We know there‚Äôs a lot of gatekeeping and ego in the road bike male-driven cycling scene. Too much road bike-shaming, too many people acting like they were never beginners. Not here. This ride is for those who have been pushed away by that culture‚Äîfor the road cycling-curious, the long-distance hopefuls, those on a health journey, for non-male riders, and anyone looking for a safe, ego-free space to learn and road ride.

Maybe you‚Äôre riding a vintage steel bike, a $10k dream build, or something you got secondhand. No matter what you ride, if you‚Äôre looking for an open and supportive cycling space, this is your ride.

What to Expect:

‚úÖ No egos. No bike shaming. No dumb questions.
‚úÖ A no-drop pace‚Äîeveryone stays together.
‚úÖ Seasoned riders to answer questions.
‚úÖ Social ride + space to learn road cycling basics.
‚úÖ Women, POC, non-binary, femme, lgbtq, cyclists encouraged to join.

üì£ Q&A can be asked privately to our seasoned riders or ask out loud! 

üö≤ All you need is a road bike, a helmet, and an open mind. Let‚Äôs build something together.

Well, I stole this map from Randy and his friends over at @goodneighboraltadena (go visit them‚Äîthey‚Äôre open and they want you to come by for a drink or 5) to speak for me.  This is a map of Altadena‚Äîthe RED shows ALL of the structures that were impacted by the Eaton Fire on January 7-8, 2025.  For now, this map will do the talking‚Äîthis map paints an accurate depiction of just how damaging and destructive this fire was to our community.  Thank you, Randy, for helping us find the words when we have none to be spoken‚Ä¶

We love you‚Äîand we hope you are finding the time and space(s) to hug family, friends, neighbors from the Altadena community‚Äîin your own time, in your own space, at your own pace‚Äîbecause right now, it‚Äôs just hard‚Ä¶even 2+ months later.

I want to tell you about Pat's family. Like so many others, they lost their charming Altadena home in the Eaton fire.

Pat was used to seeing fire and experiencing dangerous winds in the area, so he had found a place for them to stay in advance - super prepared! But what they did not expect was that the house wouldn't be there the next day. That was absolutely out of the question.
 
And that next day was Daniel's 16th birthday, and the family Subaru was secretly to be his. As you can see, that didn't work out. 

The day we met was the first time they'd all been back together on the site, so they were looking for some buried treasure and found a few things‚Ä¶ Some beads from Stella's collection, a small glass bear.

For Stella, one of the worst aspects of this was losing her various crafts including beaded jewelry projects. 

Both Pat and his wife, Alison, are educators. Pat is retired but Alison continues to teach composition and literature. I asked whether it's too difficult to continue working at this time, but she said that, in a way, it's helpful - takes her mind off of things for a few hours‚Ä¶

The bright green area in the back was their Potted designed garden and next to it, an almost-finished beautiful architectural ADU with gorgeous wood details. 

And despite all this loss, so many smiles. This is such a lovely family and I felt honored to spend the time with them and hear their stories.

If you know someone who might like to be photographed with what remains of their home, or just have me photograph what's there, see the link in my bio to the Eaton fire Chimney project. Time is of the essence, three sites I went to yesterday had already been bulldozed, so I was not able to document the tile fireplaces for @savethetiles, which is another one of my activities in the area these days.

Please join me in sending best wishes to this family.  And if someone has a connection with Subaru, this is their moment to do a great deed for a very deserving young man.

I drove through Altadena today, reflecting on the aftermath of the Eaton fire. It was heartbreaking to see the damage firsthand. The burnt house stood as a silent reminder of the devastation. I couldn't help but capture a few sad photos, hoping to preserve the memory. The charred remains tell a story of loss and resilience. It's a somber sight, but one that highlights the strength of the community.

I walked and drove past Jim‚Äôs house a thousand times before we finally connected. Why? On his property sits my dream car, a 1967 Mustang Fastback. I fell for her when I was a kid, I‚Äôve told this story before. @isaacnceja knows all about my love for her, he even started his story for @laopinionla about the fastback. I‚Äôm not going to act like he didn‚Äôt show me that love on purpose. Isaac and I have a lot in common, we do most things on purpose, for a purpose, with a purpose and let others feel the energy to figure out the message. I happen to reach Jim the morning Isaac showed up. ‚ú®The timing ‚ú®. He was the last interview of the day which ended during our beautiful Altadena golden hour. Even more special now, since those golden bubbles started rising up over all the burned lots of Altadena. So ready with love that as they connect with each other, the growth turns exponential. Love scales over the planet and into the cosmos and beyond into Gods newest creation billions of light years away. 
Altadena scales via the Stardust of its dream. The same stardust that is the make up of our bodies, the natural world and the cars we love so much. We are made of the things of the Universe. And we are the Universe staring back at itself. There is a giant cosmic mirror starring you down, everyday and all day. It just needs some polishing now and then. And when you do that, you can see Jim who was building this car for his son‚Äôs 16th birthday. What a gift that would have been to the both them. And look again into the mirror and you can see Isaac.  You can see Carl, and Max, and Lauren, Rodney, Danny, Junior, the Jacksons, Sean, Kenny, Sergio, Sarah, Juan Carlos, Anabela, Greg, Keni, Robert, Greg, Kenneth, Brian, Rick, the Cooleys, Rebecca, Holden, Harry and my brother my mother my father the entire town of Altadena and beyond. There is no end. There is only love, love scales. Love scales. Scale it with me. I ‚ù§Ô∏èyou Altadena. I ‚ù§Ô∏è your dream.
#altadena #pasadena #1967mustang #ford #petersenmuseum #eatonfire

For St. Patrick's Day - another in our Nextdoors fundraiser single releases! Flogging Molly's "If I Ever Leave This World Alive" for your listening pleasure today - stream free, or download (pay what you want) and all profits will go to some true Saints of the Pasadena/Altadena - Families Forward Learning Center.

They provide free education and social services to low-income families with children from birth to five years old. Serving the Dena area since 1961. 

We along with Mr. Pasadena, got a personal tour of the facilities last year and saw first-hand the amazing work they do in the community- needed now more than ever post Eaton Fire.

Today, Democratic Caucus Chair and Assemblymember Rick Chavez Zbur (D-Hollywood) announced AB 478, the FOUND Act, Friends of Oreo Uniting During Disasters, a critical new bill to ensure that companion animals are protected during emergencies and that local governments implement clear procedures to support pet owners during evacuations. Sponsored by Social Compassion in Legislation, the bill was inspired by the heartwarming story of Oreo, as seen on the Today Show, a Pomeranian who went missing during the Palisades Fire and survived for five days in the debris before being reunited with his owner.

‚ÄúPets are more than just property‚Äîthey are family. When disaster strikes, no one should have to choose between their safety and their pet‚Äôs survival,‚Äù said Assemblymember Rick Chavez Zbur. ‚ÄúThe FOUND Act ensures that local governments have clear rescue plans in place, so pet owners don‚Äôt have to risk their lives to save their animals. While we‚Äôve seen incredible examples of fire and safety officials working alongside the public to reunite pets with their families, as well as the extraordinary efforts of local animal shelters and rescuers, we owe it to pet owners across California to ensure that every city and county has a plan in place before disaster strikes.‚Äù

‚ÄúTime and time again, we‚Äôve seen animals abandoned or lost in the chaos of wildfires and other disasters,‚Äù said Judie Mancuso, Founder and President of Social Compassion in Legislation. ‚ÄúThis bill is about making sure animal family members are not left behind. Our beloved companion animals are not like a pair of prescription glasses, they are sentient beings that must be rescued. The bill provides the necessary tools to coordinate rescues, support evacuees, and reunite families with their beloved animals.‚Äù

Continued in comments‚Ä¶

#oreothedog #dogrescue #petrescue #animalrescue #palisadesfire #eatonfire #lafires #losangelesfires #la #losangeles #news #oreo #dogsofinstagram

Investigation Underway into Eaton Fire‚Äôs Cause: Could a ‚ÄòZombie‚Äô Power Line Be to Blame?

Investigators are delving into the potential cause of the devastating Eaton Fire that ravaged Los Angeles County, destroying nearly 10,000 structures. The primary focus is on whether the fire was sparked by a disused ‚Äúzombie‚Äù power line ‚Äî old, non-functional power lines that were not fully decommissioned but left in place.

The fire, which has already caused widespread destruction and displaced thousands, continues to raise questions about infrastructure safety and the consequences of neglecting decommissioned equipment. Authorities are working diligently to determine if the ‚Äúzombie‚Äù power line played a role in igniting the deadly blaze.

As the investigation unfolds, local residents and officials alike are hoping for answers to prevent such tragedies in the future.

#EatonFire #ZombiePowerLine #LosAngelesFire #FireInvestigation #DizzyDiddyMag #CaliforniaWildfires #LosAngelesCounty #FireSafety #WildfirePrevention #DizzyDiddyPlus
Some things that survived the Pacific Palisades and Altadena fires

I used to think love meant knowing someone so well that you could predict them‚Äîanticipate their reactions, finish their sentences, move through life in sync.

And then grief entered the room.

Loss doesn‚Äôt just take what‚Äôs gone. It reshapes what remains‚Äîincluding your relationships. Suddenly, the person who once felt like home feels just a little bit foreign. Not because the love is gone, but because pain changes the way we connect.

Maybe you‚Äôve felt it too.
‚Ä®One of you shuts down, the other reaches out.‚Ä®One of you needs words, the other needs space.‚Ä®One of you is still tangled in the past, the other is trying to move forward.

And if you‚Äôre not careful, the space between you turns into distance.

This week, we‚Äôre talking about:

* What to do when you and your partner grieve at different speeds.
* How to keep resentment from creeping in.
* How to stay close when pain makes you push each other away.

Because love isn‚Äôt about working through things the same way. 

It‚Äôs about choosing to deal with life together. ‚Ä®
Read the full post at link in bio. 

-Dr. Z‚Å†

#photojournalism #photo #altadena #altadenastrong #eatonfire #rebuild #latimes #latimesphoto

Anyone who has driven through Altadena since the fires has seen the stark and haunting landscape left behind‚Äîlot after lot of burned-out rubble, with only fireplaces and chimneys standing as silent reminders of what once was. For lovers of classic design and enduring materials, Altadena‚Äôs historic tile fireplaces are a masterclass.

Ernest A. Batchelder, a pioneer of the Arts and Crafts Movement, began producing hand-crafted tiles in 1910. His early creations drew on Medieval, Renaissance, and Art Nouveau themes, often featuring intricate low-relief patterns with muted earth tones and blue accents achieved through a single-fire engobe process. Batchelder‚Äôs tiles became synonymous with fireplaces, fountains, and architectural details in both residential and commercial spaces. 

Today Batchelder tiles along with his contemporaries, Claycraft Potteries, Gladding-McBean, and California Faience tiles remain celebrated as iconic elements of Altadena‚Äôs architectural legacy.

Because all of these tiles were kiln fired, they survived the Eaton Canyon fire that burned virtually everything around them. In the burn area today, brick chimneys and tile fireplace surrounds are often all that is left as clean up begins along these burn sites.

@savethetiles is leading a momentous effort to rescue, repair, and restore these irreplaceable tiles from the devastation of the Eaton fire and return these beautiful tiles to Altadenans at no cost to homeowners.

Learn more about @savethetiles and support their GoFundMe through the link in my bio. If you‚Äôre interested in volunteering with their effort (or if you‚Äôve lost your home and would like them to recover your fireplace‚Äôs tiles), please fill out the forms on their website, www.savethetiles.org. Let‚Äôs ensure these classic materials continue to grace Altadena‚Äôs homes for generations.

#savethetiles #eatonfire #lafires #preservinghistory #batchelder #greeneandgreene #vintagetiles #altadena #altadenahistory #tilefireplaces

Join us every Tuesday at 11AM and 4PM for ‚ÄúNotes from the Fires,‚Äù a special weekly series of short radio documentaries produced and hosted by John Rabe where listeners will be introduced to members of the classical music community affected by the Palisades and Eaton fires of Jan 2025.

Today‚Äôs second episode, takes us to Venice to meet Nina Evtuhov, a sought-after session violinist whose house burned down in the Palisades on January 7th. Nina‚Äôs on more than 400 film and tv scores, from Frozen to Star Wars to Indiana Jones to all the new Star Trek TV shows. Plus, she was in the pit for lots of Broadway shows, like The Boy from Oz, Oklahoma, and Les Miz. Losing everything in the fire means rebuilding her life again, because Nina‚Äôs husband died in 2010, leaving her to raise her two daughters.

Listen to the episode on kdfc.com or kusc.org

Loss doesn‚Äôt just rewrite your story‚Äîit rewrites the space between you and the people you love.

What once felt effortless now feels uncertain. The person who knew you best suddenly feels just out of reach. Not because love disappeared, but because loss changes how we hold each other.

One of the hardest parts of navigating grief isn‚Äôt just what you‚Äôve lost‚Äî it‚Äôs figuring out how to stay close to the people who remain.

That‚Äôs why we created ‚ÄúWhen Loss Rearranges Love: How to Navigate Hard Things Together.‚Äù A guide for anyone feeling the quiet distance that grief can bring.

Inside, you‚Äôll find:

‚ú® The invisible divide that makes loss feel lonely‚Äîeven in love.
‚ú® How grieving styles clash‚Äîand what to do when your partner processes differently.
‚ú® The 5 Loss Languages‚Äîhow to support someone without losing yourself.
‚ú® How to hold space for each other‚Äîeven when words feel impossible.

Because love doesn‚Äôt have to be a casualty of loss.

It can bend, stretch, and reshape itself into something even stronger‚Äî if we learn how to meet each other in the middle.

Comment ‚ÄúGuide‚Äù and I‚Äôll DM you the resource. 
 
Heads up: If you don‚Äôt receive the guide, double-check that you‚Äôre following me‚Äîsometimes DM‚Äôs get blocked from going through otherwise.

-Dr. Z‚Å†
‚Å†

(Video credits - Jeffery.ku) The power lines believed to have sparked the devastating Eaton Fire were overdue for critical maintenance and ignition risk repairs, according to Southern California Edison (SCE) records obtained by the Los Angeles Times.

The records, filed with the state of California, reveal that pending work orders existed for the electrical towers spanning Eaton Canyon, where the fire is thought to have originated. These orders reportedly included clearing vegetation that could pose a fire hazard.

Authorities are still gathering evidence, and dozens of lawsuits have been filed in connection to the wildfire, which caused significant destruction. Investigations are ongoing as officials work to determine the extent of SCE‚Äôs responsibility in the disaster.
‚Ä¢
Sources:
ABC7 
Los Angeles Times
Jeffery.ku

A reminder re: my chimney project.  I know you all know at least one person who lost a home in Altadena and would really appreciate my help.  Please tell them about my project!  It‚Äôs for THEM, not me... and it‚Äôs FREE - a gift from me to the people of Altadena.  They can be in the photos or not. And a chimney is NOT required at all.

The photos are fantastic!  Thank you so much.  I am fascinated by all the colors in the chimney(s). You sure can see the mountains well with all the intervening trees and fences gone!  The back yard doesn‚Äôt even look too bad! 
It‚Äôs such a great project!

These are really beautiful. you have an amazing eye. love the frames of various things and the lines that connect. you connected the big mother tree with the little decorative tree next to the front porch.  thank you for sharing.

The chimney is all that remains of 100+ years of our home.

Notable changes regarding Altadena lot inventory compared to last week: The highest sales price so far to close: $1,160,000. Price per SF of closed lots dropped to $57 per SF, down from last week's $62 per SF, likely due to larger lots closing. Also, the average sales price fell from last week's $623,000 to this week's $595,000. Similarly to last week, lots that have sold and that are in escrow exceed active lot listings (50 sold/in escrow versus 40 active). This suggests buyer activity is strong and demand is still high. Approximately 90 lots have been listed so far in Altadena since late January.

17 homes nestled in their surroundings under the warm sun. 

Their flowers always in bloom, the bees buzzing around and their people out and about or relaxing inside. 

This is what I think of when creating these home portraits. 

But each one was lost to our dear city in the January fires. 

I love hearing the stories told to me from the homeowners and friends. They‚Äôre a look into someone‚Äôs life, a detail that we all could relate to. 

Like Sea Dojo, a nickname name given by a child who misses his home, or the little sapling in a yard planted in honor of a family tragedy.

These are just 17 of my 1500 and growing list, but each one is so very special to someone. 

‚Äî

My name is Asher Bingham, I‚Äôm drawing homes lost in the LA Fires in January. I have 17 volunteer artists helping me tackle this giant outpouring for art that can heal, follow my stories to see little insights, hear stories and also see other volunteer artwork as I receive them. 

If you‚Äôd like to donate to this project you‚Äôll find üîó available at the top of my page. 

Take care friends.

This unified effort brings together community groups, local nonprofits, city, county, and state officials dedicated to helping those affected. Welcome to today‚Äôs episode, a story of resilience, strength, and the unyielding spirit of a community. Altadena, a place where history whispered through tree-lined streets and century-old homes, faced unimaginable devastation when the Eaton Fire tore through on January 7, 2025. More than 9,000 structures were lost, and the landscape of this beloved town was forever changed.

Yet, even in the face of destruction, there are stories of hope. Today, Heather Eastwood and Ruslan Abaev will share their journey of overcoming the devastation of the Eaton Fire and standing strong in the aftermath. Their story is one of determination, of finding light in the darkest moments, and of a deep love for the place they call home.

Supporting Small Businesses Matters Now More Than Ever

This post was originally meant to be shared to bring awareness to the importance of supporting small businesses‚Äîbut now, it‚Äôs even more urgent. We just got the news that our building is up for sale.

Small businesses like Esquina are what make communities thrive. When you shop local, you‚Äôre not just buying a product‚Äîyou‚Äôre investing in people, culture, and the future of your neighborhood.

We‚Äôre grateful for everyone who has supported us, and now more than ever, we need to show up for the businesses that make our communities unique. We‚Äôll keep you updated on what‚Äôs next‚Äîstay with us.
